title: Characterization of Materials
reviews: Ask the Nan and TAa any questions if you are not sure how to operate in the demo session.

Definitely go for it. If you're attentive enough throughout all the sessions, you'll definitely learn a lot. Plus, the no. of psets is just one (at the very end); no finals, just a final presentation.
Definitely take this class! Very reasonable workload and very interesting. Nan Yao is a very fun lecturer and knows so much about microscopy.
Excellent class; you will gain hands-on experience for a wide variety of essential materials characterization techniques.
Good if you don't have knowledge at all about characterization. If you are knowledgeable not worth taking it.
Highly recommended for students with different backgrounds who are interested materials science. Nan is very patient and nice.

Take it if you need microscopy or any other form of materials characterization in your research. You will get familiar with the set-up, facilities, and staff at PRISM, which will help you out in the long run.
Take this course if you want to learn about imaging techniques and get hands-on experience!

The characterization techniques you learn in this class are very applicable to research in materials. Prof. Yao and the teaching assistants are very helpful and are happy to assist you with not only course material, but also questions you may have about how imaging techniques can be used your own research.

This class is great and Prof. Yao is an awesome professor. I learned lots of relevant and useful things for my research and got credit for doing so - 2 birds in one stone! Lots of labs but I didn't mind this since there weren't weekly problem sets and it was a good class for senior spring.

This course is ideal for seniors headed to grad school or first or second year grad students. It covers the most fundamental characterization techniques in materials science and is one of its kind at the University. Dr. Yao tells a lot of anecdotes throughout the lectures, which is fun to hear. Only two assignments at the end of the semester-a problem set and a lab report using images and spectral data acquired throughout the semester. Pretty laid back in my opinion.

This course provides invaluable experience working with some very expensive and high-tech instrumentation! The only downside is that the course will end up meeting four days a week, even though you only expect two!
descrip: A multidisciplinary course offering a practical introduction to techniques of imaging structure and compositional analysis of advanced materials. Focus on principles and applications of various characterization methods. Covered topics include AFM, SEM, TEM, XRD, EDX/WDX, EELS, Raman, Ellipsometry, Confocal Microscopy, sample preparation and image processing, etc. Hands-on experience is emphasized.

title: Ecohydrology
descrip: A description of the hydrologic mechanisms that underlie ecological observations. The space-time dynamics of soil-plant-atmosphere is studied at different temporal and spatial scales. A review is done of the role of environmental fluctuations in the distribution of vegetation. Emphasis is made in the dynamics of soil moisture. The signatures revealing fractal structures in landscapes and vegetation are reviewed as result of self-organizing dynamics. Unifying concepts in the processes responsible for these signatures will be studied with examples from hydrology and ecology.

title: Solid State Chemistry
reviews: Professor Bocarsly is an excellent lecturer and presents his material very well. Professor Selloni is a start contrast in the classroom, as I nearly always found myself lost or exchanging glances with other students that revealed everyone was incredibly confused.

Professor Selloni assigns a lot of really challenging homework material and the book leaves a lot unexplained in order to generate work for the end-of-chapter problems--it was interesting to learn how to do so much, but you might reconsider taking this class for a grade if you can't devote several weeks over the course of the semester to really digging into the textbook and understanding every detail.  The problem sets are very involved, so it's not something you can do "halfway".
There is a lot of quantum physics in this course. If you don't like quantum physics and are not good at math, don't take it.
descrip: An overview of modern solid-state chemistry from the point of view of synthesis, characterization, and electronic properties of inorganic solids. Topics include: periodicity of crystalline solids, band theory, use of diffraction and imaging techniques in the characterization of solids, the chemical physics of solids and interfaces. Discussions include: consideration of optical and electronic properties of semiconductors and semiconducting interfaces, proton and ion conductors, low dimensional materials, photochemistry at interfaces. The role of solid state materials in heterogeneous catalysis is also be considered.

title: East Asian Humanities II: Traditions and Transformations
reviews: I think that while the teachers could be great, the lack of help (unless you actively seek it) could be detrimental. There are other ways to learn about East Asia or to watch movies, so think hard if you want this course. Even though it may be presented as a beginner course, in this year at least, this seemed to not necessarily be the case.
Make sure to keep track of each assignment each week or you'll definitely forget.
Really interesting and engaging course. You should take it even if you are not a hum major. Workload is manageable.
Take this course if you want to broaden your understanding of cultural themes and transformations in East Asia. The professors are great, very engaging. Be prepared to close read films and texts.

Terrible. The worst course I've taken at any level of school. Unfair, abusive, boring. Everything that's wrong with academia and teaching. Do NOT take this class. You will hate it. You will despise it. It will eat away at the very fabric of your being until you are a weeping, depressed husk of yourself. Yayyyyyyyyyyy.
interesting em.
prereqs: This course builds on HUM/EAS/COM 233, but there are no prerequisites. Freshmen and students with no previous experience of East Asian Studies are welcome to enroll..
descrip: This course begins roughly around the fourteenth century and covers the arts, history, music, literature, popular culture, film and media in transnational China, Japan, and Korea up to the contemporary period. Special focus will be given to the question of modernity in East Asia. Lectures are given by specialists in the departments of East Asian Studies, Comparative Literature, Music, and Art and Archaeology. This is the second half of a two-semester sequence introducing the humanities in East Asia.

title: Algebra II
reviews: A good course to learn intro-level algebra.
Do not start problem sets the day of.
Eh... How can you not learn Galios theory? How can you not have seen the proof of inconstructibility proofs and solutions to polynomial equations by radicals?

If you're taking the seminar, go to class and follow along in the lecture notes (or Artin where applicable) because the student presenters are not always good at explaining, but sometimes add clarification where the lecture notes lack it.
It's a good course to learn the subject material (ie, rings, fields, Galois theory) in.

Jerry's section was mainly taught by students lecturing each other in lieu of the traditional pset/test format. This made the course's workload pretty manageable, but I still got a good feel for what algebra is all about.
Only take this course if other students do not lecture.
Take it with Prof. Skinner if you can. He's very good and gives good intuition.
Take this course if you're a math major!
prereqs: MAT345 or equivalent..
descrip: A continuation of Algebra I, this course will cover the basics of ring theory, module theory, field theory, and Galois theory. Topics include structure theorems for modules, polynomial rings, field extensions, and solvability of polynomial equations by radicals.

title: Laboratory in Plasma Physics
descrip: Develop skills, knowledge, and understanding of basic and advanced laboratory techniques used to measure the properties and behavior of plasmas. Representative experiments are: cold-cathode plasma formation and architecture; ambipolar diffusion in afterglow plasmas; Langmuir probe measurements of electron temperature and plasma density; period doubling and transitions to chaos in glow discharges; optical spectroscopy for species identification; microwave interferometry and cavity resonances for plasma density determination; and momentum generated by a plasma thruster.

title: Advanced Modern Greek
prereqs: HLS 105 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Advanced composition and oral practice aimed at developing idiomatic written and spoken style. Discussions entirely in Greek. Introduces students to contemporary Greek culture and literature through the study of works by Cavafy, Sikelianos, Seferis, Elytis, Ritsos, and Anagnostakis, among others. Readings from articles on current Greek topics.

title: The Late Ottoman Empire
descrip: This course focuses on the Westernization movement, Ottoman administrative reforms, Young Ottoman, Young Turk, and ethnic-nationalist movements. In addition great diplomatic crises of 19th and 20th century and the emergence of modern Turkey will be examined.

title: Introduction to Urban Studies
reviews: A class worth paying attention in! Very interdisciplinary-- there's something in the course for everyone.

All depends on your preceptor. Typically a super easy class with minimal work... But definitely switch around your preceptor in the beginning to make sure this is true. The course isn't super interesting, lots of reading (though you don't really need to do more than skim it), and every week is basically the same exact argument. Nothing goes beyond "everything we're doing is messing up the world, hurting the poor, and helping the rich." Would say take it as a 5th course, a super easy pdf, or an easy A depending on your preceptor.
Always prepare to ask questions in precept.
Be very careful. Prof. Boyer is unashamed to insert her potent liberal opinions in lecture. Her reasoning is often ridiculous and may anger those who are encumbered by logic and reason.

Don't let the syllabus intimidate you. We were assigned a few readings and one movie out of the huge list of material each week. Interesting material and discussions. The professor is knowledgeable, though she mostly reads off of the slides during lecture. I would recommend taking it if you're interested in the material
Don't take this course - not as easy as it seems and wholly unstructured. You will just be frustrated the whole time.
Easy PDF, but pretty dull for many of the weeks.
Extraordinarily little work. I feel like I got away with murder. Take it senior spring.
Great class.
Great course
I am happy to have taken an Urban Studies course, but if I were to pick classes again I would not have chosen this one.

I took this class because I thought I wanted to get a certificate in Urban Studies but this class quickly changed my mind because I knew the only way I would be able to get through it would be if I chose to pdf.
I would encourage students to watch the assigned films and videos each work. I would also encourage students to attend lectures, because they were very informative.

If you're self-directed and get excited about cities, urbanism, infrastructure, and architectural theory, I recommend this class. It was a great PDF. I thought the readings were fantastic and I learned a lot reading them and writing my responses. Unfortunately, the lectures and precepts themselves were not so great -- professor mostly read off the slides, and lots of people in precept didn't do the readings.
Interesting material, get a broad scope of urban studies and touch on lots of different issues.
It is NOT an easy class. Ignore people who say its easy: they ramped up the difficulty a TON last spring. If you want an easy A without much work, take something else.
It's not a lot of work and very interesting.
Keep up with the required readings for precept in order to produce good weekly responses, more engaging conversation, and overall boost knowledge of course subjects.
Kind of boring in my opinion.
Must take
Not a hard class, but not an easy grade either unless you PDF. It's not an easy topic to write about because the readings are very theoretical.
Not as easy as people say.  Not worth it.
Not much to say

Pick and choose which readings you want to do, since there's no way you're going to be able to do them all (there's way too much assigned). Have a good grasp of the concepts that you do read, though, and then you should be okay.
Pretty easy class to do well in. Readings, movies, and readings responses every week plus a take home midterm and final!
Professor Boyer teaches a very interesting course with a not-too-heavy workload. A great overview of urban studies.
Recommend if you get a good preceptor.
Stay on top of the readings and films, and all exams will go smoothly.

Take it! The topics are super relevant and interesting! (but bear in mind that this is only an introductory level class and not that in depth, it is up to your own effort how much you would like to get out of the lectures and readings)
Take it! You'll really enjoy it.

Take the course. It's a painless introduction to urban studies. However, if you don't like the preceptor you get, definitely try to switch into a different precept. Precept is half the class. Make it count.
Take this class if you don't mind putting in the work for midterm and final papers.  Lectures are enjoyable and are always posted online.

Take this course, especially if you, like me, don't have a lot of knowledge about sustainability, gentrification, and related topics. I felt the topics covered by the course were really important (and usually pretty interesting), which is why I'm glad I took it.

Also, the workload isn't too bad, so it's a good class to take if you have a heavy semester and/or you want to pdf something.

This is an easy course which was moderately interesting.  There is a lot of focus on branding, i.e. various "types" of cities, without any real explanation or exploration into specifics.  Assignments are painless, do the readings and you'll be fine.

Unless professor Boyer changes things up, be prepared to feel incredibly frustrated at the one-sided nature of the content. This is the only course I've taken here that has had such an extreme level of partisan preaching.
Very interesting topics and you get to learn a lot about cities across the world and the problems being faced. Workload is manageable
take it
take it, as long as you do not get Iwanicholas as your preceptor.
take the course
take the course! not stressful, and it's incredibly broad so it will show you a million cool new ideas that you can explore further through the assignments.
very broad, if you're at all interested in the subject then you should probably take another URB course.
descrip: This course will examine different crises confronting cities in the 21st century. Topics will range from informal settlements, to immigration, terrorism, shrinking population, sprawl, rising seas, affordable housing, gentrification, smart cities. The range of cities will include Los Angles, New Orleans, Paris, Logos, Caracas, Havana, New York, Hong Kong, Dubai among others.

title: What Is Authority?
descrip: See website

title: The Later Romantics
reviews: I would highly recommend this course. Professor Wolfs is great and chooses fascinating readings and makes them even more interesting during seminar discussions.
Please, if you know what's good for you, spend some time with Wolfson and her poetry. You won't regret it.
Professor Wolfson is a little wacky, but this is a great topic with great readings (if you can keep up with them).
Take the readings seriously, submit your posts early and don't be afraid to bring up new and interesting things that surprise you from the texts.
This is an amazing class.  Highly recommended!
descrip: The flamboyant second generation of British Romantics: Keats, Percy Shelley, Mary Shelley, Byron, Hemans, Austen. Careful attention to texts--ranging from novels, to odes, to romances, and modern epics--in historical and cultural contexts, with primary focus on literary imagination.

title: Topics in Analysis - Distribution Theory, PDE & Basic Inequalities of Analysis
prereqs: MAT320 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Introduce students to important topics in distribution theory and its applications to the basic linear partial differential equations: laplace, wave and heat equations. Also introduce students to some of the basic inequalities in analysis: Hardy-Littlewood, Calderon-Zygmung, Sobolev inequalities. Restriction theorem, Strichartz inequalities. Bilinear estimates and applications to nonlinear PDE's.

title: Readings in Japanese Religions - The Buddhist Tradition
descrip: In this seminar we read representative examples of Buddhist texts in Japanese and kanbun from the Heian through modern periods. Readings are drawn from multiple genres and may include doctrinal writings, ritual manuals, didactic tales, sermons, and personal letters. Supplementary readings in Japanese and English scholarship may be assigned. To some extent, readings may be chosen to accommodate participants' research interests. Use of bibliographic and reference sources is also introduced.

title: Introduction to Microeconomics
reviews: A bit more difficult than macro. I didn't buy the pequad and it caused some issues, don't do that.
A fair, simple course that will be rewarding with due diligence.
Absolutely take it! One of the best introductory classes at Princeton! Professor Rosen is fantastic!
Always attend lecture, and be sure to do the readings. Professor Rosen is a wonderful instructor, and you will learn a lot about Microeconomics.
Attend all the lectures
Attend lecture and make sure to go to a good preceptor. Precept makes all the difference, so if you are unhappy with your preceptor, do your best to switch; I wish I did.
Attend lectures.
Be prepared to be called on in lecture

Be sure to do the readings and think about them. Go to the lectures, even if you don't agree with his take on economics because it's a testament to the value of your Princeton education that you have access to such tremendous economic minds. The challenge is super important.
Brosen is a great teacher.  Highly recommend would take

By all means, try to take ECO100 with Rosen as the professor! He is a humorous and captivating lecturer. He also provides application of economic problems to real-life problem-solving, so if you are interested public policy as well, take it! 
Maggi is a clear and helpful preceptor.
Definitely a good skill to have and Rosen is an amazing lecturer. Pretty hard and requires a lot of work.
Definitely a worthwhile class to take, especially if Rosen is teaching it.

Definitely take the course! It's an amazing opportunity to study with Professor Rosen, and the material is useful in understanding the ways in which our world and economy work. The problem sets and midterm are fair, and if you put in the work to understand the material, you'll see the results you want.
Definitely take this class but make sure you have a good study group to work on the PSets with.

Definitely take this course if Professor Rosen is teaching it! One of my absolute favorite courses so far and the lectures are actually interesting. Also, Professor Rosen is the coolest person you'll ever meet.
Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in economics! Professor Rosen is a great lecturer! I found this class to be enjoyable, worthwhile, and relevant to my everyday life.
Definitely take this course. Prof Rosen is a great instructor

Definitely take this course; I think everybody stands to gain something from Economics and the weekly workload is manageable. Try not to fall behind on the readings and to practice or at least review the concepts on your own throughout the semester.
Definitely take this! Rosen is amazing.

Do keep up with the readings, they are not that much. The textbook is virtually useless;  buy it electronically three, four ways or whatever and save money if you and others really want it. Review, review, review the solutions to the problem sets and understand step by step on how you came to an answer as it is critical in cultivating a deeper understanding. The course seems like its easy, don't be fooled. Recognize how even with Rosen, you only understand superficially and highly theoretically at those moments when you think you get it. Microeconomics seems like "oh its common sense" but if you don't practice with pen and paper, you will choke come test time.  Make a study group especially for the final. If you are a freshman listen to this: Plan accordingly on who the lecturer is 1) Avoid Reinhart like the plague. I've sat-in in his lectures and have listened to many of his victims; he is awful to have if you are not an economics genius (in which case you should not be taking this class and should have gotten a 5 on the AP test). 2) Bogan is okay. I know from six plus weeks of experience. She doesn't really teach during her lectures. She is extremely accessible though and a real treat. 3) If its Rosen TAKE IT. Lectures are gold and your notes, provided that you truly know how to take notes (actually a rare skill), you will excel. He's amazing. After the final I know for sure that me and economics don't match, but I no longer hate economics because of Rosen.
Do the problem sets and go to office hours with them. If you get a lot out of them you will be better prepared for exams.
Do the readings and attend the precepts and Lectures!! Rosen is one of the best professors so you should take the class with him!!
Do the readings. Work together on the problem sets. Attend lecture.

Don't be afraid of taking this course. Just keep up with the material each week, and it is not so bad! Be warned that the final tests all the articles from the whole year, so make sure to keep up with them.
Don't take this course unless you want to major in econ or you have to take it.

ECO100 with Rosen did not live up to its hype. Rosen is an engaging lecturer, and his no-computer and random-calling works to promote student engagement. Precept was used less to clarify or reinforce lecture material and more to teach new concepts, which often meant that each topic was covered for only minutes before students were meant to engage with it on the problem sets. Textbook reading is only useful for concept reinforcement, and syllabus non-textbook readings are worth only a skim before the final. Molly Schnell is a great preceptor, organized, clear, and concise and willing to help out students with flexible office hours. ECO100 concepts are not difficult, but are presented trickily on problem sets and exams.
Easy A.
Easy class if you are an engineer.
Easy. Make sure you understand the concepts. Rosen is very funny and the only reason i kept going to lecture
Economics is something everyone should take at some point in their life and Harvey Rosen does a great job of trying to keep you entertained while you learn.
Economics isn't for everyone. Make sure you understand the path.
Eh.
Even if you don't need it for a pre-req it's good to take. Rosen is a good lecturer and you can even get by without doing the readings, though they can be helpful.
Even if you're not majoring in Economics, it's a good SA. Especially if Rosen is teaching.
Even students who do not plan on majoring in Economics should take this course for its foundational knowledge.
Everyone should take this course

Everyone should take this course. Gives you the fundamentals for understanding economics in our world. You'll find it more interesting if you talk to people and do the readings. The textbook is actually very helpful. Be prepared to study more than you think for the exams and still maybe not so as well as you'd like. Still recommend!
Expect a lot of graphing and not much of anything else. If you liked Algebra 1 graphing slopes and intercepts this is your class. If you want to learn economics I do not recommend.
GREAT CLASS IF YOU PUT IN THE HOURS AND DO THE WORK!
Get Andres as a preceptor!

Get Cristian for your preceptor if you can! If Rosen is teaching, make sure you go to lecture, because it's the best place to learn the material (plus lectures are pretty interesting). It's a good class and you learn a ton about econ in a short time.
Get into Rosen or Molly's precept if possible. Go to McGraw, will almost guarantee you 9s or 10s on your problem sets.
Go to every lecture and be engaged

Go to lecture and McGraw. They are beneficial because the only way to learn the anything well is to do. I recommend that you take it even if you have the slightest interest because it is important to understand how the economy works.
Go to lectures.
Go to office hours with your preceptor. Go to McGraw. Work with other people on the problem sets -- collaboration will get you through this class.
Go to office hours! The problem sets aren't difficult but office hours helps in getting all the points for each one.
Good PDF and/or fifth class. If you're a science major this is a pretty good SA since there's no papers and barely any reading, just very basic math. Rosen is great, but he definitely knows it.
Good class to take if you are at all interested in Econ and just a good class for gaining important knowledge about our world.
Good class to take if you want to learn basic Economics. Would recommend taking it with Harvey. You actually learn a lot.
Good course that gives you an understanding of economics.
Good course to take as an introduction to microeconomics, you don't need any background in economics to understand the material. Rosen is great, helps to get a good preceptor.
Good intro to econ
Great class to take with Rosen. Do the supplementary readings throughout the semester so that you do not have to cram them all before the final.
Great class! Rosen is a funny and engaging lecturer - be prepared to be cold called in lecture. Make sure you go to precept - it covers information not presented in lecture.
Great class.
Great course if Rosen is teaching
Great course, take it with Harvey Rosen if possible! He's an amazing lecturer and makes things interesting.

Great foundation course to take! Would definitely recommend. Would also advise going lectures. Rosen teaches it very well, and the amount of effort beyond lectures and precepts is minimal (problem sets and some reading). Keep in mind that Rosen is slightly partisan in his approaches to things, so do not be completely swayed by some of the problem sets and examples from class. It sometimes feels like Rosen is trying to make you believe that minimum wage is the worst thing that could happen, rent control hurts the gay community, the ACA was ridiculous, and welfare and subsidies are not justified. Learn about the microeconomic principles that are involved in these issues, but be aware that they are debatable economic policy questions that have broader policy/macroeconomic implications as well.
Harvey Rosen is a great lecturer so you should go all to the lectures.
Harvey Rosen is a great lecturer. Do all the readings. Do the problem sets. Get to know the material very well, it'll help you see life in a different way which is awesome.

Harvey Rosen is a truly fantastic lecturer - he has a knack for making microeconomics seem fun and engaging, and his humorous and concise presentation style would be a chief reason I would recommend this course to any thoughtful Princeton student. The problem sets are not over-taxing and they really help with exam preparation, and there are really only two big assessments.

Harvey Rosen is very accomplished personally and professionally, but his class is okay. I think I've gained a general sense of microeconomics, but not as much of an in-depth knowledge as I would've hope. Material in lecture and precept sometimes didn't match up (i.e. we only learned Isocost lines and Isoquant curves in Precept once and never went over it lecture). The problem sets were definitely necessary in order to understand topics covered in lecture since instruction was not always the most comprehensive or clear. Problem sets were not super difficult, but did require some thinking. Also, I don't like how we took the midterm in lecture (rather than a usual three hour time block) so I felt rushed and that the exam wasn't an adequate reflection of my abilities and understanding.Overall, the class was adequate, but not amazing.
Harvey Rosen really commands a classroom. Not difficult - except Rosen's tests are much harder than any of the other professors.

Harvey is a great and stimulating lecturer. He went over a lot of problems in class explaining various concepts. I understand 500-person class limitations, but without prior econ experience, I felt a bit left behind at times (as preceptors would go over new material, and we were required to learn material on our own as well), large class makes grading completely  impersonal.
Harvey is a really awesome lecturer. Problem sets are of average difficulty. Readings are supplementary and not totally necessary. Good class with a light to average workload.
Harvey's a great professor. You may not get the best grades (final was really hard), but you'll learn A LOT. Definitely take this course.
I don't think you can go wrong with Professor Rosen, he's very knowledgable and excellent at teaching the material.
I mean, you have to take this class if you want to do any social science/econ related profession, so yeah. Take it with Rosen if you're going to take it at all.
I never went to lecture for this course. I am still doing well.
I really enjoyed the course, and I definitely recommend taking this course.
I recommend microeconomics for all students, but take it with Rosen because he is the best lecturer
I think most people like Harvey Rosen as a lecturer, but I didn't enjoy what felt like him rambling and drawing graphs on the board of McCosh 50. Maggi is a great preceptor though.
I think that the class is great! Make sure to pay attention during lecture because it makes the readings much more of review sessions.
I think this is a very useful course. Pay attention in lecture and keep up with everything.
I took it for the SA distribution requirement- probably easy if you pdf

I took this course with no prior knowledge of econ and was fine. Go to all of the lectures because that is where the bulk of the concepts are taught. Harvey is a fantastic lecturer and the classes are engaging and easy to follow. He's hilarious and makes class enjoyable. Even if you don't need this class for a major I would recommend taking it.

I was a WWS with no prior experience in economics and not a math person at all, but do not worry.  I went to McGraw every week, had a great preceptor (Molly) and found a way to get to the final with a B.  I absolutely recommend that you at least read Mankiw and do so before the lectures if you can as it really helps understand the material.  You will be given past exams but take note that the midterm was a little tricky for some, although the answer is usually easier to find than you may think it is.  When answering the problem set or even other exam questions, I found it helpful to think of the answer that Professor Rosen would want it to be, meaning he leans right and so take that into consideration when finding the answers to the questions he made up (all of them).
Also, I think taking micro by Rosen is the best path for anyone who is not a math person or is taking it for WWS as the class is well-designed overall and both the professor and preceptors try to lay the material out in a way so that everyone understands regardless of their familiarity with economics.
I would advise students to stay on top of the readings, do the problem sets early, and go to office hours.
I would definitely recommend taking this course. Be sure to do your problem sets and attend precept, and you'll be fine. I wasn't a great fan of the readings, but then again, who is..
I would definitely recommend this course for anyone looking to get a basic understanding of economics as it presents many of the fundamentals in the study in a clear and concise manner
I would highly recommend the class to any student, since it provides useful information in general.

I would highly recommend this course especially if Professor Rosen and Andres are teaching it. As long as you keep up with the readings and go to office hours for p-set help, you'll definitely get a lot out of this class.
I would not recommend this class to anyone that has a higher level understanding of mathematics.
I would recommend this class.
I would recommend this classes!
I would try to get Rosen as a preceptor, but the course is very very good.
I'd recommend this course to anyone who is interested with Micro Economics, especially if you're taking this with Rosen

If Harvey Rosen is teaching this class then TAKE IT. You will not regret it. The workload isn't too bad and you will learn so much by the end of the semester. The precepts were kind of useless (but that might have just been my preceptor - avoid Dan) but the lectures were FANTASTIC and the assignments were actually quite engaging. I cannot stress this enough: GO TO LECTURES. You will learn everything you need for the course and they are frankly hilarious.
If Rosen is teaching it, take it.
If Rosen is teaching the class, absolutely take it. He is a great lecturer and makes the class really fun!
If Rosen is teaching, take it! He's a great lecturer and the material is generally relevant for any major.
If you do all the readings and attend all the lectures, you will be very well prepared for this class.
If you have the opportunity to take Rosen's class, I strongly encourage you to do so. It is truly engaging and thought provoking.

If you want a basic understanding of the economy this is a good course to take. Yes, it's difficult to think like an economist but it opened my eyes and I feel like I came away with good information. The problem sets are difficult but set aside a night to get it done and they're doable. Also there's a ton of help everywhere to understand it. Be warned though: McGraw tutoring sessions are going to be pretty full.

If you're at all interested in economics, take this class!  It's also a prereq for majoring in the econ dept, so if you're thinking of doing that, get it out of the way early!  Workload is light.  Textbook readings can be ignored if you go to lecture.  Don't skip the essay/article readings though?there are exam questions on specific articles.  Try to get Andres Maggi as your preceptor.
If you're looking for an SA, this is a good one to take. Even if you're not an Econ major.
If you're taking microecon, take Rosen's.
Interesting and Rosen is great.
Interesting course, Professor Rosen makes it fun.
It is fairly difficult but I would still take it. IT does take time to understand the concepts but it is interesting.

It is really easy to slack in this class since problem sets are worth so little of your grade. Class is worth taking if you keep up with it during the year so you're not stuck teaching yourself the entire class in the few days before a very difficult final exam.
It's a decent course, but I wouldn't recommend it unless your are WWS or ECO Major.
It's actually fun and I learned a lot! Be careful to not wear bright colors
It's an excellent intro to micro course. Professor Rosen is very clear. He likes to call on students during lecture, though, so watch out for that.
It's ite.
Keep up on your readings (especially supplementary) since Rosen does a good job of covering most of important information during class
Keep up with readings; get a head-start on the problem sets.

Learned so much, great class, must take it even if not planning on majoring

Looking for "Econ in our World"? If so, take this course; it's a perfect non-rigorous introduction to the topic.  If you're a strong math student, or interested in the rigorous study of economics, do yourself a favor: read Mankiw yourself, and take 310.
Make sure attend lectures and precepts.
Make sure to go to McGraw if you're confused about the Psets. It helps a lot and you'll need to understand these concepts in practical applications to do well on the exams.
Make sure to meet with Professor Rosen during office hours, and follow up with other students in the class on problem sets and concepts that you don't know.

Make sure to pay attention to detail on the psets and go to all lectures and precepts. Also, read the textbook, if it is still the Mankiw version because it was really helpful for me as I had never taken an econ class before. If Rosen is teaching the course, definitely take it.
Make sure to study way in advance of the exam.
Make sure you stay on top of the textbook readings.

Manageable workload, really helpful to go to McGraw or check the weekly with friends for confusing questions. Readings are pretty easy to follow before the midterm but afterwards, lecture is important for material not really covered in the textbook or ereserves
Memorize the formulas in the beginning as to develop a better understanding of the material.
Microeconomics (especially at Princeton) is a class everyone should take
More precepts less lecture

Most students will tell you, "take this class no matter if you need it or not!". Personally, I'm not very good at/interested in Econ, but I still recommend the course in general. If you have to take Eco, try to take it when Rosen's teaching - he's a world-class leading economist, and a resource available to us here at Princeton. A very engaging lecturer and funny guy, plus he knows the names of probably a good half of our 400-person lecture. Not an extremely difficult course - if you're not good at eco, attend all lectures (actually, if you're lucky enough to have Rosen, attend all lectures anyway). People who are really good at eco may not need to go to all of the lectures. I didn't do readings most weeks, which I regret, but I'm getting by ok. Christian Alonso was a great preceptor! Precepts always present new information from the lectures. P-Sets are more difficult than the information presented in class, so work with other students to understand the questions, because P-set questions are similar to the exam.
N/A
Not a very interesting class, but not a very difficult one either. Not a bad class to take and PDF.
Not easy to get an A with only two assessments, but necessary for WWS and Econ.

Not necessarily an easy A just because it's an intro course. That said, everyone should take this class with Harvey Rosen. He makes economics relevant to everyone, and he explains things very clearly. He manages to keep even the most mundane material interesting.
Not necessarily the most fascinating material, but it's useful to know, and Professor Rosen presented it in a way that was fun and engaging.
Not too difficult (although also not easy), a good overview of micro with a couple of great preceptors. Rosen is a very entertaining and knowledgeable professor.

One of the courses all students should take at Princeton, Micro was a great class, and you should definitely take it with Rosen. He is an engaging, dynamic lecturer, and his classes are as humorous and entertaining as they are informative. I would highly recommend it!
One of the most interesting and engaging intro courses out there!

Do not just accept the material as it is presented, but try to expand and force it into different, uncharacteristic situations to preform well and best succeed in the class.

Rosen is great! (try getting his precept too) Do the weekly readings! They aren't discussed in precept but are really interesting and show up on the exam (for a few points).
Rosen is the best. He makes the class so lively and interesting. My advice wold be to go to McGraw for homework help because it is so useful
SO AMBIGUOUS. If you are BSE be aware of how ambiguous this course is. It will make you question all aspects of humanity courses and how they expect the "exact" answer when there are dozens.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Harvey Rosen will become your favorite professor at Princeton.

TAKE THIS WITH ROSEN!! Rosen is an amazing lecturer and I have never wanted to attend a lecture more than this one. Get a good preceptor (maybe even Rosen himself) because if you don't the problem sets will be harder but definitely take this course regardless of if you're going to be an economics major or not.
Take 100 with Rosen. He's a god among men and you will not be disappointed. Be diligent with the work though.
Take advantage of all resources--McGraw, office hours, ect.
Take for sure if you need it. Pay attention if you don't need it.

Taking this class is a must. It is necessary in order to fully understand and appreciate the economy. It is the most applicable course I have taken so far. Try to grasp the concepts fully, thinking about how they work in the real world in order to get the most out of the class.
The course is a little more work/material than I expected, but overall I really enjoyed it.
The course provides a solid framework and understanding for someone who has not taken microeconomics.
The econ department exaggerates how important this class is. Nothing was taught that isn't taught in a halfway decent AP class.

The material was a little boring for me at times just because I am not someone who particularly loves economics. However, I must say that this was one of the most worthwhile classes I have taken as someone who has never had exposure to this subject. It structured in a way that allowed beginners and people who've already learned this stuff to succeed and learn something new. Overall, it was a great experience, and a great introduction to microeconomics.
The readings on E-reserves are SO HELPFUL! Especially during the second half of the semester. So do them! All the preceptors that I know of are fantastic--use them!
This an incredible course to take, but make sure to keep up with the readings and problem sets.
This can be an easy A if you just do the work. Rosen is the best professor I've had up to this point.
This class is highly engaging and rewarding. Professor Rosen is incredible, so take it with him if you can!

This class might not be as easy as you want it to be, I don't think I could've done it as a 5th class like some people do. Try to keep up and really understand the material, and study hard for the midterm and final.

This class should be very easy for anyone who has some sort of mathematical background (engineering, science, etc.). Even if you have not the slightest background in econ, you can still quite easily breeze through the class as if it were an average high school course.
Prof. Rosen is a great lecturer, and very engaging. My only complaint is that he "speaks from the stump" and uses very few visual aids aside from drawing relevant plots. Overall, though, great quality.

This course is a prerequisite for many other courses and for WWS majors, but even if you don't need it as a prerequisite, take it; I developed a profound appreciation for Economics, and learned that it can even help us in issues of discrimination, global warming, etc. Many students just go to lectures (which are great!) but I would highly recommend reading the textbook every week.

This course is different than AP Micro so I would definitely recommend taking it even if you have micro experience. The class is fascinating and pretty easy, the problem sets are very manageable and the readings are unnecessary.
This course is great, and definitely worth going to the lectures. Either going to lecture/precept or doing the readings is essential to success.
This course is what you make of it because it is such a large class. Definitely go to precept, because they cover a lot of information there.

This is a difficult course, and you definitely have to stay on top of your work, but Rosen is an incredible lecturer and presents information in a really interesting way. I would recommend this course for sure.
This is an excellent course for what it is--an introductory microeconomics course. Rosen is engaging and passionate, and the material well-presented.
This is an interesting class, and the workload is pretty light. Good for a fifth class. Rosen's lectures are interesting and entertaining, but I didn't think they were as amazing as everyone says.
This is an intro economics course, don't expect anything more or less. It was perfectly fine, but nothing special. Professor Rosen is a very good lecturer though, I would recommend taking his class.
This is class is very interesting, and problem set driven, but is very manageable. Be sure to use the McGraw Center if you need help with the problem set.

This is the best course i've taken at Princeton yet. Rosen is such a fantastic lecturer and preceptor. He made me seriously consider being an economics major. I never missed a single one of his precepts.

descrip: Economics is the study of how people and societies deal with scarcity. This course focuses on the advantages and disadvantages of market systems for allocating scarce resources.

title: Food and Power
reviews: Absolutely do not waste your time with this class. There are so many other fantastic courses that you can truly learn in at Princeton.

Again, this was without a doubt THE WORST CLASS I have taken in my Princeton career, out of 32 courses. Do not take this class unless you enjoy incompetent teachers, rude preceptors and wasting your time.

Be prepared for lots of reading and confusing anthropological concepts.
Themes include capitalism, injustice, consumption, labor, and fetishization, through the lens of food
Better if not a lecture class.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. worst class i have taken at princeton. Left every lecture so confused. Also, hard to do well in.
DONT TAKE THIS CLASS
Definitely do not take this class

Do NOT take this course. It has nothing to do with the topic that it claims it will be discussing, lectures are tedious and the grading policy is unfair in many ways. I think that in four years at Princeton I have gotten the least out of this course.

Do not fall behind on the readings! There is a fair amount each week, but doing them on the week that they are due will lighten your load for the midterms/finals and improve the quality of your precis. For the precis, apply class concepts to the readings and draw from personal experience.
Do not take this class.

Do not take this course to learn about food and power! Only take this if you want a survey course about anthropology theories. The manner in which Professor Rouse teaches is all over the place, and she rarely connects lectures back to the readings or back to food. Beware!
Don't do it unless you're interested in a disorganised introduction to ANT with a tenuous link to food

Don't do it, it's not what you think unless you hear that Prof. Rouse has drastically revised the course to be actually about food and power. The topic had potential but she fell short in many many areas
Don't let the title of the class fool you. Instructor is often times unclear in her explanations.
Don't take this if you expect it to be about food or power, or if you "care about your grade". Ended up having to PDF because of uncertainty.
Don't think you will only be focusing on food, there is a lot of discussion on economic theories. Food is primarily a lens.
Easy PDF
Fine for PDF, not a great class otherwise.
Has potential, but wait until the reviews improve before taking.
Honestly just don't take this class.
I like it as a PDF course.

I really liked this course and thought it served as a nice intro anthropology course. It's not really an ENV course in my opinion, but rather uses food to discuss anthropology topics, especially neoliberalism. The lecture format was a bit awkward but if the course is offered as a seminar or with precepts I would highly recommend.
I took it as an SA/fifth class and it was chill. There's a decent amount of reading every week but not bad. Lectures are fun as long as you don't mind sitting through anti-West rhetoric.
I would advise students not to take this course.

I would recommend taking this course if you're interested in anthropology, inequality, power dynamics, food production, culture, or globalization. It's a really interesting course that opens your eyes to a whole world behind what's on your plate that you might never have been aware of otherwise.

I wouldn't recommend taking this unless you are an anthropology major and might understand what is going on.  The professor did not seem to want to help people who were unfamiliar with anthropology or had differing viewpoints.

If you are interested in the material, it is likely that you will not get much out of the course. But this course can be good if you would like to fill a distribution requirement or if you want a course with little workload.

If you need an SA and are vaguely interested in environmental issues, I would recommend this one!  Definitely not what I was expecting based on the course description, but I ended up liking it anyway.  Professor Rouse sometimes does not explain things clearly, but the general material is interesting.  And the workload is very manageable.

If you want to learn cool things about food, this is NOT the course for you. The course focused on overly complicated anthropological concepts and social problems like race and gender (way too much jargon).  Very little emphasis is paid to food history or food in and of itself.

If you're interested in thinking about food and how you can use food to think about politics/economics, definitely take this class. This class provides a lot of interesting material that has been super fun to discuss, even outside of class. You'll be writing weekly response papers (~500 words), which are very doable, just make sure to put good thought into synthesizing what you've read.  Overall, I learned a lot from this class. My only qualm is that this class can be rather jargon-heavy, with lots of key terms, so make sure to stay on top of those and maybe make a study guide before the exam.
Interesting readings, not a great class.

Not a great class.
Not too much work - you learn interesting concepts that are also relevant to other classes you may take like environmental policy and economics.
Only take it if shes dont a better job of structuring.
Probably don't take

Save yourself now and don't take this class. It sounds really interesting but it's very poorly taught and graded. I didn't learn anything from this class and it was much more stress than it should've been for an "easy" humanities class.
Super easy senior spring PDF
