Lectures are a bit dry with a lot of note-taking, but applications, when discussed, are interesting. Problem sets/midterm were fair, and the programming assignments were really interesting. People complain a lot about "having to teach themselves matlab," but if you have any coding experience (COS 126), you'll be fine. This is a good intro stats course for BSEs.

For us, the psets and programming assignments were a huge chunk of the grade, so make sure to do well on these. Not a lot of people go to lecture or precept. It's up to you what you want to do. The textbook we had was very clear, which was nice, so I'd recommend finding it. You do learn a lot, though, so it's a pretty good class.
Go to lectures, ask your preceptors lots of questions, and McGraw is amazing for the problem sets
I think this is the best flavor of stats Princeton offers.

I would probably take another stats class over this one. The assignments vary greatly in terms of difficulty and there is absolutely no guidance for MATLAB, so good luck to those who have no programming experience.

I would recommend taking COS 126 before taking this course because there was a lot of programming. Some of the course is easy if you've taken AP Stats but other parts are still quite hard. Be prepared to do a lot of independent learning.
I'd overall recommend. It's a fine course, and it's easy to do well on problem sets, but the exams set the curve, and unfortunately, don't really test you on anything you've learned.

If you have to choose between this and PDE's, then take this. But only if you are actually interested in statistics. Otherwise it's a bit of a teeth-puller. Kpotufe's lectures tend to be interesting though, I thought.

If you just want to learn stat and not necessarily fulfill a requirement, take ECO 202. ORF 245 is in the end some form of a weedout class for ORF majors (gets better in 309). Highly variable in course structure/grading depending on who's teaching (Vanderbei vs. Kpoutufe vs. other) so make sure you thoroughly research before taking this course. It'll change how you approach things and study.
If you need to take a stats class and are mathematically inclined take it
If you're interested in learning the mathematics behind statistics, you should take this course.
It is not as bad as you might have heard from other people, but do not expect it to be that awesome.

It really depends. I was looking for a statistics course that's practical and useful, and this class is very theoretical. Therefore, I didn't really get what I wanted and I didn't care much for the material presented. Moreover, this course is not exactly easy, don't ever think of it as a chill course. Also be careful when you take it, I think it's really bad in the spring but I've heard that it's even worse in the fall.
It's a requirement lol

Make sure Kpotufe is teaching the course if you are going to take the class, as I have heard very bad things about the other teacher, but I am not interested in statistics and will take more classes in the ORF department.
Meh. Manageable if not particularly exciting.
More interesting and fun than you'd think! Stephen Chen's office hours are legendary, and you definitely need a pset group, but really consider taking this even if you don't need to!
Not very hard but don't expect to learn much
Not very inspiring, but not too hard to get through. You will have to figure out what is and isn't important to know.

Pay attention (find a way) in lecture, it'll make your life a lot easier. Don't be afraid to ask questions in lecture, and office hours are great. Still a good way to learn stats and practice your skills in derivations and probability.
Pretty well taught course, not a lot of work.
Professor Kpotufe is an excellent teacher. This course helps build a really useful statistical toolset.

Professor Kpotufe teaches this course better than what I've heard about some of the other ORF 245 professors. The tradeoff is that in addition to weekly written assignments, you also get programming assignments in MatLab. Definitely make use of resources, friends, or online documentation to help you understand how to use MatLab or the assignments might take you a very long time to complete.

Samory is an excellent lecturer! Just make sure to read the book before class if you want to follow along; he goes through material really quickly. Start the HW sets early as well - especially the programming ones (w/ MATLAB) as they take longer than you'd expect. Some cos experience would be really helpful but not necessary.
Samory is not the best lecturer. His lectures are very dry and you don't learn much. Stephen Chen, on the other hand, is the best preceptor ever.

Samory teaches with a very theoretical lens. The programming assignments are really interesting, and some of the homework sets are dry but others guide you through an understanding of some stats concept in an interesting way. At least this semester you could go to any precept any time but the two precepts I frequented were often filled with awkward and time-wasting pauses because the instructors weren't very familiar with the material, it seemed. Office hours are crucial for homeworks.
Solid probability and stats course. Take it with Samory and be prepared to work every week.
Take if you need stats class - although very theoretical class - other stats classes might teach it better.
Take it only if you have to (or if you really enjoy statistics that much)
Take it only if you have too.
Take it with Samory. He is amazing.
Take it!
Take it, trust the notes, review the concepts faithfully, same old advice.

Take this class for a good introduction to statistics and to gain an intuition for statistics. The second half is a lot harder, so maybe start processing the material before it is taught so you won't be blindsided when it does come.
The material is generally adequately presented, but is not particularly interesting.

There's really not much going for or against 245: it's not too hard, not too easy (especially the final). The Matlab assignments are a load of garbage. Regular problem sets are mostly easy, but some questions are mad junk derivations. Overall, it's an absurdly mediocre class: pretty much a little more stuff than AP Stat.

This class starts off really easy and then gets a lot harder, so be prepared. (this is coming from someone without any background in statistics. Only take this if you have a strong desire to learn statistics or you have to.
This class was rather boring because the material was dry and not very well taught. Would not recommend unless required course. If you do take it, find a good group to work on assignments with.
This course is interesting, a bit theoretical at times, but if you enjoyed statistics in high school, you'll probably find this course interesting.
This course was very well taught and provided to be engaging even though it was a requirement that I did not have much prior interest in.

This isn't the best ORF course but ultimately it teaches the necessary material. It isn't too difficult; however, be sure to read the books and keep on track with lecture notes. The programming assignments can be fun if you're interested in data visualization and machine learning.
Unless you have to, this isn't really a fun class to take.
Unreasonably hard final, unfair grading bc of the need for a curve
Very solid, useful statistics course. Difficult at times but well worth the effort. Would recommend to anybody regardless major.
Worth taking if you like stats.
n/a
you kinda have to take it if you wanna do any kind of useful stuff in life, so i guess take it.
prereqs: MAT 201 concurrent or equivalent.
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated in the light of modern data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R. Precepts are based on real data analysis.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - K-12 School Reform
descrip: This course explores K-12 education policymaking in the context of dramatic changes to the status quo, but an unclear future. We will focus on differing perspectives and solutions for a diverse array of issues--from standards, assessments, and accountability to teachers/school leaders to governance, turnarounds, and school choice. The course will be anchored in the reality of policymaking--digesting the research on a topic, making/supporting policy recommendations. Students will work with 'live issues' in ed reform, analyze them, and recommend paths forward.

title: Germany since 1806
reviews: A great general overview of German history with focus on the economic and political factors behind history.
A pretty comprehensive class about German history. The class is taught with the baseline assumption that you know nothing. Stick with it! You'll learn a lot. And Professor James is awesome.

I would recommend this course. Professor James is incredibly knowledgeable on the subject matter, and you will, assuming you complete the readings and the weekly discussion questions, learn quite a bit for a twelve week class. This class focuses most heavily on German from 1848 to 1945. If you are hoping to learn more about the periods outside of those years, this class may not be for you. That said, I would still highly recommend this class for anyone with a general interest in Germany or social science concentrators who want a very well-taught class.
If you are interested in German history, take this course! You will learn a lot.

James is a uniquely brilliant professor but his teaching style is not for everyone. He is not going to stand in front of the class and make funny quips. He will, however, share his extensive knowledge and wisdom with you. The work is very manageable.
Prof. James is great, but it is a LOT of reading.

Take if you enjoy German history.  The readings aren't too bad, and interesting, although some weeks have a lot more pages than others (i.e. reading half of Buddenbooks plus textbook one week).  Essays are pretty open.

This is an awesome class. You don't need to do all the reading, but at least do some so you can participate and write good papers. Harold James can be a bit dry, but he spices up class with discussion, and he's brilliant.
pretty good take if you want
descrip: This course sets German history in a comparative context of international politics, demonstrating how nationalism and national unity emerged as responses to the European state system in the first half of the 19th century, how after 1871 German problems in turn affected the world, and finally why after 1945 Germany should be so prominent in super-power politics. It examines the origin of the German Revolution of 1989, and the place of Germany in Europe and the global order.

title: France and its Empire, 1500-1815
reviews: Amazing course with an incredible professor about a really fascinating time and place.
Keep up with the readings and take extensive notes and quotes. It will save you grief when you go to make study guides.

Prof. Bell is a good lecturer and very clear, but sometimes a bit dry. He is also very helpful when writing papers or reviewing for exams, and takes a clear interest in actually making sure the material is getting through effectively and people are keeping up with the course.
Really great professor and very interesting material. Great HA for anyone interested in French culture and I'm sure it's a great course for regular History students too.

Take it!! This class is on a very interesting subject and is very well-organized. I think that the topics (the Wars of Religion, Enlightenment, French Rev.) and readings are very worthwhile to know about. The professor is great and makes everything interesting. I highly recommend it!!
This is a fascinating course and Professor Bell is an amazing teacher.
descrip: A survey of France and its colonial empire during centuries in which this country dominated the Western world. Major topics include the sixteenth-century Wars of Religion, the absolute monarchy, colonization and slavery in North America and the Caribbean, the Enlightenment, eighteenth-century social and cultural change, the French Revolution and the Terror, the Haitian Revolution, and the Napoleonic Empire.

title: Topics in Evolution - Polyphenism
descrip: Polyphenism is the production of multiple phenotypes from what appears to be a single genotype. We discuss the role of the environment in shaping phenotypes and then include these processes in a new evolutionary synthesis. From the original model that new species were the result of developmental macro-mutations to produce hopeful monsters, to Waddington's proposal that much of the phenotype is shaped by the environment, not the genotype. We discuss contemporary primary literature to examine how a New "EcoDevoEvol" Synthesis is taking shape, one that incorporates environmental, developmental, and evolutionary pressures.

title: Language, Power and Identity
reviews: Careful in choosing this course if you are one that likes application and talks about creating step by step proposals and plans for solving the problems criticized by the ideas presented in the class. If you don't like sociology or if you are turned off by narrowed mindedness because of a lack of understanding in politics, history, and pragmatic common sense about human nature, then don't take it. You will find yourself fuming from over idealistic people who don't see that they are regarding complex issues with a simplistic mindset rather than trying to come together to talk about how to create a strategy by combining very possible simple solutions. If you can deal with all of that, think analytically, be confident in playing devil's advocate all the while doing it in a language other than your mother tongue, then attack this class with gusto and enthusiasm. Madame Sagnier will love to see it, even if you have to butt heads with her politically, socially, and culturally. The intellectual French man or woman knows well how to have deeper conversations while being civil and Madame does it superbly and amicably. If you can also delve deeper into sociolinguistics' awesome benefit in teaching you the complex dynamics of language usage that linguistic classes utterly fails to do, then you will be golden. Also, if you are in the French department or have had Madame Sagnier, you know how much of a fool you are to not have Madame C. Sagnier in your Princeton academic experience as much as possible. The course is growing. Help make Madame in creating it an excellent class; she is extremely approachable regardless of what you think. It is a regret of mine to not fully capitalize on that recommendation and her approachability. Overall, I recommend the course per that statement and all those stated above. Plus, you will come out of the class more fluent and that is prime.

Great upper-level French course that applies strongly to everyday life and will make you think about how language and culture are tied together and what role they have to play in society. You really need to be willing to engage with the material though.

If you're interested in sociolinguistics and the French (but not only) case definitely take this class. It is particularly relevant to many modern issues and will help you understand, if not all, at least part of the problems faced by Europe in general and France in particular.
Really interesting topics. A bit high workload but manageable. Definitely try it out!
Take this class -- one of the best I've taken here.
Take this class or any other with Madame Sagnier! You won't regret it!

This is a phenomenal course if you are at all interested in the interaction between French language and culture. The texts will challenge your critical reading skills, the movies are powerful, and the subject is super interesting.

This is a very interesting sociolinguistics course. The readings are sometimes challenging, and the fact that native French speakers also take the course can make it stressful for the non-native speaker, but overall it's well worth it. Sagnier is amazing! I highly recommend.

This was a fantastic course and Prof. Sagnier is a delightful professer - very knowledgeable and passionate about the subject, and great at communicating. It would be an honor to take another class with her.
prereqs: FRE 215, FRE 309, or an equivalent 300 level course in French..
descrip: This course is an introduction to language in society. Through readings and film screenings, we will explore contemporary debates related to language, culture, diversity and identity, examining how French society wrestles with the challenges brought about by globalization. The material used will be interdisciplinary and will include readings from sociolinguistics, but also essays, political discourses, films, documentaries, comic books, images and songs.

title: Mathematics in Engineering II
reviews: If you're a physics major you shouldn't take this version of complex. Way too much time spent on applications that are not very useful. You'll want more math.
It's easier than MAE305. So take it!
Not mind blowing, but not a bad departmental
This course is good at teaching you the basic principles of complex, but isn't very enlightening mathematically. Spend time on problem sets and ask questions.
This is not PDEs as much as complex analysis. If you had a hard time with 305, this is not just more of the same.
the material covered was really interesting. The title of the course however is a little misleading. Its mostly complex analysis and a week or two or partial differential equations.
prereqs: MAE 305 or MAT 301.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to partial differential equations, covering PDEs of relevant interest in engineering and science problems. The material covered includes: (i) Complex analysis, including complex functions and series, (ii) Fourier series, integrals, and transforms, (iii) Solutions of partial differential equations, (iv) Conformal mapping and Potential theory, and (v) Applications of all the above. The material will be covered in three weekly lectures, plus one weekly AI session. Grades will be determined from weekly homework assignments, class/precept participation, the two midterm exams, and the final exam.

title: Digital Photography
reviews: Definitely should take, regardless of experience. Lack of experience or a lot of experience for that matter, will not play against you in any way.
Definitely take this class with Jeff if you can! You will understand art/photography in new ways.
Definitely take this class. It's not an easy class because you do need to spend a lot of time in making the prints and taking the right photos. But it is super fun!
Definitely take this class. Professor Whetstone is a wonderful critic and a wonderful teacher.
Do all your readings and assignments and really think about them. You won't learn unless you put in time on your own.
Get as much feedback as you can from Fia and show her that you are improving in the class.

I would really recommend that you take this class, especially with Fia! You can actually track your improvement throughout the course and the readings bring to light different ways of understanding photography both as an art form and as a tool of truth.
Leave time for photographs, listen to what your instructor wants, and choose a final project that interests you. Do not be afraid to ask questions, the instructors are happy to help

Projects take a surprising amount of time--between shooting the photos, editing, and printing. Talk to Professor Whetstone before each project to run your ideas by him and get his thoughts, especially if you have no background in photography.
Start the assignments early!
TAKE!!!! A great 5th class, but you can't pretend it's not there.
Take it if Jeff is teaching it, you won't regret it.
Take this course, and give yourself time for assignments - to shoot, edit, and print.
You get out of the course what you put into it - you could skate by on the assignments, or you could create something that you're proud of.
really fun class. Fia is a character! Yes it's three hours, but they go by quite quickly.
descrip: This studio course introduces students to aesthetic and theoretical implications of digital photography. Studio emphasis is on mastering digital equipment and techniques, managing print quality, and generally becoming familiar with all aspects of the digital workspace. Popular media, found photographs, and the "life" of digital images will also be investigated. Slide lectures, readings and class discussions of student work in critique format will augment visual skills with critical and conceptual understandings of contemporary photography.

title: Subcultures
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Criticism and Theory - The Criticism Co-Op: On the History and Practice of Literary Criticism
descrip: How does the history of literary criticism have an impact upon the practice of criticism today? What are the enduring central questions that critics bring to their work and, indeed, what is the essence of that work? Our seminar immerses us in these issues. The course is designed for graduate students who would like to think deeply about their practice as critics and to explore the history of criticism as a resource for new writing.

title: Ends and Means: Issues in Composition
descrip: Composing for Shakuhachi. A hands-on workshop, co-taught by composer Barbara White and Shakuhachi Grand Master Riley Lee, Visiting Lecturer. We explore the syntax and performance of the traditional Zen repertoire, honkyoku. More recent compositions highlight the fluidity of the boundary between invention and execution, as well as the limitations of notation. Our focus is not so much on history or culture; instead, we jump right in to compose new works at Lee's invitation, working toward our final concert of new works. Arrangements, improvisations, collaborations, and technological ministrations welcome.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Frontiers of Materials Spectroscopy
reviews: I strongly encourage people who are doing research related to material spectroscopy to take up this course.
Personally, I'd suggest any beginning, mid-level or senior graduate student to sign-up for this course. This course has both the breadth and depth to engage everyone present in the class.

Take good notes, given the topic of the class, I think these are notes I will be referring to when I forget the details of a spectroscopic method.  Not only that, but I will have papers related to each spectroscopic method to reference.
This an excellent course for people wanting to develop an broad understanding of most of the spectroscopy tools available for material characterization.

This courses will improve you a lot and it is worth paying careful attention to it. You will learn how to read papers properly, write peer reviews, and make presentations. And overall you will get to know what is going on around the frontiers in the different lines of research.
descrip: This course introduces students to state-of-the-art techniques in spectroscopy and imaging of solid state systems. The topics covered provide theoretical and practical understanding of the primary materials spectroscopy tools, as well as a literature survey of current topics. Particular emphasis is placed on novel techniques such as nanoscale quantum sensing, probing 2D materials, spectroscopy of nanostructures, and new developments in surface-sensitive techniques.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
prereqs: ECO 362 and ECO 465.
descrip: This course will teach students about financial risk management through the lens of the recent financial crisis. Topics covered will include market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk, and systemic risk. Students will draw on their background in economics, finance, probability theory and statistics. The class will be in seminar format and active participation in the discussion is encouraged.

title: Molecular Basis of Cancer
reviews: Good class!
Highly encouraged to take it if at all interested in cancer biology or the bridge between research and treatment.

I loved this class. I'm interested in cancer research, so this was perfect to get a complete overview of what is happening right now in the field. It was really cool to hear from a leading expert and also from guest lectures.
Take it if you're interested in the subject. But be prepared to read some papers.
Take it! Easy, especially, to balance with a difficult senior spring. You learn a lot about specified subject matter!
Take this course before you graduate if you are MOL!!!!
This class gives you the freedom to comprehensively explore the cancer research field. Although some papers may be challenging, Prof. Kang does a great job of providing background information.
This is a great MOL course. You definitely learn how to read and interpret journal articles well. It is a chill course with a low workload.

This is a great survey of cancer biology, from molecular mechanisms to clinical applications. If you are at all interested in cancer research, this is a great class to take. You will definitely need a background in molecular biology, but that's true of any upper division MOL course. This is mostly a basic science course, so if you are looking for a clinical or epidemiological focus, this isn't a good course for you.
descrip: We will explore the molecular events leading to the onset and progression of human cancer. We will review the central genetic and biochemical elements that make up the cell cycle, followed by a survey of the signal transduction pathways and checkpoints that regulate it. We will discuss oncogenes, tumor suppressor and mutator genes that act in these pathways and review the role of viral oncogenes and their action on cells. We will investigate the role of cancer stem cells and the interaction between tumor and the host environment. We will explore specific clinical case studies in light of the molecular events underlying different cancers.

title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish
reviews: A good equivalent to 108
Alright class, not too hard, probably at the Friend Center
DO EVERYTHING YOU CAN TO GET JEANIE BYRNE! She is honestly a great professor and she is willing to work with you.
Do the homework that is assigned, it will help you.

For any student that wishes to take this class, I advise that they be prepared to stay focused and consistent in their studies. This means not only coming to class on time, but also practicing your speaking as much as possible to better grasp Spanish. One should always try to keep their head in the game by not just learning the individual concepts in grammar and vocabulary. They should also practice the language in many ways from reading to writing to speaking if they truly want to succeed in this class. It will also help a student get the most out of the class in terms of learning new ideas.
Get Marcia or Adriana if you can! Be prepared to work hard but have fun at the same time.
Get Ms.Byrne. You will learn but she is so helpful. She wants you to enjoy it.
Give yourself enough time to study before exams.
Go to class and participate. If you're being forced to take this class, might as well do your best to learn the language anyway.
I would advise another student taking this course to practice speaking Spanish outside of class with their friends and to be comfortable asking questions to the teacher in class.

I would suggest speaking the language outside of class and using the vocabulary and grammar you just learned. I would start up a conversation with one of your friends who can speak the language. Write personal journal entries in Spanish to improve your writing. Lastly, go to your professor's office hours.
If you like Spanish and didn't do AP in high school, you should take this course.
Make sure to participate in class and take time with the written work.
Make sure to practice Spanish at any opportunity because the more you hear and experience the language, the better you will do in this class.
N/A
Not to be feared; just a typical step up in the Princeton Spanish program. Engage in class to get the most out of it!
Participate in the class. You need to participate to adapt and become a better student
Participate!
Practice your Spanish everyday. Also, try to get in the habit of reading or watching/listening to Spanish television and music.
Put a lot of emphasis on the first draft of your compositions. They are worth a lot of points and hard to do well on/catch your own grammar mistakes unless you really review it well.
SPA 107 is a nice continuation of the Spanish sequence and is an engaging and well organized class.
SPA107 was a good time and I learned a lot of spanish

Stay on top of each homework as you progress and really speak as much as possible throughout class and outside of class - the curriculum is designed to improve your skills through immersion but this only works if you apply yourself to the work. It makes the work much more fun and useful and productive if you engage in the course and see it as more than a requirement, but a chance to engage with Spanish culture.

Stay on top of the work and work daily for this class for at least half an hour. Otherwise,  you will stay significantly behind and suffer a lot. Better assignments than SPA103, but still significant amount of commitment required. Try to participate in class as much as possible as it helps both your grade and your speaking skills
Stay on top of your work every day, which is lat most 20 minutes a day and this course won't be a big time commitment at all. I can recommend Malia.
Take it Manuel Malia if you can. He's awesome and really chill about deadlines.
Take the class but be ready for busy work--pretty easy. But keep your grades up cause it's really easy to slip.
Take this class. You learn a lot of Spanish and it isn't very difficult.
Take this course with Lorena. She is very helpful, and make sure to see her if you need help with any grammar structures.
Take this course with Paloma or Manuel for sure. It's easier than 103 and the work is more straightforward. Overall not bad, the tests are hard but it's not much work outside of class.
Take time to write and revise your written works
Take with Paloma

This class helped me to improve dramatically as a student learning Spanish - it filled in the gaps between just learning vocab and grammar, and helped me to understand and speak/write more naturally. Professor Paloma is incredible - definitely try to get her!
This class is required for the completion of the foreign language requirement in Spanish. Made engaging by professor.
This course is a lot of fun and not too challenging. Stay on top of the homework every night and you'll be fine. The written work is graded fairly harshly, however, the exams are graded easily.
This course is required... but its definitely tolerable so thats nice.  Lorena is a fair teacher.

This course lies right in the middle of learning a language and submersing oneself in a language. As someone who did not feel compelled to do the latter, I was unenthusiastic at many points. If you would like to though, it is a very good course.
This is a good course to finish off the Spanish language requirement. Make sure to practice the grammar on your own because not much is discussed in class.

This is a great course. It got me up everyday. 
Worth taking especially because it also fulfills a distribution requirement.
Try to speak more and volunteer; this really helps with level of comfort in another language. Mistakes are alright; it does not have to be perfect.
Very intensive!
Very well organized and very fair. Everything you need to do is clearly laid out for you on Blackboard. If you can, get Manuel Malia as your professor. He's the man.
You probably have to take this for a distribution requirement, but it was enjoyable and not too difficult.
You'll love it. If you have Lorena, be prepared to do more than the other sections because she's the coordinator, but I definitely feel due to all the extra work, my Spanish is much better for it.
a
its fine, if you are just trying to finish your requirement like i was and took spanish in high school this is a good way to go
learned a lot, great class
none. You have to take it if you're fulfilling the requirement.
you are probably taking this class because you have to, but its fun.
prereqs: SPA 102 or SPA 103..
descrip: An intermediate/advanced language course that continues and reviews the introductory level Spanish, while further developing students' communication skills through communicative activities inside and outside of the classroom, as well as various types of materials, both audiovisual and written. Goal will be to improve the Spanish skills acquired in previous courses and students' abilities to develop and express more complex ideas in Spanish both orally and in writing. By the end of the course, students should have a command of the four basic language skills: listening comprehension, speaking, reading and writing.

title: History and the Body
reviews: Do the readings and participate!

If you are willing to put in the time ? on the readings (complex but fascinating) and the critical response writing ? then you should definitely take GSS 394. It's far and away one of the best seminars I've been in at Princeton.
TAKE THIS CLASS! The material is super interesting and relevant, and really teaches you a new way of thinking about the body. Kunzel is FANTASTIC.
TAKE!!
Take this class!!!! Amazing seminar- so interesting.
Take this course! It was one of the best I've taken and it honestly has changed my world view more than any other seminar I've participated in at Princeton!
Take this course. Kunzel is incredible, the readings are engaging and the subject is applicable to any discipline.
This class is excellent! It made me think in totally new ways. The reading is very good and mostly manageable, Professor Kunzel is an amazing professor, and I can't recommend this class enough!
This class really changed the way I think about many big topics -- race, gender, disability.  I highly recommend it.
descrip: This course introduces students to new scholarship on the history of the body and the shifting political and cultural contests over understandings of the "natural" or "normal" body. Through readings in gender and sexuality studies, history, and disability studies, as well as autobiography, film, and other primary sources, we will explore changes in the ways in which human bodies have been conceived and represented, and will consider the work of historians and cultural theorists who move further to historicize the lived experience of the human body.

title: Beginning Workshop in Musical Composition
reviews: As long as you're not dead-set on getting an A, the course is a lot of fun. You have a lot of opportunity to compose a wide variety of songs, and explore a lot of interesting (and often weird) music in class.

Awesome class. I had no prior experience composing, and I gained so much from this class and loved it. That being said, I PDFed it at the last second because I realized I had no idea what type of grade I'd be getting. I put in a lot of work, and I'm still extremely happy I took it- this was my fun class, and the only class I have taken thus far in the music department.
Definitely take it. It will be a little bit of work, but it's a great PDF class. You get out of it what you put in.

If you are a MUS major or plan to be one, I would definitely recommend this course. Many peers of mine who are more inclined to MUS loved the course. If you are less inclined like me, be prepared to spend more time than you might think. Still, it is a fun way to learn about musical composition.
If you have any interest in writing your own music, this is a great, rather light yet rewarding course. Be aware that you will also be doing a lot of performing of your own pieces!
If you want to be opened to a lot of different styles of music, this is an interesting way to do it.

Juri and Noah really put in a lot of energy to show you how to write new, often strange songs. Let them push you. If you get stuck behind the piano for 12 hours in what seems like an endless compositional frenzy, that's a good thing.

Many people might disagree, but I'd say don't take this class unless you have prior music theory / composition background or are willing to PDF the class. Oh, and make sure you really can play instruments well - I felt limited while composing by my own skill level in piano / violin. Assignments would likely take more time than expected, and too many non-beginners (people who've had a fair amount of composition   theory exposure) take this class for it to really feel like a beginner's class. I for one definitely kept feeling like a failure almost the entirety of the course.
TAKE!!!!! Very lightweight, but only take if you're already OK at composing and want to improve.

This course is great if you're looking to stretch your musical expertise and write some cool music. You learn a lot from Juri's teaching and feedback, as well as from listening to your classmates' compositions. Lots of fun if you're willing to put in the time and passion composition requires.
Whatever musical background you are coming from, you will certainly find yourself in a comfortable position taking this course.
prereqs: Ability to play musical instrument(s), ability to read musical notation, no composition background is necessary..
descrip: We will develop some basic chops needed to create an original piece of music. Short weekly assignments focus on limited ranges of musical parameter (ex. writing chord progression, writing rhythms only). Students will compose, perform, and discuss their own works.

title: Topics in Architecture: Colonial Cities
reviews: I highly recommend this course if it's offered again! There is a lot of reading but it is very worth it!
descrip: This seminar examines colonial urbanism from a comparative perspective. The focus is on the long nineteenth century, an era coined as "the connected world of empires," and the goal is to open a window to understanding colonialism. The case studies are drawn from colonial cities of European empires, as well as the idiosyncratic Ottoman practices. A comprehensive study of examples ranging from Algiers to Damascus, Calcutta, and Hanoi reveals a spectrum of experiments, each raising different sets of issues in the relationship between colonial policies and built forms.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Latino Global Cities
reviews: A great course for someone really interested in learning about a culture/topic in depth and improving their language skills.

Don't take this course. The trip to Puerto Rico may seem appealing but the professors are insufferable, unprofessional, unintellectual, and self-indulgent. Ridiculous amount of reading per class that must be completed because of daily quizzes, ridiculous expectations of free time to devote both to the PR trip as well as the mandatory "field research" on your own time and dime to NYC, and arbitrarily long papers (16 pages and 20  pages). You will spend so much time on this class and yet you will not learn anything. Seriously, you will not learn a thing. They only talk about what they feel like discussing and there is no theme or content to the class discussions. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE I WARN YOU. YOU WILL REGRET IT WHOLE HEARTEDLY. I WISH SOMEONE HAD WARNED ME.

I would never advise another student to take this course. The amount of work is truly excessive. I have spent more time on this course than all of my others COMBINED. This class is also taught from an extremely liberal slant, and I felt as if there was no room for disagreement within the classroom, so I was not comfortable voicing my true opinions.

Make sure to read the readings, participate in class, and do well on the quizzes. Have fun! Arcadio and German are jewels. We're blessed to have them. Mauricio and Diego are also amazing grad students for the course.
Read and enjoy while you can.

Set aside lots of time for the reading and papers. Be sure to talk to the professors about your ideas for your papers--they are very helpful and provide great sources and potential add-ons to your initial ideas.
TAKE THIS!
Take it for the trip and the amazing professors, but be ready to devote more time to this class than any of your others! Don't take anything like it as a 5th.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission. This course is primarily open to freshmen and sophomores who are considering the pursuit of studies in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese Languages and Cultures. Applicants must submit a one-page motivation letter to Prof. German Labrador Mendez (labrador@princeton.edu) and a selection of students will be contacted for an interview. Early applications encouraged. Final candidates will receive notification before December 10th. Preference will be given to potential concentrators..
descrip: This seminar focuses on the comparative study of Latino urban cultures in U.S., Caribbean and Spanish cities (mainly New York City, San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Madrid). Topics include the 2008 Financial Crisis, Occupy-like movements, global migratory flows, popular culture, memory, debt, visuality and citizenship. Paying close attention to their political and cultural contexts, flamenco, hip-hop, graffiti, visual culture, poetry, documentary films and political performances will be analyzed. Guest speakers and musicians will be part of the conversation.

title: The Cognitive Neuroscience of Selective Attention
reviews: Don't hesitate to ask questions and stay engaged. Tim will respond well and never dismisses questions or curiosity.
Take if you like neuro!
Take it if you're interested in neuroscience and attention, and have a background in Neuro. Otherwise you might be lost.
Take it! It will help you better understand how a subfield of neuroscience came about and how actual research is done.

Take this class. The work load is not too bad and the subject matter is incredibly interesting. Prof. Buschman also does a great job of explaining the material and showing all the ways in which it is interesting. Everyone seemed to really like the demos and asked a lot of questions during lecture, that Prof. Buschman was always happy to answer.
Take this course with a previous background in neuroscience so you can ask detailed, pointed questions.
prereqs: An introductory neuroscience course such as PSY/NEU 258, or PSY/NEU 259, or equivalent knowledge. In other words, students should have a working understanding of neurons, networks, and general brain anatomy and function..
descrip: Attention is our ability to select information relevant to behavior. This is a fundamental component of cognition, as it allows us to focus our limited cognitive/neural resources on those stimuli and thoughts that are critical to our current task. This course will review the neuroscience of selective attention, from the theoretical foundations provided by cognitive psychology to the neural underpinnings identified by systems neuroscience. The course will present a `hands on' science experience by drawing on current research topics and focussing on the design and analyses of real experiments in the attention field.

title: Staging Identity: Strategies for Surviving the American Stage
reviews: Amazing class!
To any other students taking this course, I would advise coming to class with specific questions as it helps guide conversation and you get more out of it. What you will be reading isn't easy stuff.
prereqs: Enrollment priority will be given to members of the American Studies Program, the Program in Latino Studies, and the Program in Theater..
descrip: This course maps some benefits and perils of theater made for, by, or about people of color in the United States. We will investigate the difficult-to-theorize and contested space between politics and artistic craft. We will read both play scripts and critical essays, using each to illuminate and complicate the other. Some of the pairings purposefully cross categories of identity, genre or historic periods. We aim to shake loose some of these texts from identity-based or genre-specific readings and glean from them strategies for making theater and surviving.

title: Drawing
reviews: Do not take this to grow your portfolio, but take this to genuinely enjoy and appreciate art, no pressure - all that is expected of you is that you care and you try new things. This course allows you to grow as an artist personally in artistic thinking, if not as an artist technically.
Do not worry if you are not good at drawing -- still take this course, as you will not regret it!
Fun course to take to get out of the usual routine. Nathan doesn't constrict creativity at all, but if you're in his section don't expect to get to much traditional art instruction

I really liked the course; it was a great time to just concentrate on drawing and nothing else. It could be tiring after a couple hours, and it would have been nice to have some more input from the professor. He didn't really give advice/feedback on people's work, which was fine if all you want to do is draw.
If you like drawing. You should definitely take it.
Nathan is great if you want freedom to make what you'd like  in the studio, but don't expect a technical drawing  education. That said, I loved the course and would 100% recommend.
People generally say to take this class with Nathan. I had Kurt, so I can't say anything for Nathan's teaching. But Kurt seemed like he'd rather be anywhere else.
TAKE IT !!!!!! Choose Professor Nathan Carter if you want to have tons of fun and no homework.
TAKE IT! Great class if you are interested in art regardless of whether or not you are good at it.
Take it if you can! It's fun
Take it! Biggish time commitment class wise but it's fine
Take this class. It's a huge time commitment, but it's also very rewarding.
Take this course if you want to learn how to better your skills in drawing the human figure!

Take this course with Nathan, he is amazing! Nathan does a really good job in trying to make you think like an artist. The classes are long, but very relaxed, and we only had 2 assignments throughout the semester. I found it really enjoyable to go to the studio after my otherwise stressful schedule. If you have the slightest interest in drawing, (even if you don't think you're good at it) you should take this class!

The nature of the course varies widely depending on whom you take it with. Profs Ascheim and Carter are more experimental while Kauper does a traditional style. The last 6 weeks are figure drawing. Would recommend! Classes are long but you don't notice the time passing.
This course was a good opportunity to get away from the more academic side of school. However, it is a large time commitment.

This is a great course.  It teaches you foundational principles of drawing in the context of larger projects like drawing the human figure.  Kurt's comments and instructions are very helpful.  I would recommend taking his advice seriously if you want to improve, and giving the homework a lot of focus and effort if you want to get an A.  Warning: The entire second semester you'll be working with nude models, so be prepared for that!
This was a fantastic class. Nathan is a wonderful teacher. A very relaxed and supportive environment.
Very fun and relaxing - take it!

take it!!! Nathan is so awesome- we didn't do much technical drawing practice, so I'm not sure if my drawing skills are necessarily much better- but the class was such a joy and we did so many fun projects. Also no homework!!
descrip: This course approaches drawing as a way of thinking and seeing. Students will be introduced to a range of drawing issues, as well as a variety of media, including charcoal, graphite, ink, oil stick, collage, string, wire and clay. Subject matter includes still life, the figure, landscape and architecture. Representation, abstraction and working from imagination will be explored. A structured independent project will be completed at the end of the term.

title: Senior Project
descrip: The senior project is a year-long independent study intended for students who choose to work in teams of two or more. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in the spring term when a double grade is awarded. Groups develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Groups develop a work plan and select an adviser and are assigned a second reader for their work. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Groups submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Psychology of Language
reviews: Amazing! The lectures are very interesting and engaging, the work is minimal and not difficult, and the content is very eye-opening and intriguing. Would DEFINITELY recommend to fill an EC requirement or take as an easy fifth class. Goldberg is an amazing and passionate professor and this is a must have class.
Definitely take it. I really enjoyed the entire class! Really interesting and you'll learn so much about the way that we speak.
Do not take this course if you are interested in psychology.  It is 90% linguistics and 10% psychology
Don't take it unless you have a lot of previous experience. You're not bound to learn anything and you'll just end up annoyed.

Don't take this unless you are genuinely very interested in linguistics. She assumes that you know a great deal about linguistics and does not do a great job explaining key terms, which leaves people very lost. There was little structure to the class and homework's and exams were pretty difficult. Most of the time I was pretty confused. However, I know people in the class who were really into language and linguistics and I think they really enjoyed the class.
Great course if you are interested in linguistics!
Have to make sure you're really interested in language and linguistics before taking this class. It's focus, I thought, was more on the linguistics aspect than the psychology.

I can't really recommend it unless you think you'd be really interested. Otherwise, you might be pretty bored. But the homeworks are easy (when the questions make sense), and there's not too much expected of you, which makes it a fine EC if that's what you're looking for.
If you are looking for a psychology-minded course I would not really recommend the course.

If you really like the material, sure. If not, probably skip this one. No precept or lab can be nice, but Professor Goldberg isn't very clear or understanding. The textbook is fine but assessments are often on the muddled lecture info so if you do take the class, go.

Lectures were alright overall, but seemed disorganized sometimes.  We would sometimes skip up to 4 slides in a row because Prof Goldberg realized in the middle of lecture that "it didn't matter" or "we'll come back to this" - a lot of the times we did not actually "come back to it."  Overall I enjoyed the course though and the material was interesting enough and for the most part presented in an understandable manner.  Prof was enthusiastic about the material so it made up for the lack of preparation at times.
Long and boring classes, way more linguistics than psych if you are a psych major
Professor Goldberg is amazing!! Definitely take this class if the topic interests you at all, and she'll show you why everything is so fascinating.
Read the book, go to lecture, and talk to prof. Goldberg, she is an amazing person.
TAKE THIS COURSE! Easily the best class at Princeton!
Take it if you are interested in language. Goldberg is a very nice instructor
Take it if you're at all interested in language!!! Professor Goldberg is so kind and interesting and caring.
Take it! It's a great course!
Take it. Do the readings because they're interesting, though you don't have to do them in advance of lectures. A must take class.
Take it. Pay attention in class. You learn cool stuff. But don't underestimate.
Take this course if you're interested in language. It feels less like a psychology course and more like a linguistics course

This course is interesting subject matter, but it definitely helps if you have taken linguistics in the past. Prof. Goldberg will say you don't need this linguistic knowledge, but you may sit in lecture not knowing what is happening otherwise.
This is a great class. Work load is not much at all, but you definitely get what you put into it.
take it!!

the readings are really helpful. try to pay attention in class and actually get something out of the course, because there are so many cool facts about language that apply to everyday life but I never knew before
descrip: The cognitive processes underlying the use and understanding of language, and in learning to speak. Topics include speech production and perception, grammar and meaning, knowledge and words, and pragmatic aspects of language.

title: Slavery, Gender & Religious Difference in Islamic Societies
reviews: Be aware that there is a LOT of reading. Like, a LOT.

I really learned a lot in this course, and so I am really happy I took it. Professor Marmon is really dedicated to making sure you have a great experience and thinks critically about how to improve her teaching and your classroom experience, which I really admire. Take the course!

I would highly recommend taking this class if you have an interest in learning about the many different aspects and forms of Islamic slavery throughout its history, or if you wish to be able to think about the modern attempts by ISIS at a revival of slavery in a culturally and historically informed manner.

If you have any interest in the subject or want to explore something in depth that you may not have been exposed to before, I would take this course! The readings are very enlightening and can prompt good discussions and questions, and I recommend it highly.

This class is amazing - I learned so much and Professor Marmon was great with understanding due dates for papers and keeping readings short. It is once a week, but it keeps you thinking throughout the week.
You will learn a LOT about a topic that is not discussed very often; wholeheartedly recommend.
descrip: In 2014, ISIS distributed a pamphlet of authoritative responses (fatwas), based in Classical Islamic law, to questions about the enslavement and sexual exploitation of non-Muslim women and girls. This revival of slavery shocked the Muslim world and led to questions about the history of slavery and "concubinage" in Islam. We will address some of those questions through close reading of texts in translation and modern scholarship. What is the history of slavery in Islamic law and practice? What role do sex and gender play in slavery, specifically in Islamic societies? How "Islamic" is slavery? We will also include a comparative perspective.

title: Computational Geophysics
reviews: Prepare to do your work and really understand the methods and how to implement them.  Sometimes writing the codes or getting them to run is a struggle, but the TA's are flexible and very helpful in getting the codes to run so you can move on to understanding and interpreting the results.

Strongly recommended for anyone with a interest in discrete computational methods for the wave/heat equation. Programming experience recommended or you'll have trouble switching between different languages.
This is a good class, but make sure you have a strong programming background and are comfortable in MATLAB, maybe C and are willing to learn FORTRAN.
prereqs: Courses in partial differential equations and multi-variable calculus; experience with a computer language and basic programming skills..
descrip: An introduction to weak numerical methods, in particular finite-element and spectral-element methods, used in computational geophysics. Basic surface & volume elements, representation of fields, quadrature, assembly, local versus global meshes, domain decomposition, time marching & stability, parallel implementation & message-passing, and load-balancing. In the context of parameter estimation and 'imaging', will explore data assimilation techniques and related adjoint methods. The course offers hands-on lab experience in meshing complicated surfaces & volumes as well as numerically solving partial differential equations relevant to geophysics

title: Mind, Body, and Bioethics in Japan and Beyond
reviews: Definitely take this course if you need an EM that is not too theoretical. Professor Borovoy chose a very interesting and engaging selection of readings and is just the right amount to not be overwhelming. Be sure to go to all the classes and participate in the discussion and you will be fine.
I would recommend taking the course.

Really amazing course. I'd never taken a bioethics class before, but every week the topic we talked about was so interesting I'd think about it throughout the week. Not a ton of work, just interesting reading and critical writing. Do the reading and be prepared to discuss in seminar!
Take another EAS class first.
Take it! Professor Borovoy is so nice!

This course is a really fascinating introduction into bioethics, with some anthropology and East Asian studies mixed in. The readings were interesting and not too heavy. However there is both a final paper and exam, so that is something to take into account.

This course is great if you have any interest in the following: japanese culture, bioethics as it relates sociology/anthropology/health policy, or fulfilling your EM. The reading is very manageable at around ~100pp / week. The work in the class is generally minimal, with a short midterm based on class material (take notes on discussions!) a short final in the same vein, one partnered presentation, and a short 7-10 page dean's date assignment. Note that this is a 300-level EAS seminar, so you are likely taking it with students who a good background in SOC/ANT/EAS if you don't, which makes grades (not the class itself) slightly more difficult.
prereqs: One course in East Asian Studies or one course in cultural anthropology preferred..
descrip: The seminar will examine key concepts of the mind, the body, and the nature-culture distinction. We will study these issues in the context of Japanese beliefs about the good society, making connections between "lay culture," Japanese notions of social democracy, and "science culture." Topics include: diagnosis and care of the mentally ill, the politics of disability, notions of human life and death, responses to bio-technology, the management of human materials such as organs, cultural definitions of addiction and co-dependency, and the ethics of human enhancement.

title: Music in the Middle Ages
reviews: Keep up with the readings, and go to every class! The classes are very enjoyable, and if you miss a class you will probably feel like you're falling a bit behind.
Take this class if you like music

Take this course if you're interested in medieval music, but if you think you'll even be slightly bored you might not want to. Definitely a niche topic, but great if you're into this sort of thing (which I was). Be warned that this is NOT your easy class, you don't have to do a ton of work during the semester but the exams are REALLY difficult so you have to know your stuff.
This course is very history-based, so if you're looking for a theoretical understanding of medieval music this isn't the course.
Wegman grades very unreasonably. Do not take.
descrip: Introduction to some important musical repertories from before 1400 A.D.: Gregorian chant; the troubadour culture; the intellectual culture of music theory and the earliest polyphonic music. Among the problems and issues: how to recover the medieval roots of oral traditions that are still practiced today; how ancient and medieval concepts of tuning, mode, notation, form, and language continued to shape the history of music long after the Middle Ages.

title: Granada and the Fall of Spanish Islam, AD 1212-1492/1614
reviews: A true shame the University is getting rid of him...I would strongly recommend, but I guess you won't have the chance to study with this unbelievable professor.

As our grades for the course are heavily dependent on the midterm and final papers it is essential that students keep up with readings so that they do not have to search through dense texts when it comes time to write their papers.
Awesome course. Recommend to anyone interested in the fall of Spanish Islam.
Definitely take this course

Excellent course. Would definitely recommend to anyone wanting to understand not only the history of Spanish Islam and the time period but also to anyone interesting in understanding all of modern history, as Spain is the discovered of the New World and the founder of our age, this class serves to understand the rise of such empire and the historic context on which it was built upon. I definitely recommend this course to anyone!
Go to as many lectures as you can. They may seem long but they are richer than you ever couldve imagined.
Highly recommend.
I don't think it'll be offered again but if it is, take it with no hesitation and know that you will grow as a learner from this course
I would recommend this course to students who are more historically-inclined.
If it is offered, then I would recommend taking this course with Professor Barry.
It's a lot of learning on your own.
Love his class! Very clear :)
MUST TAKE A MB CLASS!
Maybe take it.
Michael Barry is a God among Men.
Michael Barry is an essential part of any Princeton education.
Prof. Barry is an incredible lecturer!

Professor Barry has a very deep love of whatever subject he teaches and cares a lot about the students' learning and understanding what he teaches. If you are interested in history, especially of Islamic Spain, take this class. The period of time being studied has had profound influences on world history. Spain in that period can almost be seen as a laboratory in which to study the interactions between different cultures, that shaped later events. Be warned, however, that this is a period full of bloody war although one must not forget the intellectual achievements of the period.

Professor Barry is an excellent lecturer and really knows his stuff. If you are interested in the subject, you should really attend his lectures because he goes into great detail into everything and really prepares you for the papers.
Professor Barry is great and the material is really interesting if you like Spanish history/religious studies!
Professor Barry is really a delight. What the University is doing is horrible. Its a shame no more Princeton students will be able to work with Prof. Barry.
Strongly recommend if Barry were still teaching it, but with a new professor, it will not be the same. I recommend taking the class if you truly have a passion for Spanish history.
Take if you love Professor Barry.
Take it
Take it without a second thought. Excellent course taught by a wonderful professor on a fascinating topic.
Take it!
Take it.
Take it. That is all. Barry is a god and this course will change the manner in which you look at the Abrahamic religions in the context of the present-day middle east.
Take the course.
Take this course if you ever get the chance. Michael Barry is the ideal professor
Take this course!
Take this course! Except you won't be able to, because this school takes perverse pleasure in finding and eliminating things that bring us joy.

Take this course! This course isn't graded as easily as anticipated, compared to what you hear. But Michael Barry is there to help you, and genuinely wants you to understand and appreciate the topics. Come to lecture, do some of the readings, and have a conversation or two in office hours. That's all it takes.
This is an excellent course for anyone who has an interest in Spanish Islam. It is a great history course as well.
This was one of my best courses at Princeton; must take! Barry is one of the best lecturers
Unfortunate that you can't take it anymore.
Wish Professor Barry wasn't leaving. Don't know if anyone else can teach the course like he did.
amazing
be a legend; be michael barry
descrip: Thirteenth-century Christian "Reconquista" of almost all of Spain after 1212 - with the significant exception of the sultanate of Granada - subjected huge minorities of Muslims and Jews to Christian overlords and challenged the rising kingdoms of Castile, Aragon and Portugal to cope with religious diversity. The course explores how the Christian kingdoms at first imitated and tried to implement Islamic precedents in tolerance but then how social strains spawned increasing sectarian intolerance, mass expulsions or forced conversions of Jews and Muslims, and finally creation of the religiously absolutist monarchies of Spain and Portugal.

title: Medieval Art in America
descrip: See website

title: African American Literature: Harlem Renaissance to Present
reviews: Definitely take the class!
Definitely take this class! Professor Nishikawa is outstanding and you'll never want to miss class.
Definitely take this course! Or any course with Prof. Nishikawa! Fun lectures with great readings!
Great reading list, but the participatory lecture format could be unproductive
I would encourage students to read and engage with the material presented in the course. I would also advise students to make use of Professor Nishikawa's office hours.
KEEP UP WITH READINGS: it is really hard to go into the final essay or the final exam without reading all of the books. They are so long that you cannot cram.
Keep up with the readings.

My primary reason for taking this class was to fulfill a requirement to get a certificate in AAS. However, I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in AAS or wants to take an excellent English course. It was literally a phenomenal course and the professor is so engaging and makes the lectures fun.
Prof. Nishikawa is one of the most engaged professors on campus. Highly recommended even for STEM majors.
Take it.
Take this course. Nishikawa is an amazing professor. You'll learn so much and have fun.
The professor is funny, prepared, and very knowledgeable. A must-take Princeton class

Would highly recommend this course for those both seasoned and newly arriving to the material. This course is also very approachable for those who have not yet taken an English course. Professor Nishikawa is an exceptionally engaging and thoroughly enjoyable instructor, facilitator, and person.
prepare to read a lto first half
descrip: A survey of twentieth- and twenty-first century African American literature, including the tradition's key aesthetic manifestos. Special attention to how modern African American literature is periodized and why certain innovations in genre and style emerged when they did. Poetry, essays, novels, popular fiction, a stage production or two, and related visual texts.

title: Sound Design
prereqs: Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: An opportunity to explore what theatrical sound design is, how to look at a text from the point of view of sound, how to launch your creative process, and how to take the ideas based on that creative process and turn them into sounds to be used in a show. Students will also learn how to communicate their ideas, palate, and the arc of their design in a way that demonstrates to directors how they will fulfull the director's vision while embracing their own artistry and response to the text.

title: European Social and Cultural History
descrip: A survey of recent scholarship in the social and cultural history of Early Modern Europe, ca. 1400-1800. Includes both classic topics like Renaissance and Reformation, and newer subjects like gender and the transnational.

title: Seminar in International Relations - International Organization
reviews: Definitely take it if you're at all interested in international organizations! I feel like it provides a good overview of the organizations as well as theories of international institutions. I definitely learned a lot and I enjoyed the class. Not too much work though the readings can be time-consuming, as can the final Dean's Date paper.

Definitely take this class if you're looking to learn more about international organizations and willing to work together with a great professor to understand why IOs are so important in a globalizing and interdependent world.
I really enjoyed this course! Professor Davis is great, and I thought that the material was really interesting. Take it if you're at all interested in international organizations.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in international policy, organization, and governance. Really excellent.
Interesting class. Prof. Davis is a great teacher.
Take this course if you are interested in how international institutions function in today's world.
This course discusses formal international organizations. Professor Davis is a nice and accessible professor. Readings are interesting. Somewhat redundant if you've already taken WWS 420.
prereqs: POL 240 or POL 381.
descrip: From peacekeeping operations, development assistance, to rules for free trade, the mandate for international organizations continues to expand. Why do states delegate authority, and what accounts for the change over time and issue in the role of international organizations to promote cooperation? The course will examine theories about the design and effectiveness of formal institutions and assess the record of specific organizations including the United Nations, World Trade Organization, and World Bank. This is an advanced seminar, and students should have completed POL 240 or POL 381 prior to enrollment.

title: Public Leadership and Public Policy in the U.S.
reviews: Awesome if you want to learn some recent American history
Definitely take if you would like to learn more about the ethical/moral factors surrounding the political decisions within the Vietnam War, Iraq War, Watergate, etc.
Gen. Nash and Dr. Scovornick are a good team - they complement each other nicely. The material is very interesting, and it will be worthwhile to take the course.
This class changed how I view leadership.
descrip: This course will review key Presidential decisions on domestic and foreign policy issues. It will examine the President's role as both chief executive and commander-in-chief, and will consider cases such as passage of the Voting Rights Act and the management of Hurricane Katrina, as well the interventions in Cuba, Vietnam and Iraq. It will consider the ethical, legal, and operational frameworks for effective, responsible public leadership. Students will review literature from history, psychology and politics, discuss the central policy issues in each case, and evaluate the decision-making process in view of these frameworks.

title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar
prereqs: This course is open only to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing guidance on planning and completing the dissertation and on other aspects of becoming a professional scholar and teacher, such as mastering the craft of the journal article (conceiving, writing and submitting), writing effective syllabi for different kinds of courses, and turning the dissertation into a book (with visits by editors from leading presses). The seminar meets every two weeks and is required of all post-generals students in residence, who will have the opportunity to present and discuss their work in progress.

title: Decoding Dress
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Small Masterpieces: Art of the Short Story in Latin America
prereqs: SPA 207 or 209, or instructor's permission..
descrip: Discover the great tradition of the short story in modern Latin American literature. A wide range of short stories will be available to read, analyze and debate from modern and contemporary writers. Students will be encouraged to investigate the internal structure of this genre through critical and theoretical essays, many written by the authors themselves. Readings included works by Jorge Luis Borges, Julio Cortazar, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Silvina Ocampo, Felisberto Hernandez, and Virgilio Pinera.

title: Political Economy Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Seminar in Pedagogy
descrip: Required weekly seminar for all English Department PhD students teaching for the first time at Princeton and scheduled to precept during the Spring 2016 semester. Balancing pedagogical theory with practical tips and collaborative discussion, the seminar helps students meet the challenges of their first semester in the classroom while also preparing them to lead their own courses. Topics include: integrated course design (preparing lesson plans; leading discussions; lecturing; teaching writing; assessment and grading); writing recommendations; and managing students, faculty, and time.

title: Religion and Ethical Theory
reviews: A lot of dense reading every week, seminar not very guided, highly dependent on others in the class

Best course I've taken so far. Prof. Stout is amazing. He really cares about helping you to become a better student and a better person. Most of the readings, although difficult and time-consuming, were fantastic. Some of them probably changed my life. Be prepared for intense discussions, and work hard on the papers. Basically, if this class is offered again, take it!
Definitely take this course if you are interested in ethics and thinking deeply about what a meaningful like entails.

If you want to think about what makes a life a good life, then take this class. You will have to do a lot of reading and mental work to keep up, but it is very doable, as the work is profitable. Read everything carefully. Do not just make "precept comments," this class is too worth your time to do that.

Stout is a terrific, careful thinker, and also one of the genuinely kindest professors I've had at Princeton. The readings and discussions span the gamut in terms of approaches to ethics, which can be frustrating at times.
Take courses that scare and challenge you. Its worth it!
This is a great course. Just be prepared for a lot of work and tough thinking. I highly reccommend it for those who are genuinely engaged in the subject matter.
descrip: This seminar will examine philosophical accounts of what it means to live well, focusing mainly on works written in the last half century that are relevant to issues in religious ethics: whether morality requires a religious foundation, the ethical significance of divine commandments, and the concepts of virtue, goodness, evil, horror, holiness, sainthood, faith, and the sacred. Among the philosophers to be discussed are Richard Rorty, Elizabeth Anscombe, Alasdair MacIntyre, Iris Murdoch, Stanley Cavell, and Robert Merrihew Adams.

title: Improbable Journeys: Travel in Time and Space in American Science Fiction
descrip: See website

title: The Ethnographer's Craft
reviews: Coyle is amazing.
Go to lab

If you have to take this class as an anthro major, then it isn't bad at all. The readings are interesting and Professor Coyle is lovely. The classes themselves are not all that interesting. If you are looking to try an anthro class, I think there are other ones that go deeper into material and provide more interesting engagement.
It's an interesting course if you like ethnography/anthropology.
Only take this course if you are an ANT major or receiving a certificate in ethnographic studies.  If you're looking to try out an anthro class, take a non-deparmental!
Take it with Lauren if you can! She's great at discussing and addressing all the issues anthropology has both past and present. The readings are super interesting and it's not a ton of work.
Take this! Coyle is amazing
prereqs: For administrative reasons, there are two ways of enrolling in ANT 301A/B. ANT 301A is for all students other than juniors in the Anthropology major. ANT 301B is reserved for juniors in the Anthropology major, as it includes enrollment in the Junior Seminar (the ANT 301B "Lab" section). ANT 301A and B are otherwise the same, and meet together..
descrip: What are the core approaches of the anthropological method, as well as the distinctive forms of knowledge that they offer? How has ethnography emerged within a broader universe of social scientific approaches? We examine classical methods, their itineraries in multiple ethnographic domains, and their afterlives in the plurality of contemporary anthropology. We examine these techniques with careful attention to their social, political, and ethical dimensions. In so doing, we work to understand the perils and the great revelatory power of ethnography, including the many counterintuitive and creative insights it can offer into our own worlds.

title: Ambition
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: 19th-Century Art - Manet and the Methods of Art History
descrip: Seminar focuses on the art of Edouard Manet, often hailed as the originator of modernist painting, and on the range of methodological perspectives brought to bear on his work, from Marxist to psychoanalytic, formalist to feminist, and beyond. We investigate those different approaches and their relationship to each other, as well as their adequacy and inadequacy to the art they try to understand. Repeated and close looking at Manet's paintings are at the heart of the seminar. Course includes guest speakers and class trips to museums.

title: Energy for a Greenhouse-Constrained World
prereqs: Freshman physics and prior coursework in thermodynamics are required. Students from any department are welcome in the course. Graduate students are welcome..
descrip: Overview of technology challenges and opportunities for energy in the context of global warming. Physics of greenhouse warming, projected climate changes, and structure of US and global energy economy are reviewed. Majority of lectures emphasize understanding engineering and economics of low-carbon energy production systems, including solar, wind, nuclear fission, and capture/storage of fossil-fuel carbon. Energy storage and efficient energy use are also considered. Intersections of energy with economic development, international security, local environmental quality, and human behavior are also touched upon.

title: Elementary Chinese II
reviews: A lot of work, but rewarding if you stick with it.
Absolutely excellent! The Chinese program at Princeton is outstanding
An excellent introduction to conversational Mandarin.
