Awesome, amazing teachers, stimulating, made class fun, encouraged participation, covered all course material, always very helpful, lots of work but totally worthwhile if you want to learn Chinese - best dept. at Princeton!
Be prepared to work hard, but it is worth it.

Be ready to put in lots of time, but also realize that although the pace is faster, you can find a routine and become very efficient in retaining the material. I would say that this is one of the best-taught language courses at Princeton.
Chinese is not extremely hard, but it requires a very consistent commitment throughout the semester. Learn the characters very well for dictation so that you know them for the test.
Chinese is very time consuming especially getting the hang of the tones; however, the department is amazing. If you're looking for an easy language don't take this.
Definitely take Chinese! It is the best department at Princeton, and will help you become fluent in a very currently-relevant language
I mean, if you're looking at this course you probably already took CHI 101, and thus have no choice but to take this. So YOLO swag bro, nothin you can do lol

I strongly recommend this course for anyone interested in taking a language at Princeton, especially if you're interested in East Asia. The Chinese department at Princeton is incredible; it's like no other language class I've taken. By the end of 101, I could speak a little with native Chinese speakers, and they were complimenting me on my tones and pronunciation!  You can expect a fair amount of work for this course, but not too much (it's very similar to 101 - just a continuation, really).  Weekly recitation/dictation class on Fridays, recordings due Wednesdays, homework due Fridays by noon, and chapter tests on Monday. 102 does more a little more quickly than 101 (some weeks we to 1.5-2 chapters), but it's not overwhelming. If you prepare a little every day, you'll do well (and pay attention in class/do your best to participate!). The sentence structures are very applicable, and the vocabulary each chapter is very relevant to life on campus. I also recommend going to Chinese table (I went to the non-first year tables and was fine, so this class really prepares you well!). Finally, I had Lv Laoshi as my preceptor, and he was excellent. Always took an interest in my progress, not to mention he's a pretty quirky/personable guy who's easy to get along with. 10/10 for this class :)

If you're going to take any language at Princeton, let Chinese be the one. Chinese is where it's at if you're looking to actually be able to speak another language. No other language department gets as great of a community of students who all become friends. Taking this as a sophomore, I wish I'd taken it as a freshman, but it's phenomenal even as a sophomore.

It's going to be a challenge, yo.  Don't get me wrong.  But if you want to be able to speak a dope language pretty well within a year's time, this is the class for you, yo.  You get out what you put in, yo.
Learning Chinese at Princeton is great fun. Probably more work than other languages, but worth it!
Make sure to use the weekly study guide and the course is lots of work but worth it
Make sure you do your work on time. Don't get behind.

No where else will you be able to learn chinese so well and quickly. Also, the teachers are all incredible and really funny people outside of class. They make class enjoyable and fun, while also teaching the course incredibly well!
TAKE IT! Taking Chinese has been one of the best decisions I made this year and it'll be so much fun. Keep up with the characters and read the passages before class and you'll do fine :)
Take if you are ready to work a lot. There is no time to relax in this class. But it's fun and effective.

Take it if you really want to learn Chinese. The teachers are extremely helpful and your Chinese will improve dramatically. However, keep in mind that this class requires a LOT of time commitment but it is worth it!
Take it if you want to. Know that if you decide to stick with it, it is extremely rewarding and interesting. That being said, if you're not ready for a ton of work, this class is not for you.
Take this course. The teachers are exceptionally talented and engaging and funny. Chinese has has been my favorite course and I don't think I've enjoyed learning anything else this much in my life.

The Chinese teachers and department are absolutely amazing. There is quite a lot of weekly homework though it's not terrible, and if you stay on top of the work then you will come away with an excellent working knowledge of Chinese.
This class will do a great job teaching you Chinese, but there's a trade-off: the class is very intense and will take a reasonable time commitment.
Work consistently; put in a little bit of time every day and you'll be fine.  Don't leave things to the last minute or you won't learn.
You need to keep up with each reading and each week's vocab. Start memorizing recitations early.

You will definitely have to spend a lot of time on this course, but if you take it because you want to learn Chinese or just because you love learning language, you will definitely enjoy the class even though it is tough and very time consuming.
it's a great course, very time consuming but not hard.
prereqs: CHI 101 or permission of the Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of Chinese 101. To develop basic competence in understanding, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese.

title: Intermediate Persian II
reviews: Anyone who can take Persian at any point at Princeton with Amineh Khanom, definitely should!

If you've gotten to this point, you know that Amineh is a fantastic instructor. Her teaching gets even better as you continue with her, and this course will leave you with a much greater capacity for understanding Persian on every level.
TAKE THIS COURSE WITH PROFESSOR MAHALLATI. Take if you want to start a new language; Persian is very easy to learn and much easier than Hebrew or Arabic.
Take this!
prereqs: PER 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: The emphasis is on reading modern and classical prose, and writing modern prose. Classes are conducted mostly in Persian. Advanced grammar drills and translation exercises.

title: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship - Venture Capital Enabling Innovation
reviews: Almost no work, good class to take but do not expect to be interested in what happens during class.
Amazing class. Take it for sure.
Amazing course, really broadens your horizon and workload is not bad at all. Guest speakers also offer a diverse range of insights and are very interesting.

As attendance is taken in lecture it is of the utmost necessity that students attend all lectures. I, myself, had to miss a number of lectures due to sports-related travel and feel as if this might have hurt me. If a student is to miss a lecture it is very important that they do all that they can to ensure that they retain what was presented. Professor Hejazi makes this very doable as lecture notes are posted on Blackboard.
Consider it.
Definitely recommend this course if you are interesting in venture capital and hearing from industry gurus. Watch out for your group assignment... it can be extremely frustrating.
Do the assignments to improve your skills in evaluating startups.

Dope class! Really interesting speakers and you get a great knowledge of the VC space. The end gets a bit more boring because it gets a bit repetitive at the end, but the rest of the class makes it so worth it. Shahram is a boss!
Easy class for the most part. Prepare to spend a decent amount of time working in groups. Also make sure the group work is shared evenly.
Highly recommend. Amazing guest speakers, interesting subject, not difficult grading.

I would strongly recommend taking this course as long as you have even the slightest interest in entrepreneurship, venture capital, or finance, because this course will really help flesh out your opinions of, and interest in, the subject.
It's a good course if you are interested in start-ups and VC's.

It's a great opportunity to hear from VCs with very different backgrounds and approaches. The class also helped improve my ability to evaluate companies and provided good insights into entrepreneurship. Assuming you're okay with Friday class, it's definitely worth taking if you want to pursue a career in venture capital and also valuable it you're more generally interested in startups.
Shahram is awesome and the speakers are interesting. Take it
TAKE IT!
TAKE! It is a phenomenal course with amazing guest lecturers. The course-load is light but very interesting. The professor is awesome and his fund is very unique.
Take it if you are interested in VC; the class is very interesting.

Take it if you can handle 3 hour lectures on Friday afternoon. Shahram is an interesting guy and there wasn't much work. The final project is pretty cool and all assignments are in groups. Go to office hours if you have questions
Take it! Really interesting opportunity to hear from top VCs and learn about the industry, and the class isn't a lot of work.
Take it. Super easy and you learn a ton from all the guest speakers

Take this course if you are at all interested in venture capital or entrepreneurship. The professor makes concepts fairly simple such that you leave the class familiar with key terms. The professor works hard to invite very amazing guest speakers; I would not miss the speakers.
Take this course. You will learn so much and the workload is very manageable.  The guest speakers are fantastic
Teaches you a lot at first but then becomes monotonous

The best part about this class is the speakers. Every class is 90 minutes with a real VC (because Hejazi knows a lot of people in the industry). Hearing from these incredibly experienced investors makes you feel like you can truly access venture capital
The quality of the guest speakers each week (leading VCs from around the country) and professor Hejazi's deep, first-hand knowledge of the industry made this an incredibly interesting class.
This is a great class to take if you're interested in entrepreneurship or venture capital.

Very good, stress-less course. I learned the basics of Venture Capital, but due to the specifics of the industry, didn't get to actually practice how it's normally done. It would help for the course to have more focus on the different stages (early-stage, late-stage), and demonstrate the different types of diligence each stage does.
Would recommend to anyone interested in VC

great guest lecturers; professor tends to read off slides but is very open to talking about htings more in-depth and providing examples during class. engaging. assignments are pretty basic. you get substantially more than you put in but I think you need to put in a bit.
take it! very little work, not too difficult, and you actually learn a good amount! I liked that the class had technical focus, like learning terminology and how to do calculations.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: Early stage investors not only fund startups but also enable innovation through mentorship and partnership with the entrepreneurs. Understanding how these investors think, and make financial decisions is critical to students that are interested in entrepreneurship as well as to those that would like to work in investment firms. The course will start by introducing how investment funds are formed and operated and cover topics such as investment process, term-sheet, valuations, market analysis, financial projections and ROI, risk analysis, due diligence, and investor/shareholder rights.

title: Ethics and Pathologies of Attachment
reviews: Amazing.  Take it if you have any interest in philosophy and in the moral culpability of such agents as psychopaths and addicts.
Go to office hours and talk to Monique about your paper topics in advance. Interesting course, would recommend!
Good class if you're looking for a distribution requirement
Great EM, especially for someone interested in psych/neuro. Relatively low workload and engaging material.
I feel like this course tackles such a specific set of things that aren't necessarily explored in other classes, but definitely can be applied, so I would highly recommend taking the course.

If you are interested in abnormal psychology (psychopathy and addiction in specific), then you will enjoy this course.  The work load is very manageable.  You should do all the readings to get the most out of the class.
Take this course but look through the readings and make sure you have a strong interest in the topic.
Wonderly is wonderful. This was my first exposure to philosophy, and now I feel like I can't get enough. If this course is offered again, take it!
descrip: This course will examine issues at the intersection of emotional attachment, ethics and agency theory. In particular, we will consider whether and how disordered attachment orientations might bear on questions concerning the moral agency and ethical treatment of members of certain clinical populations, including psychopaths and those who suffer from (certain forms of) addiction. In exploring these issues, we will engage with recent literature on moral responsibility, autonomous agency, and bioethical approaches to understanding the nature and treatment of the aforementioned pathologies.

title: Superhero Trials
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Political Philosophy
reviews: Do the readings thoroughly
I would definitely take this class if you need it for a requirement.
If you like economics and politics, and you're good at understanding/making nuanced arguments, take it. Be prepared for a great deal of reading.
Only take if you have a background in philosophy otherwise you will be lost.

Take if you like Rawls. The material is different from what I was expecting; we talked about theories of social justice like telic and deontic egalitarianism, prioritarianism, sufficientarianism, etc. for the first third of the course. We spent the second third on Rawls and his Theory of Justice. Then Nozick and libertarianism. Maybe one or two classes dealt primarily with material that I would have considered "political philosophy." The seminars themselves were unfortunately poor for the first half the course. Our room was a small lecture hall with forward-facing desks, and this made discussions difficult. Further, for the first half of the semester Prof. Frick gave handouts to the class, so all seminars followed a rigid outline. He would ask questions expecting a very specific answer rather than a discussion that allowed more creative thought. That being said, he really pulled through for the second half and reorganized the way he presented material, giving us a list of questions to answer in groups. I loved this change -- it was far more effective in getting students excited to participate, and by putting the class in discussion groups that then reported to the whole seminar, Prof. Frick successfully overcame the disadvantages inherent to the room. I was not a fan at first, but I now think Prof. Frick is a really great professor and it's a shame he's going on sabbatical for the 2016-17 school year.
Take it if you are interested in the material.
This is a true philosophical theory class, NOT a class on the application of political philosophy to political situations.

Very thought-provoking class and not too much work. Prof. Frick is helpful and good at leading discussions. I'd recommend it, but the quality of the course will depend heavily on how much effort the other students put into it.
descrip: In 2012, 10% of US citizens owned 77.2% of the nation's wealth; the bottom 80% owned 16%. A child born today in Japan has a life expectancy of 84.6 years; in Sierra Leone, it is 38 years. Of the 535 seats in the 114th US Congress, only 19.4% are held by women. Should we be troubled by these and other inequalities? In this course, we will study recent work by political philosophers on the value of equality. Topics will include: theories of distributive justice; equality of opportunity; political equality and equal representation; moral equality and legitimate partiality; health inequality; global justice and borders; gender equality.

title: Topics in International Relations - The European Union and International Relations
descrip: This seminar explores the complexities, challenges, and achievements of the EU in international relations over the past decades. Discusses relations between EU and non-member states, great powers, international organizations, and lessons from leading this organization in a globalized interdependent system. How it copes with ethnic rivalries, terrorism, financial & nuclear crises, power interests, energy market, revolutions, conflict on its borders, environmental and health challenges. How has the EU reacted to the global crises, how will challenges shape the future of European integration?

title: Cultures of Imperialism: Britain, the United States, and the Middle East
reviews: Really cool and innovative class! The dual-professor combination is interesting during seminar, and Prof. Minto is particularly amazing! I would definitely recommend taking this class.

The course was fantastic, taught by two consummate professionals who challenged the class but never thought that we were incapable of the course material. The readings reflected a wide range of interdisciplinary approaches to a specific topic that really opened up fascinating ways of thinking. I highly recommend, provided you have some background in the region and an interest in doing a lot of reading.

This is a great course if you want to challenge yourself intellectually and really gain a critical eye for the world around you, and really deconstructing one's own perspectives about the Middle East (as it were) and about the (often egregiously evil) role of the USA in the world

This is the most theoretically rigorous course I have taken at Princeton, so be prepared for that kind of atmosphere. Participation is very important in this class, as is really spending time with the readings. It might be hard at first if you do not have an NES background and most of the other people in the class do, but you will definitely find a way to bring in your own particular (inter)disciplinary background, regardless of whether that involves a working knowledge of Foucault's concept of disciplinary power (har har har).

YOU MUST TAKE THIS COURSE! The subject matter is diverse, engaging, and eye-opening. Professor Pursley and Minto are a great teaching duo. The reading is substantial, but memorable, and the written work is manageable.
descrip: Viewing culture as a technology and battleground of imperialism, this course explores transitions and overlaps between European and American empire in the Middle East through a cultural lens. Parsing the pursuit of hegemony by Western actors, it also tracks resistance to cultural domination on the ground. Imperial culture is formed by and produces power asymmetries, with effects felt both in the region and at home. We will test that proposition by attending to Orientalism, Americanization, anticolonial acts, spies and counterinsurgency, oil culture, humanitarian appeals, developmental interventions, sexual politics, and the War on Terror.

title: Chemical Biology II
reviews: A lot of this course centers on biophysical chemistry instead of biochemistry that relates to synthesis for example. So if you don't like math or are not that interested in spectroscopy, and only want to learn about things like signal transduction pathways and antibiotics, then don't take this course.
Don't take it if you want to understand any of the 4 fields of study surveyed. 4 lecturers who are allowed to throw together 3 lectures each on a wide range of topics is banal and counter-productive.

In this current arrangement, it gives a broad overview of how things stand in x-ray structural biology, natural products and their biosynthesis, ligand binding theory and quantum biology. This is a diverse selection and it seems like there are four courses rolled into one. However, I found it very useful, especially the x-ray studies and natural products parts.
Make sure to attend the lectures, as notes are rarely posted on Blackboard.

Overall a fair course. It is an interesting take on the course insofar we learned a wide array of material. If though it was more focused (less modules) or there was a consistent, pervading theme, it would have made the course more cohesive. Otherwise, it was a good course. The fact there was only two exams made the students feel a lot of pressure.
Read papers
This course, as it is structured now, caters more to the biophysics students than the chemical biology students, and should be advertised as such.

While I personally enjoyed the course, I think it is difficult to recommend, especially with its current name. Less than half of the class was really chem bio, and while that portion was fascinating, I would still be cautious in recommending the class. I think it would very much benefit from splitting into 2 classes again.
descrip: The course provides an in depth treatment of protein chemistry, natural products biosynthesis, and biophysical chemistry.

title: British Histories and Global Histories, c.1750-1950
descrip: The aim of this course is to study the multiple histories of the United Kingdom and the British Empire in the broader context of global history. This is partly in recognition of the interconnectedness of British national and British imperial histories; but also acknowledges and explores the relationship between Britain's imperial history and Britain's global dominance, which held for much of the period this seminar covers. The weekly readings combine very recent with some well established texts; some knowledge of British history, the history of the British Empire and recent developments in global history will be helpful but not essential.

title: Topics in Science, Technology and Environmental Policy - Energy Policy and Energy Technologies
descrip: Energy is central to addressing major challenges of the 21st century. This course reviews and analyzes national and international energy policies and policy options in view of : (a) available and emerging technologies, (b) environmental challenges, (c) economic and political constraints. Students will encounter a variety of policy assessment methods and tools, and apply them in the context the following thematic clusters: fossil fuel resources ; energy efficiency ; distributed energy and renewables ; transportation and mobility ; nuclear energy ; R & D, subsidies and diffusion.

title: Soil Mechanics
reviews: A class is only as good as the professor is, so if Sandiford is teaching it, take it! He has so much industry experience and is the nicest, most helpful guy.
Don't be afraid to reach out to Professor Sandiford with questions!

I would recommend this course. Even though lectures were demanding, just because of how much material we went through, it was painless in the amount of work required, hearing Prof. Sandiford's experiences was fascinating, and you cover important material. You get as much out of this course as you desire, and I would recommend trying to learn as much as you can.
If taken with Ray, the course is pretty easy. The final is takehome and the midterm is open book.
Prof. Sandiford is a very invested teacher who has a great deal of professional knowledge.
Ray is great and always willing to meet, even on Saturdays. He was really kind and you could tell that he wants everyone to do well.
Really interesting stuff even if the name doesn't say it. Ray is INCREDIBLY knowledgeable and helpful and always willing to meet you to help.
The course is pretty simple, especially if you go to lecture. Professor Sandiford is a supremely nice professor, who is very focused on getting the material across to everyone.

This class is a requirement but Professor Sandiford was very reasonable and would always try to accommodate our schedules.  The midterm and final take some time but both are very good in that they reinforce many of the things you have seen in lecture.  Overall enjoyable but the odd 3 hour lecture did not seem to work with the subject matter but this was not Professor Sandiford's fault.

This course is not a lot of work, and Professor Sandiford is a great guy and very willing to help you understand things. A great way to fulfill the materials or soil mechanics requirement for some CEEs.
This is a really easy course, but lectures are useless, everything you need is in the textbook and all exams are open everything.
You probably won't take it unless you are CEE and required to.
descrip: General introduction to physical and engineering properties of soils; soil classification and identification methods; site exploration; sampling; laboratory and in-situ testing techniques; permeability and seepage; soil consolidation and settlement; shear strength; lateral earth pressure; bearing capacity and slope stability.

title: Communicating Science and Technology in the Modern World
prereqs: Open to juniors and seniors. Sophomores and freshmen may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: One of the most important skills science and engineering professionals can develop in their career is the ability to communicate their research. This course, aimed at science and engineering students, is not intended to be a journalism course or a teacher education course but rather seeks to familiarize students with concepts and methods to effectively communicate technical content to a wide array of audiences. Practical science communication and educational theories will be examined. Students learn from hands-on methods focusing on interactions with the public, guest lecturers, assigned readings, discussion, and project development.

title: Microeconomics for Public Policy
reviews: Course is decently well-structured, but didn't find that I had learned much about policy in the course. Will not be fun if you don't like math. The preceptors are great - So is a sweetheart and Richard is always pleasantly snarky.
Do not take this course if Professor Marc Fleurbay is teaching it.
Do not take this course unless the professor and the structure of the course change.
Don't do this to yourself.
Don't take it, but if you have to, make sure you spend time independently teaching yourself the material

Don't take this course with Fleurbaey. Take ECO 300! The ECO 300 professor gave one of our lectures and I learned more from him than from Fleurbaey the entire semester. The lectures were extremely dull and did not help me understand the concepts. The precepts did not clear up topics in lecture or the problem sets. The only reason people didn't drop this class was because they needed to fulfill a requirement. I really like econ, but this class was taught very poorly and I feel like I am still at an intro to micro level, which is very disappointing.

Don't take this if you think the "public policy" aspect of the class means you will spend more time focusing on qualitative concepts or actual policy implications. As someone who hasn't taken math courses at Princeton because they don't interest me and I didn't think I needed it to be a WWS major, this class was incredibly frustrating. You're going to do math anyway, so you might as well take ECO 300.
Don't take this unless you have to.
Don't take unless you absolutely have to
Go to all of the office hours! Start early on problem sets and work in groups so you can all help explain concepts to each other as you do the problems.
Go to office hours. Try to get So as your preceptor. Read the textbook. Practice problem sets for the final. Take it in the fall.

I know this course is supposed to be an 'easy econ' but I personally still found it pretty challenging. If you have to take it, I would definitely recommend going to office hours, especially is So is precepting.

I wish more than anything this was not a required course for WWS because it is so irrelevant to anything I am studying. That being said, it's pretty hard if you're not an econ/quantitative minded person.

I would neither recommend nor recommend against; I had a definite leg up with experience with game theory, econ and math going into this class, and unfortunately these aspects often overshadowed what could have been an interesting conceptual understanding of microeconomics.
I would not recommend taking this course unless you have a very good attention span and an acute interest in microeconomics.
If you can avoid this course, AVOID. IT. LIKE. THE. PLAGUE.
If you want to take an Economics requirement and are relatively good at quantitative data, then take ECO300. WWS300 is okay, but if you're looking for a policy base, this is not that course.
It is a departmental so take it but Econ 300 might be a better option
It's actually more math than you think. If less math is the reason you are choosing WWS 300 over ECO 300 think again.
Look into who's teaching WWS 300 vs. ECO 300 (even go as far as emailing professors to find out). Then choose which one to use for the requirement based on the decision.
Not a great course but if you're coming from intro econ with a good professor it shouldn't be that bad
Only take if you must. There are too many interesting and fulfilling classes at Princeton to waste a spot with this class unless you have to take it as a requirement
Only take it if it's mandatory.

Only take it if you absolutely need to and/or if you are extremely interested in economics. There is not much about public policy in this class; it is mostly a harder version of ECO100, but with a lot of math.
Only take this class if you plan on reading the textbook. Lectures were horrible; however, you can skip all of them if you read the textbook to understand the material.
Pretty indifferent. I had to take the course for my Woodrow Wilson School departmental, but otherwise, I don't think I would have taken it. You will get as much out of it as you put into it.
Take ECO 300.

Take this class! Marc is really chill. 
Not too hard, and important concepts are conveyed. Read the book and do the PSETS

The class is definitely hard, but I think if you have a good preceptor you can manage. 

Best of luck.

The course itself was very heavy on math and calculus--unnaturally so for a public policy economics course. But I learned a lot, and Prof. Fleurbaey is an excellent resource to learn from if you put in the time.
The course was okay, but hard. It is doable though.

There is weekly psets, which is manageable even if you don't go to lecture. The midterm was based largely on the psets, so prepare by reviewing past pset and slides. The textbook is okay for understanding concepts, but sometimes contains too many details that you don't need.

You are probably taking this for the WWS microeconomics departmental requirement. It sucks, but you'll get through it. Find a study group very early on to do the problem sets with and to go to office hours.
You probably have to take it, but be prepared to spend a lot of time watching econ youtube videos and going to office hours

You will deeply regret taking this class with Fleurbaey. The lectures were simply horrible, and the problem sets had a lot of concepts with complicated calculus that were NOT well-taught. We were left to learn everything on our own ? without the textbook I don't know what I would have done. That being said, it was a big time suck to try to learn everything with the textbook as well ? it was as though I had an additional class. Consider taking ECO 300, or WWS 300 if there is a better professor. Also, before you decide to be a Woody Woo major, remember that you might be forced to take a horrible econ class such as this one. Perhaps Politics could be a better major choice.
don't take it if you're not woody woo
take is a the woody woo requirement!
prereqs: Prerequisite: ECO 100. This course is not open to students who have taken ECO 300 or ECO 310..
descrip: Microeconomics is the study of how individual agents (households, firms) make economic decisions and how societies allocate resources. This course, taught at the intermediate level, focuses on markets as a mechanism for dealing with resource allocation, and uses examples that cast light on public policy.

title: Explorations in the Science of Ritual
descrip: The seminar is an experiment in developing a formal means of representation with a strong explanatory power for a diverse set of ritual systems. It begins by focusing on Ancient Israelite and South Asian sacrificial ritual texts and practices, and it extends the investigation to systems of purity and impurity.

title: Mythmakers, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Sophomore Independent Work
reviews: A wonderful way to gain research experience -- but make sure you are self-motivated!
As rewarding of an experience as you put time in. I enjoyed ultimately since proud of final product and seeing real applications. However, very easy for it to be disorganized and unproductive
Definitely consider doing it. I think independent work is a hit or a miss. Make sure you like the topic. You have to put in a lot of time. But if you're genuinely interested, it is worth the effort.

If you want to do sophomore independent work, make sure there are no other classes that you want to take or should take. If that is not the case, then go ahead. It can be an eye-opening experience. It can also be not much work or a lot of work depending on how much you take on (I was more toward the latter side).
Prucnal is great!
Take this course if you like research!
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation and poster session during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office by Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a state of the art project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Life and Death Online
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Renaissance - England Reads Venice
prereqs: None..
descrip: Venice fascinates the English early moderns, for its politics, its religion, its art. Dramatists locate plays there, travellers return with fantastic stories, Sir Philip Sidney gets his portrait painted by Veronese. Our questions have to do with ways in which creative figures from one linguistic or generic sphere read the evidences from another sphere. We consider works by Shakespeare and Jonson. But we also follow other trains of cross-cultural familiarity: historiography, travel writing, diplomatic relations, issues about gender and religious minorities, and the role of the visual arts in creating an image of the Other.

title: Beginning Polish II
prereqs: PLS 101.
descrip: A continuation of PLS 101. This course continues to develop and refine the four language skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing), teaching all fundamental aspects of Polish grammar and basic communication skills on a variety of situations. As the course progresses, the rich Central European culture will be sampled through poetry, film and fictional, as well as expository prose.

title: Advanced Arabic Reading: The Short Story
reviews: If you have the Arabic skills, definitely take this course. Ustaadh Bell is fantastic as usual, and the stories are excellent. The readings take time and effort, obviously, but it is quite worth it (and also quite reasonable).
Take this class if you are interested in diving into Arabic literature in a substantive way, through the genre of short stories. The readings are interesting and the class is very well structured.
it's not too much work, just make sure to actually look up the words if you don't know them because you'll be reading aloud in class
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course will use the genre of the Arabic short story to help students expand their reading and, to a lesser extent, their speaking skills in Modern Standard Arabic. In addition, students will learn about the development of the Arabic short story through reading representative examples of the genre from a variety of periods and authors. The course will focus on a new short story each week, with one class meeting devoted to close reading of a portion of the week's story and the second focusing on a more general discussion - part in English and part in Arabic - of the story under consideration.

title: Introduction to Italy Today
reviews: I would completely recommend this class! Professor Frassica is amazing and if you want to learn about modern day Italy this class is perfect.
prereqs: ITA 107 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is designed to familiarize the student with major features of contemporary Italy and its culture. Its purpose is to develop the student's ability to communicate effectively in present-day Italy. The course emphasizes Italian social, political, and economic institutions, doing so through the analysis of cultural and social differences between Italians and Americans in such everyday concerns as money, work and leisure.

title: Obsession and Addiction in Early Modern Spain
reviews: If you are interested in history or Spanish even just a little, I would take this course.  You will not be disappointed!
Professor Brownlee is incredible. Wouldn't want to graduate without taking one of her classes!
Very good course. The readings were interesting and Professor Brownlee is very intelligent and nice.
descrip: Early Modern Spain exhibits a variety of fascinating obsessions and addictions resulting from extreme and rapid political, social, and economic changes. Addiction to sex crimes, to transgendering and tobacco offer some of the most spectacular accounts of the period. The advent of mass culture produced by print technology, tabloid journalism, and public theaters leads to the rise of the "vulgo" which the elite seek to control and condemn. The obsessive focus on money (both for "picaros" and "indianos") as well as attempts at social engineering by the would-be problem-solving "arbitristas" and inquisitors all make for compelling reading.

title: Contemporary Facade Design
reviews: Best when Sameer and Adamo speak, student presentations are less informative

For the level of (albeit, seemingly) commitment towards the class, they expect more out of the student. 

They will respond to emails quickly etc - however I would have liked to learn more directly from them.
descrip: The course introduces the students to the main themes of performance oriented technical design of the building enclosure while reinforcing the generally understood idea of the facade as the primary language for communication of the architectural idea, developed in harmony with material, its techniques and several other forces of the industry. The students will develop a historical, theoretical and practical understanding of the contemporary building enclosure and the architect's role within the process of its design and execution.

title: Advanced Quantum Chemistry
descrip: Traditionally quantum mechanics is presented as the antipode to classical mechanics; as a result, no attempt at reconciliation is made. The primary purpose is to present quantum and classical mechanics in a unified fashion by clarifying only essential differences; also, how quantum-mechanical methods can be applied to classical dynamics and how quantum phenomena have classical analogies; special emphasis on open quantum and classical system dynamics.

title: Introduction to Coptic Language and Literature
descrip: Emerging in the first and second centuries of the Common Era, Coptic is a syncretistic language of ancient Egypt, transliterated with Greek and Demotic letterforms. Although it is no longer spoken today outside of its role in Coptic Christian liturgies, it was once the language of Roman and Late Antique Egypt. This course will introduce students to the fundamentals of Coptic grammar and prepare them by course's end to read ancient Coptic literature. In addition, this course will introduce students to some of the basic skills required in Coptic studies today.

title: Introduction to Formal Semantics
prereqs: Students should have basic familiarity with logical formulas (or an ability to acquire it quickly)..
descrip: We will study a formal approach to meaning that develops a technical framework for assigning meanings to expressions (primarily English ones) that makes use of functions and sets. This is a course for anyone interested in how formal methods can be applied to the study of language. The course covers material that is essential for any prospective student of linguistics or philosophy of language.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy Extensions: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Provides a thorough examination of statistical methods employed in public policy analysis, with a particular emphasis on regression methods which are frequently employed in research across the social sciences. This course emphasizes intuitive understanding of the central concepts, and develops in students the ability to choose and employ the appropriate tool for a particular research problem, and understand the limitations of the techniques. Prerequisite: 507b.

title: Immigration Politics and Policymaking in the U.S.
reviews: Anyone who is interested in Immigration and Policy Making should take this course
Definitely take this (or any class with Valenzuela!). Avoid preceptor Kustov though. He's terrible.

Disclaimer: this was the first year of the class, so the class will probably change next year. Very informative about immigration politics in U.S. A relevant topic, but be prepared for discussions that focus more on the academic's theoretical views behind immigration rather than the issue itself. Sometimes the theory does not correspond with the current events(?!?). Professor Valenzuela is great and I'm sure he will make significant improvements to the content for next year
Do not take this course if you are looking for an objective, academic look at immigration in the United States. Expect to be presented with an extremely liberal look at immigration politics.

I really enjoyed taking this class with Professor Valenzuela. He is really passionate about research and studying the hypotheses of other scholars and the implications of their results. This was my first class dealing with Immigration and I would totally recommend anyone interested in learning more about the topic to take this class. It is a great POL class and definitely have Professor Valenzuela as your preceptor if you can.
I really liked this class, especially the second half of the course. Do the readings, show up to class, go to office hours. Good course!
If you don't feel comfortable asking questions out loud or during office hours, try asking friends/other students in the class to help you out.
It's a very interesting topic that involves a lot of work. If they change the type of readings, then definitely take it.
It's a very relevant class, and I would highly recommend it.
Make sure you always skim the readings before class.  If you are interested in immigration many of the theories will be eye-opening.
Make sure you stay up to date on readings because there are random quizzes. Also, stay on top of things with the group project.

Personally, I would definitely recommend the course. It is one of the most well organized courses I've ever taken, with a logical arc and the papers actually relating and adding to readings as well as readings and lectures all tying together. Professor Valenzuela is engaging, friendly, and really willing to support the students. The reading load is reasonable as well. It was interesting material, especially during an election year. That said, there definitely is an expectation to be engaged in class (students often participate in lecture some), so really only take the course if you are interested in doing so.
Pretty easy class, Valenzuela is cool.
Really interesting class; not too hard, but it definitely is worth keeping up with the material.
Structure your notes for each reading like this and it will save you a lot of time (trust me): (1) Main concept being tested/addressed, (2) Hypothesis(es) about the concept, (3) Results/findings.

TAKE THIS CLASS.  Although the lectures basically go over the readings and not much else, the assignments were pretty interesting as we actually got to speak with our congress member's office and other immigration interest groups, and by being able to write preliminary assignments before the midterm so you know what is expected, writing the midterm itself was made much easier.  I suggest keeping up on  the readings as there are about 6 reading comprehension quizzes during the year (only two questions each, the two lowest grades are dropped).  My favorite class this semester and you get to work on some cool projects!

Take it, especially if you're an underclassman majoring in the social sciences, since you'll learn a ton about research and academic writing over the process. Be aware that it's a course about immigration politics, not immigration policy, so expect elections, not legislation.

Take this class if you have any interest in immigration, especially if you're curious about quantitative approaches to politics. By far one of the most interesting classes I've taken so far at Princeton.
Take this course if you want to know more about immigration or if you need a politics course. You won't regret it
The course was very interesting. Please take it. You will learn a lot specially if you don't have much prior knowledge on how legislative process occur.

This class is especially helpful for freshmen and sophomores looking to get an introduction to reading political science literature. Valenzuela is a great professor and I would recommend this class to those interesting in learning more about immigration. Valenzuela is very approachable and he tries to learn everyone's names. Lectures and precepts were very open and I felt comfortable in the class. The grading is fair. If you meet what is expected, then you will do well. The case study can be tedious but I think it is worth the work. Would recommend!

This class is not about actual immigration politics, so if that is why you are taking the class, I would suggest taking another. The main focus of this class is the attitudes of White Americans towards immigrants, so if you're interested in that, then I would recommend it. Overall, I would not take this class again.

This course is good. It's particularly useful if you are a freshman or sophomore interested in public policy or politics as it provides a good introduction to reading social science articles and interpreting regression results. It is less useful as a junior or senior if you are familiar with these methods. There are pop quizzes but you can do well if you do the readings. The class does require substantial effort though. It's a good PDF if you don't want to be extremely actively engaged. The topic is interesting.

This is a must-take course if you are interested in immigration. You will not only learn theories in an abstract matter, but apply them to your own case studies, which is a helpful introduction to independent work here. Be mindful that this is immigration POLITICS, not a legal studies class.

This is my favorite classes i've taken at Princeton. Take it if you're interested in US immigration, or want to explore political science. Professor Valenzuela is absolutely amazing, and makes this course balanced, engaging, and challenging in all the right ways.
Would recommend if interested in immigration attitudes (more on the sociology side).
good and topical course
have to go to lecture (easy pop quizzes), basically don't have to read b/c go over everything in class, minimal work all year until final project/test
descrip: Founded and built by immigrants, the U.S. has a complicated relationship with newcomers. How have politics shaped U.S. immigration policy and with what effects on the character of inflows and American identity? Are changing demographics tied to exclusionary attitudes and public views about immigration policy? Do Hispanic attitudes conform to nativist fears? What role do norms, culture and economics play in public attitudes about immigrants? Do members of Congress follow their constituents' preferences when voting on immigration policy? This class will tackle these and related questions about immigration politics and policymaking in the U.S.

title: How to Write A Song
reviews: Amazing course! Maybe the best course I took at Princeton (I'm an ORFE major). Be prepared to put in at least a couple hours a week, but it is well worth it.
Definitely try to take this with a friend or two that you can bounce ideas off of and converse with outside of class.

I would say that this course is less about traditional learning and more about learning through creation; therefore, it is important to come into this class knowing that less will be learned in the actual classroom itself, but instead learning will occur through songwriting efforts done through collaboration.

If you already know how to write music or lyrics, this class is great practice collaborating with other lyricists and musicians and it's a lot of fun. That being said, don't expect to learn the fundamentals of songwriting or any technical skills- it's primarily a chance to independently work on creative projects with other songwriters.
It's a fun way to engage creatively with other students.
It's more time consuming than you imagine.

Professor Muldoon is a wonderful and esteemed scholar in the field. I would recommend anyone who has any interest in song writing to take this class. It is a lot of fun and the time commitment is definitely bearable and easy to manage. There are also a lot of esteemed guests who come to visit throughout the semester. Honestly, one of my favorite courses at Princeton.

TAKE THIS COURSE NOW, YOUR LIFE WILL NOT BE COMPLETE UNTIL YOU DO!!!  (Provided you like making music or writing lyrics.  You'll make a lot of great friends.  Make sure you record the songs during the weekly presentations--the entire class will really appreciate being able to go back and listen.)
Take it! Low commitment and absolutely lovely.

Take the course, it's very fun. But beware that it takes longer than you expect to write a song every week, especially when you're writing with 2 other people and their personalities and musical tastes. Certain people tend to control the class and that can be frustrating.
Take this course. Phenomenal.

This is the best class I have taken here. No background in songwriting is necessary, and it is very interesting to see how to write a song in a collaborative process, and how it varies according to the people you are working with.  I was amazed at how each group would be able to come up with a great song each week!

This was an incredible class! I loved everything about it. If you have the chance to take this class, take it. It was so much fun, and you really connect with your peers. It is a once in a lifetime experience!
You don't need to have formal music training or understanding to do this class, but you should be comfortable with playing an instrument/singing/or writing lyrics.
prereqs: Some familiarity with writing and/or music composition/performance. Interested students complete an application (arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app). Application deadline is November 22, 2015.This course cannot be audited.
descrip: An introduction to the art of writing words for music, an art at the core of almost every literary tradition from Homer through Beowulf to W.B Yeats and beyond. Composers and writers will have the opportunity to work in small songwriting teams to respond to such emotionally charged themes as Contempt, Gratitude, Revenge, Desire, Disgust, Joyousness, Remorse, Loneliness, Despair and Defiance. Assignments are based on study of a range of works in the popular song tradition. There will be several class visits from distinguished singers/songwriters. The final exercise will be a public showcase of work from the semester.

title: The Literature of Fact - Subcultures and Social Worlds
reviews: A really good class. A variety of interesting readings! Steady workload across the semester and worth it in terms of improving your non-academic writing skills.
Amy Waldman is an incredible professor, and this seminar's topic was fun and fascinating to interview for and write about. One of my favorites classes at Princeton.

Easily one of the most enjoyable courses I have taken at Princeton. You get to read a lot of really interesting articles for homework, and there's a lot of flexibility with choice of paper topics. Incredible for improving your writing.
I definitely recommend this class! It was my first journalism course here, and it was the kind of class that made me want to really put all the effort I could into each assignment.
I've definitely put less effort into other classes and gotten better grades, but I learned a lot from taking this journalism class. Definitely recommend.
TAKE IT
TAKE IT.
This is a great course for people interested in long-form journalism. I came in not interested in that but I am now thanks to Prof. Waldman.

Unfortunately this JRN440 class switches topics every year, but if this Subcultures and Social Worlds one makes a comeback, DEFINITELY TAKE IT!!! It's a lot A LOT of reading, but it's very interesting things. Professor Waldman is an amazing professor. Very friendly vibe and extremely knowledgable. You get to meet a lot of great journalists in the field as well!
prereqs: If the course fills, you may email ldetitta@princeton.edu to be put on a waiting list. Please include a paragraph about the reasons for your interest in the course..
descrip: This course will focus on subcultures and social worlds -- Freegans and trolls, the urban poor and the "one percent", Wagnerites and goths, Iraq war veterans and Iranian immigrants, the deaf and their families: subcultures shape the news and culture but also emerge as responses to them. Writing on such groups, and their origins, rituals, and beliefs, has made for some of the best non-fiction of the past half-century. Students will read from that body of work in the service of creating their own, using reporting on the subcultures of Princeton, its surrounds, and the Internet.

title: Scientific Integrity in the Practice of Molecular Biology
reviews: Come with an open mind, contrary to expectations, I had a great time in this class and often continued the conversations outside of class.
Even though it's 3 hours, with Abby the time flies and it's a nice break from courses and research. I think overall this course is very important to young researchers.
It is required
Prof. Abby Notterman makes the course very interesting!
Required course
This requirement course can be a fun discussion if you are engaged. Pay attention and you will learn a lot!
You gotta take it. (I mean this literally: if you are a graduate student who does work related to Biology, you have to take it. It is required.)
descrip: This course satisfies the mandate of the National Institutes of Health for training of molecular biologists in the ethical practice of science. The nature of -- and response to -- personal "misconduct" will be a principle focus. Through case studies and class discussion, we will examine the societal framework for the public support of basic biomedical research, the rights and responsibilities of students and mentors in the conduct of that research, and the significance of intellectual property. We will also review regulations concerning research with human subjects and animals.

title: Quantitative Analysis II
descrip: This course builds upon POL 571 and introduces students to applied regression analysis in cross-section settings. It begins with the basic principles of statistical inference, and then covers various statistical techniques including linear regression, instrumental variables, structural equation models, maximum likelihood estimation, and discrete choice models. The materials are taught at the level of Hayashi's Econometrics, and Freedman's Statistical Methods. Prerequisite: POL 502 (or permission of instructor) and POL 571.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: Excellent course, amazing teacher. No reason not to take it.
Great course. Very insightful and offers something a little different if you are in an MFin, ORFE, COS...etc course.

This is a great class if you want to obtain some perspective about what investing in Asia is like. It's a discussion-based class, so the value added mostly comes if you are ready to be engaged in the discussion at all times.
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course explicitly considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system and its implications, as well as the potential revival of Japanese capital markets.

title: Health Reform in the US: The Affordable Care Act's Origins, Impact and Implementation Challenges
reviews: As someone who identifies as a moderate conservative, and as an engineer who has never taken a WWS class, I had my reservations when I signed up for this course. I now have to say that this was one of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. Professor Howard is an excellent instructor and promotes debate and discussion in the classroom, but never in a bullying way. If you're at all interested in healthcare policy and implementation, take this class.

Definitely take it. I had no experience with public policy or healthcare coming in, and it was no problem. Prof. Howard also understands that people have theses in the spring, so she knows from week-to-week your participation may change.
Definitely take this course! You will learn so much about healthcare in America. This course has been immensely useful!
Definitely take.  Professor Howard is smart and nice and engaging.  Plus she brought cookies every class!
Incredible course with a professor who is an expert in the field and so passionate about teaching. Learned so much.
Must take as a pre-med. Thoughtful and inspiring analysis of the ACA.

One of the best classes at Princeton - great background on the ACA, the readings are incredibly interesting and accessible to those from all concentrations, and the discussions are really thought provoking. A must-take!
Strongly recommend.
TAKE IT. One of the best academic experiences in my 4 years at Princeton. Incredible professor, interesting topic, low workload, and genuinely fulfilling. Can't really ask for anything more.

TAKE THIS CLASS. This is the best course I have ever taken at Princeton. Professor Howard is funny and really wants everyone to participate, even if you disagree with her. She makes insurance sound like the most interesting topic you have ever encountered. Also, she bakes cookies every seminar. Take take take.
TAKE THIS COURSE. You won't regret it. Seriously, do it.
Take it!
Take it!  Professor Howard is incredible and this course is a must take

Take the course! Especially if you're interested in healthcare, but also if you're an American citizen or foreign national who wants to know what's going on in the world of healthcare and how it may impact you.
Take this class! Heather Howard is great and you'll learn so much about the ACA.
This course and Professor Howard are amazing!! The class was extremely enjoyable and taught me a lot! Definitely take a class with her if you can!

This is a great class, one of my favorites at Princeton. Prof. Howard makes such an effort to engage everyone and her enthusiasm is contagious. It's not too much work but you will learn a lot! Participation is important
descrip: The Affordable Care Act, enacted by President Obama in 2010, is an unprecedented federal-state initiative, with provisions to expand health insurance coverage, control health care costs, and improve the health care delivery system. This course will focus on the history of health reform, as well as the implementation challenges since its enactment. We will examine the federal regulatory process, the role that states are playing in implementation, legal challenges to the statute, and Congressional oversight.

title: Foundational Concepts in Anthropology
descrip: An introduction to key anthropological concepts and their relevance to the comparative study of societies. Themes include the cultural embeddedness of gender and sexuality, the organization of social life and religion, the importance of language and symbols, evolution and human nature, economics and global capitalism, and the representation of cultural differences in relation to power and authority. The course considers the application of fundamental anthropological concepts in inquiry on contemporary social issues, such as the environment and technology.

title: Inorganic Chemistry: Reactions and Mechanisms
reviews: Great course and super interesting subject matter. Schwartz is hilarious and brilliant. There is no structure, so if you like structure in your courses, sorry. Totally recommend for the subject matter and Schwartz alone.
Highly Recommend. This course is very hard, but it totally changed the way that I think about chemistry. Take this course!

I highly recommend taking CHM 407 before taking this course.  There is no textbook in this course; Professor Schwartz posts lecture notes, but the details of the material are explained in lecture, and sometimes the topics are covered rather quickly.  Therefore, having prior knowledge of inorganic chemistry helps substantially.  The primary determinant of your grade is the final exam, as problem sets are self-graded.  It is thus very important to keep up.  You should work in groups on homework to facilitate your understanding of the material.  Overall, though, this course gives a very good overview of inorganic reactions and mechanisms.

I really like Schwartz as a lecturer because he is so funny. But be warned: his style of teaching inorganic is not something you can look up online. That said, this course will definitely deepen your understand of chemical reactions and molecular reactivity. Advice: Get into study groups as soon as the first pset comes out - they will be lifesavers.
I would definitely recommend taking this course. I felt like I learned a lot, and it helped me think in ways that other classes did not.

I would not recommend this course for senior year, but rather junior year if possible, because it would be incredibly stressful to have a class where basically everything came down to your grade on the final for your senior spring. 

This class was very interesting in what we learned, but also unnecessarily stressful because of the lack of structure and because some of the things the problem sets were evaluating were never discussed in class, and there is no book to reference. In addition, if you were not in Professor Schwartz's precept, then you never knew if what the preceptor said was actually what Professor Schwartz would say was correct, because there were several occasions where the preceptor said something that was later directly contradicted by the professor, or said something which was the right answer, but with unclear logic.
What you learn about how to adjust reactivity and mechanisms for inorganic processes, though, could be incredibly valuable depending on what you are working on. Also, lectures are incredibly engaging!
If you take this, the final practice exams do not have answer keys, so take them early enough in reading week so that you can schedule appointments with Schwartz in order to go over questions you have. This is the most valuable test prep.
Overall, I would take 407 for the inorganic requirement, and maybe take this as pdf or audit. Or you can just take it if you are willing to deal with some frustration but rewarding lectures.

Like everyone has said before, there is very little feedback before the final exam so it's hard to gauge where you're at. That being said, Inorganic chemistry is an extremely interesting field and Professor Schwartz knows so, so much. I think you'll learn a lot, and it's so necessary for anyone thinking about entering a inorganic or organometallic lab. If you're thinking about taking it: work on the problem sets alone, check with other people, but trust your intuition and know why YOU think a certain answer is right. This is the type of reasoning that is required on the exam. 
For any Chem majors deciding between 407 or 408, 407 is more textbook-style, great for the fundamentals but stuff you'll probably never see in your research. 408 is less structured, more data driven, and stuff you'll hear about in your group meetings.
Not a bad workload. Grade your own problem sets, which puts seemingly your whole grade on the final exam. Ample practice tests are provided for the final.

TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! This is one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Prof. Schwartz's lectures are fascinating, clear, and quite entertaining. The material is very difficult, but if you spend time grappling with the it, you will both learn a lot about inorganic chemistry and how to think in a highly methodical and logical way. This course will improve your problem solving abilities in different ways than organic chemistry, and it's worth taking. Good Princeton courses are usually interesting but also change the way you think-- this course does just that!!

This class is good, but it is a lot of work. Problem sets take many hours (even in groups), and even then it is hard to tell whether you have understood it correctly. Take it if you are willing to put a lot of effort into it! It will be worth it if you have the time.
descrip: Structure-reactivity correlations for inorganic complexes will be emphasized. Ligand substitution and electron transfer processes will be presented. The course will highlight applications of inorganic and organometallic chemistry to areas of current interest to both organic and inorganic chemists. These areas will include organic synthesis, "redox" reactions, catalysis, and materials. Prior completion of a full year of organic chemistry is required for enrollment.

title: Decision Modeling in Business Analytics
reviews: Although the homework might occasionally seem intimidating, the professor ultimately wants you to learn, so try your best and you'll usually be fine (although you might need to see the professor to complete the assignment). Be wary of taking if the class size is greater than 30. Requires fairly good background in MATLAB, R or NumPy.
Definitely take the course. It has a lot of interesting material.

Good intro to business analytics problems in theory. However, in practice, it was an odd dynamic. Seminar size but lecture-style, and a little too long (80 minutes as opposed to 50 minutes). Good if you have a long attention span and can handle potentially highly difficult PSETs.

Great class, definitely recommend! You won't find a professor as engaged and willing to help as Prof. Wang. She provides incredible support and is always willing to listen to the students to make the class fair. This class was truly defined by her motivation to make it an enjoyable experience for the students. It also has a manageable work load and a variety of applications, which is definitely worth exploring. Take it!
Interesting subject matter, great professor. Not a ton of work. Take it!

Mengdi is such a helpful professor!! So fast at responding to emails and very excited to see you learn. Cool material, cool problems - lectures can feel a bit long at 80 minutes and can be dry, but this class has improved so much from last year and will continue to get better.
Much better than previous iterations of the course (from what I've read). Take it!

Take this course. Mengdi is a cool teacher and helps with the homework assignments. Also, creating the final project was fun and she allow students to give her feedback on dates and assignments if you don't feel like a deadline is fair.
prereqs: ORF 245, ORF 307, ORF 309, or approval by instructor.
descrip: This is an introductory course to decision methods and modeling in business and operations management. The course will emphasize both mathematical decision-making techniques, as well as popular data-based decision models arising from real applications. Upon completion of this course students will have learned analytical tools for modeling and optimizing business decisions. From a practical perspective, this will be a first course that gives an overview of advanced operations research topics including revenue management, supply chain management, network management, and pricing.

title: The Social Psychology of Social Change
reviews: Absolutely take if you're a psychology major! Might be harder for non-psych students. Professor Prentice is a legend in the psych world, and a great professor - don't pass up an opportunity to learn from her.
Absolutely take this course if you have any interest in how psychology can be used to enact change in a real world context. Professor Prentice is fantastic and the course material is fascinating.
Excellent class. Please take.
If there is any class with Dean Prentice, TAKE IT.
If you want to sit there for 3 hours bored out of your mind each week but still get a decent grade, take it. Otherwise I'd stay away
It's a great course that combines psychology and some policy work. Professor Prentice is also always willing to provide feedback. Take it especially if you're a psych major!

Manageable course load, with interesting (and fairly brief readings). Social psychology is applicable to so many AB fields and the topics covered (such as prejudice and empathy) are thought-provoking, so I highly encourage you to take it if you're AB non-psych.

Professor Prentice is a great teacher and this class is a great opportunity to discuss psychology and social change with WWS, PSY and other majors. If you have any interest in social policy, applications of psychological theory, interventions or social issues this class will be of value.
Take it! Great readings, really interesting material and concepts
take this course!! it is a great psych course and Prof. Prentice is awesome!
prereqs: PSY 252, WWS340/PSY321, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar examines the use of social psychological theory and research to explain, predict, and engineer social change. It also explores how social change has inspired theoretical and methodological developments in social psychology. In so doing, it reviews the major ideas, theories, and findings of social psychology with a particular emphasis on their applications to real-world examples of soc stasis and change. The seminar is organized topically, with sessions on conflict and prejudice, gender, and sexuality, authority and legitimacy, crime and punishment, identity and culture, environmental behavior, education, health, and economics.

title: Studies in Greco-Roman Religions - Authority, Ritual, and Politics in Early Christianity
descrip: Our seminar investigates several major topics (c. 70 C.E.- 500 C.E.), including the following: Authority, "Scriptures," and leadership, seen in comparison with Jewish groups; Rituals, especially exorcism, in context of Greco-Roman cosmology and practices; Constantine's "Christian empire"; Discoveries of "heretical" texts.

title: Political Theory
reviews: Absolutely take it. Very relaxing and great readings!

Although some readings are not necessary, in that you might not have to use them in essays, it is important to read most of the assignments in order to fully grasp the themes and different opinions behind each one.

Although this course is often reviewed highly, keep in mind that the ratings are inflated. This is not a course that will allow you to engage with the material meaningfully. It has all the material to be a great life-altering experience and falls completely short of that. The readings are the only redeeming part of the course material, and Professor Lane's lectures are remarkably unremarkable and the essay prompts are restrictive. If you place any value on political theory and discourse, do not take this course...you will be devastated as I was and will be hard-pressed to find meaning in it. As I said, the only fulfilling parts of the course were when completing the readings and if you occasionally found a way to wriggle out of the horrendous prompts to actually THINK.

As a politics major, I would recommend this course with Prof. Lane to anyone remotely interested in political theory, the Politics department or ideas of freedom, equality and liberty. The lectures are great, and Professor Lane is very accessible and friendly. An introduction course that is very fair and exciting - a rare combination.
Attend all lectures and spend time with the readings outside of class in order to produce high-level papers and contribute to precept discussion.
Class isn't as dry as people say, and it's an easy B /A if you have any idea what you're talking about. The 4 papers were not hard to write. Take the class for an easy 4th or for Pol Economy cert.
Definitely take this class! It is interesting, engaging, and not overly difficult if you go to lecture.
Do the readings and come to precept ready todisciss
Do the readings and pay attention in class
Easy distribution, but very boring
Good for distribution, PDF'd it but you probably don't have to if you do all the readings and keep up during lectures. The papers are only 1000 words but make sure you have some quality content.

I assumed that this class would be a political science class that explored different concepts and structures related to politics but it ended up being more of a humanities course that focused on different texts instead of the ideas exemplified in the texts. If you're into the humanities then you'll enjoy this class as it covers a lot of key works in history. But if you're more of a social science student, like me, then this class is not for you. Lectures (Professor Lane) just summarize the readings and the papers have overly straightforward prompts. But the workload is pretty manageable. Gabrielle Girgis is a great preceptor.

I had already covered about 3/4 of the readings from the course in other classes, so there were times when it was difficult for the material to feel fresh. This is by no means a "practical" political science course, and so most readings are philosophical in nature. But overall, a well-taught and quite easy course as long as you actually make an effort to keep up with the readings, which are themselves very reasonable for a course of this nature. Prof. Lane wants to help you do well, and Gabrielle is a great preceptor. I also did the CBLI component, which was great (if they offer it again).
I really enjoyable course. The precepts and readings are engaging but sometimes it felt like the lectures only added slight nuance to the readings.

I suggest taking this introductory course if you have an interest in political theory and want to confirm that you enjoy all of the different levels of philosophical reading. It serves as a good base line for developing this judgment.
I would highly recommend this class to other students.  It is very interesting, meets a few requirements, and in addition to all of that was very fun.
I would highly recommend this course. The readings are fantastic, the grading is fair, and the discussions are truly eye opening.

I would highly recommend this course. The workload is very manageable and Professor Lane is great! It won't be an easy A but it should also not be anything under a B. Overall great course and you should have no problem getting a decent grade.
I would not put off the readings as they can build up pretty quickly! Also, attend every precept because it will allow you to parse through all the dense materials!
I would recommend it to all students.
If you do all the readings and pay close attention, you basically do not have to attend lectures, as they cover the material in the readings.

If you're at all interested in politics, take this class. The readings are actually pretty interesting. If you're not interested in politics, take this class anyway. The lectures are interesting but completely unnecessary to succeed.

If you're looking for a easy way to fulfill your EM distribution requirement, I recommend this class. However, do not expect lectures to be particularly insightful, or intellectually stimulating, or in any way challenging--you can get away with not attending any lecture (not that I'm encouraging truancy). The essays are easily produced. The grading is fairly lenient. You will get to read some very interesting texts. Overall, I was fairly surprised by how well received this class had been in previous years.
It is a decent class, and a good politics class to take if you need it.
It's a good way to fulfill a distribution requirement, but other than that only if you're really into politics
Plan your essays in advance and keep up with the readings. I would also advise students to attend preceptors' office hours as these sessions were extremely helpful.

Take if you want to develop a basic foundation in politics. This course is organized around 5 themes: the individual perspective of power from below (ex: civil disobedience, extent of obedience), power from above (ex: whether rulers have the same obligations as the bottom or whether they can get their hands dirty), freedom and slavery, popular sovereignty, and equality (ex: sometimes we ardently pursue equality as an end in itself and forget the purpose of equality, & how extreme equality can actually threaten political freedom). If these things seem interesting to you, then you will enjoy the lectures and precept discussions (Gabrielle is great!). If not, move on.
Take it for an interesting EM distribution.
Take this class! Professor Lane is a brilliant lecturer and the material is fascinating. A great introduction to Political Theory.

Take this course if you have any interest in the foundations of political thought. This isn't going to tell you how Trump got so far, it is going to open your mind to the myriad of different questions and balances at play within a political system. Professor Lane is interesting and helpful, and the readings are all essential for an educated person.

Take this course if you're interested in some classic political theory.  You'll get your Locke and Rousseau and Thoreau and Douglass plus a few more modern theorists.
