Be sure to do as much of the reading as you can; it'll really come back to bite you on the final if you don't, even if you get through the rest of the semester okay without it.  Be warned, though; there's a lot to read.

Take this course!  I loved it!  It is very normative, which makes it different from other classes I have taken about politics.  The class is also manageable, but make sure you keep up with the readings.
Take this if you want to be a politics major or just sound smart when talking about Political Theory in the real world.
There are flaws in what is asked in the papers, however Lane is a great lecturer and all the preceptors are great. Interesting class.
This course is very well taught. It is an easy course with minimal work because of how accessible all the info you need for the class is.

This is a really good class. Not too hard, not too much reading, lectures are very informative and helpful. If you do all the readings and go to lecture you will understand the material and get good grades on the essays.

Very good introductory course. The CBLI community teaching program is a really great experience too. Keep up with the readings as well as you can and you'll have plenty to write about come paper time.
attend lecture
definitely take the class if you are okay with dealing with a lot of theory
go into office hours
good intro to political theory, interesting papers
if you like political theory go for it. its a good class with a good amount of work involved
intersting class
take it

this course is a good introduction to pol theory covering a wide range of themes including civil disobedience, freedom and slavery, equality and inequality drawing on the writings of Locke, Rousseau, Thoreau, Douglass, Wollstonecraft and others
prereqs: This course is open to first year students.
descrip: This course explores ideas of individual ethics and political community, the ethics of political rule, freedom and slavery, democracy and representation, and equality and inequality in political thought. Readings will be drawn from both canonical and contemporary authors, including Sophocles, Machiavelli, Locke, Rousseau, and Tocqueville. This is an introductory course, which emphasizes both thematic and historical approaches to political theory, and its role in informing contemporary civic engagement.

title: Language at Princeton
reviews: Absolutely TAKE THIS. Josh Katz is the man. Such a great lecturer and overall a super easy class. You will not regret it.

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS COURSE! Students will learn so much about languages in the University and in the town. Professor Katz is a gem in the Princeton community and he will make the class enjoyable and intellectually stimulating. The focus is broad in the field of linguistics but nonetheless teaches more than you could ever expect. Take it!
Definitely do take.
Definitely take this course! Really fascinating, great professor, not much work.

Definitely would recommend.  Prof Katz is amazing and a really interesting lecturer.  You don't learn in the traditional sense, but there is always lively class discussion that makes the lectures worth going to.
Great course! Super easy - npdf but there is absolutely no reason why you would have to PDF this course HAHA!
Great fifth class! Katz is super engaging
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in gaining a general understanding of linguistics in an applicable manner.

I would recommend this course if you're interested in applying linguistics to, and thinking more deeply about, the world ("Bubble") you live in. However, it's not a light workload, so if you're a senior and it's the spring and you have a thesis, it might not work out too well...
If professor Katz is instructing take it. Period.
If this class is ever offered again, you have to take it! Katz is a complete beast and lectures are phenomenal.
If you get a chance, take this class. Professor Katz is fantastic, and the course will really get you thinking about this crazy, weird place where we're all spending four years.
If you're interested, do it, you learn a lot about Princeton though more than you do about linguistics
It is too bad that this course is not taught more often. I would recommend it to all.
It's an easy LA. Take it. Also talk a lot in class - apparently that matters.
Katz is an incredibly professor but the course material is less interesting than it might appear. Beware: this class also has more work than you would think.
Professor Katz does a phenomenal job with this and really ties in current on- and off-campus issues effectively. Had me wanting to come back for more every week.
Really fun!
Take any class with Katz.
Take any class with Professor Katz. He is great. This class was good because of him.

Take anything that Josh Katz teaches. A Katz lecture is like watching a really good movie. Don't expect to become a linguist by the end of this class, but you will think about language and Princeton in a different way for sure.
Take it for Katz.
Take it! It is just a cool interesting class that is very laidback and a good time to hear Katz talk about a subject he is interested in.
Take the course. It is a great change of pace from other work and it inspires you to think about issues in an analytical way.
Take this class, it's very chill, and you get to learn a ton about Princeton you probably didn't know before. Very few classes here are so Princeton-focused.
This class is great, the work is very reasonable and interesting and it's obviously fun to analyze Princeton and the communities you are involved in.
This is a good class to take for the LA requirement. It's not too difficult and interesting enough. Professor Katz a great lecturer and a good preceptor.

Very thought-provoking and eye-opening. Katz is a fearless lecturer, who encourages discussion about sometimes controversial issues. Don't expect very heavy academic linguistic knowledge from this course. This class will open your eyes about Princeton and issues going on at Princeton in a different way. TAKE IT!

chill and was more of a discussion than anything. It's not so much a linguistic course (morphology, syntax, etc.) but rather is about language. You talk about free speech, language requirements, stuff like that. Katz is rad tho so take it.
take it and try hard
prereqs: No prior experience with linguistics is expected. There will necessarily be some overlap with the material in LIN 201, but students are welcome -- indeed, encouraged -- to take both, in either order..
descrip: An introduction to linguistic analysis, with an emphasis on hands-on work. Making use of as many different sorts of resources as possible -- animate, inanimate; written, spoken; town, gown -- we will try as a group to understand the history and current state of language at Princeton University and in Princeton, NJ just outside the "Orange Bubble." What languages and what modes of communication have and have not been used here? When? Why? How? By whom? We will discover the answers by exploring archives, conducting interviews, and generally engaging in original and creative research.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: A nice course to PDF on. If you want an easy A, look elsewhere.
Fairly easy class, go to every lecture and you will be fine for the exams.  If you are in the B section the labs aren't normally over 2 hours.  Take this class!
Fun course that will make you appreciate architecture more
Go to lab
Good for a very easy STL. Not necessary to attend lectures to do well
Great PDF, fun to take with friends!
Great STL. Reasonable work load, friendly preceptors and a great lecturer. Interesting content. Definitely recommend it. However, be prepared for assignments with crappy directions.
Great course for non-engineers to get the STL requirement and engineering seniors who want to dedicate their time to their thesis and job search rather than a class.
I honestly wouldn't take this. If you're looking for an easy science, at least try something that you'll learn valuable info from.

I think the topic is really interesting so it might be a good class for you if you are interested in fulfilling a distribution requirement. However, it is more work then people make it seem, but manageable.

I would recommend that students not take this class. If students do decide to take the class, I would recommend students only take the A, non-lab, section. This class is a poorly put-together, content-stretched class. The lectures are boring and can be avoided if the David Billington "Tower and the Bridge" book is read. The labs do not really provide much of a supplement to the class, as most concepts are already basic to begin with (and this is coming from a history major). You will find that assignments, like labs and problem sets, are often vague or, in some cases, contradictory.
I wouldn't recommend against it or anything. It was pretty good, and I'd imagine it could be fun if you apply yourself to it in full. I just didn't give it the attention it needed.
If you need an STL, this is an easy and relatively interesting option. If you take it seriously you will almost definitely get an A, but if you don't you should probably PDF.

It is unfortunate that many students have a perception of this course as "easy-A," but from my experience and from many others who took the class this term, it is anything but.  Again, I came into the course with this mentality that it'd be super easy and did not think it necessary to devote an adequate amount of time to study material that count nothing toward my major or an area of interest.  If you dislike math or having to figure out which equation works where, I would not recommend taking this course for STL.  Take CEE102 in the fall instead.  The course material is however interesting, but I don't think you should waste one of your 32 or however many classes at Princeton on this course.
It's a fun way to fulfill the distribution requirement. You learn a lot from this class about the structures (bridges, buildings etc.) around you.

It's a really good course to take for your STL! The lectures, homeworks, and labs are well designed and easy to follow. It's also pretty interesting, since Professor Garlock talks about some of the most important structures in the US, that most of us have heard of.
Make sure to thoroughly read the Structural Study as it pertains heavily to the problem set.
Pay attention in lecture, specifically with designs and structures.  Background information with the engineers are usually unnecessary.
People who call this an easy A?what are you smoking?! This class was fairly difficult, really boring, took a lot of time, and taught me nothing interesting or life-enriching.
Please go to lectures, will help for the final! Great STL to take, pretty chill
Stay on top of problem sets and labs

Structures, is a rather interesting class if you have any interest in engineer or architecture. I quite liked thinking about the buildings, but the class lacks a certain conceptual component, and the work (labs problems sets) are easy but tedious.
Study the structural studies, and everything should be very manageable
Take as an easy STL. You'll do well if you actually do the assignments and go to lecture, unlike most of the class.
Take for STL, but expect a decent amount of "busy work"
Take it for sure

Take it! Easiest STL, especially if you PDF it. You actually do learn about bridges, skyscrapers, etc, which is generally pretty cool. Math is just plug-and-chug formulas, essays are straight from the Powerpoints. Try and get Alexis as a preceptor if you can, he's super chill.
Take it!! Accessible for humanities majors while still being interesting, and I felt like I learned a lot from the course.
Take it, very interesting and the labs are fun. Get alexis if you can for your TA.
Take it.  It is an easier, interesting STL option.

Take this course as an STL - the lectures are interesting and labs can be fun. You do have to put in work but it is a reasonable course. Just make sure you get a lab TA who knows what he/she is doing and put in effort in the labs because it's really annoying if everyone just slacks off.
This class is a good way to get the STL requirement taken care of. I had to PDF, but you can probably A it if you take it seriously.
This course (especially as an STL) is not as easy as you would think! Tons of work
This is an excellent course for those interested in fulfilling their STL in addition to getting a preview of what other engineering courses might require.
This is very educative and entertaining course.
This was a great STL. The ratio of what I got out of the class to time put in was fantastic!
Very easy STL. Worth taking even if you aren't mathematically or scientifically inclined.
Work hard on lab reports.
You must go to the lectures. The slides are available but they are all pictures. The content of the course is really only accessible through attending lecture and writing down all of her words.
bridges, take it for the easy pdf and move on from your stl.
dont neglect the work- eng major who took it as STL and devoted little time to it and ended up PDFing
lecturers are honestly the most important
take it!
take it, easy STL... absolutely no work.
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through laboratory experiments students study the scientific basis for structural performance and thereby connect external forms to the internal forces in the major works of structural engineers. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities in the U.S. and abroad.

title: Transmission and Compression of Information
reviews: Be aware that although you only need basic probability knowledge to be in this course, this course is basically comprised of a lot of math majors who really will bring up the curve.
Definitely take this class with Abbe. He is very good lecturer, knows the material inside out, and a great person overall. Most importantly, he shows that he cares about the students.
For ELE the class is pretty diverse in terms of people's majors, but the material is well taught and everything is manageable.
Go to lecture!
Great class! Not that much homework. Almost completely theoretical--lectures and homework are just theorems and proofs. Nontrivial probability pre-requisites. Not too hard for a math major.
Great class! Prof. Abbe is a very good lecturer, explains things in an approachable and intuitive way. Definitely recommend to anyone interested in Information Theory.
Great course: amazing lecturer and very cool ideas. Take if you are somewhat comfortable with math and are interested in information theory! Highly recommend.

It's less work if you know what you're doing--problem sets are spaced apps. 1.5 weeks apart. Concepts are presented much more formally and rigorously than in ELE 201 classes, and the goals are different. It's an APC class covering ELE topics.
Surely take the class if Professor Abbe is teaching it! It is a fantastic course! (Perhaps the best I've taken at Princeton)
Take it.
The subject is interesting and Emmanuel's lectures are always very clear and accessible in despite of some hard parts.
This class is very easy and chill if you have good math background, would recommend for math majors looking for chill class that doesn't count toward rule of 12.
This is a great course. Prof. Abbe is an excellent lecturer and the material is interesting.
prereqs: Linear algebra and basic notions of probability..
descrip: Our digital world relies heavily on our ability to extract, store, and transfer information. Consequently, much effort has been devoted to perform efficiently such tasks. This class covers the fundamental limits and algorithms for data compression and transmission, providing an introduction to information theory and coding theory. It also discusses connections with unsupervised machine learning problems, in particular with data clustering.

title: Elementary Twi II
prereqs: TWI 101.
descrip: This course is a continuation of TWI 101 and continues to focus on the communicative approach to studying the language. It includes specific socio-cultural settings and events. Speaking, reading, writing and listening continue to form an integral part of the course and students will build on their grammatical skills. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Novice High and Intermediate Low.

title: Spanish in the Community
reviews: Amazing class! Alberto is one of the best professors you will find here and this class is extremely interesting and relevant. Take it!
Do the readings!

Great course. Alberto is a phenomenal instructor who cares about his students. There is quite a bit of class time, given the community service component, but the written assignments aren't too taxing, and the reading list is phenomenal.
Highly recommend this course! Best Spanish course I've taken thus far.
If Alberto teaches this class again, take it! He's the best Spanish professor at Princeton and the subject is very interesting.
It's a fair amount of work but a great class and Alberto is great
Speak Spanish whenever you get the chance. Don't be afraid to make mistakes. And get involved with Spanish-speaking communities in the Princeton area. It will be a fruitful experience.
Take it! Alberto is great and so helpful. Community service isn't bad, and you get to pick what works best with your schedule.

Take it! Especially if you are interested in immigration and the issues that face Spanish-speaking communities in the United States. Be engaged/enthusiastic in the community service, it's not that much work and it pays off! Overall, the class is fun, enjoyable, and not a huge time commitment. Strongly recommend.
Take this course! Especially with Alberto. Super interesting and engaging and meaningful especially with the CBLI component
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or equivalent proficiency in Spanish (contact the instructor). Participation in the community service program "Latino Link" will be a requirement for this course..
descrip: This course is connected with the Latino Link volunteer program, which brings together Princeton University students and Latino/a youth attending public schools in the Princeton area. This course will enrich the volunteering students' experiences with readings, discussions, ethnographic projects, and visits from experts and members of the community, with the purpose of reflecting critically on Latino communities and Spanish language in the United States. The course will also provide intensive language practice inside and outside the classroom.

title: Of Love and Other Demons
reviews: Decent course. Not a must take but I don't regret taking it either. It isn't that much work and can be a nice 5th class to take (even though it is not PDF - at least I don't think so).
Good class if you're interested in a philosophical analysis of amor in Spanish lit. Relatively light coursework throughout the year, but the midterm and final are pretty extensive.
Great class in the Spanish department. Loved all the readings and films. Would definitely recommend
It takes up a lot of time, but it is worth it! Your Spanish will definitely improve.

It's probably one of the less intense 200-levels. If you're going for the certificate I say take it because the workload isn't too much of a burden! But if you think you're entering into some deep seminar on the nuances of human love, I regret to inform you that this class is not that. But what I can tell you is that some of the films are SOFT-CORE PORN!!! Just a PSA. Be prepared haha.
Take it if you enjoy Spanish!
Take it if you want a kind of weird, but funny class.
Take it if you're interested in the subject matter
The texts and films chosen are very interesting and wide-ranging, take the course!

This class leaves a lot to be desired. The professors' emphasized analysis of texts (or the professors' "readings" of texts) often feel incredibly tangential and impractical. I took a class on love to learn more about love, not learn about obscure love analogies and symbols. At times, the class achieved this, but more often than not it was inaccessible.

This is a really interesting class. Most of the readings are great, and the work load is pretty minimal. Make sure to do the readings so you can pay attention in lecture and precept. The grading of the papers is very subjective, which can be pretty frustrating if your ideas aren't the same as the professor's.
This is one of those courses where the teaching staff is interested in getting to know the students, which means that it is possible to get a lot out of it.
good class, interesting material but gets a little repetitive towards the end. Take it if you're interested in latin american literature.
participate in class
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission..
descrip: Love is the subject of the world's greatest stories. The passions aroused by Helen of Troy brought down a city and made Homer's masterpiece possible, while the foolishness of those in love inspired Shakespeare and Cervantes to create their most memorable characters. Many powerful Latin American and Spanish stories deal with the force and effects of love. In this course, we will study a group of films and literary fictions that focus on different kinds and forms of love. We will pay special attention to the forms of narrative love (quest, courting, adultery, heartbreaking), as well as the translation of love into language, body, and image.

title: Introduction to Genomics
reviews: A pretty good crash-course on the basic experimental and computational techniques of genomics. If you are looking for hardcore programming, take QCB 455, but this course is better for the average molecular biologist who will certainly be doing genomic analysis in his or her career, though not necessarily hardcore coding. Very manageable workload, final project was quite fun.
Do not take this course to fulfill your distribution requirement unless you come prepared with a decent background knowledge of biology and computing.
Highly recommend. Teaches you bioinformatics from biology standpoint.

If you're interested on some of the biochemical techniques used to generate sequence and microarray data as well as the computational techniques for assembling and clustering the data, then take this course. If you're looking for a legit,  programming-intense bioinformatics course, then this is not it. It's pretty laid back. the assignments can be done in a few hours most of the time (there are only four). The galaxy assignment, however, will take you days, if not a week, to finish since you're dealing with gigabytes of data and processing it on a remote/public server. The actual work that you do won't take more than an hour but there is a lot of waiting.
The beginning and middle of the class are really not what you're there for- it's only the culmination. I would recommend this course if you have the patience to wait it out.

This was the first time this course was taught, so it was somewhat unorganized (due to having two separate professors), but I liked how casual it was. Both professors are very knowledgeable and approachable and will answer any questions about topics beyond what was discussed. Helps give you a broad survey of what people have done in the field.
prereqs: COS126.
descrip: This course is intended to give students a hands-on introduction into the main computational approaches used in molecular biology research, with a special focus on Genomic approaches. We will reiterate the central dogma of molecular biology, by explaining the biology behind every component of the dogma (DNA, RNA, Protein, and Metabolites), introducing state-of-the-art computational approaches used to analyze large datasets of each component, giving examples of medical or industrial applications of these approaches, and finally, demonstrating how to perform an actual analysis using the most common tools available.

title: Cosmology
reviews: A very easy course (about 1 hour of homework per week) which teaches you about cosmology. Definitely worth taking if you want to learn about the evolution of the universe as a whole.

Definitely take this course. The topics are incredibly stimulating but very accessible. The course is difficult conceptually, but Professor Bahcall is very helpful and able to make everything understandable. TAKE IT.

I really cool class!  Professor Neta teaches cosmology in a way that makes it super-approachable, super-doable, and super-fun.  I had at least some background in astro (as in, at least AST 204), which helped a lot (although it wasn't necessary).

If you know nothing about cosmology, will give you an equivalent understanding as watching NOVA documentaries or spending time on wikipedia. If you have a background in cosmology (even outside of class as a general interest), you may find this class to be boring or not very new.
If you want to be an astrophysics major, this class is essential.
Make sure to spend time doing the textbook readings.
Not a very difficult class, but can still learn a lot about the Universe even if you have some background. Professor Neta Bachall is super nice and friendly
Take the course, it is very interesting and not that much work. Especially now that new advancements in Cosmology are coming, students should really learn about the universe. Well, also generally.
Take this class! Neta is amazing and cosmology is the coolest thing ever.
Take this even if you're not an astro major. Professor Bahcall is awesome and open to any questions. The work is interesting and doable and she makes you want to know more.

The material is fascinating, and as far as an astro/physics class goes, it's not too demanding; however, everyone does well on psets, so the exams set the curve, and the smallest mistakes can cost you unnecessary amounts of points.
Would not take again - too quantitative. Don't take if haven't taken advanced physics/or astro courses.
Would take it if you were comfortable in 204 and like thinking about very theoretical concepts.
it's relatively chill which is nice but i wouldn't have taken it if i didn't have to.
prereqs: MAT 201 and MAT 202 and PHY 207 or 205 (and PHY 208 (recommended).
descrip: A general review of extragalactic astronomy and cosmology. Topics include the properties and nature of galaxies, clusters of galaxies, superclusters, the large-scale structure of the universe, evidence for the existence of Dark Matter and Dark Energy, the expanding universe, the early universe, and the formation and evolution of structure.

title: Memories of the Ancient Past
descrip: The cultures of ancient Egypt and the ancient Middle East have been essential touchstones for Western and Middle Eastern cultures, as sources of identity, inspiration, competition, or the exotic other. This seminar considers how cultures throughout western history have looked at ancient Egypt and the Middle East, centering the roles of memory and materiality. Students develop independent research projects on this theme considering any time period, up to and including current events.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Geosciences (Half-Term)
reviews: The course is a low-pressure evening discussion. Participate and use it as an opportunity to discuss ideas or questions you have about research.

This is a half-semester course that provides an overview of responsible conduct of research in the geosciences. The lectures are led by a different pair of professors representing AOS and GEO each week. Most graduate students are expected to take this course during their first or second years in GEO/AOS. The quality of discussion varied a lot from week to week, with some interesting case studies of current issues. On average, the level of professor and student engagement was lower than I hoped. I recommend taking this course first year if it is required, so that it doesn?t interfere with later commitments.
This is required. And I strongly recommend reading the materials before the class.
descrip: Course educates Geosciences and AOS students in the responsible conduct of research using case studies appropriate to these disciplines. This discussion-based course focuses on issues related to the use of scientific data, publication practices and responsible authorship, peer review, research misconduct, conflicts of interest, the role of mentors & mentees, issues encountered in collaborative research and the role of scientists in society. Successful completion is based on attendance, reading, and active participation in class discussions. Course satisfies University requirement for RCR training.

title: Gold, Gods, Kink, and the Modern Fetish
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Portuguese II
prereqs: POR 101. No credit is given for POR 101 unless POR 102 is taken. Students who successfully complete POR 102 will place into POR 109..
descrip: A continuation of POR 101. Students will continue to develop skills of oral/aural comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining further exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa.

title: Political Philosophy - Problems in Contemporary Political Theory
descrip: This seminar covers some basic concepts deployed in political thought and practice, looking at the various ways in which they may be institutionally implemented. The concepts discussed include those of the state, the constitution and the people as well as some more regular social concepts like that of agency, corporation, freedom and power.

title: Directed Research
reviews: It is a lot of work but well worth it if there is not a professor in your direct field.
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions.

title: Technology and Society
reviews: A must-take for anyone interested in the tech space. Lectures are extremely interesting and cover topics from history, sociology, politics, and more. Definitely changes the way you think about technological development for the best! Assignments are also very reasonable and the professor/preceptors are very willing to help.
Definitely take this class! Dr. J is fantastic, the material is really interesting and relevant, the readings are engaging, and it is just an overall great class.  One of my favorite at Princeton.
Do the readings as they are required and think deeply about them. The articles have ideas that are helpful in the real world.

Don't be misled by the cross-listing: this is a sociology course. If you are into sociology, talking about frameworks and how things are socially constructed, this will be a really interesting course with a manageable workload. If you are like me, who doesn't really care for sociology and thought I would get to use some engineering skills in this class, avoid this one.

For a student taking this course it is essential that they keep up with course readings and are constantly thinking outside specific course information. Lecture attendance is also a must, as attendance is regularly taken.
Great course. Totally fascinating, not too demanding, and I walk away knowing so much more than I did going in! Highly recommended!

I would advise them to try and attend every lecture; my only complaint of the class is that there is lecture attendance, which is infrequent and adds stress to juggling all of one's lectures and commitments.

I would recommend this course! A great overview of the intersections of technology and society, very important in today's world. The content is very interesting, and Professor Vertesi is an engaging lecturer (though she speaks pretty quickly!). Workload is manageable, although the final project is frustrating and time consuming.
If you are getting the T&S certificate, you won't regret taking this course. The content is pretty intuitive, but you still learn quite a bit!
Interesting. It's an easy class for anyone who's used to SOC thinking, and STEM people can pretty easily get by just with knowledge and opinions. Gives people the idea that SOC is easier than it is.
Just listen in lecture, and it'll be alright.

Much more sociology than technology. Its really about applications sociological framing and thinking to technology less than how we can use technology to solve social issues. Still, many of the topics are very interesting and the class definitely shapes the way you think about technology in your daily life. Work load is incredibly manageable and the final project is not too bad if you attended the lectures of the first half of the semester.
Nice course, interesting. Doing the readings is helpful

Only take it if you are doing the certificate. This is a sociology class through and through. If you like that and want to think about the design of products "in a social context" this is for you. If that does not sound fun, avoid this class.
Really interesting class, fun readings.
Really interesting! Not a huge time commitment but you learn a lot that is useful no matter what you end up doing and that you can't easily get from any other class.
Really no reason not to take it. Not too much work, you'll learn a lot, although the final projects are a little annoying. Interesting lectures, interesting material. Really good class
Should take even if you don't want to complete certificate. Really interesting course for anyone.
TAKE IT!! If you love technology for your own sake take it.
Take this course! It doesn't matter if you don't know much about sociology or about technology. You just need a critical mind! Dr. J (Vertesi) is amazing!

There's a new topic presented every week and they are all super fun and interesting! Make sure to take the class with a friend, as there is a partner project that's worth 40% of your grade. Although, beware the class seems a bit arbitrarily graded. Fun topics though!
This course is really interesting and not too much work, Dr. J is an awesome professor. Definitely take it if you want to gain an essential perspective on technology and engineering.
This is a good course. I would recommend taking if you're interested in the topic. The workload isn't too bad, and all of the material is very straightforward.
take it !!! with dr j!!!! you will learn so much
take it, even if you don't need to for departmental/distribution. you will learn valuable things
descrip: Technology and society are unthinkable without each other, each provides the means and framework in which the other develops. To explore this dynamic, this course investigates a wide array of questions on the interaction between technology, society, politics, and economics, emphasizing the themes such as innovation and regulation, risk and failure, ethics and expertise. Specific topics covered include nuclear power and disasters, green energy, the development and regulation of the Internet, medical expertise and controversy, intellectual property, the financial crisis, and the electric power grid.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Geometric Representations for 3D Fabrication
descrip: This seminar explores the emerging world of 3D printers and computer-controlled fabrication devices. In particular, we focus on computational aspects, including the geometric representations that enable design, optimization, and simulation.

title: Independent Work with Design
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principle difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principles of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work with design is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.

title: Dreams and Nightmares in Hispanic Fiction and Film
descrip: From Artemidorus in antiquity to Freud in modern times, dreams and nightmares have been a perennial human concern. This course will explore political, philosophical, medical and psycho-sexual representations of dreams and nightmares by such authors as Cervantes, Zayas, Calderon, Cela, Martin Gaite, Munoz Molina, Bolano, Piglia and Vargas Llosa.

title: Topics in Number Theory
prereqs: Undergrads must obtain permission of instructor.
descrip: This course covers current topics in number theory. Specific topic information will be provided when the course is offered.

title: Democracy in India
reviews: Absolutely great course on Indian politics if they offer it again. Readings were not too much, and the course structure allows you to really focus on what interests you within the context of the class. Highly recommended if you have an interest in either South Asia or how democratic institutions work in other nations.
Do the readings! Come to class prepared to think and engage critically. The better the questions you come up with for class, the more informative the discussions will be.
Great class to learn more about Indian politics

Take the course! The material is fascinating and of tremendous importance. But this is one of those courses for which you really get out as much as you put into it. If you do most of the readings and come to class prepared, it can be a highly engaging experience.
The readings are insightful but the quality of the seminar discussions is poor.

This is an important course for any student interested in international politics or relations. The professor is a fair grader and does a good job facilitating discussion among students. I would recommend this course.
prereqs: Some basic familiarity with India and a parliamentary system of government is necessary or a willingness to read beyond class materials in order to catch up. It is not within the scope of the class to cover very basic questions like "What is a parliamentary system," "What is the Congress (it is a political party)" etc. Students are not expected to be experts on Indian politics, but should be willing to judiciously web search facts, names, or events they are unfamiliar with..
descrip: This seminar will focus on politics in India, a diverse and populous democracy. In a country characterized by deep, pervasive inequalities, how does democracy persist and what role does it play in mitigating or exacerbating inequalities? How do parties appeal to voters, what political differences are the most salient, and what role does the media play in a developing democracy? The class will include a contemporary component where students will be asked to track developments in Indian politics, through Indian newspapers, discuss them in class, and link them to class readings.

title: African American History to 1863
reviews: Definitely take this course!
Go to office hours. Speak up in precept, but also pay close attention to what your classmates and preceptor have to say.

I highly, highly recommend this class! The history is so important, and Professor Hunter is incredible. The reading load is manageable, especially for a history class. This class has a lot of writing assignments, but this also puts less pressure on the outcome of individual assignments. Even if there is more writing than other classes, it is worth it. I'm so glad I took this course! It's changed my life.

I would highly recommend this course; the period of American history through the civil war for African Americans is glossed over in most pre-college curricula in days or a week and it is multifaceted, nuanced, highly important, and fascinating.

I'm not gonna act like the workload isn't a lot, but it is worth it because you will actually learn so much in this class about a topic that's generally glossed over. Tera is a queen. Take Professor Hunter's precept if possible!
Just be prepared for a lot of assignments but Professor Hunter is wonderful and you learn so much.
Keep up with the papers, start early.

Take it! You will never learn this side of history anywhere else. It breaks down so many misconceptions we often hold about America's troubled racial history. Everyone should take this to be an informed citizen.
Take this course if you enjoy doing research and have a strong interest in the subject matter.

This is not an easy A. The grading is very subjective. You will need to do a lot of writing and will have to go to Mudd and the Rare Books section of Firestone for the four short research papers as well as the final research paper. However, the material is fascinating. We don't learn enough of African American history in our current educational system K-12.
it's a pretty interesting class but it's a lot of writing with little structure.
take this!
descrip: This course explores African-American history from the Atlantic slave trade up to the Civil War. It is centrally concerned with the rise of and overthrow of human bondage and how they shaped the modern world. Africans were central to the largest and most profitable forced migration in world history. They shaped new identities and influenced the contours of American politics, law, economics, culture and society. The course considers the diversity of experiences in this formative period of nation-making. Race, class, gender, region, religion, labor, and resistance animate important themes in the course.

title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop
prereqs: REL 518.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics. Note: REL 518 (fall) and REL 519 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Macroeconomics/International Finance Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Intermediate Russian II
reviews: Do all the work, otherwise it'll be hard to know what's going on.
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in improving their Russian skills. It's a very interesting and laid-back class. Just lots of time-consuming reading at the end of the semester.
prereqs: RUS105 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Major emphasis on the development of vocabulary and oral expression with continued presentation and review of grammar. Vocabulary thematically organized to include such topics as travel, city life, nature, hobbies, politics, etc. Training of all language skills in a cultural context. Vocabulary reinforced through reading of cultural texts.

title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared. BSE candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Medieval Architecture
reviews: Ask questions and contribute in class: the course is much better that way. Do the readings because they will help you write your papers cogently.
If you're really into architecture this would be a great class.
It's easy but not very interesting
Take it
Take it if you have any interest in beautiful architecture or Medieval times.
Take the course.

Take this course as an easy LA if you aren't interested in the subject, or have no prior knowledge or only a vague interest. I took this course as part of my major with a lot of prior knowledge, and found it immensely disappointing. You won't learn very much, but not much will be required of you.
This class is not as organized as the other art history classes I have taken. However, there is very little work besides papers and you get to look at cool buildings.
This is a great class, everyone at princeton should take it
take it
descrip: A survey of Western architecture and urban design from ca. 300 to ca. 1500 A.D, with a particular emphasis on Italy, Germany, and France. The aim will be to explore the major developments in religious and secular architecture in the West from Early Christian times to the Renaissance. Various aspects of architecture will be considered (patronage, functional requirements, planning, form, structure, construction techniques, symbolism, decoration) with the aim of attaining as complete an understanding as possible of architectural developments and urban design in their historical context.

title: Topics in American Literature - American Jewish Writers
reviews: A beautiful example of an English course-- you learn a lot about a history/culture/group of people through fiction. I loved it a lot and I think anyone could find it interesting, Jewish background or otherwise.
It was amazing! Just a little reading-heavy, but as long as you are willing to read a novel per week, you'll really enjoy it.
Lots of reading but an excellent course.  One of my favorites.
Take it!
Take this class to read and talk about great literature, but be prepared to spend a lot of time on the readings. Seminar is much more rewarding when you're prepared.

Take this course (or any with Prof. Schor)!!! She is someone who genuinely cares about your writing, will meet with you in person, and will consistently provide incredibly generous feedback on your work! She also keeps each seminar fresh with different activities (free-writing, group work, excursions, presentations, discussions). She is one of my favorite professors I've ever had.
This course is great if you're interesting in the topic. The readings were really cool and I enjoyed discussing them. I wouldn't take this course if you don't plan on reading the books, though!
This is a great English seminar!

Would recommend to anyone with an interest. You learn a considerable amount of history in the course and Professor Schor is fantastic. Also, she does a really good job of making sure people without much of a Jewish religious background don't get lost in the theological references. Be ready for a significant demand on your time from the reading, though, and understand that Jewish literature is often pretty depressing stuff.
a lot of reading
descrip: American Jewish Writers adopt a variety of personae: they may write as exiles, as citizens, as provocateurs, among other figures. Why these strategies--and what sort of mark have they left on American Jewish writing? On American letters? On modern Jewish literature? We'll consider the historic sweep of American Jewish writing from the 18th to the 21st centuries--and what better time, since the course coincides with the Princeton Art Museum's exhibition on American Jewish life before the Civil War. Students are invited to explore the collection, and develop docent talks as part of their coursework.

title: Religion, Freedom, and Equality--taught at Columbia University
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar considers religion's relationship to politics in the context of modern arguments for freedom & equality. The course is taught at Columbia University, & includes students & faculty from Princeton, Columbia, & Yale. The instructors are Jeffrey Stout (Religion, Princeton University), Akeel Bilgrami (Philosophy, Columbia University) & Philip Gorski (Sociology, Yale University). Topics include 17th-century English radicals; civil religion, secularism, & dialogical democracy; Marxism & its influence on Gutierrez, MacIntyre, & West; Gandhi, King, & Michnik.

title: Research Ethics & Scientific Integrity (Half-Term)
descrip: This course is concerned with the professional obligations of social science researchers. Topics covered include teaching and mentoring relationships, human subjects protections, professional codes of ethics, data management, peer review, collaboration, scientific misconduct (fraud, fabrication and plagiarism), conflicts of interest, and scientific agenda-setting. The course is intended for graduate students in Sociology and the Office of Population Research.

title: Buddhist Philosophy
reviews: A good course if you're interested at all in Buddhism OR philosophy. Would strongly recommend to get a non-Western perspective.
Be engaged and try to stay on top of readings.
Be prepared for precept every week.
Chill workload. Eye-opening philosophy. You might even attain Nirvana by the course's end, like I did.

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS COURSE, even if you aren't interested in Buddhism, this course is so helpful in helping you think creatively and analytically. Professor Gold is amazing and lectures and even the readings are always very interesting.
Decent course if you're interested in learning more about Buddhism. Stay away if you're not however. It can get boring fast. Midterm and Final were not too difficult.
Definitely take it.

Definitely take this course. It is an extremely easy distribution requirement. The only work is readings and postings in a discussion board each week for precept (which are graded for completion). The midterm and final are both 3 short answer questions that are only 500 words each. The material is relatively interesting even though it can be confusing at time.
Definitely take this.

Do not take this course if you are only interested in Buddhism for the religion, the stories, or the historical aspects. This course focuses heavily on the philosophical argumentation behind Buddhism, which can be confusing (metaphysics, emptiness, epistemology, etc.). However, Prof. Gold is extremely experienced in this field and if you are interested in philosophical arguments, this course is perfect for you.
Don't take this as a BS course - it's harder than it might seem. That said, the material is interesting and Prof Gold gives a solid lecture.
Even though it is easy to let your mind wander in lecture, if you focus you may be surprised about how much you learn.
Extremely boring. The only reason I showed up to class was because they check attendance. Ended up PDFing it.
Go to lecture - it really is very interesting material and you'll enjoy thinking about it.
Handle all concepts with patience and complete open-mindedness, and you will greatly enjoy this course!
I learned a lot and had a good time.
I loved it. Best/easiest PDF class ever.
I strongly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning what Buddhism is and the rich philosophical traditions within it.
If you PDF you literally don't have to do anything except the midterm and the final

If you are coming in looking for an easy A course, I don't think you would enjoy this class. This class is definitely challenging, at least to me, because I had a hard time trying to come up with creative arguments on the midterm and the final. But by all means take it if you are interested in Buddhism or philosophy.
If you like Buddhism, go for it! If you don't know anything about Buddhism but want to learn, definitely go for it!
If you think this an easy A think again.  Work is not demanding, but grading is pretty harsh.  Take to PDF.
Its a light and easy course.
Its an interesting class. Don't miss lectures

Lecture are really boring and dry but the readings and precepts balance that out. (Daniel is an AWESOME preceptor.) The dry lectures are worth the easiness of the class. Take home midterm and final are both really easy.
Make sure to read, attend lecture, and most importantly, go to precept!
More philosophical than I thought. Concept kinda hard
Not the most exciting class. Lectures were boring but precepts were somewhat engaging.
Occasionally dry/slow-moving, but an interesting introduction to central Buddhist philosophies/ideas. Definitely recommend it if you like philosophy. Not too rigorous -- definitely approachable.
Only take this course if you're actually interested in Buddhism. A lot of the concepts are foreign and quite abstract... so they won't be interesting unless you really like this topic.
Read.

Recommended for the sake of making you think about beliefs other than your own. Prof. Gold is generally a good lecturer, but has very dry humor that is hard to understand. Blackboard postings are a pain, but the only other work is take home essay midterm & final.
Take if you don't want a lot of work.
Take this class if you're interested in the subject and/or philosophy.

Take this course if you need an easy class or humanities requirement. Seems like a random subject to take but it really opens your eyes and gives you a more cultured perspective of the world. Professor is great as well.
Take this course if you want to learn about the subject, but it is a bit confusing.

Take this course if you're looking for something with not much work.  Definitely go to lectures and precepts (you get graded for attendance at both) and participate when you can.  Beware of how boring it is, but I would still recommend it.
The course is much more difficult than it sounds simply because of the density of the material.  Mr. Gold is fantastic and fair in his evaluations.

The ideas in this class will blow your mind! It is a great class to PDF because the workload is minimal and you still get a lot out by doing the minimum amount of readings because those are the ones focused on in precept and lecture. Also the take home midterm and final are reasonable short essay questions.
This class was one of my best classes. It was harder than I thought but I feel like I learned a lot because of the same reason.

This is the best class I have taken here so far. Gold is a great lecturer--very deadpan but also hilarious--and the course material is truly insightful stuff. I thought I knew about Buddhism before this class. I was so wrong. I think the great thing is that the class is less about the religion, and more about the thousands of years of philosophical debate that has occurred in India to make Buddhism what it is today. This is one of those perfect classes where the workload is relaxed, but its still truly interesting and engaging. Two short take home tests and that's it. They're graded pretty fairly, but you WILL spend a lot of time writing them, moreso than you would probably suspect. Or maybe that's just me...Anyway, take this class.
Very intensive look at Buddhist philosophy with a heavy emphasis on the nuts and bolts of Indic thought; lecture and precept participation is a must, because readings are frequently dense and opaque
Very interesting and non-time consuming class. Would recommend.
Very minimal workload, pretty interesting ideas but lectures very boring, readings often dry. Good 5th but not worth taking in a 4 course semester.

Very strongly recommend. However, you need to make sure to take the course seriously and not just view it from an orientalist perspective. This course can really provide a helpful lens for seeing and understanding the world.
You should really have an interest in the subject matter, otherwise you will be bored and lost.
You'll sometimes lose track of different theories or people, so try and always take a few minutes of the week to review the last week, and what has been built up to until that point of the course.
it is quite an interesting philosophy to learn
descrip: An introduction to the Indian Buddhist philosophical tradition from the time of the Buddha until its decline (c. 400 B.C.E - 1200 C.E.). Topics include Buddhism's view of the world, the person, and the path to nirvana; equanimity, compassion and meditation as core elements in Buddhist ethics; early Buddhist metaphysics; the doctrine of "emptiness" and its various interpretations in the Great Vehicle schools; Buddhist epistemology and philosophy of language; and modern attempts to apply Buddhist philosophy to contemporary philosophical issues.

title: Thermodynamics
reviews: Attend every precept and make sure to read the book carefully. Make sure to go to the office hours to do the PSets. The TAs are a big help.
Attend office hours!

GO TO OFFICE HOURS. BECOME FRIENDS WITH FELLOW CBEs. Thermo will honestly make or break you and determine whether or not you'll declare at the end of the year. It's definitely worth it. Despite how much I've struggled, I'm better for taking the class and am now 100% sure about declaring at the end of the year.

GO TO OFFICE HOURS... go to office hours... go to office hours... don't fall behind. And go to problem sessions. This class is known for being very difficult, but the problem sessions and frequent office hours make it doable.
Go to office hours, read the book
Go to office hours. Do practice quizzes and exams before taking the real one.
Go to precept every week and attend at least one (if not more) office hours per week! Understanding the problem sets thoroughly, while difficult, is essential to doing well in the course!
Have fun! bond with your classmates
It is not as bad as people make it out. Go to office hours. All of the preceptors are awesome. Try and read the book before the lectures.
It's not as horrifying as it sounds. Work hard as you do for your other classes and you'll be fine.
Liked the class a lot. Talk to the TAs. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on it though!

Make sure to go to office hours because that's the only way to get the pset done. Don't worry if some of the concepts don't make too much sense at first because everyone is confused. Take advantage of the amazing TAs you'll have too!
Make sure you have a good understanding of how to manipulate multivariable derivatives and integrals. Read the textbook before going to lecture and reread each chapter multiple times.
Not as hard as people say but do not underestimate either...ENJOY ;)
Only take if CBE and sure about it.

Prepare to invest more time in this course than you think it might need. The concepts are both complicated and proven with large amounts of math. I found that there was no difficulty memorizing things though, because by the time I had understood the section, I had read it enough times to fully ingrain it. Make sure you're interested in CBE, this course has persuaded sophomores to switch majors.
Put in the time and dont get behind.

Read the book closely - it's nice and clear and some of the homework problems are based off chapter examples. Go to AI office hours/email them if you are stuck on a problem because chances are there's a trick/seemingly random assumption you won't think of on your own. Go to Aksay's office hours if you have a more fundamental question or issue with a derivation. The AIs and Prof Aksay do care about the students and it's a big bonding experience. The material is pretty interesting, too.
Reading the textbook, attending office hours, and attending precept is far and away more beneficial to you than lectures.
Show up to office hours! The preceptors are very helpful, so don't be afraid to ask questions.
Stay ahead on the readings, attend precept and office hours and work with others to finish the PSETs. That is the only way to really learn the material in this course.

Take it if you are or are considering CBE. Read every section for the week over the weekend in order to understand the lectures fully. Also, the book is very brief and skips a lot of steps so search for online resources or ask the professor or preceptors the moment you get confused.
The instructors really care about the students and the material is relatively interesting for a CBE course (much better than 245).

This class has interesting material, and it is taught pretty well. The homeworks are more difficult than in most classes, so be sure to visit the TAs during office hours, and attempt the problems before seeing them. The powerpoints are helpful for conceptual problems, but you will need to go to office hours for learning how to approach problems algebraically. The exams are reasonable, but be sure that you understand the problem sets and past exams.

This class is very hard but not impossible to do well! The curve is kind (most get a B or A) and the material is much more engaging than 245. You'll find this out on your own if you take this, but Office Hours are a must and AIs are so helpful. Don't ever skip precept! Try and preread the lectures and book otherwise lecture might be hard to follow along and understand. The support system is incredible in this class, as long as youre willing to put in the work consistently!

This class was the most difficult one I have taken so far. I made the mistake of not keeping up with the readings from week one. If you do that, and do your honest best with the problem sets, then you will do amazing in the class. The preceptors are best of any class at Princeton, so use them as a resource. Good luck!

This course requires a lot of dedication to developing a deep understanding of things conceptually. It is very difficult, but taking advantages of the resources of precepts and office hours makes it much easier.
Work with friends and go to office hours as often as possible. It'll make your life easier.

You'd probably take this course because you have to. I don't know why you'd take this thermo course over any other. I'd look for ones that are more suited to people with no thermo background if you're taking thermo for the lols.
You'll take it if you need to.
You're probs taking it cause you have to... sorry. PS SANG IS THE BEST TA EVER
go to office hours and ask questions, hard, but doable!
learn as much thermo as you can beforehand, go to every office hour even if you dont think you need it.

you're obviously only taking this if you're CBE. GO TO OFFICE HOURS. literally every night. find a good group of people to collaborate with, but make sure you understand it or you won't do well on quizzes. be prepared for a large time commitment. reread the text several times
prereqs: CBE 245 and MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The course focuses on basic principles governing the equilibrium behavior of macroscopic systems and their applications to materials and processes of interest in modern chemical engineering. In the first half of the course we introduce the fundamental concepts: energy conservation (First Law); temperature and entropy (Second Law); thermodynamic potentials; equilibrium and stability; and the molecular basis of thermodynamics. These ideas are then applied to problems such as calculating the equilibrium composition of coexisting phases and reacting mixtures or analyzing the thermodynamic efficiency of cooling and power generation cycles.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: A generally enjoyable class.
I had heard some bad things about Paul's hands-off teaching style, but I loved it.
Poetry workshops are always worth it; invest yourself and you won't be disappointed.
Professor Muldoon is fantastic and I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to challenge themselves with protest poetry
Take CWR with Paul if you have a chance!!! He's phenomenal.

Take an Adv. CWR course ASAP if your even considering a certificate. The sooner you take them the better. Many people neglect to take 2 Adv. before the end of Junior year and thus cannot apply. Plus this is a great class for anyone who likes poetry.
The feedback you receive from your peers in advanced poetry is so helpful

This course changed my life. I grew a lot as both a poet and as a person through this class - it was quite possibly the best academic experience I've had at Princeton. 

Commit yourself. Have an open mind. Enjoy!
You should've taken this course, but Marie is visiting for only this semester.
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level poetry courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website (arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app) for application information. Application deadline is November 22, 2015..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of poetry for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the places of literature among the liberal arts.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Connectomics
reviews: Graduate level course in a particular topic. If the topic is of interest to you, the course is a must-take.
This course is not for the faint-of-heart, but if you are interested in the material and willing to  take on a serious term project, you should definitely go for it.
descrip: Survey of contemporary techniques in computational neuroanatomy. Brain imaging via light and electron microscopy; computer vision, graphics, machine learning, and crowdsourcing for neural circuit reconstruction; graph layout, spectral methods, and latent variable models for connectome analysis; examples of C. elegans and mammalian retina.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Securing Cyberspace with Big Data
reviews: Definitely take the course if you're interested in the topic.
Great course to take. You need to do some reading on your own to keep up with the topics.
Manageable workload and interesting topics.

The course is interesting, but focuses more on a few data structures and their theoretical bounds than practical application. There were also a lot of guest talks from industry. The industry talks provided an interesting and different perspective but they were more akin to management pitches than academic talks.
This is a must take course if you are looking for next generation of challenges related to big data analytics and cyber security.
prereqs: open to qualified undergrads/seniors.
descrip: This course teaches students how to search the type of "big data" that becomes routinely available to future cyber experts. In particular, it introduces students to distributed streaming data algorithms that are suitable for efficiently and effectively searching distributed and dynamic data warehouses for clues or evidence of suspicious network-wide traffic patterns or end host behavior.

title: Religion and Social Change in Early Latin America
descrip: A history of religion and social change, the role of the Catholic Church in society, and the dynamic between Christianity and Native American religious traditions from Spanish colonization to the early nineteenth century. We will grapple with the many paradoxes that characterized the role of religion in people's lives through the lenses of "conquest" and religious change in indigenous communities, women and men's daily encounters with church institutions and devotional culture, changes in religious expression over time, changes in ideas of race, gender, and spiritual status, and the changing relationship between the church and state.

title: Studies in Renaissance and Baroque Architecture
descrip: Advanced research in the history of architecture from 1400 to 1750. Topics vary, with the focus each year on important European centers and architects, and on issues related to architectural theory and practice. In spring 2016, this course considers the forms of early modern architectural theory, with particular attention on the history of the architectural book. We explore a set of key genres-including the treatise, the model book, the biography, the construction manual, and the travel narrative-through a close reading of primary sources and direct study of original objects.

title: Playwriting II: Intermediate Playwriting
prereqs: THR 205 and Program Director's permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen for more information at: tvasen@Princeton.edu.
descrip: A continuation of work begun in Introductory Playwriting, in this class, students will complete either one full-length play or two long one-acts (40-60 pages) to the end of gaining a firmer understanding of characterization, dialogue, structure, and the playwriting process. In addition to questions of craft, an emphasis will be placed on the formation of healthy creative habits and the sharpening of critical and analytical skills through reading and responding to work of both fellow students and contemporary playwrights of note.

title: Introductory Sculpture
reviews: Awesome class, Martha is an amazing teacher/person! Be prepared to devote a fair amount of time outside of class to it - it is well worth the effort though, and really rewarding. Plus working in the shop really is like a break compared to standard school work.
Definitely take this course! It is different from many other Princeton courses in that it helps you learn how to be involved with art and go from beginning to end with art projects.
Definitely take this course.
Definitely take this!
Definitely take under Martha. Very engaging, and thought-provoking.

Great class, definitely not one to take as an easy elective though - you will be spending a lot of time outside of class working on your sculptures. Martha is hilarious and wonderful and you will learn a lot about art and sculpture and your own artistic style through the various projects. Highly recommend!
Great course! Huge time investment, but definitely worth it if it's something you're interested in. Pam is super awesome!

Incredible course- makes you think in critical and spacial ways. Take it with martha - she has so much to offer (also a practicing artist). Great for humanities and engineers alike as it makes you think about how things are constructed in a theoretical but also practical sense. Favourite class all year.
Pam is a great instructor and you get to explore/try out a variety of different mediums. Not traditional sculpture, though, if that's what you're looking for. 10/10 would recommend this course!
Set aside a lot of time for this class and you will be rewarded.
Spend a lot of time working on your sculptures! It will make you happier with your results and feel you've learned a lot more.

TAKE IT! if you want to work in the shop with tools and your hands. At times it will take up a lot of your time but it will be a great class and well worth the time you put in because sculpture is sort of like a study break sometimes.
TAKE THIS CLASS WITH MARTHA
Take it!
Take it! Different experience but be ready to put in effort
Take this but be warned that it can take a surprising amount of time.
The sculpture classes are completely different depending on who is teaching. I took with Martha and she is amazing!
descrip: A studio introduction to sculpture, particularly the study of form, concept, fabrication and the influence of a wide variety of materials and processes on sculpture and its consequences. Students will develop an understanding of contemporary sculpture and a basic facilities in woodworking, metalworking, carving and casting.

title: Form Finding of Structural Surfaces
reviews: Be prepared for the plaster-mixing!
I would recommend
good class to take
prereqs: Open to all CEE and Architecture graduate students. Undergraduate students must get approval from Professor Adriaenssens..
descrip: The course looks at the most inventive structures and technologies, demonstrating their use of form finding techniques in creating complex curved surfaces. The first part introduces the topic of structural surfaces, tracing the ancient relationship between innovative design and construction technology and the evolution of surface structures. The second part familiarizes the student with membranes(systems, form finding techniques,materials and construction techniques) The third part focuses on rigid surfaces. The fourth part provides a deeper understanding of numerical form finding techniques.

title: The Medieval Period
reviews: A very interesting course with a very reasonable workload.

If you have any interest in Medieval literature, take this class. In addition to the great readings, you'll get the bonus of being able to learn how to read Middle English aloud - which of course is everyone's secret dream. Also Professor Smith is super knowledgeable, humble, and engaging. Good class material   good professor = a win.

There's a lot of reading, and it's pretty much impossible to skim Middle English, so this is maybe not a class to take in a semester with a lot of other ENG or reading-heavy courses. However, if you are interested in the Middle Ages and you have the time to really work with each text before class, you can get so much out of this class. Professor Smith really knows his field, and I found myself totally falling in love with some of the works we read.
descrip: This course will survey some of the most important medieval literature of England (partially excluding Chaucer). Violence is one of its obsessive concerns, and we will examine how its many forms--political, personal, philosophical--shape literary representations of war, insurrection, love, death, consolation, and the sacred. Readings will include many of the brilliant examples of different kinds of Middle English literature: chivalric romance, saint's life, the chanson d'aventure, mystical vision, debate, lyric, and elegy.

title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style
reviews: Do your homework conscientiously.
Excellent class, small size and lots of individual attention.  Lisa Hirschmann is a wonderful teacher!
Expect a lot of homework and reading.
Great course.

I entered SPA207 with a weak grammar background, which made it difficult for me to earn high grades on assignments. Though the course does not teach much grammar, often 40% of a student's grade (looking at the rubrics for assignments) is related to grammar, which means that you must have good grasp of grammar from high school or Princeton coursework--which I didn't. Make sure to do the homework on time, because the homework will often be the topic of the class on the due date. Gorka is a difficult grader, but is a wonderful man and an engaging teacher--I highly recommend him if you want to look forward to the fun you will have in class. Be prepared for a lot of group work.
I recommend this class if you want to improve your Spanish reading and writing skills.
If you want to improve your Spanish skills, I strongly recommend!
Its a difficult course but will definitely help your spanish.
Pretty easy for those coming from AP, some of the work is tedious but there isn't a lot of it.
So much fun!!! Make sure to do the readings and watch the assignments though! Doing them will only make the classes better.
Take the class, it's worth the time. Interesting, insightful, and good practice of the language. Get Gorka as your instructor if you can!
This is a great course to take following SPA 107. The material is really interesting and the professors work hard to make sure you improve. I would take this class again in a heartbeat.

Very enjoyable class, and I loved Gorka as a professor! However, the course is not easy. There is a decent workload, because you have weekly homework assignments, and it can get quite heavy around midterm time. Grading is quite strict, so you have to be careful with your assignments. If you love Spanish and will put in the effort to improve, this will be a good course for you. However, if you are looking for an easy course with minimal work, don't take it.
prereqs: SPA 107 or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed the Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score..
descrip: An advanced language course designed to increase students' fluency and accuracy in Spanish with an integrated approach to content: classes and assignments draw on various types of texts (literature, film, visual media) that focus on Madrid and Buenos Aires. Students hone their linguistic skills by engaging in discussions about the urban environment, and its cultural and artistic productions. The course aims to raise intercultural awareness and to explore the contexts in which cultural values and meanings are created. Reading and writing assignments cover different genres, and verbal interaction and personal production are actively encouraged.

title: Philosophy of Science
reviews: Ahh :) a great course really. Please take if you are deciding. It is pretty interesting and Dasgupta is a wonderful lecturer. I will admit that if you understand the readings, lecture can seem kind of repetitive, but go anyway.

As someone who has no background in science, some of the topics were difficult to grasp.  However, still incredibly interesting overall and definitely manageable - your entire grade is written work for which you have a lot of help available and it's nothing time-consuming either.  Definitely take with Professor Dasgupta - he's amazing!

Attend all the lectures. Making audio lectures is super helpful too. Dasgupta is a great lecturer. Although this course is often difficult and requires a lot of effort, it was very interesting! Def take it if your other courses are on the lighter side!

Dasgupta is an amazing lecturer, and while some of the content itself sometimes seemed a little circular, the course overall is great. If you're interested at all in things like general relativity without getting too involved with the physics of it, this is a perfect course for you

Dasgupta's lectures are really good! The argument mapping assignments he assigns also really help you learn how to write a Philosophy paper. However, make sure to choose a precept with attentive students!
Definitely take if you've ever had an inkling to "see behind the curtain" in your science class -- what's really going on when the science class establishes certain ideas or laws as its premises.
Definitely take this if you're interested in the philosophy of science. The readings are long and difficult.
Fairly low workload, fantastic lecturer (if Shamik is teaching it), good material
Great course to learn how to think about science and the world around us. Shamik and the levels system will make you smarter and more rational
I deeply enjoyed this class. As an engineer, this class helped me get to know philosophical arguments and it is not very hard. I enjoyed it!
