I really enjoyed this course by the end, but at first it seemed impossible. If you like thinking about cool scientific and philosophical problems, this class gives you that, and you can skip a lot of the readings if you go to lecture. That being said - go to lecture!!!

I think this course is a good fit for anyone interested in learning something about how philosophy and science interact. It's probably best to have some background in science or at least to find physics interesting. I think it is a good way to learn what modern philosophical argument can look like, in a formal/analytical approach. There are probably better options for students who are very serious about learning advanced material in the subject - the course was a fairly elementary survey of the subject.
I thought that this course was extremely interesting and well-taught. The lectures were very engaging and the material was pretty fascinating. I definitely recommend this!
I would look for something else - I don't feel like either my scientific knowledge or my philosophical skill increased that much.

I would take this class if you are any science student looking for an EC because it was great to learn about where the ideas and theories you use actually come from and the larger idea of what these scientific things actually mean.

If the lecturer is good and known to be good at reducing and simplifying information, definitely take the course. Without a good lecturer, I guess take the course but make sure you get a good preceptor. Without good instructors, you might as well just read papers yourself and learn equally as much. Good for both quantitative and non-quantitative people.
If you are just looking to fulfill a philosophy distribution, I would recommend some other course that has easier concepts to wrestle with (like practical or normative ethics).
If you don't like the first few classes, they don't get any better. Make sure you're interested in the material.
Interesting class at the intersection of philosophy and science that may be particularly appealing for STEM majors.
Professor Dasgupta is good. Take his classes.
Really interesting. you learn a lot. Dasgupta is a fun lecturer.
Take if you have a burning desire to ask questions that don't really need to be asked.
Take it! It's really interesting, not incredibly hard, and Shamik is a great teacher.

Take it. Dasgupta is phenomenal and the material is interesting from both a scientific and philosophical perspective. Would recommend for people in any concentration. Good for a first philosophy course.

The beginning of the course is a bit slow, but by week 4 and 5 things start to pick up. Stick with it for the material after the midterm. The levels system makes this a very fair course for those who haven't taken a philosophy class before. Professor Dasgupta is a fantastic lecturer and great with questions. His conceptual explanations of concepts were far and away better than anything I have received in a STEM class. Highly recommend for physics/STEM majors who need an EC.

The topic is interesting and lectures were good, but the best part of this class was definitely learning how to do argument maps and being able to do the levels system - it's really helped me understand arguments not only in this class but in all my other philosophy classes (and, to be honest, in most humanities classes).

There seems to be two ways of doing philosophy of science, one more philosophical, the other more scientific. Our class was more scientific in the sense that we looked mostly at actual scientific theories rather than considering the methodology of science as a whole. I think the flavors of these two types of philosophy of science are fairly distinct so make sure you enjoy the type being taught in your semester.
This class is a great chance for science majors to think about the "grey areas" of science that are usually not discussed in science classes.
Very cool class! Would definitely recommend if you're at all interested in the subject, but it's not particularly easy.
Very interesting materials and actually learned to think/speak more intelligently after taking the course.

Very worthwhile. Fantastic lecturer, even if you don't have background in either philosophy or science (mostly theoretical physics), though you may need to brush up on one or the other. Course addresses both technical and fundamental concerns. The levels system is a great form of evaluation. Great "trying new things" course.
take it, good class
prereqs: No prerequisites; all relevant science will be introduced in class form scratch..
descrip: The concepts of space, time, and chance have long been of interest to philosophers. This class will investigate how our thinking about these concepts has been shaped by developments in science. Topics may include: (1) What does physics teach us about the structure of space and time? (2) Is there a scientific explanation of the flow of time? (3) Are chances in quantum mechanics objective, or just measures of subjective uncertainty? (4) How are chances in high-level sciences like biology and economics related to physical chances? Along the way we will discuss the question of realism vs anti-realism in science, and the problem of induction.

title: Loss and Longing in the Anglo-Saxon Era: Elegy & Elegaic
reviews: Don't be intimidated by the course's title, or even by the first seminar. Everyone will soon be on equal footing, and Professor Anderson welcomes all different academic backgrounds for the course.

I highly recommend taking this and/or any other class offered by Prof. Anderson! She is fabulous and incredibly knowledgeable about her subject matter, as well as wonderful at bringing in numerous points of view and avenues of academic discourse on a topic. Students who have previously taken her Old English class will probably get the most out of this class, but really anyone would benefit from taking it!
I would recommend this course for any student who has an interest and feels that they can handle the environment of a high level discussion based seminar.
Sarah Anderson is one of the best professor's at Princeton (in my opinion). Take her classes.
Take a course with Professor Anderson if you love literature--it doesn't matter if you're a trained medievalist or not. She's fantastic and you will be glad you met her.
prereqs: A knowledge of medieval literature and of Old English would help, but are not assumed. All texts in languages other than Modern English will be available in translation. Supplementary reading gladly supplied by the instructor..
descrip: The "art of losing isn't hard to master," claims modern poet Elizabeth Bishop. Yet the genre of elegy in English isn't easy to master or account for. We write elegies because we are shredded by loss. But of what does the art of representing what we lose consist? We will consider the searing witnesses to yearning and regret in texts of the Anglo-Saxon period to learn what could be mourned, who could grieve, and how one could be consoled. By methods comparative and critical, we will read how these millenium-old speakers comprehended, and perhaps even mastered, their losses.

title: Russian Science-Fiction (SF) in the 20th century -Utopia-Dystopia-Post-Utopia
descrip: The course will trace the development of Russian science-fiction, moving chronologically from the early twentieth century through the Soviet period to the present. It will also serve as an introduction to Russian politics (since many of the works are profoundly political) and to Russia's great literary tradition (since science fiction was practiced not only by science fiction specialists, but by the foremost writers).

title: Research in Architecture
reviews: I highly recommend the course!
Make sure to participate to get everything out of the course
Thorough
descrip: This course is an advanced pro-seminar that examines the spatial histories and representational forms of the modern city and advanced technologies. Students read architectural, urban and theoretical texts and conduct individual research on how spatial theory and technological advances affects the manner in which cities and architectural forms have been written about, envisioned and built.

title: Main Currents of Spanish Thought, 1848 to the Present - Spain: The Struggle for Modernity
reviews: A worthwhile experience. The reading material is stimulating and Angel has very insightful, careful readings of all of them. Really good if you're approaching the books for the first time or for coming back to them.
Definitely take this class.
This seminar is a great decision to learn about how to think critically and from different points of view.
descrip: An examination of processes of national construction in 19th and 20th century Spain, in connection with history, modernization, gender, subjectivity and social class. Among the topics to be discussed: country, city and migration; women and modernity; history and tradition; Hispanidad and Spanish nationalism; culture of the Spanish Civil War; subjectivity, social class and nation under Franco; history and memory in democratic Spain.

title: Creative Exploration of Color in Life and Art
descrip: See website

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science and Engineering
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering. Non-Credit. Enrollment by application..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars. To apply, visit http://www.princeton.edu/writing/wse

title: Experimental Physics
reviews: A great core lab course.  You learn a lot and the material is interesting.  Take it even if you don't have to; you'll learn about how physic sis really done and get to use some cool stuff.  Graded generously if you can show that you've put in effort.
Brace yourself and get help often.

Definitely take this class- it's going to be one of your favorite classes ever! Do yourself a favor, though- start your labs as early as possible. That way you'll have plenty of time to tinker with things and actually have fun instead of stressing out over fast-approaching deadlines. And experimental physics is not as simple as you might think it is...a lot of things go wrong in unexpected ways!

Even if you are not a physics major (contrary to what other comments might say) I would think this is an interesting and useful course to take. If you are at all interested in engineering or other types of experimental work, this class will expose you to how it is done in physics. Additionally, the experiments are really something else... world class.
Fun class. Try to find people you'd work well with. Try to find labs you will find interesting.
If you have to take this class, take it - it's good.
If you're taking this, you're a physics major. If you're a physics major, you're taking this. It's actually better than you might think.

It's actually a great course and a lot of fun. Even though I want to do theoretical physics, I really enjoyed this course, and it wasn't much work at all. The format is absolutely amazing. At some point I was thinking of not being physics because I dreaded this course, but it was a very fun class. I would recommend it even for non majors. Take it Junior year after taking quantum though.

It's all about picking the right labs. 21 cm line and interferometry were VERY easy. Mossbauer was pretty easy to perform, but conceptually a little bit difficult. Start early on the electronics lab. Don't do optical tweezers!!
Loved this course!! Spent a lot of time in lab, but the experiments were very interesting and rewarding.
One of the more enjoyable physics courses. Perhaps not saying much, at least to me, but I thought it was well taught and well run.
Some people might really like this class. You know, the kind that enjoys coding for fun or has a fetish for Excel. I am just not one of those people.

This course is fascinating, in addition to being extremely organized. The labs, the supplementary lectures on electronics and other topics, and the professors make this course completely worth your time, and while a large amount of work is expected, it is also manageable.

This course was great, and the experiments offered are a  unique opportunity to use various apparatus, learn more about experimental techniques and data analysis. The positron annihilation and optical pumping labs were very interesting.
This is a great course and a good introduction to the experimental world. Would definitely recommend taking it!

This is a really great and fun class! Marlow is a great professor. Get started on labs early; it lets you collect more and better data, and gives you more wiggle room. You learn a lot from the labs, and they're way more fun than the freshman labs, and you learn a lot about practical electronics.
This is a very interesting course that allows you to deepen your knowledge of experimental physics and to master the analytic skills you need to make sense of data.

Try to start the labs early ? at least the prelabs, so you start thinking about how the experiment works. Don't be afraid to ask your peers and your instructors for help! They're very helpful and will push you to learn things on your own!
You probably have to take it if you are considering it at all. The course is demanding in terms of time and effort, but the effort pays off in the amount of things you learn.
good course, labs are fun - learn how 'real world' physics works!
prereqs: PHY 103/104 or equivalent; PHY 208 or equivalent. Not recommended for sophomores..
descrip: Students work in small groups and perform four experiments and an electronics lab. The list of experiments to choose from includes muon decay, beta decay, optical pumping, Mossbauer effect, holography, positron annihilation, electron diffraction, single photon interference, NMR, the Josephson effect, and an observation of galactic hydrogen. Weekly lectures will provide an overview of various experimental techniques and data analysis.

title: Theoretical Machine Learning
reviews: Go to all the lectures since the material is not really available elsewhere.
I had a great time and learned a lot. Make sure you're comfortable with basics of machine learning and statistics, or that you're comfortable learning on your own as you go.
Not a huge fan of the class. Decent introduction to theoretical ML, very biased views and list of topics.
Recommend if interested in theory of machine learning, as this course is primarily focused on online convex optimization

Take it if you're interested in theory and are willing to spend time/effort really figuring out the math and details. This is more of a typical graduate course where the material is hard and there is a fair amount of handwaving in lectures. The course didn't have a practical/programming aspect at all, so don't expect that coming in.
I would also take it just for Professor Hazan because 1) he's extremely approachable/kind/helpful 2) he's an incredibly high impact researcher in the active field of online learning.
To undergraduates: make sure you have a friend with strong math background or you have taken a real MAT class before you take this class.
You may want to take note of Elad's suggested prerequisites. I did not and had to spend a fair amount of time catching up. Worth it.
good class
descrip: This course introduces theoretical machine learning, including mathematical models of machine learning, and the design and rigorous analysis of learning algorithms. Likely topics include: intro to statistical learning theory and bounds on the number of random examples needed to learn; learning in adversarial settings and the on-line learning model; using convex optimization to model and solve learning problems; learning with partial observability; recommendation systems and matrix learning; how to boost the accuracy of a weak learning algorithm; universal portfolio selection; learning in games.

title: Seminar in Romance Linguistics and/or Literary Theory - Levinas and Blanchot
descrip: A seminar on the work of Emmanuel Levinas and Maurice Blanchot, following the development, from a common origin in German phenomenology, of the ethics and the aethetics for which they are respectively well known.

title: Into the Deep Past
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to the Evolution of Jazz Styles
reviews: It was great! Enjoyed every class.
Make sure you do the readings, otherwise you cannot participate in class discussion.
This class would benefit from a more comprehensive and prepared curriculum.

This is a great course if you're genuinely open-minded and interested in the music. Even if you already know a lot about jazz, there's always more to learn, plus you get to take a class in which you get to just talk about and listen to this music and get graded for it (so why wouldn't you take it?)

This is a wonderful course to take if you are at all interested in music and/or African-American history. One of the best parts about this course is that it's listening-heavy, so unlike other LAs you won't be buried with reading and writing assignments. I would highly recommend taking this class!
You will enjoy some eras more than others. It is also super cool to notice the things you talk about it class appear in popular culture music.
descrip: An introductory survey examining the historical development of jazz from its African origins through the present. The course will place an emphasis on the acquisition of listening skills and will explore related musical and social issues.

title: The Wise Guys: Readings in Biblical Wisdom Literature
prereqs: JDS 302 or permission of instructor..
descrip: We will read selected passages of Biblical Wisdom Literature (primarily from Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, and Job). Particular attention will be paid to techniques of generating ambiguity in Wisdom Literature. The course is open to students who have completed JDS 302, as well as students with intermediate/advanced Biblical Hebrew.

title: Statistics for Social Science
descrip: The Course will consist of an introduction to probability as well as key topics in statistics and how they can be used in the public policy realm. Subject areas will include random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression modeling. The data sources will include pubic policy examples. Stata, a general purpose statistical programming package will be used to perform the statistical analysis.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Institutions
reviews: A good class to take for the practical applications, and it is probably one of the more "applied" courses at Princeton since Yully really emphasizes the connection of course material to the real world. Also, Donghwa is a fantastic preceptor, and Yully/the preceptors are all really engaged and helpful!
Better than 362
Boring topic but Yuliy makes it not totally unbearable, and the exams are a good level of difficulty.

Certainly take this class if you are interested in finance. The case studies and real life examples truly make the class very interesting, while at the same time, you cover a good amount of theory behind corporate finance.
Class is worth taking; conceptually much of corporate finance is very interesting and applicable to lots of different fields.
Decent but relatively uninteresting. Only take if needed for the certificate/departmental.

Definitely take this course. I thought it was extremely interesting and that Professor Sannikov is a great professor who knows his stuff and produces excellent PowerPoints for us to follow. This course is WAY better than ECO 362. ECO 362 was a crash-course through all of finance and I felt confused a lot because there was very little guidance. ECO 363 goes at a much better pace and examples/problem sets are clear and helpful for learning the subject matter. However, I would definitely recommend coming into the course with prior background in finance and investment jargon, as it is extremely useful for learning the more difficult concepts. On top of that, everyone else in the class has background in finance so you should know the basics before venturing to this course. Lectures are too long, so they get boring even though Professor Sannikov is good. Precepts are very unhelpful too. But on the whole, solid course. Would recommend even if you do not plan to have a career in finance because these concepts are useful for everyone regardless of major.

Do not take this class if you think you are not interested in finance. I took this class for "fun" -- no certificate, no interest in financial sector, no prior knowledge of finance. I couldn't really say I enjoyed it...
Do this to see if you like corporate finance and want to go into banking/PE/whatever
Dropped the finance certificate and P/D/F'd the course after a month or so because I hated this course so much. Don't do finance unless you actually like this mundane, superficial, douchey field.
Finance is lame and take other classes, but this class is still well taught given its task of teaching such boring material.
Go to precept its worth it!
Good course
Good course to take even if you don't want the finance certificate. Best with 362 taken beforehand because it builds on those concepts
Good intro on fundamentals of corp fin. Light course-load
Good intro to financial world
I would definitely suggest taking this course.
I would take this course if you are interested in business or finance. One of the more useful courses at Princeton.
I'd recommend this course if anyone wanted to solidify what they learned after taking ECO 362. It also pretty interesting in itself.
If you are interested at all in going into anything related to business--not necessarily into finance/banking--this is a good class to take for a basic knowledge of corporate finance.
Make sure you have some basics before taking this class, I had no finance background and it was manageable, but would have been much better with a better background.
Midterm was difficult. Psets are reminiscent of real-world problems and can be a bit vague. Professor is helpful and very receptive to feedback! Not too bad overall
OK class, boring material but moderately useful.
Required for Finance Certificate students. For others, it's an interesting way to learn more about "how the real world works" and would have been useful before junior Finance recruiting.

Study hard for the midterm and be sure to understand the dividend growth model. Midterm was very long and it was difficult because of the time allowed. Do a lot of practice tests, study problem sets, and read the powerpoint lectures.
Take it - it's very well-taught and it's interesting
Take it for Finance, you will be ok

Take it if you are interested in corporate finance, the professor is great. Beware that the midterm is usually really hard, and the final is tough, but the assignments are fair, and if you are pursuing the finance certificate it doesn't really matter since this is required. Just know, that this material is usually really important for any job or internship in finance, so I would recommend taking it if you are pursuing that path.
Take it if you have a general interest in finance, regardless whether you go to lecture. It's one of the more valuable classes that can be used in the real world.
Take it if you have to, would guess other electives are better for general corporate interest. 362 is a better choice for exposure to financial concepts.
Take it to know whether you want to do corporate finance/banking. It helped me make my decision a lot better.
Take it! Not easy, but definitely worth getting exposure to this material. Lecture slides are easy to study off of. Problem sets are kind of tough--go to office hours for them!
Take the course if you want to learn about corporate finance, because Prof Sannikov covers a lot of important material. Go to lecture, because the slides can be difficult to decipher without lecture.

Take this class even if you are not planning to go to finance. This is a very useful class to learn the basic finance concepts in everyday life. It's also organized like a business school class with lots of case studies and real world examples. It's less theoretical than usual econ classes and I really enjoyed that. You need a practical class once in a while and this class helps you learn about the real world and gives you useful skills.
Take this class if you need it for the finance certificate. Pretty easy, not much work, short problem sets. Overall pretty chill.
Take this course if you are interested in finance at all. It gives a good overview of various aspects of the financial world.

Take this course if you have any interest in corporate finance, how companies make decisions, or want to go into banking. Sannikov is the one of the nicest professors you'll meet here - so speak up during class when he asks for volunteers! Problem sets are reasonable, and exams are manageable. Best yet, the professor takes into account student suggestions midway through the course and adjusts accordingly. This resulted in the second quarter having more guided psets, as well as content that was more geared towards students' interests.
Take this only if you have to or if you're really interested in the material. Professor Sannikov teaches well but the material can get quite dry at times.
The material is pretty interesting if you're interest in finance/ wall street stuff.  Also, Yuliy is really nice and a pretty good lecturer.

The topics you learn are very relevant to the real world, but it can be a bit dry. Yuliy does his best in making the material interesting. Overall, I would recommend the class even for those who aren't pursuing a finance certificate because a lot of the topics are important to understand. I took it without taking ECO 362 and don't think it really should be listed as a prerequisite.
This is actually a really good class! Lectures can be dry at times, but I thought I learned a lot.
Useful, easy and pretty good class.
Very Interesting Content
Very good course to take if considering going into finance. Honestly, I would have done fine if I saved the 160 minutes every week and instead read the Powerpoint notes when necessary.
Very hard. Make sure to be fully immersed in the material
Very practical, good if you're doing a finance internship/want to do ibanking
You pretty much have to take it. It's not bad. You'll be fine
definitely take if you have any interest in the very basics of how businesses work and how financial institutions analyze businesses. very useful knowledge even if not finance/econ etc major
finance requirement otherwise don't
more useful than 362 for finance recruiting; consider taking before junior fall.
only take it if have to take it
you learn a lot which is good, lectures not necessary.
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 362.
descrip: This course investigates the financing decisions of companies and financial institutions in the wider context of the workings of financial markets. Topics include capital budgeting, capital structure choice, risk management, liquidity, corporate governance, and the interactions between corporate finance and the workings of financial institutions and markets.

title: Elementary Persian II
reviews: Anyone should take this course because it truly is a beautiful language.
Take it. You won't regret it. Amineh is amazing and she is incredibly helpful and sweet

Take this course if you enjoyed 101! The readings and content are so much better and more engaging--I got a lot out of this semester and looked forward to going to class everyday. Professor Amineh is extremely welcoming and a great instructor.
prereqs: PER 101 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop the skills of understanding, speaking, reading and writing modern Persian. The classes are conducted mostly in Persian with emphasis on oral drills and conversations.

title: Classical India from Rigveda to Kamasutra through Verbal and Visual Art
descrip: See website

title: Empire and Global Regimes
descrip: Course investigates the relationship of empires to global regimes and processes. Students apply theoretical perspectives on empires and global regimes drawn from the disciplines of history, political science, and sociology, and seek to develop their understanding of the role of empires as mantles of global exchange and as sources of the rules and norms that have governed global affairs. Offered as part of a John E. Sawyer Seminar, this one-time-only course features five guest lecturers.

title: The Other Side of Rome
reviews: Definitely take it for an Em if youre interested in classics!
Feldherr is a great professor. Good course to PDF if you like classics.
Good course to satisfy distribution requirement! For students more interested in literature/history

If you have not previously taken courses in the Classics or taken Latin, be advised that you will have to do a lot of studying just to pass the exams. However, the content is interesting and the readings can be fun.
Not very interesting, easy to do well
Take it for an easy and interesting EM
Take it if you are interested in knowing about the less addressed issues in Rome: slavery, women, family, etc. Amazing professor. I personally enjoyed the class.
Take it if you want to learn more about how Romans reflected on their own culture!
Take notes on the readings throughout the course, it'll help you prepare for the final and midterms and help keep all the names and dates straight.
This course is a great way to get acquainted with Rome and Roman culture. However, if you already know Rome pretty well, much of the material will be redundant.

This is a pretty laid-back and interesting course if you have an interest in classics and/or want to get your EM requirement out of the way. The readings don't have much commitment, but you should work hard to edit your papers and ask the professor and/or preceptor for feedback.

Very good class if you are into history. I took it PDF because I needed a distro and really like Roman history. The readings were a bit heavy, but they were always interesting. Wouldn't recommend as a "PDF class" for the faint of heart or the non-interested. For everyone else, it's a great course.
descrip: An introduction to Roman culture designed to complicate the traditional image of Rome as a static, rigidly conservative society, the course will explore how the Romans used such issues as gender and sexuality, conspicuous consumption, and slavery to define the place of their civilization within the natural order. Authors like Petronius, Lucan, and Tacitus will focus our attention on the social complexities of imperial Rome. We end with a look at contemporary representations of Rome to ask what role stereotypes of ancient Rome have come to play in 20th century America.

title: Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics Simulation in Statistical Physics & Materials Science
reviews: Car's pace is not hard to follow and you will learn a lot from his course!
Take it if you have any interest!
descrip: This course examines methods for simulating matter at the atomistic scale with emphasis on the concepts that underline modern computational methodologies for classical many-body systems at or near statistical equilibrium. The course covers Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics (from basics to advanced techniques).

title: Slavery, Freedom, and the Archive
descrip: Given the conditions of loss, transience, and fragmentation that structure both the experiences and archives of slavery, is it possible to talk about a coherent tradition of African American literature before the twentieth century? This course will investigate that question by taking a book history approach to early African American literature and by exploring the problem of the archive and of the literary itself in the contexts of slavery and nominal freedom. Finally, we will explore the methodological and theoretical implications of studying slavery in an age of digitization.

title: Introduction to Data Science
reviews:
A very well-rounded, comprehensive introduction into data science.  I recommend for anyone on the fence about whether or not data science is a good career path for them or not.
I had at least a little programming experience coming into the class, which helped (although it was not necessary).

Challenging stats req compared to others, but you do learn a lot about data analysis and real world skills that are emphasized. Professor Storey and the preceptors are all really nice and it isn't too much work on a day to day basis since there are only four main projects.
Definitely start projects early so that you can go to office hours with any questions.
Fine course, but pretty dry.. Not very work intensive though.
Good survey of statistics, data science, and use of R and R Markdown. Projects are interesting and no exams.
Great class!
Great class! Teaches you the basics of stat and how to use R.
Great class. Informative and engaging.
Great course and alternative to cos 126 for Neuro majors.
I don't know if I'd recommend this. Some students seem to really enjoy/benefit from it. I did not.
I would recommend this class

If you want to learn R and are too lazy to do that on your own, consider taking this class. But be warned -- going to lecture is required because of (very easy but annoying) pop quizzes. I think this was a ridiculous thing to do, as Storey realizes his lecture slides are pretty much copies of the textbooks we use and also are self-contained in the sense that lecture doesn't add anything to your understanding. If you can audit or PDF the class and avoid going to lecture, definitely take it for an easy intro to R! If not, consider whether it's worth it for you -- I found that it's not.
If you're looking for an easy fifth class, take this course. Be sure to start assignments early, since they take a while, but there are only four and no exams.

It was the first iteration of the course, and even then I liked it. I think it can only get better from here. The only thing is that at times I don't feel like I learned stats to heart like in the traditional pencil and paper classes. However, I do feel like it was more of a programming class and  that I really learned to manipulate a data set using R.
It's a steep learning curve if you've never used R before.
Keep up with the weekly lectures and make sure you get help early and not wait untill the last minute before a project is due
Lecture is boring. You learn from the projects. A lot of the project work requires you googling to teach yourself.

Lectures were boring and felt like coding camp, but I learnt R, albeit probably 5x slower than I could teaching myself.  Still, a great introduction to one of the most powerful data visualization tools.  If you're in a quantitative social science, this class will upgrade your skills quite a lot.   Take it early if thats your major, otherwise take it whenever.
Make sure to stay atop on the material to do the homework.
Not an incredibly difficult class, but also may not teach you as much as you would like. I'd take it but not have the highest expectations
Not too tough a class, although the projects can be time-consuming.

Only take this class if you are really interesting or are required to take it. Very challenging without any prior R or machine learning knowledge but doable if you put in the time and effort. Go to office hours and ask questions on Piazza because the preceptors are SUPER SUPER helpful.
Start your projects early! Pay close attention in the lectures, even though it may seem boring and mundane material like codes in R.
Super interesting and definitely learn a lot. Also not stressful but does take a fair amount of time.

TAKE IT. This is an incredibly important course if you want to know how to do anything with data ? in the natural sciences, engineering, or the social sciences. When they say that you do not need to have a coding background, they actually mean it: the first project will get you up to speed on all the coding necessary. I have had experience in Java and MATLAB before taking the course, but I know some people who had absolutely no coding experience before and they also caught on pretty quickly. 

Start the projects early and ask Wei and Emily (the best preceptors at Princeton!) lots of questions and you will do fine. Storey is very reasonable about his expectations but he also will challenge you with the projects. Take it to learn data science, or even as an alternative to COS 126 if you need some coding experience but don't want to waste time doing Nbody and stuff.
Take it with people you know so you can work together on psets! Helpful and I find you understand the material better
Take this class if it is ever available! This course teaches you a real way to use R for data analysis that you're not going to get in your intro or even intermediate stats classes.
Take this course if you want a great crash course in R and basic statistics! You will learn a lot!

Take this course. Super practical, very applicable, interesting, and not too hard. Requires minimal effort, no exams. Projects take about 12 hours each and are actually interesting. Useful for any discipline.

The projects are a ton of work. I'm a WWS major and found this class to be really difficult. Would not recommend unless you were highly interested in the material and have a solid foundation in statistics.

This is really an introductory course -- there is a lot of overlap in the first few weeks with Q-APS R bootcamp, and in the middle of the course with ORF 245 / other intro stats courses. It's a good exercise to keep your R skills sharp, though, and the introduction to ML in the last two weeks is a good (and much less strenuous) introduction to more difficult courses (ORF 350, COS 424)...
Very good course to take before ORF 350 if you are interested in the field, a must if you are doing the SML certificate
You should come into this class with background in stats.
You will gain a lot of skills from this class. Great for beginners.

emily and wei were awesome. they were always willing to help via email or piazza or whatever and had good precepts. Lectures were boring but the notes were really well-done. Best part of the course was probably the project though. They were really cool. I came into this classing having a lot of coding experience so the first few weeks were a bit slow for me but i enjoyed learning R and all the cool stuff you can do with it.
make sure you can wake up early enough to get to class to take the quizzes but you'll probably zone out for most of lecture. Read OS3.
worth taking for R, but maybe not for statistics
prereqs: There are no official prerequisites for this course. However, it is recommended that students be comfortable with the basics of command-line computer usage and undergraduate-level mathematical notation and symbols (e.g., summation and product symbols, algebraic notation). Note: COS 126 or an equivalent course is NOT a prerequisite. Please see the course web site for further information..
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the burgeoning field of data science, which is primarily concerned with data-driven discovery and utilizing data as a research and technology development tool. We cover approaches and techniques for obtaining, organizing, exploring, and analyzing data, as well as creating tools based on data. Elements of statistics, machine learning, and statistical computing form the basis of the course content. We consider applications in the natural sciences, social sciences, and engineering.

title: Neuroscience of Social Cognition and Emotion
reviews: Do the readings and make sure to ask for criticism on the papers early on in the semester.

Great course. Workload mostly consists of weekly one page responses. Pretty interesting readings - made more interesting when Prof. Hasson puts them into context in his lectures. The seminar is a nice contrast to the many memorization-based, survey psych courses in the department. Professor Hasson encourages discussion and thought about abstract concepts, another difference from the average psych class.
Interesting NEU course, but the readings can be a little dense. Not a lot of weekly work though.
Not too much work and fairly interesting. Material can get a bit repetitive and dry.
Really depends on quality of student conversation.  Material is fairly similar to other neuro courses.
Stay on top of your readings and think critically. Do not miss a class because every lecture is intertwined.
prereqs: PSY 258.
descrip: This course explores the neural foundations of social cognition and social emotions. The objective is to provide a comprehensive overview of research topics relevant to the emerging field of social neuroscience. We will also discuss questions that cut across the specific topics that will be covered. Do neural systems exist that are specialized for social cognition or do the systems that participate in social cognition have more general cognitive functions? Can neuroscientific research shed new light on social cognition? How can different disciplines in neuroscience and the social sciences contribute to social neuroscience research?

title: Humanistic Perspectives on the Arts - The Enacted Thought: Performance Practices and the Theatres of Learni
descrip: This course examines the relationship between cultures of performance and cultures of pedagogy in the modern period. The last thirty years have seen a range of new creative experiments at the convergence of critical and creative discourse -- leading to new categories of thought-theater like the "Performance Lecture," together with various art-space re-imaginings of the scenography/dramaturgy of teaching and learning. We reach back in an effort to recover a genealogy for these contemporary crossings of pedagogy and performance. Our aim? A deeper appreciation of the inosculation of stagecraft and mindwork since 1600.

title: Leaders and the Making of U.S. Foreign Policy
reviews: Absolutely a must take. Professor Yarhi-Milo is brilliant and the content of the course is incredibly interesting for anyone who has even the slightest interest in politics, both domestic and international.
Ambivalent about this course.  Really interested in the subject material, liked the readings.  Prof not terribly accessible.  Not convinced leaders matter
Do the readings thoroughly! They're vital in understanding later material and Dr. Yarhi-Milo wants you to be able to synthesize information!
Highly recommend this course, extremely interesting blend of psychology and international relations, Professor Yarhi-Milo is engaging and insightful

I recommend the course for students who are interested in an alternative approach to the study of politics that focuses on the important role of leaders as individuals who command incredible influence.  The material is very cutting-edge, as it applies psychological concepts and methods to the study of politics (which has traditionally never been done).
I'd say take it. It's worth learning about whether or not leaders matter, and helps you to think about how you can apply certain frameworks on a daily basis.
KYM is the coolest and this class is information and a perspective that you won't get anywhere else. take it, if just to say you've taken a class with her--she's going places.
TAKE
Take this class if you're very interested in the material and have medium-strong writing skills. You also have to be able to read everything under the sun in a week to survive.

This is a good course that will expose you to a different section of the IR literature. I'd especially recommend this course if you've already taken intro IR, as it will give you a different perspective. The course is not much work, though the lectures can be pretty dry.
definitely take - a lot of reading but worth it
hard but interesting
descrip: How do US presidents make foreign policy decisions? The class will review the constraints, dilemmas, risks and opportunities that American presidents face during international crises and wars. It will expose students to alternative explanations for how states make foreign policy, with an emphasis on the decision-making process. We will critically analyze the decision-making process that led to the undertaking of major and historical decisions in the US history, and will conduct simulations of potential crisis scenarios.

title: Religion and Culture Workshop
prereqs: REL 521.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows. Note: REL 521 (fall) and REL 522 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Introduction to Architectural Design
reviews: I had so much fun in this course, but I am an architecture major and love making models and creating things. If you're not interested in architecture or designing, it is not for you. It will take up a lot of time outside of class. But if you are thinking about majoring in architecture, this class will give you a clear idea of what it's like.

I loved this class. I was good at it. I enjoyed it. That being said, I picked this up as a side-LA, which has been one of the greatest mistakes I've made here at Princeton. This is the architecture weeder course, in my opinion. I can not put enough emphasis on how much time this course will take up. Expect to put in 80-90 hours over the last six weeks. You come to appreciate studio time.

Unless you are a prospective/are a architecture major, DO NOT, DO NOT, DO NOT take this class. I loved it and died for that love.

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who has even the slightest interest in architecture, although especially to those intending to major in the field. The course requires a large amount of time and effort both during and outside of class hours, but the communal nature of the studio space and exciting projects make it worthwhile. This was my favorite architecture course during my time at Princeton so far.

If you are an architecture or civ-arch major, you have to take this class. But it's definitely worth it! Lots of hours, but you'll bond with your classmates and it'll be a great time. Paul and the AIs are going to be extremely helpful!
It is not necessary to know or have an appreciation for famous architecture projects to create interesting projects in this course, but it may enhance the experience.
Keep your hands steady. Model building is difficult. Not like surgery, I imagine, but more than my shaky fingers could handle.

MAKE SURE YOU HAVE ENOUGH TIME FOR THIS CLASS--VERY TIME CONSUMING and your friends will complain about how you're always in the studio. 

Have some kind of knowledge of architectural theory/ideas before taking this class or else you'll struggle with understanding the basic goals of the assignments. Honestly, I asked so many questions about each assignment, but I still don't know what I was supposed to take away from it because this was my first arc class and I didn't understand a lot of the terminology used in assignments/project explanations. 

It also helps to be kind of crafty, so you can finish your models faster without sacrificing craftsmanship. Not that you can't develop those skills, it just definitely helps to have them already.
Only take it if you have 20 extra hours a week to spare and are legitimately interested in architecture.

Paul was one of the most helpful professors I have ever met. He's super engaging and makes you want to talk about design and space forever. I'm so glad that he took the time to stop by and reconsider design with me on a regular basis, and I only wish I had had more time to pick his brain. I am a COS major, but I am so glad that I took this class. It has taught me so much about how my mind works. I took this class with four other time-intensive classes, so take my fair warning and know that you may be living at the studio ever so often. If you are a freshman, don't be afraid to take this class. You won't regret it, though you might pull one or two all-nighters.

Prepare for a lot of growth in how you view yourself as an architect/ designer and some growing pains along the way. There will be times when you don't like your project anymore and get tired of it, but those are the times it is really important to keep working so that you don't slowly slip behind on your work. Even if you stay on top of your work for this class, the last week is going to be major crunch time because you might have to remake your physical model and drawing matrix within 48 hours. In those moments the friends that you've made in studio will be there for you!
Take it as long as Paul is teaching it! He's an incredible professor. It's a lot of work but it's super enjoyable and studio life is the best!
Take it even if you're remotely interested in architecture! Paul is great, the projects are interesting and you'll learn basic skills in Rhino.
Take this course if you're interested in architecture, shaping spaces, etc, but be prepared to put in the time. Start early and always seek feedback.

Take this only if you are an ARC major or are considering ARC as a major. It is a ton of work, very rewarding, but not worth the time you put into it if you're not planning to major in ARC. But Paul is awesome, the AI's are awesome.
This is a good first studio course. Paul is a really encouraging professor. Because it is a studio, it obviously takes a lot of time so plan your schedule accordingly!
This is lot of work, but is rewarding and interesting.
Would recommend.

YOU GET YOUR OWN DESK. Enough said. Although that desk comes with the price of many many hours of work every week. Architecture major or not, this is a highly stimulating class that will let you reenvision space around you.
a wonderful first studio experience, you will learn a lot
take the course
prereqs: ARC 204 is a prerequisite for entry into the departmental concentration. Students will be expected to purchase materials in order to carry out various assignments..
descrip: The first in a series of design studios offered to students interested in majoring in architecture. The course will introduce architecture as an "impure'' plastic art, inseparable from a network of forces acting upon it. The student will be confronted with progressively complex exercises involving spatial relations in two dimensions, three dimensions, and time. The course will stress experimentation while providing an analytical and creative framework to develop an understanding of structure and materials as well as necessary skills in drawing and model making. Two three-hour studios with lectures included.

title: Art, Apartheid, and South Africa
reviews: Good course to take if you are looking to PDF and are interested in the subject.

If you are looking for an interesting course to take, this could be the one. Prof. Chika is an experience and an excellent, intelligent, and thoughtful professor. He brings a lot of insight into the classes and draws on a plethora of his personal experience as an artist.
Professor Okeke-Agulu does not disappoint. Do the readings and participate actively in class. The topics presented are very interesting.
Take it! The professor and subject matter are very interesting.

Take the course to gain a thorough understanding of South African art politics.  You will emerge with a good base in this subject matter. Be prepared for many readings per week, and plan your time accordingly.
This was incredible class! Professor Okeke-Agulu will teach you how to think about art, politics, and history, and how to apply this to anywhere in the modern day.
Very interesting subject manner! Professor Chika is awesome - take it if you are interested in one of the three - race, sociology, or art history.
descrip: Apartheid, the political doctrine of separation of races in South Africa (1948-1990), dominated the (South) African political discourse in the second half of the 20th century. While it lasted, art and visual cultures were marshaled in the defense and contestation of its ideologies. Since the end of Apartheid, artists, filmmakers, dramatists, and scholars continue to reexamine the legacies of Apartheid, and the social, philosophical, and political conditions of non-racialized South Africa. Course readings examine issues of race, nationalism and politics, art and visual culture, and social memory in South Africa.

title: Stable Isotope Geochemistry With An Environmental Focus
descrip: Examines the use of stable isotope measurements to investigate important biogeochemical, environmental, and geologic processes, today and over Earth history. Introduction to terminology, basic underlying principles, measurement techniques, commonly used analytical and computational approaches for analyzing data, followed by a review of typical applications of the isotope systems of carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, and other elements. Lectures by the instructor, problem sets, numerical modeling assignments, student presentations and a final student paper based on readings from the scientific literature.

title: Ethnography of Gender and Islam
descrip: The 21st century has witnessed the explosion of public and scholarly interest in gender in Islamic cultures. Within this context, anthropology has advanced path-breaking approaches in diverse localities from the Middle East to the United States. This course surveys theoretical and ethnographic approaches to the study of women, gender and sexuality in Islamic cultures, focusing on work written in the last decade.

title: American Madness
reviews: Do the readings-- they're fabulous, and you'll get so much more out of seminar.
Great course for any non English major trying to fulfill a distribution requirement, but also be engaged in the class every week. Papers are short and straightforward. Professor Brown is the man.
Highly recommend this course. Engaging seminar on the various forms of madness in American works, as the course title suggests.

This course is full of awesome literature in combinations that you wouldn't find anywhere else; it's a great opportunity if a bit unfocused; you should invest yourself in the readings you like and it will be very worth it.
Very interesting course with a light workload.
descrip: So many texts of the American literary tradition revel in failures of rationality. The collapse of reason in these stories reveals deep disjunctures in the predominant narratives of American exceptionalism and self-fashioning that define so many of our readings of the nation's literary identity. This course will explore how and why madness occupies such a central place in American literature. Drawing on legal documents, psychoanalysis, visual media and critical histories of madness, we will read canonical and less-well read texts from the last two centuries to explore the efficacy of insanity in the literary imagination.

title: Topics in the Formal Analysis of the Urban Structure - Environmental Challenges of Urban Sprawl
reviews: High quality course- definitely take! The trip to LA was a great opportunity to do urban studies fieldwork. Professor Gandelsonas is one of the best professors I have had at Princeton.
Take it! It's very relaxed, and Mario is so flexible and really knows his stuff! This class got me thinking in different ways than I have for any other courses.
Take the class if you are interested to explore the topic.
The assignments are pretty open-ended so if you choose topics you're passionate about, you'll get more out of it.
descrip: As part of the search for solutions to climate, water and energy challenges in a rapidly urbanizing world, it is crucial to understand and reassess the role of exurban sprawl in the environment. This interdisciplinary course aims to add theoretical, pragmatic and cultural dimensions to scientific, technological, and policy aspects of current environmental challenges, in an effort to bridge the environmental sciences, urbanism and the humanities

title: Topics in Medieval Italian Literature and Culture - Boccaccio
prereqs: One 200-level ITA course or Permission of Instructor required..
descrip: Boccaccio's "Decameron" is the preeminent masterwork of early Italian prose. A complex set of stories, linked by the author's convictions about literature and love, the "Decameron" offers both a panorama of fourteenth-century European society and a point of entry into some great traditions of European literature. This seminar will concentrate on a close reading of the "Decameron" in the original language.

title: Contexts of Composition
descrip: Rules and Freedom: concentrates on the dialogue between rules (control) and freedom in the compositional act. We start out analyzing some rule-oriented composers such as Tom Johnson, John Cage, and Arvo Part, among others, and contrasting them with those where a rule-oriented method intersects more freely with an instinctual approach. We then examine the music of composers who embrace an altogether less prescriptive approach in favor of a kind of compositional freedom. Some may argue that this may not be quite as it seems. Students should bring other examples to the table, and are also asked to compose little assignments.

title: Problems in Byzantine History - Rethinking the 11th Century in Byzantium
reviews: An good course that will teach to critically examine big historical problems and the frameworks that they sit within. Just make sure to get the instructor to make clear what sort of assessment he wants so that can't change his mind.
Do as much preparatory reading on the period as possible before taking the class, because without a frame of reference, this course would be very difficult.
Start thinking about your paper topics (both of them) early!

Take the presentations seriously -- you can talk for more than twenty minutes if you have good things to say. Don't ramble, but also don't stress too much about timing the whole thing.

Do as much of the background reading as possible before the class starts, since it is structured around specific topics -- it's good to have a handle on the narrative before you're busy with the topics.

Watch out for the end-of-term assignments (probably two papers!) and get started on them early (don't just tell yourself you will -- actually do).
descrip: The eleventh century is now generally seen as a period of economic expansion in the Byzantine and east Mediterranean world, on the one hand, but of military and political collapse on the other, chiefly as a result of the defeat at the battle of Manzikert in 1071 at the hands of the Selcuk Turks. Is this picture justified? How do contemporary sources view the empire and its politics at this time? What is the nature of the evidence for both the economic and social and political history of the empire? This course will re-examine key sources for the period to see how far the currently-accepted view is justified.

title: Queer Boyhoods
descrip: This course examines enactments of youthful masculinity in U.S. popular performance with a particular eye toward accounts of variant or queer boyhoods. As we scrutinize the regimentation and valorization of specific boyish behaviors, we will explore the cultural impact of non-normative youthful masculinities (ie. sissies, tomboys, bois, punks, transguys, etcetera) as we also assess the place of queer boyhoods in American life. Course readings will be historical, literary and theoretical, with play scripts, films, memoirs and literature for young readers functioning as primary objects for the course's analytic project.

title: Electronic Circuits: Devices to IC
prereqs: ELE 203, ELE 206, ELE 208, ELE 301.
descrip: The course will cover topics related to electronic system design through the various layers of abstraction from devices to ICs. The emphasis will be on understanding fundamental system-design tradeoffs, related to the speed, precision, power with intuitive design methods, quantitative performance measures, and practical circuit limitations. The understanding of these fundamental concepts will prepare students for a wide range of advanced topics from circuits and systems for communication to emerging areas of sensing and biomedical electronics.

title: Advanced Topics in Applied Physics I - The Physics and Engineering of Sound: From basic acoustics to 3D audio
reviews: Don't be intimidated by the math - focus on understanding the concepts and developing the practical skills to implement software and conduct experiments in the lab.
If you have an interest in the topic, there's no way not to love the class
If you're at all interested in acoustics, waves, or how science is applied to create new technologies, take this class!
Take it if you're interested at all in the field of 3D audio. If you're into acoustics and want to expand your knowledge into a field, it's also good.

This is an excellent survey course in basic acoustics and 3D audio. It's very "hands-on", and you will pick up a lot of audio signal processing tips and tricks that will be useful as a starting point to conducting more advanced audio research. The course also offers an excellent introduction to 3D audio. I'd strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in audio (especially audio signal processing) research, and 3D audio research in particular.
prereqs: Calculus; Differential Equations ( e.g. MAE 305), and some familiarity with Fourier and Laplace transforms.
descrip: We start with a review of basic concepts in acoustics including, point sources, wave propagation, diffraction, and transducer (speakers and microphones) dynamics. We then study relevant topics in digital signal processing (e.g. digital filtering; convolution), psychoacoustics (e.g. human perception of sound; spatial hearing), and recording techniques, and combine these concepts and tools to study advanced audio recording and reproduction systems with special focus on virtual reality 3D audio through speakers and headphones.

title: Intermediate Hindi II
reviews: Amazing class! If you want to learn hindi, definitely take it.
Be a heritage speaker or suffer the consequences
Good course if you can speak Hindi but aren't super great at grammar. Not terribly easy, but not too hard either if you do the work.

Pretty good course. Robert Ji is pretty strict about his syllabus, which isn't entirely apparent throughout the course. He's strict about attendance so make sure you go to every class and hand in the homework. He's a really nice guy and wants the class to genuinely learn Hindi!
Take it if you need it. Otherwise, I would recommend self-study or shopping it. The 9 AM time doesn't help either.
prereqs: HIN105 or the equivalent level of proficiency.
descrip: Continuing from HIN 105, this course provides training in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Students will attain the ability to read and understand texts in Hindi on familiar topics, to speak with other Hindi speakers in a wide range of common situations, to write concise texts expressing thoughts and views, and acquire general familiarity with the cultural context(s) in which Hindi is used. Students will have exposure to the cultural contexts of South Asia through multimedia resources, and will engage in interactive and collaborative task-based activities in the classroom.

title: Topics in Non-Western and General Literature - Ideographs
descrip: Weekly three-hour seminar. Conceptions of the ideograph, based on misunderstandings about the way writing works in systems that are not predominantly phonetic, have had a rich and productive role in Western literature, art and film. This course starts from such creative misprision, then turns to a consideration of how the scripts of "ideographic" languages, such as Chinese, Japanese, ancient Egyptian and ancient Mayan, actually work, in order to explore the possibilities for a more accurately grounded understanding of the ideograph.

title: Forms of Literature - Mystery and Detection
reviews: Do the readings. Pay attention to the theory. This is such a wonderful class and really gives you such insight into the genre of detective fiction.
Take if you're interested in mysteries and want a relaxed, accesible course.
Take it! Professor Johnson is the best and the readings are really good!
Take this class!
Take this class! Awesome! And Professor Johnson is so nice
Take this course! Reading list is great, and the two papers are enjoyable to write. One is analytical, and the other is creative. Class was low key and interesting. Loved this course!
descrip: Because they foreground issues of interpretation, signs, and narrative, mysteries attract "high-brow" readers while maintaining their "popular" status. Our class will trace the development of kinds of mysteries -- classics, cozies, noirs, thrillers, post-moderns, metaphysicals -- across historical contexts. Reading theorists such as Freud, Moretti, and Todorov, we will examine the nature of blindspots, doublings, plotting, clues, and suspense, and consider how racial, sexual and cultural difference puts pressure on literary form.

title: Law, Institutions and Public Policy
reviews: Definitely take if available

Heavy workload if you are going to keep up with the readings. That being said it can be very rewarding if you can pay attention, take notes, and stay on your game with understanding the material. Absolutely recommend splitting up readings with friends and then making brief summaries for each other.
I wouldn't take it unless you have to- readings were pretty dry and lectures weren't especially  interesting.

If you are interested in the topic, this is a great course to take for either the Woodrow Wilson school requirement or just general interest. Be aware, however, that Prof. Starr swears against using power point, and that the readings begin to get heavy after about the midway point of the semester. This is definitely a course in which you'll want to attend lecture and complete the readings as much as possible. If you do that, the exams are really fair and not that difficult.
Interesting course that covers a lot of themes
Interesting course. Would recommend if taking for WWS departmental.
Interesting, but not as interesting as I thought it would  be
It's a really interesting course and Prof. Starr has a lot of knowledge to offer. Excellent class to PDF because you get a lot out of it by just going to lecture.

It's pretty much what you think it will be, given the course title and description. Some of the readings are dense, and there are a LOT of them; I HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend getting a study group together (I was with two other people and that worked perfectly). If Jason is precepting, try to get into his precept! (Better than Starr's!) Good choice for the WWS departmental.
Lectures were great I thought! Professor is very interactive and makes an effort to get to know students. Took it senior spring with thesis--totally manageable.
Not as hard as it sounds; very helpful in that it provides many analytical tools to apply for many fields of social studies/ history.
One of the easier WWS departmentals
Professor Starr is great - take this course!
Professor Starr is so charismatic and knowledgeable! I enjoyed his lectures a lot, but be prepared for a lot of reading!
Readings not really necessary, just go to lecture. Overall enjoyable and informative, but didn't knock my socks off.
Really interesting!
Take it

Take this course! Prof. Starr is an amazing lecturer and really knowledgeable. He'll teach you how to think about sociology in terms of institutions and institution-making--it'll change the way you perceive and analyze the social sciences.
Very interesting course. Prof. Starr is brilliant
take this class if you are interested..it covers a lot! go to all lectures
descrip: This course will examine how institutions develop, vary in design, and shape public policy. Law will be a primary focus because it is central to the development of institutions in modern societies and provides the formal means for expressing and fixing policy. The course will cover a wide range on institutions-social, economic, and political - not only in an American context but also in comparative prospective.

title: Topics in Empirical Macroeconomics
reviews: I think the course is very good and doing some of the readings for each class will help a lot.
This is a good course for either macro or applied micro economists.
descrip: This course is geared towards (i) understanding how finance and the macro economy interact with each other, and (ii) introducing micro-empirical techniques and data sets for answering traditional macro questions. The focus of the class is empirical but we begin each topic with a discussion of its theoretical foundation.

title: Beginning Studies in Acting: Scene Study
reviews: Absolutely take this class, it will teach you so much about acting and theater but also so much about what's really important to you in your general life. It's the most important and influential class I've ever taken here.
Attend all of the classes, pay attention to the feedback, and practice exercises outside of class.

Be prepared to do some memorization! This class is tons of fun but also requires a good deal, so don't just tack it on as a fifth class. OR maybe you COULD do it, but you might not enjoy it as much! Give it your all!
Give it a go. Even if acting doesn't sound like something you'd be interested in, you learn a lot nevertheless.
TAKE IT! TAKE IT! TAKE IT!!
Take it and go all in.

Take it with Suzie; she is frank and delightful. She's kind of no bs, so if you like that you're in good hands. She may be honest, but she is also very encouraging--I took the class with very little confidence about my acting and she helped me a lot with constructive criticism.
Take the great course.

There are 5 hours of class time a week and the class ends up being nothing like the first couple weeks are. Too much work for a class in which the grading is as subjective as it is. Suzie is not enjoyable.

This course definitely requires effort. Lots of time is necessary for rehearsing monologues/scenes; weekly journal entries; and various written assignments. What you put into the course directly affects what you get out of it.
Tracy was INCREDIBLE. Everything you could ask for in a teacher... but she's leaving so new instructors may have a different way of teaching/course structure.
be open to critical feedback. if you're unsure about something, embrace it and commit yourself, because that's how you'll get the most out of this class.
prereqs: Enrollment is by application. Please visit the Theater Program website for application information (http://arts.princeton.edu/academics/theater/theater-courses/).
descrip: An introduction to the craft of acting through scene study, monologues and, finally, a longer scene drawn from a play, to develop a method of working on a script. Emphasis will be placed on honesty, spontaneity, and establishing a personal connection with the scene's substance.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Physics & Technology of Low-Dimensional Semiconductors
descrip: A broad overview of materials science and physics of low-dimensional semiconductor structures will be presented. Emphasis will be on the fabrication and physics of high-mobility carrier systems in modulation-doped structures. Examples include two-dimensional, one-dimensional (quantum wire), and zero-dimensional (quantum dot) systems.

title: Economic Perspectives on Inequality (Half-Term)
descrip: Economics is centrally concerned with models of human capital development, educational attainment, labor market dynamics, unemployment, labor turnover, job duration, wage setting institutions, the role of unions, human capital formation, the relationship between economic status and other aspects of well-being (including health). Economists are essential partners in the behavioral study of preferences and decision making, mobility and redistribution, and the institutions of industrial relations that govern the labor market.

title: Climate Science and Communications
reviews: Best class I've taken at Princeton
Definitely recommended. Just amazing.
Flora and Mike are a great team with so much to share! I learned a lot about journalism and video production in this class and highly recommend!
Take it!!
Take it!! This was an interesting course with a really manageable workload.  Most of the work was at the end of the semester finishing the video project.
Take this course! It is a really chill course with amazing and engaging professors. Perfect senior spring class.

This class was a lot of fun and very engaging.  I walked away with better writing and film skills and more knowledge about the field of science communication, which is very intellectual, creative, and engaged with global concerns.
This course is amazing. The work load is not bad but you're expected to be engaged with and put effort into the things they do assign. Flora and Mike are fantastic professors!

This is an informative course about the good practices you should employ if you are interested in spreading pertinent, and often hard-to-understand scientific information. You'll really learn how to use video editing software (we used Adobe premier), a valuable skill in general, and how to write/ speak concisely and directly about frequently-convoluted topics. The workload *is* weighted towards the end of the semester (when the video project takes place), but with advanced planning it shouldn't be an issue.
prereqs: Strong interest in science and communications; no previous coursework or experience necessary..
descrip: In order to address the risks of climate change, people need accurate information. Most of this information comes from the world of science and requires translation. The role of science communicators is crucial. The goal of this course is to give students the technical, narrative and critical-evaluation skills needed to communicate climate science in both print and video. The course begins with an overview of the state of climate science and communications. We then discuss critical elements of journalism, and apply those discussions in a series of writing assignments. The last weeks focus on video production using Final Cut Pro software.

title: Special Topics in Screenwriting - Intermediate Screenwriting: Writing the Feature Film
reviews: As with all CWR courses, you get out of it what you put into it, so make sure you are blocking out enough time each week to work on your script that you will be proud of what you produce. Also, watch all of the films and journal about them -- it's worth it.
Definitely take it!!
Definitely take this course if you're interested in it!
Prof. Lazaridi is very knowledgable, I feel like I learned a ton just from hearing how she thinks about films we viewed in class over the course of the semester

Professor Lazaridi is a wonderful, supportive professor, and her workshops really help work through issues in your writing in an energizing way. She does a really good job of helping you tell the story YOU want to tell, the best that you can; her personal tastes never got in the way. Deadlines/quantity for turning in work are pretty flexible, which can be a blessing or a curse, depending on how motivated you are. Overall, great course. Take it!
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (http://arts.princeton.edu/academics/creative-writing/creative-writing-courses/) by attaching a statement about why they want to take the course and, optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre. Students must have completed ONE prior CWR course or obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: How does a screenwriter, organize and develop the ideas that will form a feature narrative script? In this class, students will become familiar with feature film structure, plot evolution, character development, scene shaping and dialogue, and effective techniques for achieving the complex visual and emotional rhythm required by compelling narrative scripts. Moving from their initial idea to outline and scene formation while analyzing examples of classic and contemporary films, students will tackle the unique challenges and opportunities of crafting a feature length screenplay.

title: Intermediate Swahili II
prereqs: Intermediate Swahili I (SWA 105) or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course emphasizes conversational fluency and increased facility in reading and writing skills while introducing students to Swahili literature. This literature forms the basis for a survey on cultural aspects and more advanced grammer. Students will be able to understand and analyze the main ideas and significant details of materials in Swahili such as media articles, short stories, poetry, short novels, films and plays illustrative of East African cultural issues. Covers advanced-level Swahili grammar, as well as the development of expository writing skills.

title: Information Security
reviews: Good course. Not too much heavy math. Lot of thinking required as there is usually not a unique good solution to a problem.
Great course! Reasonable course load, but very interesting and relevant material!
I bet one of the more interesting COS departmentals. Interesting material, sometimes confusing assignments without much guidance.

I like this course and its programming assignments. However, I do think the requirement on webpage should be improved and more clear. They use auto-grader for grading but does not make it clear on website, what are the assumptions, what is the grading matrices etc.
If Professor Mittal is teaching, take it -- he is a fantastic lecturer. The information surveyed in this course is widely applicable and quite topical.

If you're interested in security at all, you should take this course. It may be difficult to get through the first half, but the second half of the course is far more enjoyable, and will improve the way you design software, and systems as a whole.
It was fine.
It's a good course. Problem sets are very useful.
It's honestly not as great as it sounds. Then again, all the infosec related classes at this school are trash so what can you do.

This course is a very broad background in security with emphasis on practical applications, not cryptography. Overall it's pretty well put together, but the assignments can be tedious and the grading is a bit opaque.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Security issues in computing, communications, and electronic commerce. Goals and vulnerabilities; legal and ethical issues; basic cryptology; private and authenticated communication; electronic commerce; software security; viruses and other malicious code; operating system protection; trusted systems design; network security; firewalls; policy, administration and procedures; auditing; physical security; disaster recovery; reliability; content protection; privacy.

title: Animal Behavior
reviews: Be prepared to memorize details.
Class sets the standard for Princeton.
