DO IT!! Gould is awesome and subtly hilarious. Also animal behavior is just really interesting, especially when you then use it to think about human behavior
Don't take it for an STN. Only take the course if you have to (a.k.a. for EEB majors)
Don't take this class unless you have to.
Fascinating material. Takes work, but you will love what you learn.
Figure out what preceptors want because it will have a big impact on your grade.
Go to lecture and try your best to pay attention for the entire two hours. Basically everything on the exam is from the lecture.
Good easy class to take for EEB majors.
Great course! Definitely worth taking if you're interested in the subject matter, even if you're not planning on majoring in EEB- Gould is awesome!!
I took this PDF for a distribution and regretted it--take something easier the tests are pretty specific and hard

I would highly recommend this course to another student who is interested in this material. Do all of the readings! They are crucial to the exams and make sure you have a preceptor that shows up because the precept and discussing the material is super helpful to understanding the course.

If you love, love, love, love animal behavior, then this course is satisfactory and you can make the most out of it. If you don't like animal behavior or don't feel any affinity to it, then I would advise against taking this course, simply because it is not your typical academic course: that is, the pieces don't fit together academically, but cognitively; you should certainly not take this class if the academic side of coursework is all that matters to you.
If you're an EEB major, take it.  Go to lecture and take notes on the main ideas.
If you're even a little interested in animal behavior, TAKE IT!
If you're interested in this take it but if not stay away. Not an easy class.
Informative and entertaining

Informative lectures and precepts, lots of concepts and key terms quickly brushed over with little coverage, and lots of varied readings; make sure to do as many of the readings as possible, which will be difficult
It's not as fun as it sounds.
Make sure to understand the readings well and participate a lot in precept.
Professor Gould can be pretty funny and is a good lecturer, but the material is often very detailed and if you're not interested, it might be painful.
Professor Gould is amazing and this class is so interesting! Take it if you need an STL or if you have any interest in animal behavior or human beings's place in the world
Readings are okay but definitely go to lecture and precept!

Take it if you're in EEB and/or if you find this topic interesting naturally. I think a lot of seniors take this as a PDF STN but I'm not sure this is the class to do it for. It is a substantial amount of information to learn if you don't have knowledge from EEB classes to support you.
Take it!
Take this course! The material is very interesting and Professor Gould is hilarious.  Readings are more supplementary than necessary.

The material presented in this class is pretty straightforward class, and the topics are fairly interesting. The exams are based pretty much all on lecture so go to class, take really good notes and listen closely to what Professor Gould says because not a lot of info is written on the slides. Don't really need to read the textbook or do the readings to do well.

This class presents interesting material that is relevant to everyday life in an excellent fashion without that much work. I this is a great class to get an STN or to take for general interest but a bet an EEB major would also like it.
This course is very specific and detailed on exams. You need to memorize all the small things. (For Gould, not show how it's going to be next year)
This course isn't going to be offered again, as Prof. Gould is retiring.
This course was interesting and well taught. However, there is a lot of reading that goes along with the class. The precepts are also graded fairly harshly.

This course was very interesting and accessible to students of all academic backgrounds.  I entered the class expecting for it to simply fulfill a distribution requirement and am leaving the class with a newfound appreciation for the field and and for the complexity of animals and their behavior.  I would definitely recommend this class to pretty much anyone who wants to learn more about animals, and especially if you want to learn about bees, as they are Professor Gould's speciality.

This is a good STN to take if you need one. Just know that there's more reading than you might expect (but it's probably not all necessary), and the class isn't just all cool facts about a bunch of different cool animals.

This is a really interesting course, and I would take it! Gould is a great professor, but he does provide you with a lot of material. Be aware there will be a lot to study for for the midterm and final, but it's really interesting and not too difficult of information. Precepts are not the best, but try to talk and write good questions because that is how you will get a good grade!

This is a very interesting course and you will learn a lot. I took it to fulfill my STN and I am very glad that I did. However, be advised that this is not a bird course (although you will learn a lot about birds). There is a lot of reading, and exams require you to really know your stuff. Gould is an expert in the field and lectures are quite good. Also, you must attend lectures. The slides do not have enough info on them to get by without his commentary. Overall, not super difficult and well worth it.
To EEB : Take a different behavior departmental
Uhh.... Go to the lectures. All of them. Drink coffee to stay focused for the entirety. Read the textbook. Know examples. Take this with friends but don't get distracted. Gould's really funny.
Very good course, not much work, good for STN
Very informative and detail intensive. Gould is very funny in a dry sarcastic way. If you are interested in the subject matter you will do well.
do the readings!!!!!
don't take
fine distribution requirement for bio, easy STN for those looking to not put in a lot of work.
theres better STNs out there
descrip: One of the fascinating challenges in biology is to understand the origins and organization of animal behavior. Ethology is the branch of biology concerned with the mechanisms and evolution of behavior, especially innate predispositions and programming, and their interaction with learning. The course begins by examining the discovery of early ethologists of behavioral units or "programs", and relates these to our understanding of the nervous system. We look at how complex behaviors such as navigation, learning, and planning are organized. We study the social behavior of several species and end with an ethological analysis of our own species.

title: The Mongols in the Middle East
reviews: Anyone who wants to learn about the Mongols should take it.
I wish future students could take this course, alas the departure of Professor Kamola is sad.
It isn't offered again but if was you should take it!
This course is great!  If you want to learn about the Mongols then definitely take it, you won't get a better introduction to the topic.
descrip: This course offers a focused study of the period of Mongol conquest and rule in the Islamic world in order to understand the full importance of the period in the broader scope of Middle Eastern and World History. After a short overview of the Islamic world before the coming of the Mongols and of the origins and nature of the Mongol Empire, we will examine particular topics--art, historiography, religion, and commerce--as they developed over three centuries from the first invasions by Genghis Khan to Babur's flight to India.

title: The Crusades
reviews: A very well taught class that covers a fascinating period in history. Would highly recommend for majors or non majors alike. Much better use of time than taking one of the 200 level intro classes.

Definitely take this class if you are into medieval history, military history or crusading. The readings are not too long and they are very interesting, while the assignments are definitely doable and a very good application of the material taught, despite the timeline being fairly long

Do the readings anyway, and keep good notes (preferably by date, as it will help you stay organized and feeds directly into the timeline assignment). Feel absolutely free to talk with the professor and preceptors.
I would take it, very interesting course and fantastic teacher.
If you like the crusading movement take the class,

If you're a medievalist or looking for a distribution requirement / departmental, this is a great class, taught very well, with very manageable readings and assignments. The Crusades are also super relevant in context with current events.
It is a shitload of work. The readings are manageable but it feels like there is something due every week. Still, it is incredibly exciting, and the professor knows her stuff.
Stay up to date with the readings.
TAKE IT! It is awesome
Take it. Shawcross is great. Do what readings you can, but don't worry too much about it.

Take this course if you're interested in this period, or if you know nothing about it and want to.  But be warned, there's a ton of reading.  You can get by without doing all of it, but make sure you read the primary sources and the atlas selections.  They're comparatively short and will get you through precepts and papers.
Take this course. Meet with your preceptor and take advantage of the rewrites. Keep up with your timeline and enjoy every lecture.
This is an amazing class.  Highly recommended!
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators.
descrip: The Crusades were a central phenomenon of the Middle Ages. This course examines the origins and development of the Crusades and the Crusader States in the Islamic East. It explores dramatic events, such as the great Siege of Jerusalem, and introduces vivid personalities, including Richard the Lionheart and Saladin. We will consider aspects of institutional, economic, social and cultural history and compare medieval Christian (Western and Byzantine), Muslim and Jewish perceptions of the crusading movement. Finally, we will critically examine the resonance the movement continues to have in current political and ideological debates

title: Optimization
reviews: A boring, useless, and outdated course. Take ORF 363 instead if you want to learn optimization.
All that you've heard is true.
Attend lectures and read the textbook weekly.
Don't take it if you are not an ORFE major. Take another optimization course. It is not easy and its not too hard but its tedious and the lectures were not that engaging, at least for me.
Don't take it.
Don't take this if you don't have to.  I studied a lot for both midterms and still did poorly--only take if you're really really smart.

Good class with interesting applications of optimization. The lectures and textbook are great in preparing for the problem sets and exams. The final project was on a very interesting topic, but I would recommend practicing programming in AMPL so you can be prepared for any errors that come up.
I mean you have to take it if you're looking at this,

If you're ORFE, you have to take this, but if you have any interest in taking an optimization course, take ORF 363 instead. This course is pretty one-sided in terms of material: you learn how to use the simplex method many different ways using Professor Vanderbei's very own simplex tool. However, even though the techniques we used to solve problems were usually manageable and fairly straightforward to learn, it was often unclear what we were actually doing. I don't think anyone will be using these techniques in the real world unless you are planning on graduate school in the field. So if you don't have to take this course, save yourself the trouble. You won't be missing much.
Interesting course. Material has some very useful applications. Not really a hard course, especially within the ORF department
It's an ORFE requirement

It's not as bad as everyone makes it out to be.  Vanderbei is a really nice guy and really cares about teaching (even though he presents the material in a way that's a bit unclear).  The workload is pretty manageable.
Make sure do well on the assignments. The workload is not too bad. It doesn't have a final which makes things so much better.
NOT THE BEST COURSE! You do not learn anything substantial apart from the pivot method. Switch to COS if you are on the borderline between COS and ORFE.
Never take this course unless it is a requirement.
Not as bad as a lot of people say, but not exactly my favorite class here.
One of the easiest ORF requirements.

Only take it if you have to (ORFE majors).
Learn how to use ampl early on. The final project is not an evaluation of whether or not you learned optimization; it's only whether or not you know how to code in ampl. Luckily, Elahe (preceptor) was amazing and a huge help throughout.
Only take this course if you have to. It is not that hard, but it seems a bit useless. None of the material really got me excited.
Read, do homework and learn up
Take a better class if you can
Take this course if you need to (as an ORFE major). If you're interested in linear programming, it is a good class to take as well as an intro to LPs. It is not too demanding in terms of courseload.
Take this if you must but find Elahe to be your preceptor. Also, Vanderbei says collaborate but the preceptors take off points.

Taking this class as a CS major. Thought it had a reasonable courseload, don't really regret taking it. Vanderbei is extremely kind and helpful, but not the best lecturer. The material may seem dry and unmotivated... it's actually pretty practically useful, but I think the lack of programming assignments may have not allowed this to show. Imo, do the readings and ask questions in office hours if you really want to feel like you're getting something from the class. I'm kind of happy I took it -- wasn't too much work and I got a good understanding of techniques in linear programming. If you don't want to put in this time, you could probably trudge your way through, but you'll prob hate it. If you need a reasonable 5th class, take it.
This course isn't too bad or difficult and optimization is a really useful skill to have.

This is a low workload course graded against mostly orfe majors.  It's not particularly exciting, but fits very well as a fifth class.  Haotian holds very good office hours and is absolutely a pro at helping students with the material.
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204. Basic computer programming knowledge suggested..
descrip: Many real-world problems involve maximizing a linear function subject to linear inequality constraints. Such problems are called Linear Programming (LP) problems. Examples include min-cost network flows, portfolio optimization, options pricing, assignment problems and two-person zero-sumgames to name but a few. The theory of linear programming will be developed with a special emphasis on duality theory. Attention will be devoted to efficient solution algorithms. These algorithms will be illustrated on real-world examples such as those mentioned.

title: Epidemiology: an ecological and evolutionary perspective
reviews: Chill class. Kind of boring but very straight forward.
Definitely take it if it is applicable to you!
Don't take unless you need to for GHP. Very unorganized and inefficient.
Dull and low in content - unless if it's required, I recommend a week's worth of reading or internet searching will teach you all this course teaches you in a semester.
Follow all the guidelines for the case studies, and start studying a week before the (one) exam in the course. The final paper isn't bad.
Go to the lectures and keep up with all concepts! Ask questions you may have and keep track of practice problems to prepare for the exam.

I basically just learned how to read a scientific paper, which is very useful. But it was not what I was expecting out of an epidemiology course at all. Did not fell like I learned how to do epidemiological work. Only take if you're GHP and have to.
I think this course can be made better; if you're doing it out of interest, it's an interesting course but be prepared for some boring technicalities.

If you are interested in infectious disease control (or public health in general), then you will enjoy this class.  If you keep up with the lecture material and take the time to do the problem sets carefully, then you will do well.  The work load is very manageable.
If you're GHP, you have to take this anyways. If your thinking about a career in public health or Epi, definitely take the course. You will learn so much!

If you're interested in epidemiology, take this class! It provides the foundation for this field. However, be aware that this is a GHP course, so it is a little heavy on policy at times rather than biology and statistics.
Interesting class, glad GHP offers epi b/c it's a good skill set to have in public health
Interesting.
It's a great course. Take it!
It's rough as a 9 AM but not a bad class. Assignments are interesting although readings and lectures might not always be.

Lectures were too early in the morning to be fully engaged/to consistently attend. Content of the lectures was interesting. Textbook readings were useful but supplementary readings were not as useful. You have to take this class if you are a GHP certificate
Make sure you know the general themes of the course
Only take it if it is required of you.
Overall, a well-developed core class worth taking even for non GHP students
Pick a clear, pared down case study.
Professor Metcalf is really great and energetic about the material. It was annoying that it was at 9am, but I ended up really learning so many useful skills and a lot of information!
Really understand the problem sets! It will pay off when you study for the final.
Take it if you are interested in statistics
Take it!
Take it. Just take it. It's a great class. Good and solid work but not too overwhelming.
Take the course if you have to and if you are interested at all in epidemiology. It's worth it; not too hard but still intellectually stimulating.

Take this course if the old professor (not Metcalf) is teaching. She may get better since this was the first semester she taught it. Don't expect to get more out of it if you've taken a stats course and GHP 350 or other disease ecology courses. Don't take unless you're getting the GHP certificate.

This class was honestly really easy. It was pretty unorganized so if you just did the bare minimum it was really easy to do well. The exam will literally only test you on the stats stuff from the first few lectures, so don't bother studying the later ones.

This is a good intro to epidemiology. I enjoyed the first half more than the second half; the first part of the semester was very applicable for people interested in global health in learning what exactly epidemiology is and about study designs and calculations, but the second half was mostly interesting topics kind of related to epidemiology. During the semester there were problem sets due at precept for about half the weeks, then 3 case studies where you choose an article and analyze it based on some epidemiological criteria, one "midterm" really late in the semester, a presentation for precept, and a policy paper for Dean's Date.
This is an alright class if you're required to take it for GHP. Otherwise, this course was less interesting than the course description might make it seem.
What you get out of this class is dependent on how much effort you put into it. Engaging during lecture and during precepts will improve your experience.
attend lectures
pay attention in precept
prereqs: Completion of an approved basic statistics course (e.g., ECO 202, EEB/MOL 355, ORF 245, POL 345, PSY 251 or SOC 301, SML 101 and SML 201), or completion of an advanced statistics course (e.g., ECO 302, ECO 312, ORF 405, SOC 404, WWS 200, and WWS 332)..
descrip: This required course for GHP students focuses on the distribution and determinants of disease. Diverse methodological approaches for measuring health status, disease occurrence, and the association between risk factors and health outcomes will be presented via classic and contemporary studies of chronic and infectious illness and disease outbreaks. The core underlying ecological and evolutionary drivers of human health will be introduced. Emphasis on: causal inference, study design and sampling, bias and confounding, the generalizability of research, health policy and research ethics.

title: Junior Independent Work
prereqs: This course is open to juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty member.

title: Introductory Logic
reviews: A good course. Not too much of a time commitment. Interesting. Thomas is a great preceptor

Definitely take this class if Halvorson's teaching it! He's an incredible lecturer and cares about students. I felt I really grew as a thinker in this class. Not a difficult or time-intensive EC, though (at this time) it's not PDF-able. Still glad I took it.
Do all of the problem sets and read all of the readings, since there aren't that many. Also, always reach out to instructors whenever you encounter a problem.
Do the readings and go to office hours. Don't be afraid to ask for help.
Get Thomas Barrett as your preceptor!!! He's amazing and so funny. Overall good class, easy
Go for it. Really interesting, fun, and not too hard.
Go to office hours. Don't get left behind.
Great (extremely easy) as an EC if you're quantitatively-minded.

Great class! Very challenging and gets very "meta" towards the end. Fun and different from other types of classes, definitely makes you think. Not a horrible amount of work, but not worth PDFing because the subject matter does not lend itself to only understanding half.
Halvorson is a wonderfully clear teacher, material not too difficult (until the very end)

I am a math major who took this as a distro. Was way too easy for me and I learned very little. If you are a math major or are very comfortable with proofs, maybe take a more challenging class. However if you are anyone else, Hans is a great lecturer / preceptor, so if you have not done proof-based stuff before you may find the course very valuable and rewarding.
I think this might be an interesting class for people with no background in logic, but if you have experience with propositional logic or even boolean algebra, PHI 340 is probably better.
I would always go to precept. It is very helpful.
If you are interested in understanding symbolic logic with some fun philosophical qualms thrown in for fun then go for this class. If you do not do p-sets so well, think twice.
If you're an analytical sort of person, this class should be a breeze. If you're not, with a little work it should come easily--but be careful to not get lazy near the last couple weeks!
It shouldn't be taken as an easy class just to take. It requires a lot of outside work
It's a nice mixture of quantitative and philosophical. would suggest at least giving it a try!
It's an amazing class. More math-y than EC, but since I liked math, it was good to take as an EC. Thomas is the best preceptor.
Not a very time-consuming course. Just start problem sets early, and make sure you understand everything as the course moves along (since the material is fairly cumulative).
Probably one of the best taught courses here at Princeton. Moreover it counts as an EC, and is problem set based if that suits your fancy. Definitely recommend.
Prof. Halvorson is very helpful one-on-one. Also, logic is super cool. You should do it.
Psets are worth a lot, so go over them with a classmate. The practice final bears no resemblance to the final, the midterm is too long to take in 50 min.
Read.
TAKE IT WITH HALVORSON. He is a genius, and super nice.
Take if you want an easy EC. (HW takes less than an hour/week.) Most of it is kind of boring though, especially if you've done proof-based math before.
Take it if you need to fulfill an EC to avoid all the other humanities.
Take it with Halvorson- for the most part he's clear and straightforward and the material is really rewarding once you get into it.
Take the course if you are and engineer looking for an interesting AB course but do not expect a walk in the park.
Take this course if Halvorson is teaching!

Take this if you have an interest in the foundations of math and computer science.  If you've taken ELE 206/ COS 306 you'll have the basics of propositional logic down, but predicate logic and the rest of the course still kick butt, so be ready to handle some difficult material later in the course!
Take this with Hans!
This class is fairly easy, especially if one has a strong computational background. Easy psets and exams. Take this class if you want an easy EC class or u love proofs and logic-based problem solving
This is a fantastic course that you should take if you enjoy thinking rigorously. Also, it is a fantastic EC for engineers and other STEM majors.

This is a low workload course that could be done in a five class semester.  It's graded against a class of maybe 2/3 phi students and 1/3 cos/math students.  Hans is a great teacher and I would strongly recommend this course.
This is a very hard course. Interesting. Expect a lot of work in order to understand the material.

Tough but worthwhile, good if you wanna do COS or maths etc. later on 
Warning it's a lot of work at the start though
Very interesting and not a lot of work. Highly recommend.

Your experience with this course will probably depend on how much math/proof experience you already have - if you've done a lot of math, it should be pretty intuitive and straightforward whereas if you haven't, it will be more challenging. The topic is fairly interesting and the workload is fair.
take it - awesome class
descrip: Logic is the study of the principles of valid reasoning. This course provides an introduction to symbolic logic, which studies the principles of valid reasoning from an abstract point of view--paying attention to the form of valid arguments rather than their subject matter. We will cover the basic concepts and principles of symbolic logic: validity, logical truth, truth-functional and quantificational inference, formal languages and formal systems, axiomatic and deductive proof procedures.

title: Ghosts in the Machine
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Origins of Japanese Culture and Civilization: A History of Japan until 1600
reviews: A very interesting class with a lot of unique views that isn't available in textbooks.
Do the readings. Go to lecture.
Engage yourself in the lecture and with the readings
I fully recommend this course. Make sure that you go to Dr. Conlan during his office hours to improve your essays, and try to keep up with the narrative instead of studying for it at the last minute.
I would recommend them to take this course. It's a lot of reading but its worth it and very well taught.

If you are specifically interested in Japanese history, then this course is a good choice. Tom is a witty lecturer with a great sense of humor, and even though I'm not a history buff, I thoroughly enjoyed this course. Just make sure you do the readings! They are crucial in understanding the material and writing your assignments.
descrip: This course is designed to introduce the culture and history of Japan, and to examine how one understands and interprets the past. In addition to considering how a culture, a society, and a state develop, we will try to reconstruct the tenor of life in "ancient" and "medieval" Japan and chart how patterns of Japanese civilization shifted through time.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture II
reviews: If you can take it, take it!! Yun really puts in a lot of effort and will help you improve.
Spend more time with the professor!
prereqs: KOR 401 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion of Korean thoughts and issues in contemporary Korea. Readings drawn from a variety of cultural and historical topics. Class discussions will be conducted in Korean.

title: Reasoning with Data
prereqs: There are no official prerequisites for this course. However, it is strongly recommended that students be comfortable with basic computer usage and some college level mathematics..
descrip: Data-driven decision-making, research discovery, and technology development are everywhere. It is now more important than ever for individuals to understand how data are used for these purposes. This course will introduce the student to how statistical reasoning and methods are used to learn from and leverage modern data. The emphasis will be on concepts and strategies for learning from data, rather than on sophisticated mathematics. Students will be exposed to the basics of statistics, machine learning, and data science through real world problems and applications. Students will also analyze data sets using the computer.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering
prereqs: Course open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.

title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
reviews: The course gives a broad and detailed introduction into QFTII. A lot of additional reading and work is necessary to apply the methods of the lecture and to do the comprehensive problem sets.
descrip: Relations between Quantum Field Theory and Statistical Mechanics, Renormalization Group, Non-Abelian Gauge Theories, Asymptotic Freedom, Quantum Chromodynamics, Chiral Lagrangians, General Constraints on RG Flows.

title: Judicial Politics
reviews: I recommend taking detailed lecture notes and notes on the various mathematical models discussed, and to start the paper early if this course is taught in a similar manner.

I would recommend this class, but only if you are genuinely interesting in learning about the politics of the judicial branch of government. Otherwise, you may find the readings, lectures, and (12-20 pg) paper to be tedious. Because I liked the topic, I thoroughly enjoyed the assignments. The midterm and finals were fair and there were no real surprises. You should take this class.
Only take the class if you're genuinely interested in the subject matter. Also a good class for those interested in game theory and the more methodological side of politics.

Tommaso Pavone is a great preceptor and Professor Kastellec is responsive to questions. The material is interesting enough, but this is definitely not one of the more exciting classes in the Politics department.
Worth taking.
this class is really interesting and worth taking. amount of work for it is very average with any other princeton class I've taken
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the political science of law and courts. Topics typically include: bargaining and decision making on the U.S. Supreme Court; political struggles over doctrine within the judicial hierarchy; the politics of Supreme Court nominations; juries as political institutions; court packing, jurisdiction stripping and judicial intimidation.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

title: Problems in Literary Study - Postcolonial Heterotopias
descrip: This course invites rethinking established theories of postcolonial literature outside the national allegory, modern subjectivity, & the politics of identity. Focusing on "minor" works of major postcolonial writers, the course seeks to understand the postcolonial imaginary beyond the utopia of community, the dystopia of postmodern angst, & the romance of individual life. The course tries to develop a mode of reading postcolonial & related literatures from below, outside the monumental & the canonical, seeking the figurative language that emerges in a range of heterotopias, including islands, deserts, borders, & other fugitive spaces.

title: Media Arabic I
reviews: Definitely take it. Hannah really cared about us. It was a really welcoming course and we learned vocab that we can actually use.

Hannah is a very helpful professor and always willing to meet outside of class. This course really expands your vocabulary in relation to current events so it is very motivating to study because everything is so relevant.

I would recommend this course to students interested in current events and potentially reading and listening to the news in Arabic. It is a very specialized set of vocabulary that requires general interest in the topic to make the lessons seem important to your overall Arabic education.
It's great way to build vocabulary and listening comprehension

Prof. Essien is a great teacher and her class on Arabic Media was the most helpful class I've taken so far. If you're interested in being able to read Arabic sources on the elections, terrorism, military operations, etc, take this class!

This class is relatively low-effort but a good way to keep up with your Arabic. Prof. Essien is extremely understanding and wants to improve your Arabic skills. However, make sure you study for the vocabulary quizzes, which also tend to test grammatical concepts!

This is a great course, and really the only Arabic course I've taken at Princeton that focuses on contemporary Arabic and important current issues. I would definitely recommend taking it, and Ustaaza Hannah is really a delight.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or the equivalent..
descrip: In this course, students will develop their skills in reading and listening to Arabic news media, including newspapers, magazines, websites, radio and satellite TV broadcasts (including BBC and al-Jazeera, among others). Attention will also be given to informal discussion of current news, and we will also take a brief look at political cartoons.

title: Islamic Family Law
descrip: This course examines the oulines of Islamic family law in gender issues, sexual ethics, family structure, family planning, marriage and divorce, parenthood, child guardianship and custody, etc. The course starts with a general survey of Islamic legal system: its history and developments, structure and spirit, and the attempts of the Muslim jurists to come to terms with the challenge of time.

title: Introduction to Financial Mathematics
reviews: Always start the problem set early.
Be prepared for a lot of math in the second half of the course, and definitely go to lecture to get those notes. Take if you want a very mathematical understanding of options modeling.
Be prepared to put in a lot of effort and time on the psets and work with other people.
Decent course, not sure why you would want to take it if not ORF major or finance. Need ORF 309 or equivalent.
Difficult course. The professor is a good lecturer. ORF 309 is useful here
Do not take this unless you are an ORFE major - like really, it is not worth it. And, good luck if you are taking it!
Don't take it unless you have some background in finance or are an orf major! Biggest mistake I've made at Princeton!

Even if you are not an ORF major, this is still a course that I highly recommend you. A good introduction to the application of mathematics in the finance industry, and how the industry functions in general.

Go to lecture - this is essential for this course. Lectures are interesting and if you go to lectures, studying the material through the notes will be 10 times easier. Also use the Hull book as a 2nd reference.
I thoroughly enjoyed this class until the final exam. If you're not ORFE, take ECO 362 to learn about finance and this class if you want to be a quant.

If you aren't comfortable with math, do not take this class. You will be working with stochastic differential equations and other not-easy math stuff. Even as an ORF major, I felt like I was up against a lot of MAT majors who found the problems/proofs much easier than I did.

If you're interested in more math-y finance like options, take this class.  It's pretty well taught, and you learn a lot of tricks that you might use if you end up going into trading / other quant stuff
If you're taking this, you probably have to, so just be prepared to work hard and put in the time
Interesting course, not too difficult.
It is a very solid ORF course, and for anyone interested in stock and options pricing. The difficulty makes it a challenging choice for an interest course for non ORF/ECO majors.

Of the required course for ORFE majors, ORF 335 is definitely the most interesting and applicable to some of the things that financial engineers will be doing in their careers. Professor Sircar teaches this course well. The course begins by learning how to price all kinds of options by coding in Matlab and learning the theory behind essential concepts like no-arbitrage and Black-Scholes. I found the first half of the semester to be much more concrete, more "real-world" than the latter half. The second half was much more theoretical and stressed proof-based math with some techniques similar to (although not quite as difficult as) ORF 309. I would definitely recommend the course to non-ORFE majors as well if you are looking to gain more experience with options and finance-related mathematical techniques. However, this course is very demanding. Take it if you are looking for an interesting challenge.
Psets become increasingly harder as the semester goes on. Material rather easy in the first half, picks up a lot in the second half. Work hard.
Ronnie is one of the least caring Profs. I've had at Princeton - he seems completely disengaged from the class and course. While the course starts out pretty easy, the second half is really intense.

Sircar: Very thorough and explains the right amount but almost no engagement with the class. Will explain something that only one student understands and feel comfortable moving on if that student is the one to raise their hand. Also speaks quietly so be in front 3 rows. HW: first 4 are easy, last 2 are much harder but overall not that bad compared to 309 or something. Precept: Alternate between completely unhelpful to somewhat helpful. Notes: Thorough notes provided on blackboard so little reason to ever go to class. Midterm and Final: Similar to previous years, so study practice tests
Study hard after the midterm.
Take if you are interested.
Take if you have interest in mathematical finance and have decent math background
Take it!!

Take the course to get some basic knowledge about options and finance in general. However, it can be tedious at times (especially with regards to problem sets). It's not particularly difficult, but it does rely on material from 309 as well as calculus and diff eq.
Take this class if you want to learn financial math. The class gets hard after the midterm.
Take this course if you are interested in quantitative finance at all. It is a good intro to options and a great applicational follow-up to ORF 309. I learned a lot in this class.

Take this if you're interested in finance or want to see a practical application of ORF309 knowledge. The material is well taught, although the problem sets and exams can be pretty math heavy and thus time-consuming.

The lectures were very good but there were no structured lecture notes, which means missed classes can really pull one back. But Prof. Sircar is an amazing professor and the course itself is very rewarding. It will also really help if you already know MATLAB. This is one of the ORFE courses that requires persistent attention to the course material, regularly going to lectures and office hours to get a decent grade. Be very certain you need/want to take it as it is definitely not an easy course.
Very Cool Course.  Should take
Work with other people. Don't worry, everyone else failed the final too.
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 104 and ORF 309 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Financial Mathematics is concerned with designing and analyzing products that improve the efficiency of markets and create mechanisms for reducing risk. This course introduces the basics of quantitative finance: the notions of arbitrage and risk-neutral probability measure are developed in the case of discrete models. Black-Scholes theory is introduced in continuous-time models, and credit derivatives and the term structure of interest rates are discussed, as well as lessons from the financial crisis.

title: Computer Graphics
reviews: A great class to take if you're interested in graphics or want to learn more about it. You cover a broad range of material and get to apply it in assignments (using JavaScript). At the end, your final project is completely open-ended and gives you the freedom to pursue anything you want.
A little time consuming, but the things you make in the assignments are super cool.

Adam Finkelstein does an excellent job keeping students engaged (plenty of cool stories about computer graphics in industry) even when the material can become very mathematically dense, also the assignments are very gratifying to look at when finished (retooling the assignments to make the best use of WebGL is still a work in progress, but there seem to be much fewer hassles with it compared to the stories I'd heard about this course when it was taught in C  ). Certainly an excellent primer to different areas of research in computer graphics and left me interest to pursue the topic further.

Although it might take a bit of mathematical background to get the most out of (e.g. linear algebra), the course covers a wide range of interesting topics. Lectures are great and engaging, and the assignments are a bit time-consuming but also interesting and not overly difficult.
Assignments take a long time, but are very very cool.
Definitely take it.

Definitely take this course! It exposes you to a lot of different topics in computer graphics, and the assignments are really fun and interesting. Make sure you dedicate a lot of time to this course, though, because the assignments take a while to do.
Fun class, very cool assignments. Definitely take if interested in Computer Graphics.

Good class! Professor Finkelstein is a pretty good lecturer. The first programming assignment took 20  hours and required a lot of code to be written, but the time you are given to complete the project is adequate. You also learn a lot from figuring out how to write filters for image processing. After that, I felt that I was learning less because a decent chunk of the code I was writing was implementing pseudocode or mathematical calculations within the code base given to us to complete various features. It's hard to say whether there's an alternative, because the projects are so large that it is necessary for the TAs or professor to have written much of it already. These assignments also took significantly less time than the first one. I probably spent less than 12 hours on each. Definitely recommend it as a good COS class to take though! This course has fun assignments and a final project in which you implement really cool graphics applications. They can take a fair bit of time to do, but nothing is too conceptually difficult. The final project is really open ended, so it's tough to know what to do, and students with prior experience in graphics have a huge advantage. However, no experience is required to do very well on the assignments, which are the focus of the class.

Though the course has strong reviews, take the course only if you think that you may enjoy studying graphics itself. As someone who is not particularly interested in image processing or game design, I found myself losing interest during lectures. That said, some concepts were interesting and you get a lot of programming experience with javascript, which you don't need to know beforehand.

You make really cool looking things, and yes it does take time, but the secret is to *gasp* start your assignments early. Honestly though, it's not that difficult unless you're last minute stressing out.
take this if you're ready to commit to all the work; otherwise, it'll just be stressful.

descrip: This course examines exchange relations in a variety of high-risk and criminal fields, to develop an understanding of how participants navigate their worlds. The weekly readings and lectures will focus on the various ways in which relationships, identities, reputation, and trust, are defined, established, and negotiated, and how this establishes order in the professional and social lives of those involved in high-risk transactions. Readings will be from ethnographic and biographical works on street gangs, drug dealers and traffickers, sex workers, organized crime operations, sports bookies, organ and human traffickers, and others.

The course is unstructured and you get little to no feedback on why you miss questions on problem sets and the midterm, which makes it very difficult to study and correct your mistakes. Your time is better spent taking another chemistry class.

title: Introduction to Machine Translation
reviews: A decent COS class. The material was presented at an approachable level and Professor Bangalore cared a lot about helping us learn. Unless you have an interest in NLP or MP, I'd say there are better COS classes to take. The final project was a lot of fun. I'd say to make sure you pick a topic for which you know in advance that you'll be able to get decent results.

Extremely interesting class if you are at all interested in languages or linguistics! Great introduction to NLP. I would recommend taking it after 126 and 226 (and possibly concurrently with 217), although there were students taking it concurrently with 226.
There 3-4 are assignments, one every 2 weeks, which take 15-30 hours, but the end of the semester is just a project, which takes as much time as you're willing to put in and makes it easier to balance with other classes.
Good course to get an idea of what machine translation is. The workload is also very manageable.
Great introduction to NLP. Course is well-taught, and not too time-intensive. Final project is very open-ended, and provides the chance to pursue topics students found most interesting.
I recommend you have experience programming before taking this. But it's a decent course.
If you've taken COS 126   226 and are interested in linguistics in the least, this is a really great course to take! Super interesting, great professor.

It definitely increased my appreciation for the challenges of NLP and MT. Recommendation: definitely learn Python (don't try to do assignments in Java). Assignment specs can be kind of confusing. Still an overall good experience though! Also pick group project partners carefully and make sure they're as committed to working on it as you are.

Not a ton of work and interesting if you're into language or machine learning. Be warned: rquires a decent amount of programming experience to do well in, COS 226 at least, but COS 402 and 424 will help.
Not particularly.

(note: I am a COS Major with interest in NLP and MT)

This is a great course! The Prof is really fun and nice, the class is a cool format where you can actually discuss the material in class, and the material is SO COOL. This is great class, but it requires a lot of self-motivation to really make the most out of it. Only take it if you have a genuine interest in MT and NLP, otherwise you won't really enjoy it. Also, even though there are no COS prerequisites, it's wise to at least have some coding experience so that you'll be able to concentrate on building stuff for the assignments rather than trying to learn how to code. And do take advantage of the final project to explore the topics that REALLY interest you- it will be extremely rewarding.
Would not recommend. Not much guidance from the professor.

You definitely, DEFINITELY need more than just COS 126. I had taken 126 and 217 and was way out of my depth on the programming assignments. You should probably know Python too. The final project is fun though.
prereqs: Students are required to have programming experience or should have completed COS126 (Introduction to Computer Science). TRA 200 is recommended (may be taken simultaneously)..
descrip: This course will provide an in-depth study of the MT paradigms (direct, transfer, statistical/example, and interlingual) used in state-of-the-art speech-to-speech and text-based MT systems, from computational and linguistic perspectives. Machine-learning techniques for processing human languages (morphological analysis, tagging, syntactic and semantic parsing, and language generation) will be discussed in detail. Linguistic variation across languages and its impact on computational models will be presented. Projects will involve implementing speech/text translation components, identifying their limitations and suggesting improvements.

This is great class that will help you distinguish facts and opinion on inequality. It uses several tools of econometrics, so if you liked ECO 302 or 312 you will probably enjoy this class.

This is pretty interesting. Kuziemko is a really great professor. The course is not difficult at all. If you're looking for an econ departmental, think about this class, and definitely take a class with Kuziemko at some point.

the material in this class is so interesting and relevant so definitely worth taking for that reason, but exams are really hard. the class relies on a lot of econometrics and models from previous econ classes, so if you struggled with econometrics it might not be the best course to take.
prereqs: ECO 300 or 310 and ECO 302 or 312.
descrip: In the US and many other developed countries, economic inequality has risen to historic levels in recent decades. What are the causes of this trend -- "natural" market forces (e.g., globalization?) or changes in public policy (e.g., erosion of the minimum wage)? Are measures currently proposed to counteract inequality and poverty -- e.g, progressive taxation, transfer programs to low-income families, public insurance programs such as Medicare -- effective? An emphasis is placed on understanding what basic microeconomic theory as well as empirical evidence can (and cannot) tell us about these questions.

title: Queer Sexualities: Biopsychosocial and LGBT Perspectives
reviews: You'll learn a lot
if you're debating this class, just take it! really interesting and covers material that most of the other GSS classes i've taken have only briefly (if at all) touched upon
prereqs: Open to Sophomores, Juniors and Seniors Only.
descrip: Queer Sexualities is an interdisciplinary course, which intertwines the study of human sexuality from scientific and public health perspectives with queer academic writing about sexual orientation and gender. Through the lenses of human sexuality theory, social science and medical perspectives, biological and sexual functioning, and LGBT history and subcultures, this course will explore the many ways in which queer sexualities, identities, and relationships are constructed, expressed, and regulated.

title: Artistic Entrepeneurship: Creating and Producing Live Performance
prereqs: None - This course is open to students who want to create and produce live performance after college: directors, designers, playwrights, monologists, composers, choreographers..
descrip: This course looks critically at existing and possible creative and producing strategies for emerging artists in dance and theater. Combining workshop sessions on students' performance works with practical skills for getting live art funded, produced and seen in the professional world, the course asks students to think of the two sides of their artistic lives as part of a whole, rather than aspects of a split personality. Once you're in the real world, how can you best support the way you want to work? What are the myths and what are the realities about how you support the work you want to make?

title: Tang Intellectual History
descrip: The scholar-officials of the Tang dynasty created the sources on which we now depend for Tang history. But what ideas did these people have about the state, society, the role of government and its institutions, or the wider world? In this course we read primary sources in literary Chinese, supplemented with secondary scholarship, to come to a better understanding of the intellectual landscape of the time, and how it is reflected in the source material.

title: Proseminar in Anthropology
descrip: Second half of a two-semester seminar required for first-year graduate students in social-cultural anthropology. Along with ANT 501, the course introduces students to fundamentals of anthropological thought. Predominantly, the course focuses on anthropology's engagement with ethnography and writing. Through reading key texts in the discipline, we try to understand how anthropologists transition from their fieldwork to theorizing, and from their ethnography to text.

title: Comparative Ethnic Politics
descrip: This course examines the political implications of ethnic diversity across contexts. We will discuss questions such as: How and when do ethnic identities shape political behavior and political cleavages? What explains ethnic conflict? How are ethnic minorities incorporated into politics? Readings will cover advanced democracies (with a focus on the US and Europe) as well as economically and politically developing countries.

title: East Asia since 1800
reviews: Definitely take this class even if  you have no background in East Asian history. Its a nice cursory course and the workload is not bad at all especially for a history class. Just go to lecture and you will do absolutely fine.
Easy history course that gives you a good overview of the material.
Every student at Princeton should take this course regardless of their major. The understanding and knowledge of East Asian history and history itself is incredibly important .
Good course to obtain a broad overview of the histories of Japan, China, and Korea since the 1800s and how they are interconnected
Great course, would recommend.
Highly recommend this course. Readings are very well-chosen, and the professors are very engaging.
I hate to say this, but textbook readings only help minimally. Also, focus on broad topics and comparisons between the East Asian countries!

If you're interested in taking future EAS courses/interested in modern E Asia, etc., I definitely recommend this course. It provides an excellent (general) overview of East Asian history in the last 200 years, which is really important to understand if you plan on pursuing EAS further. I'm not very good at history, but I found the grading fair and the class relatively easy. Do the precept readings! All precepts center around discussing the readings, and essays (2) are focused on these readings as well (with that in mind, go to precept!). Claire Cooper was an excellent preceptor - very good at facilitating discussion and analyzing primary sources. Lectures were interesting (I recommend going). One note - while I'm sure the textbook was nice for extra in-depth context, I didn't find it necessary for the course (I went to 90% of lectures and took notes instead). I didn't do textbook readings, so I wish I hadn't purchased the textbook.
Interesting, especially if you have a busy courseload and need a pdf class. Not too much work, its doable.

It's a pretty interesting course, and provides a very general outline of East Asian history. It helps to put in some effort into the lectures and readings, but a lot of the material is easy to absorb on your own.
Loved the readings, Garon can be a harsh grader but this course is so so so worth it - convinced me to be a history major
Make full use of office hours.
Really interesting class, and lecture is great. You don't have to do the textbook readings which is nice but grading on essays was harsher than expected.
TAKE THIS CLASS!! Best 200 level EAS/HIS class to take! Teaches you a great deal about modern history of Asia and gives a pretty equal representation of all 3 nations.
Take it only if really really interested. Really tough grade intro course.
Take it! Didn't think I would like it but ended up loving it. Carter and Garon are amazing, and the class is very entertaining.
Take it! Really interesting class to PDF. I think East Asian history is neglected in American education, and this class is a great way to learn more.
Take this class! Highly recommend
Take this course if you want a general broad understanding of Asian history.
Take this course if you want a general overview of East Asian history, and are prepared to attend lecture each week.
The course is a lot of work and the readings are not something to be left for the last moment.

The readings in this class are a lot. Only take this class if you have taken two history courses here because their grading on their papers is tough. This class requires almost as much work as a math class, i.e. 7-10 hours of reading and studying your notes a week

This is a decent course - lectures are interesting and I really enjoyed the precept readings. Take it if you want a general overview of East Asian history. However, choose your preceptors carefully. I would definitely opt for one of the professors not just for quality of precept but also so you can get actual feedback on your work. My preceptor only offered general feedback and graded more harshly than the professor-led precepts, so be aware of that.
take it!! you will learn so much about East Asia and actually go into a fair amount of detail!
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the history of modern East Asia. We will examine the inter-related histories of China, Japan, and Korea since 1800 and their relationships with the wider world. Major topics include: trade and cultural exchanges, reform and revolutions, war, colonialism, imperialism, and Cold War geopolitics.

title: Introduction to Historiography of Science
reviews: If you have any investment in the history of science as a discipline, this course will provide an indispensable orientation.

It's an excellent introduction to the historiography of science and to science studies more broadly. I would recommend it highly to any humanities graduate student with an interest in that literature.

This is a great course to take because you will not only learn about central issues in contemporary historiography, but you will also gain an understanding of the ideas that created history of science, philosophy of sciene, and SSS.
enjoy!
descrip: This course is designed to introduce beginning graduate students to the central problems and principle literature of the history of science from the Enlightenment into the 20th century.

title: Survey of Selected Works of Twentieth-Century Architects
descrip: This course is intended to expose the students to a range of major works, built and unbuilt, of architecture from 1950 to the present. This course will focus on these particular buildings as they open themselves to a textual analysis. These analyses are intended to open up issues such as criticality, autonomy and singularity as they begin to evolve in architectural building (as opposed to texts) in the last half of the 20th century. This course will concentrate on individual buildings not architects. Each analysis will be accompanied by an illustrated presentation and selected readings.

title: Foundations of Political Economy
descrip: Course focuses on modeling the interaction of politics and economics, with applications to a variety of substantive areas. Topics include: politics of taxation and redistribution; governmental structure, political economy of constitutional arrangements, development, and growth. Familiarity with microeconomic theory and POL 575 or the equivalent are prerequisites.

title: Life on Mars - Or Maybe Not
descrip: See website

title: Advanced German
reviews: It's easy to skip the homework since it's not graded, but you'll get much less out of the course if you do that.
Really good class. Highly recommend.
Take it if you enjoy German, not as good as 105, but its a language requirement. If you're taking German as a third language, stop at 105.
Take it if you have to obviously and if the instructor is good then it will be even more fun.
Take this class and continue German studying.
Take this course, take German! It's a really cool language, and the courseload isn't much as long as you're developing your language skills.

The German professors are actually so so wonderful. All of them are super willing to help you and are great! It is a difficult class, Kafka is difficult to understand, but it is fun. It is really chill
This course is fun especially because the conversations are the kind one would have in their mother tongue--analyzing word choice, creating word play, and enjoying/writing fiction.
definitely take if you want to learn the language, but bear in mind it's not very intensive. You can get away with not doing much unfortunately.
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using texts, online media, and other sources as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included. Conducted in German.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Class is filled with athlete and frat fuccbois, but there are teams within EPICS that will genuinely be interesting to work on.  Great 5th class, but its easy to blow off since theres little oversight.
I would advise him/her to maximize time in the lab and utilize the vast resources and sage wisdom offered by the TA's to make as best a final project as possible.
Take the course.
Take this if you want to engage in student-initiated projects.
Very good class, get involved in guided projects
prereqs: Completion of EGR 350.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Math Alive
reviews: Easy as A$$. If your taking this course your a humanities major like me and an absolute dumba$$ in anything quantitative. Congratulations sir this course is for you.
Go to more classes than I did and don't be afraid to ask the lecturer (Ian) for help.
Go to most or all of the lectures, and do all of the problem sets.
Ian is brilliant and will make you actually enjoy this course.
Only take it with Ian, not Adam Marcus.
TAKE IT WITH IAN! Amazing class

TAKE THIS CLASS! I cannot recommend it more and you will not regret it! Ian is an amazing lecturer and he really works hard to relate a lot of complicated mathematical topics in understandable ways--it was through this class that I became interested in math again after being turned off of it for so many years. He also worked really hard to get to know his students and tailor the content around our interests, as well as offer a whole range of office hours that were suited to us. Adam is also great but kind of new, so his examples aren't worked out as smoothly as Ian's, but as a whole the class was amazing!
Take if you want to fulfill a distribution requirement. Papers and psets are fairly easy and lectures can be engaging.
Take it but do the work even if you are PDFing
Take it for your QR, definitely.
Take it if you need a QR and aren't the best at math. It's pretty fun.
Take it. Makes math a little more interesting
Take this class! Very easy and a great QR.
Take this if Ian Griffiths is teaching. Do not take it if Adam Marcus is.
This is a solid QR for those who do not have much of a math background or those who are looking for a more application-based, practical math course.
This is the best solution to the QR problem. Actually interesting some of the time if you go to class
definitely take it for a QR!
not difficult but likely worth PDFing if you don't want to attend lecture
prereqs: This course is intended for non-science, non-engineering majors. When this course has closed, please email amainzer@princeton.edu to be placed on the waitlist..
descrip: Mathematics has profoundly changed our world, from the way we communicate with each other and listen to music, to banking and computers. This course is designed for those without college mathematics who want to understand the mathematical concepts behind important modern applications. The course consists of individual modules, each focusing on a particular application (e.g., digital music, sending secure emails, and using statistics to explain, or hide, facts). The emphasis is on ideas, not on sophisticated mathematical techniques, but there will be substantial problem-set requirements. Students will learn by doing simple examples.

title: Chinese Cinema
reviews: Fantastic course but you have to be engaged!  It's very easy to just sit back and zone out, if you care about the course you will love it.
Great class, take it if you are interested in film. Be warned that the 3 hour seminars can feel very long though and sometimes the topics can be a little dry.

I think Prof. Silbergeld is retiring this year, but an awesome class that I'd recommend if it were continuing under his tutelage. The movies are generally pretty good and you learn so much about really analyzing film as a medium. I also learned a lot about China, which is really cool. Would recommend!!
It's a fun class to learn about film and China
Professor Jerome is very knowledgeable. This class is not a lot of work: you just need to watch movies. The seminars could seem long sometimes, but overall I enjoyed the movies and the discussions.
Take it!
Take this class! It's a great way to learn to critique and understand film as art and in a different lens.

This was an incredible class, especially for someone like myself who's looking for a little bit of a different perspective on Chinese culture! This was, unfortunately, Professor Silbergeld's last semester teaching this course. I'm not sure that other professors will be able to do this course justice, but I guess that remains to be seen!
descrip: Thematic studies in Chinese film (Republic, People's Republic, Taiwan, Hong Kong), 1930s to the present with emphasis on recent years, viewed in relation to traditional and modern Chinese visual arts and literature, colonialism and globalism, Communist politics, gender and family values, ethnicity and regionalism, melodrama and the avant-garde, the cinematic market, artistic censorship, and other social issues.

title: Microeconomic Analysis of Domestic Policy
descrip: Examines a series of major issues of policy designed to illustrate and develop skills in particularly important applications of microeconomics. Topics will include education and training, the minimum wage, mandated benefits, affirmative action, the theory of public goods and externalities, and the basic theory of taxation. Prerequisite: 511b.

title: Readings in Early American History
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the historiography of American history in the long 18th century. Readings cover the late colonial period, the American Revolution, and the early national era. While the course is designed to prepare students for general fields in these topics, considerable attention is also paid to wider hemispheric developments as well.

title: Modern Methods for Organic Synthesis
reviews: Be prepared to do exclusively independent learning.
Enjoy the presentations!

Of course, it's a long haul to bust out your best effort at a high quality powerpoint which describes your chemical synthesis of a complex natural product. But the growth and learning is worth it and you'll feel good when it's done.
Really tough, but I'd recommend it.
be prepared for some hard work
prereqs: One full year of undergraduate organic chemistry.
descrip: This course exposes you to many types of carbon-based molecular structures, the transformations they undergo, and many kinds of chemical reactions and strategies that are important to the field of organic synthesis. Recent advances in asymmetric catalysis, cascade and other complexity-generating structural transformations, and powerful strategies for chemical synthesis that evolved from ideas about the structural origins of important, biologically active molecules such as steroid hormones, cofactors, and alkaloids are addressed.

title: Causal Inference and Research Design (Half-Term)
descrip: In this course we explore and critique methods for conducting causal inference in the social sciences. These methods are drawn from a wide variety of disciplines, including economics, sociology, statistics, education, psychology, and epidemiology. We cover quasi-experimental and observational research designs from causal inference perspectives.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Environmental Engineering Laboratory
reviews: A couple of fun field work days. Otherwise not terribly interesting, but useful for some basic lab skills.

Great introduction to lab techniques and materials for environmental engineers (especially those interested in water quality). Class isn't particularly hard, but be prepared to devote a significant amount of time on lab reports. Definitely try to get it over with junior year and not senior year.

Probably not taking this if you're not CEE, but it's a good course.  A lab report a week is a lot senior spring, so try to take it earlier if possible.  Also recommend taking water pollution beforehand if possible.  The class generally assumes a base knowledge going into a lot of the labs.
Start lab reports early
Take junior year if possible!
Take this course if you have to for environmental track of CEE.

There's not much point in taking this class unless it's required or you think that the idea of tasering fish  (which is a component of one lab near the end of the semester) is exciting, but it's probably a requirement for you if you're considering taking it. Get started on the lab reports early so you have time to interrogate Jaffe on what he actually wants, because what he wants is extremely vague. The lab reports are long and tedious, and you do better on them if you're meticulous to a passive-aggressive level.
prereqs: CEE 303 and CEE 306 or Permission Of Instructor. CEE 306 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Designed to teach experimental measurement techniques in environmental engineering and their interpretations. Analytical techniques to assess biodegradation of wastes, lake eutrophication, non-point source pollution, and transport of contaminants in surface and groundwater, as well as hydrologic measurements to determine river and groundwater discharges, and soil-moisture dynamics in response to precipitation events will be conducted.

title: What Does It Mean to Be Free?
descrip: See website

title: Water, Energy, and Ecosystems
prereqs: MAT 201.
descrip: This three-week course, offered as part of a four-course study abroad semester, takes place at Princeton University's Mpala Research Centre in central Kenya. The course will provide an introduction to the principles of hydrological sciences through the development and application of instrumentation for characterizing surface/subsurface hydrological dynamics in field settings. Lectures and field activities will address the theory of operation, design, and implementation of methods used to quantify hydrological patterns and processes.

title: Extramural Public Policy Fellowship
descrip: This course is limited to students participating in the Scholars in the Nation's Service Initiative (SINSI), the Richard H. Ullman Fellowship, or an approved MPA middle year out. Enrolled students participate in one or more internships with a federal, state, or local government agency, non-governmental organization, or multilateral institution in the U.S. or overseas. The purpose is to provide a learning environment for students to use/develop quantitative and qualitative analytical skills in an active public policy setting, with oversight from Princeton University faculty and staff.

title: Narrative Film: Working from the Script
reviews: Highly recommended if you're prepared for the time commitment.
Invest hours early on so that you don't end up with lots to do at the end.

Overall, I did not particularly enjoy this course. The films and readings were compelling but at the same time (since the class is not geared toward theory) it felt like a footnote to the class. The actual filming was enjoyable and so was editing but having the professor be so overbearing in regards to shooting schedules felt condescending and like there was a lack of understanding between the two on the professor's part. The class grows to be very time consuming but that is all explicitly stated at the beginning of the course.

Take only if you're ready to take a short film from start to end. You need to be able to pace yourself, problem-solve by yourself, and be a strong individual worker or else your production will fall apart (and Su will tell you).
Take this course if you are ready to indulge in extravagent filmmaking. This course will challenge you to work beyond your given abilities and really help you craft your eye as a cinematographer.

This is a good course. Su can be a little scary at first, but get to know her- she's very helpful if you want to go into the filmmaking world.

The class is very time consuming and demands that you take it seriously, it's hard to slack off on it. And filmmaking is actually really hard when you're expected to do it on this level. But it's fun. If you're new to film however, I recommend an intro class. If you're a little experienced, take this.
You should be willing to put the time in to film and edit. If you're willing to do that, then you will be great. It's a great course.
prereqs: Either VIS 261/262 (Intro) or VIS 263 (Documentary) or VIS 264 (Narrative) or VIS 362 (Intermediate) and self-sufficiency in film editing software, either Premiere CS6 or Final Cut 7. PLEASE NOTE: There will not be a classroom workshop in using the editing software. We will closely work on the art of editing, but you must know the software already..
descrip: A script is only the beginning. Then come the interesting decisions: the actors, the visual style, and the sound design. In this class, each student will be given one segment of a script which they can interpret in any way they choose. Will your part be done as a film noir? A musical? Will it be shot in black and white? Acted in the nude? Reimagined as a documentary? At the end of the term, all the segments will be strung together to make a complete film--a surprising collage of everyone's individual vision.

title: The Universe
reviews: Definitely take the course if you have any interest in the universe!
Do your pset and study them thoroughly for exams.
Don't let the "no calculus" fool you: the class isn't that easy. Class average was about a B-.
Extremely easy and quite interesting, would highly recommend.

Go to lecture! They are only 3 hours a week and each lecture is basically a storytelling session, super interesting. P-sets take no more than 3 hours to complete if you're following the class. It's a really interesting class for a small commitment.
Great and interesting class for anyone interested in space, physics, or history of science. Very do-able for students even with minimal science and math backgrounds.
Great class to PDF or take for grade - fun and engaging lectures with great observation sessions to view planets!
Great course! A little busy work intensive, but conceptually extremely cool, with new astro. examples and topics brought in from as recently as breaking news from the morning before lecture.

I recommend this class. As a humanities-oriented person, it challenged me to think analytically, which has important consequences for my own preferred major. Quantitative reasoning is a valuable skill in any field. Besides, the subject material is fascinating. Even a cursory understanding of the universe (which I'm afraid is all even the best scientists can boast) is enough raise meaningful questions about human existence.
If you have any interest, definitely take the course. It's really well taught and you learn a lot of really cool, relevant astro things. If you have a math background, it will also be super chill.

If you need a QR or want a general introduction to astrophysics, take this. Otherwise, I wouldn't recommend it. The lectures are somewhat boring (hardly anyone attends), and the problem sets do require work.
If you've watched a bunch of space documentaries or whatever the beginning half might be extremely boring
It's a pretty cool class. Lectures are worth going to, even if they're 90 minutes, and problem sets don't take too much time and can be sorta cool.
It's ok if you need a QR.
Learn to solve all problem sets and study lectures.
Not bad QR, actually listen in lecture and do the readings and the PSETs will be much easier.
Not stars for stoners. Actually hard,
TAKE IT!
Take if interested, but be warned - harder than expected for an AB kid (and TOO MANY BSE KIDS IN CLASS TO KILL THE CURVE)
Take it.
Take it. The material is interesting if you're even remotely interested in space, and the class isn't overly time consuming.
Take this class and go to lecture as much as you can.
Take this class, professors are great and the work is very simple and straight forward
Take this course if you are at all interested in space. Take the course seriously and it will be a very enjoyable experience.
