The material is fascinating. The problem sets are annoyingly tricky, but easily manageable if you do them with other people. Professors are great.
The problem sets are tricky - don't wait until the last minute to do them
There's really no reason not to take this course. It's very interesting and, if you have a PDF to spare, not particularly time intensive.

This class is billed as the "non-math" astronomy class for the non-math crowd, but as a person who feels more at home in the humanities, I felt pretty mathed. You should probably have at least a little bit of a physics background if you really want to succeed in terms of grades. However, the content of the course is all extremely interesting no matter the previous level of astro knowledge of the students. This topic includes a lot of material but it was all engaging.

This course is incredible! The lectures were mind blowing. If you have any interest in astronomy at all, you should definitely take it! Maybe having a physics background would help. But I took it without having any background in this, and without having taken physics since I was a freshman in high school, and the material was fine. Start the problem sets early, because they are pretty long. Make sure you understand using ratios to do the problems... it will save you many hours. If you go to the optional precepts and talk to professors and TAs, every problem set should be fine. Make sure you go to the review session before the final. It will tell you most of what you need to know for the exams. Understand the formula sheet well. No need to read, unless it's out of interest (in which case you definitely should!). Sit back and enjoy lecture! It's an amazing course!!!
This course was actually a good bit harder than I anticipated, but not undoable for a non-STEM major.

This is a fascinating course! If you are interested at all in how the universe works, this class will provide the scientific background to many concepts you may have a vague knowledge of. The homework is manageable, so it is a great QR for humanities majors.

This is a very easy course, but an interesting one. If you take it, try to pay attention and learn stuff. I did not take it as seriously as I could have and feel like I could have gotten more out of it or another class.
Very easy course, reading is light and material is pretty self-explanatory. Perfect if you need the distribution requirement or are looking for a lighter work load.
You won't really feel the need to go to lectures, but they are enjoyable and these teachers are some of the top people in the field. It's an enjoyable class.
definitely take the course but be aware there is a lot of math you need to know
loved it

this is a VERY easy fifth class. like make sure not to get too cocky and like not go to lecture at all cus then it might be difficult to get the information later, but if you try a little bit you can do well. the material is cool but covered at such a shallow level that its a lot like watching like cosmos or something. its cool but you wont really understand why some shit works past a 8th grade level
prereqs: This course is intended for humanities and social science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful..
descrip: This specially designed course targets the frontier of modern astrophysics. Subjects include the planets of our solar system, the birth, life, and death of stars; the search for extrasolar planets and extraterrestrial life; the zoo of galaxies from dwarfs to giants, from starbursts to quasars; dark matter and the large-scale structure of the universe; Einstein's special and general theory of relativity, black holes, neutron stars, and big bang cosmology. This course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry. High school physics would be useful.

title: Workshop on Social Organization
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work is at the intersection of the fields of organization studies, economic sociology and social network analysis. In addition to covering foundational readings in these fields and addressing selected special topics (e.g. social organizational aspects of economic crisis), the workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

title: Intermediate Turkish II
reviews: Do the extra-credit work Dr. Hatemi assigns! She wants you to do as well as possible and provides the opportunity for you to succeed if you take her up on her offers!
If Nilufer Hatemi is teaching this course you absolutely must take it.  She is one of the most, dedicated, caring, and intelligent professors at Princeton.
prereqs: TUR 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: To enable students to communicate in Modern Turkish, and to read Turkish (current events, editorials, literature and academic writings) with some speed and accuracy.

title: Connection and Communication in the Digital Bazaar
descrip: See website

title: Locked Up: Theatre, Literature and Cinema of Coercive Confinement in Ireland
reviews: Be prepared to do all the readings, but the course itself is always rewarding.
Great course. Fintan O'Toole is spectacular. Definitely worth taking. Lots of time spent lecturing about the subject so especially good if you are more shy about speaking in class.
If you are at all interested in Irish culture/history/theater/anything take a class with Fintan.
If you are interested in the subject matter, regardless of prior background to it, absolutely take a class with Fintan.
Take it if you're an English major or a theatre certificate student or simply want a nice, great, loving professor!
prereqs: Warning: of its nature this course deals with traumatic and disturbing experiences, including the physical and sexual abuse of children. Students must be willing to reflect on material that is often uncomfortable. No specific prior knowledge of modern Irish history is required, as there will be an introductory orientation..
descrip: From the 1920s until the 1950s Ireland locked up people who did not fit the state's desired image in a vast complex of institutions - Magdalene laundries for women deemed to be in "moral danger"; industrial schools for children regarded as potentially unruly; mental hospitals for adults who were socially deviant-all of whom were vulnerable both to effective enslavement and to physical and sexual abuse. Revelation of these abuses has shaken Irish society and the Irish church. In this course we consider how this system was reflected in plays, fiction and film, sometimes in direct testimony by survivors, sometimes in the most surprising ways.

title: African American Autobiography
descrip: Autobiography has long played a pivotal role in the development of African American literary, cultural and intellectual history. This course will survey major fictional and non-fictional texts in the evolution of African American autobiography. We will read these texts both as representative of literary and cultural trends in the history of the genre, and for their individual significance.

title: Senior Thesis with Design
descrip: Similar to 442 with the principle difference that the thesis must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior thesis with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Religion and Secularism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Financial Management in the Corporate and Public Sectors
descrip: Designed to introduce graduate students in public and international affairs to certain principals and analytic tools widely used in the financial management of organizations, privately or publicly owned. Course is based on the premise that future civil servants should be familiar with this subject matter, either because they may be involved in the financial management of public agencies, or negotiate financial contracts with the private sector, or regulate financial management in the private sector.

title: Integrated Building Studios
descrip: Integrated design studios approach architecture from a synthetic perspective. Considerations of structure, environmental technology, building materials and systems, exterior envelope, and site design are integrated directly into the design process through the participation of technical faculty and outside advisors in critiques and reviews. Projects are developed to a high level of detail. At least one course is required for professional M.Arch. students.

title: Southeast Asia's Global History
reviews: Good class, but will definitely be easier for those who are already familiar with the region. I wish I had perhaps done some preliminary reading beforehand.
Take it - it's fairly chill. A bit confusing if you have no idea what Southeast Asia is - which I think a few people in the class probably felt.
Take it out of interest or cause you need it, it works as either
Take it, show up, and do the readings.
Take scrupulous notes, research all the readings briefly, and go to office hours.

This course was one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Laffan made the lectures very interesting and I was never bored. The readings were also very interesting (surprisingly) and the assignments were thought-provoking. Overall, I learned so much about Southeast Asia that I had no clue about before, and I did so without even realizing it. I recommend this course to anyone who wants to have fun while learning about SE asian history. I had ZERO knowledge of the region and I'm leaving the class with a basic historical understanding of nearly every country/state in the region.

This is a great class if you'd like to learn about the modern history of SE Asia. There is also some background in premodern history of the region?which was helpful in understanding SE Asia as a whole. The seminar was structured in part-lecture, part-discussion style.
descrip: This course aims to provide an introduction to Southeast Asia and its prominent place in global history through a series of encounters in time; from Marco Polo in Sumatra to the latest events in such buzzing cities as Bangkok, Jakarta and Hanoi. For the early modern period we will read various primary sources, before turning to consider a series of diverse colonial impacts across the region (European, American and Asian), and then the mechanisms underpinning the formation of some of the most vibrant, and sometimes turbulent, countries on the world stage.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Accounting
reviews: Give you basic understanding of corporate finance.
The book is pretty useful.
Unless the teacher changes, you're way better off with reading a book.
descrip: Major topics in modern corporate finance. We study investment policy (investment decision rules, project valuation, cost of capital) and financial policy (mostly capital structure decisions). Additional topics (private equity, bankruptcy and reorganization, merger and acquisitions) are covered if time permits.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Seniors only (except for juniors who have completed EGR 351)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Nonlinear Models
descrip: This is half of the second-year sequence in econometrics methodology (ECO 513 is the other). The course covers nonlinear statistical models for the analysis of cross-sectional and panel data. It is intended both for students specializing in econometric theory and for students interested in applying statistical methods to statistical data. Approximately half of the course is devoted to development of the large-sample theory for nonlinear estimation procedures, while the other half concentrates on application of the methods to various econometric models.

title: Approaches to Contemporary Dance and Movement Practices
reviews: Be prepared to have your understanding of your body changed!
Definitely take this class if you have a love for dance. It is a huge time commitment, but if the quality of class stays the same or improves I highly recommend you try it out!
I loved that the course met 4x a week. I plan to take this again if it's offered. Can't recommend highly enough.
Interested in contemporary dance? TAKE.
Take it if you like to dance!
Take this class--you will learn a lot, be stronger, and dance a ton!

This was one of the best, if not the best, dance courses I have ever taken. Rebecca Lazier is not just a great professor, but one one of those professor's who has had a profound impact on my life -- dancing and otherwise. I feel immensely stronger and better prepared to deal with the dance world. I highly recommend taking this class
prereqs: Students must email Prof. Rebecca Lazier (rlazier@princeton.edu) to request permission to enroll..
descrip: This advanced studio course compares approaches to contemporary dance and movement techniques to explore how training fuels choreographic process and aesthetic research. Students will train intensively in Contact Improvisation, Gaga, Forsythe Technologies, and contemporary African dance, learning each form's origin and theory to facilitate physical transformation. Workshops in modern and non-western forms will widen historic and global perspectives. Knowledge gained through a comparative embodied practice allows students to form research built on a synthesis of the influences that have shaped current movement research and choreography.

title: Intermediate Arabic II
reviews: ARA 107 is a struggle, just as are all Arabic classes at Princeton, but take this with Tarek and he will make it worth your while! He is an incredible teacher and person. He will make you fall in love with the language, if you haven't already.
Great professor!!
I would tell another student to be prepared to roll up his or her sleeves and relish the chance to work hard. Arabic can demand a lot of work, but the rewards are tremendous!

If you're interested in Arabic, keep taking it at this level. I REALLY, HIGHLY recommend taking it with Tarek. He is the best language teacher at Princeton, and is definitely among the best teachers at our university overall. He is one of the reasons I love this school so much. He is hilarious, and believes in you enough to get you through this very tough language. And throughout it all he builds an atmosphere of love and care in his class. Tarek is awesome! And so is Arabic in general!
Make sure you're interested in knowing the language, it's a lot of work but it's worth it if you put in the effort.
Take it with Tarek, nobody else is nearly as good a teacher as he is.
Take the course with Tarek if you're at all interested, but be prepared for a lot of hard work.
Take this course with Tarek.
Tarek is a great teacher who cares about all of his students and will try his hardest to make sure you learn the language well.
Tarek is the best. He is the best professor in the department and will make you fall in love with the language.
would absolutely recommend.
prereqs: ARA 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Study of Arabic grammar and syntax, and use of the language in functional contexts. Reading of extra material from articles, newspapers, short stories. Discussions are held in Arabic to enhance students' speaking skills.

title: Elementary Modern Greek II
prereqs: HLS 101 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: To provide the basis for acquiring a command of written and spoken Modern Greek.

title: Social Structure in Africa: Responses to Socio-Political and Economic Forces
reviews: Do it
Great class to get a non-Western perspective on African history and society! Excellent, comprehensive intro and encouraged me to take more AFS classes in the future.

Great course. Prof Agawu is an excellent teacher. As an African, this course taught me so much about the continent and its history as well as its present condition. The title is misleading, this course covers so much more than social structure -- we talk about colonial history, independence movements, political and economic systems, growth, aid, witchcraft and religion.
Professor Agawu is an excellent professor who engenders community in her class. I made friends as well as academic colleagues who weren't afraid to challenge me or each other. Take this class!
Strongly Recommend

Take this course!
It was fun and I learnt a lot about African History.
Take this course. Professor Agawu is awesome.
prereqs: No previous knowledge of Africa is required..
descrip: This seminar addresses structural responses and strategies developed by African nations and communities upon their insertion into the global political and economic world. What are these structural strategies? What traditional and or modern resources have African nations and communities utilized? Themes to be investigated include political, social and religious structures; global economic interaction; and women in society. The character of Africa before modern nationhood will form the backdrop to discussions of Africa as we know it today.

title: Freud on the Psychology of Ordinary Mental Life
descrip: See website

title: Intermediate Chinese II
reviews: A lot of homework, quizzes, tests, exams, etc. but they are not hard and you'll learn a lot
Always try to participate and continue to improve in the class.
Definitely take it if you[re up for it. The work isn't hard, but it's a lot.
Definitely take this course! you learn a lot
Don't cram for tests. Learn vocab then learn grammar. Learn vocab and grammar preferably before they are taught in class.
Exceptionally well-taught. However, true second-year students may struggle, as a lot of material is covered.
Great course, very rigorous though so be prepared to work hard.

I love taking Chinese! You should absolutely take this language. It is so rewarding and the teachers are really great. The program is so efficient, and the classes are actually so fun and entertaining.

I would tell the other student to take advantage of the opportunity to participate in class, and to be sure that the student makes sure that they will have time in their academic schedule to have Chinese class as a priority.
If you took CHI105, you're going to take CHI107. It's just as amazing as a class. The Chinese department here is intense but phenomenal.

If you want to really improve in an important language, take Chinese. It's an exciting and rigorous department that gives you back everything you put into it. Despite the difficult grading, your skills show how much you gain!

Just pay attention in class, and read the textbook the night before the class is taught.  Make sure you know how the grammar structures work, and the context in which you use the words taught in the lesson (usually found in the study guides).

Significantly harder than 105 since you learn terms related to Chinese history, politics and society as compared to learning about everyday life. That being said the department is really great and the teachers are always there to help (they will almost always meet with you immediately if you express the need). Also, prepare for class in advance! You can wing it even if you don't but it really helps to know the material beforehand
Taking Chinese at Princeton is one of the best decisions you can make. By the end of second year, you'll have a very solid foundation - but it's just a start. Continue into third year!
Taught very well! Really enjoyed it, and my Chinese definitely improved a lot.
The Chinese department is tops. absolute tops.

This course isn't amazingly fun, but it teaches the language well, and you will likely come to like your teachers and enjoy class.  Having taken it for 4/4 of my terms at princeton so far, it got tiresome, but I'm glad I chose this language.  Be prepared to work harder than other languages, though.
This is an awesome course! You will learn a lot of really useful and important vocabulary and grammar, but be prepared to work hard.
Yes, but only if they actually want to learn Chinese. It is too much work to take solely to fulfill a requirement

class is well taught! always same amount of work, it's kind of a lot but not too bad once you get into the schedule. you won't have to memorize how to write the characters, which is a pro or con depending how you think about it.
its a great class if you put in the effort.

never fear 101-102 chinese students. this level is much less work and way more fun. You finally get to start talking about interesting aspects of chinese culture politics, development etc and learn more vocab. still sticks with the imitation of dialogue approach and emphasis on repetition rather than spontaneous thought but definitely worth continuing
stay on top of the material
take it
prereqs: CHI 105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Continuing the intensive study of modern spoken and written Chinese, this course shifts the emphasis to the reading of modern cultural and social issues.

title: Quantitative Analysis IV
descrip: This course will introduce Bayesian statistics and machine learning. The first half of the course will cover the basics of Bayesian statistical analysis, including linear models, hierarchical models, and missing data models. The EM algorithm and Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms will be implemented. In the second half of the course, we will cover recent methods in statistical learning. Possible topics include variable selection, smoothers, regression trees, support vector machines, topic models, belief nets, and deep learning. The course will be taught at the level of Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective by Kevin Murphy.

title: Fragmented Past, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Macroeconomics
reviews: DO NOT TAKE IT unless you have to. I didn't believe my friends when they told me not to take it, but they were right.
DO NOT TAKE IT. Zaidi is so bad. You won't learn a thing and all the material is from the book. Worst class I've ever taken. Take 311 instead.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS UNLESS YOU HAVE TO.
Don't take expecting to become interested in economics. Covering mostly macro applications of the IS/LM model, there's really not much here that can't be better learned by reading a textbook.
Don't take it with Iqbal.
Don't take this class with Zaidi unless you HAVE to.
Don't take unless you need to
Don't take with Iqbal - It was the worst experience of my Princeton University career
Good material but not taught well at all. Don't take unless you're Econ.
Horribly taught, precepts are unhelpful, you have to take this course, but you will gain nothing from it. Honestly, worst class I've experienced at Princeton. I absolutely hated it.
I do not recommend unless you are willing to learn all the material by yourself.

I have a feeling Professor Zaidi will get criticized in these reviews, but he's a good professor to take it with. Really felt like he cared about the students and wanted people to do well. Fair examinations, very willing to answer questions! Professor Zaidi was great!

I wish the Econ department would put in less monotonous professors in intro and core Econ classes. This has to stop.
It says something when about 20% of the class shows up for a core class in the second biggest department at Princeton.

I would tell other people not to take this course if they are not an econ student because there are other courses that are easier and more interesting. However, if you are an econ student, then take it and make sure to read the textbook.
I'm sorry you have to take this. The lectures will bore you, and eventually you will not attend, which is a shame since the material is actually kind of interesting.
If I didn't have to take the course I probably would not have but it was good for what it was.
If it is not required, do not take it.
If you don't enjoy lecture, just read the slides on your own.

If you take this course, be prepared to do a lot of self studying, as lectures and office hours are not extremely helpful. Get a good study group together and read the textbook, don't overlook small details/concepts, and understand how to derive things for exams.
Iqbal is by far the worst lecturer you'll ever have. He's uncharismatic, unclear, and overall terrible. I learned the entire course from the textbook
Iqbal is not a good professor for this course. A lot of work on your own.
Learned mostly from reading the book.
Make sure to pay attention in lecture. Take if needed for a major; if you are not planning on being an econ major, perhaps consider other departmentals.
Not well taught.  Read the textbook, find a good study buddy and be prepared to do a lot of learning on your own.
Obviously, take the course if you need the departmental and don't feel that your math is strong enough for 311.
Only take if required to.
Only take if you're econ

Only take this class if you are required. Otherwise, it is a complete waste of time. The lectures are uninformative, and no one has any idea what is going on. Please make better core classes for the econ department!
Only take this course if you have to for the economics major.

Only take this course if you have to for your major, and even then think about not taking. It was a painful class. Lectures were boring, problem sets were impossible and the Iqbal did not explain anything in lectures.
Prof Zaidi is a nice guy but his presentation is extremely dry and the course's content, as well, is quite dry.

Prof. Zaidi is a really nice person who is very passionate about economics, but it is very hard to learn in this class. I'd recommend going to office hours and asking questions consistently during the semester.
READ THE TEXTBOOK.  The lectures were hard to follow and without the text book I would not have understood much.

Read the text book CAREFULLY and re-read chapters. One cannot just go to lecture or just read the text-book, so some form of happy medium must be reached. Also make sure to go to precept to ask as many questions as possible.
Read the textbook and attend office hours in order to do the psets. Take only if you have to.
Read the textbook and lecture slides. You know the drill; this is an econ course.
Read the textbook before lectures.
Take it because you have to but not an easy class. Go to lectures or look at the slides at least. Find a good pset group and go over the practice tests in depth.
Take it cause you have to or want an understanding of macro, but if you want an engaging class it might not be for you
Take it if you have to. I was much more interested in macro after I took intro - this class sapped some of my interest out of the subject.
Take it if you have to. Pretty dry
Take it only if you have to. Zaidi might not be the most engaging lecturer but he knows his stuff. Easy B

Take it! The tests are super fair and predictable, so not a pain to prepare for at all. The material has a lot of overlap with ECO 353 (international monetary economics), so it'd be awesome to take concurrently.
Take this course if you are an econ major, but stay away if it is not needed. Interesting in some regards, but there are better courses to take.
Take this course to learn more about macro--lectures are quite dry and hard to follow along.
Take this over 311, definitely, but if nothing changes, don't expect lectures to be too engaging. I don't know much about the other preceptors, but try getting Olivier Darmouni if you can.
Terrible, but you have to take it
The lectures did a poor job of explaining the concepts we needed. Grading requirements were unclear because most questions were qualitative.
The worst taught class I've ever taken at Princeton. Only take it if you need to.
This class can be really dry, confusing, and boring. I would only recommend it if you need it for Econ.
This is a terribly taught course. Only take it if you need to.
Understanding lecture slides and the problem sets are key to doing well in the class. Preceptors are more than willing to offer assistance, so take advantage of that.
VERY boring. Read the textbook
Very poorly taught. A lot of seemingly nonsensical weird logic. Don't take unless it's a departmental.
Yes if an economics major.
You have to take this class if you're an econ major. If you're not, I wouldn't recommend it. Take an econ class on something applied to a particular topic instead.
do not take this is Iqbal is still teaching.
g
only if you have to.
required.
take it
terrible class, you have to take it though if you're an econ major. Do yourself a favour and don't major in economics.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101..
descrip: This course covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. We will focus on the determination of macroeconomic variables -- such as output, employment, price, and the interest rate -- in the short, medium, and long run, and we will address a number of policy issues. We will discuss several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Contemporary Society, Politics, and Culture
reviews: A good way to continue learning the language through writing and speaking while also learning about politics and history.
Fine course. Your German will improve.
Great course, definitely take it
Highly recommend if a native German is teaching. Fun if you're comfortable with your German. Not too difficult.
I would take this course if you need to fulfill your requirement.
Mareike is great. Unfortunately she is leaving, so it is hard to say how this class will be with another professor.

Quite a bit of reading and film-watching, but Professor Stoll won't force you to speak in class if you don't want to. That said, the readings and films were really interesting, so I would encourage you to do them at least on a semi-regular basis.
Take it - Prof. Stoll is a wonderful professor and person, the material is genuinely interesting and not too demanding, and you will learn a lot.
Take it but make sure too many people haven't signed up! Really interesting material.
Take it if you want to improve your German, regardless of your interests - it has something for everyone content-wise! A very good class.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: This course traces German history and culture from 1945 to the present by examining, in a variety of media, the period's most heated debates: first, the controversy around the aftermath of Nazi rule, which escalated in the 60s and 70s in violent clashes between students and government; second, the ideological rivalry between two German states up to the reunification; third, the persistent struggles around multiculturalism; fourth, the debate around Germany's role in Europe, and why Germany is equally loved and hated by its neighbors. This course facilitates advanced competence in written and oral German.

title: Advanced Physical Chemistry: Chemical Dynamics and Thermodynamics
reviews: Just take 306, it's less of a struggle.

Most people taking this class are doing so because they are chem majors who need it. Don't take this class out of general interest or unless you have a true need to take it. That being said, it's not a horrible class, just not a great one. Work is very manageable but exams are very difficult to prepare for as no practice material is provided. I'm not sure I can truly recommend this course over 306, but it's not a bad choice if you choose to do so.

The math is not too hard in this class, but it is not a particularly well taught class and is very very theoretical. If you don't have to take a thermo class I would recommend against it, and if you do, I would recommend checking out 306 as well.

This thermo class is the first class that really challenged me to think about how to explain science using math, and not just accept intuition as a solution to problems. Learning how to use, understand, and apply math to be able to derive relationships and formulas are very valuable skills that you won't get in many other math based sciences. However, the opportunity to gain these skills is mainly the responsibility of the learner and not built into the class. While it isn't entirely necessary to go beyond the surface level to "do" the class, it is necessary if you want to get valuable skills out of it in my opinion. In this sense, going beyond the minimum involves seeking office hours, spending time with the book before and after classes, and/or reviewing homework problems for insight and understanding. Basically, it's up to you how much you want to get out of this course. The minimum time commitment for doing the work is not an insane amount, but the more work you put into past the minimum, the more you get out of it. So if you're adventurous, be prepared to set aside time for the class or else you put yourself at risk of being disappointed. A few side notes include Dr. Wang being a speedy but overall good lecturer, the readings being really good, and tests being extremely difficult.
Would recommend this class! Problem sets are really helpful and not too difficult. I appreciated the level of material (as compared to 306).
prereqs: MAT 201 or equivalent. Some knowledge of thermodynamics is useful. This course is open to freshmen and sophomores only with instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is an introduction to statistical thermodynamics, kinetics, and molecular reaction dynamics. Following a review of classical thermodynamics, the statistical mechanics of molecular systems is developed. Discussions of transport properties, chemical kinetics, and reaction dynamics form the rest of the course.

title: Religion in the Americas Workshop
prereqs: REL 523.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. Designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Latin American Politics from Below
reviews: A lot of reading but comprehensive in what is covered and great to build a foundation on social movements in general.
Lots of reading but an  amazing course.

Take the course if you are at all interested in Latin American politics and social movements form below. Professor Sanin is really interesting, albeit it a bit intense at times, and you'll get a lot out of the course.
This class is great. You will learn a lot about Latin America. Be prepared for a lot of reading-- up to 200/250 per week

This is a great class. It will help you understand better poor people social movements, which are extremely relevant in Latin America (and in now in the US due to the recent wave of populism). If you want to learn more about Latin America, Professor Sanin is probably one of your best options out of the WWS, SPA, LAS, and POL departments.
descrip: This seminar focuses on the role of from-below groups in Latin American political history. It begins with an exploration of theoretical works that deal with social movements. It then analyzes the different periods in which the mobilization of from-below groups has influenced political transformations in the region. We will study the demands of indigenous, slaves and peasants during colonial times, and their contributions to the independence movement, early democratic transitions, social revolutions and guerrilla groups. We will also explore the region's new social movements, such as women, LGBTQI, and victims of political violence.

title: Topics in American Literature - Henry James and William Faulkner
reviews: Definitely take this class if you can!  The authors are interesting, and Mitchell does an excellent job working with the material and making sure that class is dynamic, engaging, and thought-provoking.  One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton, by far.
Definitely take this course. Lee Mitchell is incredible and it is an extremely manageable workload.
Don't be overwhelmed by the reading. They're far from easy reads, but Professor Mitchell does a good job of walking the class through them.
Enjoy it
Incredible-- one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Take it! Lee Mitchell is an inspiration, and his lectures are incredible...
Mitchell is a great lecturer. The Faulkner readings were particularly good. Overall an enjoyable class with loads of reading.

Professor Mitchell is a truly amazing teacher. He encourages students to engage with dense texts with a critical eye and a conscientious mind. This is a must take if you are interested in Henry James and/or William Faulkner! Strongly recommended!
Take this course!
descrip: This course examines the careers of two of America's most accomplished novelists. Manifest differences aside, both authors were obsessed with the ensnaring effects of plot, prompting both to imagine fictional realms that are as much "designs" on the reader as on characters.

title: Dissertation Seminar
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. The seminar aims at assisting students in their research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. It meets for two hours each week throughout the academic year.

title: Illusions, Delusions, and Neuroscience
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Policy Aspects of Federal and State Budgeting and Fiscal Decision-Making
reviews: Definitely take it!
Good class to learn about state and federal fiscal problems. Keevey is sweet and understanding, and there is VERY LITTLE work. Take this class!
I feel like a much more well-informed citizen having taken it.
Professor Keevey is wonderful and this is one of the best classes at Princeton. An extremely useful course and a wonderful man to know.
Take it!
Take the class and be engaged. Budgeting is very interesting if you could get over some of the more boring aspects of it.
Take the course! It's super easy and actually pretty interesting. All you really need to do is read a few articles and the midterm/final are really a walk in the park
Take this course. Great grading, amazing professor, and genuinely valuable knowledge.
take the course. Keevey is the cutest man in the world and the nicest. He really wants everyone to do well. and "gives at least a C for bringing a name tag", easy A
descrip: Is government spending and debt limiting our country? The course will examine key aspects of federal and state decision-making. We will examine budgeting, taxation, bonds and debt, resource allocation methods, and impact on policy. We will examine the implications of the current confrontations over budget policy in Washington and what is meant for the future. The `feds' spend more than any corporation in the world, but, states in the aggregate spend just as much; thus the course will consider the financial differences between the two governmental levels and the impact both have on our economy.

title: Poverty, Inequality and Health in the World
prereqs: WWS 507 and 511. Please see instructor to apply for enrollment..
descrip: About well-being throughout the world, with focus on income and health. Explores what happened to poverty, inequality, and health, in the US, and internationally. Discusses conceptual foundations of national and global measures of inequality, poverty, and health; construction of measures, and extent to which they can be trusted; relationship between globalization, poverty, and health, historically and currently. Examines links between health and income, why poor people are less healthy and live less long than rich people.

title: Cell Biology and Development
reviews: Be sure to read the papers carefully and ask questions.
I would only take this class if you plan would like a primer to prepare you for your own literature review of development in a particular system.
If you do not have previous experience in developmental biology, you will feel this course is hard.
It's a waste of your time so don't work so hard  in it.
Just read the papers and make sure you understand the figures
Some developmental processes are very complex, so sometimes you can take advantage of Youtube to get some background knowledge if you are confused with the papers.
prereqs: MOL348.
descrip: A continuation of MOL 504, with two modules, Cell Biology II and Development. Cell Biology II concerns how cells assemble into functional tissues, covering the molecular components and fundamental concepts in cell communication, adhesion, shape, division, and differentiation. Development covers the basics of developmental biology, focusing on important concepts and model systems. Primary literature is used to introduce seminal works and classic approaches, modern experimental techniques, and outstanding questions in the field. Students learn the basis of a good paper, to read critically, and to think beyond the reading.

title: Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences
reviews: Attend Class or fail: The choice is yours.
Do your homework and sit in the front. It forces you to pay attention and you'll be thankful.
Don't be afraid to ask questions and class and go to office hours
Don't take this course unless you need to. But it's not too bad of a course.
Even if everything is completely new, it's definitely a doable math course! As long as you do all the practice sets and make sure you understand notes form class, you can do well.
Hard course. Take it only if you have to and/or if you are interested in math
Hard, but easier than 103
I definitely recommend taking this course. The instructor is great.
I definitely recommend this course. It is by no means easy but the professors do a great job of introducing the material clearly and thoroughly. Overall, great course!
I don't know how this works out in the long run. it's basically a short cut but unless the 201/202/310 track feels like a must to you, then it's exactly the short cut you will want to take.
I think it's a very good course. I really enjoyed all of the teachers.
I took this class because I needed it for econ. It wasn't riveting but it was a pretty good math class. Challenging but not super difficult. I thought Ilya was quite good. He's a cool dude.

I took this course because it was required to be an Economics major. Ilya is absolutely amazing! He truly is a fantastic professor and teaches the content so well. He explains topics so well and make math fun, which is such a hard thing to do. Being someone who hates math, I really loved this class and would totally recommend it to anyone. Problem sets were not that difficult and there were only three quizzes all semester. As long as you attend and pay attention in lecture you are golden. The midterm was not that difficult. The final was more challenging but doable.
If you are an Econ major, make sure you take this class. It is miles better than 201. Only take 201 and 202 if you are certain that you want to get the finance certificate.
If you do not need to take for economics, I would not recommend it. For your QR, I would take MAT 103 or something outside of the math department.

If you need it for econ, take it and it's not too bad. I would recommend if you don't love math not taking it until you're sure you're doing econ- not something you need to get out of the way after just taking calc since it doesn't build on MAT103/Calc AB too much!
If you want to preserve your GPA and your sanity, take this class instead of 104, 201, and 202.
It's a pretty easy math class. Take it, but think about whether it will prepare you for what you need it to.

Keep up with what you are learning every week! The class moves pretty quickly, so falling behind can really kill you. If you have any questions, make sure to ask! Ilya is very helpful but sometimes moves very quickly so it's okay to tell him to slow down.

MAT175 is the most non-math-person friendly math course at Princeton. The hardest problems on exams are easier than the hardest problems in the textbook. Ilya is a fantastic professor, working to be engaging in lecture and always eager to help in office hours. Covers the first 6.5 weeks of MAT201 material though, which does mean students who hope to move on to courses that recommend 201 as math background could be at a disadvantage. MAT175 is also uncurved.
Not bad. Take it!
Not easy, but necessary.
Only if you need it

Only take this course if you need it for a major requirement. It is not well taught and will require you to learn most of the material on your own. The department decided to make the course harder in Spring 2016, so the tests and quizzes had very low averages. Hopefully they will fix it by next semester.
PRACTICE as much as you can, fairly. The rest is history.
Prepare like crazy for the quizzes, the midterm, and the final. Don't fudge the homeworks because they really are integral for you to do well on the exams
Spend time looking through your notes and trying to make sure you understand them well.
Take this course (especially if you're not a math-heavy person)!

Take this course if you plan on majoring in anything that isn't 100% writing based. This really is essential information, and you don't know calculus until you take it. It isn't too hard, and is fairly interesting, but mostly it teaches you such important math that it simply cannot be disregarded.
Take this math! it's the best!
The class got harder recently so I wouldn't take it for an easy A.
The course goes fast, so stay on top of your weekly work
They made it harder this year and onward
This was a great course to take Ilya is awesome and made this class fun
Use the book to teach yourself in terms of material you do not understand.

Very manageable class!  If you're worried about math, Ilya is extremely helpful and patient.  If you are hoping for a fast-paced math class with lots of critical thinking and problem-solving, this is probably not the right one, though.
You're taking this either for QR or a certificate. It's not terrible like other math courses, but it requires many instances of intense studying.
f
good course
take it if you aren't too good in math and don't need to take 201/202. but do not underestimate, the final is hard AF
you have to take it anyways no matter what these reviews say.
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Survey of topics from multivariable calculus as preparation for future course work in economics or life sciences. Topics include basic techniques of integration, average value, vectors, partial derivatives, gradient, optimization of multivariable functions, and constrained optimization with Lagrange multipliers.

title: Grand Strategy
reviews: A great course for anyone interested in strategy, war, and history. Lots of reading though for sure.

Courses like this that deal with highly theoretical yet also highly historically-contingent subjects run the strong risk of missing the forest for the trees or the trees for the forest. This course managed to miss both the forest and the trees, by going into no more depth and analysis of historical events in its kiddie pool-shallow lectures than a middle school history class, and by bringing up each reading at most once and then never discussing them again. It was immensely difficult to determine who "major theorists" were, given that we discussed every reading except Thucydides (seriously, not everything has to be compared to Ancient Greece, and if I have to hear or read one more bozo who insists that Greek civilization ended after the Peloponnesian War...historically illiterate statements like that were a frequent occurrence in lecture) exactly once. That lack of in-depth analysis makes the comical volume of reading assigned (fewer than 200 pages A MEETING was light, and for one meeting we were assigned an entire 500 page book and another 100 pages of supplemental readings) all the more unconscionable. In short do not take this class, especially if you are interested in strategy or history. The offensively shallow treatment of nearly every aspect of the subject and the mismatch between the depth and volume of the reading and the intellectual barrenness of anything in class, puts me in mind of a certain scene from from Billy Madison. A poor grade is a badge of honor.
Crazy amount of reading but great lectures. The amount of information can be overwhelming, but you will be exposed to very fascinating ideas.
Definitely take it. Be prepared to do a lot of really interesting reading. Be prepared to learn 5000 years of history. Try to get Travis as preceptor!
Definitely take!
Do the readings and go to every lecture.
Don't do all the readings, be strategic and choose the ones that are emphasized the most in lecture
Don't take the class unless you really want to go into IR. Otherwise, its not for you.
Great course but it takes a LOT of work.

Great course. If you're taking it for a grade you are gonna have to kill yourself to read every article. But skimming is highly encouraged by the preceptors, who really do a lot to help. Ikenberry and Friedberg are very approachable, but also pretty busy. So get to know them if you can catch them.
Heavy but intensely interesting reading workload. Learn to read fast, or be overwhelmed!

I originally took this course for the History & the Practice of Diplomacy certificate...but disliked the class so strongly that I ended up PDFing it and dropping the certificate. First of all: it is mis-marketed because this is really a military strategy class. So if you're like me and not at all interested in military strategy, you will be miserable. Lectures are pretty good but there is an inhumane amount of (very dense, very dull) reading. In sum: this class is worth it if and only if you are really really interested in the subject matter (ie you basically want this to be your career, you are in ROTC, etc) AND you can organize your semester so that this class is your only major commitment. 
(Also FYI this is a pretty miserable class to PDF because it has both a final paper and a final exam. Don't do it.)

If interested in recorded world history, take this course. It is basically an analytical approach to history. The course has a historical focus! Way too many readings, but very interesting and important material. Professor Friedberg is an amazing lecturer. I found grading was rather harsh.
If you have to take it for some reason, sure go ahead. Otherwise, it's a lot of reading and I don't really think I learned a ton. Definitely don't take it as a fifth class.
If you want to get everything out of the class, do the readings.

If you're deciding between this and POL 240, take POL 240 (with Moravcsik, at least). It's a decent course, though, if you keep up with the readings. And if Travis Sharp is still precepting, ABSOLUTELY take his. Besides, as of now, it's the only HPD prereq.

If you're taking this course, it's probably because you've heard a lot about it and really want to. It's a decent course, although it is definitely a big time commitment and you may not get much more out of it than you would have from the readings.

Its a solid class. For CIV, Age of Empires, Total War, and Universalis geeks like me, this class is like playing those games but actually learning it and knowing how to apply it to the highly salient and meaningful conversations on what is US GS for the 21st century and the conversations on how to analyze other nation's GSs. Just make sure to not waste time playing those games when needing to actually read the plethora of amazing books and journal articles Ikenberry and Friedberg have in store for you. All the preceptors, and even the professors, are very, very approachable regardless of what you think. Enrich this class by popping into Christensen's, Kotkin's, and others' classes. Go to the talks and panels that CISS, LISD, and other security studies and political organizations on campus have organized throughout the Spring, especially in the second half of the course if taught in the Spring. Make this class come alive for you. It will seem like a lot for the first three weeks or so, get over it and recognize the bigger pictures. Contextualize the material on what is happening today. Play devil's advocate, even with Ikenberry and Friedberg; they love seeing new ideas on the table to nuance or even debate their main beliefs of what is occurring today with America's GS. This was my favorite class, so I am biased in saying this: TAKE IT.
Lectures were basically a history class, the strategy was actually discussed in precept.
Really interesting course. Take it, but be prepared to do a lot of readings! The grading can also be very hard.
Recommend if you're extremely interested in the subject matter.
Suck it up and do the readings. It's what being in social science is all about. You will never learn everything this class has to teach you, so do as much as you can, and you'll get a lot out of it.

TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. If you played Civilization, this is the class for you. If you like Game of Thrones, this is the class for you. It's literally about people's plans to conquer the world and how they failed. Ikenberry and Friedberg are excellent lecturers, and Travis is an AMAZING preceptor. There is a rather outrageous amount of reading, so make sure to stay on top of it.
TAKE IT! Obviously be prepared to work incredibly hard and read a lot, but two greats teach this class and you don't want to miss out on this really amazing opportunity to learn from them.
THIS CLASS IS SO REWARDING! take this class but be ready to put in a lot of time reading. PDF if you do not want to do all the readings.
Take this class! If you are interested in problems of rise and decline in the historical perspective, this is a perfect course for that. Don't be scared off by the workload!

The course was interesting but covers an incredible spread of history and material. be prepared to delve into time periods you are not familiar with and be expected to know the historical info behind it. There are an insane amount of readings each week, many of which reiterate similar points.
This class assigns over 300 pages of reading a week, and the readings generally are not interesting, but instead very dry.

This class is a tremendous amount of work if you try to do even some of the readings (I normally read everything assigned for classes, and I managed about 20% of the readings for this class). If you're going to take it, accept that the readings are not possible to finish, and don't take it during a busy semester.

This class is hugely overrated. Ikenberry is a pretty bad lecturer and Friedberg is marginally better. You can get the same worth out of this course by reading Sun Tzu, Clausewitz, and Machiavelli on your own time. The preceptors are very nice and intelligent, more so than the professors.

This course is hard. They force a grade distribution, so only a few students can really do well. The material is very interesting but they really expect you to read everything. Take at your own risk. You'll learn a lot, but if it's overwhelming, it's possible you'll regret it.
This course is relatively overrated in my opinion. Also, expect a huge amount of readings.

This course offers an important perspective on national priorities and international relations that I would say every concerned citizen should be aware of before weighing in on foreign policy debates. The readings are a lot, but they won't kill you and you can afford to miss a few here and there. The course staff are awesome.
Very hard. Also very interesting. Maybe PDF or do a lot of work.
prereqs: Some knowledge of U.S. European, and/or Asian history is essential, through there are no prerequisite courses.
descrip: Grand strategy is the broad and encompassing policies and undertakings that political leaders pursue-financial, economic, military, diplomatic-to achieve their objectives in peacetime and in war. This course will examine the theory and practice of grand strategy both to illuminate how relations among city-states, empires, kingdoms and nation states have evolved over the centuries and also to identify some common challenges that have confronted all who seek to make and execute grand strategy from Pericles to Barack Obama.

title: Radical Political Thought
reviews: A good course with interesting material but lots of reading.

A lot of reading and substantial amount of work, but worth it for anyone interested in leftist political philosophies. Prof. Mueller does not inject his own views into the discussions or lectures, so despite the overall leftist tilt of the material, don't be afraid of political bias affecting your grade or making you feel out of place in the class. While a background in political theory isn't necessary, the class is definitely very writing-intensive and Prof. Mueller expects you to be able to take normative stances on the readings; summarizing information is not enough to do well on papers and discussions.
ATTEND ALL LECTURES! They are helpful and fascinating. Try to do as much of the readings as you can!

Do not get behind on readings. It make it really hard to concentrate on the full breadth of the course if you are behind. It happens, but at the same time don't do it. Go to office hours or email because Professor Mueller is a great teacher and is willing to do more for students who are engaged. Also, if you choose the research paper do start early and feel free to as Professor Mueller for his thoughts.
Do the readings for precept. Don't be intimidated by the amount of reading. You get the hang of it and the material is so interesting, that it is worth it.
Do the readings.
Don't take unless you already know about politics and like reading a lot.
Excellent course, with engaging material throughout. Lectures are great.

I think the content of this course is especially interesting, more engaging than most courses at Princeton. But I found Professor Muller somewhat unwilling to help with papers and something of a bad listener in precept. In addition, I thought the organization of the readings should be changed to prioritize depth or quality over quantity. I still recommend this course for the content, but I think it could be vastly improved.
I would definitely take this course if you are interested in the material.

I would highly recommend taking this course. I took it because radical political thinkers are super fascinating to me. Readings are overwhelming but you don't have to do all of them thoroughly to succeed. Papers are challenging but fair. Take this course no matter what familiarity you have with politics or political philosophy!
I would recommend this class to students who are particularly interested in the subject matter and have sufficient time to really engage with the texts we read.
If POL301 and POL303 seem a bit conventional to you at times, take this for some more challenging and contemporary ideas.
Need to do the readings - crucial for precepts.
Take this class! Its subject matter is so important, especially in these times. This is one of the few classes at Princeton that deals with some of these fascinating thinkers.
Take this class. It is more interesting than an intro political theory class and manageable work load.
This class is really reading-heavy and very broad. You don't have to do all of the readings, but I also question how much I got out of the class by skimming. I would pass for a more specific course.

This is a course I would recommend to everyone here, not least because the world really needs radical thought & action to literally survive. Take this. Hopefully it will change people's minds and lives, as it did mine.

This is a very good overview course and the lectures are well worth attending. Do as much of the reading as you can but you will not be able to do anywhere near all of it. If you want to do a final research paper at the end of the course, you should really only do that as a freshman or sophomore unless you are ridiculously on top of your independent work.
descrip: This course will examine traditions of political thought--mostly, but not only, on the Left--which challenge mainstream conceptions of liberal democracy and modern capitalist society. The main focus will be on Marxism, anarchism, feminism, religious radicalism, ecological thought, and critiques of alienation in everyday life. Particular attention is paid to the relationship between political and cultural criticism, and to the philosophical anthropologies underlying different theories as well as the mechanisms for social change they envisage. We also ask if liberal democratic thought can effectively respond to radical challenges.

title: Comparative Physiology
reviews: A lot of information to process for this class, but the labs/dissections are amazing and informative, which help better your understanding of the lecture material.
A lot of material to remember. Cool stuff, but a lot
Don't take this unless its required!

I literally cannot emphasize enough how amazing the labs for this class are. The lab TAs are all incredibly kind and helpful, and just this lab has been one of my favorite Princeton classes. The lab practicals very straightforward (read: easy if you put in effort) are about memorizing parts of anatomy in different animals which is actually really fun and useful to learn. The lectures are less enthralling, but there is a lot of material to be learned! Learn how to stay focused for 80 minutes straight because the lectures are incredibly dense. The midterm was really hard after having no previous written work in the lecture segment of the class so keep up with the material.
Interesting content, lectures were very boring and monotone, however still a cool class to fulfill an EEB departmental.
Labs make the lectures worth your time but lectures are dense and boring.

Labs will be awesome.  Know that lectures will be dull to sit through. But be thankful that she gives us the lecture slides (these are your lifeline for exams), and that you don't have to read/buy the book (it is so horribly dense).  Know that the actual subject material is really cool/interesting and that alone will be enough to keep you awake in lecture.
Loved the labs! Lectures were dry, but you learn a lot. A lot of memorization and the exams require a lot of detailed memorization.
Only take if you have to, its a lot of work.
Take it, but know that Goldberg's lectures are rough. Labs are fantastic!!! Made the entire class worthwhile. This class is a lot of work though for the exams.
The course is very difficult and requires a lot of work, but it's worth it if you put in the required work.
The lab is amazing (have fun with it!); the lecture is quite disengaging (try to get through it). This is a heavily memorization-based course.
The labs are amazing.. the lectures aren't as good. This course requires a lot of memorization.

The labs are the best part of this course! I was worried taking a lab class as a senior, but it was so worth it. I'm not pre-med, but this information was still so interesting for understanding our own bodies better as well as understanding behaviors of animals we see (and learning a lot of fun facts). Go to the open hours before lab practicals. The lectures are not the easiest to pay attention in; Prof. Goldberg is very organized and prepared for every class but not the most engaging, but still go, pay attention, and take notes. It'll help in starting to memorize and study early. Maybe read the textbook because the lectures are based off of it.

The lectures are deadly, but the labs are great and make the course (you get to look at a lot of bones, do some dissections, and take a trip to hang out with elephants and giraffes). Print out the lecture slides ahead of time and take notes on them, if you try to take notes on your computer you'll end up surfing the internet within 5 minutes because the lectures are so monotone. It's really a shame the EEB department hasn't found someone besides Goldberg to teach this class, because the subject could be so interesting and the course has so much potential.
The lectures will put you to sleep.  The lab is very fun.

This class was wonderful! Professor Goldberg's lectures are very informative, although sometimes a little dry, and she cares very strongly about helping her students learn and enjoy the material! 
The labs were the best part, and I thoroughly enjoyed and learned from the dissections, and even the lab practicals. And the field trip at the end was fantastic! Do study and just memorize for the lab practicals, though. Use quizlets to memorize all of the terms on the lists they give you, and definitely make use of the open lab hours.

For the exams, make sure you understand the concepts which are present on the practice questions for each lecture. I found the exams very fair. 

This class was supremely helpful for learning material that is on the MCAT. I highly recommend this before taking the MCAT if you are premed!!
This is a fairly good EEB course. If interested at physiology at all, take it! Be warned that this course does require quite a bit of memorization though.
Unless you're really interested in physiology, anatomy, and dissections, don't take this course. It's hard, there's a ton of material and it's mostly memorization-based.

While lectures can be terribly dull and you will be online shopping most of the time, the labs are amazing and so worth it! The trip at the end to the safari apr to 6 flags would be worth the whole course, but all the labs in between were so interesting and I learned so much about systems and evolutionary processes. Great course for EEB majors and pre-vet students!
if you're interested in physiology or are premed take this class. the lab is awesome
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: This course explores the mechanisms of animal function in the contexts of evolution, ecology and behavior. We will cover the physiological bases of osmoregulation, circulation, gas exchange, digestion, energetics, motility, and neural and hormonal control of these and other processes in a variety of vertebrate and invertebrate animals, thereby revealing general principles of animal physiology as well as specific physiological adaptations to differing environments.

title: The Invention of the Gentile: A Case-Study in Ethnic Distinctions
descrip: The distinction between "gentiles" and "Jews" is significant not only due to the great impact it had on the history of Jewish and Christian communities, but also because it has become a paradigmatic case of the distinction between outsiders and insiders, us and others. This class, based on new research, will probe the origins and construction of this category, beginning with the Bible and proceeding through other classical Jewish and Christian texts.

title: Studies in Ancient Judaism - The Palestinian Talmud
descrip: This course examines the literary and intellectual character of the first Talmud, the Yerushalmi, and the scholarly culture that produced it. It centers on certain general characteristics that make this work distinct from the rabbinic literature that preceded it, on close readings of selected passages, and on possible connections between the developments evident in the Yerushalmi and in other contemporaneous scholarly works of the Greco-Roman world.

title: Theory of Games
reviews: A rigorous course on game theory. Proof-based problems can be hard at times. Overall the course is very enjoyable!
Don't be intimidated by the fact that this class is MAT; it's very doable. Fick is an awesome lecturer, and the HW's are very reasonable.
Fairly easy--if you are not a math major make sure you are comfortable with proofs

I'm the kind of person who wanted to see proofs for everything... until I took this class. Even for the hardest-core math majors, I would highly recommend taking an applications-based econ alternative. The "theory" was just overwhelming amounts of notation and annoying linear algebra / arithmetic. The book was also terrible--I hope they change texts in the future. Although the course is very easy, I would highly recommend against taking it. 

If there is any bright side to the course, the Professor was good. However, I would recommend taking a different course instead with him.
It's easier than a normal math class but it's not a blow off A.
Really great math course. Prof. Fickenscher was a great prof who really seemed to care.
The lectures are theoretical and the homeworks are numerical. You can make as much of the course as you want to.
Tougher than it look but if you are interested in game theory at all, you should take it.
Very good.
prereqs: MAT 202, 204, 217 or equivalent. MAT 215 or equivalent is recommended..
descrip: Games in extensive form, pure and behavioral strategies; normal form, mixed strategies, equilibrium points; coalitions, characteristic-function form, imputations, solution concepts; related topics and applications.

title: Fragmented Past, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Condensed Matter Physics II
reviews: Be careful.

If you have a strong background in condensed matter and are interested in learning about topological phases in CM, I would recommend taking this course and constantly asking questions during the class
It will be better if you can spend more time and supplement the stuffs you learned from class with other relevant papers or textbooks.
Very difficult course material, requires some background on topological physics going in.  Professor Bernevig is a good and engaging lecture however and the work load is fairly light
You need to have a solid background of Ashcroft Mermin CMP.
good
descrip: Course introduces and present ongoing theoretical investigations of new research topics in condensed matter physics: topological insulators and Chern numbers, topological superconductors, the fractional quantum Hall effect and non-abelian statistics, as well as new high-temperature superconductors. The techniques needed to deal with such systems, such as Chern numbers, topological band theory, Berry phases, conformal field theory, Chern-Simons theory, t-J models, Gutzwiller wavefunctions, Hubbard models, are explained.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Discusses the main tools of econometric analysis, and the way in which they are applied to a range of problems in social science. Emphasis is on using techniques, and on understanding and critically assessing others' use of them. There is a great deal of practical work on the computer using a range of data from around the world. Topics include regression analysis, with a focus on regression as a tool for analyzing non-experimental data, discrete choice, and an introduction to time-series analysis. There are applications from macroeconomics, policy evaluation, and economic development. Prerequisite: grounding in topics covered in 507c.

title: South Asian Popular Culture
reviews: Be prepared to read a lot. Overall an easy class if you are able to keep up with the work. Prof. Phillips is incredibly patient and knowledgable.
Definitely be prepared for a lot of reading and not that much engagement with primary sources.
descrip: The course will provide an introduction to several South Asian popular culture forms and their study. Popular culture forms and practices to be discussed will include comics, film, music, visual culture (posters, calendar art, photography, etc.), clothing, and sport, with attention given to their historical and contemporary contexts.

title: Independent Study II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.

title: Second Language Acquisition Research and Language Teaching Methodology
descrip: Designed to provide future teaching assistants with the knowledge and conceptual tools needed to reflect critically on pedagogical practices in the second language classroom. Examines issues related to teaching language and culture in a university setting, highlighting the relationship between theory in Second Language Acquisition and language pedagogy and helping students understand the practical implications of theoretical frameworks in the field.

title: Accelerated Honors Analysis II
reviews: A nice continuation of MAT 216. The class gives some nice background in the topics covered.
Challenging but interesting.
Fantastic freshman course. Gunning introduces mathematical ideas from so many different realms; great beginning to the math major.
Fun and interesting!
Great, fantastic, excellent class. Gunning is an awesome lecturer, nice problem sets, no complaints.

Gunning is a really great guy, and this course could be really helpful for future math majors, but the number of typos and computational problem sets made this class not my favorite. If you take it, take it for Gunning.

I highly recommend this course if you are interested in theoretical math. Although the course's focus is on analysis, it teaches much more than analysis and helps you gain an appreciation for math in general.

I think that anyone who plans to be a math major should take the series 216-218 because it covers both algebra and real analysis very well and helps the student construct a solid basis in each of them.
MAT216-218 is a great course to begin your mathematical adventure! Prepare to have genius classmates though :D
Problem sets and the course in general are more computational than 216. Work on psets or at least check answers with a classmate.
Start the problem sets early. Tutoring sessions are only useful if you have a specific question.
Take this course only as a continuation of MAT216. It is not as difficult as the first semester, but still takes significant effort. Completing the sequence is very rewarding, though.

This course, while not bad, is far worse than MAT 216. The course loses a lot of rigor, the book gets worse, the problem sets are much more computational, and the subject material (in my opinion) is less interesting. The only reason why this comment could be relevant to you is if you were in 216 and are choosing whether to drop to 217. I guess I would recommend staying in 218, because from what I hear there is a lot more busy work in 217. But it's not a clear choice.
it's like mat216 but deals with some more abstract stuff (and integration). so yeah.
prereqs: MAT 216.
descrip: Continuation of the rigorous introduction to analysis in MAT216

title: Comparative Constitutional Law
reviews: Although Professor Scheppele presents interesting arguments in this class, I would recommend going to her public lectures rather than taking a graded course with her. Engaging participation is minimal, the exams are confusing and extensive outside knowledge of global constitutionalism is needed to meet her expectations.

Do not hesitate to take a class with Prof. Scheppele. You will be challenged and learn more than you thought one course could offer. Prof. Scheppele is the most engaged professor I have ever had, and you'll be lucky to spend a semester with her.

Prof. Scheppele is extremely knowledgeable and friendly, and she truly cares about her students. She certainly has her (very liberal) opinions, but she's exceptionally fair to everyone. If you disagree with her views, as I do, you should definitely take this class because she'll challenge you and teach you quite a lot. Overall, it's a great and interesting class that offers insight into a fairly specialized field that you've probably never been exposed to before. It mostly focuses on European and Commonwealth law. There's a little bit of Latin American law, but don't expect anything on Asia or Africa. Because readings are pretty technical be sure that you're genuinely interested in the material. Familiarity with American constitutional law is helpful. My only real complaint is that lectures can get kind of dry. This is not a discussion-based class.
TAKE IT! The reading is above average but all necessary. The course covers a broad range of topics in the subject, so there is something for everyone. Best course I've take at Princeton!
Take this course if you are interested in learning more about the constitutions of various countries but not if you want to engage and talk in precept.
Take this course if you are interested in the subject matter, but be prepared to do the work.

Take this course! If you have any interest in international law and how other countries approach human rights issues within their constitutional frameworks, you will enjoy this class. Professor Scheppele is an engaging professor and the class gives a comprehensive overview of constitutional systems and different rights. Each lecture is fascinating.

This class goes over a lot of material, leading to a very broad but meaningful introduction to the field of comparative constitutional law. Prof. Scheppele is accomplished, intelligent, and also incredibly down to earth - I cannot recommend this course or another taught by her highly enough. If you have an interest in law, you'll appreciate this course!

This is a fairly technical course that might take a bit of getting used to for non-majors, but if you have the chance to take a course with Professor Scheppele, you should absolutely take it. She goes above and beyond for her students and is brilliant. Definitely not my highest grade in a Princeton course, but well worth the time and effort.
descrip: This course will introduce students to the variety of forms of constitutional government and the way that human rights are understood and enforced by courts around the world. We will trace the emergence of a global constitutional culture and explore the constitutions of South Africa, India, Germany, France, Hungary, Israel, Colombia and Canada. We will give primary emphasis to the rights provisions in national constitutions but will also consider transnational regimes through examining decisions of the European Court of Human Rights and the Inter-American Court of Human Rights.

title: Advanced Japanese II
