descrip: The course is designed to further students' proficiency in the four language skills aiming for ACTFL-ETS advanced level. Learning materials include the Japanese anime "Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi (Spirited Away)" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: Topics in International Relations - The US and Iran
descrip: This course examines the complex relationship between the United States and the Islamic Republic of Iran. For 36 years the two countries' interaction has consisted mostly of trading insults, threats, and accusations. In the last two years there has been a partial thaw, but deep differences remain. We examine how the relationship between the U.S. and Iran affects domestic politics in both capitals and consider alternatives to the current enmity, prospects for change, and policy choices for both sides.

title: Experimental Methods I
descrip: A laboratory course that focuses on basic electronics techniques, digital electronics, and data acquisition and analysis. Topics include introduction to digital and analog electronics, digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital conversion, microcomputer sampling, and data analysis. There are approximately four laboratory hours and two lecture hours per week. There is one project.

title: The Nature of Theatrical Reinvention
reviews: A great course for anyone interested in theatre professionally - John Doyle is an absolute role model and hearing about his life/methods is irreplaceable.

Definitely take a class with John if you are even remotely interested in pursuing theater after Princeton. And if you're not, he's just a wonderfully kind professor who will earnestly hear you out. Take it either way!
I have gained a new appreciation for theater and I feel like an actor reborn. John Doyle is candid, wise, open, and cares about the true purpose of theater, which is storytelling.

Professor Doyle has a lot of wisdom to share and it was great being in such a small class with him. The class seemed unstructured at times, but assignments were really fun and creative and you got to work a lot with your own ideas for theatrical reinvention.
Take it! Doyle is awesome and it's very low-committment.
Take it.
Would highly highly recommend. Truly amazing course, Professor Doyle is amazing, very light work-load that is nonetheless exciting. Absolutely take it.
prereqs: No restrictions or prerequisites..
descrip: This seminar explores how iconic pieces of theatre can be re-explored for modern audiences. The course will examine various aspects of how an artist can think out-of-the-box and the mechanisms the artist can use to do so. There will be discussions, theatre visits, possible access to theatre practitioners and assignments which will encourage the participant to explore their own imaginative approach to storytelling. The course is designed for performers, directors, designers but would also be of interest to dancers, writers and those interested in how theatre can be challenging and relevant.

title: Gender and Sexuality in Modern America
reviews: A great history class if you want a look at some lesser told stories in American history and to challenge your understanding of social constructs related to gender and sexuality.
Absolutely take this course, and if you can, get Kevin Kruse's precept. Powerful and enlightening lectures and fantastic readings - which you should try to do as much as you can.

Canaday is amazing. The readings are a lot, but amazing. Even if you know a lot of the stuff, it's wonderful to get all these narratives stitched together into one. I don't like large lectures and I liked this one.
Definitely take this class!! Get Professor Kruse as your preceptor.

Definitely take this course, or any other course with Margot! If you have any interest in feminism or movements related to sexuality this is the course for you. Also, the readings are all extremely interesting.

Do as many readings as you can, and try your best not to skip lecture. If u do miss class, get someone's notes. However the most important thing to do in this class is to read. If you do that, you'll be in great shape for the final
I would take this course if you do not know much about the subject and are interested in pursuing a degree in history/politics.
If you're at all interested in feminism/ queer rights (or even if you're not), take this course-- one of the best decisions I've made here.

It is a wonderful course, I would hope for all students and not just HIS/GSS concentrating students (as a student of both disciplines, I am biased)... A very well-structured course that allows one to understand the relation of state to US society through the lens of gender and sexuality, thereby having a better sense of the way institutions have been structured (and continue)  to benefit white heterosexual men.
It's a great history course on really interesting material! Definitely take it- and try to be in Prof. Canaday's precept if possible!

Professor Canaday is an extremely engaging lecturer, who knows exactly what she's doing. Go to lecture, read what you can, and you'll get a lot out of this course. I'm not a humanities major and this course made me want to write essays for it.
Show up prepared for lecture.  You'll get a lot more out of the class.

Super interesting content but lots of reading and precepts aren't those chill kind that you just go to and sit around in, you have to be ready to contribute since participation is a quarter of your final grade. TONS of reading, but you only have to do it for the weekly precepts, not as much for the final. PACE yourself for the final report, i have a week to do the entire thing and highly regret that. take it if you love the topic, and don't otherwise.
Super super interesting HA. Canaday is an amazing lecturer. The class was a lot of work and a ton of reading. But if you take the reading seriously you will get so much out of it.
TAKE IT!! It will totally change your perspective on the world around you. The lectures and precepts are great and the material is SO interesting.
TAKE THIS CLASS

TAKE THIS CLASS! Dr. Canaday is an amazing lecturer. Overall, this class is not too work heavy although the readings can be dense at times. All the material is super interesting and relevant though. You will not see the world in the same way after you take this class.
TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Canaday is a boss and you will learn so so much about a history that isn't examined nearly as closely as it should be by most people.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! It is the best class I've ever taken. You will learn so much. I looked forward to going to lecture every time. Professor Canaday is so smart, interesting, passionate, and kind. This course made me certain that I want to be a history major.
Take it because it's extremely educational about an important topic in American society
Take it if you are interested in the subject -- otherwise not.
Take it! I learned a ton about topics I thought I already pretty much understood, and Professor Canaday is seriously one of the best lecturers at Princeton.
Take it! It's a great lens through which to learn about gender and sexuality.
Take it! Some of the best lectures I have ever had at Princeton. Definitely not the lightest reading/workload but completely worth it.
Take it! You will learn so much about sexism in history and government policy. Makes you a more informed citizen.
Take it.

Take the course! Great professor, great preceptors, great readings. A lot of work, make this your only history class if you're not a history major. A lot of readings, but it's interesting enough to hold you through.
Take this class!
Take this course but pick a final topic paper that you generally have interest in doing, other wise it can be tough to finish
Take this course if you are interested in understanding and knowing more about gender and sexuality in the US. The material is not hard to understand.
Take this course! Professor Canaday is an amazing lecturer and is clearly passionate about what she is teaching.
Take this course! Take it take it take it!
Take this course!!! It has really been my favorite course at Princeton. Some advice is to always go to lecture and take great notes.
The reading is a lot but the material is interesting. You have to dedicate the time to do the readings, as it will help you on the final exam and for the final paper.
This class is absolutely amazing. It teaches you topics that everyone should know, and frames history in a new light, without being too difficult. I would recommend this to anyone!

This class was one my favorite courses that I've ever taken. The topics are highly interesting, and though the readings are dense and long at times, they're engaging and very insightful. Professor Canaday is very kind and engaged, and her lectures are both fascinating and moving. The class feels less like class and more like a community.
This course is a must take. You will learn a lot, and Canaday is an excellent professor. Will Schultz is an incredible preceptor, and I cannot say anything negative about this course.
This course should be mandatory for all students! It's so important and so interesting - definitely take it!
if you want to learn about gender and sexuality in america, take it!
take it if you enjoy this history--otherwise not
take this class!!!
descrip: This course examines the history of gender and sexuality across the 20th century, with emphasis on both regulation and resistance. Topics include early homosexual subcultures; the commercialization of sex; reproduction and its limitation; sex, gender, and war; cold war sexual containment; the feminist movement; conservative backlash; AIDS politics; same-sex marriage; Hillary; and many others.

title: How to Make a Film
reviews: Beware, 6 hours is alot1

I would not take this course unless you are willing to commit the times and energy. It is not an easy-A. The trek up to the Lewis center for 6 hours once a week is not an easy one. Only take this course if you have an interest in filmmaking and are willing to commit the energy, because otherwise it will be a waste of time, and will not improve your gpa.
If you enjoy film making, take it.  Keith is an enjoyable man to get to know and he'll support your creative endeavors.
It is a really big time commitment so be prepared to put a lot of work into it.
It's a great class if you're interested in film, but definitely make sure you're willing (and able) to devote the many hours needed to assignments.

Really good 5th course. The video assignments are all very short and don't have to take long at all, unless you are really trying to go all out. The 3 hours classes are basically lectures, not seminar, and they can be unbearably boring. But the upside to that is that Keith doesn't care if you are on your computer or on your phone, so you can get lots of other work done while he's talking. Keith is a pleasantly sarcastic little man. I thought he was hilarious and liked him a lot. But if dry humor and sassiness isn't your thing, then you may not like him. Don't let his quirky attitude turn you off the first week. He's actually pretty cool.
Start planning early!
Take it if you have an appreciation for the painstaking art of filmmaking. Make sure you have friends who are willing to participate in your projects!

This course will allow you to familiarize yourself with the cameras used by the VIS department and with Adobe Premiere, but does not give you much creative leeway during the semester. The final project is the most important part of the class, but there is not enough time given for this project.
W/o prior experience this will be a time suck. 6 hours of class in one day. Too much. Not a good 5th class oops.
prereqs: This course is now open enrollment.
descrip: A film can be fictional or documentary, but there are also many other ways to tell a story. Through hands-on studio work, screenings, critical readings and group critiques, this course teaches the basic tools and approaches for film production with digital media including writing, camerawork, sound, editing, and postproduction. Technical instruction paired with conceptual frameworks will give you the means to find your visual storytelling voice and your filmmaker's point of view.

title: Wind Turbine Aerodynamics and Technology
prereqs: The potential students must have some basic programming skills. A basic course in structural dynamics or in fluid mechanics is not absolutely required but is recommended..
descrip: The course addresses basic wind turbine technology such as aerodynamics, control and structural aspects. Theory will be provided that can be used to predict the aerodynamic loads on the wind turbine blades and their impact on the structure with respect to internal loads and deflections. The influence of the stochastic loads from atmospheric turbulence will be addressed and the structural dynamics of a wind turbine and possible instabilities will also be covered. Small computer programs will be written based on the lectured theory and verified in some papers.

title: Topics in Modern South Asia - Subaltern Studies
descrip: This course explores special topics in modern South Asian history. The precise topic varies from year to year.

title: Topics in Economic and Organizational Sociology (Half-Term) - Seminar on Alternatives to Capitalism
prereqs: Open to graduate students; all others with permission of the instructor..
descrip: This seminar uses the perspective of economic sociology to address alternatives to capitalism and the institutions of post-industrial capitalism by examining the varieties of alternatives, the reasons to consider alternatives, and specific proposals. The seminar will explore institutions and policies to broaden ownership of capital and access to capital income (such as profit sharing), the role of rapid technological change in envisioning alternatives to capitalism, and the potential for sociology of finance research that explores whether the institutions of capitalism are amenable to a change that will improve the social good.

title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop
prereqs: REL 525.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion. Note: REL 525 (fall) and REL 526 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Advanced Korean II
prereqs: KOR 301 or placement test..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 301. Continued development of proficiency in speaking and reading through class discussion and short readings. Vocabulary learning and discourse skills are emphasized.

title: Special Topics in Information Sciences and Systems - Lossless Data Compression
reviews: Good class to take if you're familiar with some information theory. It's not too hard and Verdu is too lazy to assign written work that he'd have to grade later.

If you are reading this review and wondering whether to enroll, I will make this very simple: you should take this course.

This class is fantastic. It presents both deep, abstract mathematical concepts and powerful, practical tools and highlights how they are connected in a unique way.

This class covers data compression algorithms in depth, and along the way incorporate ideas from information theory, computer science, mathematics and statistics. If you do work in any of these areas (as well as any others), you should set aside time for this class.

The workload and time requirement is quite manageable. Some information theory is helpful, but the introduction is fairly self-contained. Some probability theory is definitely useful, but even without it I think this would be doable.
Take it!
prereqs: Familiarity with probability..
descrip: Algorithms for data compression: Hoffman, Shannon, Arithmetic coding, Lempel-Ziv, Burrows-Wheeler Transform. Analysis of the fundamental limits of lossless data compression algorithms.

title: Topics in Literary and Cultural Theory - Media Theory since 2000
descrip: This seminar offers a critical survey of recent trends in the field of media theory, focusing in particular on how these developments engage with questions of aesthetic form. Following several 'schools' that have assembled under rubrics such as cultural techniques, media archaeology, and media ecology, the course also considers how these methods interface with other discursive frameworks that have emerged in the humanities in the last 15 years, including new materialisms, network theory, and affect theory.

title: Trade Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Human Rights
reviews: A great class with one of the best lecturers in the politics department. Highly recommend taking a Bass class, and this course covers a lot of interesting IR issues and current events.
A lot of reading and was difficult for me to jump in without any pre-knowledge about the topics. Having said that it is a brilliant course and Professor Bass is such a talented lecturer!
Absolutely one of the best classes you will take at Princeton. Professor Bass in fantastic

Absolutely take this class. Professor Bass' lectures are excellent, an understanding of this topic is very important for current public policy and international relations, and Bass is simply one of the most impressive, yet nice, funny and entertaining professors at Princeton.
Absolutely take this course; it's a bit of work, but worth it.

Although the subject is Human Rights, it still is within the Politics Department. So don't expect too much information from Gary Bass or from precept that falls outside the neo-liberal narrative the State Department would give.

As long as you can handle the massive amounts of readings, take this course. Bass is a fantastic lecturer and the content of the class is fascinating, disturbing, and essential for any human. Undoubtedly, before you graduate, this course is a Princeton must.
Bass is a great lecturer and sums up the readings well. You can easily get a B by doing very few readings and just taking notes in lecture.

Bass is a great lecturer. If you're interested in POL at all, take this class. It's great not only to learn about international politics, but also about how we as humans react to rights abuses, especially when we don't see them up close.

The workload can be as much or as little as you want; readings aren't super necessary, except for maybe the readings on political theory. If you really want to learn though, I would do the readings and participate in precept, because it really does give you an in-depth insight into what Bass lectures about.

There is a 10 - 15 page research paper that is fairly heavy in terms of work-load, and due at a really random, stressful time in the semester.

But overall? This course was worth it. Take it.

Definitely recommend - Professor Bass is great and so are his preceptors. Globally-oriented discussions on matters such as human rights are also important issues for us to grapple with as scholars and global citizens.
Definitely take it, it'll open your mind
Definitely take this course. Be prepared to give yourself time to read the readings.

Do the readings! Also, be sure that you pay attention to current global affairs and world leaders. Overall, Professor Bass is a great lecturer and honestly, this course can give you such a different perspective on international affairs. It will either make you cynical as hell or an inspired idealist.

For the love of God and all that is holy take this course. You'll learn SO MUCH about historical human rights issues, theory, and current events. It taught me to be a more aware consumer of media and politics and basically made me a Politics major its just incredible talent. Even if you're intimidated just do it. Also start the research paper early and make friends with your preceptor.
Gary Bass is an incredibly engaging lecturer with amazing career stories. Fascinating (yet harrowing) material. A lot of reading.
Good lecture, readings are amazing. Sharan is an awesome preceptor. It is more of a history class though than a politics class.
Hard, but worth it. Amazing lecturer, mostly good readings (too many), and mostly good preceptors.
I great way to fulfill an SA and gives you context for your Princeton experience in terms of global duty

I had no experience with Politics or the Politics dept before taking this class. If you're on the fence for a similar reason, I recommend this class. The lectures are extremely helpful in sifting through the readings, and the only main assignment in the course in a research paper, which you can receive help on if you start early.
I really enjoyed this class. Be prepared to put in a lot of work for the final and the research paper. If you are interested in international politics I would recommend this class.
I was in Prof. Bass's precept section. Although we had lively, substantial discussions, I would have benefited from the perspective of a different preceptor.

I would recommend taking this class, especially if you are in the POL department. I took it as an underclassmen, and I feel like I could have gotten more out of it if I had waited to take it. With that being said, I really enjoyed the class and I felt like I learned a lot.
I would recommend this course, as it explores an important topic well.
If you decide not to take this course, you should rethink every decision you've ever made in your life because it is the single best course I've taken at Princeton.
If you're into politics and don't mind a lot of reading, take it.

Incredible course. Professor Bass is a phenomenal lecturer, the best I have had at Princeton, and the material will floor you. Not a lightweight class - which is what I expected when I signed up. Morally demanding, philosophically complex, historically wide-ranging. Extremely impressed not just with lectures but with the readings. I now also look at the modern political landscape much differently. A must for all interested in being a contributing member of the human community.
JUST TAKE IT. It's definitely the best course I have taken here yet!
Keep up with the readings! Come prepared to precept. Start your paper early. Go to office hours.

Lectures are phenomenal, but the readings are too long and the exams are so dense that I could not finish them in the allotted time. It's a great class to PDF for the lectures, but if you're taking the course for a grade be prepared to do way more reading and writing than you'll want.
Make sure to stay on top of the reading - I would recommend creating a schedule for yourself every week to make it more manageable.
Must take it. Best course I have taken. Bass is an excellent lecturer. Try and get Tolya as a preceptor.

One of my favorite classes at Princeton. Don't believe the negative comments about Professor Bass in earlier course evaluations. He was highly accessible, always willing to answer questions after class or in office hours, and just a great, humble, funny guy. His lectures are some of the best I've had for a class. The material is fascinating.

Pick precepts wisely! This course has a lot of (admittedly boring, dense, and sometimes nepotistic) reading -- if your preceptor wants to keep you very accountable, then this course is a lot of work. Otherwise, prof. Bass is an amazing orator and brings to the table a very intriguing and important worldview.
Professor Bass is an unreal lecturer. Take the course its really interesting and the lectures keep you engaged.

Professor Bass' lectures are interesting and a lot of fun. The reading is hard but worth it and you dont need to do all of it if you go to all of his lectures. it is a hard class but they grade pretty easily on the paper and it is really worth taking!
Reading notes!! Do not undervalue keeping up with current events, either.
Really great lecture. Find a good precept. It's a hard class that takes a lot of work but if you are truly interested in the topic, well worth it.
Split up the readings with other people in the class.

TAKE IT! Professor Bass is incredible and you learn a lot about important policy and theory issues regarading human rights. He's also very fair in terms of presenting a mostly balanced view of the subject and has amazing personal stories to share from his time as a journalist/award-winning author that really makes his already spectacular lectures (which are both funny and information-packed) come alive.
TAKE IT. It's hard, though
TAKE THIS CLASS. It is THE best class. Professor Bass is one of those once-in-a-lifetime professors; do not miss this.
TAKE THIS COURSE even if you aren't a politics major! really makes you see the US and the rest of the world differently.
TAKE THIS COURSE. Absolutely fascinating and incredibly powerful. Imperative for anyone who cares about human rights

THIS COURSE IS AMAZING. I loved every moment of it. Take this course, but be prepared to do a substantial amount of work. There is A TON of reading, but it's very interesting and you could get away without doing all of it.

Take it!  I'm not a politics major so this was just for general interest but it really helped me think about how to evaluate proposed political solutions to human rights violations.  I also learned a lot of recent history.  Lots of readings but if you form a reading group that shares notes it's possible to do quite well.  The paper is also not due during midterms week so that's nice.
Take it! Prof. Bass is one of the best professors I've hard at Princeton. You'll see the world differently after this. You'll actually have to put in some work to get the most out of it.

Take it! Professor Bass will enlighten you in so many ways. Having taken this course after POL 240, which seemed to skew toward the realist school of IR theory, this course revived my hope in the liberal school. Attend all the lectures; they're the reason you take this course. Professor Bass is an incredibly knowledgeable and passionate speaker. You won't be disappointed.
Take it!! Will change your perspective on the way that we are taught world history in schools. definitely take if interested in any social science disciple and human rights.
Take it.  Do all of the readings you can manage.
Take it. It's super interesting. It is a fair amount of work though, so be prepared. Wasn't a super easy PDF (obviously doable, but not the easiest)
Take it. You won't be able to do all of the reading. Take it anyway. Important material by people who care and know what they're talking about.
Take the class! Try to get the lead preceptor or Professor Bass as your preceptor.
Take this class because it's eyeopening. Beware of the heavy readings!
Take this class if you're remotely interested in the subject. Professor Bass is fascinating and very funny. Relevant topic from a great professor, what else are you looking for?
Take this class!  Manageable workload for non-majors and extremely interesting material.
Take this class! Gary Bass is incredible.
Take this class! Keep up with the readings, you will get the most out of the course that way.

Take this class!!! Unless you are a freshman without any experience with politics classes, in which I would recommend waiting until you are a little older and wiser. And beware: the amount of reading is difficult to handle.
Take this class. Honestly one of my favorites at Princeton. You will learn so much and work hard but it is beyond worth it.
Take this course for the great lectures with Professor Bass. Do not expect much from your precept. Good class to PDF.

Take this course if you're remotely interested in human rights, global affairs, or recent world history. Be prepared for a lot of reading -- probably 200-250 every week. Bass is an extremely engaging lecturer, but I suggest choosing a precept with another preceptor who may be more supportive and helpful. I felt as though Bass could become condescending at times in his precept.
Take this course! Although it's not an easy course, it's taught very well and shapes your thinking.

Take this course! It's a really interesting survey of human rights and various genocides throughout history, and I learned a lot by taking it. The professor is also really engaging. Just be wary of the research paper and make sure to start it early.
Take this course, if only to see Professor Bass as a lecturer.
Take this course. It's a lot of work, but very worthwhile.
There are a lot of readings, dont do them all in too much detail. Just know what they're about and Professor Bass will go over them again in lectures. It's definitely a good course
This class was pretty fun, worth taking. A good amount of work, but manageable.
This course changes your perspective on a lot of things-- every Princeton student should take this before graduation. It is challenging but worth every minute.

This course is SO worth taking, there are events in our atrocities recent history that I did not know about and shocking that I knew nothing about. Bass is an amazing lecturer, really hilarious, and the readings (with the exception of some of the theoretical ones) are all super interesting. POL380 was probably one of my favourite courses this year.

This course is so worthwhile. You learn so much about politics, history, philosophy, economics and current events, and Prof. Bass makes it all so fascinating. Take the class and learn so much about humanity, where we've been and where we're at.

This will be one of the best courses you take at Princeton. Professor Bass is an amazing lecturer and professor, the readings are interesting, and the one term paper is actually extremely fun to write.
could not more highly recommend
take it take it take it! this class will teach you so much
take it!
descrip: A study of the politics and history of human rights. What are human rights? How can dictatorships be resisted from the inside and the outside? Can we prevent genocide? Is it morally acceptable and politically wise to launch humanitarian military interventions to prevent the slaughter of foreign civilians? What are the laws of war, and how can we punish the war criminals who violate them? Cases include the Ottoman Empire, Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Bosnia, and Rwanda.

title: Mechanical Design
reviews: Great class, success often depends on your group.
Great course, though you have to take it or trains, I would suggest this course if you're more interested in the mechanical side of engineering as I am.

I personally think machine shop work is really fun, and this is a great opportunity for more practical, hands-on work that most other classes lack. Try to plan well ahead for your project and reports.
I would definitly recommend this course to anyone who likes building things, but know that by the end of the semester when the project is due it is very stressful and a lot of work.
Really interesting lab work. Lecture can be dry but the design is awesome.
Take if you have a reasonable amount of time that semester and actually like Design.
This class can take a lot of work, but is totally worth it when you look back at the robot you built.

This course was good for undertaking your own design project; you have a lot of freedom to shape the experience with your team. As with any design course it is best to start early and be prepared to work hard.

Yeah, you COULD take Trains over this if you wanted to. Littman is cool, I'll give you that. But in this class, you make robots. Do you make robots in Trains? You do fucking not. MAE is the king of thing that move, and robots are the pinnacle of that. You didn't become MAE to play with electricity. You're MAE so you can create new mechanical life and then tell it what to do. Choose robots. Take 322.
take it if you need a good design course.
prereqs: MAE 321 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course builds on the technical foundations established in MAE 321, and extends the scope to include a range of advanced mechanism design. Students, working in teams, will be challenged to design and fabricate a robotic system that will draw upon multidisciplinary engineering elements. The robot will be used to facilitate common daily tasks. The selected tasks vary each year. CAD, CAE, and CAM will be utilized in the design/simulation/prototype process. Labs are designed to reinforce and expand CAD and CAE skills. A final public competition will be held among the design teams. Judges from relevant industries will be present.

title: Books and Their Readers
reviews: An interesting course on a unique subject with a wonderful professor. Worth taking, but a lot of reading.

Dr. Grafton is one of Princeton's crown jewels. If you have the opportunity to take this course (which is on a topic very near and dear to his heart) and do not take advantage of it, you will have done yourself a great disservice. All components of the class work well. The readings are strong (albeit sometimes heavy), the discussion is typically rather enjoyable, and the assignments encourage research, reflection, and creativity. I would recommend this course without reservation.
Grafton is a legend, but be prepared to bring your A game to seminar discussions. If you like reading, you'll like this course. If you dread reading, then perhaps not for you.

If you are of literary stock, this will be great, but don't expect too much history. Readings are lengthy, and class discussions are sufficiently broad that the readings can be perused rather than digested. Grafton is mostly a moderator, and you'll mostly be hearing from fellow students (many of whom are excited about the material).
Take it, if you can!

Take the class if it's offered again. Enjoy the opportunity to simply discuss ideas in a community of other enthusiastic thinkers. 
Also go to office hours.
Take this class and any other class you can with professor Grafton.
This course was interesting if reading patterns in different contexts is a topic of interest. It is heavily composed of student discussion and interaction in seminar and includes a lot of reading.
This is a very reading heavy course. Only take it if you are very interested in book history. Professor Grafton is very good, but it is hard material to get into.

This is an AMAZING class, among the best I've ever taken. There's a lot of reading and you're going to want to do it well so make sure to give yourself enough time. It's a class (and professor) that attracts a lot of really bright people, so seminars are sure to be great. It the topic isn't perfect enough, take it for the professor ? Grafton is one of the best professors I've ever had and you're doing yourself a disservice if you haven't taken at least one class with him during your time at Princeton.
descrip: This course will offer an intensive introduction to the history of the making, distribution and reading of books in the West, from ancient Greece to modern America. By examining a series of case studies, we will see how writers, producers, and readers of books have interacted, and how the conditions of production and consumption have changed over time.

title: Computational Complexity
reviews: Computational complexity is a very interesting subject: it feels like "mapping" and finding connections in all the phenomena you find in computation. Also Sanjeev is a great lecturer.
Definitely take it.
Great class but quite hard. Make sure you have enough time for the problem sets and prepare well for the final.
This was a great course! Professor Arora presents the very complicated material in a clear and interesting manner. Problem sets are very hard, but the problems were really cool. Would recommend.
prereqs: COS 423.
descrip: Introduction to research in computational complexity theory. Computational models: nondeterministic, alternating, and probabilistic machines. Boolean circuits. Complexity classes associated with these models: NP, Polynomial hierarchy, BPP, P/poly, etc. Complete problems. Interactive proof systems and probabilistically checkable proofs: IP=PSPACE and NP=PCP (log n, l). Definitions of randomness. Pseudorandomness and derandomizations. Lower bounds for concrete models such as algebraic decision trees, bounded-depth circuits, and monotone circuits.

title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part II
reviews: Terrible class, at least he never shows up.
prereqs: Open to freshmen with prior approval. ARC 514 or equivalent is a pre-requisite..
descrip: Design and analysis of a 100,000sf net-zero energy building using techniques and information from ARC 514 or similar. Selection, design and evaluation of mechanical and electrical systems including air conditioning, ventilation, lighting and renewable energy systems with an emphasis on design integration with architecture and structure. Selection of building envelope components and materials for optimum thermal performance. Sustainable design and energy conservation are stressed throughout.

title: Plato and His Predecessors
reviews: Absolutely take it if you have even passing interest in Plato
Best teacher of philosophy at Princeton. Every lecture and precept is phenomenal. Not a PHI major, but loved this course.
Cannot recommend more. This is one of the best classes in Princeton. It also taught me how to live in a way that I have never thought about before.
Go to lecture and listen.
Good course. Lectures were entertaining and thought-provoking. Make sure you get really precise in your written work.
Highly recommend anything with Professor Morison, he's a phenomenal lecturer!! Take a class with Morison (Aristotle or Plato). Take it Take it.
It is a good PDF.
Morison is a treat- witty and engaging, and truly invested in students understanding Plato
Morison is an amazing lecturer and Plato really becomes modern and applicable in his hands. If you think philosophy doesn't apply to everyday life, this course will make you reconsider.
Must take for philosophy majors and anyone interested in the classics.  Take this early in your philosophy curriculum if you have to.

My first written assignment in this class was the worst grade I have received yet at Princeton. The instructors have a very specific approach in mind for the papers which mostly entails regurgitating the lecture and the important nuances of Plato's arguments. Don't deviate from that. Great class to PDF and chill in.
Please take this course even if you don't want to study Philosophy. It will enhance your critical thinking. The workload isn't outrageous, but you will still learn a lot.
Take it if you are interested in classical philosophy.
Take it!
Take it, but do the readings always. You will owe that much to such a wonderful and carefully constructed course.
Take it. It's awesome
Take the course if you are interested in Plato or need the distribution requirement.

Take this class if you like philosophy! Professor Morison is one of the best profs at princeton. I hated Plato at the beginning of the semester, but this class changed my mind completely. Get into Prof. Morison's precept. Admittedly, it is a very hard class, but worth it. There isn't much work, but the material itself is difficult to understand sometimes.

The professor is the best I've had at Princeton- his lectures are very informative and entertaining. Grading was much tougher than the grading in Ancient Philosophy, so you have to put a lot of thought into the assignments
This course is very interesting. It was not a ton of work, but more than I expected. It's only 4 assignments and take home midterm and take home final, so low stress. Def would recommend

This is a class that everyone should take. You will learn to think about the nature of things and what it really is that constitutes existence. Morison does an excellent job of breaking down Plato's sometimes complicated arguments to make them accessible to everyone. Moreover, he will teach you how to read Plato for yourself and you will come away from the class with a book containing many texts in which you can lose yourself the following summer.

This is a very interesting course with a bunch of very important points and arguments about life, and it is a very focused, well-selected intro to Plato's thought and coolest arguments. Make sure you are extremely precise when doing the assignments though.
Well-taught; lectures are engaging and Morison really drills in the importance of being precise in philosophical writing. However, grading can be harsh, esp. early in the semester.
take it. awesome course. not super easy, but also not super difficult. right in between.
prereqs: At least one prior Philosophy course.
descrip: We shall investigate Plato's views on knowledge, metaphysics, and the nature of the soul, including moral psychology. We will read and discuss Plato's dialogues philosophically - for their philosophical content - rather than from a literary or cultural point of view. Only those interested in reading Plato this way should enroll.

title: Buddhism in Japan
reviews: If you're interested in Buddhism, take it! Otherwise might be a little dry.
Take it if you have interest in Buddhism or Japan! If you work hard and ask for help on papers it should be a great class!
Taking a buddhism course before/ have some knowledge on the general subject before would have helped a lot.
When preparing presentations, do not worry too much about incorporating every single historical fact - simply prompt discussion with relevant questions.
descrip: This course will examine representative aspects of Buddhist thought and practice in Japan from the sixth century to the present. We will focus on the major Buddhist traditions--including Lotus, Pure Land, esoteric Buddhism, and Zen--as well as Buddhism and the literary arts, modern challenges to traditional Buddhism, and contemporary Buddhist movements. Readings will include scriptures, sermons, tales, and philosophical essays, as well as selected secondary sources. Some background in either Japan or Buddhism is strongly recommended.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Urban Economics
descrip: This is a course in urban and regional economics. Course studies the main economic forces that lead to the emergence of cities and regional agglomeration, and the effects on worker productivity, urban amenities, and congestion. Course discusses the problems in measuring these urban characteristics, the methodologies to do it, as well as the design of optimal urban policy. Course also studies the economic theory and evidence on the internal structure of cities, as well as the policies that can enhance urban living. Finally, the course analyzes the role cities play in aggregate economic development.

title: Renewable Energy Systems
reviews: As a leader of a group of 20 freshmen and sophomores in the Sustainable Engineering and Development Scholars (SEADS).  I will be recommending to them to take this course next spring.  Great course if you want to understand renewable energy technologies works from an engineering perspective as well as how these technologies function when applied in real energy markets.

I think it's good for grad students, but I didn't personally enjoy it as an undergrad.  Gives a good knowledge of the systems, but wouldn't recommend if you've taken a lot of energy certificate classes
Interesting material with no exams.

This course provides a really great introduction to renewable energy systems. It touches on technical topics of several technologies, as well as policy and economics. The course is a lot of work though. The homework assignments take several hours a week and the final project took a solid month.
Very good course introducing to the practical side of renewable energies. However, you must be interested in the topic to truly appreciate it.
prereqs: MAE 228 Energy Technologies in the 21st Century, or evidence of equivalent proficiency in energy topics. Fluency in MATLAB, python, R is an asset.
descrip: A thorough introduction to renewable energy systems. Students will learn the physical, chemical, and engineering principles underlying renewable energy (RE) technologies: principles of operation of RE systems and technical challenges in planning and installing them; environmental and social impacts of energy technologies; challenges of integrating RE sources into existing energy systems; energy technology innovation systems; and economics of RE systems. Implications of transition to RE-dominated systems will be evaluated. The national and international policy context for RE will also be discussed.

title: Elementary Swahili II
reviews: #chill
10/10. Must take this course.
Absolutely take this class, Mahiri is a great professor and really helpful for learning Swahili or culture of Swahili-speaking people.
TAKE SWA!!!!!!!!!! MAHIRI IS AMAZING YOU WILL LOVE HIM AND THIS CLASS. IT WILL BE ONE OF YOUR FAVORITES AND WILL MAKE YOU LEARN SO MUCH MORE THAN JUST A LANGUAGE. PLEASE PLEASE TAKE IT!
Take this class! Review the vocab, have fun, and go to Dar!
prereqs: Only those who have taken Elementary Swahili I (SWA 101) should enroll..
descrip: This course is a continuation of Swahili 101. It enhances communicative skills with emphasis on writing, reading, comprehension and conversation. Class activities review and enhance already introduced skills in speaking, writing, listening and reading; all embedded in authentic and contemporary East African cultural content. Cultural themes include the basics of daily life such as relationships, food, physical features and other aspects of material culture of East Africa. Learners are expected to perform functions related to basic services, comprehension of basic spoken and written texts and writing of a 1-page essay in Kiswahili.

title: Contemporary Issues in African Societies
reviews: Always ask Sara what order she would recommend doing the readings, as there is often one way that makes the most sense. She is very upfront about what types of demographic material may be over some individuals' heads and is always happy to answer questions accordingly. Meet with her one on one! She is wildly helpful and makes it very clear that she values your time and efforts.

Definitely take this course! Sara is so kind and so intelligent. She is clearly well-studied on this subject material. This course taught me to study world and societal problems from different perspectives. It was interesting and definitely not an overwhelming course. I learned a ton without feeling bogged down every week.
If you have never taken a demography course, I recommend this one! Its a great introduction to demography and challenges you to think critically about contemporary African issues.
Take it!
Take it! Sara is awesome and you won't regret it.
descrip: This course approaches contemporary African issues through the lens of population studies. What theories explain the recent fertility declines observed in so much of the developing world, and why have some African countries failed to adhere to that path? What traits are characteristic of African households today, and how were present-day family relations shaped by pre-colonial norms? Discussions will stress intra- and cross-continental comparative analysis to foster an appreciation for characteristics, trends, and challenges that are uniquely African.

title: Renaissance Altarpieces and Religious Crisis
descrip: As objects that threatened to stimulate idolatry as readily as they promised to arouse devotion, altarpieces were sites of polemics and anxiety. This course examines the multifaceted visual strategies Italian artists like Raphael, Michelangelo and Titian, alongside reform-minded patrons, adopted in response to critiques of Christian imagery in the decades before and after the Council of Trent (1545-63). We will also reconsider the traditional view that the experimental and unsystematic reforms typical of pre-Trent altarpieces ceded to more regulated, conservative art following the Church's formal plea to chasten religious art and its makers.

title: Introduction to Differential Geometry
reviews: A very nice introduction to some interesting geometric ideas. Definitely a good class to take - problem sets are a little challenging, but manageable.
Differential geometry is an interesting subject; but this class has pretty annoying problem sets.

I would say that if you can stand the computation then this is a very interesting course to take. It touches on some nice things that are just too much to explain in words, at least by me.

Lucas Culler did a good job. Go to his office hours and ask questions if he's teaching.
Lucas is certainly way better than Prof. Yang; you see some cool stuff, but the class can be annoyingly computational sometimes.
Take it, but be sure to know the material of the prerequisites.
Take this class but be prepared for a lot of computation in the problem sets. The final exam was hard.
prereqs: MAT218 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to geometry of surfaces. Surfaces in Euclidan space, second fundamental form, minimal surfaces, geodescis, Gauss curvature, Gauss-Bonnet formula, uniformization of surfaces, elementary notions of contact geometry.

title: Beginner's Latin Continued: Basic Prose
reviews: Latin 108 is generally more of the same of Latin 105, but the final translations are more interesting than Wheelock, anyway
Latin is a beautiful and interesting language. I believe everyone should give it a try at least once.
Latin is hard but fun.
Make sure to do the readings and keep up with vocab. Overall a really good course.
Master the vocabulary.
strongly recommend
prereqs: LAT 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continues Latin grammar from LAT 101. The second half of the semester will be devoted to reading continuous Latin poetry and prose.

title: Unmaking the Bomb:The Science &Technology of Nuclear Nonproliferation, Disarmament, and Verification
prereqs: PHY 101 or PHY 102 or PHY 103 or PHY 104. MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers the science and technology underlying existing and emerging nuclear security issues. Part I introduces the principles of nuclear fission, nuclear radiation, and nuclear weapons (and their effects). Part II develops the concepts required to model and analyze nuclear systems, including the production of fissile materials and the detection and characterization of these materials with radiation measurement techniques. Relevant applications are explored in Part III and include nuclear forensic analysis, nuclear archaeology, and nuclear warhead verification. Such case studies will also be part of the final projects.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Public Management in the Age of Digital Technology
descrip: Big data, social media, the internet; digital technology, is changing the nature of government and leadership in democratic societies. This course introduces students of government to the ramifications of digital technology, and its technical concepts and infrastructure. This course emphasizes how the changing technological landscape can drive performance improvement and innovation in government. We discuss what digital technology means for leaders in the public sector, and how its potential can be better used to serve the public. The course relies on the case study method.

title: Property, Wealth, and Equality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Religions of China
reviews: Go for it! If you'll be invested and keep up with readings/go to lecture, you'll learn about Chinese culture/history more generally, not just about religion.

Good introduction course for not only Chinese religions but East Asian religions. I found it particularly enlightening that the course goes through a number of the main texts from each discussed religion.

This is a great EM. The readings can be dense, but the preceptors will help with understanding them. There are short discussion board posts every week, two easy quizzes, and two essays during the semester. Attendance in lectures is graded but the content is never asked about again. Again, great EM, PDF, or fifth class.
prereqs: Open to students who have not taken prior courses in Religion or Chinese studies..
descrip: A thematic introduction to the history of Chinese religion. Topics include cosmology, ancestors, gods, mythology, ethics, shamanism, divination, gender, and mortuary ritual. Readings drawn from a wide range of sources, including sacred scriptures, philosophical texts, popular literature, and modern ethnography.

title: Ocean, Atmosphere, and Climate
reviews:
1) Don't let this course discourage you from the awesome GEO department!
2) Don't expect it to convince you that GEO is cool.
3) Don't expect to do much cool stuff in lab (the highlight was counting plankton in a microscope)
4) GO ON THE FIELD TRIP it was the best part.

Do not take unless you are specifically interested in oceanography! Dry lectures and lots of busy work (a problem set and a lab each week). The labs are poorly organized and normally I was forced to complete most of the lab questions on my own time because we ran out of time in class. I took this course because I was excited to learn about the interaction between the ocean and climate change, but that ended up being a very small part of the course. My least favorite out of the 8 classes I have taken so far at Princeton.
I would recommend this class if you have an interest in oceanography
If you want to be a GEO major or have a general interest in climate/the environment, definitely take this.
If you want to take any other classes on ocean/atm/climate, take this one first.
It's a good course to learn more about geo and decide if you want to major in geo
Take it if Sarmiento is teaching & you have an interest in oceanography and/or the atmosphere. You'll learn a lot and the TAs are super helpful.
Take it only if professor is teaching it! Don't take if he is on sabbatical!! Not hard, don't do the readings.
Take it!!
Take it!! It is so well-taught, thorough, and interesting. The course, and the Geo Department as a whole, is the best.
Take this course!

This year Jorge Sarmiento was on sabbatical, but I've heard he's a great teacher. Definitely an intro-level course (over half freshmen), but you still learn about lots of cool stuff. And GEO is a great department! More "Ocean" than "Atmosphere and Climate."

You probably will end up having to take this course if you want to be a geo major, and it's definitely not a bad required course. You learn a lot of relevant information, and the material presented are great examples of how physics, biology, chemistry all come into play in geosciences. However, the material does get dry sometimes.
prereqs: High School biology, chemistry and calculus..
descrip: An introduction to the ocean, atmosphere, and climate from the perspective of oceanography. Covers coastal processes including waves, beaches, tides and ecosystems; open ocean processes including atmospheric circulation and its impact on the surface ocean, the wind driven circulation, and surface ocean ecosystems; and the abyssal ocean including circulation, the cycling of chemicals, and ocean sediments and what they tell us about the climate history of the earth. The final part of the course will cover humans and the earth system, including a discussion of ocean resources and climate change.

title: History and Theory of Architecture and Climate
reviews: I strongly recommend Daniel Barber as a professor, no matter what kind of seminar he's involved with
prereqs: Open to Graduate Students Only.
descrip: Architects have long been concerned with the relationship of a building to its climate. Focused on the decade immediately following World War II, before mechanical HVAC systems were affordable or widespread, this seminar explores the archive of methodological experiments and technological devices that were intended to refine the climatic performance of a building. Many of these explorations took place at Princeton, in architecture and elsewhere. We also explore the conceptual frameworks that allow us to consider these architectural experiments in light of the historiographic and epistemological challenges posed by climate change

title: Metabolic Engineering
descrip: Introduction to the engineering of metabolism. The objective of this course is to introduce students to current techniques and challenges within the field of metabolic engineering. Specific topics range from applications for energy and the environment to human health. The course also includes lectures from industrial speakers, a mock NSF panel review of research proposals, and debates structured as reviewers discussing the appropriateness of manuscripts for publication.

title: Elementary Hebrew II
reviews: Overall, this was a fun and valuable course. I would recommend taking it if you like small courses and a lot of attention from the professor. Since the teacher is changing I think the structure and content of the course will change as well but I'd still recommend!
Take it!
prereqs: HEB 101 or equivalent.
descrip: This course is designed for students who are familiar with the Hebrew alphabet, and who have rudimentary skills in reading, writing, speaking and comprehending modern Hebrew. Over the spring term, students will further develop their proficiency in these skills, and acquire a solid grounding in modern Hebrew grammar and syntax. By the end of the semester, students will be able to read and comment on short articles, stories and poems, to conduct conversations, and make short presentations.

title: Afterlives of The Iliad
descrip: See website

title: Chinese Biography and Autobiography
descrip: This reading seminar focuses on the many forms of biography and autobiography in medieval China. Our focus will be on texts from the Tang through the early Northern Song. We read biographies from standard dynastic histories, religious compendia, informal biographies, and commemorative accounts found in epitaphs and other funerary steles, and we consider the ways in which these forms overlap with and shape one another. We also consider the role of biography in the larger historiographical tradition. We examine both prose and poetic autobiographies, including fu and some long regulated verse poems (pailu).

title: Legal and Regulatory Policy Toward Markets
descrip: This course employs the methods of microeconomics, industrial organization and law and economics to study where market failures warrant gov't intervention with policies implemented through the law or regulatory agencies. Topics include antitrust policy toward business practices and vertical and horizontal combinations; policy approaches toward R&D and intellectual property; reliance on tort law, disclosure law, and regulatory standards to mitigate information and externality problems pertaining to health, safety, and performance risks; and the implications for pricing, entry, and investment of different forms of public utility regulation.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Economics
reviews: Enjoy the free lunch every Friday. :-)

I genuinely think this is an excellent plateform for students in the same cohort to exchange about essential things that make us a community in this department. I think it allows to raise a lot of issues that are harder to debate outside of an official framework like this one. I am very grateful for the department to organize this, and I strongly recommend it to all first years.
descrip: This seminar is designed to help graduate students in economics cultivate ethical research practices they may apply in future work at or beyond the University. Students are encouraged to discuss concerns that may arise during the conduct of their research with experienced faculty and devise solutions for dealing with these concerns. The course provides necessary training for newly mandated RCR training for graduate students supported by government grants, and is required for successful completion of the program.

title: Biophysics
reviews: Fascinating and diverse subjects. Very manageable work.
descrip: The course presents a broader view of biological physics. While the course starts with an overview of the fundamentals of biological physics, using Frauenfelder's text book as a guide, the course will move on to higher levels of biological systems, using evolution and ecology as our primary organizing principles. The course will have a section on the Physics of Cancer at the end.

title: Hydrology
reviews: For a class about water, this course is painfully dry.

For a class all about water, it was pretty dry. Also, there were never enough equations on the equation sheet for exams, so be prepared to waste your valuable time memorizing really convoluted and long equations. And be prepared to come out of the class without any real knowledge about what hydrology actually is and how to solve problems in the subject. I know a few friends who took this course and ended up switching out of the major because they became so disinterested in the material. Don't take it unless you absolutely have to.
Go to office hours and start assignments early. They can be confusing and often need clarification from office hours.

I would highly take this course! If you are in CBE, I think this counts as an elective - so you should definitely take it! Professor Smith is incredibly kind and knowledgeable, and you will end up learning so much valuable information about rivers!
If you are interested in Hydrology both quantitatively and from a socioeconomic and political standpoint, this is a good class to take.
It's hard to not do well in this class, especially with all the help Professor Smith and Maofeng extend. Just be sure you're able to memorize a lot of formulas
Make sure you like the subject - and if you do, you'll learn so so much

Prof Smith is a wonderful lecturer, which gave me the motivation to work in this class (I otherwise have a lack of interest in the subject). He also writes the readings he assigns for the class, which is actually very helpful in many ways.
Really interesting course that explains some stuff about the weather. Very fairly graded class with a fair level of expectations from students

The course focuses on both the qualitative policy history of rivers as well as serious numerical models. The lectures are a bit dry, but the class notes are so detailed that you don't really have to pay attention during lecture to do well in the class.
descrip: Analysis of fundamental processes in the hydrologic cycle, including precipitation, evapotranspiration, infiltration, streamflow and groundwater flow.

title: Science and Technology of Nuclear Energy: Fission and Fusion
reviews:
All that Goldston cares about is making sure his students learn the material.  The technical (read: engineering-level) nature of some of the material, especially at the start of the semester, makes the class hard to follow at times.  Goldston is funny and obviously an expert in the field, but if you're not comfortable having to figure out most of it for yourself, you may struggle.  The class is not unfairly difficult; it's just the nature of the material.

That being said, I'd urge anybody with an interest in the field to take this class.  It's a very rewarding class and you will learn more in this class than ANY other physics class.  The breadth of material is astounding and Goldston teaches you about things other than just the physics; you get into environmental, proliferation, and political issues as well.  Goldston is an important figure in the field of fusion energy and the TA for the course is phenomenal as well.

Overall, this is a course that may confuse you at times, but Goldston doesn't grade too harshly and tries to help out every step of the way.
Be prepared to stay up late.

I wouldn't recommend taking this course. Although I do feel like I learned a decent amount about fission and fusion energy, the problem sets take a decent chunk of time, are a treasure hunt through the lecture slides, and were often not accompanied by a greater understanding of the material, detracting from the experience.
Make sure you're physics background is good

Not worth your time. You can find a better elective that's not nearly as frustrating. Psets took forever, had little to do with what was covered in class. It was also the worst of physics and public policy combined. So you are expected to have an opinion on things like the Iran nuclear deal, which wasn't what I signed up for in a physics class.
Pay attention in class and try to review what symbols mean. Fusion scientists did not create a good standard of terminology and symbols.
This class was not as good as I expected/wanted it to be. The material is pretty interesting, but the class was much harder and time-consuming and less well-taught than it could have been.

This is a great elective course for physics majors. It was a small class and was taught lecture style with slides. The slides were unintelligible and definitely worth taking notes on the derivations. The problem sets were very, very long each week but were doable. I would recommend this class as a not-so-easy elective.
prereqs: PHY 101-102 or 103-104 or 107-109, MAT 201 or 203, or EGR 191-194. CBE 246, CHM 306, MAE 221, PHY 301 prior or concurrent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Concern about climate change and need for energy independence has driven recent growth in nuclear fission power. However the events at Fukushima Daichi and the negotiations with Iran illustrate some of the issues. Fusion energy is moving towards realization of an alternative approach to nuclear power, with fewer dangers, but not yet ready to be commercialized. In this course we will study the science and technology of both fission and fusion. You will gain a good physical understanding of how both approaches work, including their benefits and risks, through applying and expanding your scientific and mathematical skills.

title: Verse in Shows: Poetry on Stage, 405 B.C.E.-2015 A.D.
descrip: From Attic tragedies to Broadway musicals, verse forms have been central to the way theater works. Playwrights have deployed them to deliver powerful, sometimes subliminal effects to the ears of audiences well-versed in registering them. In plays ranging from Euripides' Bakkhai through Elizabethan and Restoration theater to Lin-Manuel Miranda's Hamilton, we'll look at, and above all listen for, the intricate interactions of verse, prose, and song, trying to work out how they may have operated on their original audiences (whose ears were often in such matters more acute than ours), and how we can make sense of and savor them now.

profs.name: Andrea de Castro Melloni, Course Head

title: Intensive Portuguese
reviews: Definitely take this course if you want to learn portuguese in 3 months.

For those with a good level of Spanish this is a cleverly constructed course to run through the grammar essentials of Portuguese. Expect to do some listening and speaking practice separately if you want to be able to speak as well as read and write.
I would highly recommend this class for anyone who already speaks Spanish and wants to learn Portuguese.  Andrea is a fabulous instructor.  The pace is quite fast, but very manageable.
This is an intensive course, so make sure you have the time to do the homework and write the essays.
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.

title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
descrip: The aim of this course is to familiarize students with work in contemporary sociological theory that has had a major impact on empirical research in the U.S., or holds untapped potential for such impact. We will focus especially on bodies of theory relevant to large tracts of the discipline. Rather than attempt a survey, we will read in depth select theoretical texts that together illustrate the heterogeneity and richness of the field.

title: Ethics and Economics
reviews: Be prepared to read all of the extra material from the syllabus, because usually the answers for the assignments are from these readings
Go to lecture.
Great class, great professor! If you liked Law and Economics, you will like this course. Great EM for people not that into philosophy courses.
I highly recommend this class. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Professor Leonard was very easy to listen to and explained the material very well.
I recommend it to all students interested in economics, law, or philosophy.

If you are at all interested in the qualitative/philosophical/ethical aspect of economics, this is the course to take! Professor Leonard is a wonderful lecturer, the class fosters many amazing discussions, and the material is inherently very interesting. Grading is a bit subjective and unpredictable, but in my opinion worth it.
Important to take good notes.
One of the best econ classes I've ever taken.
Overall great departmental and I will probably use the material covered in this class for future independent work. Good class if you're into "freakanomics." Would recommend.

Some overlap with Law and Economics if you took that with Leonard in the fall, not so much that it gets boring though. Interesting class; lots of non-philosophy majors will try to argue like they know anything about the subject. That's the only annoying part.

Take it if you're interested in the material. The lectures are engaging and the course isn't too hard. However, Professor Leonard does play favorites at the beginning, although as the semester goes on and he gets to know more of the class, this is less obvious.
Take it!! My favorite Economics course at Princeton.
Take it.

Take this class - Leonard has interesting things to say. Also this is one of the very few Econ classes that are take home midterms and finals, which I love. Less work than most Econ classes. 10/10 would recommend.
This course was one of my favorite classes over my four years here.  Professor Leonard is a great lecturer, and class discussions were engaging.

This is a solid course for anyone who needs an EM distribution requirement, and vaguely interested in economics at all. Last semester, I was a prospective econ major, but taking ECO310 made me realise that theoretical econ really isn't that interesting. This class takes econ approaches and ideas and makes them applied, allowing you to really engage with them as ideas and understand how economics works.

Leonard is a fantastic lecturer - the 1.5 hour class is normally pretty easy to stay awake and engaged with, and that isn't something I would say for every class that I attend. Attending lectures is crucial to get a good grade since Leonard lectures without PowerPoint, and if you attend lectures, most of the readings aren't really necessary. Leonard covers most of the material he thinks is pertinent in his lectures, and this is taken from the assigned readings. 

In terms of workload, the assignments take a long time to complete, but are entirely manageable. They aren't always written in the most coherent way, but attending office hours to clarify what he wants from a question solves that problem. You don't need to be quantitatively amazing to complete his assignments, just take good notes on everything he says in lecture and do the occasional readings that are mentioned in the assignments, and you can do well in the course overall.

Overall, Leonard is amazing, this course is great; take it.
Your grade will certainly be based on the word count. High workload, but grading seemed fair.
prereqs: ECO 100.
descrip: Introduction to ethical issues in market exchange, and in laws that regulate it. How ethical commitments evolve, and influence cooperation. The moral dimension of low wages, outsourcing, "fair" trade, price discrimination, and banning sales of sex, blood, organs and other "repugnant" goods. The nature, causes and consequences of economic inequality.

title: Civil Society and Public Policy
reviews: Definitely take this course! Professor Katz is very kind, but pushes you out of your comfort zone (in a good way). I really enjoyed it. Although I'm not sure how I will do, I would say I would actually take it again. I may regret this in a few days.

I would recommend taking this course. It provides a nice balance if you're taking a full course load and Katz is really nice and so interesting to listen to. I would definitely recommend getting started on the term paper before reading week.
If you have no interest in the material at all, Prof Katz is still a strong enough reason to take the course. He is one of the gems of Princeton.

If you're interested in the course, and want to take a course with a great important professor, you should take the course. You can spend a range of time on the work for the course, depending on how much time you have and what you want to get out of it. I think the course fostered great conversations, and I really enjoyed it.
Prof Katz is amazing, this course is super interesting, and the discussions are thoughtful. Highly recommend!
Professor Katz is great - take this course!
Take it if you are excited to do the readings
Take it! Professor Katz is awesome. Good for anyone interested in general public policy.
Take this - it's a rare course that works for everyone ranging from beginners to POL/WWS majors.

The reading list seems long, but Katz makes it manageable by identifying the important material each week. Absolutely develop a relationship with Prof. Katz. Not only is he incredibly sweet, but it will give you better insight into his personality and what he's looking for in the final paper. Plus, he loves students and can be incredibly engaged once you've gotten to know him, helping with academic or career advice, etc.

This is a great class to take! Professor Katz is truly a legend in the field and the department, and he brings so much knowledge and wisdom to the course. He's also very understanding about the Princeton workload, and the amount of reading and assignments (just one final paper) are definitely manageable. It had a particularly American focus this year (though Prof. Katz said that might change in future years). For anyone interested in civil society or taking a class with Prof. Katz, I would strongly recommend!

This was a great class, very relaxed but very interesting. Professor Katz is a wonderful teacher and mentor, and really cares about his students. There is not a huge amount of workload, just readings to keep up with each week, and a final research paper. I thought it was a good balance for my junior spring semester, when I had to take five classes plus a JP (this being one of the five).
descrip: Civil society is the arena of voluntary organizations (churches, social welfare organizations, sporting clubs) and communal activity. Scholars now tell us that such voluntary and cooperative activities create "social capital" -- a stock of mutual trust that forms the glue that holds society together. The course will be devoted to the study of the history of these concepts, and to the analysis of their application to the United States and other societies. This will be an interdisciplinary effort, embracing history, philosophy, anthropology, sociology, and other disciplines.

title: Ottoman Diplomatics: Paleography and Diplomatic Documents
descrip: An introduction to Ottoman paleography and diplomatics. The documents will be in divani and rika scripts.

title: Techniques of Conducting
reviews: Absolutely take this class with Gabriel!! It's phenomenal. Even if you feel that you're struggling, it's still an excellent learning experience.
Be prepared to commit a significant amount of time to actively improving your conducting. Probably not for non majors with a casual interest.
Definitely take it!  It is incredibly fun and Gabriel is a great instructor.

If you are interested in conducting, take this course, especially with Gabriel Crouch. That goes for both instrumental and choral conducting. It's rather fast... it's good to have some gesture under your belt before the course. But once you get past building the basics, you'll get to learn a lot of advanced techniques.
Take it - it increases your musical awareness and it's super fun

Take this course!  It's a fair bit of work and not for the faint of heart, but it will give you a greater appreciation of the music you are singing/performing.  Professor Crouch is a fantastic teacher--encouraging, detailed, and hilarious--so don't miss this chance to work with him.  Whether or not you have conducted before, you stand to learn a lot from this class.
Take this course. It is fun and very necessary for musicians and people with strong interests and investments in the performing arts.
This course was great. My conducting improved a lot over the course of the semester.
This is a great course! Take it if Crouch is teaching.

This is a really fun course! You will get the most out of it if you are willing to practice conducting seriously outside of the classroom and if you are actively engaged in singing for your peers during class.
if gabriel is teaching this definitely try to take it. conducting has changed the way i encounter music. this course is not easy, it requires diligent work. gabriel wants to see your improve
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of instructor. Some background in music theory. Basic keyboard facility. Member of a faculty-led choral ensemble for the semester in question. Contact Gabriel Crouch to schedule an interview..
descrip: This course will focus on: 1) the development of competency in choral conducting technique, 2) verbal and non-verbal communication in rehearsal, 3) the study of choral repertoire of various styles and genres, emphasizing analysis and interpretations and 4) the development of good rehearsal strategies.

title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities - The Invisible Renaissance--Science, Art, Magic in Early Modern Europe
reviews: All the students were very happy about the class. Everyone felt at the end to have participate with significant contributions.
Take it if you are at all interested in Renaissance thought or in thinking about a different way to conceive of the world.
Try it. Be ready for the occasional heavy reading, but try it. Talk with the professors, ask questions, make connections. Do the impossible, see the invisible.
