Very good course. Both professors Rampling and Kaufmann are excellent, would recommend taking a course with either one. This time period is highly worthwhile studying if only because it offers a startlingly unfamiliar worldview in a deeply familiar setting. Also very much enjoyed the gallery project at the end. Few final projects have required so much work and care as this one.
descrip: How did early modern people depict phenomena they could not see? This course traces attempts to represent the invisible: from angels and the influence of stars and magnets, to microscopic creatures and the human passions. Philosophers, painters and magi puzzled over these unseen forces, beings and structures, seeking to describe them in writings and artworks. We will unpack their arguments and try to reconstruct their practices, including optical tricks and alchemical experiments. The course culminates in a virtual exhibition, curated by students, as we follow in the steps of Renaissance thinkers and artists, and put the invisible on display.

title: Media and Public Policy
reviews: Ask the guests questions, they've lived it. Prof Zelizer is quite good facilitating discussion.

I was not a fan of Prof. Zelizer's seminars. Another student had told me how wonderful his lectures were, and from seminar you can tell that lecturing is his strength. He talks a lot about history, especially in the early seminars, and infuses so many things with personal anecdotes. Unfortunately this leaves little opportunity for students to engage in discussion compared to a normal seminar course. I often had things I wanted to say but couldn't; a person actively trying to talk was afforded the opportunity maybe twice each seminar. As a result, there was little actual discussion; we wanted to share what we had been sitting on for five minutes rather than respond to the last student's point. I think discussions were not very productive for this reason. There was also not a feeling of connectedness and warmth, but Prof. Zelizer is not entirely to blame for that, as the room setup was really poor -- it's a very industrial room and for no reason at all the desks are arranged so that there is a large hole between them, which pushes people apart and makes everyone distant. I think Prof. Zelizer might have been fighting an uphill battle there. And although he couldn't connect with us and moderated discussion poorly, he secured some great guest speakers like Stephen Engelberg, editor in chief at ProPublica. The readings were interesting in isolation, but they did not form a coherent course. The reading load was heavy, usually a book a week, and we rarely talked about them in seminar. Therefore most students did not read most of the books. Overall I am grateful to Prof. Zelizer for the experience, the hard work he put into securing the speakers, and the lectures that gave us a good sense of the history of the country's media. I might, however, recommend a different journalism course. We did very little writing over the course of the semester so this course is not likely to help you become a better writer or journalist.
If you are interested in the topic of media and policy this is a great course to take.

If you have an interest in what the journalism industry looks like, definitely take this course. The guest speakers are top quality and will give you an honest opinion about the industry. The class isn't that heavy in policy and politics though.

Look, if you want a class where you meet a bunch of different journalists and have some interesting moments, take it. But if you are looking for a well structured and organized course where the readings, seminars, and assignments all tie together in a cohesive manner, then don't (because they are often quite unrelated).
Make sure to be thoughtful with your work!
Take it! Zelizer is tough but a good, passionate professor.
Take this class if you are interested in journalism and politics, and you want to meet a lot of really important journalists who will undoubtedly visit the class.

This course is worth it if you are interested in hearing from top-tier journalists, with emphasis on the hearing.  There's not much discussion in Zelizer's iteration of the class.  It's also an easy class to skate by in, if that's what you're looking for.  That said, Zelizer's connections will open doors for you in journalism and if you have any interest in the discipline the seminar is a fascinating, 12-week discussion of its future.
best class i took at princeton- take it
descrip: Introduction to the media, politics and public policy. Using historical methods, we will study the relationship between the press and public policy in a number of realms, including war and diplomacy, taxation, civil rights, and more. The seminar will also examine important milestones in the development of public policy that impacted the structure and substance of the news media. We will have a number of award-winning reporters, editors, join the seminar as guests.

title: Painting
reviews: A really good class if you're dedicated. There is a lot of time spent out of class.
Check Blackboard for assignments, and don't fall behind!

Eve is amazing! Her class is fun and engaging, but also purposeful and insightful. She teaches many skills and techniques, so it doesn't matter whether you are a master painter or haven't painting a thing in your life - the environment is welcoming to everyone of all levels of artistic talent. You will truly improve as a painter through this class was having fun along the way!

Great class! I took this as a 5th class with 4 technical classes. 5.5 hours of studio plus 3 hours of homework per week, although you can spend more time on homework if you want. Eve will help you if you want but is also pretty flexible if you want to try your own style, especially in the second half of the course.
Great course; have fun and embrace the challenge! Make art that you love making, but be sure to test the limits of your comfort zone!

It is time consuming, but a great way to balance the time of work you do. Often feels like a study break rather than work to paint for hours. Of course, it is still work and takes up time, but overall the class is a really fun creative release that does a good job of developing you as an artist

It's a great course and you will learn a lot about painting. But don't go in thinking it's going to be a chill/joke class. You better be serious about putting in the work because it's a lot of time but very rewarding.
Just take it seriously. Try to learn something and don't just goof off.

Loved painting -- wasn't a huge fan of the structure of Eve's lessons sometimes. One thing that really bothered me was the subjectiveness of the instruction. Some paintings that I loved, she hated. Some paintings that she liked, I didn't. It didn't always seem alright to voice my opinion about certain artwork or to justify certain things done.
Painting is not actually a "chill" class unless you are planning to PDF. This class is time consuming in that not only during classtime, but also out of class.

THIS IS NOT AN INTRO CLASS. The studios are generally fun, although really long some times, and I ended up learning a lot in the class. If you are taking it as an "easy" class, don't (!). It is very time consuming (~6 hours in the studio in one day), and you should expect to put in a lot of hours outside of class time to work on homework (at least 4 hours per week).
Take it only if you're genuinely interested in painting.

Take it with Eve, she's great and understands that the class should be fun. But from the get-go you need to decide if you're painting to please her or to please yourself, because that can result in two totally different paintings.
The course was good, but sometimes the criticism could be harsh.
descrip: An introduction to the materials and methods of painting. The areas to be covered are color and its interaction, the use of form and scale, painting from a model, painting objects with a concern for their mass and interaction with light.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Highly recommend!
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: The Origins of Rome: Livy and Vergil
reviews: A fairly easy, yet enjoyable class.

Class experiences will vary widely based on who is grading and what their standard is. Blair is strict (i.e. not afraid to give out Cs), but is also extremely knowledgeable of the lingua Latina and emphasizes precision, which is crucial for those who will continue to study Latin in third year.
Definitely, people make tremendous improvement of Latin in the class.
Do the readings and review every weekend.
Harder than you might think but a good and helpful class
If you like Latin take this course. It was well-taught and the work was reasonable.
If you want to read some Livy and Vergil take the class.
It's going to be difficult but you get to read some of the coolest things you'll ever read.
Prepare the homework ahead of time, and come with questions if you have them. If you keep up during the week, the weekly quizzes and exams will go well.
Review every night and write out translations.
Take for language requirement or Classics major/Latin certificate. Much less time commitment involved than other intro language courses. Easy if a) you know the grammar b) you do the readings.

This course is a definite step up from LAT 105, even from the first day. The first few chapters of Livy are definitely tough considering that it is the beginning of the course. On the bright side, it doesn't get significantly harder. It's pretty important to keep up with the daily readings. It was hard to predict where to read up to in advance if there was time to (I personally didn't on top of another four courses, and especially because this was just a distribution course for me) because the syllabus was abandoned so early on. Also, for me just keeping up was a lot of work. I tended to do better when I made flashcards for quizzes, but didn't always have the time to make them. I would have had a lot harder time in this class if I were not somewhat familiar with the readings beforehand. Then again, I did this for a distribution requirement and do not plan to major in Classics or study Latin intensively in the future.
This course is harder than LAT 105! Prepare to do a significant amount of work daily.

Very interesting tangential discourses and knowledgeable professor (esp. with regards to historical linguistics); quiz/exam prep. could have been a little better. I've definitely taken better Latin courses at Princeton.
strongly encourage them to take it
prereqs: LAT 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: We will read selections from Livy and Vergil, the masters of prose and poetry respectively in the period of Augustus. Our objectives are: to develop the ability to read Latin with greater ease and enjoyment; to improve sight-reading skills; to experience the artistry of Latin prose and poetry; and to examine some of the questions associated with the Romans' interpretation of their history.

title: Ethnicity and History
reviews: Take this class. It is very interesting and the professors are very invested and take your thoughts seriously. Take this class if you want to learn to think critically and try out independent work.

This is one of my favorite courses that I have taken at Princeton, and I highly recommend it. The professors are great and relaxed, and students have a lot of liberty to explore areas that interest them.
descrip: We live in the age of ethnicity. The surge of ethnic conflicts after the collapse of the Soviet Union has brought dramatically to the fore the importance of ethnicity as a motive for social action, often violent. Ethnic difference is a key factor employed to explain social inequality in the Global North. In the United States, ethnicity and race are official categories applied by governmental agencies in dealing with discrimination and poverty. In this course, students will look at ethnicity as a historical phenomenon that happens in different times and places, and become familiar with theories and methods as well as case-studies.

title: Science, Society & Dinner
descrip: See website

title: Energy Storage Systems
prereqs: Knowledge of ODE/PDE.
descrip: This is a survey course on energy storage systems with a focus on electrochemical energy storage. Fundamentals of thermodynamics will be reviewed and fundamentals of electrochemistry introduced. These fundamentals will then be applied to devices such as batteries, flywheels and compressed air storage. Device optimization with respect to energy density, power density, cycle life and capital cost will be considered.

title: Electromagnetic Field Theory and Optics
prereqs: PHY 103 and PHY 104..
descrip: This course should provide the students with a broad and solid background in electromagnetics, including both statics and dynamics, as described by Maxwell's equations. Fundamental concepts of diffraction theory, Fourier optics, polarization of light, and geometrical optics will be discussed. Emphasis will be on basic engineering principles, and applications will be discussed throughout. Examples include cavities, waveguides, antennas, fiber optic communications, and imaging.

title: Topics in Algebraic Number Theory - Galois Representations
descrip: Over the course of the semester, we discuss automorphy lifting theorems: theorems that assert if a mod l Galois representation arises from an automorphic form, then so too does a suitable l-adic lift. We start with the simplest two dimensional examples and then explore cases in which various subtler complications arise.

title: Physical Chemistry: Chemical Thermodynamics and Kinetics
reviews: Definitely try to spend time actually understanding the material the first time you read it in the textbook for the reading responses, it will pay off in the end. Also, this class is more conceptual than you would think for a pchem course. Treat it like any other class (orgo) and make sure you understand concepts, not just how to solve the problems. The conceptual questions in the book are really helpful!

If you are considering this course, I assume you are a Chem major. In that case, I recommend this course. I recommend going to precepts and actually putting effort into understanding the readings before class. Participation will be emphasized!
Make sure to do the reading and start studying early (you'll regret it when you're cramming your cheat sheet the last minute). Review psets.
Take it because you have to and because the Chemistry department except for this class is phenomenal
Take it because you have to, but it could be worse
Take it if you need to. Otherwise, it's not such a riveting course. If you like thermodynamics then take it. If you're a chem major, then you're probably taking it anyway.
This class is fine if you put in effort on problem sets and read the book carefully. Don't depend on lectures to learn material.
Very well structured course that gives a good grasp of thermo. Kelly is great! Duyu and his office hours are really helpful. Great CHM departmental.
What's to say? Not a class one takes out of choice, but thermodynamics classes could definitely be more painful than this one is.

You are probably taking this course because you have to.  Don't worry; it's not that bad.  Dr. Kelly does his best to make lectures understandable, and the course is graded quite fairly.  Read the textbook carefully and go to office hours for help on the problem sets.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 and MAT 104, or CHM 215, or permission of instructor. Course is open to freshmen who have completed CHM 215..
descrip: At the center of this course is the recognition of Gibbs Free Energy as a fundamental quantity describing physical processes. From this, we will develop concepts of thermodynamics and kinetics, and illustrate them with examples from chemistry.

title: Solid-State Physics II
prereqs: ELE 441 or PHY 405 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Electronic structure of solids. Electron dynamics and transport. Semiconductors and impurity states. Surfaces. Dielectric properties of insulators. Electron-electron, electron-phonon, and phonon-phonon interactions. Anharmonic effects in crystals. Magnetism. Superconductivity.

title: Studies in the Religions of the Americas - Twentieth-Century American Religious History
descrip: This course provides a broad introduction to major themes in and recent literature exploring the history of American religions in the twentieth century.

title: Climate Change, Adaptation and Urban Design
reviews: Take it if you want to hear stories about Guy's incredible career.
descrip: Climate change adaptation is a pressing and difficult challenge to urban design, ecological and engineering planning theory and practice. It is clear that architects, planners, engineers and designers have an important role to help cities contend with climate adaptation. This seminar reviews the general state of science and practice of climate change and adaptation with a primary focus on the United States. It looks to the work of Frederick Law Olmsted for some of the theoretical basis of developing an approach to climate adaptation that is democratic and progressive and evaluate the impediments which restrict change.

title: European Intellectual History
reviews: Class discussions may lack focus, but Prof. Rabinbach's insights and the readings are excellent.
If you are interested in intellectual history, take this course.
Read the syllabus first.

This course is great if you are good at working independently and if you are interested in perhaps writing a longer research paper. The readings each week are not super extensive so there is plenty of time of research on the side.
descrip: This seminar will discuss methodological and historiographical issues in intellectual history with a specific focus on "conceptual history" (Begriffsgeschichte). Among the figures we will consider are Reinhart Koselleck, Carl Schmitt, Daniel Bell, Hannah Arendt.

title: Special Topics in Environmental Engineering and Water Resources - Interfacial Water in Natural Systems
reviews: I strongly recommend those who are interested in MD simulation, interfacial water, surface science and material science/chemistry in general to consider this course.
N.A.
Need good foundation in physical chemistry and molecular dynamics.
Very interesting class if you are interested in MD simulations and interfaces. Would recommend.
descrip: This course examines and discusses current research on the behavior of interfacial water in natural systems. Topics covered include adsorption at water-solid and water-air interfaces, the thermodynamics of adsorbed water films, interfacial mass transfer, interfacial energy and wetting, colloidal aggregation in saturated and unsaturated soils, surface waters, and the atmosphere. The course focuses particularly on insights gained from the combination of experiments, atomistic simulation, and geochemical models.

title: The Evolution of Russian Poetic Form
descrip: The course serves as an introduction to Russian verse forms and genres. Considerable attention is given to translations into Russian (and conceivably out of Russian) to understand the qualities of Russian poetry that distinguish it from other European verse traditions (English, German, French, Italian). To some extent exemplary texts are chosen in conjunction with students' linguistic competencies and interests.

title: Introduction to Science Fiction
reviews: A great course to take as a fifth class or to PDF. There's not too much work (two short papers throughout semester, midterm, and final) and Prof. Bendixen is very engaging and knowledgable. The readings are classics that I've been wanting to read anyway, so I thought this was a great way to get a more academic approach.
Bendixen is fantastic, he's sort of a toned down Nunokawa. If you like sci-fi and/or need an LA, definitely take! The class is very fair.
Bendixen's great! If you like the class topic, you'll like the course. I learned a lot!

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS.
AMAZING.
One of the best classes I have taken here, as auditors from the community will agree.
Do the readings, you'll get way more out of the course. And go to lecture, since bendixen is a great lecturer
Do the readings.
Do the readings. They are very doable because they are enjoyable. Don't make this class harder than it has to be. You will have fun if you know what you're talking about.
Fantastic course (especially for engineers looking for an easy distributional). Engaging lecturer, fun readings, open-ended and flexible assignments.
Fun class, great readings, pretty chill grading.

Good class to PDF. Not bad to take for a grade if you're not amazing at essays. If you go to lecture and just write 3 essays, 2 short stories and 1 more or less throwaway essay you can probably get a solid grade.

Great PDF. Great reading-- I took it to have an excuse to read Watchmen. You can choose to turn in 2-4 papers and you can choose when to turn them in. One of them can also be a short story. Fantastic readings  and not too much work. Get to know Bendixen also, he's very smart and well-read.
Great class, excellent lectures! I found it hard to keep up with a novel a week, especially when we got to the thicker ones, but if you PDF, this is a great LA!
Great course - interesting lectures and readings, flexible paper prompts and due dates, and no dean's date paper!
Great course for an LA. Readings are really interesting and the lectures and precepts are a lot of fun to learn more about science fiction.
Great course with a great trio of instructors, reading lists, and assignments, which is rare. Great LA.
Great readings, lectures can get boring but they are not the worst. Professor Bendixen is very nice and enthusiastic about the topic.
I would recommend keeping up with the reading. I got behind working on my thesis in the second half of the semester and had to read a ton of books before the final.
I would recommend taking it, this was a pretty good class.
I would recommend this class if you're interested in science fiction.
I would strongly suggest taking this course if you have even the slightest interest in science fiction. Not only are the readings excellent, but the analysis is equally good.

If science fiction or the books on the reading list appeal to you, take it. I used this course's readings to procrastinate on my other classes' work, and I really enjoyed the class. Bendixen's lectures and jokes can get repetitive towards the end, but he's a good lecturer.

If you are interested in reading more science fiction, or gaining more perspective on science fiction you've previously read, this is an excellent class to take. Workload is fair, readings are very enjoyable, and lectures are reasonably interesting.
If you have any interest in sci-fi, take it! Just make sure to not procrastinate on the papers.
If you're interested in Science Fiction, take this course. It's not necessarily an 'easy' A, but it's definitely an easy P if you do all the readings
Interesting and fairly fun class. Great PDF.
It's a good class to take, the workload is not that bad and novels are assigned over the weekend, which is really nice. Professor is great and engaging.

Lots of fun, little effort - I gained a lot from this class without having to stress about it. Awesome reading list. Bendixen's lectures can wander sometimes, but as long as you pay attention to the parts of the books he emphasizes, you'll ace the exams.
Make sure to do all of the readings. They are really enjoyable and normally fairly light reading. Turn in essays early.
Not too much reading and very manageable work load for an English class. Take if you have interest in science fiction!

Probably my favorite course so far at Princeton. Prof. Bendixen is such an interesting lecturer and really makes you read science fiction (and literature in general) in ways you never thought of before. And the readings are excellent, you won't want to do the rest of your work because the readings are so engaging and overall a lot of fun.
Reading list is fun
Stay on top of the readings. Get the books from the library earlyish if you don't wanna buy them, better than reading online copies.

Students who are taking this course should make sure to attend all lectures, as these will provide the main discussion points of precept. If one does the readings, attends precept, and attends lectures, it is not difficult to do well in the course. In fact, I think that I would have liked to attend the lectures and the precepts even if they were not required because they were quite interesting.

TAKE IT! Professor Bendixen is an interesting lecturer and the topic and readings themselves are way more interesting than a lot of other english classes out there. Also, the grading for the class is definitely fair and forgiving as the exams are definitely reasonable if you pay attention in class, which you should definitely do because it is just interesting in general!
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! Although I had never read many science fictions coming into the course, I really liked it. Professor Bendixen's lectures are phenomenal and are very interesting!
Take it if you like sci fi and don't mind quite a bit of reading every week (you actually do have to do the reading by the time you take the exam). Professor was great!
Take it out of interest in the subject matter. Lots of fun, not too heavy of a work load

Take it! This class was both very interesting and fairly laid back. You may not like every book discussed, but you are guaranteed to thoroughly enjoy at least a couple of them. I found the novels all very interesting and the lectures very enjoyable.
Take it!! Prof. Bendixen is a really interesting lecturer, not too difficult of a course, and the preceptors are great. Very good readings too
Take it.

Take it. It's a great class and will open your mind to things you have never seen or thought before. If you like Sci-Fi already, this will change the way you read it for the better and will only make you like it more. If you don't like Sci-Fi, it will certainly show you the merits of the genre.
Take this class
Take this class if you like Sci-Fi. you will probably have read most of the books. Lectures are funny but also insightful. Just take it
Take this class!
Take this class! Definitely one of the funnest class I've taken at Princeton.
Take this class! Very fun, good lectures...or, at least, entertaining ones. Not very hard, but very rewarding.

Take this course! It's a great way to fulfill the LA requirement and is a really interesting class even if you don't need to do so. Keep up with the readings, the midterm and final are primarily identifying quotes from each text.

Take this if you want to do all the reading. As long as you do all the reading, even if you don't go to lecture, you will have no trouble with the assignments/exams. If you like the reading list and need an LA, definitely take this class.
Take this!!!! So fun and not hard at all as long as you do the reading (which is all really fun)... You get to read the hunger games for homework!

The readings for this class are really fun, so think of reading them as study breaks and keep up with them throughout the semester. Also, if there's still the "short story" paper option, I'd really suggest giving it a shot; it's fun to do more creative writing for a change of pace (also tends to be graded more forgivingly).
The readings for this course were entertaining and interesting, and Professor Bendixen does a great job of identifying the main themes and meaning. Relatively light course load.
This is a really fun class and the reading is great.
Unparalleled. May be my favorite class I have taken thus far
Very fun class I wouldnt hesitate to reccomend
Worth taking if you're interested in the reading list.
Yay. But be weary if you want more diversity.
You'll do well in this course if you do the readings and attend the lectures. If you don't at least read, there's not really a point to being in the course.
great class
read the books, they are fun
descrip: An exploration of the ideas, issues, and aesthetic values that mark the development of science fiction from the 18th century to the present, with particular attention to the ways specific texts confront the philosophical questions underlying scientific inquiry and invention, travel in time and space, the creation of life, robots and robotics. The ways in which this genre reframes the basic question of what it means to be human will be the foundation of our analysis of contemporary short stories and representative novels.

title: Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: AM Homes is laidback and funny and classes with her were always a blast. It really wasn't much work, but she was available for those students who really wanted to get a lot out of it. This course is what you make of it, but there's something for everyone!
DEFINITELY take CWR with AM Homes! She's chill, sarcastic, funny, and very smart.

Darcey is a really understanding professor. If you want a chill new-to-creative-writing course, take it with her. If you've had creative writing in the past and want something more intensive maybe look elsewhere.

Definitely consider taking this course. It is a good amount of work but is quite fun and rewarding. It's also really cool to see not just what you end up writing but what others end up writing as well.

Definitely take intro to short fiction if you want a chill class with a small group of students that will be both fun and informative. Definitely opened my eyes to the technical and craft considerations that go into good creative writing.
Definitely take it! The assignments are fun and the class workshop sessions are very helpful.
Don't procrastinate on the papers.
Don't write at the last minute, because there's no point getting your mediocre work showed to and critiqued by the class.
Fiona Maazel is a wonderful professor who has a lot to teach you, and I definitely gained a lot from this class! Take it with her :)
Fiona is cool and a good teacher. Take creative writing!

Fiona is very particular. Very "by her book". Her teaching style can be stifling. When analyzing readings, she frames everything so that there is a correct answer, which is her answer. She got better (less like this) as the semester progressed. Her critiques on full stories were good, but the exercises sometimes felt pointless because she would not read them and give feedback, or we would not all be able to share during class time. Overall, I really like how the class was structured in terms of each week being themed (openings, endings, line editing, etc.) I learned a lot lot. If Fiona were more friendly/open/less rigid/different, the class would be A1
For sure take it if you love to write.
Fun class. Low work. Sigrid Nunez is great!
Good class if you truly like creative writing.
Great class to take to learn a new perspective - even if you're an engineer.

I absolutely loved Professor Homes' class. Everyone participates since she always goes around the table to ask about people's responses to each reading/workshop paper, but I feel like she would let us pass as well if we wanted to. I'd also imagine that creative writing also largely depends on your classmates, and I happened to be with a batch of students that seemed actually interested in creative writing rather than simply BSing it as a PDF class. We started out by doing some shorter writings in class and readings for homework, and Prof Homes eased us into short stories for homework after we'd done a little in-class writing. It made me feel a let more confident about my writing when my first long workshop story was due after I'd had some practice before--I think most of my friends in different creative writing classes had their first workshop stories due much before the first of our classes'. Prof Homes is also just a really interesting and chill person, and she's very receptive about possible changes and student opinions.

I definitely think you should take a CWR class before graduating. It's such an awesome change of pace, and the P/D/F makes sure its not too demanding. Writing short stories can be very time consuming, and you write a lot of them, but it's such a fun break from the other kind of work classes usually have you do. Also A.M. is amazing. She's really kind, REALLY experienced, really awesome, and really helpful. Definitely recommend her class.
I highly recommend taking this course! If you have the chance, think about what you would want to write for your stories in order to avoid writing a 10-20 page story the night before it's due.
I like CWR, which is why I'll still recommend even despite one bad experience. Just find a good teacher?ask around?read the reviews. Hanna's a wonderful person but her class is a bit . . . lacking.
I think a class with White is better for people pursuing creative writing over several classes than those with just a general interest/taking it for an LA.
I would highly recommend both creative writing and taking with Darcey because it was a great course and introduction to creative writing.
If you are at all interested in writing fiction, I'd highly recommend this course! Not only was it a lot of fun, but I feel like my writing skills also improved over the course of the semester.
If you have ever thought about writing or ever wanted to try, take the course. It's extremely open and dynamic, letting you try out whatever you want.

If you're at all interested in Fiction, be it reading or writing, take the course! You can't go wrong - it can be very little work if it doesn't thrill you, but for me it made me read and write completely differently.
It took me a little while to warm up to her, but Fiona is great if you want a more structured class with more concrete writing lessons
It's a great class to take and will help you as a writer if you take it seriously and put in the effort. What you put in is what you get out for sure!
It's a great pdf only class if you have a hard semester.

One of the best classes at Princeton! Professor Homes is truly extraordinary, and you'll see your writing improve so much while enjoying a laid back and encouraging atmosphere. It's just a lot of fun!
Participate in the discussion and don't be afraid to step out of your comfort zone!
Please only take this if you want to become a better writer--there are already too many people taking it for an "easy" LA, and they usually make the classes miserable.
Professor Nunez is great! The workload is low, but the class is very rewarding.
Really put effort into creative writing because you will improve as a writer and you'll have fun doing it!
Relatively light work load and lots of fun.

TAKE THIS CLASS. Darcey is absolutely amazing and interesting. She has so many funny and sincere suggestions to improve your writing. She also exposes you to many different styles and modes through the readings so she really does give you tools to craft beautiful prose. The workshops were very helpful (this is coming from someone who loves horror/sci fi/fantasy, while Darcey writes very different stuff).

Take a Creative Writing Course!!! They are very fun and worthwhile. Sigrid made every class interesting and was very helpful in her comments. One thing I would think about is that her classes are strutted differently than most. You have two large stories instead of small ones leading up to a large one. It was fun to be able to write a 10-20 page piece of fiction, but I didn't feel that my writing improved as much as it could have. I think she'd be a great teacher for a second CWR course, but a bit challenging for someones first experience with fiction.
Take a creative writing class! It's great.
Take it
Take it if you like writing
Take it, it's easy, fun, and teaches you how to do creative writing the right way.
Take it...why not?
Take the class. Why not? It's fun.
Take the stories seriously and try your best to write something you would want to read. Criticism is hard to take but its ultimately very helpful!!!
Take this class, and take it with AM Homes.
Take this course if you're genuinely interested in creative writing! Don't take it if you want an easy PDF, because it's a waste of everyone's time.
Take this course.

The class is a little less structured than other CWR classes, but Prof. White is a really lovely person with some very interesting stories to tell.  His critiques are helpful without being harsh, which I appreciated.
The course is a nice introduction to fiction writing. You really learn a lot about how to improve your writing style and I definitely recommend it to anyone interested in creative writing.

This class was incredible! Professor White is funny and very encouraging, and I learned so much. The class was fun and engaging, and I was always looking forward to it. My skills as a writer have improved vastly.
This course is highly enjoyable but may not hugely benefit your writing, especially if you already have a strong sense of your identity as a writer.
This course was really fun in that you could write about whatever without the pressure of a grade. You should definitely take a CWR class at Princeton!
This is a great class that is chill but also full of lots of fun reading and writing. It is very much a class where you will get out what you put in. Professor Steinke is great!

This was one of my favorite courses in my four years at Princeton, and I wish I had taken it earlier. I highly recommend this course for students of all backgrounds. It's fun to write stories and read those of your classmates, and it's a nice change of pace from other courses.
Very good and engaging course. Light workload, PDF only, also a good class to explore or further an interest in fictional writing. White is very chill.
Very good! Although more tedious work than might be expected, but in general pretty low-key.
must take
prereqs: Interested students complete an application (arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app) and include a writing sample of 3-4 pages of fiction. No prerequisites. Application deadline is November 22, 2015..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: German Stylistics
reviews: Great course and a lot of fun!
I don't know if this class will be offered again, but if you speak German you should definitely take a course with Professor Vogl the next time he comes back to Princeton.

If you are a German major, or interested at all in German Lit/Philosophy, you MUST take a course with Prof Vogl when he is here every third year.  He is brillant, and a funny, interesting person as well.
Professor Vogl is incredible and I would recommend any class with him.
Take it! Professor Vogl is amazing!
take it
descrip: The beginning of a story or a novel marks a delicate threshold. It signifies both the entrance into a fictitious world and the advent of a new order. Narrative openings not only determine a story's further course and continuation, they also offer fundamental insights into the logic of narration as such. In order to address all of these questions properly, a selection of canonical works of German and European literature will be the basis of discussion.

title: Theories and Methods in the Study of Religion
reviews: Good course for religion and non-religion majors alike to understand how to study religion

I would definitely take this course, however there is a lot of reading which is sometimes quite dense.  It isn't an easy class but it is very interesting and thought provoking.  Dr. Carlson is also fantastic and is very willing to meet with you which is also incredibly helpful.
It's a good P/D/F class
Take if you're a REL major. If you want a general overview of the study of religion, go for it. If you want to learn about more interesting religious studies, there's other classes to take.
The readings are often somewhat long and dense. However, doing the readings wasn't particularly relevant to the class.
This class was okay. Lectures were kind of boring and I don't think I walked away with very much.
This is a great course to take. Professor Carlson was a great lecturer and all the readings were very interesting.

Took this class because the other evaluations said that you got to watch movies and it was interesting but I guess the university caught on and made it much more difficult. A lot of dense readings, don't take unless you are a senior in the Religion department.
You don't have to do the readings every time but you should or you get that awkward silence in lecture where nobody knows the answer. Talk to her about your papers and go to office hours.
prereqs: Required for Religion Department majors..
descrip: This course explores major theories and methods in the study of religion, starting with Enlightenment thinkers (Spinoza, Hume), before turning to the rise of social sciences in the study of religion (Durkheim, Weber), and ending with contemporary topics in the study of religion. Topics to be explored include rationality and religion; secularism; the effects of colonialism on the study of religion; gender and sexuality; religion and psychology; the conflict between freedom of religion and the state.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Program and Policy Evaluation
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.

title: The Evolution of Human Language
descrip: See website

title: Genes, Brain, and the Human Mind
reviews: Always do the readings before hand and try to say something in class always.

If you're STEM looking for an SA, please just take a real SOC class
If you're expecting some kind of genetic or biological explanation for complex behaviors and social issues, you won't find it here. What little you do learn can be learned properly from a regular genetics class in a fraction of the time. Since this is an SA course, the professor attempts to speak on current issues in society, but obviously lacks familiarity. He unconvincingly attempts to link genetics to society as an afterthought and often leaves one wondering what was the point of this class. There are many better classes with better professors who won't come across as rude or annoying.

If you've never taken a MOL class, this class may be a bit challenging for you. There are also a lot of readings, so if you're going to take this class, do so during a litter semester. This class requires a high level of commitment.
It is imperative that you are familiar with statistics.

It's a great class if you want to be exposed to a wide variety of topics linking genetics, the environment, and neuroscience! However, be warned that it's not your typical survey class because there's also a lot of material and how much you get out of it really depends on how much you put in.
Strong understanding of neuroscience really necessary to engage in class discussion.
Take the course if you are interested, but be prepared to be active during discussions. Taught me a lot about genetics.
Take this class if you can!

The course material is incredibly interesting, but the teaching style and structure was less than ideal. Expect harsh grading, ridiculously stringent attendance policies, and confusing presentation of topics.
This is a fairly relaxed course until the week of your presentation. I wouldn't recommend this course unless it is really necessary.
read the papers, including the optional ones and supplementary information. talk during class
descrip: How did the human brain become the most complex organ in the animal kingdom? How do genetic and environmental forces produce its capabilities and maladies? These questions have fascinated philosophers, humanists, physicians, and scientists for millennia and will be the focus of this course. The course will use human genetics and systems neuroscience to analyze topics including autism, Alzheimer disease, bipolar disorder and drug addiction. Class time will emphasize lectures, discussion, and student-generated presentations. The goal is to reach a modern understanding of how the human brain works and sometimes fails.

title: Bilingualism
reviews: A great multi-disciplinary EC. Professor Fellbaum is wonderful.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take this if you're interested in bilingualism. Helps if you're bilingual and you'll learn a lot.

I definitely recommend taking this course. Professor Fellbaum is very knowledgeable about the topic and undoubtedly provides great expertise and insights. The readings are all very interesting and I think they cover the basics of what you should know in the field. Make sure you keep up with the readings though and write your bi-weekly responses. Would definitely recommend!

It's a really fun course, and Prof. Fellbaum is an excellent guide through all the studies. This was my first linguistics course at Princeton, and I was really surprised by how scientific the approaches were (I'm a STEM major).
It's pretty easy and professor Fellbaum is a great lecturer.

Professor Fellbaum is great! Having to submit comments on the readings before each class ensured that I actually did the readings, which greatly improved what I got out of the course. A great class to take for anyone that is interested in bilingualism!
Really interesting and chill class that I highly recommend you take if Fellbaum is teaching!

TAKE THIS CLASS! You will not regret this decision. Fellbaum is one of the sweetest, kindest professors to walk this campus and she really tries to get to know you and help you through areas you're confused about. As someone who didn't have a background in LIN and taking this as my first linguistics course, I was a little concerned but Fellbaum put all that to rest by going through the material very carefully. The papers and reviews were all very open ended so I was able to explore my interests in much greater detail than I would have thought. Bilingualism is the best!

Take it! Professor Fellbaum is excellent, the workload is very reasonable, and the topic is super interesting no matter your language background. It helps to have taken LIN 201 or any kind of neuro class beforehand, but you definitely don't need any background to enjoy (and do well) in this course.

Take the class! The workload is optimum (on the lesser side) and 3 papers in total is the best deal one can get for a 300 level LA distribution course. Besides, if you are a bilingual you get to learn a lot from this course about your own linguistic abilities and about research that is ongoing in the field from a neurological and psychological perspective.

Take this class if you can! You don't have to be bilingual; it's really interesting to hear personal accounts and thoughts from the bilingual students. If you are bilingual, there will definitely be at least one time when you can really relate to the class discussion.
Take this class if you like linguistics or if you're a bilingual yourself! You learn a lot with very little stress and work.
The course isn't only for bilinguals! The content we covered is enlightening for monolinguals as well.

This course is an excellent and engaging survey of many topics in linguistics. I had never taken any linguistics courses before but absolutely loved this course. Prof Fellbaum is a super engaging lecturer. The work load isn't too much and as long as you do the reading and speak in class getting an A won't be too hard. TAKE THIS CLASS!
This course is very enjoyable, especially if you have an interest in bilingualism. Prof Fellbaum is a really great and encouraging professor to take a class with.
descrip: The course covers the linguistic, psycholinguistic, neurolinguistic, and sociolinguistic aspects of bilingualism. We examine language acquisition in monolingual and bilingual children, the notion of "critical age" for language acquisition, definitions and measurements of bilingualism, and the verbal behavior of bilinguals such as code-switching. We consider the effects of bilingualism on other cognitive domains, including memory, and examine neurolinguistic evidence comparing the brains of monolinguals and bilinguals. Societal and governmental attitudes toward bilingualism in countries like India and the U.S. are contrasted.

title: Behavioral Economics Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics

title: Princeton Atelier - Art, Ecology, And Community: A Lake Carnegie Pageant
prereqs: Students with an interest in environmental studies are encouraged to apply. We are also seeking to build a team of visual and performing artists - musicians, dancers, playwrights and actors, a cappella groups, drumming groups - who are looking for a new artistic challenge. Students with interests and backgrounds in theatrical production and management are encouraged to apply. The course offers community outreach opportunities. A brief application is required and can be found at arts.princeton.edu/atelier. Application deadline is Friday, December 4..
descrip: Students will study the cultural traditions of processions and theatrical pageants in the context of ecological art. Theatrical pageant director Felicia Young and environmental visual artist Michele Brody will collaborate with students across science and art backgrounds in the production of a theatrical pageant highlighting environmental issues relating to Lake Carnegie. Environmental researchers from the Millstone Watershed Association will introduce students to the Lake's ecosystem. Students will collaborate on performance and visual art works inspired by their research into one of Princeton's environmental landmarks.

title: Varieties of Spanish
reviews: Great class, would recommend it to anyone interested in learning about the social and historical context of language or Spanish-speaking countries in general! Dunia is an incredible and very laid-back professor, and you will learn a lot without having the out of class work consume for than 2-3 hours of your time per week.
I do not necessarily recommend.
If you like Spanish and want to learn about different dialects/the cultural and linguistic side of the language I would recommend taking it. There are a lot of assignments,
It's a lot of time for one course, so if you're only taking the course out of interest, then pick something else. However, if you are pursuing a certificate or concentrating, this is a great class.
Take it! Professor Vallejo is great. She's relaxed but helpful, and you'll learn a lot. The semester-long project seems daunting but since it's broken up into steps it's not too bad.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course. Students who have fulfilled their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score can take the course only with instructor's permission..
descrip: Offered as an overview of sociolinguistic variation in the Spanish-speaking world, students will learn about social, political, and cultural aspects related to dialectal variation in Spanish and become acquainted with important linguistic features present in various dialects. Upon completion of the course, students become familiarized with particular features distinguishing one dialect from another, while gaining knowledge of the development of these differences. This course will greatly enrich a student's view of Spanish, either as a native/heritage speaker or Spanish learner, and allows for the development of analytical skills.

title: Neurogenetics and Evolution of Behavior
reviews: Course has daily assignments but overall it is not very much work and you learn a lot about a really interesting topic!!
Great class. If you have little neuro background do not sweat it too much. Not too much reading and very manageable.
Great preparation for the Spring JP in the EEB/MOL departments-- practice reading papers and thinking about future directions for research.

Take it! It's not too difficult of a class, and you'll learn a lot about reading scientific papers, which is Prof. McBride's goal. You might need to spend some extra time at the beginning reading if you're not used to it, but it gets much easier. It's an interesting class with a great professor.
Take it! You will learn a lot about evolution of behavior in a wide range of animals and strongly improve your skills in scientific writing and proposing a research project.
Take this course if you need a departmental. It is really interesting and laid back. Professor McBride is really cool.
Very helpful to have a strong neuroscience background but not totally necessary. Great professor, great class.
prereqs: This course is designed for juniors and seniors in EEB, neuroscience, and possibly molecular biology. Introductory Biology (MOL 214 or 215) is a prerequisite. Students should also have take either EEB 211 (Intro to Ecology and Evolution) or NEU 201 (Intro to Neuroscience). MOL 342 (Genetics) is recommended. Exceptions may be made by permission of the instructor..
descrip: How do genes and neural circuits encode behavior? How have genes and circuits evolved to generate the incredible diversity of behaviors we see across the animal kingdom? This course will explore these questions with an emphasis on recent advances in the primary literature. Each class will focus on a specific behavior with a lecture introducing what is known about its genetic and neural basis followed by a discussion of a paper that builds on that knowledge to ask how the behavior evolves. A major goal of the class will be to learn how to critique contemporary research and generate new testable hypotheses based on previous results.

title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities
descrip: What is the world? What does it mean to make, unmake, and remake a world? This course on Cosmopoiesis seeks to answer these questions in its study of early forms of premodern worldmaking in Greco-Roman natural philosophy and their afterlives in medieval, early modern, and modern philosophy. In this course we will imagine the cosmos at every possible scale, from the infinitesimally small to the infinitely large, and reflect on the ethical stakes of such a practice. We will also attend to the problems of mereology, teleology, dialectics, and figuration, and seek to rethink the philosophical and historical grounds of "theory".

title: Transformations in Engineering and the Arts
reviews: An incredible experience-- take it if you can!
I would recommend this course! You get to play with a lot of different things. Professors and awesome TAs always willing to help.
If you have a chance to take this class, I highly recommend it. I know it's a big time commitment, but it's definitely worth it.
Take it! Unlike any other course I've taken at Princeton. The professors are all awesome and supportive and the project is a great creative opportunity.
Take it, but come in with some ideas and an open mind! It's basically a maker space, with highly qualified lab assistants and an arsenal of impressive professors.
Take this class! One of the best experiences I've had at Princeton

Take this! One of the best class experiences I've had here. Everybody involved is great in class and to talk to in general and really excited to be there. All the students in it were super cool. Also, of course, it's a great chance to explore interdisciplinary creative stuff, between all of the exercises and the half-semester final project.
There is no other class like this. They basically give you access to a bunch of super expensive equipment and let you create anything you can imagine.
take it!
prereqs: By application only; no prerequisites.
descrip: This course will explore the parallels and intersections of design/composition in engineering and the arts, emphasizing a merging of artistry and systematic thinking. Students will use what they learn to create as engineer-artists and artist-engineers. The course will be organized around four modules: A) Visuals, B) Sound, C) Structure and 4) Movement, led by faculty from COS, MUS, CEE, MAE with faculty from the Lewis Center for the Arts. 'Transformations' will unify the modules by engaging the different disciplines and allowing the course to serve as an introductory experience for students with diverse academic backgrounds.

title: Luso-Brazilian Seminar - Cities and Nature
reviews: Fascinating mix of urbanism, anthropology, and poetry in a Brazilian setting.
It can be a bit tough, but worth your time if willing to work.
The reading is manageable, but be sure to do it and to read carefully. The texts are not incredibly long but can be dense, and it can take a while to form connections and for ideas to sink in.
descrip: Brazilian society has become one of the most urbanized in the world. At the same time, many of the more widely circulating images of the country pertain to natural landscapes. In this course we study how ideas of city and nature have been constructed in opposition and complementarity, focusing on the 18th and 19th centuries. Emphasis is placed on Lusophone engagement with "non-western" epistemologies, urbanization, and "the production of nature." Topics to include transatlantic circulation of knowledge; slavery and the natural sciences; city planning and race; literature, visual arts, and spatial imaginaries.

title: Multilevel Models (Half-Term)
reviews: I would highly recommend this course. It introduces you to multilevel methods at a much deeper level than you would get in an introductory stats class and gives you a new tool for your research. The final project is the most valuable part of the course as it gives you an opportunity to try out the methods yourself.

This course provides a nice overview of multilevel models that builds intuition and also teaches you computational tools for estimating the models, as well as warning about pitfalls people often fall in.
prereqs: POP 507/WWS 509 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to statistical methods for the analysis of multilevel data, such as data on children, families, and neighborhoods. Reviews fixed- and random-effects models for clustered and longitudinal data. Presents multilevel random-intercept and random-slopes models, discussing model fitting and interpretation, centering and estimation of cross-level interactions, and extensions to binary and count data using maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods. Course emphasizes practical applications using the multilevel package MLwiN. Half-term course, offered second half of spring term.

title: Health and Human Rights
reviews: Amazing class!! Amon is incredible. Only, the final paper was ridiculously long -- it ended up being the length of a JP.
Do all the readings and be sure to ask questions because there is a lot you can learn from Prof. Amon!
Interesting course. Made me understand what I meant when I called things "human rights violations."
Make sure you've taken some other GHP courses first.
Meet with Professor Amon before papers are due to help guide you through the best possible approaches.
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Very interesting and great course to take.
descrip: This seminar is an introduction to the discipline of health and human rights, with an emphasis on how human rights abuses are investigated and how advocacy is conducted. The seminar will use case studies and discuss current debates around a "human rights approach" to health and the methods and ethics of health-related human rights research. Specific topics will include: HIV/TB, environmental health, maternal mortality and LGBT rights. Students will also choose their own topic to research related to health and human rights.

title: The Economics of Health Policy in Developing Countries
descrip: Early death is arguably the worst manifestation of poverty in developing countries. Much of this premature death, and the low quality of life that goes with it, is avoidable with well conceived and executed public policy. Setting priorities for what government (and well-meaning outsiders) should do with very limited means requires hard choices-matters of life and death. The choices are limited both by the severe resource constraints in poor countries and constraints of and constraints of effective implementation of programs. This course focuses on how economic reasoning can help inform effective policy.

title: The Literature and Culture of Spain and Colonial Latin America: Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course..
descrip: A study of the formation of a literary tradition in Spain through the close reading of selected texts in several genres from both Spain and colonial Latin America.

title: Policy Seminars
prereqs: Assignment to these seminars is by a separate application process through the department. Enrollment is limited to WWS majors. The course is required for majors, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. WWS juniors are automatically signed up for the policy seminar as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 402. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy seminars students work in groups first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.

title: Political Bodies: The Social Anatomy of Power & Difference
reviews: Absolutely don't hesitate to take this class. The readings are incredible, the discussions are fascinating, and Professor Benjamin is one of the most interesting and relevant professors I've had at Princeton. Honestly, take the class just to hear her talk & change your perspective on life.
Assessment
Definitely go to the writing center or have your written work reviewed by other students. They may catch grammatical errors or other content issues that maybe you didn't.

I could not recommend this class enough. YOU MUST TAKE IT! Professor Benjamin is the best professor you will ever have at this university. You get out of the class what you put in- so put in your all.
Take it!
The course provides an interesting perspective on thinking about the body, medicine and science so I would recommend it to any student no matter their area of interest or concentration.

This class radically expanded the way I think about social issues and the way we talk and think about the physical body. Professor Benjamin creates a class environment that is open and lively; it taught me a lot in ways that went beyond the purely academic.

This course has high expectations. It is challenging, but can be extremely worth it. Professor Benjamin collects very interesting material for her courses, and the end result is a very provocative, thoughtful, and nuanced discussion.

This is the best course I have taken at Princeton! Take it! Even if you don't have that much experience with sociology or African American studies, you'll really enjoy this course. The readings are very interesting, and the writing assignments are manageable. Professor Benjamin is also an extraordinary instructor.  I learned a lot from her. 

My advice: don't fall behind with the readings and weekly memos. Obviously start the papers sooner than later. And go to Professor Benjamin's office hours (she's very helpful).
descrip: In this seminar students will learn about the human body in its social, cultural, and political contexts. The framing is sociological rather than biomedical, attentive to cultural meanings, institutional practices, politics, and social problems. The course explicitly discusses bodies in relation to race, class, gender, sexuality, ability, age, health, geography, and citizenship status, carefully examining how social differences come to appear natural. From clinics to prisons to borders to virtual realities, students develop a conceptual toolkit to analyze how society "gets under the skin", producing differential exposure to premature death.

title: Introduction to Medieval Latin
reviews: Do the readings and pay attention in class. I didn't and just ended up lost.

I believe another professor will be teaching the course after this semester, so I don't know how relevant my recommendation is. That said, this is a really cool class that offers a new perspective on Latin.
I highly recommend this course if you have an interest in Medieval Latin. Plus, a real Medieval Latinist is coming to teach it next time.
It's a straight forward Latin course that shows a different facet of Latin.

Over all, an excellent course which I can say that I am very very glad that I took. I learned a lot about Medieval Latin and history thanks to it. Expect to spend 1 to 2 hours on the reading outside of class.

Pretty dry material. I thought it would be more interesting than it turned out to be. One of my favorite things about studying Latin is how we weave it into the historical stories of that time, and I realized I didn't like Medieval Latin because the connection to the history of that time was not as strong.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
Very fun, especially if you've done a lot of classical latin and are looking for something a little different. Would highly recommend!
prereqs: LAT 108 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Selections from Medieval Latin prose and poetry, with emphasis on Late Antiquity and the early Middle Ages. Attention to developments in Latin in the period, as well as to the transmission and reception of the literature and values of Classical Antiquity.

title: Topics in Modern Astronomy
reviews: Engineering and science majors comfortable with calculus should take this as an easy class for senior year or a rough semester.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to get a really great overview of how stars/planets/the universe works, while also applying math/physics. As a premed, non-physics major who took this class to fulfill the premed physics req, I definitely felt a little out of my depth at times because my physics was a rusty. However, Prof. Ostriker is always willing to take questions and clarify concepts, which is really helpful. Lectures can be a bit dry when they're very equation-heavy, but just focus on understanding the big ideas that motivate the math. 

For psets, use the textbook to find the equations that you need. For exams, just focus on the lecture slides, they show you the concepts that you need to know. Don't be overwhelmed by the equations/derivations, the focus of the exams is on conceptual understandings and applying the laws of physics to bodies in the universe.

If you are an astro major or thinking of being an astro major, this class is heavily recommended, and for good reason - it's good to have exposure to the content before delving into higher-level astro classes, even if the course isn't technically required. I find that material tends to stick better in the brain if one has seen it multiple times, each subsequent time in greater depth. The content is quite interesting (though I may be biased since I am an astro major). If you've experienced the wonder of PHY 106 or ISC, then you may be disappointed by the way the content is presented, which is rather unimpressive. I guess it's taught rather like a PHY 103/104 class.
It's very interesting but tough. If you're up for the challenge, it's worth taking.
Take 205 if you can, this is good if you like math with your info
This course is an interesting introduction to astro materials, but if you have a strong physics/ math background there's no reason to take it.
This is one of the few math and physics classes where doing the problems sets and going to lecture actually does sufficiently prepare you for the exams.
Unless you have a strong interest in Astrophysics (i.e. are considering majoring) then this course probably won't be worthwhile.
give yourself a couple days to work through the problem sets
prereqs: PHY 103 or 105 and MAT 103 or 104 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course provides a broad overview of modern astronomy and astrophysics for students in the sciences. Emphasis is on the application of basic physics to understanding of astronomical systems. Topics include the Solar System; planetary systems and exoplanets; the birth, life, and death of stars; white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes; the Milky Way and distant galaxies; cosmology, dark matter and dark energy, and the history of the Universe.

title: Topics in Development - African Political Economy
descrip: This course covers new advances in the politics of economic development. We first review key theoretical results from the political economy literature that explain the way political institutions affect development. We then review empirical findings on a wide range of topics such as democratization, elections, and government accountability, the politics of public good provision, and decentralization. It is recommended, but not required that students have taken basic econometrics and introductory microeconomics, and development economics. The materials of the course are recent research papers to be presented by students.

title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives
reviews: Make sure to understand the different greeks and hedging process.
Take it if you want to understand markets better and/or are curious about derivatives. For a finance class, it leans on the more interesting side and isn't as math-heavy as you'd think.
Take it if you're interested in the topic, don't expect anything spectacular.
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The course offers an introduction to financial derivatives and the models used to price them. Pricing techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), as well as extensions to accommodate time-varying volatility and more complex contracts. We also devote great attention to discuss the roles played by derivatives in shaping financial markets and the real economy by using commodity markets as a focal point. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and spreadsheet programming.

title: Art as Interaction
reviews: Be prepared to be self-guiding in your ability to engage with the world creatively.. the material is great but the instruction is a bit more loose. You'll need to be confident in your decisions because you'll have to leave your comfort zone in a very self-directed way

This course could use a lot of restructuring. Overall, I am fairly disappointed in this course. The first two assignments were a great way to get us started engaging in "social practice" and more assignment like them would have been really helpful to get us to experiment and develop our work. Critiques and class discussions were often good. I didn't really enjoy the Pablo Helguera book that made up most of our readings as it often felt really simplistic. When it came to the class collaboration and our final projects, it felt like there were often moments in which Fia had a particular vision in mind that she did not do a good job communicating to us, which often resulted in disappointment and confusion on both ends. However, she was very open to our feedback.
great
prereqs: Any 200-level course offered by ATL, CWR, DAN, MUS, THR, or VIS.
descrip: This class - a kind of "advanced" Art for Everyone - investigates the process of creating objects and performances that explicitly interact with people and spaces around campus. With such diverse roots as sports, mural painting, street fairs, or community activism, art as interaction endeavors to insert itself into specific contexts and directly engages its audience, transforming the very structures of society into art. In what ways can audience participation and collaboration be part of artistic practice? What kind of aesthetic decisions does recording call for? What kind of questions can art pose while still being art?

title: Readings in Classical Japanese
prereqs: JPN 403 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Selections from outstanding works of Classical Japanese prose and verse from Nara to early Showa period, particularly in the genres of history, philosophy, and poetry.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced Italian
reviews: An absolute must if you did 101 in the fall. The workload is very manageable and the 1.5 hours won't feel long at all if you have De Feo (although the other professors in the Italian department are great as well).
Awesome class! Definitely worth taking if you have to fulfill a language requirement or you're like me and just want to have fun learning a new language!

I strongly recommend taking this course, however, you have to be willing to put an hour to an hour and a half in every day.  This class was time consuming but well worth it, and a great trade off for two credits.

I would highly recommend this course to students interested in challenging themselves in improving their speaking and writing skills. The small class allows for a lot of discussion and collaboration and students are very willing to speak to each other and help improve speaking. The professors (Teardo and de Feo) are great professors looking to help students get a tight grasp on Italian language and culture.

If you are planning on going to Macerata or anywhere else in Italy in the summer, take this course.  If not, it might be better to take 102 and 107 because you will likely experience a small drop in your grade from 101 in 1027.
If you loved ITA 101, take this course. The accelerated pace was more suited to my learning speed. The fact that it counts for two courses is a bonus.

If you thoroughly enjoyed ITA 101 and don't mind an increased time commitment, definitely take this class! If you do take it, be sure to do all the readings and watch all the movies. Also expect a significant increase in reading difficulty, as all your Italian skills will be challenged. Getting to finish your language requirement in 2 semesters instead of 3 is definitely worth it though!
TAKE IT! De Feo is an amazing professor who truly cares. Italian is an easy, low workload, good-fifth class course thats super fun

TAKE THIS CLASS! It will be challenging and time consuming, but it is completely worth it. Professor De Feo will work with you to help you reach a 1027 level of Italian. Be prepared to learn more than you thought possible within one semester. Again, TAKE THIS CLASS! YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT!!!
TAKE THIS CLASS.

Take this course! It's no more than half an hour to 45 minutes of work a night, and you'll learn a huge amount of Italian. Classes seem long, but they're really interesting and go by very quickly. Professor De Feo is amazing, and the Italian department is very close knit; I met many of the other professors at the language tables, and my class and I were good friends by the end of the course. Don't hesitate, take it.
Take this if you are willing to put the time and energy into keeping up with the fast pace. It goes quickly, but can be very fulfilling.

This course is great!  Especially if you're interested in pursuing a certificate in Italian.  The readings, artwork, and movies will help you learn a tremendous amount about Italian culture, and the classes will greatly improve your skills with the language.
This was the best course I have taken at Princeton so far. Professor De Feo is a truly phenomenal teacher and an unfailingly kind individual.
be ready to be deeply engaged and have an open mind for cultural immersion
prereqs: Successful performance in ITA 101 and permission of instructor. Interested students should contact instructor at danieled@princeton.edu.
descrip: Italian 102-7 is an intensive double credit course designed to help students develop an active command of the language by improving upon the five skills of speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural competency in the interpretative, interpersonal, and presentational modes. The course emphasizes communication and grammatical structures through use of various forms of texts (literary, artistic, musical, cinematographic, etc..) in order to refine students' literacy.

title: Topics in German Literature - Science & Fiction
descrip: Lunar dreams, machine men, electrified life, human experiments and artificial intelligence -- these topics lead us to the exploration of interactions between literary texts and scientific scenarios. By looking at the appropriation of scientific findings and experiments in literature, questions concerning the combination of literary elements (narrative, fiction, imagination) and scientific practices arise. Historical case studies, running the gamut from the modern era to the 20th century, are accompanied by methodological considerations concerning both the history of science and the relationship between literary and scientific discourses.

title: Advanced Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: Difficult, expect to spend time on problem sets. Requires very different thinking from MAT 203, so don't take it expecting it to be the same.
Do not take. Take either MAT 217 or MAT 202.
Do the readings before the lectures if you can. Do problem sets with other people rather than alone in your room.
Don't fall behind on work! Try as much as possible to figure problem sets out for yourself, but give yourself enough time so you can find help if needed.

Don't just start the problem sets -- make sure you understand the material first. The textbook is awful -- really, really awful -- but there are plenty of resources online to help you. Go to the problem sessions, but only after you've exhausted your own abilities; don't just start there, or you'll understand less.
Great class and definitely easier than MAT203. Take it if you enjoy the challenge. Doable Psets, Hard quizes and exams so study a lot more than you think is enough for exams and quizes
I love this course. Never change Christine Taylor.

I took MAT 204 after have a great time in 203. The first few weeks were okay but then the lectures became really dry. Prof. Taylor is great in office hours/as a mentor. However, I felt like she wasn't a very good lecturer. Sometime's she was just really incoherent and her lectures  didn't flow. She would present facts in an unnecessarily confusing way. I ended up going to < 5% of the lectures. Overall, it was a good class but definitely has a lot of room for improvement.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in a discipline that requires a lot of math.  Compared to 202, the class gives you more of a theoretical grounding so that you actually understand why the math works, rather than just applying formulas.
