For me this class was harder than MAT 203.  Get to class on time because if you are a few minutes late it is hard to catch up.
I would suggest starting the problem sets early in the week. As long as you keep up with the lectures, you should be fine.

If you are coming from MAT 203 and (whether you did well or not) were even somewhat interested in the theory, take this class. If you are not coming from 203 and either have experience with theory or think you might like it, take (or at least shop) this class. Taylor has planned it out extremely well, and it really makes you comfortable with linear algebra, proofs, and theoretical math in general. But beware that the class is a SIGNIFICANT workload. If you take it, it will inevitably become a priority, as it forces you to constantly stay on top of everything. But there will always be help along the way - you can reach out to Taylor at office hours or friends/fellow students at problems sessions pretty easily if you are willing. In fact, the environment is extremely collaborative because of Taylor's availability and the problem sessions. Overall, I highly recommend this class, as long as you have the time to commit to it.

If you fall behind or find your usual study habits are not working, ask for help IMMEDIATELY. Do not waste a single day as one lecture's worth of confusion can destroy you for the rest of the semester. Other than that, this is a good class!

If you have Christine Taylor, take it! She's the best math professor I've had and you will think about mathematics differently after taking this course! Definitely recommended over MAT202 even though it is a more time consuming.

If you took MAT 203 and enjoyed it, or if you'd like to learn clever and thought-provoking ways of understand mathematics, then you should continue with MAT 204! Christine is a great, but very fast lecturer. You may find it useful to actually sit and listen during her lectures instead of trying to jot down every thing she says and writes on the board. Her lecture notes are incredibly beautiful and organized, and they comprise the bulk of what you should know for the course (in addition to precepts and supplementary problems). Be aware that the course is incredibly demanding, but, at the same time, nothing is as rewarding as learning mathematics from Christine Taylor.

Take this course iff you want more MAT203. If you took MAT203, you should be able to judge that for yourself. If you did not, then consider that it is a CONSIDERABLE step UP from MAT201: you should ask to see past MAT203 exams to compare the level of difficulty, and then extrapolate from there to the comparison of MAT202 and MAT204. If you are coming from MAT215, DO NOT EXPECT AN EASIER COURSE THAN MAT217. MAT204 will likely take less time than MAT217, but it is a very challenging course, and will likely be harder for those who are not expecting the structure of the course from prior experience with MAT203.

The proofs on problem sets and tests really aren't bad at all, especially compared to 215/217. Be prepared to work hard, because the exams can be rushed unless you see the computational tricks that you pick up from lecture and precept notes, but absolutely take it over 202 if you have any curiosity about applications.
This class is extraordinarily hard. Don't take it if you have other time consuming classes. You will get a lot out of it, but only if you are prepared to dedicate many hours to the class.

This class takes a fair amount of work but you'll learn a lot about matrix algebra and gain basic proof-writing experience. I'd take this class if you plan on taking 300 level math courses besides mathematics in engineering but otherwise it probably isn't worth the time
This course is more work than 203 (probably an extra 2 hours a week) and is very difficult. Take it if you really want a challenge.

This course strikes a great balance between proof and application, and will give you a strong and useful introduction to linear algebra. Take this instead of 217 (and 202) if you want to feel like you know how to do things.
Very challenging, if you aren't able to grasp the concepts the extra work probably isn't worth it.

Very similar to MAT203. It is more challenging that MAT202, but covers a lot more material. If you are interested, I would surely recommend you go for it. The course is very fast-paced, so make sure to go to lecture and pay close attention. I would also recommend using the lecture notes. Bottom line, if you enjoy math/applied math and want more material/more of a challenge, take this course!
Whatever you do, do not fall behind on coursework. Do the psets in time and read the book before lectures, otherwise it is very hard to understand what is going on in lecture.

Wonderful course, Christine Taylor is an excellent professor. I came in after taking MAT 201, and while the difficulty and length of the problem sets was a bit of a shock (expect 6-8 hours per week), it was a very rewarding and enjoyable experience. Prof. Taylor really understands the material and is invested in helping her students during office hours, although the lectures do move quite fast. Overall would highly recommend this course, particularly for ELE and COS majors who would benefit from the proofs and applications.
Work through her lectures; don't be passive. Pay attention the whole time, and don't be afraid to ask questions or go to office hours.
challenging. lots of work. but it is a great class!
definitely a difficult and time consuming class, but christine taylor is awesome, and from speaking with other students, I think 204 is way better than 202 in terms of teaching and interest.
descrip: Companion course to MAT203. Linear systems of equations, linear independence and dimension, linear transforms, determinants, (real and complex) eigenvectors and eigenvalues, orthogonality, spectral theorem, singular value decomposition, Jordan forms, other topics as time permits. More abstract than MAT202 but more concrete than MAT217. Recommended for prospective physics majors and others with a strong interest in applied mathematics. Prerequisite: MAT104 or MAT215 or equivalent.

title: Narrative Prose in Latin America - Finance and Form
reviews: Highly recommended -- innovative approach to analyzing literature.

Parcel out the reading for some weeks accordingly, as some of the texts are rather long. Take some time to think about the overarching questions of the course on your own, and try to construct a hypothesis that can be proven or disproven; otherwise, it may be easy to get lost in very abstract questions
This course is a good place to think and discuss from different backgrounds. The materials are interesting and accessible. Moreover, Professor Price is a good teacher and well debate conductor
descrip: This course examines the relations between economic systems and aesthetic form, paying special attention to the effects and representations of finance capital in Latin America from the eighteenth through the twenty-first centuries. Focusing on a cluster of questions rather than a historical genealogy, the course asks how economic systems translate into aesthetics and how aesthetic form renders, inverts or mimes such systems. Emphasis on slave-based economies, nineteenth-century finance capital, petroleum economies, and contemporary finance. Readings in literature, art history, and criticism.

title: Court, Cloister, and City: Art and Architecture in Central and Eastern Europe
descrip: Central and Eastern Europe are once again in the news. This class studies the origins of (and differences with) current situations in relation to the culture and history of the region ca. 1450-1800 as revealed through its art and architecture. Austria, Hungary, the Czech and Slovak Republics, Poland, Germany, Ukraine, the Baltic States and Russia, ca. 1450-1800 will be considered in relation to the rest of Europe. Works of art in Princeton's collections will be used. Lectures and discussion, two meetings per week.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
reviews: Be sure to use both lectures and the readings and resources to understand what you are doing in your data analysis programs. This knowledge is critical to rigorous experimental research and it is a great gift to have it efficiently communicated to you via this course!
Definitely recommended as a practical intro to cognitive research
Take this course.
This course is required for neuroscience graduate students. Until the course structure is refined, I would not recommend it to other students.
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501B or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This lab course introduces students to the variety of experimental and computational techniques and concepts used in modern cognitive neuroscience. Topics include functional magnetic resonance imaging, scalp electrophysiological recording, and computational modeling. In-lab lectures provide students with the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs, but the emphasis is on the labs themselves, including student-designed experiments using these techniques. This is the second term of a double-credit core lab course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Quantitative Methods
reviews: A good option to fulfill a stats requirement. Professor Junge is great and a very understanding, helpful and interesting professor. Grading is not arbitrary and is quite fair (and professor Junge does a great job of explaining how the grades are allotted).
DO NOT TAKE THIS WITH JUNGE.

DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS. this is probably the worst class I've ever taken at Princeton. not hard, but confusing lecture slides, poorly taught, dry, and oversimplifies statistics. take a different class if you actually want to learn.
Don't take it unless you have to as a Psych major.
Don't take it, take another stats course. This course doesn't make sense. But he is a fair grader.
Don't take it.
Don't take it. Worst class if I've ever had. New prof who doesn't know what he's doing.
Dont expect it to be easy.
Easy class
Easy stats class, professor is great

Exams were killer (as in not fun at all - made me hate my life), but the material makes sense. A lot of stuff, but without too much detail, so it was a little weird to learn it all. Take it if you need to, I guess.

Frustrating multiple choice tests where you can have a good understanding of material but still get confused by ambiguous wording.  And it's curved weirdly - I got close to average but because the curve was just plus a certain number of percentage points, I still had a B- on the midterm?  But the pro is a very manageable workload in terms of problem sets - none took me more than a couple hours.  Not a big time commitment if you have other time-consuming classes.

Go to every lecture and precept! Professor Junge is one of the nicest and knowledgable professors that you will meet. Exams will be hard, so make sure you stay on top of your work and thoroughly understand each concept!
Go to lecture and read the textbook closely.
Go to precepts, do the readings, try to do extra practice
Good statistics class to take
Great stats class to take
I would say study with others to test each other on the material.
If with justin, he is super chill and a fun guy and will help you succeed, just read the book and be prepared for some weird mentally challenging tests

If you are looking for an intro statistics course I think this is a good one to take because above all it will make you a smarter person. Most people are probably writing pretty negative reviews of this class because it was a little difficult, but if you go to lecture and pay attention and ask questions and really go through the textbook you will learn the basics of statistics for science purposes. Lectures will make you a more knowledgeable person and the professor is a really good and smart person interested in many things.
Justin is great at presenting information in a new, highly visual way. Some concepts are harder than they need to be, especially in the wording of exam questions.
Justin really really tries to make this an engaging course and I think he does a good job with stats material that can sometimes seem dry.
Keep up with the readings, and don't be afraid to ask questions. Work with other students!
Most poorly taught class on campus. Don't take.

Not a bad class to take for a stats requirement. The textbook is available for download for free, which is nice, and it features relevant examples from medicine, psychology, education, economics, etc. I would suggest going to precept even though it's not technically mandatory, and attending lecture as Justin gives examples of questions that might be on the exams.
Not as easy as it was in previous years!

Only take it if you need it as a pre requisite or as a departmental class. If you have a background in statistics you'll probably be fine, if not MAKE A STUDY GROUP, GO TO MCGRAW STUDY HALL HOURS, AND TAKE ADVANTAGE OF ALL THE HELP YOU CAN GET!
Prof. Junge is amazing and this course is very enjoyable overall. Low stress, high effort, and high learning.

Professor Junge really cares about his students, but he also really cares about statistics. He does not want it to be brushed aside, so don't plan on this class being very easy, as it may have been in years past.
Stay on top of the readings - play with data to help you figure out these vague concepts.
Take eco 202
Take it - its easy
Take it if you need a QR or a stats class. Not too time-consuming and well-taught.
Take only if you have to, not easy

Take the textbook readings seriously!!! They give a lot of background that you have to understand to understand lectures. Also work with people and go to McGraw for tutoring!! Reach out to Justin and Tasha too!
The prof's lecture slides were pretty but lectures were kind of useless because there was so little overlap between the lectures and the readings. Precept is actually pretty helpful -- attend it!
This course is a decent course for stats and not to mathematically rigorous.
This course is a large time commitment, so keep that in mind when planning your other courses.
This course was revamped by the new professor so be weary if you want to actually learn stats.

This is a very challenging course (much harder than previous years). So you should stay on top of your psets and reading responses. When preparing for the tests, focus on concepts that were covered in both lecture and the textbook. Looking back at pset problems is also helpful for studying.

This used to be an easy class but in Spring 2016 it definitely was a lot more difficult than expected. Probably still an easy QR but for psych majors you should do the readings and take notes in preparation for the exam and midterm in order to do well. Course is really dry.
This was a good class that provides a working knowledge of the principle of statistics. I would recommend to anyone who has interest in this field.
Try and go to office hours, Junge might be better at explaining things in person. I never got the chance to go.
You get out of it what you put into it.
You need to do a lot of outside learning because the lectures are not extremely helpful.
don't take it if you want to learn statistics
descrip: Science searches for patterns in data. Quantitative methods are tools for finding and evaluating these patterns. This course introduces foundational concepts in quantitative methods, including data visualization and common statistical tests used in psychological research.

title: Ancient Literary Criticism
descrip: A close reading of Aristotle's "Poetics" with selections from related texts.

title: Lyric Form and Language II: The Modern Period
reviews: Claudia Brodsky is an absolute master by sea. Probably one of best teachers here. Take advantage of her, go to office hours she'll talk about anything.

Prof. Brodsky isn't for everyone, but stay long enough and you may just hop onto her crazy train of insights and learn ways of thinking that you wouldn't encounter anywhere else. About this course in particular, Brodsky focuses at once on very close readings of the poems (it would help to know French and German) and the larger ideas the poets live with. For each poet we read a selection of poems and some prose to help clarify the poet's thought.

Since the only assignments are the papers, you are really responsible for your own education in a course like this. If you consistently do the readings and attend all classes, Professor Brodsky will change the way you think about literature and philosophy.

This course is ideal for linguistically and philosophically adventurous readers of poetry. Highly recommended if this describes you. A challenge even for those with some background in theory and poetics, but doable with patience and some confidence. Don't be put off by the initial (or ongoing) difficulty of some of the material, and seek help from classmates and the professor if need be. Students with different language backgrounds can be particularly useful to one another here.

This isn't a normal poetry class, and for the most part that's a good thing. Take it if you want to experience some utterly wild readings of great poems and gain a better understanding of the intellectual history of modern literature.
descrip: This course is the continuation of a 2-semester sequence for undergraduates and graduate students, but may be taken independently of the fall semester course (COM 421). We will focus on reading major poets of the modern period in English, French, German and Spanish with additional readings in the theoretical reflections on modernity, poetry, and the arts written by several of the poets we read. These include: Baudelaire, Mallarme, Rilke, Celan, Garcia Lorca, Pax, Borges, Stevens, Bishop and Ashbery, among others. Secondary readings will include essays by major theorists and critics.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A full year study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering culminating in a senior thesis. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written thesis, poster presentation, and oral defense required. The senior thesis is recorded as a double course in the spring. Departmental permission required.

title: Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: --Trust me, you don't need to go to class at all.  Just read the book carefully; it explains everything way more clearly than most of the professors could in class.  Don't fall behind though.  There is a significant amount of homework every week, about twice as much as MAT 201.  It's a lot more theoretical, and the problems tend to be more challenging.  Be prepared to put in time (5-8 hours each week), but the problem sets will help you learn the material well.  Study very hard for the exams.  Math curves are never generous.  But this is a very useful class overall.  Linear algebra is a whole new way of thinking about problems (including many with real-world applications) compared to calculus or whatever else you've learned before.  If you can put in the time, I would definitely recommend taking it.  It helps quite a bit if you've taken differential equations before.  By the way, on my note about not going to class, I never went to class but got a near-perfect score on the final, and I'm not a math genius.  The book will serve you very well.
201 was awful. 202 was great. I'm not going to do that well but I feel like I understood what was happening in general. It's the type of math that I enjoy.

A bunch of times you will feel like a robot. A robot that is endlessly computing the rref's of matrices, and finding the kernel etc etc. These mini calculations are annoying especially when you are up at 3 am finishing up a pset. Start early. Be prepared to feel like a robot. 

However towards the end, when we learn about orthogonal complements and Eigen basis you start to see some of the cool applications of Lin. Alg, and why people would want to bother with it. Also dynamical systems is pretty cool, keep eye out for it. Wish more time was spent on them !

Actually do the readings before lecture, even if it seems easy to begin with.  It quickly builds - this stuff is aggressively cumulative, and if you don't understand something make sure you ask asap or you will fall behind.
Although I HATED math 201, this class was actually pretty fun, interesting, and much easier in my opinion. Boumal is great as a teacher.

As an engineering student, you'll have to take this course. Try and read the textbook before the lectures because falling behind in the beginning is the worst thing you can do in this class. Try to memorize some of the theories early so that studying for the other exams isn't so bad.

Ask lots of questions about concepts you don't understand at first, because they will show up throughout the entire course. Do lots of practice with True/False questions and work with a study group on problem sets. Try doing as many practice exams as possible to prepare for assessments.

Better than 201, stay on top of everything in the second half of the semester 
A lot of random stuff to memorize and everything is interrelated which is sometimes very annoying because it pulls things from throughout the year into exams
If you're taking it you probably have to take it...
Better than MAT 202! Try to get McConnell!

Can be a difficult class if your math background is not really strong. Stay on top of material throughout the semester rather than cramming right before an exam as applying concepts can be challenging.
Classes aren't very helpful, but textbook is very thorough.
DON'T take this class unless necessary.
Definitely a doable class! Read the textbook and do the psets regularly!

Definitely don't take it unless you have to. It's not a fun or particularly interesting course. Also, it seems like one of those you get it or you don't courses, so even if you have historically been good at math, be prepared to maybe have to work a bit harder at this.
Devote extra time to this course. It's hard!
Difficult but worthwhile, familiarizes you with an essential discipline of mathematics.
Do a lot of practice problems!
Do practice exams and make sure you understand the solutions. Go to class. Keep up with the material.
Do the psets on time and study, not an easy course.

Do whatever you can to get into Hansheng Diao's class because he is incredible. Check problem sets with friends because they are easy points. The exams are really hard -- go to office hours and do lots of practice exams.

Don't be fooled by the course title - there are no "applications" in this course. Very theoretical and proof-based. If you're thinking about taking this course, it's probably because you have to, so good luck! Do as many practice tests as you can, that's the only way to study for quizzes and exams.

Don't let the course pass you by?make sure you understand all the terms from each class before the next one or the reasoning behind stuff won't make sense and therefore the new stuff won't make sense. Good alternative to MAT 204, though.
Don't take it if you don't have to.

Don't take it if you don't need it for your major (though I can't imagine many ppl wanting to do so for "fun"). Know that you won't learn any applications in the course, except for maybe passing mentions of why we care. We never do any applications problems though.
Don't take it unless you have to or really like math. Not extremely time consuming but it is taught quite poorly.
Don't take this class unless you have to.
Don't take this course. Take 217 or 204 instead. And if you do take this course, do NOT take it at 9am.

Don't take this or any other math classes here unless you absolutely have to... The exams are almost always after dean's date and despite endless studying you're probably still not going to do well. It seems basically no one is in the middle; everyone either does super well or super poorly.
Don't take unless required. Absolutely go to every class, or you will certainly fall behind.
Don't take unless you have to; if you're just looking for a QR, this isn't it.

For those who took 203 and don't feel like having every test beat the crap out of you, 202 is an ok next step. At least on the 202 exams, you can understand what each question is asking (not saying that you can necessarily solve it...)
Found it easier to just study from the book rather than attend lessons. Easier than 201 but curve is much higher.
GET FLORIAN AS YOUR PRECEPTOR. Stay on top of the work, and studying for the quizzes as they are essentially study guides for the midterm and finals. Tough class, but Florian made the experience fun.
Get Florian!
Get a head start on each problem set so you're not rushing to learn the material. Go to McGraw and/or office hours if you can.
Get help if you need it. Go to True/False help sessions... they help a lot.
Go to class and pay attention. Do the hws and try to find somebody to study with.
Go to office hours for homework and quizzes.

Go to office hours. Don't do the psets alone. Go to tutoring or consult with friends in the class and do the psets together. Understand the early material really well and be able to think of everything geometrically.
Go to office hours. Go even if you don't have any personal questions because questions others ask are always helpful.
Go to office hours/McGraw study hall if you run into problems on the homework. Also start those practice exams early.
Heavy emphasis on abstract, difficult to visualize concepts (5 dimensional hyperplanes and the like) but definitely worth taking.
However much you think you understand the material, your grade may still be screwed by the exams.

I found MAT 202 to be the easiest out of the math classes of the BSE sequence. It's definitely a lot of work and there are hard concepts, and the problem sets are actually pretty hard (lots of theory questions), but the material itself is interesting, and the chapters go together beautifully. Don't be intimidated!

I personally think it is more difficult than mat201 because it is not as tangible (some people think the opposite). The psets might take 2-3 hours/week. Do not miss any class cause it is not so easy to learn it by yourself especially after midterm when things get dramatically harder. I like this class so much.

I think a crucial aspect of doing this course right is figuring out early the best strategy for learning the material and then employing that strategy. You could do the psets at the beginning of each week so that precepts reinforce the concepts, or you could do the psets in segments after each class to reinforce what you learned that day, as long as your approach works best for you. In any case, you will get much more out of the course if you do the psets to learn and practice the material and not to simply get them done.

I was disappointed by the lack of applications we actually saw, so it was hard to remain engaged at times when only considering arbitrary theory which is often times difficult to mentally picture due to the nature of the material.

I would highly recommend reading the sections from the book prior to going to class; otherwise you sometimes are so busy writing things down that you aren't really understanding what you're writing. Also don't start the psets the night before they're due, it's just a bad idea. If you don't really like math and are not a BSE, would not recommend, but if you need to take it it's not too bad. It's very different from calculus, in that you can't really visualize what you're doing in many cases; you have to just rely on the math.

I would not advise anyone (except people who truly love math) to take this course. If it is a prereq for your major, I suggest first learning it on your own or taking this course at another college/university. May the light be with you if you end up taking it here.
I would strongly recommend keeping up with the readings and going to office hours regularly as it is easy to become lost quickly.
If you are considering taking this course, it is probably because you have to take this course. So, I think you should just go ahead and take it.
If you are taking this course, personally I recommend taking it Professor Tkocz and you will love this course.

If you are taking this course, you probably have to. That said, it's terrible. It is very difficult to follow and the textbook is not helpful. I would recommend finding a better textbook to clarify anything you don't understand. Also, don't let yourself get lost in the first few weeks, because beyond that point it is very difficult to get un-lost.

If you don't have to, don't take this. I don't think anyone ever takes it who doesn't have to because it's really hard. Especially if you are a sophomore because freshmen will be in the class who have taken linear before and will ruin the curve.

If you enjoy logic and want to learn a different branch of mathematics, 202 was really interesting to me! I also found it extremely hard--just as hard as 201, even though many people don't seem to feel that way.

If you get Florian as a preceptor, he is definitely dedicated to all of the students. That being said, the quality of his lectures can definitely be improved. He does not explain or prove concepts/formulas, or when he does, not as clearly as you'd like. Most of what I learned in this class was from reading the book, or from other students' questions in class.

If you have to take it you have to take it. Otherwise save yourself and please don't.  This class is more theoretical than 201 and the problem sets are longer. Just do your best not to fall behind by going to office hours and McGraw. It is also essential that you find a teacher who is good for you. My suggestions would be Hansheng or Mihai if either of them are teaching. Good luck.
If you have to take it, then do it. Otherwise save yourself the pain.

If you have to take the course, getting into one of McConnell's section will make life a lot nicer for you. The class overall is not too bad, but it's not something I would take just because of a general interest.
If you have to take this course try to get a class with Professor McConnell.

If you have to take this course, prepare to work very hard to understand challenging theoretical concepts and spend a long time on theoretical pset questions. If you don't have to take this course DONT unless you find theoretical math exciting. Unlike calculus (which is easier to setup and visualize but harder to calculate) the calculations in 202 are fairly straightforward, but understanding their meaning and how they all relate is very difficult.

If you survived MAT 201, you can definitely survive 202. It's a lot more theoretical than computational, which is a nice change. You do have to put in effort outside of class in order to understand the material, so make sure you do the problem sets thoroughly and really prep for exams-- do as many practice exams as you have time for.
If you're BSE, you have to take it. Make sure you shop around for a good preceptor.
If you're good at math, it really shouldn't be too challenging. The material although dry is fairly straightforward.

If you're reading this, you probably have to take 202. It's actually a pretty in-depth coverage of Linear, so don't take 204 unless you have to. Also this semester's exams were easier than in previous semesters, so beware of a shallow curve.
It's a BSE requirement. Nothing special here. Just do all the past exams in preparation for the final.
It's a worthwhile class to take, but I'm not sure how useful that it'd be outside of specific areas of STEM, so perhaps don't take it unless it's required.

It's all connected, so you need to learn it all.  Find someone to discuss concepts with, otherwise you're going to have a rough time intuiting problems.  Also, I would give McConnell a positive recommendation if you're looking for a lecturer
It's on okay course, be prepared to study outside of class and read the book to be able to understand material.
It's true that this class is better than 201. Reading textbook helps tremendously.
Its pretty boring. Not much "applications"
Just another standard math class you probably have to take because you're BSE. Very different and more interesting than calculus.
Keep up with class and the textbook.
Keep up with the content!
Keep up with the material.
Linear algebra is always useful to know. I recommend this class, given that you put in the time to follow along and understand the connections between concepts, both algebraically and geometrically.
Linear algebra is cool to learn. The class is well-taught and interesting (if you enjoy math). Hansheng is an AMAZING preceptor!!
Make sure you do a lot of practice problems to cement the ideas in your head.
Make sure you get a good professor. Personally I endorse Hansheng Diao but I don't know if he will teach it in the future.
Make sure you get help and don't let yourself not understand something because unlike other courses every concept is used to understand another concept
Make sure you read the book and get a good preceptor. If you need it, look things up online because you will understand how things work theoretically but not practically.
Make sure you understand your material while it is being taught to you. Go to office hours throughout the year.
Make sure you watch Adrian Banner's videos!! So helpful.
More theoretical than 201. Easy to lose points on psets, quizzes, exams, so don't underestimate. Not fun, but not a bad course.
Most important to understand procedures of problem with homework, and then take a lot of practice quizzes and exams.
Much better than 201. About what you've likely come to expect from the 103, 104, and 201 in terms of quizzes, problem sets, etc.
Much more enjoyable than 201. Make sure to study hard for the two quizzes as they are much more difficult than you would expect.
Not a bad course to take. Manageable and not too hard.
Not an amazing class, but you're considering this 202 you probably don't have a choice.

Not easier than 201, and definitely not more enjoyable. If you actually are taking this class to learn you should take 204--otherwise the superficial level at which this stuff is taught will just make you confused. If you are in this class because you have to take it (like 95% of you), God Bless.

Not easy but there's a lot of support available (weekly review sessions, 20 different office hrs a week, McGraw, tons of practice and notes online) and has some really fascinating applications to computer science and math modeling. I used to absolutely hate matrices but now I feel somewhat empowered knowing about them.

Obviously take this course if it is a requirement. If taking it for fun, know that while the end goals are interesting and useful, you must wade through a lot of theory and will spend months just defining things before you ever really see how it comes together.
Only take it if you ABSOLUTELY HAVE TO. I hated every second of it
Only take it if you have to.
Only take this class if you have to. It isn't very well structured and it is very very challenging. If you do take it, make sure you get a good preceptor.

Only take this class if you need it as a prerequisite. Make sure to put a lot of time in in the beginning of the semester because the material there forms a huge basis for what is to come, and if you miss the boat, you can fall behind in understanding very fast.

Practice Practice Practice, you don't want to forget previous lessons because it will come back to bite you. To clarify also against rumors I heard coming into this class: curves ARE NOT based on you individual lecture, they are determined by course-wide performance.
Practice. Ask for clarification when you do not understand something. Practice some more.
Probably don't take it unless it's required
Problem sets are a small commitment. Take it.
Problem sets can be a pain, stay on top of the material and review as you go because concepts build off each other. If you can stay on top of everything it's really not too bad

READ THE TEXTBOOK!  The textbook follows the course very well and makes it easy to learn the material.  The problem sets take anywhere in the 2-5 hour range, which honestly is not that bad for a math course at Princeton.  Easier than 201.  Do all of the practice exams before the midterm and final.  You can learn everything in the 2-3 days before the exams.

Read the sections, spend time understanding how to do the problem sets, and most of all, do the True and False questions at the end of each chapter. If you understand those, everything else should be relatively simple.
Read the textbook and go to office hours. Can't emphasize enough how crucial the textbook is in surviving this course!
Read the textbook for sure, and find people to work with on the problem sets. If Hansheng is teaching, definitely try to get his class.
Read. The. Book.
Review math beforehand
STUDY FOR THE QUIZZES DEAR GOD, if there's anything you can do to succeed in this course, STUDY FOR THE QUIZZES BECAUSE THEY WILL CRUSH YOU.
Slightly easier than 201 but more boring. Take it only if you have to
Spend time on the psets to do well because they're graded harshly.

Start the problem sets earlier than the night before they're do, and go to class--textbook is at best adequate at explaining the concepts, and you'll certainly consult it while doing the problem sets, but you really do benefit from an instructor offering alternate ways to grasp the material. I enjoyed the course more than 201, but that varies greatly from person to person--and ultimately you're probably taking this because it's required for your major or a prereq for more interesting courses.
Stay on top of the subject material. Everything builds upon the previous topic.
Take McConnell's class if you can, and skim (if not read thoroughly) the textbook after lectures!
Take good notes and take advantage of all of the online materials that they provide.
Take if BSE. I personally preferred MAT 201 (Multivariable Calculus) over 202, but a lot of my friends preferred MAT 202. I found T/F questions to be very difficult.
Take if you need to

Take in fall if possible (you can take it before 201). Do not fall behind or things will be really bad. First half of the course is essential, so in particular make sure you are diligent in the first half or else the second half will be impossible. Office hours, office hours, office hours - can't stress enough - get your questions answered as soon as possible.
Take it cause you have to. It's boring. Who cares.
Take it if you have to.

Take it if you have to? I personally hate math so there really wasnt going to be a way for me not to dislike this course. That said, make sure you get a good professor. Shop around if you have to, if you get someone that doesn't teach well you are screwed.
Take it if you need to

Take it if you need to, probably don't if you don't. It's the end of the course now and I still don't really know what linear algebra is or how it is helpful in the real world (even though abstractly I know it is used extensively in other fields). That being said I'm getting a decent grade and you can get by without fully understanding the concepts.
Take it if you need to. Don't take it if you like math or you'll be bored.

Take it only if you have a strong interest in linalg or if it's a requirement for another class that you're planning on taking. This class does not focus on applications at all, so it tends to be quite abstract.
Take it over 204!! Much more relaxed, you will learn what you need to learn.
Take it with Hansheng if you can--he's great. Overall the course isn't too bad, but it's definitely still very challenging and will require lots of time and effort.

Take it with Yeuchen if possible! The material is hard so really buckle down around both exams and do the True/False from the textbook if possible - good preparation and there are sometimes similar questions.
Take it! Hansheng is a great teacher.
Take it! It's a challenging course, but you will definitely learn a lot. Linear Algebra is important in many real-world applications, so it is an essential class to take.
Take it, cry over it a bit, try to stay on board and do some practice problem, and remember Cs get degrees. (hopefully).

Take the class if you're interested in linear algebra and/or it's a prerequisite for another set/track of courses. The class is hard, I'd say comparable in difficulty (but totally different in material) to MAT 201.
Take this class seriously, and work hard.
Take this course if you need to or may need to. It takes work but is a good course overall.
Take this if you have to. It's hard but it's interesting if you like math.
The book is good, do the proofs by yourself at home and use the teachers when you encounter problems.

The class material starts off dry, but as the course progresses you start to see some interesting applications. Be warned that although the math is simple, the concepts are very tricky! Pay attention to the foundational definitions and concepts from day 1 or you will get lost as things get more complicated. Attend office hours if anything is fuzzy because you NEED a solid grasp of the concepts to do well.
The class moved a bit too fast for me so I didn't get so much from the lectures, but the material itself was interesting. I found the class to be more interesting than MAT 201.
The curve is terrible. Take at your own risk.
The material is not that bad, problem sets are not too time consuming, and exams are fair, but the professors are not terribly invested in the course. The book is very important.

There's a high chance you're taking this class because of a departmental requirement. Don't be afraid to ask your instructor in class why you should care about the theories you're learning, and go to office hours to get a more physical intuition for the concepts.
This class is a lot of hard work, but it is worth it
This class moves extremely fast. Take it with Hansheng if you can - great teacher and very funny.
This course covers the material that it needs too. I wouldn't take it unless you need to for BSE or some other math major.

This course is a different ball-game than other Math courses. Linear Algebra is highly conceptual and abstract. There is a lot more emphasis placed on how well you've grasped and can manipulate the concepts than on your ability to do rote calculation. So, spend the time this course demands!

This course is a very interesting one if you are interested in mathematics or systems solving. The course does have quite a bit of applied theory for an introduction to linear algebra, so be prepared to try to understand the theory of the processes that you employ.
This course is incredibly difficult, don't take it just for fun (though this is probably a requirement for you). In any case, just work as hard as you can and USE THE LECTURE NOTES.
This course is very difficult and not super interesting, only take it if it's required.
This course requires a lot of work and attention, especially if you're not really good at math. It starts out fine, but accelerates so don't be fooled.
This is NOT like 201; there's a lot more proof-like stuff and a lot less calculation stuff. Be ready.
This is a fairly straightforward class that won't be very hard if you are coming from MAT 203.  Hansheng is highly recommended.
This is a good course and you learn a lot! It is extra helpful to do the readings before class to better understand the material.
This is a solid introduction to linear algebra. Read the textbook - it'll help explain concepts!
This is a well-taught course. Through hard work, this course will help you build up your mathematical skill set incredibly effectively.

This is an extremely difficult class. Far and away the most difficult course of my freshman year. Considerably harder than MAT 201, PHY 103, PHY 104, and COS 126 (just to give engineers a comparative metric).

This is not really a course to take unless linear algebra will be useful to you. If it will, however, I do highly recommend this course. Steven Sivek taught very clearly and well, and was very invested in being prepared for the class. The material is not always easy, but the structure of the course will not get in your way when learning the material.
Took it as an engineering requirement, but would actually recommend to anyone thinking of majoring in a science.

Try to get Hansheng Diao as your instructor. Really makes the class much more interesting and much more manageable. Strongly encourage practicing with the True/False at the end of each section and doing as many practice exams/quizzes as possible before the assessments. As for the textbook, it's pretty bad so would advise looking for another online textbook or something to supplement your learning. I started reading another one during reading period for final studying, and it helped immensely
Try to read carefully through the book before class so you can follow what is covered.
Try to start the assignments early and be on top of what is going on! Every class builds up on the previous one, and it's very easy to get lost
Try to understand the concepts very well. It's hard to master but it's cool when you understand what's going on. The questions are like puzzles.
Understanding the relationship between different parts of the class is far more important than memorizing the theorems.
Very solid course on a useful topic. Would recommend to anyone.
Whatever math class you take here is going to be hard but this is one of the more organized classes

Will most likely be taken as a distribution requirement for BSE. The material is easier to understand than MAT 201 but is still challenging and requires that you put in the work to fully understand the material.
Work hard, study a lot.
Wouldn't recommend unless it is a pre-req
You have to anyways.
You have to take lin alg, because you have to take lin alg. Just do your work and you'll be fine.
You have to take this class so nothing I say will change that

You have to take this course so you might as well get through it. Would reccomend watching adrian banner videos who used a more indepth approach to the concepts. To this day, I still don't understand how this course is applicable to my life or why the kernel of a matrix is important.
You probably have to take it, but like in the other large math classes for non-engineers, quality of the instruction and textbook is spotty and the class is curved around a B.
You're probably only taking this class if you have to.

if you're BSE you have to. if you did well in mat201, you'll probably be fine because it is very similarly structured. i think the material is also easier; if you read the textbook,  things will really click
if you're taking this, it's because you have to. you can't really do much except try to make sure you understand everything in the problem sets each week.
its hard but doable

review the chapter before class to understand what is going on
take it if you have to.
take it its pretty interesting
useful for finance and COS among other things, generally good to take if you're quantitatively inclined!
prereqs: MAT104 equivalent..
descrip: Companion course to MAT201. Matrices, linear transformations, linear independence and dimension, bases and coordinates, determinants, orthogonal projection, least squares, eigenvectors and their applications to quadratic forms and dynamical systems.

title: U.S. Foreign Relations
reviews: ABSOLUTELY take this course if you are interested in U.S. history or international relations, but prepare to work hard and know the material. It will be worth it.
Do all of the reading, it may be a lot, but you get a lot of information and knowledge out of it.
Favorite class I've taken
Great course. A decent workload in terms of reading but the lectures are interesting.
I recommend this course if you like American history and are willing to read and participate in precepts.
I would be aware that this course covers a very long period of time. I would definitely attend lecture and do the reading.
Interesting course, solid lectures, pretty easy. decent amount of reading
Take it! Don't be nervous if you haven't done anything about US history before. The content is manageable and interesting

Take it! It's a wonderfully taught course and helps you to see the history of the United States in a more nuanced light. If you're not a history person, I would still recommend the course and it is a good course to take to fulfill the Woody Woo history prereq.
Take it! Take the initiative to really engage with the readings
Take the course, but you might be struggle a bit if you are not a well-versed historian.
This course will push you from time to time, but you walk out the other end having enjoyed the ride. I highly recommend this course to other students.

This is not an easy history course. A lot of primary source reading, and you really need a strong background in American history to get the most out of the course. If you are interested in American history, a history major, or wiling to do the work than it could be good. But do not take this as your first history course or a senior spring course, otherwise you will find yourself lost/frustrated.

This may very well be the most outstanding course offered at Princeton. Professor Fronczak is a world-class mind, an engaging lecturer, and an outstanding professor. You will learn so much about international relations, diplomacy, and history without ever feeling overwhelmed or being even slightly bored with the material. Take this course!!
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course covers the history of US foreign relations from the American revolution to the present day. Lectures take up questions of diplomacy, foreign policy, ideology and culture, empire and anti-imperialism, and revolution and counterrevolution. Precepts emphasize primary sources, from the writings of Tom Paine, George Washington, William Jennings Bryan, Ho Chi Minh, Phyllis Schafly, Elaine Scarry, and more.

title: Communism and Beyond: China and Russia
reviews: Great course, very interesting readings and discussion topics. Kaple is also really really nice. Reaction memos and papers were not a huge burden.

I would highly recommend taking this class. The lectures are interesting, the attached precepts are engaging, and the readings are nothing short of excellent. In fact, in regards to the latter, you'll probably be happy to learn that there are few theoretical readings, which means that weekly readings (which, at times, can be large) are the kinds of things you'll actually want to read.

It was an interesting class to PDF. I think if you try even a little bit though, you can get a very nice grade. The reading is kinda heavy, but I'm an engineer so maybe it's a reasonable AB reading schedule?
Low work class with interesting material.
Take it!

Take this class! Professor Kaple is great and this class is a necessity if you are going to conduct more research on Chinese or Russian policy. It is impossible to understand communism without understanding the histories of these two countries. I've done almost every single page of reading for this class and I'm BSE (so I never read). Love love loved this class.
Take this class!! The material is really interesting and professor Kaple is great!

This is a great and interesting course, and Professor Kaple is wonderful.  However, sociology majors should be forewarned that this class focuses a lot on the history of communism, and discussions tend to deal with policy and politics, due to the large number of POL and WWS majors taking the class.
take this class!!! do the readings!
descrip: This course focuses on the communist experiment in the Soviet Union and China. The first half of the course presents the political, social and economic histories that characterize the USSR's and China's particular path to communism. The second half of the course focuses on the consequences of communism by examining each country's demographics, environment, social structures and so on.

title: Methodology of Spanish Language Teaching: Seminar and Practicum
descrip: This course is an introduction to key terms and ideas in the field of second-language acquisition and core issues in teaching modern foreign languages, with special attention to Spanish and Portuguese. Students will develop and practice skills and techniques of teaching foreign languages, selection of content and materials, evaluation of student performance, and self-assessment of their own pedagogical practices. The theoretical foundation will be applied to the teaching of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). The teaching of culture and the use of new technologies will be also considered.

title: Labor Economics/Industrial Relations Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: A lot of people just know about ISC for being hard and a lot of work, but it's also so much more than that. The level of collaboration and support among fellow ISC students and alumni is unlike anything I've experienced in any other class here (so far). You get to do really cool, involved labs that are less like the cheesy activities you do in high school and more like what you might really do in a research lab. Plus you learn a lot about MATLAB from doing lab reports. The lectures this semester were very understandable and follow-able, even when they were on tough material. The COS component is kind of randomly shoved in the middle, but it was well taught. And you can probably get a free tshirt at the end so just do it!!

Although a lot of negativity is thrown at ISC for its difficulty, it is the best choice I have made at Princeton thus far and for anyone with an interest in science and a love for math, this is the place to go. After going to class every day and having your mind blown, you come out of ISC a changed person with a completely new perspective on the world. If you have any interest at all in this class and are looking for a tipping point...this is it! Take this sequence!

Be prepared for a lot of work, but it's absolutely worth it if you like the material. You should definitely try it, and you can always drop if you don't like it. This is a course that you should be passionate about.

If you're going into Physics, Chem, Bio, or some BSE major, then yeah, just go ahead and take the second semester. If you're not even sure you're going to stay in science, I'm not sure I would recommend taking the second semester. I would say that second semester is more rough than first semester, because you don't have as many breaks as in the fall, and you're past the honeymoon stage of Princeton in general, so be careful with your mental health and all the stress. I actually had a pretty terrible semester in general, and I wish I had taken better advantage of ISC, and I really don't think ISC is for everyone, but it's good that ISC exists. You'll learn about waves, which are pretty cool, Fourier transforms, which are useful in many different scientific disciplines, some standard stuff like optics and E&M (which I personally found to be meh), a little fluid dynamics, all the way up to quantum mechanics and how quantum mechanics explains chemistry. Is ISC worth it? Probably, especially if you're going into science. Really try to develop relationships with the various professor. And do summer research in Lewis-Sigler!
It's an incredibly challenging course, but if science fascinates you and you don't believe in boundaries, take this class! Bonus: you make a great set of friends.

The class is absolutely great, and I learned a lot that I would not have learned in other conventional classes. Thermo and Quantum are challenging but very important to learn, and you only get that in ISC. Also, doing such interesting experiments and writing lab reports is an important experience that should not be missed.

There are many reasons not to take this course, but there are just as many to take it. If you enjoy feeling overwhelmed intellectually, and are good at maths and physics, go ahead. Is it worth it? I don't know... I don't think I ever will. One thing I do know, is that ISC has taught me that I will never be a scientist
You can take from this course as much as you want, but getting into more advanced material will make you have to skip over basic syllabus.
prepare to study
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC 231/232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multidisciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); S. Shvartsman (CBE); H. Yang (CHM); R. Sedgewick (COS); P. Andolfatto (EEB); E. Wieschaus (MOL); J. Gadd, A. Leifer, B. Machta, A. Nourmohammad (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.

title: Madness and Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Bodies in Cultural Landscapes
descrip: See website

title: Analysis of Big Data
reviews: A decent course, you'll get a good understanding in a small number of topics in data analysis. Heavy workload
A good class, wasn't too bad at the beginning, but difficulty level increased significantly right when theses were due. Would not recommend for seniors.

Absolutely take it! Prof Liu is methodical and crystal clear in his presentation of the material. No professor answers student questions in a more clear fashion. The theory of machine learning can be abstract at times, but in homework you got to apply the concepts to real world problems. Assignments can be frustrating at time because the coding parts are in R. But you have some hands-on experience this way. The TAs are wonderful in replying to Piazza posts and take huge amount of time to design the homework.

Absolutely take this class! It's really tough and will probably be your heaviest of the semester, but it's 100% worth it. The homeworks are super relevant and helpful, and you'll end up applying this stuff to your independent work for sure. Han Liu is an amazing professor, and the TAs are all super dedicated and helpful, particularly Ziwei

Amazing class--it will make you understand statistics like no other. But, it is a soul-crushing amount of work (problem sets take 20-30 hrs / week, and there is one per week.) This is not an exaggeration. Make sure your other courses are light.
DO NOT TAKE. This class is poorly organized, the problem sets are long and tedious, you won't learn very much, and it's a large amount of work. I don't recommend it to any Princeton student.

Definitely one of the better ORFE courses. Han Liu is trying to reach course nirvana and is very receptive to students' feedback, and is constantly trying to improve the course. Beware of VERY long psets, especially towards the end of the year, and be prepared to get pretty comfortable with R.

Do not take ORF350 if you haven't seen linear algebra and probability theory before. If you have, this is a though class in terms of workload, but you will meet some of the most genuinely dedicated instructors I have seen at Princeton, and will most likely enjoy it.
Do not take unless you are willing to invest 10  hours each week.

Fantastic class! Admittedly, it was a lot of work, but we were warned against this. I don't think I've ever learned so much useful material in a class ever. Teachings were fantastic, and so much thought went into the problem set questions as well, unlike many other courses. You don't need too much background to succeed in this class -- I had taken no statistics before, and got away learning a lot. Take it, but make sure you're taking no more than one other hard class.

Gets more into the weeds than 424. Assignments are a lot but if you ask enough people you can get close to 100% every time. Don't get caught up in the details of things (notations etc.) and you'll be more than okay.

I haven't had a grade this high since sophomore year of high school.
Go to lecture and pay attention.
Good class but can be difficult at times. Honestly a tough workload, would imagine it's worse if you're not relatively familiar with R or are very good at getting by with other languages.

Han Liu, the lecturer, is incredibly good at what he does. If he isn't teaching the course, I would not recommend taking it. I also wouldn't recommend taking it unless you're prepared to spend 7-15  hours on homework per week for the first 8 weeks or so of the semester. That said, the content is quite interesting.

He doubled the amount of work this year, so it became very time consuming. However, that being said it was the best course I've taken at princeton. I think I've learned the most out of any course from this one, and the assignments are really interesting. I wouldn't take it unless you have a lighter schedule, otherwise you will suffer.
Highly recommend this course. The professor is great, the TAs are very dedicated. The assignments are challenging, but you will receive a lot of help from the course staff.

Honestly, I'm not a huge fan of the material, so I didn't enjoy the class a whole lot. However, I can recognize that it's well-taught for what it is. If you think you might be interested in big data analysis, go ahead and take this course. Don't kill yourself trying to answer every question perfectly.

I recommend this course to anyone who is seeking a bit of a challenge. It is a tough course, but a very rewarding learning experience. Also there is an amazing amount of love and effort put into this course from both the TA and Han Liu resulting in well refined lectures and assignments. You will probably not find a higher quality course in machine learning/statistics.

I'm an ORFE major and I still learned so much in this class. You gain a mathematical intuition for broad concepts like Bayesian statistics, regression, and clustering that you took for granted in other classes. However, the TAs were overloaded this year and gave us assignments back way too late.

I'm glad I took this class because it taught me some new data science concepts and will look good on my resume (I am trying to go into the data science field), but good god do the instructors not make it easy. The problem sets will consume your entire life, and the TA's seem to take sadistic pleasure in you complaining about them, sending disrespectful gifs of cartoon characters crying. Our last problem set was our longest and was due just a couple days after our midterm (normally we get a week). Problem sets take at least 10 dedicated hours - MUCH longer if you're not good at theory. The TA's don't seem to know the material well, so you'll have to rely on finding other people in the class to supplement the areas you're not great at. You'll code some cool models, but be warned that this class is the most time intensive one I've taken as an ORFE major.
If you have ANY interesting in statistics and data science, you MUST take this course.
If you have the time, please take this course! You won't regret it. Learned so much and inspired my thesis topic.

It definitely can be a challenging course, and the problem sets will generally take a very long time to complete. That said, the material is very interesting, and the instructors work hard to accommodate the students. If you take this class, be prepared to spend a lot of time on the homeworks, and also work in groups and check Piazza a lot.

It's a good course for non-ORF majors (like me), though my ORF friends said it covered a lot of material they'd already seen in previous classes. The instructors care a lot. They're very active on Piazza. The workload was very high this year, but I think they're going to get a lot of feedback about that and make significant changes to the course for next year.
It's a lot of work!
It's a lot of work. More than ORF 309. But you learn a ton and it's invaluable if you want to work in a data-analytic field.

Learn great material, however the organization of the course this semester was very poor. Constant corrections made to HW near the deadlines, and "undergraduate course designer" was unnecessarily sassy on Piazza to students genuinely seeking help. Everything tested in this class felt like an intentional trick, and that doesn't make for great self confidence.
Perhaps the best class I've taken at Princeton. This course is a must take if you're at all interested in data science
Prof. Liu is a great professor and really cares about his students. He makes sure that everyone understands the material before continuing to the next part of lecture. The workload can be difficult.
Take it!
Take it! Han is great. The material is great. The assignments are great. Take it.
Take it, but be prepared to work. The professor is phenomenal. I can't think of a more thorough analysis of Big Data.
Take it.
Take the class. I think it is a little overrated, but still easily one of the BEST classes the ORF department / Princeton has to offer.
Take this class if you have a lot of time to spare. Very interesting though.

Take this class, you will learn a lot. Plan ahead, start hw early and go to office hours.
Be prepared to be constantly flooded by Piazza posts.
Take this course if you want to learn about big data statistics and applications of statistics.  It is a little bit a work, but well worth it.

Take this course, take it! It teaches you so much about data analysis. Han Liu is one of the best and most caring lecturers out there; while the homeworks may be tedious and the class very fast-paced, I learned a lot and it's one of the most valuable courses I've taken here at Princeton so far.

The best class at Princeton I've taken, and I've taken a lot of quantitative classes. Compared to COS AI, it's a much more unifying perspective on Big Data: focusing on fewer topics while tying a lot of methods together with a common theme, unlike in AI where the topics are often scattered and barely adequately addressed. The participation assignment (10 minutes of writing out important points in the most recent lecture) was actually really helpful - often at Princeton I don't have time to look over the most recent lecture, which is a bad habit.

This class has interesting material but spends a lot of time on some concepts to the point of getting repetitive. Han Liu is really determined to make sure every student understands the ins and outs of what he teaches, which probably means you'll come away from this class with a good understanding of the concepts but also have spent a lot more time than you wanted to on assignments and lectures that test and repeat what you already understand.
This class is so effing hard. That being said, you learn so much. I think that it's certainly worth taking, but just be prepared to spend a lot of time!

This class is very interesting, but it is extremely time consuming.  Would recommend to anyone who wants to learn more about machine learning and big data analysis, but just be aware that this class will take up a big chunk of your time.

This course had exceptional reviews last year. I and many others were very excited to take it this year, but we found a couple surprises: Prof. Liu's lecturing style is good and very organized, but was irradically paced. The course was also very full, and the weekly assignments were very long and didn't feel like they went with the lectures very well. Nevertheless, as the course continued, I did feel myself learning a lot about ML and statistics, and at the end of the lecture I can see how everything was organized. I highly recommend this class to everyone interested in ML. It provides a solid understanding of the basic concepts, but don't expect to learn much about the exciting concepts like NN and what not. This class isn't about applications.

This course was a rare gem. Not only did I learn and gain a deep understanding of concepts taught, I also immensely enjoyed the material because of the way in which it was presented and taught. The course is very well paced and reasonable. Han Liu and his team are amazing. One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton!
This is a great class in terms of content, teaching, and focus on the students' learning outcomes. Do not take if you are not willing to learn or work hard.
This is the best course that I have taken in the ORFE department and I would highly recommend this course.
This was a relatively chill class (weekly problem set, exams very lowly weighted) given how well I feel I learned the material.

Towards the end, the problem sets were unrealistically long (e.g., I would work for 20  hours on them and still not finish). But the teaching staff was very responsive on Piazza and in office hours, and Professor Liu even canceled one of the final problem sets to make it easier on the class near thesis and JP deadlines. Overall, I really learned a lot and would recommend this class, just be sure you're able to devote the necessary amount of work.

Wonderful class to take. The workload was very tough to handle, though, especially as a senior. Problem sets were also not returned in a timely manner at all. However, this is largely due to the fact that the course was understaffed given a large amount of students. Overall, it was worth the effort to learn such useful and interesting material.

You need a math background to get a lot out of this class. 
I'm hoping the curve is generous!!!

You will definitely learn a lot, but it will also take up a LOT of your time.  This is definitely one of the best classes in terms of how much and how well I learned a specific topic, but it will be your hardest/most time consuming course.

han liu is the best ORFE professor out there. his class is phenomenal and he absolutely enjoys teaching. you will learn a lot, and it will take a lot of time, but it is definitely worth it if you have the time to spare. don't take during a heavy semester.
prereqs: ORF 245.
descrip: The amount of data in our world has been exploding, and analyzing large data sets is becoming a central problem in our society. This course introduces the statistical principles and computational tools for analyzing big data: the process of exploring and predicting large datasets to find hidden patterns and gain deeper understanding, and of communicating the obtained results for maximal impact. Topics include massively parallel data management and data processing, model selection and regularization, statistical modeling and inference, scalable computational algorithms, descriptive and predictive analysis, and exploratory analysis.

title: Psychopharmacology
reviews: A true mess of a class. Reconsider taking unless they sort out the grading/rubric components in an appropriate manner.
Absolutely take it! Amazing professor and interesting class! You'll have fun!
Chill class, but frustratingly disorganized. The textbooks are helpful resources.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. You don't have much time at Princeton. Don't waste your time with a course that has very little interested information and is not very thought-provoking. The lectures don't really improve your understanding of the concepts, and the exams don't really require much either, so it's easy to leave the class having not learned anything.

Definitely take it!!! Like 1000 stars- easy class with less work. Pay attention and take notes for the midterm but the final is a take home that was open book and computer so that's no worry. Also space out posting the discussion posts and start them early so you aren't cramming them in at the end. Otherwise, great class!
Great class, super interesting material. Would take if you are interested in the biology behind drugs and the overall subject of pharmacology.
I loved this course and definitely take it!!!

I recommend taking the course. Pay attention up to the mid term. If you do well on that, the rest of the class isn't difficult at all. An interesting topic with a light amount of work. Perfect for seniors who need/want to take a departmental in the spring while doing their thesis. A win-win in my opinion.
I would take it because it is interesting and not very much work.
It is worth your time. There is also pizza.
Really cool material if you have any interest in the topic. Light workload and pretty easy to do well if you have any background in neuro.
Tests were arbitrary and did not really test on important things. Classes were chill though.

The course seems to change a lot throughout the semester, so be prepared for formats of assignments and exams to be different than what you sign up for. Interesting material, fairly interesting lectures, very relaxed.

The final was absolutely ridiculous. It was over a hundred true and false questions on Blackboard discussion posts that students made, yet some of the questions were ambiguously worded. And, upon looking at the original literature, many of the questions had ambiguous answers too. The midterm was also annoying because it was memorization-based. Otherwise, the material in the class is very interesting.
This class is not a lot of work each week.

This course and its instructor(s) come off as being really chill, which isn't necessarily untrue, and you cover many interesting topics. But the utter lack of organization in the grading and structure of the course made it way more stressful than it should've been. Beware: They have this tendency to change grading policies over the course of the semester.
This course is packed with really interesting information. Definitely take it, especially if you need a science departmental.

While this isn't the most exciting or well executed course, it does cover very interesting material. In addition it also isn't very difficult and there is pizza offered in every lecture.
I would recommend this course for anyone interested in the topic and/or looking for a course with lighter work load, that still offers a lot to learn.

You definitely get how much you put in! This class is great for those who are looking for an introduction of drugs, their uses, and their effects on the brain. It also presents a more applicable and medical side of psychology/neurology.
a class for Dowon Dan Kim
prereqs: MOL 345 or equivalent.
descrip: The molecular biology and biochemistry of pharmaceuticals and natural products that target CNS function will be examined. Specific topics include: the blood-brain barrier, addiction and tolerance, analgesia, treatments for mood disorders, cognitive enhancement, stimulants and ADHD, treatment of dementias such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease, psychotropic drugs, antipsychotics and the treatment of schizophrenia.

title: Innovation in Practice: Pathways and People
reviews: By the end of the course, you should have an area of innovation that you feel like you can contribute to.
Do not take class unless you have to.
Do the readings and go to lecture. You get out what you put in for this class.
Don't take it. I didn't learn a single thing.
If you are truly interested in entrepreneurship, the Keller Center offers other courses probably more suited to what you are looking for.
Interesting course!
Just go in with no expectations and a positive attitude. Don't be skeptical of everything like I was...but also don't take it too seriously.
Shop this course before committing. Attend the first week or two if you can before fully committing. This way you can see if it s a good fit
This course has a lot of work towards the end of the semester and assignments were not given until very last minute.

This course is not difficult and still teaches concrete techniques and concepts for innovation within business, although the course is not intensive on the subject. The time commitment gets to be more near the end of the semester but is never very much.
prereqs: This course is open to students from all disciplines who are interested in innovation. Class examples will describe value creation built on science, engineering and technology..
descrip: Innovation has been defined as "the intersection of invention and insight, leading to the creation of social and economic value." In this course, students build on expert and practitioner experience and insights, as well as readings, to develop an enhanced understanding of innovation and roles in the innovation ecosystem. Companies -- and individuals and social enterprises -- use innovation to establish and drive success.

title: Master's Project II
descrip: Under the direction of a Bendheim affiliated faculty member, students carry out a master's project, write a report, and present the results in the form of a poster or an oral presentation in front of an examining committee.

title: Convex and Conic Optimization
reviews: Awesome course. Awesome professor. Awesome TA. Take it.
Challenging but well taught and interesting. Take if curious about optimization
Great course and Amir Ali is a great lecturer. Somewhat challenging assignments and exams. Immediately applicable to a lot of research.
Great course!

If you believe that Convex Optimization could be a necessary tool for your research or you otherwise have an interest in the material, I would highly recommend you to take this course. I doubt that you would regret the decision even if the material is not essential for you.
It's an ok/good class. Homework can be very annoying. AAA is a good lecturer, entertaining.   Material itself is good and well presented, both from a theoretical and applied perspective.
The lecture notes posted online are very helpful and usually contain everything said in lecture.
This course is very helpful. Strongly recommended.
different styles from other ORFE classes
prereqs: Prerequisite: linear optimization.
descrip: A mathematical introduction to convex, conic, and nonlinear optimization. Topics include convex analysis, duality, theorems of alternatives and infeasibility certificates, semidefinite programming, polynomial optimization, sum of squares relaxation, robust optimization, computational complexity in numerical optimization, and convex relaxations in combinatorial optimization. Applications drawn from operations research, dynamical systems, statistics, and economics.

title: Pro Seminar: Computation, Energy, Technology in Architecture
descrip: The pro seminar is offered to incoming PhD students in the PhD track in Computation, Energy, building Technology in the School of Architecture (open to other interested graduate students as well) and is organized as a research seminar to introduce the participants to scientific research methods in the context of design in Architecture and science in engineering. It is structured as a series of introductory presentations of exemplary methods based on case studies and a number of guest presentations from collaborating disciplines.
