title: Instrumental Music: The Symphony from Haydn to Stravinsky
reviews: A shame Prof. Burnham is retiring, unsure if class would be the same with different teacher.
Alas this won't be offered any more.
Alas, if only Scott were back to teach this again
Amazing class with the best professor and preceptor! So glad I took it during Prof. Burnham's last semester here, and so sad that he'll be retiring...
Do yourself a favor and take this class.
Don't think you'll do well unless you're in PUO. That being said, it is a very well taught and exciting class, great PDF.
Extremely easy, and I probably won't take another music class, but for what it was I greatly enjoyed the lectures.

Great class to PDF. I don't play any instruments, and I can't read music, and I still got by just fine. You'll get out of it what you put into it. At the very least, you'll learn to appreciate some famous symphonies. It's too bad that Burnham's retiring; he was passionate and hilarious.
Great course - very fun and enjoyable, learned lots. Workload is not heavy. Class is just listening to beautiful music and listening to stories. Would definitely recommend!

Great course. As a certificate program student, I liked the music we covered and there wasn't too much listening needed. Listening exams used very obvious excerpts and were pretty easy.  Unfortunately Burnham is leaving, so maybe this course will change. If he ever comes back and lectures on anything though, you shouldn't miss it!
I would definitely recommend anyone to take this course.

I'll try to speak to the content of the course,  which I would recommend any music-lover to become acquainted with! The selection of symphonies allowed for a nice overview of the evolution of music across the ages. Obviously, the characteristics of the course will vary greater depending on the lecturer and how s/he presents the material. In any case, listen to the music! Know it! Love it!

If you like symphonies, you should definitely take this course, assuming it is still offered ? Professor Burnham was absolutely amazing, he leaves big shoes to fill but if someone steps up to the challenge, I'm sure it will make for a fun and informative course!
If you're interested in music without wanting to go into music theory, take this course! It teaches you to listen to symphonic music in a new way.
Just make sure to start early for the symphonies. Very hard to memorize last minute. Definitely take!
Prepare ahead for the midterm and final listening exams because it is impossible to absorb the information in a condensed time period.
Professor Burnham is amazing and pulls you in so well for lectures. Take any class with him before he retires!
SO MUCH FUN
Scott Burnham was an amazing lecturer for this course
Study for listening
Super chill class that will teach you about the language and impact of the symphony. Scott Burnham is bae.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Except that Burnham won't be teaching it anymore, which is probably 80-90% of what made this class what it was. I hope that, regardless of who teaches it next, it will be as stimulating and captivating for you as it was for me. If you just want to be know more about music in general, take it.  I don't know very much theory/music history, but I now know about sonata form, program music, and codas and have developed an appreciation for Mozart and Beethoven that I never thought I would have.
Take dis ish.

The Symphonies with Scott Burnham is one of my favorite classes so far at Princeton. At first, being an engineer and not having taken/played music for several years, I thought the class would be over my head, especially since many music majors and members of PUO were in the class. However, I found the class to be a complete pleasure, especially with Scott Burnham who is an outstanding lecturer and an expert on all things music. I was excited to go to lecture each class. The symphonies were new to me, so I was blown away every lecture by the musical genius of the composers and by the ability of Professor Burnham to discuss the music in a relatable manner. This course is great for anyone with a genuine interest in Classical music. Listening exams and papers require time, but they only happen periodically throughout the semester, so not too much work on the whole. Overall, excellent class. Highly recommend.

This class has a low time commitment and is not that difficult. There are two 4 page essays and a final 10 page essay. You basically do not need to go to lecture to do well in the class, as long as your essays are thoughtfully written and you are good and identifying music excerpts. Overall, pretty chill class and would recommend to anyone interested in classical/romantic symphonies.
This class won't be offered again. So sad.
This course is really awesome for beginners and music majors alike. The course staff is really passionate, and the class felt more like going to a show than a lecture. 10/10 would recommend

This course was amazing. Take it if you have any interest in classical music at all because you'll learn a lot about not only the music itself, but the composer behind the music and his mindset as he wrote his work.
This is the best class I have taken at Princeton.  Unfortunately, Professor Burnham is retiring this year.

Though no one will be able to take this course with Prof. Burnham anymore (he's retiring :( ) maybe the next professor to teach it will do a good job as well. The content covered is very helpful in educating someone who barely knows any symphonies at all!
Too bad that Burnham is retiring. If a good professor steps in to teach it (ex. Simon Morrison), then definitely take it.
You can't take it with Burnham anymore, so not sure! Good luck!
You need to take this class! Unfortunately, you won't be getting it with Burnham, which was definitely the best part.

great class with great lectures (although burnham is leaving now) 
the essays are kind of dull though so be aware of that
prereqs: Required background for enrollment: any prior course in music or some ability to read music..
descrip: Consideration of the symphony from the mid-eighteenth century to the mid-twentieth century, both in terms of musical procedures & cultural significance. The course is designed primarily for non-concentrators. The focus will be on intensive listening, minimal ability to follow musical notation helpful.

title: Elementary Arabic II
reviews: Be prepared for A LOT of work (especially vocab) but its rewarding
Be prepared to work, toil, struggle, cry, and see progress. Nancy is the best professor so do anything to have her as your teacher. If not Nancy, get Greg. Only Tom as a last resort.

Be willing to work hard this semester. Nightly practice and willingness to put in serious despite the repetitive nature of some of the assignments is very important. Also, be mindful of previous vocabulary and grammatical concepts learned, as they appear on quizzes specifically for the unit in a way that was different from first semester.
Do all of the homework.
Do not take this course.
I would suggest taking a different language until the Arabic department hires more native speakers. Nearly all other languages have professors who's native tongue is that language.
If you want a challenge take Arabic.

Take Arabic if you're willing to commit to a long time of practice, study, and interest.  The course load varies, with some heavy nights of transcribing sentences to easy online exercises, but overall it's a great course to bond with your classmates and get a window into another part of the world.  Ustaadh Greg is the best!
Take Arabic with Greg. He is an excellent teacher and keeps the course very enjoyable and manageable despite the pretty demanding workload.

Take Arabic. Get Greg or Nancy. You won't regret it unless you have zero interest in Arabic because it is work even if its not super time consuming or difficult- but why would you be considering taking an Arabic class if you're not interested?
Take it with Greg, no matter what your level of background or interest. He's one of the best teachers I've ever had.

Take it with Professor Bell- he's absolutely wonderful. The class is a lot of work- don't take if you haven't taken a foreign language before. But if you're interested in Arabic, you'll learn a lot in a year!

This class is a lot of work and more fast-paced than 101. You have to really stay on top of the workload and make sure you understand every concept. At the end, you will  be impressed by how much you learned.

This is a good class and Professor Greg is a lot of fun. I feel like my Arabic has improved but the class wasn't always a lot of fun. It could be pretty boring and there was a lot of work. Still, to continue with Arabic and become even better felt great, especially now that I can say so much more using this language.
This is an awesome class and the professor is great. However, be prepared to work hard-you get out of it what you put into it.
prereqs: ARA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course continues the study of Modern Standard Arabic and spoken colloquial Arabic commenced in Arabic 101. Emphasis in class is placed on active use of grammatical points introduced in the book; reading and writing increasingly longer texts; further vocabulary acquisition, and continued practice in listening and speaking Modern Standard and spoken colloquial Arabic.

title: Islands In The Sun: Caribbean Literature
reviews: An important course of material that doesn't really get covered elsewhere in the department. If you want to think about race, gender, sexuality, colonialism and historical trauma, congratulations! This is a class you should take. If you don't want to think about those things, tough! You probably should! This is a good way to do that.
I recommend this course as an introduction to ways of thinking about the literature of the Caribbean through deeply historical and transnational perspectives.
If you're interested in the Caribbean, even the music, take it. We discussed a lot of music and dance in the course aside from literature.
Take this course! Be sure to read the books and have your essay (midterm and final) topics approved. Use the writing center!
This course is as much work as you put into it.

This is a pleasant class. Not much work and you get to make a soundtrack/music is incorporated into the course. BEWARE, this course is not a caribbean literature course. The books are all essentially by diaspora writers

This was a great course and I highly recommend it if you're interested in the Caribbean legacies. The books are great and so is Professor Goffe. As someone with roots in the region, it was gratifying to take this course and reimagine my own conceptualizations of Caribbean history and culture. I hope Princeton offers it again soon, because this was the only Caribbean centered course that was offered in the past four years I've been here.
descrip: From the "Chigro" henchmen of James Bond's Jamaica to Edwidge Danticat and Junot Diaz's Haitian, Dominican Caribbean collusion, to the ethics of all-inclusive resorts in the Caribbean and offshore banking, this seminar explores the islands through their literature, films, photography, and the music of Mighty Sparrow and Bob Marley. More than simply a vacation paradise, at the center of the Caribbean is the legacy of European colonialism, African enslavement, and Indian and Chinese indenture. Students will produce a seminar soundtrack, selecting relevant songs each week, which will be mixed into a collective track as part of the final.

title: Ghosts in the Machine
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Disability and Difference
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Making of Modern India and Pakistan
reviews: Good course, you'll walk away with a better understanding of the region and the history. Focused on themes, which is great and appropriate for a topic of this scope. Definitely more introductory in nature-- no real deep dive, I'd say (I had no prior knowledge).
I would recommend the course to students who are looking to understand India from a cultural standpoint.
If interested about topic, it is a very good course. At times it may seem a little dry, but it is taught well and graded fairly.

If you are interested in learning about India and Pakistan, take this course. However, the course is not one of the most dynamic and entertaining courses you will take at Princeton, even though you will learn a lot! Not for everyone.
Take it, it's a good 5th class, and you'll learn a lot.
Take this class

Take this class for sure if you are interested in a sweeping review of the major historical and socio-political events / themes that have shaped India since before the colonial period, through Partiition, and up till the present day.  You'll learn a lot about religion (hindu/islam), ethnicity, caste, democracy, nationalism, etc. all through the Indian/Pakistani context.
Take this course if you are interested in learning more about India and Pakistan.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: An exploration of three major themes in the history of India's and Pakistan's emergence as nation-states: colonial socio-economic and cultural transformations, the growth of modern collective identities and conflicts, and nationalism. Topics covered include: trade, empire, and capitalism; class, gender and religion; Gandhi, national independence, and partition; and post-colonial state and society.

title: Intermediate Statistics for Social Science
prereqs: WWS 200 or equivalent.
descrip: This course has two related goals. The first goal is to give you the tools needed to evaluate empirical studies in social sciences. The second goal is to learn how to use these tools to analyze a data set methodically and comprehensively. At the end of this class you should be well-equipped for writing a successful, rigorous senior thesis. An important part of the course will be analysis of real datasets to shed light on particular policy issues in precepts, in the homework, and in the take-home exams.

title: What is the Euro Crisis Really About? Political and Economic Perspectives
reviews: A great course, I highly recommend it.
Course is worthwhile if you are genuinely interested in the euro crisis and what really happened, as a general elective I might avoid it because a lot of people seemed checked out.
Definitely very interesting, but be ready to do a lot of reading
Do it but make sure you do the readings and youll enjoy the course

Do the readings throughout the semester and you'll be so happy when the final comes around, seriously.
Go to class, Delatte is full of anecdotes and in general hearing the material makes it much more understandable
Do the readings!

Fantastic class. You'll greatly increase your knowledge in macroeconomics, not just the Euro crisis. Perfect combination of explaining the Euro crisis while giving a solid foundation of macro concepts.
Fantastic opportunity to actually apply the theory from micro and macro.
Good introduction to Euro Crisis, although you may not learn a lot after the first couple weeks. Quite repetitive as there is a lot of consensus about what happened.

Keep up with the readings and participate in class discussion. That's really the best way to get everything you can out of the class. It's a very interesting topic and Professor Delatte is very knowledgeable, but you must put in the effort in order to make it a worthwhile class.
Learned a lot, though the learning curve was steep for me because I hadn't taken macro yet (I took 301 concurrently), and we were expected to have a lot of the knowledge already.
Take it to learn about the debate surrounding the EUR crisis. Def useful material for a mature dinner conversation
Take it to learn more about the Euro crisis, the EU and applied economics in general
Terrible
This is a cool departmental. You get the opportunity to go in depth on a relevant current event and educate yourself on what's going on in the world.

To econ majors: great departmental, so I definitely recommend.
To non-econ majors: I don't think this counts as one of the distribution requirements, so take it if you're really that interested in the Euro crisis, but know that a good portion of the course does not deal with the crisis itself. 
To everyone: Delatte is a great instructor, and always wants everyone to input something in a class discussion. The general format is that she will assign readings for next lecture, and then during the lecture ask questions about the readings to kick off a discussion, led by her, of course, but supplemented often by the students. My general advice would be to do the readings and always try to make an effort to say something in class, and then the midterm and final should come relatively easily.
do the readings and participate in class
this class really teaches you everything about the euro crisis in detail and currency crises in general. would highly recommend taking ECO353 first
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 required.
descrip: Since 2010, European countries have faced sequential crisis episodes which have generated serious social deterioration, fiscal imbalances and fragmented financial markets. Should euro be considered as an experiment that failed? How has Greece which weighs less than 5% of the Eurozone GDP put all the system at risk? Can this crisis be overcome? The euro crisis is arguably an interesting intersection of economics, politics, and current affairs. This course combines international macroeconomic theory and political science analysis to explain the crisis and draw lessons on monetary regimes beyond the specific event under study.

title: Democracy and Its Enemies (Half-Term)
descrip: We examine how liberal democracies should react to political actors that we might suspect of being opposed to core principles of liberal democracy. Who should legitimately be thought of this way will itself be subject to discussion. Does someone have to engage in violence to be subject to sanctions by a democratic state? Can speech that is not leading to imminent lawless action ever be sanctioned? Should parties be banned that, like the Nazis, might come to power to end democracy? The course draws on historical and contemporary material from political theory, public law, and comparative politics.

title: Introduction to Hip-Hop Dance
reviews: Definitely take this class
Good for senior spring when you have thesis

I couldn't recommend this course highly enough. It is so, so much fun and you learn a lot. I had never danced before and thought I could never do it, but after improving so much I love dancing. It'll make you a lot more confident about your dancing ability

If you are interested in the subject, absolutely take this course. Be prepared to be challenged slightly in studio portions if you do not have much prior dance experience, but never to the point that the course seems unmanageable or loses its appeal. Overall, the course is a pretty minor time commitment and a great deal of fun.
Take it if you want to move out of your comfort zone, learn about hip hop origins, and have some fun.
Take the course if you're interested in learning more about hip-hop dance.

You're not going to learn anything more advanced than a six-step (look it up). No windmills, no freezes, no flares, so if that's what you were expecting then don't take the course. Otherwise go ham, it's basically DAN 209 except the dance moves you learn are actually fun.
maybe? see if they drop, shorten, or change professors for the lecture portion. KEEP STUDIO PORTION as is.
descrip: This introductory survey course gives equal weight to scholarly study and embodied practice, using both approaches to explore a range of hip-hop dance techniques, as well as the cultural and historical contexts from which these dances emerged. Special attention will be given to breaking - the most prominent hip-hop form - as a foundation for exploring other forms of movement. By critically exploring these physical and historical connections, individuals will adapt and apply their own philosophies to dance in order to develop a personalized style.

title: The Life Cycle of Behaviors
reviews: A good course, especially to fulfill the neuroscience requirement if you're a psych major. The material is actually really fascinating even for somebody that didn't want to take a neuroscience class. One awesome thing is that all work assigned seemed worthwhile and not like busywork. Just go to lecture (there's no substitute for this because there's no textbook) and pay attention and you'll be golden. Overall, definitely recommend.

A low intensity but incredible interesting class. Would definitely recommend! This class won't really help with my major or distributional requirements but I'm so happy I took it because I've learned so many cool new things.

Definitely take this class if you are interested in the epigenetic effects on behavior. If you are confused about whether or not you want to be a neuroscience major or a psych major, definitely take this course! Also Ghazanfar is the bomb!
Definitely take this course. Very interesting and manageable.
Developmental psych would be a better option. It's a relatively easy class if you have to take it though.
Don't skip lecture

Don't take it - the older reviews all say that Asif is super approachable and the exams are easy but this isn't true. Many people get terrible grades on the exams. The class doesn't have a textbook so you have to rely 100% on what Asif is saying. The class is 80% exams, so you really need a professor that cares that you understand the lecture material. This professor is the opposite of that. He answers emails but is condescending, rude, sarcastic, and dismissive of your questions and concerns. He doesn't hold office hours (you have to schedule meetings) and he avoids having meetings because he thinks precept is sufficient. Precept was extremely unhelpful and assignments were graded harshly without feedback. You will not receive any feedback on your assignments, and exams come back with scribbled writing but no rubric is provided. There is an arbitrary standard of grading. Once he asked students if they wanted him to wear a microphone so they could hear him better, a few students raised their hand, but he said he wouldn't because he didn't like "the disembodied voice" and then muttered "I'm sure I'll hear about this on the course reviews later." Princeton prides itself on professors that care about the undergraduates, but this professor is the opposite - he only cares about his own climb in the university rankings and will openly tell you that.
Don't.
Dongwon was a very good preceptor and funny too
Easy course, very decently interesting material. Definitely take if you're looking for a chill PSY/NEU course. Works well as a 5th class. Also, none of the exams are cumulative!
Eh. Not as described, still interesting, don't do the readings.
Good to take if you need a neuro requirement.

Great course. You learn a lot and Prof. Ghazanfar is a great lecturer with a really good sense of humor. He's really chill and definitely wants to make the class about learning rather than about how to get a good grade. Take it if all at all interested in psych or neuro!
I don't feel too strongly about this course.  The information is interesting enough, but pretty typical for any course about behavior.
If you aren't familiar with these topics, could be a good choice. Otherwise, steer clear.

If you have a strong science/psych background, this will be a very easy course for you (and even if you don't, it's quite accessible). Regardless of background, this course covers a number of really interesting topics, and Prof. Ghazanfar is a great lecturer. Definitely take it if you can!
If you need an STN, consider taking this course! Asif is a great professor, and you will enjoy listening to him lecture. Not too bad of a course.
It is interesting with not a lot of work.
It's an engaging course for those with wide range of interests/neuroscience backgrounds
It's, chill.
Just take it,
Lots of premed, hard science kids take this class so you are competing with them.
Pay extra attention to the lectures.

Ridiculously easy. Exams don't cover precept meaning they don't cover any of the readings in the course... There is no textbook, it's just lecture slides. Exams straight memorization and non-cumulative. Beware you have to go to lecture every time, but you put in zero work besides that. Easy A and even easier 5th class. Don't take if you're genuinely interested & have taken a class on the topic before.
STN that is pretty difficult but interesting. Take only if you have an interest in neuro/ biology
Such a good class.  Take it!
TAKE IT, great class, and really enjoyable interesting lectures
Take it if you're a neuro major!
Take this class! Interesting material, not too much work.

The course covers interesting and relatively easy material, but the grading I found to be much more difficult than other neuro and psych courses, some of which had even had more difficult content. Exams are short answer and graded to a level of specificity that might not be expected given the conceptual emphasis of the lectures.
The course material is very interesting, and can be discussed with people outside of the class; if you do this, you'll get better at reciting the information for the exams!
There is a particular way to study for this class, and it is taking very good notes in lecture and writing them out in detail on the tests. Don't expect lectures to last longer than half an hour...

This is a really interesting course. There is no need to have a neuro background to understand it. Make sure you understand the studies presented in lecture very, very well. You will probably be tested about that.
This is an easy class. Not that much material is covered, so it's pretty chill. If you're really interested in the topic, don't count on exploring it in much depth or substance.
Would not recommend this course, thought it would be easy and really interesting but found that the first test was extremely harsh and the professor was bad about responding to emails
Would recommend. Really interesting and if you aren?t in the sciences then it?s a great opportunity to engage with some topics that probably won?t come up that often or ever for you.
prereqs: Any 200-level (or higher) PSY, NEU, MOL, or EEB course..
descrip: The goal of this course is to illuminate the interactions between the brain, body and behavior over the course of development and how this shapes a species' evolution. We will first explore developmental events at the cellular level that are shaped by parental behavior. We will then see how these events influence the developing circuits of the brain. Finally, we will learn about influences at the level of niche or culture, where the changes that organisms make to their environments and to themselves influence and modify the patterns of behaviors exhibited in the next generation.

title: Graphic Design: Typography
reviews: Definitely take it!
I would recommend this course! David is great and the workload is mostly confined to class time. I learned a lot about how to think about typography and design.

If you are in the least interested in typography, definitely take this class. It is incredibly well-taught and provides students with a solid understanding of the foundational principles of typography through hands-on projects involving using a printing-press and learning, more practically, how to use InDesign. This is one of the best courses that I've taken at Princeton and it was the first VIS course I'd ever taken. I'm a senior and was disappointed that I didn't take a class like this earlier.

If you only want to learn about tools like Adobe InDesign, this isn't the class for you. But if you want to learn about the history of typography and how to think about it beyond just digital tools, then it's a great great overview.
Overall, a good class. Different from other classes you might take and not too much outside work. Reinfurt is cool, and you learn a lot about the history of typography and how to set texts.
Really interesting course!! If you're curious about typography and want to do hands-on work, take this. There's a lot you can learn. You'll see the world in a different way.

Relaxed course, most of the work is done during class hours. Class is done before Dean's Date. Learned a lot about design without even realizing it or having to put in a ton of effort. David is more approachable than some of the other vis arts professors, feel free to ask him for feedback on your designs!

Take it! David is a great teacher. He is so kind. He has a great smile and manner with his students. He is also very smart and both practically- and theoretically- oriented in his thinking about typographic design. Love him and love this course!
Take it. David is great.
There aren't that many graphic design courses offered. This is an interesting one to take, for typography occurs in all sorts of design
take it, you learn so much
descrip: This studio course introduces students to graphic design with a particular emphasis on typography. Students learn typographic history through lectures that highlight major shifts in print technologies and through their engagement in studio design projects. Class readings provide the raw material for hot metal typesetting in the letterpress print shop, photo-typesetting in the mechanical paste-up studio, and state of the art typesetting and design software in the digital computer lab. Overall, the workshop synthesizes hands-on graphic design skills with aesthetic awareness and a critical vocabulary.

title: Computer and Electronic Music Composition
reviews: If you're interested in music production I'd definitely recommend taking this course.
Jeff is super relaxed. 314 really isn't needed-there is no programming in this class it's just electronic music composition. No previous knowledge needed and super chill.
Take it if you want to make music!
prereqs: MUS/COS 314 or Permission of the Instructor.
descrip: A composition workshop class, in the context of the traditional sound studio. Emphasis will be on the student's creative work, composing both "fixed media" works and live electronic/laptop music.

title: The 18th Century - The Eighteenth-Century Novel, Reconsidered
descrip: The question of whether or not, around 1700, a form known as The Novel rose into being, has been debated for over 60 years by the discipline's most distinguished critics. Little has been settled. But the novel and its significance remain central issues in any attempt to understand 18thC literature. This course offers two things. First, an energetic survey of the 18thC English novel from Defoe to Austen. Second, an overview of important challenges to univocal accounts of the form's rise. Challenges include work on religion and the post-secular; new accounts of empire; revised formulations of "subjectivity" and new work on political economy.

title: Mesoamerican Art
reviews: Take it,  you will get to see a lot of things and learn about a beautiful culture.

This is a great course to take in order to learn about Mesoamerican art, even if you knew nothing about the subject before. Professor Just is great, and since he's a curator all precepts are held in the museum and you get to handle artifacts which is really cool.

This is the best course I've ever taken at Princeton, hands down. Prof. Just is an amazing prof/ person; his knowledge and excitement about the subject matter is contagious. Whether you know anything about Mesoamerica or not, you should take this course. The lectures are great, you get to touch actual artifacts with your hands in precept (which is in the art musuem every week) and the work is super interesting / manageable. Take this course!
Turn up to lectures
descrip: This course explores the visual and archaeological world of ancient Mesoamerica, from the first arrival of humans in the area until the era of Spanish invasion in the early 16th century. Major culture groups to be considered include Olmec, Maya, and Aztec. Preceptorial sections will consist of a mix of theoretically-focused discussions, debate regarding opposing interpretations in scholarship, and hands-on work with objects in the collections of the Princeton University Art Museum.

title: Topics in Paleoecology, Paleoclimatology, and Paleoceanography - Mass Extinctions
descrip: This course investigates biological and environmental effects of Deccan volcanism 66 m.y. ago in India that led to the KT mass extinction and delayed biotic recovery. Investigations include climate and environmental changes, weathering, ocean acidification and its effects on calcareous marine microplankton and the observed high-stress marine assemblages. The timing of major volcanic eruptions and the time elapsed between individual lava flows will be investigated based on red bole layers.

title: Earth's Climate History
reviews: Highly recommend. Get Bender before he's gone. Work-to-learning ratio is off the charts. Very interesting material and nice to hear it presented from the perspective on someone who has shaped the field for decades.

If you have prior exposure to how the climate system works, the first half will be largely a review. However, as soon as discussions about past climates began, the course became fascinating. Professor Bender is an expert on paleoclimate, and this course is an excellent primer to learning about different aspects of past climates.
TAKE IT! Professor Bender is great and really knows the subject

Take it!!! Professor Bender is an incredible teacher and wants to engage all of his students in each lecture. The subject matter is interesting and will teach you a lot about geochemistry and paleoclimate.
prereqs: GEO 202 and/or GEO 361, or permission of the instructor.
descrip: This course examines the nature and causes of major events in Earth's 4-billion year climate history, ranging from Snowball Earth to the "equable" climates, lasting hundreds of millions of years, when Earth was far warmer than today. We discuss the evidence for each event, and examine its cause by analyzing interactions between the ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere. The course integrates fundamental topics in paleoclimate, including biogeochemistry and stable isotope geochemistry. Three lectures.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Research Seminars
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; fourth-year students for 596; and fifth-year students for 597. The seminars are offered in four fields: political theory, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Masterworks of European Literature
descrip: In this course we will examine the major forms and themes of Western Literature since the Renaissance: the drama, essay, lyric and novel. We shall read major works by British, Spanish, French, German, Russian and American authors, considering the unique contributions of specific nations and languages and the transformations of themes and genres over a span of five hundred years.

title: America Then and Now
reviews: AMS101 is an interesting course. It definitely pushed me to think critically across disciplines and topics. The readings and assignments were mostly interesting. On the whole, this course provides an interesting EC, if you still need one.
Be prepared to think!
Definitely worth it; excellent class.
Don't take it.  It will literally just annoy you.
Don't wait until you're a senior to take it!
Easy course but very basic material
Fairly easy course, although not overly interesting. Very liberal, pessimistic reading of American history.
Get Elizabeth Bergman as your preceptor. She is incredible!
Get ahead on the essays
Go to lecture. Probably the most helpful with papers, etc.
Good class with low work load. Covers a lot of topics.
Good option for an easy class.
Highly recommend.
I don't really recommend it. It was trying to do too much.
I don't recommend unless you need it for the AMS certificate.

I would advise students to take this course if they're willing to fully engage and read the material. The course offers some amazing literature and makes precept a lot more fun when you can actually participate.
I would recommend taking this course if you are interested in the cultural, racial, and gender struggles of our nation's past that have helped shape the identity of present day America.
I would recommend this course because it serves as an interesting EM credit and covers important issues in the US.
If Elizabeth Bergman is not your preceptor.........sorry. She  is the make or break factor of this class. You have to have her as your preceptor, or I'm sorry you had to miss out on that experience.
It is a fairly interesting course but very long lectures to sit through
It is ok.
It's a good course.
NOT as easy as everyone says. very dry and boring lectures.

Overall, I really enjoyed this course, even though there were some logistical and administrative hiccups.  I thought the guest speakers were phenomenal for the most part, especially Daniel Rivers. This course made me excited to pursue a certificate in American Studies.
TAKE IT! You'll learn so much while engaging with important conversations in America
TAKE THIS CLASS!! Get Elizabeth Bergman as your preceptor! She is amazing. The class sparks your curiosity in a lot of different ways. Precept is what made this class so enjoyable, so don't miss it!!
Take it!
Take this class if you want a low work class.

Take this course if you need an EC or if you have a general interest in America's past. It is much more exciting than a history course, and I highly recommend it. Get Elizabeth Bergman if possible, she is AMAZING!
Take this course if you're interested in American Studies! The coursework is entirely reasonable and it's all very interesting.
Take this course! And if you can, don't pdf it. There's so much you can get out of this class if you take it seriously. It's not too much work, you'll do fine.

Take this course! Take it!!! This was by far my favorite course so far. I came into lecture on the first day with very little idea on what it was really about, and I cannot express how much I do NOT regret my decision. A lot of people will take it for the distribution requirement, but if you're any bit interested in past and present-day social issues (such as gender, sexuality, immigration, race, etc), then this class is a must. The assignments are interesting and leave you with a fresh perspective on contemporary topics. Try to get Elizabeth's precept - she is a wonderful person and truly made going to precept the highlight of my day.
Take! Manageable workload and interesting topics!

The lectures were terrible. All of the professors sounded like they were reading their senior theses word for word off of a piece of paper. As a result, lectures typically had less than 30% attendance. The readings are good and the papers had easy topics, but were graded too harshly considering how lazily the course was taught by the professors.
This course does not have too much work but sometimes the lectures aren't interesting.
This course is not rigorous but very interesting and enjoyable and a good introduction to American Studies that could peak one's interest in a number of areas.

This course is really great in a lot of ways, but in its current form it is not a very good class (though it is easy, if that's what you're looking for). The subject material is fairly interesting and it covers a ton of topics. However, its current format (80 minute lecture x 80 minute precept (that can even be back to back) does it a disservice. Additionally, it tries to cover too much material. What's more, we spent much of the class time discussing gender and race, and while these are crucial topics, they took up too much class time for what the class was billed. Also: having 3 professors rotate lectures disrupted any momentum the class got going, and this was especially tough because it only met once a week. If you are taking for the certificate or for an easy class: definitely take it. If you just want an elective: there are better options unless this course gets a makeover.

This course will be a little bit confusing since every week is a different topic, but I'd still encourage you to take it as a helpful survey class of American culture. It's definitely a simple way to fulfill a distribution requirement, and is of course a prereq for the American Studies certificate. Try to get Professor Bergman (Elizabeth) as your preceptor, she is absolutely fantastic, kind, and helpful! Also, you'll have plenty of help preparing for paper assignments, and the final is not too much to stress about.
This is a fairly easy class that does not require too much in depth thinking, but as such it is not as interesting as the description makes it sound.
This is a good EC course, but I wouldn't take it for fun.

This is a really good intro course, and each week covers a different topic in American society. The grading is fair, and the assignments are well spaced out and not overwhelming at all. Having a take-home at the end is nice, as opposed to a final paper. I'd definitely recommend it!
This is a very good class for those interested in American history or for those who merely need to fulfill a distribution requirement.
This is an interesting course that does not require too much work. Try to have Elizabeth Bergman for a preceptor.
Unless you're trying to get the certificate, don't even bother.
You will get out of this class what you put in. Be engaged in precepts.
do the readings
good class that doesn't take much. show up to lecture and precept and you will pretty much learn everything you need to know. Take this class.
it's very boring
lectures aren't that necessary, but you'll get more out of the course if you attend/ do the readings
recommend
descrip: This course introduces students to the intellectual and creative possibilities in the interdisciplinary field of American Studies. Employing literature, law, history, visual culture, and politics, the class will examine the idea of "America" in global, national, and communal contexts. Each week students will engage with primary and secondary sources dealing with a select key concept: e.g. citizenship, American Exceptionalism, land/property, race, gender, and more. The course attends to how knowledge about America is produced, disseminated, and consumed, emphasizing analytical skills, close reading, verbal articulations, and critical thinking.

title: Spinoza's Intellectual World
descrip: In this seminar we locate Spinoza and the Tractatus Theologico-Politicus (1670) in the exciting currents of seventeenth-century philosophy, theology, biblical scholarship and exegesis. Resituating Spinoza in Golden Age Holland we examine the resources and relevant controversies that shaped the Tractatus, with an eye to common concerns and traditions: the legacies of humanism and Reformation in the Netherlands, for instance, the larger worlds of his friends, as well as the vibrant Jewish community in Golden Age Amsterdam and the varieties of Christian lay piety that fall broadly under the banner of "the Radical Reformation."

title: Intermediate/Advanced French
reviews: A great course, with a manageable work load. No reason not to take this course, if you need it for a language requirement. Allows you to be creative and discuss interesting ideas with the french you do know.
Be sure to keep up with daily homeworks in the course packet.
Definitely take it if you want to gain fluency in French. Don't be shy, and speak as much as you can, because it will open doors for you (And cross your fingers for Charlotte!)
Good course.
Great class to take to fulfill language requirement. Not to difficult and Rachel Hart is an AWESOME professor!
I thought this was easier than 103 because it was less niity-gritty grammar topics and more focus on french history and culture in addition to all of the grammar.
If you can get Professor Hart, consider yourself very fortunate. She's amazing
It is good, well organized and fun. Only issue is it is heavily undergrad oriented, so the grads may feel little weird in classrooms.
Madame Hart is great! Interesting material mixed with less exciting grammar, but projects and presentations keep it engaging.
Overall, class time is the best way to learn and develop speaking skills. Don't be afraid to participate.
Take
Take it! Great for improving your French.
Take it!! Rachel Hart is awesome and fun! Not that much work.
Take it. Experience heavily dependent on instructor.
The best way to pass this class, is to do assignments in advance, have your teacher correct it and submit a final version. Also go to office hours. Basically, suck up to them; that's what they want.
This class is great! Try to get Professor Hart. She is wonderful and really wants you to do well!
This course is extremely engaging. If you love French, this is a great course to take. Take it with Rachel Hart.
This course will help you become more confident in your French-speaking and grammar skills! Take it.
This was my favorite French course at Princeton! This course does not focus on grammar and moves toward learning about French culture and literature.
a good class. active participation.
asdf;lkj
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103, or special permission..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while giving you a foundation for understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a selection of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material.

title: Intermediate Czech II
prereqs: CZE105.
descrip: A continuation of CZE105. Advanced grammar topics, building of vocabulary through studying Czech word formation and reading challenging samples of Czech literature (prose, poetry, drama). Continuing practice in oral communication. Three hours per week. Prerequisite: CZE105 or with instructor's consent.

title: Introduction to Historical and Comparative Linguistics
reviews: Fun course, can sometimes be tedious with the amount of work but very, very enlightening. Professor Barnes genuinely cares about the material and how well each student understands it.
Good course to take, though I would suggest having some linguistics background.
I highly recommend the course to any student interested in linguistics. This course will not disappoint.
If you have any interest in linguistics or languages at all take it! It's not that hard!
If you're at all interested in linguistics, I recommend this course! You'll come out with a decent grasp on how to reconstruct languages and how they are related.
Take a lower-level linguistics class first! You will have to teach yourself a lot on your own if you don't.

Take it! Professor Barnes is incredible - he's really nice, extraordinarily knowledgeable, and tends to believe that his students are as intelligent as he is (not quite true, but it's appreciated). The problem sets are very manageable, and you learn a lot without having to stress.
Take it! The problem sets are sometimes time consuming, but you'll learn a lot.

This is a fantastic course if you are interested in the subject. If you want to take LIN 201 as an easy class, do not substitute this class. Start the problem sets early, as some of them are brutal and require a lot of abstract reasoning. Highly recommended for anyone interested in languages and language change, this course will teach you a lot.
Tim Barnes knows what he's talking about. He is engaging and extremely knowledgeable, and I would take any class with him.
prereqs: Freshmen are welcomed. Prior experience with linguistics is helpful but not necessary. Knowledge of Greek and Latin is neither required nor expected..
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the study of language change and linguistic relationship. We will describe and analyze change in the building blocks of language (sounds, morphemes, and words), discovering, accounting for, and extrapolating from regular patterns manifested in numerous ancient and modern languages the world over.

title: Work and Inequality
reviews: Get a look at the syllabus ahead of time to make sure it aligns with your interests. The format of the course is great -- read one book per week, but read it carefully and discuss it in-depth in class. It was very nice.
I would say take it! It was a really good experience and shaped the way I approach reading a work of history.
Take it! It will challenge received wisdom about labor history while incorporating key insights from other historical subfields.
descrip: This seminar surveys classic and more recent scholarship in the history of work in the United States. Path-breaking studies to be considered include many that are imbricated with histories of capitalism as well as those that emphasize transnational approaches. Inequality will be a central thematic throughout the semester.

title: History of European Fascism
reviews: If you have any interest in Nazi history, it's really fascinating. Plus Prof. Rabinbach definitely knows his stuff.
If you have any interest in fascist studies, you MUST take this course.

Take it!!!! This is an absolutely amazing course looking at the history of Nazism, and you won't get another opportunity to examine sources with someone as well-versed in Nazi history as Professor Rabinbach.
This course is wonderful and Rabinbach is not be missed.  You have nothing to lose and everything to gain by taking a class with him.
descrip: This seminar will survey interwar fascist movements and regimes with a special emphasis on Nazi Germany. Topics will include the genesis of fascism as a response to political and cultural crisis, the role of ideology and culture, and Nazi society in peace and war. The seminar will focus on past and present historical perspectives.

title: El Nino: Blessing or Curse?
reviews: Course was interesting but generally unorganized and without a lot of focus because it was the first time it was offered.  I'm sure it will be more focused if offered again.

I really enjoyed this class, but it was definitely a very niche topic.  Most of why I liked the class is because I was really interested in the material.  With that in mind, definitely take this class if it is something you are interested, but if not then don't bother.
Interesting and easy course. Good for humanities majors because the science is light.
It was an interesting topic, but I was always so lost in the course, there are better options at this school
Very interesting material for anyone who has never taken a GEO course. Philander is a passionate professor and will appeal to your interests no matter what your background is.
descrip: The natives of Peru originally welcomed El Nino as a blessing but today everyone regards him as a global environmental disaster. What caused this remarkable change in perceptions even though the phenomenon has not changed? This course addresses questions concerning this product of coupling between air and sea from two perspectives. One is scientific and explores interactions between the ocean and atmosphere. The other deals with the social and political issues that influence the science, from famines in India to the ruin of fisheries in Peru, and floods in California.

title: The Arts of Japan
reviews: Good course
One of my favorite classes at Princeton - take it!
Take it whether or not you have art history experience. I had never taken an art history class before and found the work manageable while incredibly interesting.

Take this course if you are interested in Japanese arts (as well as culture!) or just for a distribution requirements. Professor Watsky is a captivating lecturer. Go to his office hours if you need help writing the papers! The course load is very manageable.
descrip: ART 217 surveys the arts of Japan from the pre-historic period through the present day. Painting, sculpture, and architecture form the core of study, though we will also examine the critical role of other forms, including calligraphy, lacquer, and ceramics. Throughout the course we will take close account of the broader cultural and historical contexts in which art was made. Our topics include the ongoing tension in Japanese art between the foreign and the indigenous, the role of ritual in Japan's visual arts, the re-uses of the past, the changing loci of patronage, and the formats and materials of Japanese art.

title: Quantitative Analysis in Psychological Research
descrip: An introduction to quantitative methods in psychological research appropriate for first and second year graduate students. The topics covered include experimental design, null hypothesis significance testing, power, effect size, and confidence intervals. Specific procedures covered include ANOVA, ANCOVA, multiple regression, moderation, and mediation.

title: Seminar on Education-Theory and Practice
prereqs: Prerequisites: See Teacher Preparation Program requirements. Course requires admission into the Teacher Preparation Program. Enrollment limited to students doing their practice teaching (TPP 402) except by special permission from the program director..
descrip: Seminar taken concurrently with Practice Teaching (TPP402). Students investigate the processes of curriculum development and implementation, develop learning goals and rubrics for assessment, study national and local issues in education and their impact on schools, examine current philosophies and effective practices, reflect on their work and evaluate their performance as practice teachers.

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French
reviews: Be expected to move quickly through the material.
Grammar is king, study it and you will do well.
While Vincent won't be here next year, I would encourage this course for other students, especially graduate students with some background in the language.
You'll probably get a B and it isn't terrible but man oh man is it boring sometimes. Take it, it's a good option for a language.
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Readings in Ancient and Medieval Japanese History
descrip: This course is designed to introduce fundamental themes and debates about ancient and medieval Japanese history, and how conceptualizations of Japan have changed over time from the third century CE through 1600. Approximately two books, or a comparable number of articles, are required each week, and wherever possible, a brief passage of Japanese scholarship will be presented as well. Reading knowledge of modern Japanese is desirable.

title: Approaches to Ballet: Technique and Repertory
reviews: Amazing for ballet dancers who want to keep up their technique! Loved it!!
Definitely take this class if you want to take ballet!!
I loved this class!  If you are serious about ballet and want serious training then this class will be great for you.
If you are a ballet dancer, this is the course to take! A wonderful way to maintain and improve your technique while also learning more about the ballet world.
If you are a dancer, you should definitely take this class!
If you are trained in ballet and looking to better your technique while also being introduced to new choreography.
It's really nice having three ballet classes a week consistently in your schedule (although it is six hours a week, which is a significant time chunk), I would definitely recommend this course.
Take this course if you are interested in ballet!
Take this course!  Tina is the best.
Take this course. It's wonderful.
The class will push you and keep your ballet skills honed while allowing you to learn more academically about the art form.
This is one of the best classes offered at Princeton. If you love ballet and love to dance, take it
loved it. absolutely take it if you are a dancer and have taken ballet before
prereqs: Application by Interview/Audition only. Please email Professor Fehlandt (fehlandt@) for an appointment..
descrip: This course will be divided in units focusing on Jerome Robbins, Antony Tudor, and other 20th century choreographers. Students will be coached by internationally known guest artists, Robert LaFosse, Amanda McKerrow, John Gardner, to master and understand the diverse styles of each piece of repertory learned.

title: Voting
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Unmaking the Bomb:The Science &Technology of Nuclear Nonproliferation, Disarmament, and Verification
prereqs: PHY 101 or PHY 102 or PHY 103 or PHY 104. MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers the science and technology underlying existing and emerging nuclear security issues. Part I introduces the principles of nuclear fission, nuclear radiation, and nuclear weapons (and their effects). Part II develops the concepts required to model and analyze nuclear systems, including the production of fissile materials and the detection and characterization of these materials with radiation measurement techniques. Relevant applications are explored in Part III and include nuclear forensic analysis, nuclear archaeology, and nuclear warhead verification. Such case studies will also be part of the final projects.

title: The Book in East Asia: Oracle Bones to Smartphones
descrip: What were books? Amid laments for the decline of "old media" and the discourse of permanent revolution that surrounds digital media forms, this course reexamines the history of human interaction with the written word, focusing on East Asia in the context of world book history. Emphasizing hands-on interaction with the changing material form of texts using objects brought into the classroom and visits to Princeton collections, we analyze the interplay between technological innovation and aesthetic expression in a series of scrolls, serials, comic books, and websites from antiquity to the present.

title: Dante's "Inferno"
reviews: A great course, but if you are taking for Italian credit make sure you are ready linguistically, because it is difficult to compete in exams and papers alongside your peers who will be taking the course in English.
Fantastic course. Marchesi is amazing. Maybe try to read at least a summary of The Aeneid beforehand.
I would say to really take the time to make sure you understand what you are reading before you go to class.

If you are very interested in Dante (and Virgil!), take this course! I have really enjoyed it, but I think it would be a difficult course if you are not invested in the subject matter. Do the reading each week very carefully. If you neglect that throughout the semester, studying for the exams will be very difficult.

If you're genuinely interested in learning about Italian literature, history, and culture, take this class! It's a fantastic opportunity to learn about The Inferno, and from one of the leading experts in the world. Be careful to read closely, however, and constantly keep in mind potential topics for your final paper.

Studying Dante at Princeton is a must!  The tradition here is so strong, and the interdisciplinary nature of the poem means you can apply your expert knowledge from any field and come to a variety of new thoughts and conclusions.
TAKE THIS COURSE! It is easily one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton and is worth every person (not just humanities majors) taking it.
Take it if you want to learn more about The Inferno, which means you will be learning a bit about everything.
Take it, especially if you speak Italian. I imagine you'll get more out of the course if you can read the text in its original language.
Take this class!

Take this course. Everyone should study Dante's work, one of the greatest references in world literature. Professor Marchesi is exceptional - creative, enthusiastic, funny, clear. It's also a great opportunity for an in-depth analysis of a literature work.
Take this course. Princeton is rightly seen as one of the greatest places to study Dante. Prof. Hollander's legacy lives on in Prof. Marchesi.
descrip: Intensive study of the "Inferno", with major attention paid to poetic elements such as structure, allegory, narrative technique, and relation to earlier literature, principally the Latin classics. Course conducted in English with highly interactive classes and preceptorials. One precept in Italian will be scheduled on a need-to-be basis.

title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified juniors if they have already taken COS 398. BSE candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Talking Politics
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Practical Models for Environmental Systems
reviews: Differential equations is not a must but is a would-really-help! No other class at Princeton like this and is extremely relevant to environmental science. You should take it if you want to go into this field.
Good course for anyone interested in environmental science. Workload comes in waves depending on when problem sets are due.
If you have done any other modeling than this class will be pretty simple. Make sure you start assignments early.
Lighter workload; Celia goes through more mathematical derivations in class, but actual math you need to know is simple.
Pretty sure Celia is gone in 2017, but if he comes back after then this is a great course to fulfill ENV/CEE requirements.
Really consider the background experience you have with calculus and coding before opting into this class.
Start early on all the problem sets, and take advantage of office hours if you need them!

This course is all about environmental modeling. It's a little different than in the past because only Celia taught it (so more quantitative, but also probably more unified and excellently taught) as opposed to Celia and Hedin. Topics are more like a few in-depth case studies than broader intro courses, but it all connects by the end.
This course is pretty interesting, but a lot of information to take in.

This is a good class that will give you a strong philosophical/theoretical understanding of how environmental models are created and modified. The downsides of the class are: midterm and final questions will involve manipulating models in a way that you have not practiced on problem sets, and a final project and the final exam. There's absolutely no reason for any class to have both final project and a final exam, it just takes up an excessive amount of student time. However, Celia is a great instructor and this class gave me a broader understanding of how environmental models can be made for virtually any system.

This is a great class if you are interested in potentially using any sort of modeling in your JP or thesis.  Also the lectures are very interesting and very necessary to do well on the midterm and final.  Not an easy class but very rewarding in what you are able to accomplish in just a semester.
This is an interesting course that is a good introduction to environmental modeling.  If you have little/no experience in Matlab, it will be difficult but probably do-able.

While sometimes the material is presented in a slightly confusing way and the professor arbitrarily changes notation without warning, it's a pretty chill course for someone who has done modeling and used differential equations before.
You really don't have to do much of the reading to do well. Just make sure you go to class, pay attention, and take good notes.
prereqs: Prerequisites: Mathematics equivalent to MAT 104 or instructor's permission; and Chemistry equivalent to CHM 202 or instructor's permission; and Biology equivalent to EEB 211 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Humans are increasingly affecting environmental systems throughout the world. This is especially true for activities associated with energy production, water use, and food production. To understand the environmental impacts, quantitative modeling tools are needed. This course introduces quantitative modeling approaches for environmental systems, including global models for carbon cycling; local and regional models for water, soil, and vegetation interactions; and models for transport of pollutants in both water and air. Students will develop simple models for all of these systems, and apply the models to a set of practical problems.

title: Research Program in Development Studies
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Experiments in Economics
reviews: 100% TAKE IT. ONE OF MY FAVORITE CLASSES AT PRINCETON

Stay on top of the readings (some pop quizzes) and it's a very interesting course. I learned a lot about both economic experimental design and how to evaluate it, and behavior in politics, the workplace, etc.
Take it! It's different and you will learn a lot in a bunch of econ realms. Go to class!

This class gives to unique opportunity to dive straight into the current economics literature on economics experiments. If you are interested in applied economics or policy, this is a great class to take. You learn a lot about research design and the process from reading papers and from designing your own experiment in the research project. Highly recommend.
prereqs: Students must have taken a course in econometrics, and should either be juniors or seniors.
descrip: This course is an introduction to experimental economics: its methods and some recent applications, both in the laboratory and the field. Rather than rely on a standard textbook, students will be expected to read and analyze current research in experimental economics. The course will provide a summary of recent experimental findings in different areas, and explain how to gather and analyze data using experimental methods. Students will be asked to develop ideas for their own experiment. This course will require critical writing and thinking and active class participation, as well as familiarity with basic econometric methods.

title: Beginner's German II
reviews: Amazing course. Really difficult but worth it.
Be aware that this course is a major commitment during the semester, and is easier during final exams week (80% is quizzes and 10% is a final vocab test which is pretty straighforward).
Definitely take! Great curriculum, and it definitely helps to substantially improve your German ability.
Do the homework, engage in the class.

German is difficult but the class is worth it. The AIs are so nice and helpful, and I often looked forward to going to class, despite it being every day because I actually enjoyed my classmates and instructors.

German is one of the best languages at Princeton - it's a very well run course. I think GER 101 is perhaps a bit more well done than GER 102. Also all the grad student teachers are good but if you can get Prof Rankin definitely do - he's particularly excellent.
Good introduction to German. I would definitely recommend.

I think you can get a lot out of this class but it really requires putting in the hours. It moves quickly and I found I had keep studying past topics to keep up and remember it all. If you really want to learn German this is a great way to commit. The classes are always helpful and provide good practice.
I would definitely recommend anyone with an interest in German to take this course.
I would recommend it!
Interesting language, not an easy class. But there are many outlets for help.

It should be noted that I essentially wrote to Sean and told him what I just told you in my review, because I wanted him to see it for sure. He is an excellent teacher, and no matter what grade I receive, he helped me learn the language, and was the main reason I still enjoyed German after a year mired in its grammar,
Keep up with the online homeworl
Learn vocabulary daily, ask questions, be involved.
Make an effort to immerse yourself in the language in class

Make sure that you keep up with the online homework. Even a day of not doing homework sets you behind for the entire unit. Also learning German has been one of the most fulfilling and stimulating experiences. Requires a bunch of time, more so than other lang. classes as I have heard, but worth it. The department is amazing.
Make sure you start assignments as soon as possible. They are rather time consuming, but if you are interested in German, then it may not be a problem for you.
Take German. Ich liebe Deutsch!
Take the course and go to office hours to get better at speaking

The professors are all wonderful and the course moves at a good pace. If you're debating between 102 and 1025, take 1025 if German is your fourth class (it would count as 4th and 5th and you'd have 3 other classes), but take 102 if it's your fifth class (where 1025 would count as a 5th and 6th class and you'd have 4 other classes, it's really not worth the stress).
The tests in this course aren't easy by any means but you honestly do come away form this class being able to read and speak the language rather well.

This class is fantastic if you want to learn German, but you'll only get out of it what you put into it. Actually learning will require keeping up with assignments, memorizing the vocabulary, and actively participating in class. But these do not constitute the bulk of your final grade--your test scores do, and these are not easy to cram for--so you'll have to be consistently self-motivated to succeed. If you put in the work, though, I think you'll find the course incredibly rewarding. You will learn a LOT of German language and culture in a relatively short time. The instructors seem helpful and encouraging across the board. Intro language classes are great for meeting new people from diverse fields. And, of course, you get opportunities to study abroad. Well worth the effort.
This is a great class! Very thorough. Not too much work.
This is a hard language but I really enjoy it
Try to get Anat if you can. She's great! Just keep up with Derdiedas and the vocab each week, and you'll be fine.
prereqs: GER 101 or permission of instructor. About 12 students per section. Normally no credit is given for GER 101 unless followed by 102..
descrip: Continues the goals of GER 101, focusing on increased communicative proficiency (oral and written), effective reading strategies, and listening skills. Emphasis on functional language tasks: learning to request, persuade, ask for help, express opinions, agree and disagree, negotiate conversations, and gain perspective on German culture through readings, discussion, and film. Participants are eligible to apply for Princeton-in-Munich, GER 105-G, June, 2016. The afternoon section, restricted to graduate students, follows the basic syllabus with added emphasis on reading skills.

title: What Is Art?
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Ecology and Conservation of African Landscapes
prereqs: Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya.
descrip: Only six percent of Africa's land area (containing a fraction of its biodiversity) is protected, and these areas are rarely large enough to sustain wildlife populations. Mostly, wildlife must share land with people also facing survival challenges. This course will explore how wildlife and people interact in Kenya, where new approaches to conservation are being developed. Lectures will cover the ecology of tropical grasslands and first principles underlying conservation and management of these landscapes. Field trips and projects will examine the dynamics between human actions and biodiversity conservation.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Leadership, Management & Decisionmaking
descrip: A brilliant policy that suffers from poor leadership or bad management is likely to result in failure. This course is about best practices in leading and managing governmental and not-for-profit organizations in industrialized democratic societies. We will assume that the policy problem has been solved and will focus on the non-policy aspects of being a leader and manager. This is a case study course. The goal is to place you in the position of a senior leader, a decision maker--so that you can experience these challenges, as much as possible, in the way actual leaders experienced them.

title: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies
reviews: Definitely take it. There's quite a bit of reading, but it's worth it.

Definitely take this course if you have at least a general interest in gender studies (or feminism, or studying discriminations in general). However, although it would also be good to take this course no matter what, I do not think you will enjoy it otherwise.
Do the readings and attend lecture. Not because you have to but because they are really truly interesting. Professor Salamon is great!

I encourage students who are willing to spend time on readings to take this course, regardless of the discipline(s) in which you are concentrating and pursuing certificates. Professor Salamon is outstanding, and there is a lot to be gleaned from the perspectives your classmates will bring to the table through their digestion of conceptually complex materials.
I would highly recommend this class. I thought it was very provocative and provides theory that can be applied to contemporary issues.
It's a lot of reading, but you'll enjoy it more if you give yourself the opportunity to actually do the reading and participate in class.

It's an incredible class and I think everyone should take this class at some point. It's a topic that's very important to current society, and coming out of the class I realize that I was making broad claims and statements about feminism without knowing anything at all about it. This class made me realize how  much I didn't know and also how little policy-makers, politicians and other influential people know about gender/sexuality studies and still think they can write laws. Please take it, do all the readings and you won't regret it.
Keep up with the readings, and come to class with an opinion on them so that contributing to discussions can be easier.
Make sure to read everything - not only will it help you when it is testing time, but each reading is really useful and valuable.

Take a picture of the syllabus, so that you don't lose it. Do all the readings - they are so worthwhile and you will not get nearly as much personal and academic benefit from this course if you don't engage with the texts. Also, don't be afraid or intimidated to take this course if you are not necessarily planning to pursue the field - the material is relevant for everyone and this course should be required, because it is so crucial to understand issues of gender and sexuality and intersectionality.
Take it, no matter what doubts you have. Do the reading, and participate, not just for a grade but for real life knowledge. It will help you.

Take this class, especially with Professor Salamon. There is not too much reading, but all of it is so fascinating and important. This is a must-take class for any Princeton student, whether interested in GSS or not!
Take this course!
This class should be required for everyone! All of the readings are transformative in the best way.
This course is life-changing. Be open to learning new things, questioning your own beliefs, and having honest discussions.

This course is one every Princeton student should take. It helped me learn so much about society and culture, and I'm so glad I took it! Great readings, lectures, and discussions. Don't go in expecting an easy PDF class and be ready to learn.

This is hands down one of the best classes I've taken here. Professor Gayle is a godsend, so kind and very worldly. The readings are deeply enriching on both an intellectual and personal level and I loved learning from it. For those concerned the workload is very low pressure. She knows how to assign work when its necessary but never bog you down with useless busy work. If you're even considering taking this class. Take it!

Wonderful course to take as an underclassman. Professor Salamon generates interesting conversation and it's a very safe space to practice speaking in class. If you're an upperclassman who has already thought through a lot of the issues, you might not find the conversations particularly compelling or challenging.
Wonderful course. It should be absolutely necessary for everyone to take. That being said, it is a considerable time commitment and you have to be prepared to participate a lot.
You must take this course. You should not leave Princeton without taking this course, regardless of what you identify as.
descrip: What does it mean to be a woman or a man? Or neither? How do gender and sexuality, those seemingly most personal and private of attributes, emerge from networks of power and social relations? This course introduces major concepts in the interdisciplinary field of gender and sexuality studies. We will analyze the ways in which gender, as an object of study and as a lived experience, intersects with class, race, and ability, and will examine the relation between gender, sexuality and power in literary, philosophical, political and medical discourses.

title: Art and Politics in Postcolonial Africa
reviews: If you're interested take it! Chika is really cool and very influential in the field!
This is a great course and you'll learn a lot.
descrip: This seminar examines the impact of the IMF's Structural Adjustment Program, military dictatorships, and political crises on artistic production in the 1980s, and the dramatic movement of African artists from the margins of the international art world to its very center since the 1990s. How familiar or different are the works and concerns of African artists? What are the consequences, in Africa and the West, of the international success of a few African artists? And what does the work of these Africans at home and in the West tell us about the sociopolitical conditions of our world today?

title: International Security Studies
descrip: Central topics in security studies, including the causes and nature of war, deterrence, alliance formation, military doctrine, civil-military relations, arms competition, and arms control.

title: General Physics II
