reviews: A big step up from the mess that was PHY 104 in previous years. You might even start to enjoy physics in this class *gasp*.
A fine class but dont expect a great grade unless you dedicate a lot of time.
A lot better than 103 and do everything you can to take Pufu's class because he is phenomenal.
A very interesting and important course, professor Petta is awesome and you will learn a lot.

A well taught course for a challenging topic. Find a good preceptor who is committed to helping students learn the material and pay attention in class. Not too difficult to do well in the course if you put in some effort.
Ask questions if you have anything. All concepts build on each other, so make sure you have a good foundation.
Avoid if at all possible. Too many components (weekly quizzes, weekly labs (with prelabs), weekly problem sets, etc.). Will take up lots of time. Generally unpleasant stuff.
Avoid if possible.
Better than I expected for an intro physics except for the labs.
Challenging because students have different amounts of physics backgrounds
Course is well taught and interesting, but a big commitment. If you put some work in, however, not particularly hard.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. It didn't improve at all form last year. I liked mechanics much more than this class. Labs were also the worst. Learn how to use breadboards before going to lab. You have to take this class so just get through it.
Decent course. Lectures are fun. Labs are not. ExpertTA is annoying at first, but you'll grow to love it.

Definitely better than PHY 103. Professor Petta is one of my favorite professors here, get a precept with him or Dr. Frey and you'll be good. Use McGraw for help with the weekly problem sets and quizzes.
Definitely not a bad course! Try hard every week and stay on top of the quizzes. They help tremendously for the final and midterm.
Definitely take this class. Great course and great instructors. The labs kind of suck though.
Difficult class.  Be sure to go to precept and lecture or you will fall behind.  Showing up every Monday for the quiz won't cut it.

Difficult if you haven't seen anything about physics outside of mech (Coulomb's law, waves etc.) because the class is pretty fast-paced and there isn't a lot of theoretical explanation of the concepts. A lot of exposure to the equations helps you learn them. Labs provide a lot of interesting hands-on experience.
Do all the class work because then you will understand the material and the whole class will be more enjoyable!
Do not take this class unless you have to. The textbook is really terrible, especially the first few chapters. The topics were not all that interesting, and the labs are just an annoyance.
Do practice exams, and go to class. If you can make everyone you'll be better off, though you can miss some. Get a good preceptor and you're set (N. P. Ong is the best)

Do the readings before the lecture, but don't worry too much about the reading; the summary at the end of the chapter is what you need to read the most, and use the chapter to connect the equations to situations.

Don't listen to any rumors you may have heard about pre-2015/2016 104. There was a professor change recently and the course is made a lot better for it. And all of you who sleep in and skip lecture, I'd highly suggest going to lecture, if for no other reason than to see the demos. Each one is very cool, and immediately applicable to that week's unit.
Don't take it unless you need it or like physics. I don't like physics, so this course wasn't for me.
Don't take it unless your BSE, this class is in need of a lot of organization
Easier than 103 if you know calculus. Great class in general - get the prof as your preceptor and life will be swell.
Even if you've already taken E&M, this class is worth taking again. It covered a lot of material that was not covered in the high school course.

Even though this course very well taught and interesting, it still is very hard, especially if this is your first time seeing electricity and magnetism. Go to McGraw often, do the Friday packets meticulously and definitely do not fall behind, as it is almost impossible to catch up.
Far better than 103. Professor Petta really wants you to learn and so do the preceptors. This is the kind of class that will reward you for knowing the material. Take it!
Find a good preceptor and go to McGraw for tutoring and help on problem sets. Not too bad, seems to have improved from other years.
Find a group to study with and get a good preceptor.
Find the best precept for you. Do lots of practice, make sure you understand everything.

Get Jason Petta's precept by all means!!! He will explain every concept so well you will not need to spend any time self-learning, only reviewing (unlike every other intro physics and math course). Best Professor I have ever had. I did not understand E&M at all when I studied it in high school but now I have an extremely firm grasp on it all, and I have never spent more than 1-3 hours a week completing problem sets and studying for the weekly quiz. Major exams are extremely reasonable and based off of quizzes and problems in Friday Packets, nothing we've never seen before.
Get help as soon as you see yourself struggling with the coursework/homework/prelabs! McGraw study halls literally saved my life.
Go to all of the lectures. Read the book. But most importantly, do not be afraid to go meet with Professor Petta because he is awesome!! I will miss this class.
Go to every precept. I did, and it worked out well for me. I had a 9am precept, so it was not uncommon for people to skip out on precepts, but they're definitely worth your time.
Go to lectures - they have cool demos. Study the Friday packets and read the textbook. Try to spend time understanding the homework and content.
Go to precept and do the friday packets because they really help with the weekly quizzes.
Hard but better than 103
Harder than PHY103 but also more interesting. Go to all the precepts and don't fall behind, especially around the complex circuits unit. Not a bad course overall.
I actually enjoyed physics this semester. I think that the course became a lot more organized!
I barely used the book, it's not entirely necessary. Go to lecture and pray that you get a chill Lab TA.

I recommend this class if you need to take it for bse. Be prepared to spend a decent amount of time on the class (7 hours of class a week, 2 problem sets). The material is hard but the professor is good and there are a lot of resources to help you if you are struggling.

I was disappointed with 104, except for the labs which were pretty good. I could be biased coming from EGR191 physics.
But since its a BSE requirement, just try to get a good grade, learn the material, and move on.
I wish I had done Physics C

I would definitely encourage doing practice problems for the examinations and participating in class when confused. The professor was organized and helpful, so definitely do not be afraid to reach out and actively participate within precept and outside classwork.

I would recommend taking this course, even if it's not in your distribution requirements. Lectures are helpful and the demonstrations are very interesting. the lectures might feel slightly rushed because of the amount of material, but I believe working on the assignments is a helpful way to understand the material
I would say to take it.
I would strongly recommend reading the book and going to the review sessions or office hours to help clarify any questions.
If Petta is teaching it, TAKE IT. Less brute calculation than mechanics and definitely more conceptual. Make good use of precept and choose your preceptor wisely. Shop around
If you felt like Physics made no sense in 103, you should take this class!! It's way better and intuitive.
If you go to every precept, you will get an A. It's that simple. If you're uncomfortable with the math, let your prof. know asap and he/she will help you out.
If you have taken E&M in high school and struggled, do not expect anything different from taking it here at Princeton. It is going to be hard, not make any sense, and be terrible.

If you have the physics background, PHY 106 might be the course you'll appreciate more because you won't have to deal with silly things like expertTA. 106 has pretty cool lectures, though none of the ones I went to were as cool as Petta's balloon demo.
But if like me you're not AP 5's in physics, or if 106 doesn't fit in your schedule, the revamped 104 (w/ Prof. Petta as lecturer) is pretty good. Try to get Prof. Petta, Dr. Skoge, or Pufu as your preceptor. Labs in the first half of the semester were kinda meh, labs in the second half of the semester were pretty great. The exams were much easier than they could have been, and I thought the concepts they tested were relevant and fairly marked. Don't sign up for a 9am precept unless you will actually get up for it xD, and don't miss precept because that's your main opportunity to work out problems and ask questions.
104 has been a good class, but in my case that positive experience was supplemented by some of the 106 lectures and by having lots of friends who love physics. Looking back on this semester, I'm glad I chose to take physics again.
If you have to take it, you have to take it.
If you're an engineer, take it in your freshman spring and get it over with. Shop precepts until you find a good one, because a bad preceptor can change everything.
Interesting class, really not that bad if you are taking it as a req for BSE, but I wouldn't take it for an elective.
It's a good idea to revise basic integrals and derivatives. The appendix in Tipler and Mosca should help you follow through the theorems being proven/ discussed in the text.
It's an interesting course, if you're into E/M subjects or any fields in which it might be relevant. You should take it (and you will, if it's required).
It's better than 103, but still a physics course. Use hyper physics if you want to actually learn stuff instead of reading the book
It's just a requirement. Take it if you have to. Don't otherwise.
It's not bad! The lectures are interesting and labs are easier than those in 103. Be prepared to brush up on your calculus/multi though.
It's not too bad
Its physics. you will take it if you have to. would not suggest unless you truly love physics
Jason Petta is the man!!!

Just get through it if you are BSE. Try to make it as enjoyable as possible. Go to lectures for the demos, learn from the labs, and finish ExpertTA assignments. The course is not impossible, but you do have to work and understand the material to get a decent grade.
Just go to stuff. The more you go to the more you'll get. Weekly quizzes aren't horrible, rather they help you to stay up to date with material
Just read the textbook and go to class. You'll be fine. If you're even remotely interested in physics take PHY 106 instead.
Keep up with the readings, otherwise your quiz average will suffer.

Labs are better than 103. Cool stuff, but not well taught. Expect students who have already taken higher level Physics in high school to destroy the curve and your GPA. If you need help, its never too late to go to McGraw or introduce yourself to your professor in office hours.
Labs are fairly fun. Demos in lectures are fun and engaging. Make sure you check out a few different preceptors before settling. Your preceptor makes all the difference in this course!
Lectures are good because of demonstrations. Labs are a horrible waste of 3 hours every week.
Look up your preceptors.
Make sure that you study for the Monday quizzes, and that you do the Friday Packets - they are good practice

Make sure to stay on top of the readings and assignments. If you do so, you will be able to understand the material for the quizzes and not fall behind. Almost all of the material builds upon what you learn, so it is vital to be on top of the work and reading.
Make sure you pay attention to the provided packets and practice, practice, practice problems.
Meh- not as bad as some people say it is, but definitely not a favorite. Keep up with the weekly quizes and you'll have no trouble though.
Much better than 103. Revamped with Petta so I think probably way better than 104 pre-spring 2016. Actually not bad at all and I absolutely hated 103. Material gets difficult in last few weeks.
Not really a bad class at all - but only take if you need to.
Not that bad.  A lot of people will say that this course is hard and boring, but in reality if you do the weekly Friday Packets, you will learn the material quite easily.
Only take if you have to. That being said, its better than 103 in terms of homework length and lecturer.
Only take it if you have to
Only take this course if you have to. It isn't very well organized and you have to teach yourself a lot of the material.
Only take this if you need to

PHY 104 seems to be on the upswing. Prof. Petta is really working to improve it. Don't be scared off by previous course evaluations. Hopefully it will be even better organized next year. If you put in a bit of effort to this class, you can do pretty well.
Pay close attention in lectures and this class won't be that difficult but will give you good basis for engineering.

Petta is an AMAZING lecturer. Likewise, get Pufu as your preceptor. Together, the instruction of those two is phenomenal. Stay on top of your work and go to office hours when you need it. Just suck it up and go to lab - those suck no matter what.
Please take this class with Silviu Pufu as your preceptor. It's an amazing class and I highly recommend it.
Precept is most helpful with learning the material.
Prepare for boring and incredibly long labs.

Pretty much everyone takes this class because it is a BSE requirement and they can't get out of it. This year, they seemed to be pretty aware of the fact that reviews for this class have been awful in the past, so they made a visible effort to make the labs more doable/interesting and to teach the content more effectively. As a result, I found the class to be doable and mostly engaging. I really liked my preceptor -- Monica Skoge, I found that she was really great at explaining the material!
Problem sets and labs are your chance to boost your grade.

Prof. Petta is the best! If you can, I highly recommend getting into his precept. He makes an effort to learn the names of all students and explains all concepts. He had previously taught PHY 106, so he definitely teaches you the proofs and background behind all formulas (which I found very helpful to my understanding). Also, go to lecture, but to necessary to take notes as lecture slides are posted online later! The demos in lecture makes sure that FIZX IS FUN!
Professor Peta is a good lecturer but the material can be difficult at times.

Professor Petta has  implemented major changes in this course that have made it far better than what it once was. PHY 104 is not as arduous as PHY 103. However, this course still demands a fairly decent amount of time weekly and covers a good amount of material so keep up with it all throughout the semester.
Professor Petta is a very good lecturer -- make sure you know what precept you're getting into though, as they will largely determine your understanding of the material.
Professor Petta is very good and a nice guy. He makes things a lot easier and knows what he is talking about.
Read the book
Read the book as much as possible.
Really tough class! Definitely attend lecture and class.
Stay on top of your work?don't fall behind.
Study for the quizzes each week because it pays off in the long run
Study way more than you think you have to for the weekly quizzes.  Definitely attend the precepts because they are the most helpful!
Study.
Take if it's required! Otherwise, it's not worth it...
Take if you're an engineer, otherwise it is boring.
Take it cause you have to. It's boring. Who cares.
Take it if Prof. Petta is teaching it! Also try to get Dr. Skoge as your preceptor.
Take it if you have to or if you are interested.
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you have to. It was taught well this semester, so if you are lucky than it will be good next year as well.
Take it if you liked 103 and are interested in electricity. Solve the Friday packet problems!
Take it if you need to or if you like physics! You'll only get an A if you took AP Physics C or are REALLY into physics, though....or if you work really hard.
Take it if you need to, but be ready for a challenge.
Take it if you're BSE, otherwise up to you!
Take it if you're interested in physics. Study for the quizzes.
Take it if you're interested.
Take only for requirement purposes.
The course is rigorous and challenging. Like any other course, you get out what you put in.
The course material covers a lot and can be a bit overwhelming. On the bright side, the labs are a lot less tedious than the old 103 labs (goodbye, 3 hours of calculating uncertainties)

The quizzes and exams are very fair so my main advice is to simply go to lecture, do the readings, do the psets, and spend time doing the Friday packets and past exams so you are adequately prepared. If you have any questions the preceptors are great at answering them. I think this is a great STL if you are more of a mathy person.

The staff for this course is fantastic; I had Monica Skoge as a preceptor and she tries her heart out to make sure you do as well as possible in the course. The actual material is about as boring as it gets. I don't think any reviews on here should sway you toward taking/not taking the class, considering it is an intro BSE requirement course, but know that the staff makes such a course as good as possible, whether or not you like the material.

They made this course so much better from what I heard the previous year! I happened to enjoy the material much more than mechanics and Professor PEtta did a great job with lectures. They made the exams more fair and quizzes as well. So, yes, its still a tough course but it's not as bad to go through so don't worry. Just make sure to ask for a lot of help if you need it.
This class has improved from how it was perceived to be in previous years - that being said, I would still only take the class if it is required.
This class is definitely not as hard as people say it is. The first couple of week are tough but if you work hard then you will do well
This class is much better than 103, but it is still a freshman engineering requirement
This class is not terribly difficult, but be prepared to teach yourself a lot.
This course is an interesting one if you are interested in physics, especially the lectures.

This course is far more engaging and reasonably structured than PHY 103. Professor Petta does a fantastic job in lecture (and if you can get into his precept, DEFINITELY do!!), and the labs offered far more opportunities to explore physics like actual scientists would. If you have any interest in physics at all, TAKE THIS COURSE!!! It's not easy, but it's doable and highly rewarding.
This course is not a huge amount of work, but do make sure you learn the concepts each week because they come back often.

This course is pretty well taught. Prof Petta really wants you to like the course, and that comes across pretty clearly, but unfortunately the material is just boring. You definitely want Prof Ong as your preceptor -he is excellent. Its not that difficult, but after a while you just won't care anymore, and if you haven't seen the material before in another class/high school, your grade will drop rapidly. Overall, well-taught, but not even the best doctor can revive a dead horse. Sorry.
This course may challenge you at times, but it is also remarkable how much you can learn and retain after just a few short months. Come in ready to work, and you will be rewarded.

This is a good course if you like physics.  I wouldn't take it if you are on the fence of whether or not you like physics.  Still, if you want to go down a physics track or feel confident you'll do well, I think this is a good course to take.

This is a great course! Petta is fantastic! Make sure you attend precepts and have detailed notes. The concepts build and if you can't keep up you'll fall behind, hard. Do psets early, like one week ahead. This will help.
This is a great course. The material is presented in a very clear way. Take Professor Waseem Bakr's precept if you can. He is the best preceptor.

This is a pretty good class overall, though the labs are sometimes just confirming what you already know is going to happen. The lectures are pretty cool as Professor Petta does awesome demos basically every week, as well as giving a decent review of the material. I wouldn't necessarily take notes during lecture, as you're going to be reviewing the same things in precept, though that's up to you. Be careful with doing the online homework because losing points for things like misreading units or sign errors is really irritating. Study for the quizzes; each week it may feel like you lost just a couple points, but by the end of the semester it can really add up. Try to get a good preceptor (maybe shop around a bit). I had Professor Gregor, who I thought did a really good job (though he will call on you regardless of whether you have your hand up, so be ready).
This is not a great course, especially if you are not interested in E&M, but if you have to take it, you have to take it.
Try and read ahead, it will pay dividends.
Try to get Professor Petta for your preceptor! He is amazing. Also, do the Friday packets and go to Mcgraw to be prepared for the quizzes.
Try to read the textbook every week or at least skim it. Don't skip precept, it's not worth it.
Try to study some electricity and magnetism beforehand, so you will be more comfortable with the material.

Use MIT's OpenCourseWare materials -- they frequently explain the material more clearly that the textbook or the lectures, and the only topic that 104 covers that i've seen the MIT lecture notes not cover is thin film interference.
Utilize office hours and McGraw study rooms for help. Understand how to do the psets and Friday packets and you should be fine.
Very good class. Try to get into Petta's precept!
Very manageable class if you stay on top of material and study for weekly quizzes. Do lots of practice problems and go to office hours!
Very solid physics course.
Well, it's required so there's no way around it.  If you truly are interested in physics, take PHY106 instead.
Will most likely take as a distribution requirement for BSE. The material and difficulty are comparable to PHY 103 so if you did well there you will find similar success in this course.

Would only recommend this course to non-BSE students if they were truly interested in learning more about physics. Content I found difficult, so wouldn't readily recommend to people not very willing to jump in and learn to derive physics formulae, etc.
Would only take if required.
Would probably not recommend to those who don't need to take it, but for requirements it's a good course
Yes, take this course if you are even remotely interested in physics.  While sometimes the math may be a bit challenging, if you put in a little extra effort, you'll understand everything!

You gotta take it, right? I heard you may want to take 106 just because it is better taught, but 104 is generally okay. Get a good lab TA, it'll make it way less miserable. At least the content is more intriguing than 103
You'll learn some interesting physics concepts, lectures and precepts were good but labs boring and too long
Youre probably only taking it, because you have to.
ask for help in office hours on prelabs you learn a lot
don't take it unless you really need to
dont take unless you have to for BSE
n/a
only take it if required. expect to go to mcgraw and office hours if you did not learn this material in high school
people love to complain but honestly this course is a pretty standard freshman course, not particularly "worse" in any way. shop for preceptors.
petta has done well with this revamping of this course.
take it but its hard
take it if you have to
take it if you have to.
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This calculus-based course is primarily geared to students majoring in engineering and physics, but is also well suited to majors in other sciences. The goal of the course is to develop an understanding of the fundamental laws of physics, in particular, electricity and magnetism, with applications to electronics, optics, and quantum computing.

title: Digital Journalism - Writing about Digital Culture
reviews: I learned so much about how to write a journalistic piece at the same time as I learned so much about the history of the internet. A once in a lifetime experience. Highly recommend.
Professor Kushner was amazing. He had high expectations, but they were challenging and rewarding.
The lessons from the class were invaluable for anyone with an interest in journalism.

This is a very interesting course, whether or not you already have a base of technological knowledge. If you're looking to hone your journalistic writing style, Professor Kushner gives you plenty of feedback to help you improve.
awesome
prereqs: If the course fills, you may email ldetitta@princeton.edu to be put on the waiting list. Please include a paragraph about the reasons for your interest in the course..
descrip: Digital culture is rapidly transforming our world. This course covers the essentials of chronicling this new technology and the lives of its creators and consumers. It's about learning to apply your skills of observation and analysis to fast-moving targets: social networks, video games, hackers, and more. Reporting these stories of innovation, obsession, and empowerment touches on the realms of art, business, policy, and science.

title: Human Evolution
reviews: Definitely go to precept for this course. It is Really interesting and you learn a lot.
Do not take this course! Complete waste of time, I didn't learn anything
Do the readings and take notes. They are often a good source of example material for the exams.
Easiest PDF I have ever taken. Literally showed up for ~5 classes
Excellent course, brilliant professor
Go to lecture and precept, go over your paper topic with your preceptor and attend the review session for the final exam!
Great class! A little slow but the lectures were interesting and exams were not to hard.
Great class. She is a wealth of knowledge

Human Evolution is a very worthwhile course! There aren't tons of assignments and the workload is not too bad. Plus, it's a fascinating topic and the lectures and precepts are pretty fun. I'd recommend this course, especially if you're looking to fill a prereq or want to get a basic overview of the evolution of humanity.
I think the class was good and would recommend it to people who were learning about evolution for the first time. It felt repetitive to me, but then again I just needed an EC that was interesting.
If you attend lectures you should have no problem doing well in this course.
If you're trying to get a feel for Anthropology, this is not the class to take.
It's an easy PDF but a poorly designed course.
It's not a lot of work. Lectures are alright.
Janet is a very nice teacher however the material is not necessarily interesting and engaging so if you can work to study for the midterm and final on your own it is not a bad class to take.

Lectures were okay but kinda boring. She doesn't tell you what she wants from her midterms or finals. I'd say it seems like a decent PDF but not an easy good grade if you aren't familiar with eeb types of things
Recommend
Take it. Monge is awesome.
Take this class if you want to learn about fossils, fossil sites, and the fundamentals of evolution.

Take this course if you are looking for the distribution requirement. There is no work at all during the semester besides light reading, the midterm and final, and a final paper. I would recommend pdfing this course.

Take this course if you have general interest in human evolution. The readings are really cool and interesting but not necessary for doing well in the course. The exams are graded very harshly. Final paper is very open ended. Monge is a riot.

This class is interesting and lectures are not crazy difficult, but there is a lot of reading and the midterm was difficult. More detail was expected of you for the midterm then was taught in the class.

This course is very interesting and has almost no work associated with it.  However, it did feel like a 100-level course, since it was a shallow and broad treatment of a very complex topic, and didn't delve much into the complexities of the evidence associated with human evolution.  Also, be warned that the exams are very harshly graded!
take it. it is elightening
descrip: An investigation of the evidence and background of human evolution. Emphasis will be placed on the examination of the fossil and other evidence for human evolution and its functional and behavioral implications. (See ANT 206B/ EEB 306 to determine the appropriate course for enrollment.)

title: Innovating Across Technology, Business, and Marketplaces
reviews: A lot to learn from very people with "field experience" if you want to learn. Projects are fun!

Definitely take this course! It is not very difficult and you get to hear guest lectures from some of the best people in the startup world! You leave this class with the basic tools to start your own venture!!
Don't take it!
Easy class, but attendance is required. You don't have to code if you want. Guest speakers are good
Even if you don't plan to take the course, just attend the lectures. This course has great guest lecturers.
Great class for guest lecturers. It was nice entering in with a defined group.
Great cos class to take to give you an idea of the business side of entrepreneurship.
Guest lecturers are worth it - the rest of the class is pretty disorganized and not great
I think take it! I learned a lot from it in a very different way. I love more practical classes like this one at Princeton.

I would not recommend taking this course. It's a lot of busy work, and I did not learn very much from it. The only redeeming factor is the guest lectures, but you can just sit in on them without enrolling in the course.
If you are interested in tech-related start-ups, this is a good course to select
It's the chill version of High Tech Entrepreneurship. Recommend.
Make sure you get the professor and the TAs to outline their expectations for the project early on. Guest lectures are usually good, JPs are pretty boring though.
Really interesting course! But the grading / assignments can be a little disorganized.
Take if you need a COS class and for no other reason
Take it if you want an easy COS departmental that doesn't involve lots of coding. Guest lectures are good but otherwise mostly meh. Project involves little to no feedback.
Take it! Not a lot of work and very interesting.
Take the course if you are actually interested in starting or working at an early-stage startup. Workload is what you make of it.

Take this class as your easy fifth, or PDF this class. Awesome guest lectures that you will have tons of takeaways and meet great people and manage to forge connections. Don't expect too much otherwise, this is about the most disorganized class in COS (when the average quality within the department isn't that high to begin with).

There will be a lot that you will have to figure out by yourself. But overall it is not a very hard class and if you find startups interesting, then you should take this class as it will give you an idea on how to begin a startup
This is a great course for anyone interested in the intersection between business and technology, and you might even be running your own company by the end.
arbitrary grading. random expectations. only shining light was the great guest lecturers but just have a friend in the class tell you when and who is coming
lots of cool lecturers
prereqs: COS 217 or COS 226 or equivalent. Interested Sophomores should contact Prof. Singh to request permission to enroll (jps@princeton.edu)..
descrip: Course teaches engineering students about issues tackled by leading Chief Technology Officers: the technical visionaries and/or managers who innovate at the boundaries of technology and business by understanding both deeply, and who are true partners to the CEO, not just implementers of business goals. Focus will be on thinking like a CTO (of a startup and a large company) from technology and business perspectives, and on software and Internet-based businesses. Industry-leading guest speakers provide perspectives too.

title: Materials in Civil Engineering
reviews: Good course: manageable as long as you leave time for lab reports. Lecture content is sometimes a little dry, but all you need to know is in them. Don't be afraid to ask questions.
Great CEE departmental. Material is interesting and Claire is fantastic.
Take it if you need to or if you are very enthusiastic about concrete. Also, Claire is really cool so taking it to get to know her is not a bad idea either.

This course is really fun! Start your lab reports early, post lots of questions on the discussion board, and get close with your lab group. Claire is a great professor and she is good at keeping the class engaged.
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: An introductory course on materials used civil and environmental engineering. Lectures on structure and properties of construction materials including concrete, steel, glass and timber; fracture mechanics; strength testing; mechanisms of deterioration; impact of material manufacturing on the environment. Labs on brittle fracture, heat treatment of steel, strength of concrete, mechanical properties of wood.

title: Calculus I
reviews: Do not take unless you have real interest or requirement; a lot more work than you expect.
Don't be afraid to ask questions. A lot of concepts are glossed over so stay on top of it in your free time.
Don't underestimate the Calculus 1 level course at Princeton. Still very challenging but I learned a lot and it was worth it!
Go to class and do the homework. Attend review sessions and office hours. Do not take unless you have an interest in math.
Hopefully you have some calc background before taking this class. If not, expect this to be a very challenging course.

I highly doubt you'd take this class for general interest, since if you liked maths you'd probably be starting in a higher level. But I guess if you just want to refresh high school calc knowledge and have a solid and straightforward QR then this is for you.
I would take this class. It is hard but completely manageable.
I'd recommend for students to ask as many questions as they can during lectures.
If you have not taken calculus before the course will be challenging if you do not put in the work.
If you need to take this class, do not worry it's not too bad and depending on the teacher it can actually be really fun.

If you take this class, even if you have taken Calculus 1 before, I would suggest attending all of the lectures. Tatiana does problems like the ones on exams and she only covers important topics. You don't have to read the textbook but you should do all of the homework because that will bump up your grade from the quizzes and exams.
Make sure you understand the material during class and ask questions if there is a part that confuses you.
Math is math. Take it if you have to. Would have rather waited and taken Math Alive.
Not a bad course.
Not too difficult. If you are ever confused go to office hours.
Professor Johnson is great!
Stay on top of the problem sets and practice practice practice!!!!
Take if you have already done well in Calc and want to fulfill your QR. If that doesn't describe you then take Math Alive or maybe comp sci.
Take it with Jennifer Johnson if you can. She's the best and also extremely funny. Go to McGraw and do the psets in groups.
Take the class and keep up with homework and you'll do great.

Take this course if you want to expand upon the calculus you learned in high school. Even though a lot of the material I covered in my high school calc. class, this course went into more detail and was more of a challenge.
Take this course only if you need it as a prerequisite for something. Do not take casually. It is challenging but also interesting.
The effort you put into this course is what comes out of it! Study for the exams and go to the review sessions.
They find a way to make high school calc difficult but it makes you learn your stuff well.
This class is a good class to take, but it is a lot of work and a lot of hours that need to be committed to it. Be prepared to do a lot of work.
This class is very well-taught, and the professors' passion for math is very evident. There are a number of resources you can take advantage of if you need help.
This is a challenging course, but Professor Johnson made everything a bit easier.
Try to get Tatiana!
Try to review after each class, and practice doing what was learned in class. Don't try to "learn" things right before a test.
Use your professor's office hours. :)
Very Hard. Take only if necessary

You're most likely taking this as a requirement for a major or something, so just work hard at doing practice problems and going to class. Prepare for the exams and office/review sessions really help. Especially with Tatiana and Johnson!
dont take it
only take if you have to
prereqs: MAT 100 or equivalent. Solid knowledge of precalculus (standard functions, algebra, trigonometry) is assumed..
descrip: First semester of calculus. Topics include limits, continuity, the derivative, basic differentiation formulas and applications (curve-sketching, optimization, related rates), definite and indefinite integrals, the fundamental theorem of calculus.

title: Readings in Classic Chinese Short Stories
reviews: Take this class if you are very committed to learning more Chinese and about Chinese culture. The work load is manageable if you start by reading the English translations. As a non-native speaker, this class is great for learning how to speak with native speakers in class, as well as improving writing skills. Easier work-wise than CHI 411, which is also a great class.
This is a pretty fun class. As usual, some of the readings are pretty... well, it's the Chinese department. But actually, you read a lot of different stories and I would definitely recommend.
Very interesting reading material. You will learn so much about language, culture, and history. Highly recommend.
You should definitely take it if you are interested in Ming Dynasty folk literature! Professor Chou is a beyond great lecturer!
great
if you like reading about late ming china then this is a great class to learn about the culture of the time period
prereqs: Prerequisite: three or more years of modern Chinese, or instructor's permission..
descrip: Focuses on reading and discussing selections from Feng Menglong's Sanyan, the most popular and well-known collection of Classic Chinese short stories published in the late sixteenth century. One class, two hours of discussion, conducted in Chinese.

title: Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: I would definitely recommend to any student who wants to do macroeconomics to pay a lot of attention to this class, as it is - to my point of view - a very smooth transition towards 2d year kind of classes in macroeconomics fields.

Learn the material during the semester - otherwise it'll be impossible to learn it all right before the test. Read the class notes and do as many problems on the problem set as you can (including the coding) since each one will teach you different things. They're hardly ever redundant.
descrip: This course is the second term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include classical and Keynesian theories of cyclical fluctuations; the determination of employment and real wages; credit markets and financial stability; and stabilization policy.

title: Gold, Gods, Kink, and the Modern Fetish
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Information Retrieval, Discovery, and Delivery
reviews: Boring lectures, confusing exams, but still manageable and straightforward. Personally, I would recommend taking a harder course that provides bigger challenges and actually gives you some sort of intellectual payoff. This course has no arc and failed to connect the topics covered on a meaningful level.
Don't take this class if Yinda is a TA -- his grades are arbitrary and he is unhelpful.
Final project is fun!
Good course. A "Do what you want" project at the end of the semester.
I would advise against this course if people are taking it for the applications track. I think that there are other courses that may provide more engagement.
If you are interested in the material its good! If not, then dont take it.
Interesting material and manageable workload.
It can be a bit dry but Prof. LaPaugh really does care and the final project can be really fun.

It is a relatively easy distribution requirement. That being said, I know a lot of people who dropped because they were not doing well. I would say find another Applications course, better are out there.
It's an okay course.  You'll still learn a decent amount of interesting stuff, but there is a lot of bland topics too

Not a difficult course but the project is more of a pain than anything and the lectures/topics/readings are all very boring and dry. Not a class to take if you want something that will hold your interest.
Really dry, don't take it you will regret it...
Really easy spring COS departmental, but lectures are super dry and not necessary to complete the problem sets. Andrea LaPaugh is a sweetheart.
Take it if you're already interested in the subject matter. If you're not, it may be difficult to follow the lectures and readings as they can be very dry at times
Take the course if you have a research interest in the field. Otherwise, look elsewhere first. The lectures cover important material but they're dry and the problem sets are very open ended.

Take this class if you want a pretty low-key COS departmental. Lectures are slow and dry but all the info is on the slides. Tricky grading sometimes on the assignments and the exams are annoying timing-wise but not too horrible. Project is low key but counts for a good chunk of your grade. Not a horrible class overall but I wouldn't count it as a favorite.

This is a good course - lectures can seem a bit dry but the topics are quite interesting and can actually be useful. The final project is a plus, as well. That said, don't take this course with Yinda as a TA - the grading is unnecessarily harsh and unexpected

This is an applications course, but there are ABSOLUTELY NO PROGRAMMING ASSIGNMENTS. Do not take if you're expecting to learn how to code your own search engine etc. Otherwise is a mediocre class that talks about various topics relating to IR. Pick a more engaging and fun class instead.
Though less work than a typical COS departmental, lectures are very cluttered and difficult to get through, and the material is not made interesting. Would not recommend this course.
prereqs: COS 226 and some familiarity with linear algebra..
descrip: This course examines the methods used to gather, organize and search for information in large digital collections (e.g. web search engines). We study classic techniques of indexing documents and searching text and also new algorithms that exploit properties of the Web (e.g. links) social networks and other digital collections, including multimedia collections. Techniques include those for relevance and ranking of documents, exploiting user history, and information clustering. We also examine systems aspects of search technology: how distributed computing and storage are used to make information delivery efficient.

title: The Ethnographer's Craft
reviews: Don't take this class unless you have to, or if the syllabus changes drastically..
I would say definitely take it! You will learn a lot, and be learning from who is my favorite faculty member at this school.
Take this course if you enjoy reflecting on research methods and cultural biases! Be open to the opinions presented in the readings and by your peers.

There are many readings, but if you skip over some of them the workload is not difficult. Conducting your own ethnography may be the most rewarding part of the class because some of the readings are very dense.
prereqs: For administrative reasons, there are two ways of enrolling in ANT 301A/B. ANT 301A is for all students other than juniors in the Anthropology major. ANT 301B is reserved for Anthropology juniors, as it includes enrollment in the Anthropology junior seminar. ANT 301A and B are otherwise the same, and meet together..
descrip: What are the core approaches of the anthropological method, as well as the distinctive forms of knowledge that they offer? How has ethnography emerged within a broader universe of social scientific approaches? We examine classical methods, their itineraries in multiple ethnographic domains, and their afterlives in the plurality of contemporary anthropology. We examine these techniques with careful attention to their social, political, and ethical dimensions. In so doing, we work to understand the perils and the great revelatory power of ethnography, including the many counterintuitive and creative insights it can offer into our own worlds.

title: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
reviews: Excellent course!
Great course on an important subject. Do the readings.

I learned a lot in this class, and it was incredibly useful to provide context and perspective on the conflict from the early 1900s onward.  The class was overwhelming at times because of the sheer amount of information, but it was useful and interesting.
I recommend if you are good at doing a lot of reading and listening to sometimes dry lectures

I recommend this course to other students. I really enjoyed Professor Kurtzer's teaching and feel like I have a much better insight into the Arab-Israeli conflict than I had before. I'm very happy I took this class.
I would highly recommend taking this if you are interested in the subject matter. Ambassador Kurtzer knows his stuff and provides a pretty balanced perspective.

I would recommend this to anyone who wants a comprehensive and pretty centrist view of the Arab-Israel Conflict. Really interesting guy and super nice/helpful, although he lectures a lot and can sometimes get a little boring
It's a little dry.
Kurtzer shares some really interesting stories, but only take this class for him, not for the material.
Take it! It takes a little effort to get through all of the readings but if you're at all interested in this area of the world it's an excellent course.

This course was not at all what I thought it would be. Be aware that you will not be discussing or analyzing history in class (but will be expected to do so for the midterm and final). It was cool to hear about the conflict from the perspective of someone who has been so involved in diplomacy, but this course was not at all what I expected and could have been organized much better.
You will need to read many pages and stay focused for many hours.  Content is interesting but the midterm was brutal.
descrip: The course examines the history and dynamics of the struggle between the Jewish and Palestinian national movements for sovereignty and control over territory each claims as its historic homeland. The course will review the inter-state dimension: the competition between national movements; wars and their aftermath; and diplomatic efforts to achieve peace.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Qualitative Research Methods
descrip: In this course, we consider which research questions are best answered with qualitative methods, and when/if qualitative and quantitative approaches should be combined. We examine different qualitative research designs, and their relationship to causal claims. We consider different types of qualitative data, with a focus on interviews. We discuss the analysis and presentation of qualitative data. We consider how qualitative methods can be used in program and policy evaluation.

title: Translation Theory: Teaching in Translation
descrip: Disciplines across the university rely on texts in translation for research and teaching alike. Yet few of us, from undergraduates to professors, have been trained to discuss translated materials as translations. If each translation embodies an interpretation of an original, how does this affect our own reliance on and interpretation of these texts? This course fosters a responsible pedagogy of translated texts, first and foremost by offering a solid foundation in translation theory and translation studies. Students also design a syllabus for an undergraduate course in their field; students from all disciplines welcome.

title: History of American Popular Entertainments
reviews: Absolutely take this class. Prof. Herrera is incredible and such an amazing lecturer.

Attendance is mandatory, but so worth it. I have never loved the material of lectures as much as I did in this class. There are 4-5 short projects throughout the semester, and all build upon each other to make a fun and different final project as opposed to a paper of exam.
Brian Herrera is fantastic. This was a really unique course that will make you think about how entertainment plays into politics, society and culture.
Great class! Thoroughly enjoyed!
Herrera is tremendous. If you think you'd be even a little interested in the class material, take this class.
I highly recommend this course.  The professor is awesome and all the material is really engaging
It's a fun course, light work and Herrera is incredible as a human and a professor-- I strongly recommend it if you have any interest whatsoever in popular entertainment.

Lecture material is interesting and engaging, class keeps everyone involved through the entire semester. Not allowed to miss lecture so everyone goes and participates. Assignments are mostly unrelated to readings/lecture content, but leave lots of room for exploring one's own interests that coincide with course themes.
None
Professor Herrera is very approachable and open to different ideas. The readings are interesting.
Read and participate
Really great course! Herrera is amazing!
TAKE IT!
TAKE THIS CLASS - pay attention in lecture because it's just all around enjoyable

Take this class! Do the readings because they are genuinely enjoyable. Go to class! It is basically a storytelling session twice a week with an extremely knowledgable professor. You will absolutely not regret taking this class.

The course itself is very interesting, and Herrera and Rozen led wonderful lectures and discussions that really make the class that much more enjoyable. As long as you keep up with the material, you definitely will like the course.
This course is awesome! Great readings and lectures!!

This is a fascinating, engaging course that provides much food for thought on the nature of entertainment, on deconstructing platforms, brands, and icons, and on connections between such various historical performers as P.T. Barnum and Walt Disney, or between Edwin Forrest and Donald Trump. The papers are not conventional papers but require more creativity and flexibility, but are also smaller and more manageable, so be aware of that, and start your dossier well in advance of Dean's Date.
descrip: This course investigates the history of popular entertainments in the United States from the colonial era to the present. Moving briskly among some of the myriad sites, sounds and spectacles that have captivated diverse American audiences, this course tracks how entertainment genres, venues, personalities and phenomena have shaped U.S. culture in enduring and significant ways. This course examines how U.S. entertainment--as simultaneously industrial operation and cultural production--has mapped routes of social encounter, mobility and resistance, while also serving as a platform for individual expression and imaginative escape.

title: Intermediate Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian II
descrip: A continuation of BCS 105. Advanced-level class with emphasis on oral and written communication; reading literary texts of interest to students; films

title: Integrated Engineering Science Laboratory
reviews: Alright
Be careful of the lab-reports.. They are different form themo and take a lot of time.
Don't.
Get help from a TA like Matt Fu, or get someone as good as him. Otherwise, if you run into problems, you're on your own
Getting the right lab TA can be crucial towards how well you do/how much you learned. Probably the best lab class yet, in terms of actual materials though.
Good course. Work together and ask lots of questions for lab reports.
If Pithy is still around, be ready for some frustration over that. Just try to push through that and enjoy the cool stuff that the lab intends to engage you with.

If you're taking it you probably have to. It gets better second semester. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on lab reports (15-20 hours per report) - the analysis takes a long time. Get a lab group you like.
Just stay true to the grading rubric. It's hard to figure out what they expect otherwise.
MAEs you have no choice, take it. It is an enjoyable expereince and you do learn how the stuff you learn in thermo and fludis can apply to some parts of the real world.
Majority of labs are interesting. Make sure you really encourage the TAs to help you.
No need unless you are MAE.
Only take if you're MAE. Fluids is great, thermo is boring :(
Only take this course if required. It is not the most interesting lab course as there is very little design involved.
Really interesting material - gets you excited to be MAE.
Start labs early and work with your partners on it.
Talk to Mike to really understand what the setup is doing and how each instrument works/how it measures
The lab reports are graded in pretty arbitrary ways. Make sure you take the time to do them well. They'll take a while. Generally interesting labs - much better than thermo.

This class is the first time in MAE that you really start to do hands-on experiments on really cool and applicable things. Take advantage of it, but be sure to ask many questions, and understand exactly what they are looking for in the lab reports, cause this was very hard to gauge for me.
Wide variation in helpfulness of the TAs, so pick wisely.  Overall it was decently interesting and not too stressful.
You do cool stuff but sometimes you have to stay up quite late if you do not allocate your time well.
You're probably taking this because you have to, Marcus is very sweet and you'll get through it.
you have to take it
prereqs: MAT 104, MAT 202 (may be taken concurrently), MAE 222 (must be taken concurrently). Laboratory report grades from MAE 221 fall semester will be incorporated into final grade of MAE 224.
descrip: Students will conduct a series of prepared experiments throughout the year that will culminate in an independent project of the students' design involving fluid mechanics, thermodynamics and data acquisition tools. Concepts learned will be applied in subsequent labs involving expanding flows and lift and drag measurements. Experiments will include internal and external flows.

title: Photonics and Light Wave Communications
reviews: Course is ok. I feel like there's some overlap with other optics courses, so it can feel repetitive depending on if you've already taken other optics courses. This course is known for being pretty easy, but it actually depends on who your TA is.
Good ELE breadth course. Would recommend!
Great class, especially if you're interested in fiber optics, communications, systems! You'll learn things and still be happy!
I would advise taking this course. It is a great learning experience.
I would recommend this course if you have interest in optics or in communication systems.

I'd highly suggest other students to take this course if they're interested in learning more about Photonics! Professor Prucnal is the best professor I've had at Princeton - he makes sure that his students are engaged and understand the subject matter. This course was very informative and well-organized.

Loved the class! Prof. Prucnal's lectures strike the perfect balance between covering technical material and helping you appreciate the big picture. The subject matter that you cover is what enables modern-day Internet, telephone, and television, to name a few. I didn't think I would be totally interested in the area before this class, but now I am. Overall mild workload, and the presentations at the end of the semester are a fun way to learn about cutting-edge research in optics and communications.
Take it if you're curious about the future of technology.
Take it!
Take this class! It's not a lot of work and you learn a lot.
This is a very interesting course. Professor Prucnal's lectures are amazing! You learn a lot without having an overwhelming amount of work to do.
descrip: This course provides a working knowledge of the components comprising fiber-optic networks, which form the backbone of today's communication networks, including the global internet, 4G wireless, home access (e.g., FiOS), and data center networks. The operation of lasers, fiber optics and optical routers will be discussed, as will current applications such as fiber to the home, the broadband wireless-optical interface, all-optical switching, signal processing and computing, and security in fibers. The course provides hands-on lab experience with fiber measurements and splicing, and frequent visits to the fiber optics lab and demonstrations.

profs.name: Andrea de Castro Melloni, Course Head

title: Intermediate Portuguese
reviews: Any students considering taking this course should pay close attention to the course readings; discussions that focus on readings are one of the most helpful aspects of the course.
Great course ! It is a lot of work but it is worth it because you learn a lot. Andrea is an incredible teacher.. if you can take this course I highly recommend it
Take it! Meet with Andrea outside of class if you want to correct your writing further.
Take this course! Andrea is great and will ensure that you'll have a good understanding of Portuguese.

This class is one of the best that I've taken at Princeton. Andrea cares so much about her students, and works very hard to get everyone engaged in Portuguese. In general, the Portuguese department at Princeton is incredibly engaged and enthusiastic, and I find their energy level to be infectious. POR 109 will challenge your reading and writing skills significantly, and you will be able to discuss complex topics in reasonable detail after taking this course. I think that's a super empowering feeling, and the course is structured in a way that rarely feels stressful or onerous. Lectures are pretty fun experiences where you just converse in a way that organically teaches you about the language. Feedback on all written assignments is amazingly thorough, and this course will especially improve your ability in writing in Portuguese. 

Between the structure of the material and the daily enthusiasm of Andrea, there are few courses that I would recommend more highly than this one.
You get out of this course as much as you put in. Do yourself a favor and take this course.
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.

title: Health Economics II
descrip: Examines issues in global health. Specific topics include effects of health on growth and development; health, nutrition and productivity; the relationship between health and height; the relationship between education and health; structural problems in health service delivery in developing countries; and the impact of the AIDS crisis on economic wellbeing; measurement of health and well-being around the world. Prerequisites: PhD-level microeconomics and econometrics.

title: Junior Seminars
descrip: A special section of HIS 400 for sophomores intending to major in History and who intend to spend Junior year fall term or the year abroad. Normally required of all juniors in the fall term, the seminar serves to introduce majors to the tools, methods and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This seminar concentrates on the history of property: cultures, practices and institutions of ownership in Europe, United States and Asia, from Early Modern times to the 1990s.

title: Topics in Differential Equations - Local and global regularity of nonlinear evolution equations
prereqs: For advanced level undergrads and graduate students..
descrip: We discuss the question of local and global existence of solutions of certain quasilinear evolution equations. These equations include plasma and water wave models. The main techniques include energy methods and semilinear harmonic analysis.

title: Old Novels, New Games: Gaming: Cultures in East Asia
reviews: Decent course, but needs a bit more structure. Take if you're really interested in the subject. Will get you thinking about gaming!
Definitely take this course!

I'd say this: don't expect this to be a course all about gaming. It's not, and most of it involves readings about other aspects of literature (and gaming), especially pertaining to Three Kingdoms. However, if you put that in your mind as a starting point the class does get interesting, with surprisingly many interesting readings. both the precepts and lectures are very high quality. Expect to be annoyed by the biweekly format of papers, but know that they are short.
Interesting material, but the organization could use some work. Definitely go to lecture though.
Take it if you like videogames!

The bro-duo of Prichard and Keulemans, seeking to reconnect with their video-gaming glory days while staying scholarly, have offered students a trade. "We can learn about video games and spend a ton of time talking about them, watching them, and playing them", they say, "but only if we ALSO spend a lot of time on the ancient Chinese novel Three Kingdoms and the associated culture". Take that deal, friends. That's a great goddamn deal. You'll be surprised - after a few months in the course, Three Kingdoms will be almost more interesting than the games!
This class is about much more than video games - you'll be asked to think critically and thoughtfully about humanities-based scholarship.
Very fun course to understand some of the cultural and artistic nuances to video games. The readings are fun, and it is interesting to see how a narrative transforms across media.
descrip: Video games have in the last 40 years morphed from lab experiments at MIT into a billion-dollar worldwide entertainment. How can we engage with this fast growing media platform in a critically engaged and humanities-based manner? This class does so by placing video-game culture in a much longer, two-thousand year old East Asian history of media transformations. Starting with a single historical event, The Three Kingdoms, we trace how this event was renarrativized and remediated through many incarnations from official dynastic history to contemporary video game and from Chinese novel and Japanese game to American gaming communities.

title: Engineering the Climate: Technical & Policy Challenges
reviews: I recommend this class if you are interested in climate engineering. Don't need too much of a science background.
Make sure to do the reading carefully and closely.
Recommended primarily on strength of topic, though it was also very well-presented.
This class is ok on the workload, and you do end up learning a fair amount. But the way the material is presented could be better.
This is really interesting and I learned a ton about climate engineering!
take the course and become more aware
prereqs: Freshman physics and mathematics. Social science and humanities majors who are interested in the topic but lack a physics and math background are welcome and encouraged to contact Prof. Kolemen to discuss whether they may enroll in the course..
descrip: This seminar focuses on the science, engineering, policy and ethics of climate engineering -- the deliberate human intervention in the world climate in order to reduce global warming. Climate/ocean models and control theory are introduced. The technology, economics, and climate response for the most favorable climate engineering methods (carbon dioxide removal, solar radiation management) are reviewed. Policy and ethics challenges are discussed.

title: Inca Art and Architecture
reviews: Absolutely take a course with Andrew Hamilton before you leave!
Best class I've taken at Princeton! I doubt it will ever happen again but if it does, TAKE IT! Hamilton is an amazing professor
Definitely take it if it is offered!  Professor Hamilton is fantastic to learn from.

Hamilton is not a professor you want to miss at Princeton. He's incredibly learned on his subject and will make you truly excited about the study of Inka art and architecture. Our seminar was really small and our class also really bonded well.
Take it! We went to Peru! Professor Hamilton is super sweet and engaging, and overall great human.
Take this course if you're even a little bit interested.
This class is very interesting for those who would like to learn about cultures that are very different from European ones.
This course is incredible. Take it.
Unfortunately, Prof. Hamilton will be leaving after next year, but take anything with him before then  if you can!
prereqs: Enrollment is by interview only. Students will be selected based on major, previous coursework, and languages. Department will cover basic transportation, lodging and program costs for the required break trip. Students must have a passport by the start of term and should expect to participate in moderate hiking. Reading or speaking knowledge of Spanish is not required, but is beneficial. Class participation is a major part of the final grade; thus, full engagement is essential..
descrip: This course examines the art, architecture, and worldview of the greatest Andean civilization, the Incas. Conquered in 1532 by the Spanish, the Incas are known through archaeological and historical sources. Neither, however, can be taken at face value. The destructions of the conquest and differential preservation mean the archaeological record is incomplete. Likewise, Spanish historical sources present the Incas through European understandings, logic, and attentions. This course compares the two to reach a nuanced understanding of this ancient civilization. A spring break excursion will visit Cusco, Machu Picchu, and Lima.

title: Eastern Europe: Culture and History
reviews: A good EM for those with no knowledge about Eastern Europe. You can easily get away with not doing the readings, but it's an incredibly rewarding experience if you actually do them and engage with your classmates, AI, and Professor Gross.
Great course. Not too tough. You'll learn a lot about a ton of different disciplines. Take sophomore year for your EM and you'll have many more courses you'll want to take after.
Make sure you go to class, as there are no official lecture notes and the guest speakers are very interesting.
Pretty easy DR. Prof Gross is really sweet, helpful and passionate about the topics. Do the readings and engage yourself. Eastern Europe is worth it.
Take this class if you want to look at Eastern Europe in a way you've never experienced before. The professor (and assistant) are very kind and know so much! Definitely take it.
descrip: The course will discuss the main trends in East European history and culture, concentrating mostly on 20th and 21st centuries. Each week will be devoted to one aspect of East European studies and the classes will combine theme-plus-methodology approach. There will be several invited speakers. The course is part of the track in East European Cultures and Societies (EECS), one of the two tracks for Certificate in Russian, East European and Eurasian Studies.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Students engage in a semester-long composition project working toward a performance or recording by a professional, external organization such as a dance company, theater company, film company, or something similar. Objectives and content of the course are determined by the student's adviser in consultation with the external institution. The student enrolled in the course submits monthly progress reports that include the goals of the composition project and progress to date. The student also submits any evaluations they may receive from the host institution, or published reviews of the final product.

title: Afterlives of the Iliad
descrip: What possible relevance could Homer's Iliad have today? Yet for nearly three millennia the epic has inspired countless rewritings, from ancient and early modern drama, to modern translations and continuations, to Hollywood blockbusters and contemporary avant-garde theater. This course traces the influence of the epic across languages, media, and time. Together we will ask vital questions about the formation and reformation of literary canons; the role of translation in the transformation of literary works; and the social, political, and ethical impulses that often motivate our encounters with literary texts.

title: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology
reviews: Although other people scared me at the beginning year about this course, I actually liked it! I wouldn't say it's going to be the easiest course you take, because, yes, there are A LOT of things you have to memorize and learn. Also, you are going to feel behind if you didn't take AP Bio (like me) because there are a lot of people who have taken it before. But you can definitely catch up to them if you study hard!

As a non MOL major/pre-med, I found this to be a good course for getting a peak into serious study of science. With only minimal background in biology, I was mostly comfortable keeping up, though expect a lot of unfamiliar material. Memorization will get you a B; a thorough understanding of the material will get you an A.
Attend all lectures and do the readings.  Also take advantage of the marvelous professors teaching this course.
Attending lecture is key in doing well in this class. Also office hours are a really helpful way to clarify any material you didn't understand in class.

Be prepared to do a lot of self-teaching. Read the textbook especially when you're unclear about topics in lectures. This course runs through a lot of information over the semester, so be sure to stay on top of what you're learning - especially towards the end of the year.
Be prepared to work very hard.
Be ready to do a lot of work, but worthwhile

Chances are you aren't taking this course for general interest. If you are, this will be fine. If you're not, have fun. Around 80% of this course is a review of AP bio, so have fun wasting a semester of class if you've already taken it, and have fun competing against kids who are simply reviewing the material if you haven't. Written work in this class is erratic and largely a test of how well you can understand what a question could possibly want as an answer rather than your true understanding of the material. This class isn't hard, just a massive waste of time.
Content-wise, this class isn't too difficult, but because it is rather memorization based, if you  take it, take it because you're interested in biology or are pre-med.
Definitely recommend. Great people.
Definitely take if you're interested in learning a lot of introductory MOL BIO.
Definitely take it as a pre-req, not as another class tho.
Definitely take this course, even if you're not thinking of being a MOL major! You'll learn so much, and have lots of fun along the way.
Do not skip lectures and you will succeed in this course.
Do not take this course if you do not have to. It's so boring and time consuming.
Do the readings beforehand and review the lecture slides before the exam. I'd recommend taking notes on the powerpoint slides.
Do the readings.
Don't take if you're just looking for an STL
Don't take it unless you have a real interest in the class
Don't take it unless you have to; very time-consuming, and success really depends on how well you can memorize all of the intricate details. Labs are fun though
Don't underestimate the difficulty of this course, especially if you haven't taken AP Bio. Only take it if you need it
Don't worry about going to lecture, absolutely worthless. I went once and would study more than others come midterms and kill it. Never had to wake up at 830am and walk to Frick.
Drag yourself out of bed and go to the morning lectures, they are important in understanding major topics.
Drink coffee before lectures. Be alert.
GO TO THE LECTURES, it really messed me up not going.
Gavis is an amazing lecturer, whereas you'll need coffee to stay awake during Notterman's.
Go to every lecture and make sure to ask question in precept when you do not understand something.
Go to lecture and study the powerpoint slides.
Go to lecture! It made a huge difference.  Also, keeping up on the labs, attendance, etc. made a big difference in my grade.
Go to lecture, study the lecture slides, and ask when you don't understand something!
Go to lecture.
Go to lectures
Go to lectures, don't skimp on readings
Go to lectures, go to precept, not fun but necessary.
Go to lectures. Go to precept. Go to McGraw
Go to office hours with different professors.Bruce is wonderful. Do your lab notebook as you go.
Good instructors and teaches well. I recommend it.
Great class. Super interesting. Not too much work except for the occasional annoying lab write-up.
Great course to take. 8:30 is very early.
Great course. If you're thinking about taking it, it's probably because you have to. Not bad. Tip: Take notes for Notterman lectures otherwise slides will not make sense later.
Highly recommend if any interest in bio or even as an STL distribution requirement! A lot of information and memorization but very interesting
I enjoyed it even though I didn't need it as a prereq or for premed or anything, but it is definitely harder than the average STL.
I highly recommend this class if you are remotely interested in cell biology. The class is not difficult if you put in the work, but very rewarding in the concepts it teaches.
I know the lectures are early in the morning, but it is important to attend and take good notes -- pretty much anything is fair game for the exams.

I strongly recommend this class because the professors are very strong across the board for this class. Labs are pretty fun and interesting and relevant to class and the lectures show how biology is relevant to real life. I would take this course for a STL.

I think I would have really enjoyed the course a lot if lectures had been at 11 instead of 830 in the morning - as it was I missed most of them and did a poor job keeping up with the material on my own . despite this I did not have a huge problem with the exams - ap bio helps
I would advise the student to go to the instructors' office hours and to read the slides before lecture.
I would highly recommend this course to all students interested in the natural sciences. I don't think it requires any previous experience in bio and the lectures go at a fairly slow pace.
I would recommend taking this course! It really got me interested in Mol Bio and you learn a lot from both lecture and lab.

I would say that the lectures are the most important part of the course, because all useful information--and all topics that will be on the exams--are presented during lectures. The textbook readings cannot substitute for lectures, and the precepts are simply supplements.

I would suggest reviewing the lecture slides before a lecture. This will help you see what you already know and formulate questions on the material that you struggle with. I would also suggest reading the textbook but place the majority of your study time on lecture slides.
I would tell them to constantly review the material to get a good understanding of it.
I wouldn't take it for fun, but I doubt many of you are. This class isn't too bad if you pay attention in lecture and take good notes.

If you are interested in biology, this is a fun and not too difficult (provided you have some biology background) course. The labs are a lot of fun and all of the people involved with the course are very accessible even though a lot of people take it.
If you aren't pre-med, take another course.  This one is not worth your time.
If you can, take this in the fall when it's at 11:00. Professors and TAs all very accessible if you need them, and I recommend making good use of that.
If you have to take the class, take it. It is easier than chem in my opinion. A lot of memorization.
If you're interested in MOLECULAR level biology, take it, but if you're expecting body systems and anatomy and that kind of biology, this is not the course for you

If you've taken AP Bio in high school, you'll be fine. Notterman, Gavis, and Schwalm are the most boring lecturers ever and going to lecture is an absolute drag. The labs are boring and annoying as well. All in all, not the worst class ever but it's slow.
Interesting material in class but the labs are kind of tedious and boring. Not too challenging if you have taken AP bio and the lecturers are great
Interesting material! Labs are actually pretty cool but also chill.
It's a great course. You don't need to be a pre-med or MOL to have a reason to take it.
It's nice for a required intro class.
MAKE SURE YOU ARE IN GEOFF VRLA'S LAB. He is the chillest/coolest TA. Definitely go to all the lectures and take notes religiously!!!
Make sure to approach the course from a concept based framework rather than trying to memorize all the details, since the exams emphasize problem solving rather than nitty-gritty details!
Make sure to talk to your professors when you have questions! They are very approachable!
Make sure you are interested in the course before taking

Many of the cellular processes taught in this class are interesting to learn about and understand, but require time outside of class to fully appreciate them. However, as is often the case, it is hard to find time and make yourself learn without cramming right before exams.

Most people take this course because it's a pre-med requirement or prerequisite for MOL/EEB. However, the quality of the course was so good that if you're generally interested in molecular biology, I would take it to learn more. Dr. Notterman and Dr. Gavis are some of the best lecturers I've had at Princeton. Dr. Notterman is especially entertaining and class was fun to go to. The exams are really reasonable and if you study the lecture material, you'll do well.
Most well taught course offered.
Not hard if you can memorize things easily/ you took AP Biology. Labs are simple and just busy work. Overall very little work

Not the most challenging or interesting of courses. Precepts are good, but in general the exams require more memorization than critical thinking. Some of the lectures were really interesting, especially the ones that considered landmark experiments, but others were rather boring.
