Not too difficult. Lab is relaxed and can boost your grade. Go to lecture and take notes on printouts of the slides--emphasis on visuals. This will make studying for the exams much easier.

Notterman is hilarious and Gavis can be kind of boring. Meet with your lab TAs about lab reports whenever you can and the readings really aren't necessary for the test. The tests are entirely based on the lectures so make sure you go.
Pay attention during lectures.
Pay attention in lecture. You do not need to do the readings in the textbook as long as you are engaged in the lectures.

Personally, readings weren't necessary. Spend time reviewing lecture slides and understanding them fully. Lab reports and problem sets don't take much time to complete (~2 hours for reports and ~20 minutes for psets).
Pretty easy course if you go to lecture/precept and pay attention
Read lectures notes and write down important points to best retain them!
Read literally every detail of every lecture and you will do fine
Really enjoyed this course. Go to all of the lectures.
Stay on top of the material and you'll do fine.
Study the lectures on a weekly basis to make studying for midterms easier to understand.
Take good notes in lecture.
Take it if you have to ?\_(?)_/?  but if you are looking to fulfill an STL requirement, you might be better off in EEB 211
Take it if you have to. The exams are very difficult and test the most minute details. Make sure to study the fine print, because to be honest, that's what gets tested, not the big concepts.
Take it if you need to - it's a pre-med course so the curve is tough but doable. It's a pretty interesting course and if you've taken AP bio you'll recognize a lot.
Take it!
Take the course if you are pre-med or if it is required for you to take it. A challenging class--need to put time into it. But exams are fair and doable if you put the time into it.
Take this class! Even if it is just to satisfy an STL. It is very fun and interesting and the labs are the best for a science course.
Take this course if you want to be exposed to various aspects fundamental to molecular biology!
Take this course! The material is interesting and very well taught.
The course is very interesting and engaging.  Not too much work throughout the semester, but the exams are not easy!  Stay on top of readings and go to lecture!
The lectures are great! take detailed notes on the lecture slides and study! Don't worry about the reading if you are prepared to CRAM! it is a ton of info esp if you have not had AP bio.
There is a lot of material in this course. Be prepared for a lot of memorizing. Solid intro but a good bit of work.

This class is pretty easy if you've taken AP bio. Go to the lectures (even if they're at 8:30) and take notes. The readings and precept are generally useless. Exams aren't hard they're just confusing and sometimes poorly worded. Shouldn't be too much of a struggle though

This course is very well organized and well taught but it's still very easy to let the material fly past you every week. There is A LOT of information covered on each exam, so you need to stay up to date and consistent in your studying. Most people think bio is all memorization-- this course proves them very very wrong. Exams are completely scenario-based, open ended, and require heavy critical thinking. Still very rewarding to take (and  you have to if you are premed)

This is a good course, especially if you didn't take AP Bio. The lecturers are all wonderful and very willing to help, as were my preceptor and lab TA (Bruce and Xinlei). Make sure to leave time before each exam to review all of the lectures. There's a lot of material and a lot of memorization, but the key to a lot of the short-answer exam questions is understanding why certain things happen the way they do. Labs are pretty low stress and you get to leave early in some of them (so not as terrible as orgo lab), but this is still a lab course and the longer lab reports take a while to write well.

This is a pretty cool class. If you are looking at it for an STL or for general interest i would recommend it as long as you can handle the 8:30 time. The lectures are interesting and the only work is the lab reports which don't take too long. The exams aren't too bad, you just have to put some effort into memorizing.  Overall its a good course.

This is a pretty easy course - don't hesitate to take it as a fifth class or to get it out of the way early for science majors, pre-meds, etc. Gavis is an absolutely brilliant lecturer, too - I never missed one. The class does a great job of covering everything from chemical aspects of biology to genetics and makes great cultural connections; a good class to take for general interest or to satisfy an STL as well.

This is a really good intro to molecular bio class, just be sure to keep up with your notes because it starts to become a lot to memorize and understand. But the later topics are very cool (epigenetic, cancer, CRISPR-Cas) Professor Notterman and Professor Gavis make the lecture very interesting.

Try to review the lecture material on a weekly basis because if you wait until the exams to review everything, it feels like a lot of content that you suddenly must memorize. And yes, memorization is really the only way to retain all this information.
Very good course to take, but definitely recommend that you have background in at least AP Bio from high school. Very do-able class if you go to lecture and study hard

Very manageable class if you've taken high school bio, especially if you found it intuitive then!  There is memorization involved but as long as you don't leave studying to the last moment you'll be fine!

Very well organized course. It really is AP Bio, and I tripped myself up a bit when I wanted to talk about the chemistry of why everything was happening. Don't do that - the course is very wide in breadth, but we never talk about the chemistry behind any of the biology, and it's all very memory-intensive and hand-wavey. If you haven't done AP Bio, it will likely be kind of hard for  you to get an A.
Watch out for this course!! Much harder than you would anticipate. One of my last pre-med classes and the hardest so far.

Well organized and well-taught course. Perhaps lots of premeds so average exam grades high but great class. I took this on a whim (my major totally not related to MOL) to see if I was interested and I thought this would turn me off from the biological sciences, but I surprisingly enjoyed it a lot!
Write out learning objectives with detailed descriptions and examples for each lecture.
Yes, there are a lot of premeds in this course, but don't let that discourage you. Follow along with lecture material and you'll be fine.
You get what you put in. Quality course. Even labs are fun.
You should do the readings; they're interesting and helpful. Labs are pretty cool and not hard. Attend lecture--it's easier than trying to cath up later.
You're probs taking it cause its required. If you have to take it for your major, and are NOT premed, then good luck with that curve.
meh
take it
take it if your must.

take it! it's not that competitive and people help each other. you do need to remember a lot of random facts, but you definitely don't need to make flash cards. all I did was look at lecture slides and I believe I earned a good grade. all the staff really care about you, although there are sometimes questions you might ask that are beyond their knowledge. they are great people and try to help you however they can.
take this course.
won't learn much in precept, but the lectures are interesting the last few weeks
you have to take it for premed so just get through it
descrip: Important concepts and elements of molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology, are examined in an experimental context. This course fulfills the requirement for students majoring in the biological sciences and satisfies the biology requirement for entrance into medical school.

title: Physics of the Universe - Origin & Evolution
descrip: The course is the first of a two-semester survey (along with PHY 564) of fundamental concepts which underly contemporary cosmology. The first semester focuses on the nearly homogeneous evolution of the universe including the standard big bang picture, inflationary cosmology, dark matter, and the possibility of present-day accelerated expansion. The second semester focuses on the late stages in the evolution of the universe, when gravity results in the growth of large-scale structure, perturbations in the cosmic microwave background, gravitational lensing and other non-linear phenomena.

title: Government, Poverty, and Inequality in Modern America
reviews: A class with PFK is an adventure, yo.  Make sure to talk with her at some point, definitely an interesting person, yo.  The class is pretty tight (yo), but can seem repetitive at times.  Take if you're looking to soak in some dope knowledge about inner-city poverty, dawg. Here's a hint for ya, our government needs to get its business together, yo.
Definitely take the class if you're interested in govt, policy, or just helping america be a better place for more people. do the readings--they're interesting and important.
I would recommend others to take this course.

If this class is relatively small (ours was under 40 I believe), then I'd recommend taking it; I don't think it would have the same sort of pace, nor atmosphere, if it was a larger lecture format. I've heard that this is something she does in general, but she often goes off on tangents, which I guess is nice if you're not in the mood to start right away with a lecture until about 20 minutes into the class period. Assignments are fair, although memos can get a bit annoying since there are 4 in the semester, so you're essentially producing something every 4 weeks. Try to precept with her, simply because I've always enjoyed having precepts with the professor.
If you are considering taking this class, do it. Great class, and a great professor
PDF Class. Its really annoying.

PFK definitely has favorites- if you have a lot of outside knowledge in sociology, you will always get to talk in precept. If not, you'll probably fly under the radar and your writing will simply have to be good enough not to need the help of participation. Difficult to participate in precept because 1. my precept was too many people and 2. we often didn't discuss the readings super directly- instead it felt as if you needed some extra background knowledge in sociology to keep up with the senior soc majors
Take it if you are actually interested in the class material
Take it! This class sheds new light on urban poverty and forces you to reconsider previously held thoughts. Workload is manageable.

Take this class if you're interested in the subject. The course is very repetitive, but it still has some good information. The grading is very fair, and the workload is manageable. PFK's book is about the only necessary reading; everything else can be skimmed. Take if you need an SA.
Take this course! PFK is great, and really cares about her students.
This course is eye opening.  It will force you to confront your preconceptions about poverty and policy solutions.  The readings are fascinating.  The workload is very manageable and very enjoyable.
This is an interesting course and PFK is a great teacher but you should only the this class if you are interested in poverty.
do everything on time.
descrip: The course examines poverty and inequality in relation to processes of globalization that have transformed the means of economic mobility for working people in the U.S. We raise questions about government institutions acting on behalf of different constituencies and according to varying criteria of economic "deservedness;" and evaluate vibrant debates about the role of democratic government in promoting social justice. Among the subjects covered are poverty and religion, social and cultural capital among the poor, and poverty, crime, incarceration, and entrepreneurship.

title: Image Processing
reviews: As a non-ELE major this course was challenging and time consuming but definitely manageable.  I think I could have done better if I had had more time to devote to it.  The material is very interesting and worth it.

Expect this class to be a lot of work! The material in the 2nd half is more interesting, but you need to force yourself to stay engaged. Luckily, Ramadge is a great lecturer and provides great notes and iPython notebooks! You definitely will learn a lot from this, but how well you learn it is up to your level of engagement. It's a lot of work, but can be worth it if you're into Image Processing at all. Take over Computer Vision.

I would highly recommend this course. The machine learning aspect of the course is not as large as I would have hoped, however the content is very well presented and the lecture notes and ipython notebooks provided are incredible.

Image processing is a big field, and Ramadge has a pretty broad understanding, although I believe he's most known for at ML and prediction topics. That being said, the course is basically a grab bag of topics, so you might really like it or just feel ambivalent about it. Make sure to review definitions and caveats/solution spaces of different approaches well, because that is the biggest crux of the course.
It might be quite a burden to do the assignments, project, and exams but it is definitely worth it.

It's a pretty good course where you do some pretty cool things (facial recognition, probabilistic modeling, etc). I'd definitely recommend a background in probability (ORF309 maybe). Don't expect this to be a deep dive into machine learning, we only very briefly touch on concepts near the end of the course.
Its a great course! One of the best ELE's I've taken.
Professor Ramadge is a great professor and course material is very interesting. Great course!
Recommend, but it actually is a lot of work. It's a fair class though.
The class is fine, you'll learn quite a bit but the labs take a brutally long time (midterms and finals aren't terrible, he's fair.)

The class is really interesting and Prof Ramadge has great lectures, slides and notes. I would recommend it, as it is one of the more interesting ELE applications classes. But the class is sometimes unnecessarily mathy with a lot of linear algebra. But Professor Ramadge doesnt really test you much on it, since its mostly okay.

This course is really good but hard. Ramadge has written an extensive amount of notes for each lecture and you will be drowned in material in both a good and bad way.  Those of you with an interest in  machine learning or information processing, you will learn a lot. The labs are hard and time consuming but really, really cool in practice. Be warned that there is a bunch of math in this course and when reviewing for the final you may feel overwhelmed, but at the end of the day you will have learned a lot and that's awesome.
Very interesting class, I learned a lot. As a natural sciences person rather than a COS/ELE I felt that the material was highly accessible and applicable.
Very well taught course. You'll spend a fair amount of time on the problem sets (there is no lab), but you'll learn a lot by the end of it.
descrip: Introduction to the basic theory and techniques of image processing. Topics include image perception, acquisition, display, enhancement, restoration, compression, transformation, tomography, medical imaging, video coding and content analysis. Applications to HDTV, machine vision, medical imaging, etc.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Great class
Great class overall. Work is reasonable. One challenge is, unlike other classes, you can't ever really take any time off. Assignments are small and manageable but non-stop.
Stay on top of the material
prereqs: CHI 403 or instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of 403. Reading and discussion of scholarly writings in the fields of Chinese literature and modern Chinese intellectual history.

title: Physics for the Life Sciences
reviews: A really great physics class simply because of how engaging of a lecturer Dr.Puchalla is and how much he is willing to make the labs and class demos fun. However there is fair amount of work because of lab papers, exams, and psets so you should be prepared.

Although almost everyone who takes this class is a premed, it was not super stressful or competitive. In fact, I made a lot of friends in the class who really helped each other learn the material. However, this really is NOT an MCAT preparation class, so take it because Puchalla is great, but don't take it thinking you won't have to study physics for the MCAT
Ask for help if you need it, especially since Dr. Puchalla is always welcoming and willing to help.
Definitely recommend for Mol majors who just have to take one semester. Professor Puchalla is great, very understanding and engaging, and overall makes the class as good as it can be
Dr Puchalla is fantastic - I enjoyed this class far more than I anticipated.

Dr. Puchalla's a great dude, and he does his best to tie together many different topics, cover as much as possible, and relate it all to the natural sciences; however, the class get quite annoying sometimes with the lab reports and the somewhat nebulous HW and exam questions. I have faith that Dr. Puchalla can only make this class better moving forward.
Great course, especially because it was so small. A lot of personal attention.
Great for EEB and MOL majors looking for that elusive physics requirement. It is not a great class for senior year because it's a physics class and so has labs and stuff, so it's a time commitment.
Great pre-med class. Difficult as expected, but much more interesting and a more engaging professor than the one I had for 101. Take this class if you're pre-med.
I'm sure after updates are made to the course, it will run more smoothly. I would still take it in addition to PHY 101 if you are a pre-med.
It's far from easier than PHY 102, but the environment is so much more comfortable and you feel like your professor actually cares about your engagement and learning.
Keep up with the homework and lecture material.

Only take this course if you are ready to work very hard (you'll get a lot of cool knowledge in return). This course is not an "easy out" if you are pre-med and trying to get out of taking physics 101, it's very demanding but also very rewarding. Don't take it with a busy schedule.
Overall a really good course that is still working out some kinks, but within a few years will definitely be preferable to 102/104 for any pre-meds!
Probably better than 102, but be prepared for every third week being hell.
Professor Puchalla is a really nice person and I enjoyed his lectures. Given the fact that this is a newer course, I expect that it will only get better in the coming years.

Take it if (a) You have a solid background in physics (did 101, or did AP and got 5s) (b) I can't really give you wise advice for exams because I still do not get how to study myself and the final is tomorrow :( However, Professor P is an amazing human being that has such a contagious passion for science, getting to hear him talk about science is something that I will always be grateful for - however, from the practical point of view (i.e. learning qualitative problems and solving them efficiently, doing well in exams consistently), I dont know if this is the best physics class..
Take it if you have to- it is very well taught. BUT expect to do a ton of work.
Take it instead of PHY102 if you're premed! It's a great class, you'll learn a lot, and Dr. Puchalla is a great professor.
Take it!!
Take this course if you're pre-med! The life science perspective is unique and awesome.

Take this course if you're prepared to devote a lot of extra time to go in for office hours and ask for clarification on concepts in problem sets and lab papers. It gets really confusing and you have to be patient.

The concepts explored in this class are extremely interesting (microscopes, how the eye works, circulatory systems, how your ear works, etc). But there are a lot of assignments to keep up with so make friends to do the problem sets with. Don't try too hard on the labs. Everyone I know got the best grades on the labs they tried the least on for some reason...I think the expectations of the lab write-ups were very unclear throughout the semester.

This is a good course. It is challenging and the lab papers and problem sets can be time consuming, but Dr. Puchalla is great/amazing/wonderful. He really does try to make the lectures engaging and there are always really cool experiments/demos during class time. I think that the course needs to be tweaked a bit in terms of the manner in which the material is presented, but overall I believe that you get a better understanding of the applications of physics from this course than 102.
This is a great alternative to phy 102. You essentially cover the same material, but Dr. Puchalla makes it more interesting and engaging.

This is great class for fulfilling any pre-med or MOL bio requirements. The class is designed with the life sciences in mind, and the concepts we learn have clear applications to biological phenomena. There is a lot of support from the professor and TA as well.

Took this for a pre-med requirement and happy I did. Puchalla is so reasonable, really good guy, there to help you out. A lot of science courses here have their system and if you don't fit into the system you can feel lost or left behind. Not this class. Puchalla makes sure everyone is up to speed and on the same page and will adjust his schedule and the course schedule accordingly.

Unless you love it, physics sucks. So whether you take 108 or 102, you are going to approach it with a negative attitude. 
Dr. Puchalla is a super passionate professor and will lecture with an energy that is unparalleled. 
That being said, don't think that the "physics for the life sciences" title makes it an easier. The contextualization of physics in a biological world really does help make it easier for pre-meds to understand why physics is important to their medical studies, but do't be fooled into believing that it's a dumbed down version of 102. 
There is weekly problem sets, a weekly online homework, four lab reports (that are really papers and not just lab reports), three quizzes and a midterm. All on top of 3 lectures a week and a lab. 

If you like the way 101 runs, take 101. If you hated it, take 108 but don't expect it to be much better. If you don't have to take physics, gtfo. This is for pre-meds and they will hate you for trying to ruin their curve.

moves quite fast... is harder than you may think
dr. puchalla is cool
nice class to start you off in thinking about applying tools of physics to biological/life science questions

take it (if you can get a spot)! really relevant to life sciences, especially if you're premed. go to problem sessions?Dr. Skoge is really nice. labs are less relevant and lab papers are annoying and vague.
prereqs: No course prerequisite. Completion of laboratory experiments is mandatory. A working knowledge of algebra (up to quadratic equations) and trigonometry (solving triangles, vector projection) is required. Students will be introduced to a limited number of concepts in calculus but no prior knowledge is assumed. PHY 102, PHY 104, PHY 106 are considered equivalent courses and cannot be taken multiple times for credit. PHY 101, PHY 103, PHY 105 may be taken in conjunction with this course for credit..
descrip: This new one semester physics course with lab is designed to introduce life science students to selected topics in physics. The course is broadly organized around 4 major concepts: Fluids; Oscillators (including basic electric circuits); Radiation & Electromagnetism; and Optics & Imaging. Specific topics are chosen to be directly relevant to modern life science research and techniques. Lectures are carried out in a lab-like setting and use hands-on demos to introduce material. Weekly help sessions will be offered through the McGraw Center.

title: Genes, Brain, and the Human Mind
prereqs: Admission to this course requires a brief questionnaire. Graduate students are expected to have an equivalent background..
descrip: How did the human brain become the most complex organ in the animal kingdom? How do genetic and environmental forces produce its capabilities and maladies? These questions have fascinated philosophers, humanists, physicians, and scientists for millennia and are the focus of this course. The course uses human genetics and systems neuroscience to analyze topics including autism, Alzheimer disease, bipolar disorder and drug addiction. Class time emphasizes lectures, discussion and student-generated presentations. The goal is to reach a modern understanding of how the human brain works and sometimes fails.

title: Advanced French
reviews: A noticeable step down in quality from 105. But you have to take it, so do.
As an engineer, take this course if you're interested in improving your French; it'll definitely will! Please consider taking it as an underclassman though and not senior year like I did.
Even if you don't need 108, I would definitely still take it to sharpen your French. The workload is very manageable, but it still keeps your interest!
I would recommend taking it if you want to improve in both language skills and cultural education of France.

I'd take this course with Murielle Perrier. She's very good and really cares about her students. The writing assignments are more (in number) than originally stated but doable.
Also be warned: there is a final exam during reading period (referred to as a "take home" in the course description).

If you're trying to get a language requirement out of the way, I'd recommend taking French.  FRE 108 is the final course to fulfill the requirement, and the professors who teach it are generally pretty good.
It was a decent class, very small class size and a pleasant amount of conversation was allowed with your peers. There wasn't much notable about this course.
Know the general themes for the readings, movies, etc. The fine details are not always necessary. I found a lot of the grammar to be review, so I would recommend focusing on the very detailed rules.

Perrier is an amazing teacher. She keeps you on task and by the end of the semester you will be amazed by how much better your French is ! Also, you learn a lot about french culture and history. 10/10 would take again
Professor Perrier is amazing, so if you're thinking about taking 108, take it with her!
Read the textbook. Attend office hours before turning in the final copy of compositions.

Take this course with Mme Perrier! I improved so much and didn't even realize how good I had gotten. It's fun, the courseload is really manageable, and it was definitely my favorite class of the semester!
Take this with Dr. Perrier. She makes classes fun and engaging. There is also not a ton of difference between this and 105, in terms of workload. Very similar classes.
This class is more difficult than 105. Go to office hours with your professor.
study hard
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Director of French Language Program..
descrip: FRE 108 is an intermediate advanced course, with a brand new syllabus. We'll take you on a journey through various periods of French history and culture and offer an opportunity to reflect on important questions at the center of controversial debates: national identity, immigration, relationships with the Francophone world and former colonies, the role of the State in the shaping of the nation, etc. We have selected a variety of authentic materials (films, videos, music, newspapers articles and literary texts) and carefully incorporated them into our curriculum so you'll develop your ability to communicate in French.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political theory, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Experience of Consumer Culture, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Compiling Techniques
reviews: Be aware that some offerings of this course are in SML (a functional programming language), while others are in C. I entered the course with no functional experience whatsoever, which made the assignments more difficult than they were likely intended to be.
I believe it is a course that every CS student should take because the subject is really important to learn and understand.
It's a good and clear explanation of compilers. The programs are especially helpful, since you implement (the major parts of) a compiler.

This course is alright actually, but a lot of work. Weekly programming assignments could really bite. I would recommend reading the slides over the book, because the book could be quite dense. Take it if you like to compile..
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Understand the design and construction of compilers. Concepts include syntax analysis, semantics, code generation, optimization and run-time systems. Translation of imperative languages (such as C), functional languages (such as ML), and object-oriented languages (such as Java) will be studied. Students will implement a complete compiler for a small language.

title: Pre-Columbian Peoples of Tropical America and Their Environments
reviews: Do the readings, take good notes in lecture, and ask questions. It is not as independently driven as the other EEB Panama abroad courses, but it is a valuable body of knowledge to be learned from.
I know that most of the students taking this class won't have a passion for archaeology but try and engage with Dolores and her research because it's actually super interesting.
prereqs: Prerequisites: 211, and 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring Semester in tropical ecology program in Panama..
descrip: The pre-European history of Amerind cultures and their associated environments in the New World tropics will be studied. Topics to be covered include the peopling of tropical America; development of hunting/gathering and agricultural economies; neotropical climate and vegetation history; and the material culture and social organization of native Americans. Field and laboratory experiences will incorporate methods and problems in field archaeology, paleoenthnobotany and paleoecology, and archaeozoology.

title: Studies in Forms of Narrative - Fiction in Latin America
descrip: The course explores a range of forms and uses of fiction in Latin America since the end of the 19th century, with special attention to changing contexts of politics and history. Texts are available in English, and also read in Portuguese or Spanish as knowledge or enthusiasm allows.

title: PhD Gateway in Security Studies
descrip: The field of Security Studies is distinguished by its focus on a clearly delineated set of intellectual and practical problems. This course will serve as the required gateway for all students entering the Woodrow Wilson School.

title: Introduction to Metaphysics and Epistemology
reviews: --Very light workload, and very easy way to get the EC distribution requirement.  Always go to lecture because Rosen explains the material very well.  You don't need to read the book at all if you go to lecture.  Basically the only work you have to do throughout the whole semester is to write four essays, two of which are only 500 words.  Definitely take it as distribution or as an easy fifth class.
A very good course to take if you want to see what philosophy is about. The workload is very manageable and the professor/content is super interesting.
A worthwhile class for all majors and all people!!! Wide range of topics, engaging readings and exciting discussions in precept about some CRAZY topics.
Best class I have taken here so far. Lectures and precepts are really interesting. Definitely take if you have any interest in philosophy.
Best humanities class I have ever taken. Fundamentally changed my perspective on many things in life. Fair grading, though philosophy papers are difficult in general.
Bring questions to precept

Daniel Berntson is the best- get in his precept if possible. Professor Rosen is also such a great lecturer- always speaks with the same clarity and confidence. Very interesting subject matter and fun papers to write. Not too much work.
Definitely take this class if you want an intro to philosophy class. Gideon is a great professor who will make understanding philosophy fun and simple.
Do the readings and talk to the professor. He's awesome!
Do the readings. If you pay close attention to these, you do not have to attend lectures.
Do the readings. This class is what you make of it. You can choose to make it as challenging as you want it but it is up to you. Helpful to do the readings before precept.s
Easy EC--class started out interesting but became less so as the semester wore on. Some of the arguments we considered seemed pointless thought exercises
Fantastic course--TAKE IT!!!!
Fun course, great intro to philosophy, yo.  Readings are optional, Rosen will just go over the content again in class.  Take it if you're looking to get your toes wet in a dope subject, yo.
Gideon Rosen is great. Papers are not difficult.

Gideon Rosen is one of the best lecturers on campus. He presents complicated material in an interesting and understandable way. It was a bit repetitive to do the reading and go to lecture, so it isn't really necessary to do both unless it is for a paper topic.
Go to the lectures.

Great course! Awesome professor, interesting readings, easy assignments. You can follow the lectures and keep up in precepts easily without doing the readings, just do the ones you end up writing about. But the readings are interesting, so you should do them! Easy and interesting class. Take it if you like philosophy.
Great course, especially to PDF. Rosen and Daniel the preceptor are money. The material can drift a little bit to some craziness, but generally covers interesting subject matter.
I recommend attending all lectures and taking comprehensive notes.
If just looking for an EC distribution requirement, this is a great course.

If you are not comfortable dealing with questions that have no answers, then this course will annoy you. If you put in a little bit of effort, this course will be like training wheels for academic philosophy.

If you don't know anything about philosophy, this is a great survey class that will get you thinking about some of the big topics in the field right now. The lectures and readings are very interesting and the class has minimal work. Grading on the essays is a bit tough, but you only have four essays the whole semester.
One of the most interesting classes I have taken at Princeton. Very approachable (I had never taken a philosophy class) and workload is super manageable.

Professor Rosen is a clear and articulate lecturer. Try to get Daniel Berntson as your preceptor - he is amazing. While this class won't blow your mind, it's a nice intro to some interesting philosophical topics. Light workload in general. Also, note that 70% of your grade will be determined by the last two essays, which come fairly late in the semester.
Read but mostly, write your papers in your advance and get comments on them. You have to really think out arguments and make them rock solid to do well in the class.
Rosen is a good lecturer. Attend lectures, some of the material is pretty interesting!
Take it if you are interested in philosophy but not ready for an upper-level class!
Take it with Rosen! His lectures are great. This is basically a perfect course to PDF, 3 papers and no exams.
Take it!
Take it! One of the best classes at Princeton!

Take it, especially if PDFing it. Low stress, not too time consuming, and pretty interesting in general. Just go to lecture and write your papers from that. No need to do any extra research. They graded pretty easily .
Take it. A fairly interesting philosophy class that does not require too much work.
Take the course, dude. Very minimal work with a lot of satisfaction once you do it.
Take this course if you are looking for a thought-provoking EC that has a manageable amount of work!
Take this course if you want an understanding of modern philosophy!

Take this course if you want your first taste of philosophy, are looking for great lectures, but don't need much interaction with preceptors when writing your papers.  Some preceptors in this class have a policy of specifically *not* reading essay drafts, which makes their advice nearly useless in practice.  If you write best by going over drafts with a preceptor, though, consider avoiding this course or at least picking your preceptor wisely.
The class only deals with highly philosophical questions, so be prepared for that.

This class is quite a good introduction, but you are responsible for a lot of your own learning. Papers are not too bad, but you should talk it over with your preceptor to make sure the ideas are sound.

This course is a lot of fun and not terribly time-consuming. You definitely get what you put into it, though--you can PDF it and cherry-pick specific topics and only learn those to write your essays, but the precepts won't be as much fun to attend. Very much a course where you can scale your involvement to suit your own preferences, though.

This course is fine if you need an EC. The only problem is that the grading seemed to be pretty harsh, probably because it's a large intro class so it's competitive. If you go to lecture all the time you don't have to do the readings.
This course is not very hard.

This course was very intellectually stimulating in the beginning of the semester but overall declined as the semester went on, in correlation with my motivation in the class. At least I know that I wouldn't be happy being a metaphysician/epistemologist. The questions raised by the course are certainly interesting, Rosen's lectures are great (he explains texts and ideas perhaps even a bit /too/ well), and he chose a wide variety of texts. However, I think as the semester progressed, I became increasingly disillusioned with myself for worrying about, say, the continuity of personal identity, or how best to construct an argument attempting to refute the brain-in-the-vat hypothesis, when millions of children are dying because they don't have access to clean drinking water or their families can't put enough food on the table or climate change/severe environmental conditions have afflicted their homes. Practical Ethics was a better course for me than PHI 203.

This is a great class - ideas are fascinating, Rosen is an awesome lecturer, work is minimal for the amount you get out. Most important piece of advice: shop precepts. Don't get caught with a bad preceptor.
This is a really interesting (and easy) course if you're at all interested in the subject matter. Rosen's precept is great.

This is an absolutely wonderful course. I found the lectures to be thoroughly interesting and engaging-- Prof. Rosen does an excellent job making vivid the philosophical problems presented in the course. Also, there is no midterm or final, which makes things a lot less stressful during those times of the year. Relatively easy, and really cool topics covered. Take this course!!
Too skeptical for me. Easy workload.
Useless subject matter but good professors and precepts
Very chill course if you PDF
Very interesting class.  Definitely introduced topics to me that were worth discussing
Very interesting, very accessible for those inexperienced in philosophy
Well taught

You should take this class, but you really need to spend time just THINKING about the readings outside of class. It isn't enough just to read them and go to lecture. You've got to ponder the questions on your own time.
take if you want a good broad intro to philosophy class that touches on a wide variety of philosophical questions
take the class! super interesting
descrip: An introduction to central questions of philosophy. Topics include: The rationality of religious belief, our knowledge of the external world, freedom of the will and the identity of persons over time.

title: American Political Institutions
descrip: This class is an entry-level graduate study of US political institutions. As such, the seminar provides an overview of the field and, perhaps more importantly, a foundation upon which students can begin to teach themselves additional works in this literature. In addition, through brief assignments and class presentations, we build students' ability to conduct scholarly research, evaluate others' scholarship, and serve as discussants and reviewers.

title: Philosophy of Mind - Fragmentation of Mind
descrip: We study mental representation, with special attention to the representation of incoherent, inconsistent, or fragmented states of mind. We apply our understanding of fragmented mental states to topics such as: 1) the debate between sentence-based and possible-worlds-based theories of mental representation; 2) the representation of mathematical and logical ignorance; 3) the epistemology of believers who realize they are imperfect reasoners; 4) models of the search for reflective equilibrium; 5) ascribing quasi-mental-states to groups of agents who act in concert.

title: Special Topics in Statistics and Operations Research - Stochastic Portfolio Theory
descrip: The aim of the course is to give a self contained introduction to a recently developed theory of investment in equity markets. The first part of the book "Stochastic Portfolio Theory" by Robert E. Fernholz and introduce the concepts of functionality generated portfolios, their relative performance, relative arbitrage, market stability, and capital distribution curves among others. In the second part of the course, we look at research papers from the past few years addressing questions raised in the book and going beyond it.

title: Seminar in Modern Spanish-American Literature - Archival Research Workshop
descrip: This seminar is conducted as a workshop to train students in the methodology of archival research. We work with the papers of Latin American writers housed at Firestone Library, especially with recent acquisitions of letters and manuscripts by Cuban writer Severo Sarduy. Theoretical readings include texts by Derrida, Barthes, Murat, Freud, and others. Students are encouraged to publish the result of their semester-long research.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Social Entrepreneurship for Policymakers
descrip: Over the last 20 years, the emerging field of social entrepreneurship has taken new approaches to problems in education, waste management and global public health. This course focuses on types and stages of different social enterprises (non-profits/hybrid organizations/for-profits), will evaluate nature of capital available from grants to patient capital to market-return investments. Course seeks to equip students with a framework for understanding how: 1) social enterprise can complement traditional provision of public services and 2) new markets are being created that deliver clear social benefits while generating returns to investors.

title: Violence as Metaphor: The 1916 Uprising in Dublin
reviews: Fintan is a fabulous professor and you will both enjoy and learn a lot in his classes!
Fintan is great. Irealnd is great. Take the class!
TAKE IT. Even if only for Fintan--he's a phenomenal lecturer and an understanding person.
Take this class if you are interested in Ireland and the rising. Really enjoyed it!
prereqs: No specific knowledge of modern Irish history is required, as there will be an introductory orientation. Students will, however, need to be comfortable both with historical method and with the use of aesthetic and literary texts. The nature of the course is cross-disciplinary, using primary historical sources, witness statements, novels, poems, plays and visual materials..
descrip: A hundred years ago, an armed group of Irish nationalist rebels took over public buildings in Dublin, declared a Republic and held out for a week against the British army. They had little public support and the leaders knew that they had no chance of military success. Yet, after those leaders were executed, the Rising was embraced as a ritual of sacrifice, the most effective piece of public theater yet staged. In this course we look at what happened in Easter Week, 1916, how it was imagined at the time and how it was later reflected in drama, in poetry and in fiction.

title: Kabbalah: Concepts and History
descrip: This course surveys the major concepts and historical developments of Jewish mystical traditions in the last thousand years. We will explore both theosophical (contemplative) and ecstatic (experiential) Kabbalah, including the ideas and practices of major figures, groups, and movements.

title: Psychopharmacology
prereqs: Biochemistry 345 or equivalent.
descrip: The molecular biology and biochemistry of pharmaceuticals and natural products that target CNS function are examined. Specific topics include: the blood-brain barrier, addiction and tolerance, analgesia, treatments for mood disorders, cognitive enhancement, stimulants and ADHD, treatment of dementias such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease, psychotropic drugs, antipsychotics and the treatment of schizophrenia.

title: Economic Sociology (Half-Term): Social Ties, Culture and Economic Processes
descrip: An introduction to economic sociology seen not as a subordination of sociology to economics but as the sociological explanation of economic phenomena. It focuses on alternative accounts of phenomena that most specialists have explained using economic concepts and theory. In particular, it seeks sociological explanations of production, consumption, and distribution, and transfer of assets. After a general orientation to economic sociology as a whole, the course explores economic activities in an unconventionally wide range of settings including households, informal sectors, gift economies, and consumption.

title: Community-Based Performance
reviews: Definitely take it!  It's a really interesting subject and Erica will challenge you to do your best while also creating a fun and engaging environment.
Erica is one of the best teachers I've had at Princeton and this is one of the best (and probably the most life-changing) class I've taken. TAKE IT.
Honestly, a wonderful class. Do take even if you don't understand what Community Based Performance is.
If you like small theater theory classes, give it a whirl.
Take it.
prereqs: Enrollment in this course is by permission of the instructor. Please email Professor Erica Nagel to state your interest in the course at: enagel@mccarter.org.
descrip: This hands-on seminar will explore contemporary theories and practices of community-based performance, investigating contemporary theatre, dance, and music groups that use these methods. The course will also interrogate the sometimes fraught politics of community-based performance, including questions of authorship, authority, authenticity, and artistry. Offered in partnership with the Community-Based Learning Initiative, this course will offer hands-on experience in the process of creating community-based performance projects, and facilitate opportunities to build artistic relationships with local community organizations.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Course offers a broad treatment of macroeconomic theory and policy issues, using the formal methods of modern macroeconomics. Topics will include long-run growth and development, labor, consumption, savings and investment decisions, the role of expectations, short-run fluctuations and stabilization policy, inflation and unemployment, trade and exchange rates. The course is advanced, so that: (i) having had some introductory course in macroeconomics is a prerequisite, and an intermediate-level one is best; (ii) the course requires a solid command of microeconomic theory (511 c or d) and good comfort with algebra and calculus.

title: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
reviews: Aizenman is a terrible lecturer. You will not follow him. There is no real reason to take this course.

Since for graduate student, the course is on a P/F basis, how much you can gain from the course really depends on your engagement. How much you can gain may also depend on what level of math you have.

This is a topics course so it is probably not going to get offered again, but if Prof. Aizenman is teaching another graduate topics course, seriously consider it. It will be an eye opening experience about what modern mathematical physics entails.
descrip: An introduction to mathematically rigorous methods in physics. Topics to be covered include classical and quantum statistical mechanic, quantum many-body problem, group theory, Schroedinger operators, and quantum information theory.

title: What is the Scientific Revolution?
reviews: Be sure to keep up with the readings; they're pretty interesting, but can also be quite dense, so you'll want to familiarize yourself with the work or the arguments ahead of precept.

I would advise them to work on their final papers as early as possible; the deadline of the final week of class is particularly brutal on juniors and seniors who, for the most part, have much more pressing things to be working on that last week of class.
Its a work load so keep on top of it.

Jenny and Kat are both great people who do an excellent job of explaining history and getting you to think about history in different ways. I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in science and needs to take a history course.
Look for overarching themes and read the required secondary readings that connect points together
Take it!
This class has an excellent professor and great lectures.  The readings are very long but worth doing most of them if you want an A
This course is a fascinating take on the scientific revolution. It might be a little older than you expect, but it's great for an HA.

You may seen previous comments that it is a good course to PDF, but it's not worth it. You still need to do the readings and still understand the material to pass, and honestly this class is very interesting and awesome
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators.
descrip: Something "happened" to science between 1450-1750. The sun replaced the earth at the center of the cosmos, Europeans encountered new worlds and new peoples, and heaven and earth shook to the impact of new technologies like telescopes and heavy artillery. Yet how much was really new? Did all these changes merge into one phenomenon that we can call "the scientific revolution"? And were there many such revolutions- or could the very idea be a modern invention? From optics and anatomy to alchemy and magic, this course will ask exactly how natural knowledge was shaped, challenged and exploited between the late Middle Ages and the Enlightenment.

title: Independent Work
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
reviews: Listen in, have fun, and ask lots of questions! Cool resource to get to interact with such a broad diversity of researchers.
Neuroscience graduate students must take this course. Unclear if others should take this, because it still needs work to become a good general survey course.
Self-studying is crucial to maximize what you get out of this course!
Take it.
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501A or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format that covers experimental and theoretical approaches to understanding how the brain works, spanning from the molecular and cellular to the systems and cognitive levels of analysis. It is organized into modules, each of which focuses on the neural mechanisms responsible for a specific subsystem or process, including perception, attention, learning, memory, decision making, executive function, motor control, emotion and motivation, and brain development. This is the second term of a double-credit core lecture course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Colonial Latin America to 1810
descrip: An introduction to the scholarship on Latin America's colonial past, ranging from "central" areas in Mexico and the Andes to "marginal" regions. New concepts and topics have emgerged. What are these new trends and what do they mean? Why do some types of questions now seem more urgent than others? To explore these questions and find out what problems of past historiographical traditions remain unsolved and deserve a new look, both classic texts and more recent works that display new approaches will be read, often in counterpoint.

title: International Trade II
reviews: I encourage anyone curious about international trade and recent advances in empirical research on trade to take this class.
descrip: A continuation of ECO 551, with emphasis on current research issues. Topics vary from year to year.

title: Early Modern Japan
reviews: A must-take if you're into Japan history. Marcon also is very good at providing epistemological/philosophical background of historical thinking.
Good PDF course. Professor Marcon is great and really is passionate about the subject.
I would definitely recommend taking this course. Prof Marcon is extremely passionate and you'll have a blast in lecture and thinking about the assignments.
I would say engage in class discussions and do the readings if you want to take the most out of this class.
I would take this class. Professor Marcon is phenomenal and you will learn to look at the world in new ways by exploring this different culture and time.
Marcon is a wonderful professor and he knows the material very well. It's an interesting and engaging course.

Marion's is a great guy--very dynamic individual. A bit disorganized however, so make sure you're okay with that. The course will make you think about how we conceptualize "the other" and what is normal.
Not too difficult, mostly memorization of key themes and evidence for them, secondary sources are more helpful than primary sources

Professor Marcon is a great lecturer! Take this class if you are interested in Japanese history, or just want to explore something new. Grading might be a bit harsh and there may be a lot of assignments, but you will enjoy the course at the end!
Take it, Professor Marcon is great
Take this course! The course title is dry, but the class itself is not. Go to lecture and you will learn everything you need to do well.
Take this course! but prepared that the lectures can sometimes be very long and dry.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the history and culture of Japan in the seventeenth through the late nineteenth centuries. This was the age of samurai rule, in which many elements of modern Japanese culture took familiar form. It was also the time when the roots of Japan's emergence as a modern state were laid.

title: Social Movements and Revolutions
descrip: Explores the study of social movements and mobilized collective action aimed at achieving or preventing social and political change. After examining various theoretical approaches to the field, we investigate a number of issues of abiding concern within the study of contentious politics: repertoires, networks, government responses to protest (repression and concessions), and protest policing. The final portion of the course is devoted to the study of the causes, dynamics, and effects of revolutions.

title: Contemporary China
reviews: Do not take this course if you have any prior knowledge of China. It is extremely surface level and did not learn anything new really. Arbitrary grading and poor organization. Disappointing overall.

Good course at the moment, with a few kinks. This was the first time it was offered and there were definitely a few procedural elements that need to be ironed out. If you're interested in China from a political perspective, this course doesn't delve too deeply into domestic politics or international relations. There's more of a focus on the demographic and economic aspects of Contemporary China, so if that's what you're interested in, this course would be a good fit for you.

Great class! Overall, I feel like I am coming away from this class with a much deeper understanding of the factors that have made China what it is today, and a much better understanding of what is happening in china economically, politically, and socially today. Coursework was very manageable in addition to readings, and lectures were typically pretty engaging. Definitely take this class if you're interested in China!
Start thinking about your final paper early. There was a miscommunication about if we could use independent work as a replacement for the final paper or not.
Take for interest! Helpful to have background in China/history/economics.
Take it! Professor Xie is extremely knowledgeable. Great class if you wanna learn about China. Provides a good overview about current topics.
The course crystalizes many key points about Chinese civilization - take it if you want to solidify your understanding of the Chinese perspective.
The readings can be heavy but are manageable for the most part. Professor Xie is an engaging lecturer, and the precepts are thought-provoking. I recommend this course.

This class is an excellent cursory overview of China. However, its confusing to me why its a 300-level class. This was the first time it was offered at Princeton and Professor Xie is new. He is extremely experienced but it felt like he was holding back in lecture. I'm optimistic that this class will improve in the future. However, if it stays the same then people with a basic knowledge of China should look elsewhere.
descrip: This course provides an overview of contemporary Chinese society. Chinese society is best understood through a number of different intrinsically-linked and mutually-interdependent aspects. For this reason, we will explore its history, cultural practices, government, economy, and family structure.

title: Senior Project
descrip: Students conduct a one-semester project. Topics chosen by students with approval of the faculty. A written report is required at the end of the term.

title: Topics in Analysis - Metric Embeddings and Geometric Inequalities
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor..
descrip: We discuss various advanced topics in the theory of bi-Lipschitz embeddings of metric spaces, as well as various fundamental results on vector-valued analysis from the local theory of Banach spaces. We also discuss various geometric inequalities that occur in these contexts, ranging from Grothendieck's inequality to metric type and co-type, and expanders with respect to metric spaces. The tools that we develop are useful in the context of approximation algorithms. We describe some of these algorithmic applications, but we mainly focus on developing the mathematical foundations.

title: The Gothic Tradition
descrip: The purpose of this course is to analyze and understand the cultural meanings of the Gothic mode through a study of its characteristic elements, its historical, aesthetic, and political origins in eighteenth-century English and German culture and thought, its development across Western national traditions, and its persistence in contemporary culture, including film, electronic media, clothing, social behavior, and belief systems, as well as literature. Films, artifacts, web sites and electronic publications will supplement readings.

title: The Modern World: Middle Eastern Perspectives
reviews: Great class to learn about how to structure a strong argument, how to counter-argue and about viewing the Middle East from a modern standpoint. Informative, engaging and fun!
descrip: Although the Middle East is often seen as exceptional, it is part of our globe: through connections and in being part of worldwide processes. This seminar's double goal is to study the Middle East from this perspective, and thereby also to explore how the modern world emerged. We will use Irye, Osterhammel, and Rosenberg, ed., A History of the World, 2 vols., covering 1870 to the present, as the backbone of the course; and in parallel read case studies on the Middle East in the world, including global cultural patterns, social webs, economic ties, imperial action, state building and international system, and the spread of political ideas.

title: Religion and Law
reviews: If you are willing to engage in a lot of reading and you like political philosophy, you will enjoy this class!
Take it if you're interested. Class discussions are decent.
Take this class. My favorite one at Princeton thus far and Professor Batnitzky is great!

The subject is fascinating and so are the readings. The regular short responses on Blackboard are an excellent exercise for learning how to write clearly and concisely. The presence of graduate students makes the level of conversation very high. However, prepare the seminars and read the readings very carefully. Mrs Batnitzky leaves much room for students' comments, so that you should expect to speak a lot.
This course is very intellectually stimulating but may require some prior knowledge about Christianity and Judaism.
This is a tough course in terms of the readings you have to do, but you'll learn a lot (and you'll sound a lot smarter in other classes for having taken it).
descrip: A critical examination of the relation between concepts of "religion" and "law," as they figure in modern Christian and Jewish thought, as well as in contemporary legal theory. If religion gives law its spirit, and law gives religion its structure, then what is their practical relation in both religious and secular life? This course explores the relation between Jewish and Christian conceptions of law, both in their ancient and modern contexts, and the relation between traditional religious and modern secular views of law.

title: Natural Disasters
reviews: A great way to fulfill the distribution requirement for a science with lab.
Boring but easy enough lab and easy to PDF
Complete work earlier in case you need guidance. Make sure you use labs to study. Reach out to Laurel or Professor Rubin for help.
Easy STL.
Easy STL. Not terribly interesting, but not a lot of work, either.
Engage with the material and the readings! And be diligent and involved with the labs!
Fairly easy course for a totally not at all science-inclined student, to fulfill STL.
Go to lecture and do readings and will do well in the class
Good

I feel like this is one of the best ways for non-science majors to fulfill the STL requirement. The labs were interesting and not over-demanding, and the lectures and the material was all very interesting because of how relevant it is to the real world.

I think this is a manageable course for those looking for an STL requirement, but go into it knowing you will need to dedicate time for labs. And please go to lectures and try to be awake to pay full attention.

I would recommend it if you are interested in taking an STL that is decently interesting at points and not back-breaking in terms of work.  It's no lay-up, though. Overall, the class is well-structured.
I would recommend this course.
It's a good course if you need an STL
Pay close attention in lecture because most of the course's vital information is given orally by the professor rather than written out on lecture slides.
Perfect STL course for those looking to fulfill the distribution requirement.
Take it!!

Take this class!!! Super interesting!!
 grades are generous as long as you do the work.
Take this course as a relatively easy STL requirement for a humanities major.
Take this course as it provides an excellent overview of many natural disasters, and it is a very interesting STL to take.
Take this course if you need a manageable STL and don't mind putting in some work.
There are more interesting classes on campus. Everyone is really nice, the material is just boring.
This class was a LOT of work, but you will learn quite a bit. Your lab instructor will make or break this course.
This is a good way to fulfill the STL requirement for non-science majors.
Try to take a lab with a preceptor thats good
f
super interesting if you are into learning about natural disasters, loved this class!
descrip: An introduction to natural (and some society-induced) hazards and the importance of public understanding of the issues related to them. Emphasis is on the geological processes that underlie the hazards, with discussion of relevant policy issues tied to reading recent newspaper/popular science articles. Principal topics: Earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunami, hurricanes, floods, meteorite impacts, global warming. Intended primarily for non-science majors.

title: Designing Sustainable Systems - Demonstrating the potential of sustainable design thinking
reviews: A fun design based course which is outside the normal pedestrian science classes and deals with topics which actually matter to, you know, the future
A good STL.
An easy STN, but you won't really learn much.
An interesting, sometimes fun class, though somewhat poorly organized.
Definitely take, really interesting course that makes you think about sustainability in a different way. Manageable/Easy workload

Don't be afraid to be upfront with your interests! It is a very customizable course in that if you express an interest in any of the particular subjects of the course, your preceptor will likely adapt, and you can style your projects however you want.

Don't take this class...information would be interesting if the lectures weren't so frustratingly pointless and boring. All the work feels like high school busy work and the preceptors offer almost no guidance on the long term projects.
Don't take this if you want an easy STN. It's not that it was particularly hard, it was just too much work for a student who isn't interested in pursuing architecture or environmental studies.
Easy STN
Engaging, interesting concepts that are useful and widely applicable.
Focus on the assignments

Good course for an overview of sustainability concepts. Be ready to learn first half of course by yourself (lectures aren't productive)- but design thinking element is great. It's as good as you make it.
Good requirement and the group project was actually super fun.
Great STN! Take it and make sure to be in Eric's precept, he's great!
Great class if you're looking for an STN
Highly recommend taking this class if you have interest in both the environment and design projects.
I would advise to take an active role in the group work.
I would not advise. Is boring. If you need a distribution requirement and are pdfing maybe
I would not recommend this course if you are trying to take an easy P/D/F. I had to put a lot of work into this course b/c there is a hard problem set and group project each week.
I would say that this is more of an STL than an STN. Be prepared to spend a lot of time outside the classroom on assignments.
I would take another stn if you are pdf-ing

If you want to actually learn technical details, steer clear. The class is quite "dumbed down" to appeal to AB majors. There's a heavy emphasis on the final design project, which means if you get assigned into a bad group, it could be a long semester.

Interesting introduction to sustainability, many topics are truly interesting and it's a good first approach. If you're actually TRULY interested in the topic, you'll get frustrated at the composition of the class: most people are there just to get rid of a distribution requirement and don't really give a damn. That makes it really really hard to work with your group (you'll work with them the entire semester and you do not get to chose your group). Guest lectures are very interesting. Professor and TAs very friendly and helpful. Definitely on the easy side (at least for STEM people)
It's a good course to take for an STN credit

It's very easy. The guest lectures are interesting, but not worth taking the entire course unless you have no prior background in the information and will be super engaged. Otherwise, you'll get bored very quickly.

Probably the most boring lecture that I've had at Princeton. Homework and precept assignments seem pretty arbitrary and pointless. Sometimes there are unnecessarily high expectations for an intro class.
Take for STN
Take if you need an STN! Not too bad and Forrest is a good guy.
Take it and start working on the final project early.
Take it but it's a lot of work for a PDF class.
Take it if interested in design and sustainability, will learn a lot conceptually
Take this course! Engage yourself in it. It's an average workload, but you will learn so many important and applicable things.
Take this if you're interested in sustainability and you want significant flexibility to embark on a project that may affect Princeton.
The course has been getting better every year, so keep your hopes up and give it a try!
The design project is a lot of fun especially if you try to make a project that will have a sustainable impact.
This class is merely okay. It can be interesting at times. While the work is not difficult, it is quite time consuming. Would recommend if you need a straightforward STN.
This is a great course that shows how sustainable design can be implemented. It can be a little disorganized, but the professor is really cool. Getting a good group for the group project is key.

This is an amazing course if you don't have a lot of prior knowledge of environmental science and enjoy creative problem-solving. It will teach you about the sustainability issues in our world today that play into every area of your personal and academic life, just take the class to find out! I think this or something similar to it should be a required course for all students.
If you have a strong background in environmental science already, this class will still be interesting but perhaps won't stimulate huge amounts of growth.
You better pray you get matched with competent group partners. Stephen is a good preceptor, if he's teaching this again.
requirement course
descrip: Integrating the process of design and system thinking with an understanding of fundamental environmental and societal principals of sustainability is necessary to enact sustainable societal changes. This course starts with a study of the science related to sustainability and how open-ended sustainable development problems can be addressed through a process of design, and leads to a major group design project focused on devising and demonstrating an opportunity for sustainability on campus. Fabrication, simulation, sensor and graphical tools will be incorporated into the design process learning and deployed in precept.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Growth, International Finance & Crises
descrip: This is a macro, international finance-oriented development course, which will focus on the political economy of policy decisions. It will cover the following themes: 1. GDP growth and volatility; 2. the size, composition, and influence of international capital flows; 3. sudden stops in capital flows and financial crises; 4. the domestic and multilateral response to crises, including the role of fiscal adjustment, external financing, and debt restructuring; 5. We will draw on several country case-studies and students will be encouraged to undertake short research assignments to deepen their own policy interests.

title: Combustion
descrip: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, oxidation of hydrogen, hydrocarbons and alternate fuels, pollutant chemistry and control, transport phenomena, laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames, turbulent flames, ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena, flame stabilization and blowoff, detonation and blast waves, droplet, spray and coal particle combustion, principles of engine operation.

title: Advanced Economic Theory II
descrip: Topics vary from year to year. See 511.

title: Milton
reviews: A fantastic survey of Milton. Thought-provoking lectures and assignments for both beginners and those who have read Milton before, and a manageable workload.
Amazing class. Take it if you can. When else will you get the chance?
Attend office hours as often as you can. Professor Leo is so passionate about the material, and every conversation, no matter how short, gets you to see the readings in a new or different way.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take it! You will come out with a huge appreciation for Milton.
Definitely take this course! Even if you don't think you are interested in Milton you will enjoy this course very much (and will come to love the poems!)

If you're at all interested in Milton/ 17th century Britain, take this course. Professor Leo does an excellent job of making material that might otherwise seem dense and dry accessible and compelling.
Professor Leo is an amazing lecturer - the best I've seen at balancing summary of the text and original argument. And he really cares about students
Professor Leo is an amazing lecturer and one of my favorite professors here. Take anything he teaches! He's incredibly engaging.

TAKE THIS CLASS...if it is with Professor Leo - take any class with him, he's incredible! Can't speak for other professors, but if it's with Professor Leo, his lectures are super, super engaging and he will make sure that you understand what's going on in Milton. He is always willing to meet outside of class and talk through ideas. Workload is very manageable - you move through Paradise Lost at a relatively slow pace, which is helpful for understanding it better.
Take it with Leo!
Take it!! It might seem out of your comfort zone, but it was worth delving deep into the works of John Milton.
Take it, be prepared to delve into the readings.
Take it. Go to office hours for guaranteed A on your essay.
Take this course!! Professor Leo is incredibly passionate about the material and enthusiastic in helping students understand it. Schedule office hours if you can. Don't miss out on this one.

This class is great for anyone who has any interest whatsoever in religious writing, epic poetry, and John Milton. The professor and preceptor are very energetic and engaging, and invite students to look at the material in new and unconventional ways.
This was a phenomenal course.  Highly recommended!

Whether or not you've read Milton, and specifically Paradise Lost, this course is fantastic. Professor Leo is an amazing lecturer. I learned so much in this class, and was always engaged in it. The work was manageable and interesting. I highly recommend the class.
Would very much recommend this course. Whether you are looking to complete a distro requirement or to study Milton in depth, this is a great course.
descrip: We will explore John Milton's entire career, largely as poet, but also as prose writer and thinker: a lifelong effort to unite the aims of intellectual, political and literary experimentation. In doing so Milton made himself the most influential non-dramatic poet in the English language. We will spend much time with Paradise Lost, regarded by many as the greatest non-dramatic poem in English or any modern language; we will encounter Milton's profound, extensive learning and his startling innovations with words, and in ideas of personal, domestic and communal liberty.

title: Econometric Theory II
reviews:
Go over the lecture slides after class and the problem sets will be much easier as a result since they both give fair questions based on what they taught. 

For Ulrich's part of the course, the Hamilton time series book is a good resource. I also recommend attempting all of the coding problems since they are very helpful for understanding the concepts.
I would strongly recommand this class to any student who wants to extend a little the basic curriculum of econometrics, or who needs a solid introduction to time series.
descrip: This course begins with extensions of the linear model in several directions: (1) pre-determined but not exogenous regressors; (2) heteroskedasticity and serial correlation; (3) classical GLS; (4) instrumental variables and generalized method of movements estimators. Applications include simultaneous equation models, VARS and panel data. Estimation and inference in non-linear models are discussed. Applications include nonlinear least squares, discrete dependent variables (probit, logit, etc.), problems of censoring, truncation and sample selection, and models for duration data.

title: Social Lives, Social Forces
reviews: Ask questions, challenge, debate, engage. Taking a course with Dr. Greenhouse is a true treat, make sure you take advantage of it.
DO THE READINGS
Do as much of the reading as possible and contribute in seminar - and don't hesitate to visit professor Greenhouse with any help understanding the class.

I would definitely recommend this course! I think it is extremely interesting class and gives students a nice sampling of what anthropology has to offer (examples of what ethnographic field work can yield, anthropological theory and "everything" in between!) Do the readings! They are interesting and having done them makes the seminars much more interesting.
I would recommend it for anyone with an interest in anthropology, or someone who is simply trying to get requirements out of the way.
I would say that other students should be prepared for class and actively ask questions while reading and of their classmates' points.
Professor Greenhouse is truly brilliant. Interesting course
Take it; take it; take it. You won't regret. Greenhouse gives a great introduction into Anthropology.
Take this course if you are interested in law and the way in which social forces shape our lives.

This class is good for students familiar in anthropology, and also those who want an exposure to the field. Professor Greenhouse is great - be sure to make use of her office hours and your class experience will be even better!

This course is amazing! Professor Greenhouse speaks poetry, truly cares about the students, and teaches brilliantly. You will think about yourself, society, and things like the interaction between work and family in totally new ways. There's not too much of a workload, and the readings are really interesting.
definitely take a course with professor Greenhouse if you get the opportunity!
descrip: This seminar takes up the connection between authority and obligation as a cultural question. We draw on diverse sources (anthropology, case studies, social theory, literature, public documents, art, etc.) to probe conceptual and real-life gray zones between individual and community, liberty and constraint, state and private sector. We consider formal and informal institutions (e.g., courts, legislatures, police, workplaces, families) and a range of formal and informal norms (from court rulings to common sense).
