Authority and obligation emerge as complex social relations that shape and are shaped within and across cultural contexts.

title: Medical Spanish
reviews: Definitely take this course at some point at Princeton if you are interested in medicine in Spanish-speaking countries. Just know that if you're jumping straight from a 100-level course (107 or 108), it might be a bit of a transition! Definitely put in the work, and see Paloma if you ever need help - she is fantastic!
Overall, a very solid Spanish class. A decent time-commitment; however, for anyone interested in pursuing a medically-related field, I feel like this class would be of great use in the future.

Paloma is a great professor and really nice. If you have any interest in medicine and Spanish this is definitely the class for you. Workload is minimal, although this class is NOT an easy A. You could definitely get a B  without doing a ton of work. Lectures are primarily Paloma just talking about medical spanish or her injury history. Grade consists of medical interviews, vocab tests, compositions and a project. Overall a nice class.
Prepare for entrevistas, work on your speaking, and pay a lot of attention to the essays.
TAKE IT. The most useful class I have taken at Princeton. Paloma is bae.
Take it! Most practical course I've ever taken!
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission) or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP 5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: An advanced Spanish language course with a focus on health and medical topics. Its main purpose is to provide students with the tools to interact with Spanish speakers in a health environment, either in the US or in Latin America. Students will improve their general communication skills and learn the specific vocabulary necessary for the medical interview. The course will also explore aspects of the Latino culture in the fields of health and medicine through authentic documents and the contribution of guest speakers. There will be a project in which students interact with the local Latino community.

title: Documentary Filmmaking
reviews: Great course!! You learn so much about documentary film. You really get a chance to express yourself through what you make. It's different from most other courses. Put the work in, and you'll be proud at the end of the semester. (Also, Su is blunt but awesome--she'll be real with you. Sometimes, especially in creative fields, you need that. It's refreshing to have a professor like her at Princeton.)
I recommend people who are interested in trying out a new medium to take this course. It is a great intro to film!

If you have any interest in film making, I would highly recommend this course. The workload is very manageable. The topics and films are very interesting and Su is great. You can also work a bit at your own pace, You will simply get out however much you put into it. I took this as my fifth class as an MAE if you're considering how it can fit into your schedule.

Su is a wonderful teacher, and you can tell she genuinely cares a lot about her students. Take this class for the films you'll get exposure to as well as the opportunity to do something completely new (if this is new for you). This class gives you a comprehensive introduction to all aspects of documentary filmmaking, so I'd say there is something for everyone.

Su's feedbacks were very helpful in terms of seeing how my documentary could be improved. I think it was hard to see what may be potential problems that may arise in terms of making my own documentary.
Take this!! Su is very blunt, but she is also very caring and passionate about her craft. It's rare to find professors like her!
The fact that it's PDF only goes a long way, there is far less pressure creatively. Worth it just to get access to the equipment, but you get some good tips and theory too.

This class is really great. You actually learn a lot about filming and video editing under an instructor who knows what she's talking about. And you get to create a couple of films. Just be aware that Su Friedrich doesn't mess around. She takes her class seriously despite it being a PDF, and you won't get away with skipping a class, for example. Not without doing substantial make-up work.
take it
v interesting class, would recommend, lot of work for a PDF but it's rewarding and fun. su rocks
descrip: This course introduces students to documentary film production using digital video, with an emphasis on the practical challenges of working in the real world. While students learn the traditional methods of production, they are also encouraged to range widely in their thinking about how to document daily life. Production of videos will be augmented by screenings, readings, and visiting filmmakers.

title: Leadership Development for Business
reviews: Class fills up with all seniors. Very easy in workload. I'm guessing over half of students PDF. Lectures and readings are interesting but you have to put in at least a little time and effort to get anything out of it. Lots of these topics seem obvious, but knowing how socially and professionally inept most Princeton students are, most could gain a lot by taking the class. Midterm and final are very easy. Group project was very easy. A few pop quizes which are easy if you did the readings. A really good senior PDF to help your transition into the workforce...just do the readings and contribute to class.

Definitely a course to take before you graduate! This course is an incredible opportunity to learn from someone who has had a long and successful career in business, and Professor Strigl is genuinely an kind and genuine person. Normally, discussion-based courses at Princeton are not great, but the format works for this course! The readings, project, exams, and lectures were all top quality. Expectations/grading policy were all pretty clear as well, so it doesn't take too much effort to take this course for a letter grade although many people seem to take this as a PDF.
Definitely take this class if you want to learn something worthwhile and not end up in jail for bad decision making!!!
Great course by a great instructor.
Great course!
Great course. Interesting material and reasonable workload.
Highly recommend this class. Very enjoyable experience and it's interesting to hear Prof. Strigl talk about his stories.
I would recommend this class to students planning on pursuing positions in business settings.
If you are a senior, TAKE THIS CLASS. Strigl is great and will gladly impart lots of life advice and knowledge on you.
Interesting course, particularly the business case studies! Not a ton of work and the prof is accessible and encouraging even with his hugely prolific background.
It's a very easy class, not 100% sure what I learned, much is Strigl's opinions, but definitely something different to round off senior spring. Some is common sense.
Professor Strigl has great stories and anecdotes, and provides interesting analysis on current events. Didn't feel like I learned too much more, but still greatly enjoyed the class.
Solid class, although more work than I was expecting for a safe PDF.
Strigl is a boss
Take it
Take it for Denny Strigyl. He's a super nice guy who really wants to see his students succeed. Great course to take senior year. Not to much work overall.
Take it if you want an easy class!
Take it!
Take this class! Best class at Princeton.
Take this course if you want an easy course with an extremely interesting Professor.
Take, take, take it! My favorite class at Princeton, Denny is the man!
This class is definitely one of the easiest I've taken at Princeton; very good for seniors to learn some strategies for entering the real world; Strigl's lectures can be boring though.
This class was my favorite I've taken at Princeton. I felt like I could focus on really learning the material because I wasn't piled with work the entire semester. Highly recommend.
You should take it, for a very interesting class with valuable lessons to learn.
definitely take this course if you want to take an interesting and chill class
great senior course
pay attention in lecture because exams draw on random facts we learn in class
take it. strigl is humble, down to earth, and takes a strong interest in everyones' learning.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The Leadership Development for Business course deals with the strategic, organizational and leadership challenges that global corporations face. The course provides students with a unique perspective on leadership vision, and how leaders recognize and capitalize on opportunities. We will focus on how leaders achieve results and make things happen working with and through others. This course presents innovative, practical and field tested methods used by successful business leaders to achieve sustained results. Classes will consist of a mix of classroom lecture, case study discussions and guest speakers.

title: Gilded Age and Progressive-Era United States, 1877-1920
reviews: Do not take this course unless you need it to fulfill a pre-20th century U.S. history requirement. Professor Rix's lectures are incredibly boring and hard to follow. She does not consult any notes and the class period feels like a stream of consciousness that is not prepared or structured in any way. This time period is extremely interesting but this class does not do it justice.
Great course! Not too heavy a reading load so do it all. Also go to all the lectures!

If you are interested in United States history, this class covers one of the most fascinating time periods of change.  Professor Rix does a great job at covering all of the material in an interesting way.
Pretty chill class, you will learn a lot.
Take it! Rix is great

Take this course if you have already studied some history- it's not a good first class, but if you know how to do history at Princeton it's a good one to take. Easy to connect with current events, but the professor and preceptor are anything but presentist.

This is a GREAT class. The workload is very light compared to other classes (especially STEM classes!). Don't be afraid to take it if you're a freshman; it's completely manageable, though not many freshmen take it.

Would highly recommend for anyone interested in US history, mainly because we don't get a good background on this info in other places. Professor RIx is a great professor, who will go the extra mile for any of her students.
You'll consider history through a whole new lens, entirely worth it.
take another history course
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators.
descrip: This course introduces key themes in U. S. history from Reconstruction to 1920. We explore changing understandings of individual rights and the role of the federal government in protecting liberty and equality; industrialization, the modern business corporation, and changing labor conditions; local self-government and civil society; westward and colonial expansion; the challenges posed by urbanization and immigration; the "New South;" Populism; Progressivism; reform experiments; modernism; and World War I. Period film screenings and campus Gothic architecture tour optional.

title: Macroeconomics: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: 311 is a fine ECO class. If you're taking it, it's likely because its required. Be prepared for dry lectures and a lot of derivations.

An important econ course and one that's probably a distribution requirement, but still one worth taking, as it provides good mathematical explanations for economic intuitions and develops models that are still relevant for the field today.
Consider taking this class if you are interested in macroeconomics and want to learn it from a more rigorous and microeconomics related approach.
Go to class and pay attention. If you don't understand, go to office hours. Also you should be good at math.
Go to every lecture.
Great introduction to basic macroeconomic models. Do the homeworks and study up and you should be fine.
Great, fun models. I only learned them when I was studying for the final, but was happy that I did.

I highly recommend this course for anyone interested in theoretical economics or economics in general; it gives a presentation of macroeconomics which is fully rigorous and mathematically-founded, something which may be harder to find in other classes.
It is required for Econ major anyway so you might as well take it. It is quite enjoyable and interesting if you don't mind too many theoretical approaches.
It's a fun course. Don't let anyone tell you it's too mathematical.
Only take if Econ and not intimidated by math (lots of Lagrangian)
Practice with past year problems

Ryo was good, but this class all depends on the professor. If you are decent at math (read: if you were fine in MAT 201) then take 311. 301 (non-math-track) is much drier and makes you memorize more stuff. Also, the curve is awesome in 311 (bc it's a self-selecting group) - more than half of all students get A-grades.
Study hard for the midterm. It was a bit unexpected compared to the problem sets, and the lack of time makes it very tough.
Take this class only if you want to learn a lot about some macroeconomic models. There's a lot of math involved.
Take this course. It is pretty difficult. Go to Ryo's office hours. The course is about abstract mathematical models for different economic theories of growth, business cycles, etc.

The material is difficult, but really interesting once you understand it. I definitely had to put in a lot of work, but it was interesting once I did. I liked the way Professor Jinnai taught - he wrote all of the notes on the board, as opposed to using slides, which actually made it easier to follow and remember.
The math isn't too difficult and the concepts are fairly decent to grasp. Just study your notes well!
This course is fine. If you don't have to take it I might not though.
This is curved more generously than ECO301, so if you don't have a problem with the math, which is mostly algebra, I think this is better.

Two pieces of advice: 1) Don't take this if you haven't already taken 310, and 2) Don't drop to 301 after the first lecture. Professor Jinnai is very knowledgeable in the material, but it takes a few weeks to get used to the class's structure. Problem sets are hard, but aren't every week, which is good. Class is curved very well.
You're probably going to have take it. Make sure you try to understand what's going on behind the math.
take it if you want to learn macro with more math!
the previous evaluations said this class was awful and so hard but it really wasn't that bad
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 and MAT 175 or MAT 201..
descrip: This course examines the determinants of long-run economic growth, short-run business cycle fluctuations, and the conduct of monetary and fiscal policy. The first part of the course develops a framework for the analysis of households' consumption and savings behavior and firms' production decisions, and uses that to analyze long-run growth and financial crises. The second part of the course extends that analysis to examine business cycle fluctuations, including inflation, unemployment. Current issues in macroeconomic and financial policy are discussed throughout.

title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
reviews: A very manageable class. Not riveting, but still interesting.

A very straightforward, low-stress EC. Even if the material is intellectually stimulating, the class sometimes isn't, but if you just want to get the requirement out of the way, this is the class for you.

An easy but mildly annoying class if you want to get a distribution requirement out of the way. Very minimal work - but if you want something more fulfilling then I would recommend finding something else.

An easy class IF you're good at keeping track of small details, since the grading is very picky about little things. The subject matter is fairly interesting, but the textbook can be a bit dry and the grading system is a bit annoying.
Decently easy EC. Definitely take it for an easy intro to LIN. Very little work outside of class.
Do it for the EC. PDF it. If you can pass out of this as a LIN major/minor, you should.
Easy EC, super easy PDF
Easy class to PDF for a General Education requirement. Not very thought-provoking / stimulating though.
Easy distribution. Not a lot of work, especially in the second half of the semester. Make sure you get a good preceptor, and you won't have to do the readings.
Easy, interesting course
Either read the textbook or go to class

GREAT easy, well-taught course. Try to get Cory as your preceptor. I was a computer science major, and I would've wanted a more analytical rather than mechanical approach to linguistics, but otherwise, a solid class.
Good course to learn the basics of linguistics, not very challenging, and can be a good fifth class
Good for distributions! Material tends to be a bit boring sometimes however.
Good way to do an EC. Be careful about exams though as a small mistake can cost you, since it's pretty easy and the averages are usually high.
Good, relatively easy class to take. If you attend lecture and precept and be attentive, you won't have to read very much by yourself.

Great fifth class. Spent ~1 hour a week on this class outside of lecture and precept. Skim the first few chapters of the book and always attend lectures and you'll be solid. Great for PDF, but if you want an A be ready to work at least a bit since the median grade will be like a 91%

I mean I think this class is worth taking if you don't want to do a lot of work, a low workload is its only redeeming factor but at Princeton that's a pretty big plus. I almost would give it a higher rating just because it won't overwork you and stress you out when balancing so much intensive work.) That being said its a miserable affair and would be wholly not worth it if the workload increased  at all The professor is very clearly not on your side in terms of wanting you to do well, lectures are absolutely useless.
I recommend it as long as Ross-Feldman isn't teaching again.
I would recommend this class to anyone who is mildly curious about linguistics. It is eye-opening, easy to follow and not too much of a commitment.
I would take for an easy distribution req.

If you haven't had any experience with linguistics I recommend you take it, this course has changed my academic life. Linguistics is a lot of fun, just make sure you are on top of the readings and the problem sets. Attend the lectures! The professor's lecture comments are helpful.
Interesting material about topics you perhaps haven't noticed or thought about before.
Interesting material, and not a difficult class. Probably about half an hour of work a week outside of attending lecture.
It's a chill EC, and Lord knows these don't come around that often. And it's sorta interesting. I say take it!
It's not too much work but it's worth going to the lectures they're engaging.
It's pretty easy, just actually try hard on the homework. Paying attention in precept will help with that.
It's super easy - take it.
It's super easy but really not that interesting.
Not a bad class for EC. Pretty interesting though in my opinion a pretty useless class. But still interesting and nice.
Not a great class but also not very time consuming. Take it if you want an easy EC but not if you want to actually learn about linguistics.
Not a great course.  Take it for an easy fifth class, but if you're actually interested in linguistics you will likely be frustrated at how topical the presentation of the material is.
Not exactly the glorious easy 5th class people make it out to be. Does require attention to detail, and will be more boring/less engaging than you would've thought.
One must really work in the beginning, because there is a lot of small things that one can miss and be penalized dearly for.
Read the book and do it before class, because it is impossible to get everything that Professor Ross-Feldman says down on paper, but the book will help you with some of it.
Really use your book when reviewing for exams.
Recommend taking if you are looking for an easy introduction to linguistics!
Super easy PDF course, easy without PDF as well. Dry and boring lectures straight from the textbook, memorization for the midterm but open notes/book final exam.
Super easy. Nice for second semester seniors

TAKE. This course is genuinely fascinating, very light in workload, and generous in grading. That's the perfect combination for students wanting a fifth or sixth class. The problem sets take less than an hour each and there are only four of them. The median grade in the class is an A minus. Also, and most importantly, you learn a lot in this course and it's very cool stuff. I have friends who weren't interested in linguistics at all who took the course with me and now they're thinking they'll pursue the certificate. TIPS: If the course is full, email the professor and ask for a spot on the waitlist. The semester I took it they expanded the course and everyone who asked to be on the waitlist got in. Also make sure you spend a few hours studying for the midterm and learn IPA and your vowel chart well. It's the only assignment you'll have that isn't open book. When doing the fourth problem set make sure to put an asterisk before proto-words and proto-sounds.
Take for a fun and easy EC! Still need to put a little work into it, but for the most part very manageable and fun
Take it if you have any interest in linguistics! It's a good course that's not too much work, and lectures are decent. Problem sets are fun if you like puzzles.
Take it if you want a decently interesting EC.
Take it if you want an easy A, you won't learn too much though.
Take it if you're interested in linguistics. It's a good introduction and not particularly difficult.
Take it if you're interested. You will get the most out of this class if you attend lecture.

Take it in the fall. If you do it in the spring, PDF it. It's a reachable A/A-, but you have to execute perfection on all assignments, midterm, and final in order to not fall into the B  range. Otherwise, great class to PDF since you don't have to go to lecture.
Take it! Interesting and not too much work.
Take the course if you want an easy P but generally interesting course.
Take this class - super fun and not a lot of work (the only hard p-set is #1, don't let it scare you).
Take this class. Easy enough and very interesting.
Take this course if you are looking for an easier EC or if you are interested in linguistics.
Take this for an easy EC.

The grading can be pretty nitpicky. Lecture slides are not posted online. Course material is interesting and preceptors are helpful. No homework or midterm solutions are posted, but they are reviewed during precept.
There are MUCH better EC's, so please spare your time.
This is a good course to take as an EC. It is pretty interesting and does not require an insane amount of work or preparation. Provides an interesting way to think about languages and other things.
This is a good introduction to the subject of linguistics. It's always a great class to take to fulfill the EC requirement.
This is a great elective course.  Low work load but not boring.

This is a really good class to fulfill your EC requirement. You learn interesting material, it doesn't take too much work, and the assessments are very reasonable. No need to PDF unless you are planning to not attend any lectures.
Understanding how to do each problem from precept and the homework assignments should help you prepare well for exams.
Very interesting subject matter, light course-load.
take if you have to, beginning material is really interesting
take this! it is fun and different to any other class you will take
descrip: An introduction to the scientific analysis of the structure and uses of language. Core areas covered include phonetics and phonology, morphology, the lexicon, syntax, semantics and pragmatics, with data from a wide range of languages. Topics include the biological basis of language, language and cognition, the neurology of language and language disorders, and first and second language acquisition.

title: Theory of Algorithms
reviews: A good class for fulfilling your theory requirement, that isn't too difficult.

As a student who found 340 to be pretty difficult, 423 ended up being not so bad. While the problem sets are usually harder, there are fewer of them and Professor Tarjan is very helpful if you ask for help. A good class to fulfill the second theory requirement.
Find a good group and go to office hours.
For a theory req, this is good.
Go to Tarjan's office hours. He's great to talk to for the problem sets.
Good for the theory requirement, a little dry, but not too bad
Hard

Honestly it's not a great course, but I put in a medium amount of effort and am going to get a grade I think I'm satisfied with. That being said, if you're trying to learn from this class with Tarjan, you may face great difficulties - our last pset was revised not once, not twice, but FIVE TIMES, due to errors in the problem specifications that STUDENTS caught and the professor did not. This happened many times throughout the semester. The lecture notes are also not very clear, and Tarjan seems to be constantly catching errors he wrote himself in the slides.
I learned not from lecture but from the problem sets and office hours. Curve is nice enough. Grade is 100% problem sets (final is a pset that counts for double)
I'd take the course to fulfill the theory requirement.
Interesting material but some of the problem sets are very challenging. Luckily usually a problem set only every other week which helps. Not bad to fulfill your theory and useful material
It's a reasonable second theory class. Just bite the bullet. Workload is definitely smaller than 340.
It's hard but collaborative. You will learn quite a bit
It's hard, but you just have to suck it up and make the most of it. Consider yourself lucky if you're allowed to work in teams.
Its a class worth taking, but don't expect to get much out of it beyond the problem sets themselves.
Just work hard on the problem sets, but this class isn't actually so hard and Tarjan is awesome. Office hours are crucial.

Lecture are extremely dry. Tarjan's a really dull lecturer. However, he is amazing in office hours. Office hour's and one on ones with him make you realize how brilliant this guy is. Definitely take it and you won't regret meeting him.
Less work and feels easier than 340, and it forces you to think rigorously about most of the algorithms and data structures covered in 226. Great way to fulfill the theory requirement.
Let's be honest, you don't really have a choice.
Make sure you're interested in algorithms before taking the class. Rereading lecture slides and referencing CLRS after lectures will help to understand them.
Not sure how much lecture/precept helps, but the material is nice and Tarjan is a god.
Poorly managed course
Pretty awesome class, Prof. Tarjan is the best- so patient, so smart

Professor Tarjan is very tough but very fair and will go out of his way to help you. The more math and CS background before taking this class the better. For a rather theoretical look at practical algorithms, this class is a must-take.
Reasonable to take for the theory requirement.
Recommend for last cos theory requirement. Biweekly psets take much less time than 340.
Recommend this course to fulfill Theory req.
Start psets on the earlier side. Go to office hours, which are very generous.
Super interesting and makes you think. Good class.
Take care...
Take it and go to Tarjan's office hours.
Take it as your theory requirement if you have to. It's pretty high stress due to the binary grading, no collaboration policy, but Tarjan is very nice and helpful in office hours.
Take it if you're interested in theory. The proofs aren't that bad.
Take this course but be prepared to work hard -- lectures are pretty useless, psets are difficult. Still probably the best theory class though.

Take this course. It will teach you to analyse algorithms. Or rather, you will learn to anal analyse algorithms as a result of the class. You, though, will be responsible for most of the learning, for you will have to read and review material a lot outside of lecture. But, it is totally worth it. Also, Tarjan is a legend and it always pays off to take a class with a legend. Go for it, but budget 10-20 hours on the biweekly psets.

This class was mad decent -- to get the "bad" out of the way, lectures are SUPER dry. No point of going to them if you had enough sleep the previous night. Pretty much everything else is good about the class -- problem sets are not too long and are comprehensive (only 7 the whole year) and Tarjan's office hours are the bomb. Take the class if you're interested in algorithms or theory, but don't expect it to change your mind on either.

This course is very time intensive, and with the binary grading scheme, a large amount of time can be spent working on a problem, to get 0 on a question. Given that the course is out of ~50 points, each time this happens there is a noticeable drop in your potential grade.

This was similar to 340, except with 2 weeks for problem sets, they teach you all the material on the homeworks, and the grading for problem sets is all-or-nothing, with ~90% correct as the threshold for getting points. Go to Tarjan's office hours if you need help! I found it very enjoyable but I am an algorithmically-minded COS major. Definitely a good way to complete your theory requirement.
Try to avoid unless you need the departmental or are really good at strong proofs
Typical theoretical cos theory, but fewer problem sets than 340 so not quite as much work.
Work hard, you need to learn the material on your own.
its a theory class. actually wasnt too much work.
take if you need a theory
prereqs: COS 226 and 340, or permission of instructor.
descrip: Design and analysis of efficient data structures and algorithms. General techniques for building and analyzing algorithms. Introduction to NP-completeness.

title: International News - The Foreign Correspondent and the New Media
reviews: Deb is absolutely amazing. She knows so much about the field and how to help make your articles even better. I could see a clear improvement in my writing over the course of the semester. While I'm not going to be a journalist, this was a great class to take, to explore a new field, and to improve my writing skills, especially in a non-academic style paper setting.
Definitely worth taking. A great class that is at times challenging, but overall a great balance. Very good for people interested in an intro to writing journalism

Experiences with this course will definitely vary with the professor. Deb Amos is an experienced, well-connected journalist with lots of knowledge on the Middle East. If you have any interest in that region, whether or not you are interested in it from a journalism perspective, I would highly recommend this course. Otherwise, it's still a great experience that only (though significantly) lacks the aspect of actually being abroad.

Good amount of reading but nothing unreasonable.
Start early on the final project!
Journalism classes at Princeton are absolutely wonderful. I highly highly recommend taking this course and using the opportunity to learn from an active and experienced journalist!

Take this course. Best course ever taken with the best professor (Deb Amos) that I've ever had. It's work, it's time consuming, it's difficult, but there's nothing better even if you only have cursory interests in journalism. 11/10.

Take this if you have some journalism experience or know how to write for journalism (vs. academic papers), and are confident enough to spend hours emailing and calling people to track down sources for your assignments.  Also possibly be prepared to take a GPA hit. That said, it's an incredible opportunity to meet cool speakers and learn from an experienced, famous journalist who's here to teach for the semester and has a lot to impart.
prereqs: If the course fills, you may email ldetitta@princeton.edu to be put on a waiting list. Please include a paragraph about the reasons for your interest in the course..
descrip: International news is delivered across a wide variety of platforms. There has never been a better time for reporting based on deep background, an extensive network of sources, and good writing. This course teaches skills to report international news through radio production, print, blogs and websites. The course stresses fundamentals of journalism: fact-checking, narrative story-telling, and developing a lead. Guest lecturers include journalists who report for traditional outlets and the "new media" as well as international area experts.

title: "Yellow Peril" -- Documenting and Understanding Xenophobia
reviews: Definitely need a lot of internal interest to propel you through this course; that said, if you are interested, take it!

Stay positive and stay engaged. Don't be bogged down by the work - there isn't much! It is what you make it. It is probably more meaningful for Asian-American students who can reflect significantly on their own histories and backgrounds.
The class was a little all over the place but it was a lot of fun and you learn a lot.
descrip: Fears of "yellow peril" (and "Islamophobia") run deep in the present and past of U.S. political and commercial culture. SARS fears, charges of Chinese "pirating" and "hacking," the profiling of Arab or Muslim "looking" peoples, and Asians "taking over" U.S. higher education all illustrate contemporary forms of Asian "peril." Americans remain particularly vulnerable to its ideological and affective power. Seminar students will learn historical research skills and collaboratively document historical and contemporary case studies. We'll explore what can and must be done to counter these fallacies and practices.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Excellent. Be ready to work alone, and the success of your project is entirely up to you. Please don't take this for an easy grade. It's a fun class, you get to work in a group with your friends, and you don't have any homework beyond the shop hours. But if you're just going to slack through this, it's a missed opportunity, and it ruins the environment for the rest of us.
Great for hands-on engineering experience. Good break from all these psets.
I would recommend to take this class if students are looking to complete a 5 class/semester credit in their freshmen or sophomore year.
Take this if you want to spend some time each week building something tangible. Loved this course and it's an easy class to PDF especially senior year.
take it if you need a 5th class. you can literally do whatever

take with friends! and you'll get more out of it if you do a lot of independent learning to figure out what you're going to do, and take the opportunity to stretch yourself and try new areas or learning.
prereqs: EGR 250.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Urbanization, Migration and Climate Change
descrip: This course examines two hallmark demographic behaviors of the 21st century: urbanization and migration and places those changes in the context of climate-change adaptation and mitigation, and consider policy and programs that address these issues. The course focuses on changes in a developing-country context. Students learn to examine theory and evidence that is used at the local, national and international level to understand populations at risk in the short and long-run, internal and international migration flows, city-growth and urban dynamism in the context of climate change related hazards.

title: International Theatre: Plays and Politics
reviews: ABSOLUTELY take it! Mara and Tamsen are two of the best professors you'll have in ENG/THR, in my opinion. And the material is just fascinating. Don't miss this class!
Excellent. highly recommend to anyone who is remotely interested in theater or politics.

I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in either theater or the political uses/implications of cultural productions. The professors are both incredibly skilled and know what they're doing, and do a great job of supplementing the course with guest speakers and performances. I would highly recommend this class!

This course is eye-opening and presents a really great alternative to the established theatrical canon. Great for anyone who wants to learn more about contemporary theatre from different parts of the world.
descrip: This course addresses when and why producing political theatre matters. We will look specifically at contemporary and canonical plays from around the globe that take on various political crises (e.g., the Israeli/Palestinian conflict, Chile under Pinochet, the Liberian Civil War, the Arab Spring). In order to consider the challenges of producing highly charged political theatre, students will also attend professional productions and hear directly from artists who are engaged in making this kind of theatre around the world.

title: Homer
reviews: Do it! Dr. Fincher was a fantastic professor and this course was great for reading the language and cementing your technical base of the language for further study.
I imagine that it probably won't be taught by Josh again since he's leaving, but it still might be worth it for the Homer readings. Be careful, though- most Greek professors are vicious.
take the class!
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: To learn to read Homer with pleasure. Introduction to Homeric dialect, oral poetry, and meter; discussion of literary technique, historical background to the epics, and Homer's role in the development of Greek thought.

title: Special Studies in Modernism - Post-War Realisms: British and Irish Fiction, Documentary and Film
descrip: This course interrogates critical approaches which read contemporary realism as a legacy of modernism. In the first half of the course we examine a number of 1950s realist and "documentary" writers and film-makers, including Alan Sillitoe, Colin MacInnes, John Berger, Edna O'Brien, Philip Donnellan and Doris Lessing, in the context of work by Richard Hoggart and Raymond Williams, and debates on working-class realism, feminism, migration, and the New Left. This literary-historical background form the basis for our examination of later realist writers in the latter half of the course. These texts are chosen by the group.

title: Atmospheric and Oceanic Wave Dynamics
descrip: Observational evidence of atmospheric and oceanic waves; laboratory simulation. Surface and internal gravity waves; dispersion characteristics; kinetic energy spectrum; critical layer; forced resonance; instabilities. Planetary waves: scale analysis; physical description of planetary wave propagation; reflections; normal modes in a closed basin. Large-scale barclinic and barotropic instabilities. Eady and Charney models for barclinic instability, and energy transfer.

title: Radiogenic Isotopes
reviews: Budget your time.
Dating rocks is necessary in most of geology. If you're interested, take it
Fascinating class but be prepared to spend a lot of time on each problem set.  Blair is very accessible and willing to help with any aspect of the class.
Get help from Blair and do the assignments with a group of friends -- you'll learn very little if you try to do it all alone.
This class was a bit more of a time commitment than I anticipated, but you'll learn a lot in the process. Blair is a great teacher and basically lets you decide what topics to cover each semester.
descrip: Theory and methodology of radiogenic isotope geochemistry, as applied to topics in the geosciences, including the formation and differentiation of the Earth and solar system, thermal and temporal evolution of orogenic belts, and the rates and timing of important geochemical, biotic, and climatic events in earth history.

title: Versailles: Court and Culture from Louis XIV to Marie-Antoinette
reviews: Amazing class.
TAKE IT! Fascinating class, great materials, wonderful discussion, minimal time commitment.  Professor Schroder really cares about his students and is incredibly passionate about Versailles.
Take it if you know about French culture
Take it!!! You won't regret it.

Take this course if you are interested in the integration of culture, architecture, history, and personal lives of a monarchy! Professor Schroder is great and you get to learn so many interesting things you wouldn't have otherwise. Seminar can be a little slow sometimes, but you still get a lot out of it.

The content of this course is extremely fascinating and if you are at all interested in Versailles I would definitely recommend it. It's a really great interdisciplinary look at one place. However, classes themselves often moved very slowly and are not so engaging.
There are so few time when you'l be able to study anything this precisely, especially in France, that's not Paris. You should take this course if Versailles is any interest to you at all
This class was very interesting and really provides a great insight into the history and culture of Versailles

taking this as a P/D/F is probably the way to go because of the amount of reading. But you can also get by with just reading one of the given readings and focusing on that. And PARTICIPATE! it's a big part of the grade
descrip: Three hundred and fifty years ago, the young Louis XIV, King of France, transformed his father's hunting lodge at Versailles into the site par excellence of absolute monarchy and court society. In this course we will study the making and meaning of the palace and its gardens, and analyze some of the manifold cultural artifacts associated with them. Readings, both literary and non-literary, will be complemented by various visual resources, ranging from original prints to websites and films.

title: Lyrical Traditions in Portuguese
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission..
descrip: A voyage through the lyrical traditions of Portugal, Brazil, and Portuguese-speaking Africa, this course seeks to trace the evolution of the poetic form and illuminate dynamic and enduring intertextualities. Through close-readings of major works of poetry we will explore the ongoing dialogue between poets and artists of the spoken word across time and space, providing the foundation for a deeper understanding of the diverse Portuguese-language literary and cultural landscape.

title: Advanced Heat and Mass Transfer
reviews: Although the book, Deen, is somewhat difficult to read, it is the best resource in completing homework.
Attend all lectures, make a comprehensive exam prep sheet, and do well on the presentation/final paper. I would not take this course if it was not required by my department.

I would not recommend this course as my level of interest in the material decreased significantly, however it is required for the CBE degree program. This is a shame, because heat and mass transfer can be very interesting and applicable, and the course did not do this.
Solid course and not overwhelming like many other courses in the department! :)

Start by reading the lecture notes before class, and if you don't understand something after lecture, then refer to Deen for a more detailed analysis or examples. Do not try to read the whole Deen textbook to begin.
The class presentation project was very interesting. The class notes were very well written.
This class shouldn't be your first choice if you have an option.
descrip: A survey of modeling and solutions methods for processes involving heat and mass transfer. Topics will include convective and diffusive transport, conservation equations, scaling principles and approximation techniques, forced convection, multi-component energy and mass transfer as well as buoyancy and turbulent driven transport.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students & post-docs.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: A great class if your interested in learning/potential working in Asian capital markets.
Be interested in the region or this course is hard to sit through.
Definitely do recommend. It is a challenging class but one that is interesting and engaging especially if you want to PDF it.

Definitely geared towards finance students, but JC is actually one of the nicest professors who genuinely cares about his students and also is very understanding/welcoming of everyone's academic background. Would definitely recommend if you want to learn something new about finance or Asia, as JC has a wealth of experience and also brings in the insights of people he knows.

Definitely take this course (especially if considering a career in finance or business, in general). Professor de Swaan is a highly engaging lecturer, from whom learning is a pleasure. You will thoroughly enjoy hearing Professor de Swaan's insights on investment ideas and business strategies. A must-take before graduating!
Fantastic course, even if you're not interested in finance. Prof. Swan provides a great overview of the political economy/economic structure of Japan, China, et al.
Good course especially for senior year
Great course. But - this isn't an "investing in asian capital markets" course - it more concerns general themes in capital markets (esp currencies) than how to formulate trades
Great non-quant elective for Econ majors, also quite interesting for anyone interested in markets and macro.

I would definitely consider this exam, especially for anyone interested in economics but with the perspective of going into finance or consultancy. Professor de Swaan is a teacher in the most noble sense.
I would definitely recommend. Interesting and fun.

If you dont know anything about Asian markets or finance this course will be a little difficult for you. However, definitely a good class to PDF for anyone interested int he subject who doesnt have the background
Instructor teaches you by example on how to give good lectures. He has a philosophical flair, which was unexpected by interesting. Data presented/analyzed in class was interesting.
Interesting course, very PDFable, and still interesting. Tougher if actually graded, could be much more stressful.

JC is the absolute best professor I've had at Princeton in my 4 years. This has been hands-down my favorite class at Princeton. Period. You should definitely, most certainly, 100% take this class if you want to learn from a professor who cares about his students and is more than willing to spend time & provide career advice. Any one interested in the buy-side, or just learning more about how financial markets work, would benefit tremendously from this practical, hands-on class with minimal work load. Most coursework relating to finance at Princeton is pretty theoretical, and this is one of the few classes that looks at finance from the perspective of actual practitioners in the real world. I would have regretted NOT taking this course

Only take this class if you have very little knowledge on financial markets, as most of the analysis is kept very surface level and rigorous frameworks are not introduced often, which can be frustrating to those expecting to dive deep into the investment process and experience of JCdS. Definitely do the readings, as that is the true substance of the course.

PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE take this class if you can. Princeton is so honored to have JCdS come teach year after year and inspire students who have an interest in banking, finance or international relations. He has a unique insight and background which really comes through when he opens up the class for discussion and debate. Guest lectures are amazing and you will NOT regret taking this.
Participate a lot! Close readings of materials not entirely necessary. deSwaan is a legend
TAKE THIS SENIOR SPRING - but definitely consider a P/D/F. JC de Swaan is an amazing professor and this class is worth taking just to hear his thoughts.

TAKE THIS! I have no finance experience and at times I felt nervous about that but I learned so so so much about the world of finance in an interesting way that didn't feel cutthroat at all. JC's also a great lecturer that really does care about his students.
Take This Class!
Take it if you are truly interested in the subject. Professor de Swaan has tremendous experience from which he teaches.
Take only if you are already comfortable with how markets work. I wasn't and felt at a large disadvantage.
Take this course.

This is an interesting class, although it is definitely not an entry-level finance class and you will be at a disadvantage in participation part and papers relative to other students if you do not already know Asian markets.

You're retarded if you don't take this class. I've learned more about Economics, Finance, and Asia than my other 7 classes I've taken on those subjects combined. AND please take advantage of office hours. There's a reason why people go too often that office hours begin to be rationed.

good course if interested in finance
otherwise can be tough to get through

great class if you are interested in asian capital markets. a lot of grad students take the class as well, which is quite irritating at times since the class is participation based and the grad students are overwhelmingly overeager

take this class if you are interested in asia but want to learn more about finance from a relatively basic level. You will have to do some study on your own in order to fully understand what is going on, but the discussions are really valuable and interesting. Also, go to office hours! Professor de Swaan is great and can talk about anything.
prereqs: For those who are unable to register because the course is full, please contact Professor De Swaan directly (jdeswaan@princeton.edu)..
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions and investment case studies will combine analysis of historical trends and recent data with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system, the potential revival of Japanese capital markets, and the development of Indian capital markets.

title: Introduction to Digital Humanities
reviews: @Humanities Majors: take this course. DH is an important new area that our fields are moving in, and Princeton is (hate to say it) a little behind the curve on this wave. The Center for DH is a beacon of awesome on campus, and this course will challenge you to think about your work differently going forwards. Non-Humanities people will also enjoy. People who like Humanities and Non-Humanities, this is gonna be your jam x10000.

Claude was one of the best lecturers I had this semester--super witty and really engaging. Intro to Digital Humanities is a good course to take if you're interested in getting exposed to the ways the humanities and digital can be combined in the form of visualization tools. DH is still an expanding field that's getting defined/explored so if you're interested in that kind of growing field of study take this course!

Definitely consider taking the course. I've never been in a class with so much engagement from the students, and Claude is great at facilitating discussion. The format is different from regular classes, but in a way that I think works well for the subject. You'll learn about a lot of awesome tools that can be used for more than DH work as well and have some very interesting discussions.
I would strongly recommend the course to any student interested in the fusion of technology and humanities.

TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN GET IT. Claude is fantastic, the workload is very manageable, and the field is vast and super interesting; you definitely won't regret it. We had a balanced mix of COS/humanities people, so discussions were always really interesting. I'd recommend brainstorming your final project early -- don't discount the class just because it's not a lot of work for most of the semester! It's not hard to stay engaged with the material, but if you keep up you can get a ton out of it. Take it!
Take it if you want to get meta about technology and why/how we study humanities.
Take it!

Take the class if you want to learn more about the fascinating field of DH! Claude is very knowledgeable and open to feedback and suggestions from students. As a humanities major I did not feel that it was overly technical, but I learned a ton of stuff that I would have incorporated into my independent work if I had learned it earlier. Learning from other students from different disciplines was also a huge joy in the class. Not too much work but I always came out of class feeling like I learned a lot - the best combination!
descrip: Have you ever wondered how to measure the complexity of a literary text? What if you could map the personal connections in a Jane Austen novel or a Shakespeare play? Have you had an intuition that you haven't been able to follow because processing the information was too intimidating? If so, the digital humanities can help you. This course will explore the large and exciting field of digital humanities. You'll learn how to read and understand texts using DH methods and will start your own DH project.

title: An Introduction to Engineering
reviews: Doesn't really help in picking and engineering department.
Good class to get a feel for the engineering departments here at Princeton.
I was one of the few non-engineering students taking it to get an overview of engineering. Definitely recommend it, it's super easy but you'll have a basic understanding of engineering as a result.

If you're completely undecided, this might be helpful to you (though it will probably turn you into an ELE major). However, if you already have some idea of which department you want to declare, this class isn't going to help you much. It's not super interesting, but it's also 0 work. If you show up to all of the classes you automatically earn a P. There are probably more valuable things you could do as a 5th class, though it's nice to be able to get out of lab in time for late meal.
It was a waste of time. Don't take it unless you are truly undecided for your engineering major.
One of the lowest commitment courses at pton, all you have to do is show up to class. It was actually pretty interesting though, and the labs were fun.

Take it, but take it seriously?it is a great opportunity to explore interests, ask professors questions about topics that interest you, and learn a bit about engineering in general. Don't mistreat lectures or not pay attention just because it's PDF no-hw. If you think you would do that, then don't take the course! If you aren't going to take it seriously, it is a waste of time! But, if you take it seriously, it is a great forum to ask renowned professors questions to explore your own interests in engineering.
Take this class if you need an easy 5th, but not really helpful otherwise. Some cool labs!
Take this course if you are unsure on what type of engineering you want to do. Added benefit: no out of class work.

Take this course really only if you have no idea whatsoever of what you want to do in engineering. If you are considering between two or three majors, take a departmental instead, or talk to upperclassmen/professors. Even then, the course really only focuses on CBE, MAE and ELE, so if you are deciding between ORFE, COS or CEE, you won't really get a lot out of it.
This class is not a lot of work but is not super interesting.

This class requires no work other than to show up to lectures and do the labs. The material is generally interesting (although heavier on the electrical, mechanical, and chemical side). Take if you are BSE and unsure of which department to join.
This course actually taught me a lot. Definitely take if you have time.
Would recommend this class if you want a chill fifth course.
biggest joke class out there
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the various disciplines of engineering. It is a project-based sequence (Energy Conversion and the Environment, Robotic Remote Sensing, and Wireless Image & Video Transmission) that covers engineering disciplines and their relationship to the principles of physics and mathematics.

title: Posthuman, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Geometry and Architectural Representation
prereqs: This course is designed primarily for freshman and sophomores who are interested in gaining introductory experience in design and drawing. This course will help prepare students for ARC 204 and upper-level studios..
descrip: This course sets out two goals: the first is to understand the theories and techniques of geometry in architectural representation; the second is to develop the student's drawing sensibilities through 5 thematic drawing projects engaging both digital and manual techniques. Each new theme will be introduced through a lecture, tutorial, and discussion including a number of specific readings related to the topic at hand. The second class will be an individual desk crit to discuss the development of each drawing project. The third class will consist of a group pin-up review of each drawing experiment.

title: Molecular Basis of Cancer
descrip: We explore the molecular events leading to the onset and progression of human cancer. We review the central genetic and biochemical elements that make up the cell cycle, followed by a survey of the signal transduction pathways and checkpoints that regulate it. We discuss oncogenes, tumor suppressor and mutator genes that act in these pathways and review the role of viral oncogenes and their action on cells. We investigate the role of cancer stem cells and the interaction between tumor and the host environment. We explore specific clinical case studies in light of the molecular events underlying different cancers.

title: Climate and the Terrestrial Biosphere
reviews: I would take it. Don't be too intimidated by the course number. Medvigy is great and always is there to help.
Start problem sets early
This is the last chance to have Professor Medvigy teaching this class. And it is a huge pity! He is a great teacher and I feel so lucky to have the chance to take this class.
prereqs: GEO 202 or equivalent.
descrip: Earth's climate is tightly coupled to the terrestrial biosphere. In this course, we will explore the key mechanisms that link climate (e.g., cloudiness, rainfall, and temperature) with the terrestrial biosphere, and how these mechanisms are altered by humans. We will review land-atmosphere exchanges of energy, water and carbon dioxide. We will then analyze the processes controlling the land carbon sink, with a strong focus on seasonality. We will investigate the potential impacts of climate change on vegetation seasonality and the land carbon sink. Assignments will include analysis of observational datasets and climate model simulations.

title: Russian Drama
reviews: Great class.  Professor Hasty really makes the material engaging and the performance at the end of the year is a lot of fun.
I would tell them it's a good course. If you are interested in Russian, this is an opportunity to improve your skills in a fun way.
Take this class if you want to practice your Russian in a fun way by reading aloud famous Russian plays and discussing them. Great class!

This is the best course for anyone interested in Russian language/culture/literature! It promotes lots of discussions, enhances writing, reading, and pronunciation skills, and teaches to interpret what meaning the great Russian dramatists tried to convey in their great works.
prereqs: RUS 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is devoted to the reading and discussion of masterpieces of 19th and 20th century Russian drama. It will also provide students with an opportunity to develop aural, oral, and written language skills. Classes are conducted entirely in Russian and all readings are to be done in the original. Students will participate in a performance project at the end of the term.

title: Financial Econometrics
reviews: Good introduction to econometrics, test important theories
Highly recommend.
I recommend you taking this course.
If you want to get your hand on real-world financial data analysis, this is the place.
Read the book. It is an open book exam, need to be very organised, because we covered a lot of material.
Should take it if you have basic statistics knowledge (MLE, etc), and interested in how they are applied (theoretically & empirically) in the world of finance.
Very good introduction level of Financial Econometrics. Textbook and Notes are amazing.
prepare to learn most of the lecture material by yourself since it's hardly possible for one to follow the lecture.
descrip: Econometric and statistical methods as applied to finance. Topics include: Asset returns and efficient markets, linear time series and dynamics of returns, volatility models, multivariate time series, efficient portolios and CAPM, multifactor pricing models, portfolio allocation and risk assessment, intertemporal equilibrium models, present value models, simulation methods for financial derivatives, econometrics of continuous time finance.

title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior
reviews: Take this course.
This course simply involves attending the talks put on by PNI, which are highly recommended. It is not a formal course.
This is a great course. Take it.
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior.

title: Computer and Electronic Music through Programming, Performance, and Composition
reviews: Definitely take it!

Fantastic course, strongly recommend to anyone interested in computer science or music. It's even an applications departmental for COS majors! Classes are very chill and laid back, you learn a lot, and the projects are super fun to make. Most of the students in the class are upperclassmen, so I felt a bit intimidated taking the course as a freshman, but it's totally manageable if you put the time into it. Strongly recommend!
Great COS course, definitely try to get in!
Great class. Jeff is awesome.
If you are interested in music and computer science, definitely look to take this course.

If you like programming and/or electronic music, TAKE THIS CLASS. Jeff is awesome and the class is super fun. You'll learn a lot about ways you can make new music and sound installations. However, this class is less electronic music composition and more learning techniques that you can apply to composition. 316 is more composition but this is a prereq for that so you may want to do both (I know I am).
Interesting but fairly disorganized class. Expect to spend a lot more time than you'd think!
It's a great course if you're at all into electronic music, or programming music in general. But be aware that the problem sets are required partner work...
It's particularly chill if you already know how to code, because the first half of the course is just learning a new programming language. And it's a cool class. You make cool things.
Lectures are very laid back but assignments may take more time than expected. Having prior programming experience helps a lot.

Take this class if you have a working knowledge of computer programming and love music. This isn't a traditional music class -- be prepared for experimental music and programming challenges. Reach out to the professor and TAs with any programming questions.

Take this course ... Jeff is great and so sweet! Generally, an easy COS departmental. Your classmates will compose pieces that are better than yours, so just be prepared to not be the best at something.

This course is a great introduction to creating music with computers. The coding aspect is easy enough to follow (with some guidance from peers or instructors) even for someone with zero coding experience, and the ideas that come out of it are fantastic.

This is a really cool course that you should take, even if just for fun. Jeff loves experimenting with electronic music, and basically anything you put your effort into will produce something that you can show your friends. There's less musical than technical direction though, and that can be kind of tough, especially if the TA is subjective in her artistic feedback.

This is a super fun class! The projects will take a significant amount of time (like 5-10 hours), but its not too bad because usually its fairly concentrated time with you and you partner, and its fun to figure out how to do what you want to do in a new different programming language.
You'll get out what you put in -- this class is a good opportunity to be creative and make music. Jeff is great.
prereqs: Instructor's permission. Application available in the Music Dept. office..
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of computer and electronic music. The music and sound programming language ChucK, developed here at Princeton, will be used in conjunction with Max/MSP, another digital audio language, to study procedural programming, digital signal processing and synthesis, networking, and human-computer interfacing.

title: Independent Research Project
prereqs: Students MUST sign up in room 121 during course selection period..
descrip: Independent research or investigation resulting in a report in the student's area of interest under the supervision of a faculty member. Open to sophomores and juniors.

title: Introduction to Ballet
reviews: A very fun and engaging course - a must-take even if you've never considered ballet before!
Best class, best Professor. SO happy I took it. Take it!!
If you can get in the course, do not drop. You will severely regret it. Great course.
Must take
TAKE IT!! Tina is great. You won't regret it.
TAKE THIS CLASS
Take it! A lot of fun and a very relaxing class. Tina is awesome!
Tina is a great instructor - very enthusiastic and excellent at keeping students engaged in the course. Superb introduction to ballet.
Tina is a wonderfully patient and quirky teacher. I highly recommend this class, especially if you like getting more exercise in.
definitely take the class, its a great pdf course and tina is an excellent teacher!
have fun!
descrip: From grand plie to grand jete, Introduction to Ballet is for students with a curiosity for the study of classical ballet. No prior dance experience necessary and beginners are welcome. In this studio course students will learn the fundamentals of ballet, gaining an understanding of its physicality, artistry, and principles of alignment. Students will examine the historical origins of ballet and its absorption of cultural influences. Live music will be featured in this class and key in exploring the inextricable link between music and dance.

title: Ethics for Scientists (Half-Term)
reviews: A really fun class. We had ~18 students and for the most part everyone was engaged in the discussions. The surveys at the beginning that we had to take were very interesting in terms of where we all stood.
I would say look forward to taking it.
descrip: Consistent with requirements of federal training grants, this class broaches significant ethical issues that face scientists. These issues include: i) scientific integrity & misconduct; ii) mentoring; iii) peer review in grants and papers; iv) humans subjects and animals in research; v) collaborations and conflicts of interest; vi) the scientist as a responsible member of society. Students read case studies before each class. The instructor provides background lecture, then the students discuss ethical issues raised in the case studies. In addition, two faculty members are invited to each class to provide additional perspective.

title: 19th-Century Fiction
reviews: Absolutely inspirational. Jeff is a legend.

Any course with Jeff is going to be fantastic. The readings are so interesting and represent a spectrum of 19th century novels. However, there's a lot of reading and you should take that into account with regards to the other courses you plan on taking at the same time.
Good class to take, especially as a 5th class and PDF. You learn a lot and only have to write 2 six page papers.
Highly recommended! There's a lot of reading, but it's so good.

I took this course because of Jeff, and he was 100% worth it. Incredible lecturer though I wasn't super interested in the subject matter (the novels). Super low work load especially if you read over breaks. Go to lecture because it's worth your time.
I would advise another student taking this course to get a head start on the readings prior to taking this class and to participate.
I would definitely recommend this course!

If you're a slow reader, please try to read the novels before the start of the semester. There's no time to read them during the actual semester. If you do read them before the start of classes though, you would enjoy the class much much more (and be infinitely less stressed!).
Jeff is a good teacher but just be aware that his lectures may be a bit intense and he's a little too hyperactive. Precept with him is a little more toned down though and excellent.
Jeff is probably the best lecturer at Princeton. I don't even like Victorian literature and still loved the class.

One of the best classes I have taken in Princeton. Lectures are very insightful, and these novels are considered to be some of the best in the English language. Take the class for Jeff because he is definitely one of the most caring and funniest professors on campus.
Please take it! Professor Nunokawa is the best!
TAKE IT.
TAKE THIS COURSE! You won't regret it. Regardless of whether you are interested in these novels, Jeff makes them feel like a matter of life and death. And they kind of are.
Take it!
Take it! Keep up w/ the readings. Jeff is a fun lecturer. Takes some time to tune to his frequency, but he makes some very insightful points every now and then.
Take it. Jeff will change your life.
Take this class for Jeff - he really cares about the students and every lecture I was able to take away some gem about the meaning of life.
Take this class! It is really interesting and the readings are so worthwhile.

The book in this course are very descriptive and not always invigorating, but Professor Nunokawa's lectures make up for the lack of excitement in the story. He really makes the reading worth something and is just overall a fabulous human being. If you don't take this class, take a class with him eventually.
They should definitely take this course and try their best to complete all the readings. Everyone should read the literature covered in this course.
This was my favorite course in all of my four years here. May not be yours though...
Try to get ahead on readings!
take it if you can read quickly
descrip: This course will acquaint students with the distinctive features of the nineteenth century novel, from Austen to Hardy. Lectures will seek to illuminate relations between social and aesthetic dimensions of the texts we read. We will consider how these fictional imaginings of things like love, sex, money, class, and race help shape the ways we live now.

title: Voting
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Statistics and Data Analysis for Economics
reviews: A good foundation in statistics if that's what you're looking for. Exams can be very challenging, so be prepared to think outside the box and the textbook to solve them.

As a BSE major, this was a very straightforward class. The concepts and expectations are clear. Although stats can be a bit dry, Prof. Mueller also does a good job connecting the concepts we learn to interesting real-world applications.
Be prepared to read the textbook regularly and study on your own while devoting a lot of time to psets.
Best stats prereq for woody woo

Definitely don't take this to satisfy statistics requirements for non-econ departments. Professor Mueller wasn't exceptional and spent way too much time doing proofs instead of making the material accessible.
Definitely don't take this unless it's a departmental, but I'm guessing you already knew that.
Don't fall behind in the course, because it's hard to catch up
Don't take it unless you HAVE to! Take POL stats. All the other stats are either too hard, too poorly taught, or do not cover enough.
Don't take it unless you have to
Don't take this class. Take a different stats class if you need it for a prerequisite.
Don't take unless you are seriously going to major in economics.
Easy stats course if looking for Finance Certificate
Fair course if you want to learn the basics of statistics in an economic setting
Get the book do the readings before lecture.

Go to lecture, even though it is quite hard to pay attention. Most times, Mueller is simply going through proofs or long-winded explanations that he will summarize at the end of the lecture. MOST IMPORTANT: Use the past midterms and finals that Mueller gives out as your primary study tool.

Go to office hours if you can!
You learn the big concepts of statistics in a way I heard other statistics courses don't teach as well, but sometimes you might have to read the textbook or go back to the notes a few times to get those big ideas.
Good course for a distribution requirement. Muller is pretty interesting and entertaining.

Honestly, if you can, take ORF. If you don't need this, take a lesser stats. Very theoretical.

Be sure to keep up; attending precepts is actually essential.

I believe this is a good stats course to take, especially for those looking to fulfill distribution or departmental requirements. If you are a die-hard math-lover, this course may be too introductory.

I found this class to be incredibly difficult. Others were able to do it, but I found it almost impossible. I don't know if other stats classes are better. I think psych stats is pretty easy but that doesn't fulfill a lot of prereqs, whereas this class fulfills almost every stats prereq across departments that I've seen. As for WWS 200, there were always a good amount of students for that at McGraw, and this class had less students there on average. This class is hard especially if you've never taken stats before. If you need help, go to office hours, reach out to your preceptor, and go to McGraw. But in general, don't take if you don't have to.

I found this class very challenging. While Mueller is entertaining, I often felt that he didn't fully explain things and I left lecture more confused than when I arrived. I love math, but I found this course very difficult in terms of the math of theories and concepts. It took a lot of outside studying and learning on my own.
I generally enjoyed taking this class. I found the lectures to be very clear and quite helpful even if the precepts were not. Lectures are long, though.
I really enjoyed the course. It gets more challenging as the semester goes on, but Professor Mueller is great, and I recommend taking it.
I recommend taking this course if you are interested in statistics.

I think the course was fair. It helps if you have some background in math, particularly Reimann sums. With that said, nothing presented in lecture is impossible to learn over the course of the semester.

I would say that unless you absolutely need to take this specific statistics course, to pick a different one. The quality with which it is taught is misaligned with the difficulty of the examinations, making it a very frustrating course for anyone who is not naturally gifted in statistics or already has a strong background in math.
I'm assuming you're only taking it if you have to... It's pretty hard but it's easier than POL or WWS stats (so I've heard).

I'm not a mathy person, I put in very little effort, and I'm expecting an A-/B  out of this course. Painless way to get rid of a QR or a stat pre-req for WWS. I will say though that I feel I haven't learned much applicable knowledge, so if you're trynna do actual statistical research pol stats might be more practical for you
If you need to take a stats class, this one isn't too bad. Problem sets don't take too long, exams
If you need to take this class for a prerequisite or distribution requirement, I would probably recommend this course besides the others available. But this course fluctuates in difficulty a lot.
If you stay relatively engaged it won't be too hard of a class, but it is so boring that it is hard to stay engaged.
It is really hard and you need to do a lot of practice problems.

It seems like POL345 might be the better option for social science students, but it's a decently taught course. It's important material and Mueller does his best to make it interesting. That said, beware that lectures can get dry and long. Also, it's critical that you do all the practice tests made available to you for sufficient preparation!
It wasn't awful but I know this course was incredibly challenging for some. Keep that in mind.
It's a great foundation to statistics. Taking the course has made me want to take more stats courses and learn more!
It's actually underratedly hard and you don't really learn anything in lecture. Find some good study buddies, though!
Its a great learning experience.
Just read the text book and look at the lecture slides formulas.
Keep up with the work, and take time to understand the concepts- much easier if you internalize what is happening than simply memorize.
Lectures are confusing. Textbook is helpful. Piazza is kind of helpful. Preceptors are helpful.
Make sure to make use of the textbook.
Mueller is a good instructor.
Mueller is an excellent lecturer, especially given how boring the subject matter can be. The second midterm is considerably harder than the first. Keep up with the material every week
Mueller is honestly the greatest and stats is lit.

Not a horrible class in terms of workload, but prepare to teach yourself or have a reliable/really good tutor teach you everything.  Lectures were completely useless to my learning except I still had to attend every one to copy down the class notes (because he doesn't post them).
