Never learned anything from lecture/precept/the psets, so that's just busy work until you get the practice exams. Completing all the practice exams was the only thing that actually helped me understand the material and retain my knowledge. So essentially you have to teach yourself; however, completely manageable to do so. Just prepared to be very unamused with class.
Not bad - very easy if you want to learn about statistics but also want an easy 5th class (<3 hours per week commitment) - BSE student
Not too difficult of a course, but most of the learning falls on you
Only take if Econ or WWS and need it for requirements.
Only take if you can PDF it or are forced to take it.
Only take it if you need to. Not a very good class.
Pretty easy especially if you know stats already
Pretty hard class
Probably better than most statistics courses out there. Beware the second midterm.
Professor Mueller is an amazing lecturer!
Read the book and find a good pset group. Go over all the practice tests before the midterm and final.
Read the book or focus really hard in lecture or just learn the material in whatever way you can. Don't take unless you have it.
Rigorous introduction to stats.  Keep in mind the purpose of each thing you are learning, and how to apply them, rather than formulas.
Seek help and do the work
Sit in the front of the class so that it's harder to do other things while the professor is talking.
Start practice exams the minute you get them and off course, office hours

Statistics is definitely a really important subject that everyone should take a class in at some point.  Unfortunately, this class is really poorly taught.  Professor Mueller only seems to confuse people during lectures--so while I would recommend taking this class to learn the material due to the importance of having a knowledge of statistics, I would caution that it is quite poorly taught.

Stats is terrible at Princeton no matter what course you take. As a Woody Woo major, the amount of math here was not difficult at all, but the course just sucks. Maybe take woody woo stats instead because it has programming which is far more useful.
Study exams and read the textbook. manageable work. Very useful material
Study groups will be very important for this class
Take good notes during lecture and study extensively for the exams.
Take if you need to. Otherwise, just don't.
Take it
Take it because you have to; don't expect it to be easy just because you did AP Stats and got a 5
Take it for the pre-req, and do really well on the first midterm because the second one is really hard.
Take it for your stats requirement. Not hard if you do the readings OR go to class, but definitely do the p-sets and don't just rely on other people to do them. Then you'll be fine for the exam.
Take it if required
Take it if you have to. Made stats much more confusing than in high school.
Take it only if you need to
Take it with a grain of salt.
Take it,
Take it, lectures are almost not worth it but the book and problem sets are enough to keep up
Take the course, even if you aren't an Econ major! While difficult, statistics is helpful for a variety of majors!
Take this course if you are a potential econ major. Not really much other reason to enroll though.
The lectures are long, but don't skip class. Mueller does a great job keeping things engaging.

This course it not an easy statistics course.  If you need to take it for a requirement it can be managed but the second half of the semester is much harder than the first. If you simply needed to take a stats course, don't take this one.  Its not worth it.

This is a challenging course, but not terrible. The problem sets are a pain. I read on the comments before taking the class to do the practice tests before the exam, and that is super important to get a good grade. The psets have very little to do with the exam so definitely do as many as the old exams as possible.

This is a fairly rigorous course, but you can do well if you put in the time. Professor Mueller is great, but lectures are long and can get boring. Psets and exams are hard. Precepts were generally not worth it.

This is a great class! I never expected stat to be interesting, but lectures were always engaging and entertaining. Ulrich was able to keep my attention more than any other quant professor at Princeton so far. Highly recommend!
Tough course, only take it if you have to.

Ulrich has good lectures, but you have to read the textbook. 
Good class, but hard PSETs and Tests. Do it with smart friends.
Ulrich is a cool guy. The content may not be as appealing
Ulrich is good
Very tough course but you learn important things, good luck!
You're most likely only taking a stats class because you have to. If you are not econ, I would highly recommend taking WWS or Pol stats over this. Your competition will be much easier.
cvdnbsj
good statistics course if you've never taken statistics. easy A for any quantitive major that doesn't want to take orf 245
hard if you don't have to take econ stats take woody woo or psych stats
its pretty easy honestly, like if you are between this and wws i hear that class sucks, this one doesnt teach you a whole lot but its easy and the material is decently well presented
meh, stats.
record the lectures so that you can hear/see them later.
required.
take it over orf 245
take this if econ major.
tough stats class, but have to take it for econ, definitely doable
prereqs: MAT 103.
descrip: An introduction to probability and statistical methods for empirical work in economics. Probability, random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation and hypotheses testing, introduction to the regression model.

title: Islam Across the Indian Ocean
descrip: This seminar will consider Islam and mobility across the Indian Ocean, discussing ways that Southeast Asians, Africans, and Indians have created their distinct communities while nonetheless declaring themselves to be of one discrete entity: the Umma. Alongside discussions of knowledge creation, orientalism and nationalism, the seminar will also explore issues relating to global projects for religious and political reform, using Indonesia as a primary example.

title: The Psychology of Environmental Decision Making
reviews: Definitely take! It's my understanding that this course is no longer being taught, but take it if you can!!

Highly recommend. Interesting course with manageable workload. Students get insight on a lot of different aspects of public perception of climate change and learn practical things about behavioral policy. Helps you figure out what parts you'd like to study more in-depth.

If you have had a course in behavioral psychology before this might not add so much to what you already know. If this is the only psychology course you will take it could be very helpful, especially if you are interested in science communication, and I would recommend it.

If you're interested in behavioral science and on environmental issues this course is a must. The course concisely provides the main theories related to human behavior and biases, to then successfully link them to climate change, air pollution, energy efficiency, meat consumption, and other environment related topics. Prof. van der Linden is respectful, approachable, and -despite being relatively young- he is really an expert on the material.
It changed my views on how to approach environmental questions--a must-take for anyone interested in environmental studies!
This class was super interesting and honestly not that much of a workload!
This is a great course from a great professor!  Take it whether you have a background in psych or not!
prereqs: Junior and Senior undergraduate students please contact Instructor with the appropriate form..
descrip: An introduction to the field of behavioral science and how it is used in practice to study and change how people make decisions about environmental problems. We explore how people psychologically understand and process environmental risks and how such perceptions influence behavioral decision-making. Students explore the social-psychological foundations of pro-environmental values, attitudes and norms and how to design public policy interventions to improve environmental decision-making. Public understanding of science and behavioral strategies for effective environmental science communication and engagement are also discussed.

title: Analysis I: Fourier Series and Partial Differential Equations
reviews: A very good math departmental to take and/or just to get a good understanding of Fourier analysis. However, problem sets are a lot of work when the course is taught by Ionescu.
I highly recommend this course to anyone who's interested in analysis. The textbook is very interesting and the professor's lectures are very clear and well structured.

Make sure to look for the connections between all of the material. At the end, you will see the relationships between the different parts, and these connections are what make Fourier such a cool subject.

Personally thought it was a little boring, although probably more interesting if you're into physics. I'd also be hesitant about taking this course with Ionescu. The p-sets were very long-- he assigns problems (in addition to exercises) from the textbook.
Professor Ionescu assigns an insane amount of homework - be prepared to spend countless hours on your psets.
Take if you are interested in complex analysis/fourier series.
Take it if you are interested in analysis, or need to the real analysis requirement.
Take this class if you're interested in learning about Fourier analysis, and if you're looking for a (relatively) easier math course to take.
prereqs: MAT215, 218, or consent of instructor..
descrip: Basic facts about Fourier Series, Fourier Transformations, and applications to the classical partial differential equations will be covered. Also Finite Fourier Series, Dirichlet Characters, and applications to properties of primes.

title: High-Energy Physics
descrip: An overview of modern elementary particle physics and the Standard Model. Specific topics include: weak decays, W and Z physics, deep inelastic scattering, CP violation, neutrino oscillations, Higgs searches, with an emphasis on areas of current interest.

title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry - Arithmetic Algebraic Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebraic Geometry. Specific topic details provided when course is offered.

title: Materials Science and Engineering
reviews: Course is disorganized and lecture material is very scattered. Problem sets are tedious. I would recommend waiting to take it with another professor or taking MSE 324 if you're a MAE major.
Don't take this unless you have to. By which I mean senior MAE with no other option in order to graduate. Not well taught, interesting or any other redeeming qualities.
I enjoyed the course. Weekly problem set isn't too time consuming and the material is interesting.
If you can, take this course in the fall.

If you have to take it in the spring, make sure to use the textbooks as resources and ask Soboyejo a lot of questions.  The class is disorganized, but if you search enough you'll end up learning a decent amount.
If you're a CHM major, take MSE301 to avoid CHM core lab. Materials is a very broad subject. You will definitely find something you like
MAEs-- take MAE 324 if you can!! class was very disorganized and boring. I feel as if I was teaching myself for the majority of the semester.

Professor Soboyejo's great, and he was pretty flexible about scheduling deadlines and dates.  Make sure you review everything before exams, even if just generally. Also, if you take the course and are assigned Callister's book, the 8th-9th editions are missing the chapter on materials selection, which we did at the end of the course.
Take materials with Arnold, if you can.
Very fascinating material covered in this course with a nice combination of physics, mechanical engineering, and chemistry discussed in lecture.
prereqs: Calculus, physics, and chemistry. Course will expect some level of organic chemistry; students to carry out some basic derivation of equations. Freshmen should speak with course instructor for approval to enroll..
descrip: An introduction to the structure and properties of important current and future materials, including metals, ceramics, semiconductors, polymers and composites. Emphasis will be placed on the phase behavior, processing of materials, and how the structure of these materials affect their physical, mechanical, electrical and thermal properties.

title: Dance Appreciation: Seeing Dance in New York City/Articulating the Elusive
reviews: Definitely take this course if you have the chance to! It's a fun one with a very talented and personable professor and choreographer. Take it even if you don't know much about dance because it'll open your eyes to what exists in the dance world.
Go to the performances and appreciate the opportunity to see such amazing pieces!
Great courses that exposes you to a variety of dance forms in diverse performance spaces. It will push you to reconsider what dance is.

I would highly recommend taking this course, especially if you haven't had much exposure to the arts in the past. Pavel is extremely kind and engaging, and creates a very positive and enriching classroom environment through his discussions and choice of dance performances. I really enjoyed having a small classroom dynamic and being exposed to an area that I had never explored before, and the trips to New York are great as well. Take it if you can!
Low amount of effort for a very fascinating introduction to dance. Still a large time commitment in seeing the shows, but they are worth it.
TAKE IT!!!
There's only one answer to this class: YES
descrip: In this introductory course we will make six field trips to view live dance in a variety of NYC performance venues. Students will develop the ability to articulate their experiences as viewers starting in a thoughtful and active engagement with the dance works then in a discussion and writing while analyzing the form, content and contexts of the works in a group setting. We will study the historical, cultural, social and interdisciplinary contexts of contemporary dance forms. Guest writers and scholars will visit the class to reflect on diverse approaches to dance criticism and analysis and their role in the current cultural landscape.

title: Primary Sources in Japanese Literature - Love Letters
descrip: This course introduces students to the location, handling, and interpretation of primary sources in the study of premodern Japanese literature and intellectual history. This semester the course focuses on the genre of the love letter, with peripheral attention to broader categories of erotic verse and epistolary writing. Using documents from the fourteenth through nineteenth centuries, students develop proficiency in reading handwritten and woodblock-printed texts using hentaigana and other cursive forms. Students must have prior training in classical Japanese.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Absolutely take the class, you will get in what you put out and it is very forgiving in a busy schedule
Definitely take this course. I very much enjoyed attending class and learning more about engineering
EASIEST PDF at PRINCETON, worth it for grade
Take it!
Take this course if you are interested in the projects.
i like this course a lot. take it if you enjoy tinkering.
prereqs: Completion of EGR 450.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: The Political Economy of Health Systems
descrip: This course explores the professed and unspoken goals nations pursue with their health systems and the alternative economic and administrative structures different nations use to pursue those goals. The emphasis in the course will be on the industrialized world, although some time can be allocated later in the course to approaches used in the developing countries, if students in the course desire it.

title: Principles of Macromolecular Structure: Protein Folding, Structure and Design
reviews: Best course ever, undergrad or grad! Take it! If you know organic chemistry and nothing about proteins, this is the course for you.
Great class.

I think this is an excellent course for undergraduates to take, since it helps you learn how to read papers while also providing interesting content. I would still recommend the class for graduate students, but some of the value is lost for us, since we already should know how to dissect a paper.

I would definitely recommend this class. You learn a lot from the readings (all published articles on proteins, synthetic proteins, etc.). It also encourages you to challenge what you have read, and the class discussions look deeper into understanding the repeating fundamental concepts of protein synthesis and folding.

I would not recommend this class to graduate students. For undergraduates, it is an excellent way to get familiar with how to read scientific papers, and to increase your knowledge about protein folding and design.

If you are looking into this, take it. Without a doubt. Professor Hecht is a phenomenal professor and the seminar-style of this course makes for lively discussion. Honestly one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton and one that I will remember for years to come.
If you can read a figure legend, you can pass this class, for it's not difficult if you have a basic understanding of how proteins function.

If you have the chance, take this course. It is really interesting material, presented through the primary research itself. It's a fantastic chance to work with scientific literature, and Professor Hecht and Professor Murphy make the content accessible and engaging. I learned so, so much in CHM 542 and enjoyed the class enormously.

It is an overall excellent course, and serves as a good introduction to how proteins evolve, function and are designed. If you are familiar with biochemistry, a lot of the course can be somewhat repetitive though.
Read papers carefully.
Take it!! Not TOO much work.
Take this course if at all interested in proteins. Best class I've taken at Princeton.

The content of this course is incredible ? the papers are amazing, lectures are clear and easy to listen to, and you get a sense of the entire field in a relatively short period of time. However, if you're not naturally outspoken you may struggle to participate, especially with such a fast pace and such a large class. Definitely worth taking regardless!
The model of what a Princeton science course should be.

This course offers a comprehensive overview of how proteins pack, fold, misfold and then goes on to discuss how these principles have been and continue to be validated through computational and rational protein design. If this description interests you, go for it! The students int his class were from a diverse background and Professor Hecht and Grant found a way to more or less keep everyone on the same page.

This is a fantastic course if you are interested in learning more about proteins! It is fairly relaxed (read a few papers for each class with occasional in-class quizzes), but you learn a ton of material over the course of the semester.

This is an absolutely amazing course. The overall evolutionary perspective is well explained and makes you wonder about the epistemological reasons for protein function/structures. You must read all the articles ahead of time because you will not do well on the quizzes. Overall intellectually stimulating and a great course if you have an interest in protein research.
strongly recommend
descrip: This course will be taught from the scientific literature. We will begin the semester with several classic papers on protein folding. As the semester progresses, we will read about protein structure, stability, and folding pathways. The latter part of the semester will focus on recent papers describing new research aimed toward the construction of novel proteins from "scratch." These papers will cover topics ranging from evolution in vitro to computational and rational design. The course will end by discussing the possibility of creating artificial proteomes in the laboratory, and further steps toward synthetic biology.

title: Urban Blues and the Golden Age of Rock
reviews: A fine course to take whether it be out of general interest or not. The lectures and the material are quite tame and the course is not particularly demanding.

A great course for anyone who has ever liked rock n' roll music and its derivatives. I truly learned a lot about musical movements of the late 60s and early 70s towards the end of the semester. Just be sure to keep up with readings, because the written assignments stop with about two weeks worth of material left.
BIG time commitment, between the written assignments and the required listening.  Definitely a class that requires a lot of work, don't take if you're looking for an easy class.
Definitely take it if you love this music and each class is fairly enjoyable to just sit back and relax, but be mindful that Prof. Wegman isn't necessarily the best lecturer.
Definitely take it!!! Great course, great subject material.
Definitely take this course if you are interested at all in the history and development of rock music.

Definitely take this course! Especially if, like me, you have very little knowledge of rock & roll, but are really curious to learn. 
I really enjoyed our listening assignments and readings, although some of the response questions can be a bit tedious.
Wegman can be a bit disorganized, but he is really enthusiastic and passionate about the material. I was really excited to attend every lecture.
Definitely take this course! Very interesting topic and Professor Wegman is clearly invested and makes it fun! Do not take only if you hate The Beach Boys.
Do yourself a favor and take this course. You won't regret it. It's essentially rock n' roll history from the early 50's to the early 70's.
Great class for those that like the music but are not too interested in all the theoretical and technical aspects.

Great class. Prof. Wegman gives fantastic lectures. You don't need any musical knowledge. Helpful musical terms will be taught in lecture/precept. The psets and listenings may take some time, but doing them is a great way to supplement what you are learning in lecture. The midterm/final was very fair (just studying the listenings and lecture notes was plenty for me).

I mean, any class in which the whole point is to listen to and learn about wonderful music is probably worth taking. That being said, Professor Wegman's self-indulgent rambling about the Beach Boys is infuriating, and the preceptors don't really know what they're talking about a lot of the time.
I would take this course! If you love music you will love this course.

Its a good time. The weekly listening and response questions would take me 5-6 hours per week and I would do it all the night before,. which isn't that bad for a class with no papers. Fun to do the assigbments. That level of effort got me basically perfect scores on the assignments so even if you do less you'll be fine. really enjoyed this class!
Keep up with the reading and listening! There is a lot, and you can get behind pretty easily.
One of my favorite courses that I have ever taken.
Recommend if you don't mind having to listen to a lot of music
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT!!! One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton - super well taught, extremely interesting, so worth it!!!

TAKE THE COURSE, especially if you like rock music, even if you don't? even if you are looking for an easy LA. Go to every lecture and pay attention to your question sets, they will help you tremendously on final exams and midterms. Going to lecture shouldn't be hard though. He's a fantastic and funny (sometimes self-deprecating) lecturer, and it's really easy to enjoy his lectures and amazing powerpoints.
TAKE THIS CLASS IT'S GREAT

THIS COURSE ROCKS (pun intended). I'm an Econ major and took this for an LA, but it ended up being by far and away the best class I've taken at Princeton. Professor Wegman approaches 1940s-1970s rock with the knowledge of a professor and the enthusiasm of a music lover -- and by the time the course is over, you'll understand exactly why. Seriously, my only disappointment with this class is that I can't take it again.
Take if you like rock and roll and would like to know how it all came to be and how it evolved, strongly recommend
Take this class if you have any interest in rock n' roll. Rob Wegman is a great lecturer. He is so engaging and enthusiastic. I actually wanted to go to every lecture and do the readings.
Take this course.  Great way to kill off your LA and fairly easy grading.  Most of the grade comes from weekly responses that are fun to do and pretty easy to do well on.  Strongly recommend.
Take this course; it is fantastic
This is an excellent option for someone struggling for LAs. It wasn't a huge time commitment and was genuinely a very interesting course. Professor Wegman is also just and excellent human being.
This is an interesting course if you are curious about American rock music. I'm happy I took it.
This is the best class I've taken at Princeton. Must take. Content is really interesting and you learn so much more about music that you love.
Yes this is a great course and I highly recommend it.

You'll learn a lot about rock music and be introduced to new bands from the 1960s, as well as form new perceptions of ones you already knew. He was rather disorganized with the lectures and we didn't get to some stuff I was hoping to learn about, but it's still a great class!
Just make sure to do well on the assignments and you'll be fine with the midterm and final.
if you are interested in this period, and the music that defined it so well, take this class, you will not regret it.
take it!
descrip: Examines post-World War II blues, rock music mostly of the late sixties and early seventies, and the connections between them. Explores wider musical and extramusical connections.

title: Junior Independent Work
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, and an oral presentation will be required. Students generally spend 15-20 hours per week on the independent project.

title: Ordinary Differential Equations
reviews:
TAKE THIS CLASS!! Probably the best math class I have taken. Vlad is THE BEST - I suggest taking any class with him. 
Material was great, perfectly taught, I actually feel I have learned so much at the end. ODE might seem a boring and computational subject, but I swear this class was nothing like that. I would be amazed how fast time passed by (first time it ever happened).
Take it, it's not too hard or too boring! Be sure to prepare thoroughly for exams.
Take it. Dynamical systems are cool. Pretty pictures.
prereqs: MAT 215/217 or 216/218, or equivalent..
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the study of ordinary differential equations. Topics include: Explicit solutions of some linear and non-linear equations (using tools that span: separation of variables, integrating factors, Greens functions, and Laplace transform methods); Series solutions of ODEs with analytic coefficients and with regular singular points; Fundamental existence and uniqueness theorems (Peano, Picard-Lindelof, and Osgood); Introduction to dynamical systems (Poincare-Bendixon theorem); Stability of equilibrium points and periodic orbits.

title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: read estabans slides prior to lecture as you will surely miss something and there is no coming back from that
descrip: Macro implications of micro imperfections. The "cleansing" effect of recessions and the impact of allocative versus aggregate shocks. Recent models of consumption and empirical tests of risk-sharing. How the distribution of income or wealth affects aggregate growth and fluctuations. Role of imperfect credit markets, distributional conflict and political economy. Endogenous, skill-biased, technological change and human capital accumulation; implications for growth and social mobility.

title: Topics in 19th- and Early 20th-Century Music - The 20th Century Symphony
descrip: This semester explores symphonic composition from the era after the "death" of the symphony, (after the death of Mahler), moving through works by Scriabin, Nielsen, the neoclassicism of Stravinsky, the English and French "conservative" modernists, and a miscellany of forgotten but super-productive symphonic specialists.

title: Protest!
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Vergil's Aeneid
reviews: Great course! Professor Baraz is fantastic. Plus, we had a trip to Rome, which was incredible (though you lose spring break for doing work for other classes). It does expect a lot of you, so don't just take it for a free Rome trip if you barely know latin.
I would suggest to keep up with your readings. Additionally, not only do you need to translate, but also scan poetry lines.
If you like Latin, I would take this course. The professors are amazing, the conversation was amazing, and the text is amazing. Also, you get to go to Rome!

PLEASE DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Prof. Baraz is amazing and although you'll have to put a lot of work in (doing Latin readings, English readings, and research), you'll get a lot out of it!
Professor Baraz is such a delight both inside and outside of the classroom.  She demands excellence from her students, so be ready to do the work, but it will be worth it!
Students should take this class but be prepared for long readings. Baraz is a wonderful spirit and has a great way of leading discussions.
TAKE THIS COURSE. You will learn a ton about the Aeneid and about material culture. Baraz is wonderful. And, let's be real here, you get to go to Rome. Take the course.
Take any class with Professor Baraz
prereqs: LAT 203 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will concentrate on the role of topography and landscape in the poem. Students will be required to participate in a trip to Italy over Spring Break.

title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music
reviews: A must-take for all instrumentalists that enjoy collaboration.
Definitely a worthwhile course to take if you can get a dedicated group together.
Excellent class. If you are keen on playing chamber music, you should take this class.
I would recommend this course to any musician.
Take it twice if you can!
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.

title: Elementary Sanskrit II
prereqs: SAN 101.
descrip: Continuing from SAN 101, this course provides a firm foundation in Classical Sanskrit grammar, syntax, and vocabulary. Students continue learning the rules for phonological change (sandhi), and other building blocks of Sanskrit grammar. Students will read Sanskrit texts of increasing difficulty, acquire the skill of recitation of Sanskrit poetry in several meters, and learn to compose small but cohesive narratives of medium difficulty in Sanskrit. By the end of the year, students will be ready to read independent texts in a variety of genres, using Sanskrit-English dictionaries and grammars. SAN 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101.

title: Survival Analysis (Half-Term)
reviews: Start working on the small exercises from the very first day
Take this course as early as you meet the prerequisites. It will be very helpful to at least be exposed to the methods early on.
This is a good course that both builds intuition and teaches you how to actually estimate models computationally.
prereqs: POP 507/WWS 509 or equivalent.
descrip: Course focuses on statistical analysis of time-to-event or survival data, introduces hazard & survival functions, censoring mechanisms, parametric & non-parametric estimation, and comparison of survival curves. Covers continuous and discrete-time regression models, with emphasis on Cox's proportional hazards model and partial likelihood estimation. Discusses competing risk models, unobserved heterogeneity, and multivariate survival models including event history analysis. Course emphasizes basic concepts and techniques as well as social science applications. Half-course offered in first half of spring term.

title: Enzymes
reviews: The enzyme class is absolutely worth while to take. Professor Link is a very diligent lecturer. I loved how he took a historical overview of the material before delving into the lecture material. As a graduate student, there was a lot I got out of the course. The month long kinetics was refreshing and I indeed learned a lot.
descrip: Enzymes are the engines that fuel life, catalyzing a vast array of different chemical reactions. This course focuses first on enzyme kinetics and the structural biology of enzymes. With these tools we next move to a series of case studies about different enzymes and enzyme families.

title: Fracture Mechanics
descrip: This course covers the basic topics including energy balance, crack tip fields, toughness, toughening, and subcritical cracking mechanisms. Fracture processes are then examined as they occur in some modern technologies, such as advanced ceramics, coatings, composites, and MEMS and biomechanical/biomedical systems. The course also explores fracture at high temperatures and fatigue processes.

title: Love, Sex, and Marriage in Comparative Perspective
reviews: A lot of readings/assignments but interesting overall and pretty easy. Fun class.
Best course I've taken at Princeton. Interesting subject matter that's very applicable to life outside the classroom, and Prof. Frye is absolutely wonderful. Don't miss out!
Take the course and do the readings - they are really worthwhile and are necessary for exciting class discussions.

This course is amazing. If you're not interested in the subject matter, don't take it, but if you have any interest whatsoever, do! Don't be intimidated by the "discussion facilitations" because Maggie is really encouraging (as well as being super smart). This course has had such a positive impact on my life that I really wish everyone could have a similar experience. Try this course and you may fall in love with the universe that as blessed you with Maggie Frye.
Wonderful course. Take it!

You need to be comfortable with public speaking and confident in your abilities to express your thoughts and ideas to others. The reading load is very manageable, and doesn't get in the way of senior thesis research. It also meets once a week, so there's plenty of time to prepare.
prereqs: Under Requirement and Grading, Other refers to 5 digestion memos (6% each)..
descrip: This course provides a critical analysis of the social contours of intimacy around the world. The course is divided into three units: romantic love, sexuality, and marriage. Within each unit, we will delve into specific topics with readings providing both a U.S. perspective and international comparisons. Sample topics include: romantic love and masculinity, sexuality and labor, and marriage and inequality. The course will emphasize critical reading and reflection of original empirical studies from sociology, anthropology, history, and gender studies, as well as active and student-led discussion.

title: Touching Books -- An Introduction to the History of the Book
reviews: Come in with a sense of curiosity and an open mind. This course is accessible and would be of interest to all students, even if this area within the department is not in one's area of specialization.
I would absolutely recommend other students take the course.

If you're interested in the physical properties of books and manuscripts, this is a fun class to take. Be prepared for a definite Middle Ages focus, but the workload is definitely manageable, and the assessments are relaxed and entertaining. Professor Anderson is so kind and willing to guide someone unfamiliar in the field. I loved this class, despite early trepidations.

Professor Anderson is a great professor. She is very nice and gives accommodations to seniors writing theses. The readings and material can seem confusing at times, however, if you do not have much experience with English courses.
Really fun and interesting, though there are fewer practical exercises than you might be led to believe

Sarah Anderson's great. She's really kind and really accommodating, and even though this class doesn't cover much actual history (which I'd expected, given that the subject is 'history of the book') she does know what she's talking about and is able to enlighten anyone who's interested. Depending on the engagement of the other students this may be a really excellent class or a slightly disappointing class, because it's really all about class time ? not really any work outside of that, other than preparing for presentations. Lots of fun, I'd recommend it! (Especially for second semester seniors)

This course forces you to think critically about the book and approach it in all sorts of directions. Good way to explore new ideas each week and be able to explore your interests in connection with the history of books.
prereqs: Although I will focus most narrowly on the British Isles in the early Middle Ages, I encourage students who are curious about scribal culture, the social construct of reading, and the powers of literacy in other periods and places to join this class. Not only are students of literature welcome, but also encouraged are students of music, history, the visual arts, and computer science, etc. Curiosity is required, whatever discipline or interests the student brings to the class..
descrip: This course introduces the student to manuscripts and early printed books made in the West between the fourth and sixteenth centuries CE. We will study the aesthetic and textual programs, and the production and functions of the book, including hand-written and printed examples. Turning the (intellectual) page from chronological considerations, we will consider simulacra of books -- facsimiles, critical editions, and digital images. How should each of these textual products be used? What is the space of the page itself, and how is it shaped by audience and editorial practice?

title: Journeys in Portuguese: Studies in Language and Culture
reviews: An amazing class that explores the whole Lusophone world through readings and films. I know my Portuguese has increased tremendously and if considering this class definitely take it. The enitre Portuguese department is great but Nicola Cooney is an amazing and really encouraging Professor.
Fairly good course. It is a bot of work though, much more than in my other language courses.
Great class to learn about Lusophone countries and speak Portuguese.
Take it with Nicola, she is a goddess. It's a lot of work, but there is a lot of reward that comes along with it.
Take it!
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.

title: Europe in the World: Monarchies, Nations, and Empires from 1776 to the Present Day
reviews: A must for anyone interested in history.
Attend the lectures! Cannadine is a marvelous lecturer and he will essentially cover all the material, but you should still at least skim through the readings.
Be prepared to do the readings and have the knowledge readily accessible for the assessments. Not a walk in the park by any means if you're looking for a high grade.
Best course i have taken while at Princeton
Cannadine's lectures are amazing; he is a piece of history himself and I enjoyed every lecture. Besides the readings the workload is not too heavy.
David Cannadine is an amazing lecturer, and it is a fascinating course.
Definitely take it!! Go to Lectures and Precept and you will not need to study much outside of class.
Definitely take this class - a true masterpiece and exactly what you come to Princeton to take. If you're at all interested in being a more informed, educated person, you will take this.
Definitely take this if you want to learn more about the world, it's much more expansive than just modern European history. A lot of takeaways that are important in life going forward.

Do not take it. You will learn nothing. Lectures are dry and repetitive. Content of course is not at all insightful. Take another class if you want an easy PDF. Do not waste your limited number of classes at Princeton on this one. Please.
Extremely boring if not extremely interested in European history.

Find out which readings are necessary to do and which aren't. If you're taking the class to satisfy an HA there is a ton of useless readings. IF you want to learn more about monarchies sure do them all, if you want to do pretty well in the class, only do what is necessary, if your PDF'ing do nothing.

For a non-history person I found this class engaging and informative. There is a solid amount of reading but not much writing/essay work which I really enjoyed. Cannadine is an amazing Professor and as I have heard, is unlike anyone else in his formal lecture structure. I cannot imagine any single person knowing more about the history of European monarchies - and that made the class all the more interesting.
GO TO LECTURE! Best part of the class.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture, Cannadine is fun to listen to. You won't find many lectures that are enjoyable, so take advantage.
Good PDF class

Great course. The 21st century is an era that focuses very strongly on secularism, nationalism, and democracy, to the point that we have forgotten what life was like before today. This course is very educational and really helps you develop a cosmopolitan perspective on things, and it removes you from modern-day nationalist "brainwashing" and helps you see the bigger pictures of history. The course goes a little fast and is more broad rather than deep.
Great course. You really should go to lecture, because Cannadine makes everything interesting and it a pleasure to hear from a giant in his field twice a week.
Great, interesting course, as long as you do what you need to do you shouldn't have too much trouble with it

I cannot recommend this course. I had heard wonderful things about it, but did not enjoy it in the slightest, myself. This was not a positive learning environment for me. The subject matter is interesting, but the method for teaching it may not be a good match if you're interested in social or cultural issues. I am very glad this course is over. I hope it goes through heavy reforms before it is offered again. Also, the syllabus was incredibly confusing and a lot of the books were hard to acquire or repeated in the back of the Pequot, so just be aware of that. Good luck.

I personally didn't hate or love this course. Some of the material is pretty interesting but because of the survey nature of the course, it often feels like you're just generalizing a narrative and not able to get into the interesting details. Also, there's a lot of reading assigned and not all of it is that interesting. Cannadine is a really great lecturer though and very distinguished in his field.
I thought this was a good distribution requirement, even though I wasn't particularly engaged.

I took this as a history major. If you're in STEM and you need to fulfill a requirement, take a history class that genuinely interests and excites you. It makes me sad this class might be people's first and last experience with history as a discipline.

If you are going to take this course, be prepared to do a lot of reading and to absorb a lot of information. The course is pretty comprehensive, and it covers quite a lot. That said, I enjoyed it, and I'm glad I took it! I feel like I have a better grasp of European history now.

If you are interested in monarchy or European history and don't mind keeping up with the readings, this is an excellent course with a reasonable course-load (though some of the readings can be dull) and a great professor.
If you want to fall asleep during lectures and while reading, this class if for you

It is a fun course to take if you have to time to read all the books. I wish I had PDF-ed  the course since I had a hard time reading everything, so if you are a slow reader and have busy schedule due to other classes, PDF would not be a bad choice
It was interesting, but beware casual course takers- the books   course packet are expensive and required
Its dumbed down history.  Do not expect any revelations here, but its a good introduction to the study of history.
Keep up with the readings to get the most out of the class, but if you cannot, read the topics you're most interested in.
Keep up with the readings.
Lectures are more beneficial than doing the readings--> wish i went to lecture more by the time the final hit
Low work class with very interesting lectures
Make sure you do the additional readings for precept in addition to the lecture readings.
Not a bad class but very broad and not very engaging.
Professor Cannadine is the man
Readings aren't great but lectures are.
Relatively short readings and no papers make this a pretty low stress class. If you are looking for a 5th class, this is fine.
Take it if you're interested in European history.
Take it! Cannadine is an amazing lecturer, most of the things you talk about are really interesting and still quite relevant to today's politics.
Take it! Cannadine is great, not too hard, very little work!

Take it! Easy enough for an HA and interesting. If you're looking to fulfill the history prerequisite this is a great class to do it; there's lots of help and guidance available about learning how to write for history and in analyzing primary sources.
Take this as your HA or HIS requirement! Standard length readings, easy grading. Cannadine is an amazing lecturer, his jokes are sparse but funny, and his accent is the best! Bonus: he's a knight.
Take this class. Great PDF. Go to lecture and you will learn everything you need to know.
Take this course for Cannadine. He is a great lecturer and you will learn a lot.

Take this course!  Whether you are testing out the history department for the first time or you are a history major, it is a great choice.  Professor Cannadine is a wonderful lecturer, the readings are extremely interesting, and the workload is not in any way excessive.
Take this for an easy history.
Take! Definitely a pretty heavy reading load, but the lectures make it worth it. Focuses on European history.

The readings are long and sometimes boring, but overall they are worth it because Professor Cannadine's lectures are great. Know that you will be doing a fair amount of work, but what you put in will come back in spades - you'll learn a ton about a very interesting topic, from a perspective that doesn't usually get considered.

This course is a good intro-level class, so take it if you don't know very much about monarchies (not just the European ones, either). If you have a specific area you're interested in, this is a general course and thus looks at a wide variety of places, and it might not be the best course for you, especially because it demands a lot from you in terms of the readings.
This is a great course. Professor Cannadine is a really good lecturer and the subject is really interesting.

This was a really interesting class! I would recommend taking it, but it is not always as easy as some people put it out to be. There is definitely a lot of material to know, but I thought it was interesting and a good way to learn about some important world history.
Try it out school is fun!
Useful course regardless of whether or not you've been brought up in a monarchical country.
Would recommend very highly
awesome HA. interesting content and lectures aren't dry
don't take Flori's precept.
interesting course
it's not the most interesting
make sure to keep up on the readings, and go to every lecture.
phenomenal class
s
take this class if you want a HIS class. It is not too hard, but is very interesting and fun.
very good class to take if you are a history major or any major in general - the topic is useful to knowing about how and why things are the way they are today
prereqs: P/D/F option not available for History concentrators.
descrip: This course offers a global history from an unusual perspective: that of the nations and empires ruled by monarchs and emperors (and sometimes empresses) across the years since the American and French revolutions, which are often seen as the events which ushered in the modern world of republicanism and democracy. To be sure, many thrones have crashed and crowns have passed away since then; but monarchies are still with us today, from Japan to Britain, Swaziland to Sweden. This course will explore both the anti-monarchical trends that have thrived since 1776 and 1789, but also the surprising extent of royal resilience.

title: German Intellectual History - Sigmund Freud's Writings
descrip: The course will provide an introduction into Sigmund Freud's psychoanalysis by studying (passages from) a couple of basic texts both in German and the English translation. Special emphasis will be put on the role of language, literature, figurative writing, and translation in his theoretical approach. This includes the role of 'translation' (of psychic experiences into symptoms) in Freud as well as the translation of his texts into English. One main aim is to understand central metaphors/ concepts of his writings: Umschrift, Entstellung, Familienroman, Symptom etc.

title: Principles of Quantum Mechanics
reviews: A good intro to quantum. Study hard, get all questions answered, and you should do okay :)

Definitely a difficult class, but not unmanageable by any means. I would definitely recommend finding a couple friends to work on the problem sets with, if for no other reason than to keep each other sane as you try to understand the material.
Don't be excited for Verlinde's lecture if he's teaching. But the material is fascinating and the textbook is great.
Great topic, awful professor. MIT OCW has a great set of lectures online, watch those instead of Verlinde.

I took it for a GenEd and it was pretty manageable (even without a physics background).  The exams from Verlinde are a speed test and the problems are very difficult (but the curve accounts for that).  The last two weeks are on quantum entanglement and spin, which was very very challenging.  But everything else is fairly easy and straightforward.
I would recommend going to office hours and making sure you understand how, at a minimum, to do the problems mechanically.

I'd say take this! Be prepared for annoying computations and messy integrals in the problem sets. I did feel like I had an intuitive sense of what I was doing, though, and I appreciate that. Quantum is pretty cool. The course is hard, though.

If you are a physics major, you have to take this course! If not, you ought to take this course anyway! For anyone interested in how our world works on a small scale, PHY 208 is very enlightening and engaging. Problem sets are significantly less time-consuming than those of PHY 205 or PHY 304, and lectures are great ? Professor Verlinde does an excellent job at instilling a sense of curiosity towards the topic, and making QM feel intuitive!

If you are interested in quantum physics, you should take the course. Lectures might not be very good, but the material is interesting. Problem Sets are very important to get familiar with the material.
If you have to take it then you have to take it. If you don't have to take it, and verlinde is teaching it, take something else. It should be really cool, but as is I didn't get much out of it.

If you're not physics, you should take quantum in a different department. The physics department in general tends to focus on pseudo rigorous mathematical justifications rather than physical intuition of any kind. You'll probably learn much more in ELE or CHM quantum, and you'll definitely have a more helpful professor.
Interesting to learn the intro to quantum
It's worth taking if you are interested in the subject matter. Otherwise, probably not.
Know that this course can be difficult, and not always for the best reasons. QM is fascinating, but be ready for this to be harder than it might seem.
Make sure to befriend Griffiths as Verlinde means well and is quite intelligent but can't seem to organize his lectures.

Professor Verdlinde's lectures were most effective if you read the relevant chapters beforehand, because he didn?t walk through the lessons step-by-step the way the book did; he tended to jump around and follow tangents that didn?t make much sense unless you had already seen the material once before. In that sense it felt a little bit disorganized, and sometimes I couldn?t tell whether he had a strict lesson plan coming into class or just a sense of the topics he was going to talk about. But QM is a fascinating subject and, if you?re willing to put in the work, it?s a very interesting class.
Quantum Mechanics is instrumental to the structure and philosophy of modern physics. Anyone with a passing curiosity or familiarity with Hamiltonian mechanics should take this class.

Quantum is a rich theory and you'll definitely be exposed to interesting problems in this course. If you're a physics major, you have to talk it and you'll learn a lot from it. 
If you're a math major and want to explore infinite dimensional vector spaces in a non-rigorous way, now's your chance!

Quantum mechanics is a really interesting subject. However, if you want to learn it from this class, there will be a lot of time spent learning and reinforcing the material by yourself, since usually it is hard to fully grasp the material immediately in (the usually disorganized) lecture.
Take if you have to
Take quantum mechanics! It's awesome.

The usual: go to office hours, go to problem sessions. Griffiths isn't very good after chapter 3, so find a supplementary text if you have to. Verlinde isn't a good lecturer, so be prepared to do a lot outside of class to learn the material.
This class is required for physics majors, so I'm not sure what advice I can give. This class is a lot of work and is reasonably difficult, so plan accordingly.
This is a very difficult and rewarding course.
You have to take it if you're a physics major
take if you have to
prereqs: MAT 204 or MAT 217 and PHY 205 or PHY 207. If PHY 104, PHY 106, or ISC 234 have not been completed, one of them must be taken concurrently..
descrip: This is the Physics Department's introductory quantum mechanics course. Its intent is to present the subject in a fashion that will allow both mastery of its conceptual basis and techniques and appreciation of the excitement inherent in looking at the world in a profoundly new way. Topics to be covered include: state functions and the probability interpretation, the Schroedinger equation, uncertainty principle, the eigenvalue problem, angular momentum, perturbation theory, and the hydrogen atom.

title: The Environment: Science and Policy
reviews: A lot of the material is common knowledge or common sense.
A really good science departmental for WWS majors! Wilcove is great, Jin wasn't so great. Get Mayank as a preceptor if you can!
Actually a pretty interesting course although I don't feel like I learnt a ton of new stuff, lectures are well-organized and readings are very doable and generally easy to get through.
Actually know science before you take this so you don't become the idiot saying climate change isn't real in front of the whole class.
Apparently it's the best option for the departmental, which is a shame because the course is still terrible.
Attend lecture and try to see how readings connect. Good for EEB majors interested in environmental policy.
Be sure to spend time with the readings and take valuable notes in lecture.
Can't recommend this class enough. It's so interesting, useful, and not difficult. Wilcove is so entertaining and everything just made sense.

Definitely take this if you're even thinking about it. This is especially true if you're Woody Woo or trying to get an STN out of the way.  I could see this class being a bit "duh" if you're already familiar with the environment and environmental policy but I must say that I don't think this is a class you'll regret. Do the readings as best you can but especially go to lecture and try to pay attention in precept. Sato and Wilcove are a good team I think and definitely take it with them if you're interested in taking this class. Can't really go wrong.
Definitely the best woody woo science policy course
Do not take this course.
Good class.
Good course for the ENV certificate, not much work.

Great class to fulfill your Woody Woo science policy requirements. Use the midterm study guides to go over key concepts and create reading summaries within a study group while studying for the midterm. This class emphasizes the policy side of the environmental debate and at times is jargon heavy. But it is not that much work and you can do well.

I LOVED this course. As an EEB major interested in conservation, this class was a perfect fit for what I look for in Princeton courses. Great class to discuss the ways to approach different environmental issues, and learn how they are addressed in the real world. Make sure you are in Mayank's precept--he was awesome!
I definitely wouldn't take it for fun or even general interest.  Only take it for an STN or WWS

I really loved this class, and would strongly recommend it. I took ENV 201 last fall (also with Wilcove) and didn't love it, but WWS 350 has been awesome. There's a strong and sensitive consideration of the social impacts of both climate change and conservation which is facilitated by Sato's anthropological background. The course is pretty chill too... just short weekly writing assignments and a midterm / final. 10/10 would recommend
I recommend this course to WWS concentrators looking to fulfill the Science Policy core course requirement.
I would definitely recommend this course! It's not hard for an STN.
I would recommend taking this course. Prof. Wilcove and Prof. Sato are excellent lecturers and present topics in a compelling and engaging way. The workload is not bad either.
I would take this course if you need a departmental, especially if Mayank is a preceptor. It's a pretty easy course and for the most part pretty interesting.
If you are interested in the environment, this is a good course to take.  It's not too hard and provides a lot of good information.
If you can stay away, stay away.
If you need an easy stl or distribution definitely take this. It's not the most fun class and it's kind of vague but it's not hard.
If you need it for woody woo then definitely take it, however it can be very vague and hard to know how to study for
It can be a bit basic if you are familiar with environmental issues, but still a useful survey course on policy problems and issues.
It is a good STN for someone in the social sciences or humanities.
It is a relatively painless STN though certainly not riveting. If you're Woody Woo, it might be a good choice to knock out your science policy requirement.

It's a Woodrow Wilson School departmental, so you might end up in this class. It's a decent class and I learned a lot, but as someone who has never taken a class on the environment, I often felt lost. In my precept, it was difficult to participate without the prerequisite knowledge. I mostly enjoyed the course, but the lectures were sometimes not engaging and difficult to follow.
It's a pretty easy class, for the most part. The exams are kind of tough because the questions can be really specific. Have to do the readings.
Loved this policy course. Made me wish I was Woody woo instead of EEB.
Not a terribly interesting course, but fairly easy. Weekly precept assignments ended up being helpful in making me keep up with the most important readings or ideas each week.
Only if you have to.
Precept made this class SO great! I had it with Junnan and he was super fun! We analyzed articles in interesting ways and I loved this class! Take it!
Pretty interesting class for the science policy requirement. Not too much workload. Easy to get behind on readings.
Really cool class!
Run. If you have to get the WWS requirement, best of luck to you. If you're EEB and you care about the environment, go for it. Otherwise run to the fucking hills.
Short reading summaries with key points (no little details) are crucial
TAKE THIS CLASS!! David and Jin are awesome! Especially if you like the topic, take it.
Take for ENV certificate!
Take it
Take it if you need an easy STN. Wilcove is particularly good and very funny. Material is interesting.
Take it if you want to fulfill the WWS distribution requirement and feel like you want a rather more relaxed class but also are willing to put in some effort in learning the very relevant information
Take it it's cool
Take it! The course is well taught and a good course for the woody woo science policy requirement.
Take it! Wilcove and Sato are both great lecturers, and the material is relevant and interesting. It's also not too much work.
Take it.
Take this course if you need the WWS Departmental! Form a reading study group for midterm and finals -- but this class is definitely enjoyable and doable.
Take this is if you are at all interested in environmental policy - no prior experience or knowledge necessary in environmental topics.
The "Policy" is more like political theory; if you are trying to brush up on what is actually happening in the world, take another course.

The course is decent- some of the material is very interesting. The biggest problem is that it's not well-organized, so you don't know why you're learning certain concepts after others, and it feels pretty disjoint.
The overall quality of the course was very high. Even though it was a departmental I really enjoyed taking it.
This class is great for WWS students to fulfill science policy and STN at the same time. It's really not that science-heavy if that's not your strongest suit.

This course is a no-stress way to fill the WWS science policy requirement, but it's pretty boring and I found that I learned a lot less than I had hoped to. Take it if you're really not interested in engaging with environmental policy, but if you are, I think there are much better options to fill the WWS requirement.

This is course is worth taking. You probably won't learn too much if you have a background in ecology or environmental issues. Its very generalized and basic. That being said the lecturers and preceptors are kind and engaged and you'll most likely enjoy yourself.
Very neutrl
Wilcove is amazing, and if Mayank is a preceptor, DEFINITELY get him.
Would definitely recommend.
keep up with the readings!
take as the woody woo departmental for sure
take it!
take this class but beware if you aren't a WWS student its still not PDF! I'm a history major and its kind of annoying I had to take a grade for it.
descrip: This course examines the ways domestic US and international environmental regulatory frameworks adopt, interpret and otherwise accommodate scientific information. The course focuses on several case studies, that provide insights into the science-policy interactions which emerge from managing natural resources and environmental risk. Topics include air pollution; climate change; ozone depletion; managing the world's forests, fisheries, and ecosystem services, and global trade in wildlife. Students will explore the science underlying these issues as well as current policies and the range of future policy responses.

title: European Politics and Society in the 20th Century
reviews: Definitely take this class if you have an interest in European politics! You'll enjoy both of the professors, and even though their teachings styles are very different, they complement one another.
Go to class, skip the readings, and talk to the Profs - they know a lot about their material that they don't get to in class!
Good survey course, sometimes monotonous though. A lot of reading.
I would definitely take this course again. The material is very interesting and well-presented.

Lots of reading, but only a midterm and a final. I enjoyed this course, but I would say that the course is better for people with a minimal level of European History background (which I did). It is much more interesting to spend class time analyzing events instead of going over basic history for the people with no background.
Take early, taking it late is not worth it. Great for figuring out what one wants to do further.

Would highly recommend, even (perhaps even especially) if your primary interest is not European politics. Great professors and really interesting subject material; I'm really happy to have taken this class given my very limited background in the subject.
descrip: The course aims to cover the critical developments of twentieth-century Europe and the consolidation of democracy in European countries. It will deal with the legacy of the two world wars, Nazism, Stalinism, the Cold War, the legacy of colonialism and decolonization, the birth and development of the European Community, the development of the welfare state, the problems confronting the European Union (immigration, enlargement, political institutions, military role, and the single currency), and the varieties of democratic institutions in Europe.

title: Advanced Programming Techniques
reviews: A good systems departmental, good chance to get a feel for what working on an independent project is like. Know ahead of time who your group will be, and be organized with coordinating with them throughout the project.
A must-take. The development project really shows you all the ups and downs of working with a team on any kind of project. Start early, and be sure to keep your partners accountable.

Awesome class! You learn many new things, whether it's a new language, a new way to think, or how to test your own code in an organized manner and even automate the testing. The programming assignments took about 10 hours each and were decently difficult given that you have about a week for each, and they're all back to back. The second half of the semester is the design project, where you...design your own project with a team. This is a really great learning chance for you to teach yourself new things and use them on a project simultaneously, whether it's building a web app or a mobile app. You also get to experience what it feels like working in a team and contributing code to one large project! Overall, great class, highly recommend. I can't think of any other COS class that's as practical as 333.
COS major or certificate? Just take it. Not that difficult either.
Choose a good group of friends for your final project! You'll have more fun and your project will definitely reflect good teamwork.
Def take
Definitely take if interested in COS. A fun class in which you learn about a whole bunch of different areas.
Definitely take it if you would like to work in the industry after graduation. Lots of useful knowledge to get.

Definitely take it. Try and come into the class with a group or project in mind. Definitely attend the lectures, there is a lot of interesting content in them that will help you develop not only as a programmer, but as a person as well. I came into 333 a mere villager, a humble farmer one could say. I would water my crops and tend to my animals. After I left 333, I was Donald Trump. I was a mega mind programmer ready to take on the country and become president on the backs of shortcuts and manipulation (of regex). Definitely take this course. You too can go from farmer to blonde toupee reality star.

Definitely take the course! Make sure you have a group who is as committed to making the final project as you. I had a scenario where my group was not as interested so I was left with a majority of the coding work.
Definitely take this class if you are interested in learning the practical applications of programming.
Definitely take this class, especially if you have a good group of people to work with or an idea for the project that you're excited about.
Everyone interested in coding should take this class. Maybe not as a senior because of the amount of time needed for this class interfering with senior independent work.

Find a good group. The people in my group slacked off so much and, while I have talked to the professor, it has stressed me and my friend out for weeks and we are terribly worried for our grade (the final project counts as 60%)
Find a group that you would work well with and start early.
Get started early as possible on the project!
Gives you the most practical toolset for building things in the real world. All around a great time and a course every COS related person should take. Pick your group well.
Good class to get some software development experience in. It will be painful if you don't have a decent group to work with though, and the lectures are usually not too helpful.
Great COS class to take! Problem sets were interesting and it was fun to make a project over the course of the second half of the semester.
Great class for anyone looking to possibly go into a software job, solid amount of work especially at the beginning

Great course to get an understanding of a broad spectrum of things in COS. Moretti had quite interesting and informative lectures. The project is the main part of the class, and a lot depends on the team you have so either go into the class with a team already, or get good people to work with ASAP.

Great course! Put effort into it and you'll learn a lot that will be relevant to any work in software industry. Start your design project early, though -- and definitely leave time at the end for testing!
Great course!! Take it
Great for the design project.
Great upper level COS class to take if you are willing to put in the time and effort; you will learn a lot if you want to.

I think the students should probably pay more attention than I did to the lectures in the second half of the course. A lot of the information that is covered is interesting and will only help you in completing the final project.
I would recommend taking it. Make sure to choose a good project.

I would say take this class if you are interested in working on a personal project that you already have in mind and wouldn't mind getting a grade for that. In terms of the programming assignments during the first half of the semester, they are really cool to do if you haven't been exposed to other programming languages outside of C and Java from 226 and 217, which was really interesting to me. However, the second half of the semester definitely tanks since everyone focuses on their own individual group projects rather than shared assignments and lectures become less and less relatable and interesting.
If Moretti is teaching, don't sign up. If Kernighan is teaching, please sign up.
If you don't have a project group with members that are all really willing to work, this can be a challenging class in the last half.

If you want to be "forced" to build something, do it. It's awesome to build something from start to finish. Find a group of people you can trust and Rely on because you only have 7 weeks, that is not a lot of time. The Lectures are just a Smattering of different topics covering different technologies which isn't really very helpful on the most part but if you are interested in a particular topic you will be happy to have it introduced to you. Take it if you have an idea that you want to see come to life.

It really depends on what kind of project you decide to work on. Some people choose a hackathon level project, which shouldn't be too time-consuming. However, our group met up every week for 3 months and spent at least 20 hours every week...
Make sure to start the first assignment early so that you don't fall in a vicious cycle of catching up to finish the other ones. You don't have as much time as you think.

Meet up with your group regularly in person. I think it would've helped to have had some leader-ish person just to keep everyone on the same page. It is helpful to have people you know who have similar programming experience taking the course to make a group with.

Also, make enough time for the more regular assignments in the first half of the class; they can take some time.

Pick a good group and start the project early. Make sure you budget time for the harder assignments as well. Moretti is a pretty engaging lecturer but be prepared to have to do some outside research because the lectures are really more of a survey and don't go in depth too much even when you need knowledge for an assignment.
Put time into this course.
Start assignments early.  For teamwork, try to do everything yourself or check up on people to make sure they are ok because people will lag behind.
Start the project early! Also assignments. It's ok if your group doesn't have much experience. You'll learn a lot. Do tutorials
Take it
Take it because practical programming is very fun and applicable
Take it for some highly useful programming skills no other class at Princeton will teach. End up with a very cool project you can be proud of by the end.
Take it for the design project
Take it if you need a COS class
Take it if you want to learn applications programming.  Be prepared to work tons of hours on the final project, especially if you have lazy teammates.
Take it, Moretti and Kernighan are both great.
Take it, but be ready to devote a lot of time to homework and the project. The class takes effort!
Take it.
Take the course.
Take this class if you want to be a software engineer or ever get a job at a good company. With that being said, it is a lot of stress during the last 6 weeks, but TOTALLY worth it in the end!
Take this class with friends if you can, you'll be amazed how much you learn.
Take this class! It is a good opportunity to learn about real-world coding.

Take this course if you want to work on a semester long project! (new app on web/android/ios). Be prepared to spend a long time on the project. Also, take this class only if your friends are also taking it too. Groups of 3-5.
Take this course if you're at all interested in development, app or web. Have a few thoughts on project ideas and team ideas.
Take this course!

Take this course! Wonderful project class and you will learn a ton through the product you create. Get started early on the project and find a good group (3-5 people) when you first enroll in the course!!

Take this, especially if you're a COS major and looking to go into software engineering. It gives you at least a taste of what software development is like, and I think is the only class at Princeton to do so.
The final project is awesome and you'll learn a lot. Be sure to start early.

This class may not be easy, but it has made me learn a lot. It makes me closer to the real world because it teaches very practical stuff. The project is also really fun. I love my teammates! Professor Moretti is so funny and nice! He's the best!
This is a challenging course. Don't overload if you're taking it.

This is a fantastic class that requires a lot of work and effort on your part to read documentation and figure things out for yourself, as best as you can, before reaching out for help. Sure, you can reach out for help before you know you've done everything that you could to fix a bug or something, but it won't do you any good. If you do this class right, it comes closer than any other class at representing coding in the real world.

This is a really rewarding course! The first and second half almost feel like different courses.  The first half involves an assignment every week which is definitely a really fast turnaround.  The second half is just the project which is a very different kind of challenge.  I found that there was a lot more guidance with the assignments than the project (office hours, etc.), which was helpful.
Useful class with a moderate workload compared to other COS departmentals.
You'll get what you put into the project.... and what your group members put in. Choose your group wisely!
good course worth taking
i strongly recommend this course. it is excellent
its needed if you want to do an internship and extremely useful in teaching you how to work on large projects
take it if you want to get overview of software engineering
take it!!!! find a great group early and stay on top of your work
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: This is a course about the practice of programming. Programming is more than just writing code. Programmers must also assess tradeoffs, choose among design alternatives, debug and test, improve performance, and maintain software written by themselves & others. At the same time, they must be concerned with compatibility, robustness, and reliability, while meeting specifications. Students will have the opportunity to develop these skills by working on their own code and in group projects.

title: Borges and the Universal Library
reviews: An excellent course that will make you think about literature in a completely different way.
Be ready to engage deeply with the material.
Recommend if you are willing do devote a significant amount of time each week. A really challenging but rewarding class.
Take this class if it is ever offered again!! Professor Manguel is a literary genius and is also a very fair grader.

This will be a worthwhile course, particularly if you appreciate literature studies, because Borges is a fascinating writer and Manguel is one of the people most capable of teaching a course on Borges (check out his bio). Manguel is a genius and unparalleled scholar, which may seem overwhelming at times, but don't let that stop you.
prereqs: One SPA 200-level course above SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is designed as a survey of the writings of Jorge Luis Borges.
