Using the Borgesian notion that literature is a collaborative act between reader and writer, we will closely read a selection of texts by Borges and trace them back to his library, from German expressionism to the Nordic sagas, from Dante to Cervantes, from mathematical theory to the philosophies of Plato, William James and George Berkeley, from the Arabian Nights to the detective novel, from library science to film, from the craft of verse to the art of translation.

title: Cybersecurity Law, Technology and Policy
reviews: 100% you have to take this class if you are at all interested in Tech or Policy!
A good overview of the policy problems of encryption, privacy, and cybersecurity, if not somewhat depressing. Probably best paired with Information Security in the COS dept.
Reidenberg is a great professor. Go for it.
Reidenberg is a great teacher, really seems to enjoy the material. Take it if you want a low work seminar (with a big final paper)

Take this class (or a WWS task force/research seminar with Prof. Reidenberg) if you're interested in tech policy--it's a good survey! Prof. Reidenberg is very fair with the number of assignments (not too many!) and reading load, but the seminars can be a bit broad or scattered!
Take this course if you are interested in security at all. The material is super interesting and the professor is very experienced and engaging.

This class is very good. You don't need to do every bit of the reading as long as you are engaged and do a reasonable amount of them. In particular you will need to do a lot of readings for the issues you want to write about, but you have tremendous choice on what topics interested you most.
This is an interesting class, and it definitely doesn't require any prior knowledge of cybersecurity or coding. It's more slanted towards policy than technology.
good course to take PDF if you're working on thesis and want to sit back and learn some interesting things about cybersecurity policy which is becoming very interesting.
descrip: This seminar will introduce students to the significant challenges that government, law enforcement and the private sector face in addressing cybersecurity risks. The seminar will focus on cyber threats that jeopardize national security as well as threats that have significant legal, economic and social consequences. Students will learn about US technological vulnerabilities, the existing legal and policy framework and the development of new policies to protect US interests including those for cyber-defenses and the protection of civil liberties.

title: Problems in Latin Literature - Senecan Tragedy
descrip: We read three of Seneca's tragedies and consider the major issues such as their relationship to Greek models, to Seneca's philosophical works, their status as works for the stage, and their place in Neronian culture.

title: Religion and American Politics
reviews: Absolutely take this course! Professor Achen is one of Princeton's best professors. From a work perspective, this course is not that demanding. I would highly recommend this course to anyone with an interest in how religion affects American politics!
Achen is an animal - crazy smart, crazy kind. Take it.

Highly recommend! One of the most rewarding classes I've taken at Princeton! (and Professor Achen is very fair and awesome). If you want a class that is all about talking about those dumb religious conservatives, do not take this. If you want a class that will help you understand the full range of religious views in the US and how they affect politics and to understand each of them in a fair manner, please please go for it!

I have taken many Politics courses at Princeton and this is definitely one of my favorites.  This course helped me look at the intersection of religion and politics in many new ways. TAKE IT whether you are totally secular, super religious, or anywhere in between. 

Also, Professor Achen is such a friendly professor! He invited us over to his home to eat dessert at the end of the semester. I really loved this course. Achen is such a nice person and cares about learning everyone's name.
Professor Achen is a great professor, super intelligent, and very kind.
Take it.
You should definitely take this course!
descrip: This course will discuss the range of American religious belief and non-belief, and then investigate how each religious group engages in politics. The religious and poltical views of both clergy and lay people will be studied, along with the mechanisms by which people learn those opinions. Lectures and reading will take up key issues of current political life, such as abortion, gay marriage, and immigration policy, and the course will investigate how religion shapes opinion on each of them.

title: Bodies in Motion: Sport and Physical Culture
reviews: Don't just read the materials at face value and discuss strictly their contents. Definitely apply it to your own experience and share that. That is how you can get the most out of the class.
I would say this is a great course to take because it is an interesting subject matter, and it's a good way to get introduced to anthropology without feeling overwhelmed.

If you like sports, I think you'll appreciate this class even more.  You'll learn about the life of athletes in all sorts of events while being able to contribute through and drawing from your own area of expertise.  I'm a sports fan rather than varsity athlete, but I still got a lot from this class.
If you like sports, take this class. Enough said
Interesting discussions and topics, not very interesting reading and boring assignments, but great discussions

Make sure to be careful while doing assignments. Professor Sherouse is very relaxed and approachable, but he takes the grading very seriously. He seemed to grade a tad harsh on some accounts, but it is overall worth taking!
Take if you're interested in a sport.
Take it. This class is interesting and gives new perspectives on sports and bodies. Workload is manageable .
Take this class. expect to do some work but there are very interesting articles and the final paper is completely based on your own topic delving into a particular sport
Take this course. Professor Sherouse is awesome and he will teach a class with a unique spin on it. He is exactly the kind of high quality professor you hope to have in your time at Princeton.
Take this course. Very interesting and not overly demanding. Dr. Sherouse is great.
This course is very enjoyable if you're an avid fan of sports. Many of the examples in class discussions will come from your own sports experiences, whether that's as an athlete or a fan.
great course with really interesting material
descrip: Despite intricate training and judging rituals, sport is often cast as an uncivilized realm of unconscious bodily action in opposition to "serious" cultural pursuits of the mind. What do sporting practices reveal about cultural values? This course introduces the study of sport in comparative social and historical context. We investigate classic and contemporary anthropological approaches to leisure, games, and play. We will discuss how sport reconfigures the meanings of social categories such as race, class, and gender. This course encourages students to consider what an anthropological take on sport can provide.

title: Colonial and Postcolonial Africa
reviews: A bit disorganized, but an important subject and an incredibly enlightening look at a neglected aspect of modernity through the eyes of a brilliant South African professor who lived the narrative of protest against apartheid and helped win his voting rights firsthand.  The course was a bit disorganized in 2016, but if offered again should run much more smoothly and allow even deeper engagement.
DO NOT TAKE IT! It will in a lot of ways ruin your perception of the History department.
Definitely do the readings and come with a few questions/opinions. Talk to Professor Dlamini if you are confused on your essay topics.

Definitely take this course. This was really informative about the historiography of and common topics addressed in the study of African history. Professor Dlamini is an insightful professor who makes class really interesting and engaging.

I highly recommend taking this class if you're interested in taking one of the few African Studies classes that Princeton has to offer. That being said, prepare for a lot of reading on a weekly basis. Professor Dlamini is a great lecturer, but definitely keep up with the reading if you want to stay engaged in class.
I would take but prepare to do an hour and half of readings. Also, be prepared to change the way you think about Africa.
If you are interested in African history and can handle a hefty load, you need this course in your life. If you can't handle 300  pages of reading every week, run. Run very far away from this course.
Take the class if it improves by the standards listed above. There are other structured AFS classes out there. The class can also be an easy GPA booster if you do your work wisely.

Take this course, and do the readings to be able to engage in critical conversation. Avoid the temptation to just rant about what you already know and let yourself be challenged. Professor Dlamini is wonderful - use him as a resource!!
This class is okay. I feel like I'm not actually learning that much about African History because of too much discussion. Therefore, I feel like sometimes it a pointless class.
Unless they majorly change the structure, don't do it. Minimal lecture, largely undirected discussion based, which means you just listen to people who don't know what they're talking about.
You should really take this class.
do not take this course. it's extremely unfocused and doesn't provide insight into the time period and the region.
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History majors.
descrip: This course is an examination of the major political and economic trends in twentieth-century African history. It offers an interpretation of modern African history and the sources of its present predicament. In particular, we study the foundations of the colonial state, the legacy of the late colonial state (the period before independence), the rise and problems of resistance and nationalism, the immediate challenges of the independent states (such as bureaucracy and democracy), the more recent crises (such as debt and civil wars) on the continent, and the latest attempts to address these challenges from within the continent.

title: Environmental Law and Moot Court
reviews: Any interest in environmental policy/law, take it. What an incredible course.
If you are interested in environmental law
If you're interested in law school and want to see what moot court is like, this is a really fun class. It's not an excessive workload, and Professor Hawkins has a lot of experience in the field.
Made me not be scared of seminar courses anymore.

Professor Hawkins is a fantastic teacher whose passion for the subject is readily apparent during every seminar. If you're interested in law school, this class offers an introduction into one aspect of the legal system and legal writing that can be helpful in making such a decision.
Take the course and do the readings. The more you put into it the more you get out of it. One of the only courses if not the only course of its nature.
descrip: Examining the relationship between law and environmental policy, this course focuses on cases that have established policy principles. The first half of the seminar will be conducted using the Socratic method. The second half will allow students to reargue either the plaintiff or defendant position in a key case, which will be decided by the classroom jury.

title: Introduction to Classical and Neoclassical Transport and Confinement
reviews: It's definitely necessary for student in plasma physics to know the basics theory of tokamak transport, the drift waves.

Neoclassical transport is a necessary topic to know for plasma physicists. It is inherently complicated, but this course provides an accessible introduction that gives qualitative understanding that can help in understanding the more technical details in independent studies
The material is interesting; the two halves of the course are very different.
This is pretty fundamental stuff that every plasma physicist should probably know.
descrip: The first half of this course intends to provide students with a systematic development of the fundamentals of gyrokinetic (GK) theory, and the second half provides students with an introduction to transport and confinement in magnetically confined plasmas.

title: Education and Inequality
reviews: Definitely take this class! Professor Nolan does a great job facilitating the discussion and goes over some very interesting material.
Professor Nolan is great, she is a sweetheart! Great readings and instruction. You will meet other passionate students.
TAKE IT WHILE YOU CAN!!! Its awesome
Take it if you're interested! Not too hard. Be ready to talk in class.
Take this course! Prof Nolan is great and the readings are interesting. Make sure to talk in class!

This class is good. I recommend trying it out - if you are interested in how race and class play into educational outcomes, it is a good one to take. Know that Professor Nolan is a pretty critical grader, but she is also very accessible for help and guidance.

This is a FANTASTIC course! The seminars exceeded my expectations. The professor struck an excellent balance between providing necessary background information and contextualizing the course materials with facilitating conversation. She created a welcoming environment where we felt comfortable engaging with the material and sharing our ideas. The professor made sure that she dedicated the time to clarify the expectations for the written work. She always welcomed and encouraged students to come to her office hours and discuss the assignment with her.The readings were very interesting and provided a very thorough background on Education and Inequality. There was a good mix of the academic readings alongside some current event pieces that connected the theoretical ideas to contemporary issues.

This is a really interesting class. If you have an interest in education reform, I would recommend taking this course. The class makes you think about educational inequality from a variety of perspectives and will be sure to challenge you.

This seminar does not have an unbearable workload -- prof. Nolan is very understanding to all that is going on during the semester yet still happens to make seminars engaging and interesting. This is a good course to take as an introduction to the American education system and its problems, but most students will have some background knowledge before enrolling in the course.
Very good class. Professor Nolan is great!
descrip: In this course, students examine the relationship between inequality and schooling in the United States. We explore the educational practices and organizational structures through which social inequality is produced and reproduced inside schools and how social class, race, ethnicity, gender, and other social differences shape educational outcomes. Additionally, we examine students' responses to inequality and theories of resistance. We mainly consider theoretically grounded, qualitative research related to K-12 education. Several readings discuss the realities of urban schooling, and each week we connect the readings to current policy trends.

title: Forms of Literature - Contemporary Irish Literature
descrip: This course will introduce you to the full range of contemporary Irish literary work, including fiction, poetry, and drama. The focus will be on writers who have come to prominence sine the 1960s, and will include Seamus Heaney, Edna O'Brien, Brian Friel, Seamus Deane, John McGahern and Anne Enright. One section of the course will be devoted to thinking through the impact of the war in Northern Ireland on Irish literary production. We will also consider representations of the Republic and Northern Ireland on film.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: This is a continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. The total grading of the course is based 10% on oral presentation and written "poster" communication skills and 90% based on advisors evaluation of the semester's work.

title: 20th-Century French Poetry or Theater - French Modernist Poetry
descrip: This course investigates Modernist poetics in France from mid-19th to mid-20th c. and seeks to re-evaluate Modernism in French literary history. Course will treat the topic at a variety of interrelated levels by exploring French poetry as part of the broad historical phenomenon of Modernism, while examining the specific ways it materialized in France as formal innovation and as response to modernity. Seminal poets such as Baudelaire, Mallarme, Apollinaire, and Cendrars, will be discussed as well as specific movements. Readings and theoretical questions will also address the complex relationship between avant-garde and Modernism. (In English)

title: Religion in Colonial America and the New Nation
reviews: Definitely take it! Professor Perry is awesome and leads great discussions. Most of the readings are interesting primary sources. One of my favorite classes in my four years at Princeton.
Great professor. Great class to take
I came into this class with no background in religion so I wasn't sure what to expect, but I would highly recommend this course. Professor Perry is great and the subject matter is interesting.
I would say take it. Isn't extremely rigorous, Perry is a beast, and the readings and papers are actually enjoyable.

Start the final project early. You will quickly realize how inconvenient the hours of Special Collections are, and furthermore, since you have so much freedom, you want to make sure you are really happy with your source and your thesis. In general, take this course! It will help you engage with primary sources in an accessible way, which is fascinating and useful!
Take it!
Take it! Professor perry is great and you have great discussions, even if you're not particularly interested in colonial america
Take this course!  Professor Perry cares immensely about his students and the material that we engage in--and it shows!

This is a great course. Professor Perry is very approachable, and his precepts are relaxed yet engaging. The material is interesting, and the final assignment is unique (based on an observation of a primary source in Rare Books). I would definitely recommend it to others.
don't take the final project lightly
descrip: This class covers the history of religion in America from European contact through the 1840s or so. Emphasis will be on primary readings, organized chronologically around a few recurrent themes: contact and exchange; authority and dissent; the relationship between theological reasoning and everyday life. We'll pay particular attention to changing conceptions of religion's role in social organization and competing religious views of human nature over time.

title: Econometric Applications
reviews: Be carful with the midterm and final! Mark Watson makes this class worth of taking.
Go to precepts. It is a lot of work.

If interested in doing econ research/in econ data, wanting to learn more about how to apply 302/312 concepts in real life to actual data, or preparing for thesis, this is a great course. But be prepared to work hard!

If you are a math-track econ major, you will love this course. If you are not but prepared to write a lot of econ papers and study econ in the real world, you will probably like this course too. Maybe not so great for all others - also a really time-intensive class.
If you are not an economics major thinking of graduate studies, this is not the course to take.
If you want to learn how to write econ papers like a pro you should take this course. If you don't want to have to write half a JP every week you should reconsider.
Take it if you want to be a serious economics student.

This class has a lot of work, but it is incredibly rewarding and helpful for independent work. It was probably my favorite class of the semester. Certainly take it if you are considering graduate school in Economics or find empirical work in the field interesting.
This class is incredibly helpful. It cements your ability to write about applied, empirical work. Very useful for independent work.

This class is ridiculously hard, but worth it. Be prepared to spend 10-20 hours on homework each week. Will help you so much for JP and thesis though! Must take if you want to go to grad school for econ.

This course is incredibly challenging but rewarding. I spent more time on it than on my other three classes   JP (including 2 other ECO departmentals).  Only take it if you are highly interested in Econometric literature, but definitely go out on a limb and try it. I would suggest having 312 though its not required.
This is a key course for any Econ major. Arguably, this will change the way you look at economic problems, and help you dealing with data, which is key to any economic question.

You have probably heard that this class requires a JP a week. Except for the literature review, it is quite true. The biggest mistake I made was not realizing that this class draws the most ambitious people which is good in that the classes are super engaging but not in that you have to do an excellent job in every homework to even be average.
You will never learn more in a class. You will also never give more to the class. I 100% would recommend it, but with the caveat that you know what you're getting into.
prereqs: ECO 302 or ECO 312. Additional prerequisite: Calculus.
descrip: This course provides hands-on experience in the art and science of econometric analysis designed to help students to acquire and master the skills necessary to carry out their own empirical research in economics. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable economic models, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. A range of applications will be presented and discussed in class and on problem sets.

title: Portfolio Theory and Asset Management
reviews: A bit of a strange class since the topics are pretty practical (insights into efficient investing/the market that would be useful for anybody and not just for people who are going into finance) but the course itself is a mix of analytical, programming, and conceptual components (with the emphasis really on the first 2 categories). The assignments/exams have significant analytical (mathematical derivations) and programming components, so this may  not be a good course to take if you aren't comfortable with calculus/MATLAB programming. It's a pretty cool experience to take a course with MFin students since they contribute to the discussions in lecture in a way that enhances understanding of topics. The book is way too conceptual/general for the course, and while there were some familiar concepts from ECO 362, this course has a different focus and feels more academic. Since this was the first year that Professor Yogo taught this course, it was a bit rough/disjointed at times, and I often ended up doing things without really understanding the ideas behind them, but I think that the quality of the course will improve substantially since the topics are pretty solid.
Great course to take if you are going into Asset Management. Maybe a little heavy on the theory side, but the second half uses more data analysis.
I've learned more in this class than any other class at Princeton, but it is very difficult

Prof. Yogo is very approachable, the material is very accessible to anyone who has familiarity with finance and/or statistics, and it is an interesting experience as an undergrad to be surrounded by grad students. Great course, and I don't think there's much to change about it.
prereqs: ECO 202, or ORF 245, ECO 310, and ECO 362..
descrip: This course covers a number of advanced topics related to asset management and asset pricing. Topics include mean-variance analysis, CAPM, APT, market efficiency, delegated money management, stock return predictability, bubbles and crashes, social interaction and investor behavior, security analysts and investor relations, and mutual fund performance and organization.

title: Fundamentals of Machine Learning
reviews: A great intro to Machine Learning. Will get you familiarized with the jargon, with many of the concepts, and with how to do things in practice. But there is no emphasis on theory outside of the lecture as assignments are entirely coding and writing. You don't need to know much if any statistics, just how to code/basic logic.
Be good at math.
Be prepared for interesting material, but disjointed/confusing lectures, readings, and assignments. Not my first choice for a COS departmental.
Definitely take this course. Use office hours to help understand the problem sets and go to the problem set precepts
Do not take this course if you are more interested in theory.
Do the problem sets diligently and you can gain a lot out of this course.
Don't take it if you are a grad student, imo.

Eh. Take this course if you're interested in machine learning and want to implement it. The class is structured very strangely. You never really have to learn what she is talking about in lecture. All you have to do is be good at coding and implementing things you find online. If you can already do that then this course is fine
Good overview of machine learning techniques and how to write paper-like project reports.
Great introductory course to machine learning techniques
How much you can gain really depends on you motivation and engagement to the course, since the major tasks of the course are all open-ended with no standard answer.
I can't recommend this class. I really like machine learning. I even enjoyed COS 402 with Xiaoyan which generally gets unfavorable reviews. Unless major changes happen, I would stay away.
I found working with people I didn't know well to be a good experience.

I took this class because I thought that machine learning and data science were important to learn. I wouldn't exactly call this class disorganized, but the distance between the lecture material and the programming assignments made it so neither one was at all useful. I was fortunate to come into the class with a good operational knowledge of Python, which made the programming assignments just a matter of importing a few libraries and then running a few out-of-the-box algorithms. There wasn't really any kind of engineering challenge, and it much of the work on the assignments was filled with what I'd call "academic overhead" (Things like doing research for related work or other background research)

The course puts a large burden on the student to make their own way through the programming assignments. The TA's and professors care about the course, which is somewhat of a saving grace. But I do not think that I learned anything substantive that  I would not have gotten from reading random online tutorials on my own. This course felt more like a Coursera class than a Princeton class. 

Don't just take this class because you feel like you ought to learn about machine learning. You would probably get a similar experience just reading about things on your own, and not dealing with the seemingly unrelated tasks that this class saddles you with. (Notwithstanding the litany of superior ML-focused classes offered here) Given the interest level of the instructors and some of the framework, this class has the potential to be a good course, if it makes serious structural changes to integrate the assignments and lecture material together. At this point, the assignments are pretty much non-instructive, and this is a class that I would recommend that you stay away from, unless you have a serious desire to hound the professors/TA's to get something meaningful out of the class. I doubt you will get anything without extraordinary effort.

I'd recommend this for anyone who's interested in doing machine learning practically.
OUTSTANDING LECTURE SLIDES. I learned the litearlly solely from this.
This forces you to learn Jupyter, a great tool for intearctive computing. Also teaches you basic data analysis and paper writeups. Assignments were instructive.
Teachers/TAs could be more responsive on Piazza,  but you can get a lot out of this if you're proactive and ask questions.
It's a great chance to be creative!

If you already know Python and have taken a class in probability/statistics, you'll be fine here. If you're missing the probability/stats, you'll probably be fine, but be prepared to spend significant time reading and thinking (if you actually want to understand the material). If you know know Python or have stats, this class will be pretty difficult (at least for the first half of the semester). The lectures are okay but do not prepare you AT ALL to do the assignments. You ABSOLUTELY MUST go to the precepts before the assignments or else you'll have no idea what you're doing, as you're given almost no direction with them. If you're coming straight out of the 226/217 pipeline and planning on taking this class, keep in mind that this class isn't run anywhere nearly as nicely as those courses, and you will be heavily responsible for directing yourself and staying on top of your work.

If you want either a gentle intro to machine learning or to learn how to use SciKitLearn, then take this class; you'll get an A without very much work if you are reasonably proficient at COS. However, if you want to actually learn the theory behind everything, take ORF 309 and then ORF 350 for a much more rigorous theoretical introduction.
If you want to experience basic machine learning, don't hesitate to take it.

If you're interested in doing a bunch of side projects that just involve downloading every package in R to try and solve a random problem, then this is your class! Grading is a little hazy but if you follow their formats you should be more than okay.
If you're interested in machine learning, take this course. It's not math-heavy or work-intensive but you get a chance to play around with data creatively.

If you're looking to a more theoretical understanding of machine learning, take ORF 350. If you're more interested in the applications of ML, this isn't a bad course to take although most of the math/stats is glazed over.
Interesting topic in general. However methods are presented in a very theoretical way.

It's a relatively mediocre course for a relatively low workload, which I think is a fair tradeoff. Take it as a third departmental and really put some time into the assignments and you will learn quite a bit. Don't expect to learn anything from the lecture or readings, though.
Machine learning is a worthwhile topic -- unfortunately, this class is poorly structured and frustrating for the disjoint nature of the materials and assignments.
Not too much work week to week, but when assignments come up, be prepared to spend a lot of time. Good class, but might be difficult for someone who doesn't have a lot of statistics/ML background.
Pick your homework groups carefully and if you don't have a background using scikit, definitely pick that up as early as possible.
Sadly, one of the worst classes I've taken here. Lectures aren't particularly helpful and while both the professors are nice, that means little when no one really knows what's going on.

Some form of statistics was not listed as a prerequisite when I took the course, but you absolutely need to have been introduced to probability, statistics, etc. before understanding anything in this course. I'm lucky to have taken classes beforehand, but a few of my friends in the course had not and struggled through every reading and lecture because of it.
Suitable for more self-motivated students
Take ORF 350 for the theory (from what I've heard), take this for application.

Take ORF 350. This course presents an overview of different techniques in ML but does not do anything to help you understand them. You end up implementing algorithms through a black box approach before you even over the concepts in class.
Take if interested in learning ML
Take it if you want a decent start to learning ML - you will likely need to put in a fair amount of time outside lectures if you want to really learn the stuff though
Take it if you're interested in machine learning, though I've heard ORF 350 is better.
Take it to get a wide view of different ML techniques.
Take it whenever you have a time. Requires quite a time, but it will turn out to be meaningful.
Take it with a different prof.  Also, don't bother with the lectures, just do the homeworks.
Take stats/math preparation.

Take the course for the projects. I recommend the machine learning course by Andrew Ng on Coursera if you actually want to understand the concepts. If you want a social twist on the applications, try taking Soc 504. Prof. Brandon Stewart did a wonderful job explaining Logit, EM, regularization, GMM, etc. I understand it so much better in Soc 504 as compared to this class.

Take this class to get familiar with the jargon associated with machine learning.  You will use python libraries to implement all of the algorithms, so a deep understanding of the theory is not necessary nor is it incentivized.
The course assignments and lectures felt disjointed.
The homeworks are great and you really learn with them.

The pre-requisites are misleading -- the lectures   readings are impossible to understand without some background in math and probability theory (i.e. ORF309, to start). The assignments took a while to complete but were very interesting.

The subject is interesting and so are the projects you do, but the class doesn't require you to know much about the theoretical underpinnings of the algorithms you use.  This makes it easier than other COS courses because it's up to you whether you want to learn the nitty gritty parts, but if you're not motivated you might not get much out of it.

This class is an easy PDF with a very low workload (aside from the days before the assignments are due). But you won't get anything out of it unless you already have some experience in data analysis. If you want to learn about actual ML, take ORF 350 but be prepared to work.
This class is not very challenging.
This course is not meant to be a formal introduction into the machine learning field but a way to offer the student a small glimpse of a variety of topics in machine learning and how they are used.

This course seems to emphasize using python/R libraries to do Machine Learning without really understanding what is going on. If that is all you are in it for, then this course will do the trick. If you want to really learn the ML then I suggest the ORF department's course or theoretical machine learning based on what my friends have told me.
This course was quite overwhelming and easy.  Take if you want a lower workload COS course, not if you really want to learn about Machine Learning
Would take some time to check out the readings to make sure you can actually understand the statistics part of the course.
i know that taking a course in the hot new field of data science sounds exciting but cos 424 is really not a coherently put together thing and i suggest doing something else.
take if you want to explore interesting data sets
the class covers material very fast. you can learn something at least from homework.
wouldn't take this class. I learned very little and almost all of it was from textbook readings and assignments, not the lectures or the course staff.
prereqs: MAT 202 and COS 126 or equivalent or permission of instructor..
descrip: Computers have made it possible, even easy, to collect vast amounts of data from a wide variety of sources. It is not always clear, however, how to use those data, and how to extract useful information from them. This problem is faced in a tremendous range of business and scientific applications. This course will focus on some of the most useful approaches to the problem of analyzing large complex data sets, exploring both theoretical foundations and practical applications. Students will gain experience analyzing several types of data, including text, images, and biological data.

title: Integrated Building Systems
reviews: Fun class. Good opportunity to collaborate with students outside your studio. Learned some good basic building techniques which I will likely refer to in the future.
MArch1 have to take it, its not a bad class, just a lot of work towards the end of the semester.
descrip: An introduction to building systems and the methods of construction used to realize design in built form. First half of the course is an overview of the primary systems, materials and principles used in construction of buildings and the fabrication of elements, through lectures and accompanying lab sessions. The second half allows students to design, detail and fabricate a custom fabrication utilizing principals explored in the lectures.

title: Intermediate Urdu II
reviews: Best professor!

Definitely take this class to improve with Urdu! Fauzia-ji is great at introducing you to interesting articles, poems, and other reading materials! Plus, even if you are not yet completely comfortable with the script, the reading and writing assignments help you become more literate.
Fauzia is a one-of-a-kind professor. So friendly and warm, and genuinely invested in her students' success.
Fauzia is such a wonderful professor. The class does require quite some time outside of class as writing assignments are tedious. However, she is a wonderful professor and I highly recommend.
You couldn't ask for a better language course at Princeton than to take Hindi-Urdu with Fauzia ji. She will go out of her way to help you both inside and outside of class.
prereqs: URD 105 or equivalent proficiency. See instructor for placement..
descrip: This is a continuing proficiency-based course which refines and expands previously acquired linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Focus is on expanding vocabulary, mastering more complex grammatical structures, and acquiring idiomatic expressions. Use of authentic Urdu materials from print and electronic media, literature, and films. Equal emphasis on all skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). Various aspects of the target language culture will be integrated with instruction. Activities will be conducted in Urdu and classes will be interactive.

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
prereqs: CHI 405 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Continued reading and discussion of scholarly writings on modern Chinese literature. This course also exposes students to the social issues China has faced in recent years, while discussing various aspects of contemporary Chinese society.

title: Other Encounters: Theoretical Approaches to Representation
descrip: This seminar facilitates an elementary encounter with theoretical writings about art, literature and the writing of history. The collection of readings is not meant to be comprehensive, but is intended to establish familiarity with and foster discussion of major works that have shaped and revised our notions of representation. We move from study of major theoretical traditions such as deconstruction and new historicism to readings in nationalism and postcoloniality to a broad reflection on ?area studies? as an academic discipline.

title: Oil to Ozone: Chemistry of the Environment
reviews:
A solid overview of environmental chem. You'll go deep into the how and why of issues like climate change and the ozone hole, which is pretty awesome if you'd like to understand better the fundamental physics and chemistry underneath pressing environmental issues. 
Doing the reading is very helpful.
Go to office hours often!
Honestly, do not take this class. It is not much work at all, but the homeworks are ridiculously unclear and you will get a B with work that you should get an A for.
It's worth it.
Much better alternative to second semester orgo. Class can be tedious at times but very little total work

Recommend. This course covers a lot of ground and I learned a lot even though I've taken many GEO/ENV courses. It is what you put into it though - you don't have to be engaged but you won't benefit if you don't. Seriously recommend doing all the readings - surprisingly enjoyable and enriching textbooks.
This class is not as much chem as you would expect.  Really only the second half is chem chem. The first half is atmospheric stuff. Just be prepared. Overall a good class and pretty easy though.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or equivalent. (Consult instructor.).
descrip: The chemical background of environmental issues. Topics include energy and fuels, global change, ozone, air pollution, chemistry of natural waters, pesticides, and heavy metals.

title: How the Tabby Cat Got Her Stripes
descrip: See website

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Basic)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. Focus is on the determination of macroeconomic variables - such as output, employment, prices, and the interest rate - in the short, medium, and long run, and addresses a number of policy issues. Discusses several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions.

title: Introduction to Kanbun
descrip: Introduction to the basics of reading Chinese-style Classical Japanese and its related forms. Texts: Literary and historical texts from both China and Japan.

title: Democracies at War
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Ecologies of the Envelope
descrip: This seminar is aimed to develop knowledge about the principles of building envelope design, situated in a history of the envelope technologies. The course is aimed to research and discuss a new theory of the building envelope, able to replace the historical disciplines of the facade. We will teach the principles of insulation, waterproofing, air leakage, vapor barriers, ventilation, de-bridging, embedded energy etc,, trying to bring together technical and theoretical knowledge, into an ecological, evolutionary reading of building technologies.

title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.

title: Text as Data: Statistical Text Analysis for the Social Sciences (Half-Term)
descrip: A survey of approaches to statistical text analysis with a focus on applications in the social sciences. The course covers supervised learning, clustering, topic modeling and scaling.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: Definitely recommend if you enjoy looking at why and how we do the things we do. I don't really think you need NEU 201 to take this class though, the two courses are soooo different. So if you didn't like NEU 201, you might like NEU 202, and vice versa.

Don't do textbook readings. Do the practice exam questions. Pretty easy overall because midterm and final are open notes. Take excellent notes in lecture (literally write down everything that is said and you will get an A).

Having had a mediocre experience in NEU 201, I was very unsure about taking Cognitive Neuroscience. Nevertheless I continued because I still wasn't sure if I wanted to pursue the certificate program. 

Having completed the experience, I have extremely conflicting views on the course. For the majority of the semester, I found myself yearning to enjoy the material but never found myself fully engaged with the content. Meanwhile most of my other classmate really enjoyed Professor Norman and others' lectures - I have to admit that they were very clear and enjoyable. Nevertheless, I was very ambivalent about the actual content itself. 

Looking back, I think that there was a big difference between NEU 201 and 202. For me, 201 was very enjoyable as an engineer because the chemical and physical concepts were rewarding to learn. i appreciate the fact that the content accumulated on itself. 

202 on the otherhand take a much more high level perspective on neuroscience. The lectures span a large variety of concepts. For me, this material left me feeling lost. The course attempts to teach the concepts through experiments, but for me the facts and concepts seemed very haphazard and I wasn't sure why we were learning them or why they were necessarily relevant. I felt that I was memorizing disperse facts, so I dreaded studying for the course. 

Yet, the majority of my students found the topics fascinating. To explain this disparity, my best piece of advice is to develop some general interest in the field before taking the course. If you find yourself yearning to learn about how humans think, then your interest will ultimately drive you through the course. On the otherhand, if you know that you prefer more chemical analyses of neuroscience and do not care much for the high level processes. I would skip this class - it's for some and not for others.
I can say that this class provided sufficient fodder that I shared some of my findings with friends in dinner conversation and that's not something offered by many classes.

It's a really interesting class for anyone with an interest in neuroscience. For those looking to fill a departmental, if you go to lecture and keep up with the readings, then it's a really fair course.
Pay attention in lecture and take good notes
Pretty good intro class, but there are better specific neuro classes out there!
Take it if you are majoring in neuroscience, seeking the certificate, or just for general knowledge. It will be hard, but it will be worth it.
Take it!! It's really interesting and makes you think about your brain and the way you think completely differently.
Take it, but be prepared for the lectures to be not terribly exciting.
Take the course if you are or were interested in Neuroscience, even if Neu 201 in the Fall seemed tough or uninteresting! I really enjoyed this course a lot more.
Take the lab section! It sounded more interesting than the precept sections.

This is an excellent course! I didn't particularly like NEU201, so I wasn't sure about this course at first, but I found it to be completely different. The lecture topics are extraordinarily relevant to real life, and the concepts make sense logically. You learn a lot of really, really cool concepts about how people actually think, and the course staff is great. Definitely take it!

While this was not one of my favorite neuroscience classes, there were some lectures that I really found interesting. My biggest advice would be to really study for the exams because they tend to focus on things that were less well-discussed in class.

Would recommend if you like neuroscience. Very different from 201 since it switches from biological things to cognitive neuroscience, but still very interesting. The papers we read for precept were cool, so don't be afraid to read the papers and discuss them in precept for those participation points.
prereqs: NEU201/PSY258 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course surveys current knowledge about the neural underpinnings of cognitive functions such as attention, language, memory, learning, and decision making. Cognitive neuroscience is a young field where many questions are yet unanswered. Through this course students will learn to extract overarching principles of cognitive function and neural organization, and to effectively address questions about the neural substrates of high-level human behaviors using current neuroscientific methods and clever experimental design. Precepts will discuss primary literature pertaining to the topics covered in class.

title: Imagining Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Electronic Circuit Design, Analysis and Implementation
reviews: Actually go to lecture and engage. Also, do read the labs beforehand and anything you don't need to do physically in the lab as a prelab.

As an MAE, I took this course as an elective. It is interesting and useful; I have added a dimension to the things I can work with. But it is also challenging. Try hard in the labs or else you'll end up running late. Do the extra homework problems to make sure you understand the methods, that's what the exams are about.

Definitely a tough course, but fun for ELE majors/people interested in circuits. Don't be afraid to go to Professor Verma's office hours to get him to re-explain concepts from lecture. He is so helpful and when you go to office hours, you can really get him to slow down and explain what you need.
Don't take unless you're ELE. Definitely the hardest sophomore departmental. Very demanding course and exams are super hard.

Good course to learn about the fundamentals of circuits. The second half of the course, especially, is very interesting, as it deals with the frequency response of circuits and more advances analysis techniques.
Good course to take in conjunction with ELE 201 if they are offered concurrently, or after 201 otherwise. Cool final project (brain machine interface), but lots of time in lab.
Good intro to circuits
Great course and Verma is an excellent lecturer. Get Hossein as a preceptor if you can.
I HATED these problem sets. Computations, annoying algebra, etc. I guess you do have to learn this one way or another. But it's not that fun, at least to me.
If Verma gets more of a handle on his expectations, take it for sure if you're remotely interested in circuits.
If Verma is teaching it, you're doomed

If you're ELE then you have to take this course. If you're not and it's still taught by Verma, do not take it. He spends half the time reviewing material from previous lectures. Do you remember how in Calc I they taught you how to take the derivative by definition? Imagine starting with that for the first 10-15 minutes of every single calculus lecture. That's what lectures with Verma are like. Also he writes awful exams that take a ridiculous amount of algebra and then will deduct heavily for algebra mistakes, all the while claiming it's not the algebra that matters but the concepts.
It will take time but it's still pretty fun
Of course all ELE majors have to take it, but I would also recommend this class to other BSE students.
Only take if you have to. The tests were unreasonably difficult, and the lectures were very repetitive.
Pretty interesting course. Circuit analysis can be confusing to get a hang of, but once you understand it, everything makes sense.
Probably shouldn't take this course unless you are required to, or have a VERY strong interest in electronic circuits.
Take it
Take it even if not ELE! Professor Verma is amazing.
Take it if you gotta
Take it! Don't get monday lab, because some stuff in the lab gets ironed out over the week.
Take the course but be sure to give it more time than what you think. This course is not for the faint of heart.
Take this course for a understanding on circuitry. Be prepared to put a lot of time into the course and spend a lot of time on labs. We came in a lot to finish even after lab went over
The course starts slow, but picks up steam as the term goes on. Labs will run long, so know that. But a good class.

This course is not exciting or fun for most people (even ELE majors). I just wish it could be more fun, but it's kind of hard because the material is so dull. Don't take unless your ELE or like annoying psets/exams/etc.

This was Verma's first year teaching the intro circuits class and I think it showed. He's a fantastic professor and lecturer, but I think his expectations for us were too high, especially on the midterms/final. The problems were just so much harder than anything we had seen before. I definitely recommend taking the class just to have Verma, but I hope he irons out some kinks in years to come and makes the exams more reasonable.
Unless you are an electrical engineering major, do not take this class. The material is really interesting, but for now it seems to be going through a transitional period.

Verma is a great lecturer, and if you go to office hours he'll get to know you and make sure you understand everything. Also, it really helps to take this along with 201, otherwise some concepts like convolution and laplace will be very difficult.
WATCH OUT THE COURSE ACCELERATES
descrip: Introduction to electronic circuit theory and practice. DC and AC circuit analysis theorems and passive and active components, from resistors/capacitors/inductors to operational amplifiers. Feedback, sinusoidal steady state analysis, frequency response, resonance, diodes, transistors. Labs and demos support and extend class material, culminating in a functioning radio. Creative circuit design using light and sound outputs is encouraged. A final project on bio-sensing, including design and testing of an electrocardiogram circuit to sense real heartbeats. SPICE circuit simulation is introduced and leveraged in the labs and project.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Havana: Architecture, Literature, and the Arts
reviews: Amazing, once-in-a-lifetime course.
Both professors are retiring, otherwise I would take it again.
Don't be afraid to participate. I was a bit afraid because everyone sounded more intelligent than I ever could but I still should have participated more.
Take a course like this one if you can.
Take this course and perhaps get some background on Cuban history beforehand.
This class was one of the most amazing experiences I've had at Princeton! Both Professors are wonderful and the subject was so unique and absolutely fascinating.

This course won't be taught again in the same way, but work taking regardless of anything else because of the trip. The seminars themselves are underwhelming, but overall experience of the course is very worth it.
descrip: This seminar will study the urban setting of Havana in its articulation with literature, film, and the arts from the early twentieth century to the present day. It will explore cross-disciplinary continuities, the engagement with multiple pasts, the city as a meeting place for all the arts and crucible of social identities. There will be a mandatory trip to Havana during Spring break.

title: Theoretical Ecology
reviews: Course will be easy if you are good at differential equations. Could be hard otherwise.
Definitely worth taking
Do your readings before class!

I learned a lot in this course. Applying mathematical techniques to problems in biology allowed me to get a deeper appreciation for both fields. I would recommend this course, just be ready for the math.
If you like math and want to know more about modeling in ecology, TAKE THIS CLASS. It is so so so cool.
Learn Matlab before this course. and be ready for some math.
Take extra notes from the Hastings book with step-by-step methodologies for each topic, go to Andrew's office hours!!

This is an amazing course and I wish I took it sooner. I actually enjoyed going to lectures and I felt like I learned so many things that I wouldn't have gotten from any other class here. It's also very accessible and applicable to many non-ecology subjects, so EEBs and non-EEBs alike can get a lot out of this class.

Very math-heavy. If you aren't a math person it's still doable, you'll just be putting a lot more time and effort into the course than other students. Levin is a great professor though and you will learn a lot!
go to office hours.
prereqs: There is no limit on graduate enrollment..
descrip: Current and classical theoretical issues in ecology and evolutionary biology. Emphasis will be on theories and concepts and on mathematical approaches. Topics will include population and community ecology, immunology and epidemiology, population genetics and evolutionary theory.

title: Dangerous Bodies: Cross-Dressing, Asia, Transgression
reviews: Be aware that this course has a large amount of very dense theoretical readings.
Cool course, fascinating sources. The theory is REALLY difficult to understand and the course gets really complicated and out-there theoretically later, but for the most part it's a good course.
If you're really interested in the subject matter, consider taking it.
Take it to read and watch really interesting texts and films and deepen your understanding of culture and communities
Take this class and start the weekly forum early.
This was a very interesting class!
descrip: This course examines "dangerous bodies" - bodies that transgress existing gender and racial norms in Chinese and Sinophone cultures. Situated at the intersection of literary, film, performance, gender and ethnic studies, this course provides an introduction to the shifting social meanings of the body in relation to historical masculinity, femininity, and Chineseness. We examine different cross-dressed figures, ranging from Mulan, cross-dressed male opera singer, WWII Japanese/Chinese spy, to experimental queer cinema, in a study that unpacks whether these transgressive bodies represent social change or a tool for restoring traditional norms.

title: History of the Balkans
reviews: Not an "easy" class, first half of class is similar to HIS 428

Prof. Greene is really cool and awesome to talk to in office hours. Her lectures can bounce around a lot of interesting topics, but you will LEARN A TON OF HISTORY. I have a much better understanding of the Balkans now, and if you are in Hellenic Studies or NES, this class would probably help out your research a lot and provide a stable footing from which to continue to explore the topic. Readings are fantastic, which is a huge plus.
take it if you have any interest in the Balkans
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: Southeastern Europe has always possessed a distinct regional identity. To say "the Balkans" is to conjure up a place that, while part of Europe, seems somehow apart from European history. What is it that has given southeastern Europe its distinctiveness? In this course we will answer that question by exploring the historical experience of the area stretching from Hungary to Crete, and from the Adriatic to Istanbul. We will start in the medieval period and take the story up until the twentieth century.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese II
reviews: If you made it this far in Japanese, you should definitely take this course, especially if its taught by Shibata-sensei. For 90 minutes, you get to be relaxed and goofy and have fun!

If you want to continue to improve your Japanese, then this is the natural next step after 3rd year. I found 4th year especially works on your reading ability and vocabulary, so it's helpful for achieving a more native level of language ability.
Keep taking the class; the professor is amazing and very engaging. The class, while a lot of work, is also a lot of fun.

The Japanese language department is awesome and if you've gotten this far, definitely take this class! Do be warned that some readings may be a bit tedious, but the content is very interesting, at least I think so.

This is not a hard class, especially since at this level you only meet twice a week. As long as you do the homework and spend a little bit of time studying for the quizzes and tests you will do well. Shibata-sensei is a great teacher and is amazing at explaining grammar points we don't understand at first. She also knows that we are busy with other things like JPs and Senior Thesis so you can always ask for extensions on assignments.
its lit
prereqs: JPN 305 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, listening and speaking. Reading materials include novels, essays, etc. Video materials are also used to enhance listening skills. The goal of this course is "advanced" level according to the ACTFL/ETS guidelines.

title: Sociological Theory
reviews: Although this course is a prerequisite for sociology, it is incredibly enriching regardless of one's area of academic interest.  Take this course, attend every lecture, read every assignment, and enjoy!

As someone who is not usually drawn to theoretical courses, I enjoyed this one much more than I expected (I took it as a SOC required course). I had heard that taking a PFK course is an interesting experience, and it certainly was, but I found it to be a very positive one. If you just relax and do not stress to much about grades and just let the learning happen, you will gain so much from this course. She is also very funny and extremely insightful. Overall, would recommend!
Do not take this class unless it's a departmental and you don't have a choice. It was the worst class I've taken here
Don't take it if PFK teaches it
I woudn't take this course unless I had to/I really like PFK's teaching style

I would advise students taking the course to do their utmost to take advantage of the professor's excellent educational skill. While some of her teaching may appear arbitrarily designed, her overall guidance is extremely appropriate and she is admirably skilled at her job.

I would encourage students to keep up with the readings. The readings can be very dense, but failure to keep up with them and with the material being covered will make it very difficult to complete the memos.
I would recommend taking the course.
I wouldn't recommend this course for non-SOC majors, but if you are a SOC major, it's pretty good! PFK is a fun instructor.
If you are a Soc major you have to take it, it you are looking for an interesting Soc class there are plenty of other, more interesting and engaging courses.

If you're not a SOC major, this class can be a relatively straightforward course that allows you to read some major thinkers (Durkheim, Weber, Marx, etc) and to get a general understanding of their contributions and contexts.
Not really necessary to take unless you are a sociology major or intended sociology major. Can be a bit of a drag at points.
One of the least interesting PFK courses I've ever taken. Don't take it if you're not a sociology major. It's alright but I don't see the purpose in it if you're not concentrating in SOC

PFK goes on lots of rants that were only slightly related to the readings, and didn't analyze the readings nearly as much as I would have liked to see. She also has strong opinions that definitely come through her teaching, and shuts people down if they don't agree with her. But, she is intelligent and you will likely learn a lot (granted, you'll learn more from her tangents than you will from the actual readings)
Take it if you have to or have interest in sociological thought.  It's a really solid foundation, but does require some work.
Take it if you have to, otherwise I would pass. There are way more engaging SOC classes even other ones by PFK
Take this course without a second thought!

Unless you have to take this class, do not take it with PFK. She is extremely rude and does not appreciate or respect the opinions of students. She is also extremely biased towards certain students. I did not learn anything that I feel like I can take from this class and did not enjoy any aspect of the course. I would not recommend this class to anyone unless you absolutely need to take it.
if you are soc major you have to take it. if you arent and it sounds interesting you can take it, not much work- midterm and final were both open note take home
ssq
prereqs: SOC 101.
descrip: This course invites you to systematically review foundational texts in sociology. Attention is given to the formulation of concepts, hypotheses, and research methods. We explore social structure and action; change and conflict; norms and roles; social class and stratification; deviance; and the link between micro- and macro-sociology. We also consider phenomena such as modernization, urbanization, migration, industrialization, and global capitalism. Why does theory matter to contemporary politics and policy? These are among the questions we ask.

title: Photographic Imagination, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Reading Literature: Drama
reviews: Boring lectures. Take if you're a theater kid, not if you're into READING LITERATURE as the title FALSELY SUGGESTS.
Do the readings.
Get the readings done on time, and ask the preceptors for help with your papers and exercises.
Good english class for non English majors, very reasonable workload, good plays. Nice class.

I think there are other LAs that are easier and more fun than this one. For me, I thought I would love it as I love watching theatre, but in all honesty it didn't help me understand plays that much better, and it was more work than it could have been.
I think this course is a great choice for those interested in theater acting, writing, and analysis while wanting to learn more about English.
I would advise other students to take this class, but only if they are interested in drama specifically, both reading and watching
I would take it. You can learn a lot. Professor Sandberg is a great professor. The selection of plays is fantastic!

If you can take another English major prerec, I would recommend doing so. This class is fine, but i think there are better ways of fulfilling requirements that give you a better grasp on concepts in english.
If you have time, communicate with your preceptor and professor. I really think I would have done better had I done this.

LOVED this course, all in all. I felt like the workload was consistent but never too overwhelming, the staff and professor always available and personable, the readings engaging, and the subject matter interesting and applicable to anyone interested in dramatic analysis or theater. That said, take this course if you are looking for a good English class -- I highly recommend it!
Read all plays and engage with them to make the most of the class.
Take it, especially if you like theatre, lots of room for interaction.
The course was okay. The plays themselves are interesting, but there's not enough interesting stuff going on in the lectures to make it completely worthwhile.

This is less of a literature course and more of a theater course. Wouldn't recommend for those prospective English majors who enjoyed ENG 200 and would prefer to engage more profoundly with texts. The lectures are disorganized, placing a burden on preceptors to untangle Professor Sandberg's teachings and present them in an understandable, truly analytical manner.

This was an okay course. For ENG majors interested in theatre, it makes sense to take this course as one of your departmentals. It gives you a decent survey of the history of Western drama. There was nothing really inspiring or surprising about Professor Sandberg's lectures, but I do feel like I have a more complete understanding of theatre history?the roots of contemporary conventions. The class is informative, fairly easy, and a little dull at times.
be prepared for lots of readings
descrip: This course is designed to teach students how to read plays as literature written for performance. Key assumptions are that every act of reading is an act of interpretation, that a good reader of dramatic literature engages in an activity nearly identical to that of a good director or actor or designer, and that a reader might learn from theater practitioners how to make critical choices based on close reading and a knowledge of theatre history.

title: Seminar. History of Photography
reviews:
It is rather interesting because you get two different perspectives from both professors, to apply to various photographic material that you actually get to touch and see. 
Prof. McCauley is perhaps a legend for her remarks and comments, but suffer through the pain, and I think you will find you have improved.
Take this class only if you're really interested in this specific topic.

Take this course if you're interested in the topic! Professor McCauley is not as scary as she may seem. Professor Kesson is extremely nice. Both professors are very knowledgeable about what they study.
descrip: Why do we travel and feel obliged to shoot photographs? What do our pictures reveal about our conceptions of ourselves and "exotic" peoples and places? By examining amateur albums and commercial prints in Princeton collections, this course explores how the practices and itineraries of tourists and photographers during the long nineteenth century continue to shape racial and cultural stereotypes today. Case studies consider the French and British in Egypt; Victorian travelers in India; big-game hunters in sub-Saharan Africa; the Caribbean as a vacation destination; and the photographic construction of Native Americans as a "vanishing race."

title: The Undead
reviews: Cool readings and engaging discussion. Also really manageable load. Go for it!
Enjoy the course!
For a 300-level English seminar, this course is not too demanding at all. Professor Chihaya is dope! Take it if the topic interests you.
If you read the description and it sounded interesting to you, you will enjoy this course.

Professor Chihaya is great, but English seminars rely on the students in the class.  If you can take it with other students who will actively participate, the material is fascinating to think and talk about.
Take it especially if interested in the undead from a lot of lenses and not just as a function of the popularity of The Walking Dead.
Take it!
This course is awesome and Prof. Chihaya is so cool. Must take if you're into the topic at all.
descrip: The Undead are everywhere: on movie and television screens, in books, even in the academy. This seminar will explore the literature of the undead beyond commercially successful franchises like True Blood or The Walking Dead, from the 19th C. to the present day. Many questions are raised by these literary revenants: What do the undead do for us? What can they express or represent? How do these texts use the supernatural to address very human (political, historical, social) issues and desires, particularly in regards to postcolonial and minority discourses? Why are the undead so compelling to contemporary writers and readers?

title: Financial Accounting
reviews: Accounting is very useful, so take this course for its content if you need to. However, Prof. Weil makes this experience extremely painful because of his condescending attitude towards students and people.

Accounting is worth learning if you have any interest in working in anything even related to finance. Dr. Weil makes the seminar bearable (even at 8am). Do the problem sets without using the solutions manual.
Do the problem sets without looking at the answers.
Do the readings and try to master the concepts. Professor Weil knows how to distinguish those who understand stuff versus those who dont in his exams.
Don't bother. If you think it's going to prepare you for your internship, think again.
Don't take unless you want a departmental.
Get Balram as your preceptor! Do the practice tests for every test. Don't rely on the option to drop both midterms and have the final count for 90%. Keep up with the material!
Gives you some accounting basics. Not a great course
I would recommend doing all of the problem sets first without looking at the solutions. Use the solutions manual to check your answers.
I would recommend taking accounting because it's really a very applicable subject; but this particular course with Weil is somewhat disorganized, and I find Weil's lecture style off-putting.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in accounting and learning definitions and vocab of different types of financial statements.
If you're thinking about taking this b/c you're going to Wall St, just stick to ECO 362/363. Weil (and the 8am seminar) is not worth your time.

Interesting professor that is very stubborn in doing things his way. Some previous accounting knowledge will help you tremendously in the beginning in easing into the course. This course is very much self-led, and can be largely self-taught.

It's one of the more practical econ courses I've taken. I hated accounting before and ended up actually kind of liking it. Be warned, though: Prof. Weil has a very unique teaching style / personality that isn't for everyone. He tries to be funny but can be pretty offensive and rude to particular students. I actually felt uncomfortable being in lecture sometimes, which is why I stopped going halfway through..
Just.. this class doesn't make a lot of sense. It was weird. I don't recommend you take it with Weil.
Make sure to practice and keep on top of homework.

Take it for a solid foundation in accounting. Lectures, while somewhat entertaining, are not necessary because the textbook is really good. Still, attend more than half so that you know some random facts that he might ask about on the exam.
Take it only if you are interested in learning the concepts of accounting (also, good review of concepts for banking interviews).

This class is one of the very few practical classes offered by the ECO department, but that's pretty much the only good thing about this class. The material is incredibly dull and the professor is quite rude and wastes everyone's time in lecture with cringey jokes, long rants, and unnecessary roleplaying. Nail in the coffin? Losing points on the midterm for not knowing facts about Moby Dick. For an ACCOUNTING class.

This course gives you a solid base of accounting. However, be prepared to do lots of self-studying. Make sure you stay on top of the material, as it build upon itself over the term, and meet with your preceptor early on if there are any confusing concepts.
Undeniably useful if you're going into finance / business. Your worth as an employee ultimately comes down to your impact on a balanced sheet (reductive but fundamentally true)

You get a good intro to accounting if you're trying somewhat hard. The lectures are sort of a waste of time but once he gets to the actual accounting he is pretty helpful. A lot of it is teaching yourself but his assignments and tests are good at helping you do that. You can do well if you put in the work
prereqs: ECO 310.
descrip: The course teaches the judgments required to report on the economic events of a firm and analyzes current events that affect accounting, which is the language of business; you 'll learn the distinction between, e.g., revenue and receipt, the four meanings in financial economics of the word capital, the most misunderstood common term in accounting (Retained Earnings), the most confused word in all of financial economics and business (reserves). Accounting will differ in 10-20 twenty years from accounting today. This course, built on economic foundations, not bookkeeping detail, will equip you to understand the changes that you encounter.

title: Environmental Art: Thinking, Making, Dreaming
descrip: See website

title: American Images
reviews: Attend office hours whenever you can.
DeLue is awesome! Less of an art history class and more of an American history class. Not much work at all - very short readings, interesting lectures, only 2 (short) papers.
Don't have to do all of the readings but definitely attend lecture. It's engaging and most of the material comes from there.
Don't take this course. It represents a flat view of American images. Didn't even explore multiple meanings in the one narrative.

Go to lectures and take notes! GOOD NOTES. Also pay attention and you won't need to study that much for the final. Put images of the paintings in the lecture notes as she talks about them -- it helps a lot.
Go to the lectures, they are very clear.
I would recommend this course! I took it asa distribution requirement and I loved it. DeLue is an amazing lecturer. The material is really interesting and the work load is manageable.
I would strongly recommend the class.
If you enjoy american studies, or enjoy art history, don't take this course. You'll be unsatisfied. There are better courses for american studies, and better courses for art history.

Make sure you attend all lectures and take good notes! The final exam is heavily contingent on what Professor Delue has said about the paintings in class and if you miss that you will have a tough time preparing.
Only take this if you are really interested in art history and like survey courses that cover a lot of material but don't go into that many specific topics in depth.
Professor DeLue is my favorite professor in the Art & Archaeology department! Take this class or any class that she is teaching!
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
Take it
Take it if you interest with Professor DeLue!

Take it! It may seem like a scary 300 level art history course, but it's cross listed with AMS and Prof. DeLue is aware it may be some people's first art history class. Super interesting (think Woodstock) and relevant class!
Take it! Professor DeLue is really engaging, the subject matter is generally very interesting, and the workload completely manageable. One of the best ART classes I've taken.
Take it!!
Take this class if you are interested in knowing more about artistic movements in America from the 1600s to the 2010s. The professor is super passionate and the preceptors want to help you.
Take this class! Fun and consistently interesting.
Take this course! It's interesting and not too challenging as long as you attend lectures and participate in precept. Half of the precepts are in the art museum, which is great!

Take this course!!! Professor DeLue is a delightful lecturer and makes all of the material incredibly fascinating. The assignments are interesting and fair. Get to know Professor DeLue if you can - she's awesome!!!
Take this course. I learned a lot about American art history, something I did not know much about. Also, the material is pretty interesting.
Take this!
This is a good class to take. Not too much work, and readings aren't really necessary. Lectures are engaging. No previous art experience needed.
This is a great class. Professor DeLue is awesome! I didn't know anything about art history and it was totally accessible and really fun!
This was one of my favorite art history classes. Prof. DeLue is very knowledgeable in the topic, and lectures were phenomenal. Workload is very light, and the final exam is simple. Highly recommend!
