Took it as my first art class at Princeton. DeLue is fantastic and it was an excellent introduction, but still had a lot to offer for friends of mine that know a lot about American art. Lectures are awesome; assignments are fun. Take the class!
Try to draw connections between the readings and the artwork, and to look up historical context of paintings.
attend lecture
class covers interesting material and professor delue does a good job of presenting historical and social contexts for artworks. interesting readings and productive precepts.
do the readings
more of a history course than an art course
descrip: This course examines America through the lens of its images. Pictures created by Americans of all stripes in all periods have been integral to the shaping of American history, culture, and identity. By examining a wide range of image types--from the fine arts and photography to the built environment, scientific illustration, film, and digital media--and by considering these images in terms of their historical, political, social, intellectual, and global contexts, "American Images" will offer both a sweeping and a detailed portrait of America through the rich, sometimes strange history of its art and visual culture.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
descrip: Methods, sources, and problems of research in Chinese thought, including examination of some broad interpretations of intellectual development of China. A reading knowledge of Chinese or Japanese is required for the study of selected problems areas through seminar discussion, oral reports, and research papers.

title: Poetics - 19thC English and American Poetry: New Tools, New Archives
descrip: Histories of 19th-C poetry are generally keyed to books and anthologies--breakthrough volumes, collected works, and influential collections. Yet a great deal of this poetry was printed in or supported by the circulation of periodicals, creating dynamic poetic cultures that were provisional, collaborative, and transatlantic. In this course we tackle head-on what the new availability of these resources means for the study of British and American poetry. How might the digitization of magazines, newspapers, and print ephemera change canonical literary histories?

title: Topics in Number Theory and Related Analysis - Integer points on affine varieties
prereqs: For advanced level undergraduates and graduate students..
descrip: We discuss some basic problems and applications of strong approximation for integer points on affine varieties. We spend some time on some of the classical tools to address such problems such as the circle method and then turn to more recent and special techniques connected with the action of groups of affine morphisms.

title: Qualitative Methods and International Relations
descrip: The seminar focuses on selected topics in international security that have not been sufficiently covered in other courses and seminars offered by the department. These include topics such as power, military effectiveness, signaling and interstate communication, beliefs and emotions, the role of reputation etc. Each session, the group will discuss the evolution in a particular body of literature in the field, while placing the emphasis on issues such as conceptualization and measurement of key variables, case selection criteria, research strategy and execution.

title: Studies in Chinese Religions - Buddhism and Daoism
descrip: Survey of recent scholarship in the field, focusing on the schools of Chinese Buddhism, Tantric Buddhism, Buddhism and empire, and interactions between Buddhism and Daoism. Readings primarily in English. Especially for students preparing for general exams in the field of Chinese Religions.

title: Risk Analysis
reviews: Adam is a great TA and extremely helpful! Definitely take this class.
As an ORF major, the material is a repeat of ORF 309, and thus it is a easy departmental in terms of content. The course is a decent time commitment, however, so be ready for that.
Basically most ORFE students. Don't lose point on HW would be my advice.
Easy ORF distribution, but at the same time really helped me master concepts in probability. Adam, TA, is awesome. Lecture attendance counts towards participation grade

If you are at all interested in modeling, whether from an environmental risk standpoint or finance background, you should definitely take this course. I would try to get a head start on the final project (but even if you don't, you'll have some time during Reading Period). It is a lighter work load but a lot of skill gained. A good return on your investment!!

If you're a CEE student, you should take this course, as you will learn a lot (way more than the ORF kids taking it.) But beware that most of the class knows more than you on the subject, since although ORF 309 is not a prereq, most people taking this class have taken 309. Still worth it, but keep in mind that you'll be working a lot harder than the rest of the class.
Overall, course is very rigorous and technical. A lot is covered, as such, one should learn a substantial amount if this is their first applied stats course.
Take it for a general overview of ORFE for non ORFE majors. Fairly easy course, but can still learn lots.
Take this course if you are an ORFE Major
This is a great course for "applied statistics". Go to lectures, read the textbook, and don't be afraid to ask the TA for help.

This is a low-workload course that could be taken in a five class semester.  It's graded against 1/2 cee students and 1/2 orfe students, so the curve is a little on the more difficult side.  There's a bit of programming in R, which is cool.  The material will generally be a repeat of orf 309 / orf 245 though.

While I enjoyed this course, it is a fair amount of work so and has pretty inflexible requirements, so I don't recommend taking it unless it is applicable to your research. Also make sure to prepare well for the midterm by doing all the practice problems over again, as it is a large portion of the grade, and has a lot of problems in a short period of time, so unless you are well practiced it is easy to mess it up.
prereqs: Basic probability and statistics course..
descrip: Fundamentals of probabilistic risk analysis. Stochastic modeling of hazards. Estimation of extremes. Vulnerability modeling of natural and built environment. Evaluation of failure chances and consequences. Reliability analysis. Decision analysis and risk management. Case studies involving natural hazards, including earthquakes, extreme winds, rainfall flooding, storm surges, hurricanes, and climate change, and their induced damage and economic losses.

title: Enzymes
reviews: A solid intro to the very important topic of enzymology. Not too much time commitment, but can be a little boring at times.
Attend all lectures and you will be fine.
Attend all of the lectures!  Link's lectures are good and the notes he writes on the board are super helpful.  If you're interested in enzymes, I recommend the class.
Attend classes!
Best class I have taken.  Prof. Link is awesome, his lectures are awesome, and the subject matter is awesome anyway.
Definitely take it if you're interested in enzymes, even if you have little background!
Good engineering class for MOL students. Taught well.
Great class!
I would advise anyone interested to take the course.
I'd recommend it. Pay attention in class.

It's a good course. If you are MolBio taking this course, it would be good to review the beginning of biochem--especially Michaelis Menton. It will be reviewed in class, but if you don't want to feel lost, reviewing some Biochem can help.

It's a new course, so there weren't previous practice exams/practice problem sets to work with, but the material is interesting and very relevant if you're interested in proteins, enzymes, biochemistry, etc.
Take it if you are interested in protein structural biology and chemistry. You learn a lot about the frontiers of enzymology.
Take it!
Take this course! Link is a great professor.

This is a great class! Definitely take it if you're looking for a chill yet interesting higher level CBE course. Professor Link has had a lot of teaching experience and is great at explaining concepts clearly!
Work really hard on the final paper!
prereqs: Familiarity with biochemistry at the level of MOL 214/215 will be assumed..
descrip: Enzymes are the engines that fuel life, catalyzing a vast array of different chemical reactions. This course will focus first on enzyme kinetics and the structural biology of enzymes. With these tools we will next move to a series of case studies about different enzymes and enzyme families.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: Great class to take if even remotely interested in creative writing. People actually care during the workshops and will provide great feedback. What you put in is what you get out, though; the more effort you put into writing and critiquing others' work, the more meaningful the class will be.
Great class. Prof McGrath is awesome, supportive but with plenty of suggestions. Put in as much time as you can into your stories.
I enjoyed this course, but wish there were more assignments that were shorter in length so we could get more feedback.

If you have the opportunity to take this course, absolutely take it. Professor Lahiri is incredible. There's really no way to describe it; you need to experience it for yourself. At the same time, you need to put in effort to get anything out of this course. Don't slack off--it's PDF, but you still should do all of the readings and put real effort into the writing assignments. After all, you're being taught by a Pulitzer Prize winner and one of the best writers of her generation.

My main issue with Professor Eugenides was the way he allowed personal bias to affect his evaluation of students' work. I received more useful feedback from the other students in my class than I did from him on my second piece, due to the fact that he completely missed the point of the story -- most likely because he had already decided that I was a bad student who didn't put effort into my writing. I would recommend taking fiction with one of the other wonderful educators here, who will almost certainly provide more valuable and more constructive comments on your work.
Of course I'd recommend this course! You might get a less chummy workshop than I did, but the chance to take a class with Eugenides totally off-sets that potential negative.
Prepare for Italian writers and Turin with Jhumpa, but as she seems to not be teaching advanced fiction next semester, you should be fine.
Professor Lahiri is AMAZING, TAKE IT
Professor Lahiri is somewhat intimidating and she can be quite harsh. But if you can deal with that, then you'll learn a lot from her.
Take any CWR class if you can--if you're in fiction, McGrath makes a fantastic professor.
Take it because it's Jhumpa. But don't expect anything mind-blowing
Take it if you want to further develop your creative writing skills.
Take it!
Take this! Professor Lahiri is an incredible writer and a kind instructor.

This course is great. It is definitely faster-paced and generally with more serious writing than the intro creative writing courses, but it is well-taught and the overall higher level of writing is really conducive to improving your writing. :D
Workshops are helpful. Professor Lahiri is not particularly inspiring, but she does occasionally provide useful insights and readings.
great course - Prof eugenides is awesome!
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level fiction courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website (arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app) for application information. Application deadline is November 22, 2015..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of fiction for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Intellectual History of China from the Ninth to the 19th Century
reviews: Absolutely take it! The best seminar I have taken at Princeton. It is about how society shapes the ideas and how ideas in turn transform society. If you are interested in Chinese history or speak Chinese, this is the class fro you. Prof Peterson talks, explains, facilitates discussion, and answers questions like no other professor on campus. He can unpack the most complex historical period or the most abstract metaphysical concept in simple comprehensible words. This class will give you a framework to wrestle with important questions not only in Chinese intellectual history, but also in modern day discussions on the source of knowledge, political authority, moral conduct, individuality, etc. If you speak Chinese, it will be a plus as you can read the original works but you won't be disadvantaged in any way if you don't. Surprisingly, the course material is very relevant to modern life. We had nice discussion on artificial intelligence, US constitution, etc.

Definitely recommend, especially for students who want to enrich their knowledge of East Asian culture and philosophy. It does help to know or have taken classes in Chinese, but most certainly not a requirement in terms of understanding the material.

Do all the readings carefully, don't skim things because the material is difficult to understand and you have to fully read it before discussion in class. TAKE THIS CLASS!! Professor Peterson is amazing, and a very gentle but knowledgeable and critical professor. You will learn a lot in this class.
Take the time to do the readings carefully and take notes on them;

This is an excellent course about Chinese philosophy and statesmanship. It is challenging but not particularly hard. The readings are very interesting and not too much, if you spend three hours a week you can actually do them quite comprehensively and feel good in class and for the papers. The course is relevant even for today and you should take it if you are interested in the Chinese worldview and disputes around it.
prereqs: A prior course in East Asian Studies is desirable but not required..
descrip: The course centers on the changing role of the intellectual elite -- how they were recruited, their relationship to holders of powers, their attitudes toward the past and their cultural heritage. The aim of the course is to provide a clearer understanding of the burdens and privileges of intellectuals in Chinese society.

title: Beginner's Greek: Attic Prose
prereqs: CLG 101 or Permission Of Instructor. Greek 101-102 are a unit. Greek 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. Greek 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year a selection of short Attic prose will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: Be sure you stay in contact with the lab assistants. I failed to do that and so they were not aware of the work I was doing with my partner.
It's a good way to force yourself each week to spend a bit of time building stuff. I wouldn't recommend doing a project alone.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Religion and Ethical Theory
descrip: This seminar is a critical examination of selected philosophers who have, since the publication of Anscombe's "Modern Moral Philosophy" in 1958, challenged ethical theory for its preoccupation with moral quandaries and its relatively sparse attention to religion, virtue, and historical change.

title: Conceptions of the Sensory
descrip: In-depth discussion and analysis of conceptions of the sensory in writings by philosophers, poets, art critics and theorists, and artists, from the early modern to contemporary periods. We will investigate the ways in which the sensory is understood as the necessary basis for conceptual thinking of diverse kinds, including systematic and dialectical philosophy (Kant and Hegel), sign theory (Saussure), imaginative and figural writing, and theory and practice of the plastic arts (Rilke, Mallarme, Adorno, Greenberg, Serra, Stella, Scully, Buchloh, Warhol, among others).

title: The Soviet Empire and Successor States
reviews: A very rigorous introduction to the Soviet Union and in some respects to the practice of history in general. It is overwhelming but entirely worthwhile.

Even if you are not a history graduate student (and I do think this grad-level course should not be taken by undergrads), consider seriously taking this course. It will stretch you in ways you cannot imagine, from learning that you can in fact read as much as he asks to thinking about the world in a whole new way.

If you're willing to do the readings, and willing to be challenged, take the course.  You won't regret being in the same classroom as Professor Kotkin.  It goes without saying, but conversely, this is not a course you can "skate by" on.   You've got to work hard at it and be willing to participate, even if you're not completely  sure of every concept.
Take the course. But be invested. The course can consume your entire semester, so you need to be disciplined. But Kotkin will blow your mind every single week.
This course is extraordinarily good, but, be advised, it is also a lot of work.
descrip: This seminar covers the history of the Soviet Union from inception until dissolution and slightly beyond. The readings are exhaustive and comprehensive, with particular attention paid to institutions, empire, the cultural foundations of politics, and the world context.

title: Financial Modelling
prereqs: ECO 525/FIN 525 and ECO 526/FIN 526 (526 may be taken concurrently)..
descrip: Advanced asset pricing and corporate finance including a selection from: models of financial crises and bubbles; interaction between finance and macroeconomics, derivative pricing in incomplete markets; tests of asset pricing models and associated anomalies; models of investor behavior; financial econometrics, including tests of asset pricing models and methods for high frequency data. Pre-requisites: ECO 525 and 526 (526 may be taken concurrently).

title: Modern Political Theory
reviews: 100% take this course. It can be heavy on the readings, but raises really interesting questions. Prof Stilz and Prof Beitz are both amazing lecturers, you will never be bored.
Don' take the course with Stilz, lectures are informative but very very dry in what could be a super interesting class.
Great way to be introduced to great political writings. do the readings
I recommend this course to students with an interest in modern political theory (particularly classical liberalism).

I recommend you set aside a large amount of time for the readings. Even though there are usually only 125-150 pages a week, I found that trying to skim them is a complete waste of time. An in depth read is critical to taking anything away from the reading.  Personally however, I found this rather easy to do, because I found the readings fascinating.

Overall a very interesting class. I was not someone who had studied political theory before, and I feel I learned a lot of valuable information. A good class for PDF if you are not confident about the material and do not want too much of a workload. Nonetheless, it was a great class.

POL303 is an intimidating politics course for students (freshmen especially) with no background in political theory. The reading is dense, difficult and slow and I truthfully hated POL303 when buried under political theory readings and papers. Professor Stilz does a great job of summarizing the readings and discussing critiques (but the lectures should not replace the readings), but her lecture style is not engaging. Be prepared to do formal preparation for precept, students are excepted to participate with specific citations to the text. Ben is a fabulous preceptor, and goes out of his way to work with students in the writing of essays (office hours, one-on-ones, emails) and the clarification of concepts. Paper grading is very fair.
Take course! Texts are amazing and instruction is really strong. I got a lot out of both reading and going to lecture. Hard but in the end depends on how much thought you put into the class.
Take it if interested in political theory.
Take notes on the readings. Extremely helpful for papers.
Take the class with Professor Stilz! Also, if you think this sounds interesting, take it, but know that there is a lot of dense reading.
Take the course. It's not going to kill you, but you'll have to actually do the readings.

Take this class! The readings have such an impact on politics in the past few centuries, and it would be a shame not to take advantage of the opportunity to learn about them with such a bright guide as Professor Stilz.
This course is really important to any students who are interested in political theory!
descrip: This course offers an overview of classic texts in modern political theory, focusing on the social contract tradition. Readings include selections from Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Mill, Marx, and Rawls.

title: Children's Literature
reviews: A fantastic course, engaging readings, great lectures.
A great class to take.
A very fun class! Definitely go to lectures. Reviewing the lectures will not only help a lot with the final, but the lectures were always super fun!
Absolutely take this course. You will not regret it! It is one of the best lecturers on this campus with some of the best material!
Actually do the readings. They're fun, and not too long.
Amazing class. Take it if you can.

As a science major, I found this course so incredibly rewarding! Professor Gleason is an outstanding lecturer and this is probably the only large lecture class I've ever taken where I felt engaged with the material everyday, because he is very prepared and enthusiastic. There's a lot of inconsistency across the grading of papers in the precepts, though, so try to get someone relatively more chill (I got a really strict/hard grader so my grade for the class was a little embarrassingly low).
Attend lectures because they are fun
Bill is a great preceptor. Jay Kim should take this course.
Books are great and papers are reasonable.
Children's Literature, despite its massive size, is well-run and entertaining. One of the most, if not THE most, accessible ENG courses for non-humanities majors.
Chill out, go to lecture, enjoy it, do the readings.
Def take it! There is absolutely no reason not to. It's not much work and it's interesting.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take it. You won't regret it.
Definitely take the course, definitely go to lectures, and obviously do the readings because they are so much fun.
Definitely take this class! The readings are fun and nostalgic, and Prof. Gleason is an amazing lecturer.
Definitely take this class.
Definitely take this if you have the chance, whatever your major/background. Gleason is amazing!

Definitely wait to take this until Senior year if you can. It's perfect to PDF during thesis crunch time. It's even easier if you do the reading which is usually pretty fun to do anyway, but you don't have to do much of it to get by.

Do NOT take the final exam lightly, do all the readings and study with friends for the exam so you can draw upon each other's knowledge and cover any gaps in understanding you might have!. Reach out for help with the essays
Do not save the readings for the last minute

Do not take this class.  Yes, if you want a class with little to no work this may seem to fit the bill, but you won't learn anything.  Take a class where you will be challenged and actually learn something from the experience.
Do the readings! You'll get more out of lecture. Also attend every lecture - Gleason is amazing!
Don't see all the hype tbh. Gleason is a pretty weird lecturer, but I guess it's an easy PDF. 6/10.

Great PDF.

Harder than it seems!
Honestly probably not as easy to get an A as you might expect but probably the best course at Princeton. Take it if you want to be happy for the rest of your days. Prof Gleason is amazing
I would advise future students to take advantage of the opportunity to revisit the crowned jewels of children's literature and analyzed them at a college level.

It is also a great way to finish off senior year by taking this class; it allows you to reflect on how far we have come academically, and it really makes you think about the influence literature has on kids, especially at a young age.

In the top three for my favorite classes at Princeton. The readings each week are fun and engaging (HARRY POTTER!!! The Giver!) and don't take a crazy amount of time. Honestly I spent more time reveling in the nostalgia of having to read my favorite childhood books as REQUIRED READING for this class. The assignments are short essays that are interesting to write, though grading may not be as easy as you expect - people always say that this is a great class to PDF but you'll definitely have to put in extra work if you want an A. That being said, getting an A /A  is completely doable if you put in a little extra thought and go to office hours if you're unsure about anything (via the essays as a CS major) . We'll see how the final exam goes. Overall an awesome awesome class. Take it!!!
It's a great course if you want a break from the typical Princeton courses. The readings are always interesting and fun to do, and the lectures were consistently great.
It's a lot of fun!
Just do the readings and listen to Prof. Gleason! You won't regret it!
Just take it! Wonderful class, engaging professor, and fun reading!

Obviously, this is a popular course for a reason. The books are fun to read (it doesn't even feel like homework!) and the course is extremely well-organized. You'll not only be impressed by Professor Gleason's lectures, but also by his incredible lecture slides and Blackboard site.

Professor Gleason is AWESOME! Definitely take this course- fun and interesting.
Professor Gleason is an amazing lecturer! If you have the chance take the course. As an engineer this was by far my favorite class outside my department.

Professor Gleason is one of the best lecturers and you won't regret taking this course. Be warned that there is a decent amount of work that you have to do although the readings are usually not that long. If you enjoy children's literature at all, you will really enjoy this course.

Relatively easy class (although it's not a joke at all), and the lectures are consistently entertaining. The books also get a lot better toward the end of the semester. I don't feel like I learned too much in general from the course, but it was a nice, light, entertaining class.
TAKE IT
TAKE IT! You won't regret it - truly. It's one of those courses that you HAVE to take before you graduate - it's that good.
TAKE THIS CLASS. You won't regret it - lectures and reading are great.

TAKE. A fun course, and it will be a cinch if you elect to receive your grade on a P/D/F basis. I had planned to do this but enjoyed it so much that I took it for a grade. The grading is typical of an English department course, which means it's serious and those looking to get an A will need to be exceptional paper writers. But it's worth it, and there are only three papers, all of them relatively short (750-1000 words, 5-7 pages, 5-7 pages, respectively). You also have the option of doing a digital humanities paper and data organization for the second assignment (and maybe also the third). Melanie is a good preceptor whom I would recommend. Prof. Gleason is an extraordinary lecturer and you should get to know him outside of class.
THIS COURSE IS AMAZING. Even better than I'd expected after hearing rave reviews for 4 years.

Take it senior year.

Take it! Best class I've ever taken. You get to read children's books, write papers on them, and the secondary readings are interesting
Take it! Gleason is an excellent, engaging lecturer. It's a great PDF course, especially for senior spring.
Take it! Great for PDFing, and I hear it's alright for taking for a grade, but may be difficult to get a solid A in.
Take it! It's great!  Lucy was a great preceptor.  Readings were fantastic, papers were easy and you have  a lot of freedom to write about whatever you want!

Take it, sure! Make sure you still have some interest. Also, there's a decent amount of reading and it's not all picture books and Cat in the Hat. Nice LA.

Take notes on the secondary sources; this will save a lot of time when it comes time to the final which includes an ID section and sections where engaging with secondary sources could be helpful.

Take this course!
Take this course! Very fun and interesting.
Take this course!!! Best decision of my Princeton career.

Take this course!!! You do not necessarily have to thoroughly read all of the books, but definitely choose a book to read thoroughly and analyze it to pieces. Go to all the lectures, because they are entertaining and super interesting! Work hard on your papers and besides that, the course load does not feel heavy.

This is a great course to take. The readings were really engaging and the analysis of the readings made me reexamine the stories from my youth. I would definitely recommend this class!
This is a great course. It's not particularly difficult to do well for grade or for PDF. Go to the lectures and enjoy reading the books, especially the ones that you haven't read before.

descrip: A survey of classic texts written for children from the past 200 years in (primarily) England and America. We will examine the development and range of the genre from early alphabet books to recent young adult fiction. We'll try to put ourselves in the position of young readers while also studying the works as adult interpreters, asking such questions as: How do stories written for children reflect and shape the lives of their readers? What can children's literature tell us about the history of reading, or of growing up, or of the imagination itself? In the process we will consider psychological and social questions as well as literary ones.

title: Rituals of Governing
reviews: I would tell students considering taking this course to definitely do the readings, because they are all so interesting!
Read the material. Most classes do not have such engaging readings.

Very, very interesting subject matter delivered in a laid-back and manageable format.  Professor Coyle allows you to collapse the midterm and final papers into one term paper that is only slightly longer, so you can go through the entire semester until reading period without generating content if you choose.  On the other hand, the readings are so thought-provoking and have such wide implications that participating more heavily is also easy to do.
descrip: The spiritual and the sacred hold enduring significance across many central realms of political and social life. Anthropological studies productively unsettle standard assumptions in many aspects of Western thought, which often presume the declining importance of religion and spirituality in political life. This course draws upon classic and contemporary anthropological works on a range of topics concerning cultures of governing, including ritual theory, divine rule, stranger-kings, witchcraft and magic, spirituality and embodiment, and law. Secondarily, the course engages materials from film, psychoanalysis, literature, and critical theory.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy: Applications: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: WWS 507B.
descrip: Provides hands-on experience in the application of econometric methods to policy issues. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable hypotheses, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. The course will be taught using a set of cases in which students apply quantitative methods covered in WWS 507b to data in order to answer specific policy questions. Emphasis will be placed on interpreting and writing about results.

title: Elementary Korean II
reviews: Great continuation of KOR101.

If you're interested in Korean, take this class. The instructors are so thoughtful and really care how you do in the class. They're also just really fun (and funny!). Korean class was definitely a bright spot in my day.
Make sure you keep on top of things! Don't underestimate the vocab and lesson quizzes.
Take this class! It's fun and makes you learn a lot.
Take this course!
prereqs: KOR 101 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 101. Continued development of proficiency in basic communication.

title: Introduction to English Literature: 14th to 18th Century
reviews: Attend lectures and keep up with the reading or it can really pile up!

Do not take this course unless you need it as a requirement for English. The readings are interesting and cover a good range, but unfortunately the lectures with Professor Smith and Professor Gee are not super engaging or organized.
Do the readings ahead of time if you can. Don't fall behind. It gets very hard to catch up.

English majors: Best not to think as "something to get through"
Non-English majors: there are better, easier English courses out there; take a seminar
I would definitely recommend! We read amazing works of literature

If you like English, especially English poetry, this class will offer interesting perspectives on authors that you may normally not have read. I found the lectures engaging. But, if you don't think you would like reading these books, this class might not be worth all the reading it entails.
It's hard, but with work you should be able to get a B /A-. This is also coming from a non-English major.
It's not as bad as everyone says it to be, the books are interesting
Keep up with the readings - it'll help you understand and be more engaged during lectures.
Make sure you do all of the readings, because that will be tested on the final, and you will also enjoy reading them.

Not a class for people who don't want to major in English. If you do, it's great because the professors show you things you never would've picked up on your own and you grow as a literary critic. Prepare for the final exam two weeks in advance because it's a lot of memorization.

Overall a good course, straightforward and workload is not difficult. Would not recommend if you are only taking this as a distribution requirement--early British lit can get rather cumbersome at times.
Professor Gee is an excellent lecturer and a brilliant teacher. Try to get into her precept!!

So, the bad news is...this class isn't the greatest literature class you could take and I'd probably recommend against it if you're not going to be an English major and need to take it for the prerequisite. It's not very engaging and it's hard to feel motivated to go to lectures to be quite honest, out of fear that many bad and unsubstantial lectures will sour the taste of some actually very good books for you.  However, there is the good news...which is that, if you seek to improve and make the effort to, this class will develop and perfect your close-reading skills.  True this class doesn't really focus on what authors are seeking to say/convey, which is some of what reading and analyzing literature is all about, but it does help you to look at words/lines/stanzas very closely and think about the use of language in the text. So, truth be told, although I probably wouldn't take this class again, I was glad at the end of the course when I saw some concrete improvement in my papers and close reading skills.
Sophie's lectures are really the only one's that matter. Prepare to do a lot of reading. The amount of written assignments is extremely manageable.
Take it and declare English.

Take this course if you are interested in majoring in English. It probably won't reveal as much about the concentration as a smaller seminar, but it is still interesting and worth taking. There is not too much work besides the readings.

Take this course if you even remotely are considering being an English major! In my case, I really enjoyed the class because I was taking it with a lot of my friends and ended up being in the same precept with them, so it was really fun. I do admit that the class has poor ratings and whatnot, but give it a chance! Even if you don't end up liking this course, do not let it dissuade you from the English Department. It's one hell of a powerhouse!

Take this course if you're declaring English. It gives you the insight you need to know how to successfully be an English major and forces you to read all those books you should read to be a decent member of society.
Think carefully before taking it if you're not an English major, it is not designed for fun times but for making you a more serious writer
This is a great class if you're interested in classic English literature. Great professors. Required for an English major.
Unless you need it as a pre requisite, take this course only if you're interested in the reading and can self motivate to work through challenging literature.

You have to take it if you want to be an English major. STILL, with that being said, this class made me think on a completely new level when it came to reading. Do the readings, or as much as you can. Try to get Sophie Gee if she's still teaching it. She'll kick your butt the first few precepts, but by the end you'll write at a much more advanced level. By the last paper, you should be dropping As like no problem.
You have to take it so take it LOL. You don't have to go to lecture. Peace out!
prereqs: First-year students welcome. English 200 is a prerequisite for entrance into the Department of English..
descrip: An introduction to the leading figures of earlier English Literature, including Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, Milton, Pope, and Swift; to literary history as a mode of inquiry; and to some of the questions that preoccupy English poetry, prose, and drama across four centuries: art, beauty, romance, desire, the will, the mind, God, sex, and death.

title: World Drama
descrip: This course is a survey of classical and modern drama from Africa, China, India, Japan, and Latin America. Topics will include Noh and Kabuki, Beijing Opera, Sanskrit theater, Nigerian masquerades and a variety of selections from the rich modern Indian and Latin American canons. There may be trips to NYC or locally to see new theater works.

title: Organic Chemistry II: Foundations of Chemical Reactivity and Synthesis
reviews: About the same difficulty as first semester, so take it if you don't mind more exams
Always go to lecture and never give up.
CHM 304 is far better than 304B! If it fits your schedule, take it. Infinitely more interesting than first semester. Even if you're not pre-med or a chemistry major, I would definitely recommend.
Definitely take this over 304b. Sorenson and Knowles are both amazing and really make you excited about chemistry. The problem sets are also very helpful so definitely do them before the exams.
Do all the practice exams!

Do the work. Put in the work. Give in the work. The lecture notes you get for the day, once you get back into your room, review those days notes. Don't put it off. It'll just take 30-60 min just reviewing  the notes and understanding the concepts.

For any student that wishes to take this class, I advise that they be prepared to stay focused and consistent in their studies. This means not only coming to class on time, but also practicing through problems to get a better grasp on organic chemistry. One should always try to keep their head in the game by not just learning the individual concepts of certain reactions and reagents. They should also practice their mechanisms and study in their spare time if they want to succeed in this class. This will also help any student get the most out of the class.

For this class, lectures seem more essential than they did for 303. At least I got away with attending lectures and not looking at the online notes afterwards. Past exam papers are so useful in studying for the exams. If you're thinking about deciding between 304 and 304B, from what I've heard it seems that 304B covers more or less similar material except with biological applications, so how a protein with specific functional groups will interact with specific chemicals. If that interests you more, then maybe take that over 304 (that is if timetabling allows it). Otherwise, you might see how you like a new lecture style. It's very different from Semmelhack's 303 lecture style, and I was more engage.

Given the choice of Semmlehack and Sorenson/Knowles, I would pick Sorenson a hundred times over. BUT that is because my learning style was better met by the Sorenson/Knowles method. 
I would recommend enrolling in both courses come spring and then drop whichever one you don't like. 
Semmlehack covers A LOT more material then Sorenson/Knowles, and as you will know from fall, goes really quickly through it all. Sorenson/Knowles will skip certain things to ensure that students have a better understanding of the material. They are interactive and if you don't hide behind your ego/fear, are very open to in-lecture questions
Do NOT buy the book. Either semester tbh. You will never use the textbook or the modeling kit or the solutions manual. Use that 200$ on coffee for all the late nights and a couple bottles of tequila to celebrate the end of this torturous sequence come May. 
If you need extra help, email them to set up a time to meet. They are super accommodating about that. If you are scared of award-winning profs, the preceptors are also super helpful and willing to meet on weekends too.
Don't let the no-open note thing scare you. You get 2 pages of notes PLUS all of your lab stuff. It is more than enough (think about it-how much of your three pounds of crap did you really use during CHM 303 exams?). Sorenson/Knowles teaches you the material ina  way that you don't need all your notes because you actually really understand it. 

I am a non-science pre-med, I was terrified of orgo before starting it, but it has grown into one of my favorite classes at Princeton. It was hard and grueling and I probably cried myself to sleep once or twice because of the stress from this class, but hell it was all worth it when I realized how  much I ACTUALLY learned. 

PSA: Don't take this for fun. You will be hated for ruining the curve and the ghosts of pre-meds past will come to destroy you.

Go to every lecture. Not only is the material presented important, lecture is also nearly always very interesting. Do the problem sets and learn the material presented every week. Don't wait until the exams, otherwise the material will catch up to you. Good luck!

Go to lectures, you may think oh I can just skip and learn it later, but honestly lecture is the best place to learn. If you attend all the lectures and pay attention carefully, you won't have to study as much for the exam. The professors are amazing!

I highly recommend taking CHM304 over CHM304b. I had a great experience all semester with the TAs. The lectures, and the given lecture notes, are extremely useful and clear and definitely prepare for the exams.

I loved this course and would highly recommend it to anyone taking it. Rob and Erik are amazing professors, and Henry is always a blessing in the lab. The exams were always extremely fair, and if you study just for a little bit everyday, the class is extremely manageable, and even fun.

I would advise students taking this course to, quite simply, give it the time it takes. With enough practice, things begin to make sense, and success in this course is primarily dependent on doing the work and doing it well.

If you need orgo for your department/because you're a premed, definitely take this class! Semmelhack's class was straightforward, but Sorensen/Knowles' lectures are way more fun and easy to follow. Prof. Sorensen's love for the subject really shines through, and listening to him talk about orgo always cheers me up. Plus, Sorensen/Knowles' banter with Henry is always entertaining!  For premeds worried about whether this class will cover all the bio-related chemistry that you need to know, I took biochem concurrently and this class definitely covered all the things I needed. 

Also, if Jesus Estrada is precepting again, try to get into his precept. He's super enthusiastic and fun, he explains all the mechanisms well, and he also makes sure that working on the problem sets in groups is engaging and collaborative. 

Overall, awesome lectures   a really fun precept were what made this class my favorite of the semester.

If you want to learn take this class. If you want to get a good grade take Semmelhack beacuse it is more organized and straightforward with how the grading works. Sorensen/Knowles are fantastic lecturers, but you will not do as well.

If you're gonna take it you're probably required, but know that Professor Sorensen is so much better than Professor Semmelhack, in all aspects. I love this class way more than 303, and the material is exponentially much more interesting.
If you're not pre-med/don't have to take this, don't :/ Significantly harder than first semester orgo.
Just put in the work - it's easy to fall behind in this class, but if you keep on top of the notes, you will be fine!
Make use of office hours with professors and preceptors, they are so so helpful and kind!

McGraw tutors are not too helpful. A lot the students are "naturals". So, it would be more helpful to get help from people who had to learn how to learn. You're better off meeting with the professors or preceptors. Focus on the problem sets. I would recommend going through each posted lecture and actively going through them. Work through the problems as you go. Compile a list of questions at the end of every week and get them answered ASAP.
Only take if you have to.

PLEASE take this course! Professor Sorensen and Professor Knowles are both amazing lecturers! I have never had two professors who are both so passionate about a subject. Hands down, this is the best course I have taken at Princeton.
Put in work consistently, don't cram. It's a hard course but you learn so much.

Read over the notes before/after every lecture. Don't get behind. Sorenson and Knowles are excellent lecturers, but no matter which course you take this content is more difficult than last semester's. Stay on top of things!
Review lecture notes a couple times a week and do a lot of practice problems.
Sorensen is so much better than Marty it isn't even funny. I felt like I learned a lot in this class. I also benefitted a lot from the relative lack of premed students in this class.
Sorenson is amazing, Knowles is amazing, take this over 304B no matter what.
Surprisingly interesting class despite it's reputation. Sorensen and Knowles are great lecturers. If you work hard you can definitely do well.
Take CHM 304! Sorensen and Knowles were amazing lecturers, and you'll learn a lot.
Take Sorensen's class. Just trust me.
Take Sorrenson! He's so funny!
Take it! So glad I chose to take 304 on all fronts. It's challenging, but doable, and honestly enjoyable.

Take organic chemistry with Professors Sorensen and Knowles. They WILL change your life; Erik's incredible enthusiasm and passion for organic chemistry, coupled with Rob's beautiful and amusing delivery of topics and jokes about bugs and drugs, makes for an incredible semester. Do read Erik's lecture notes, as the Sorrell textbook is not very helpful for the course, and try your best to not fall more than a week behind at any given time during the semester. Also, Henry's interactions with the professors are incredibly entertaining. You're going to love this course, along with all of the E1CB mechanisms that come with it!
Take this instead of Semmelhack! Best decision ever
The final exam is the only real exam that matters. If you aren't consistently getting low-mid 90's on your midterms, you shouldn't try on the midterms.
This course is a lot better than last semester with Semmelhack. Make sure to go to all office hours available and bring questions from practice exams. Do all the practice exams completely.

This course is not a lot of work with very fair exams. Pretty easy to be honest as long as you pay attention and make sure you understand. Take it as the material is extremely interesting and you'll learn how to synthesize things!

This is as good as orgo gets. Lectures are fun and interesting!  Study a lot and stay on top of it--don't let one test slide even though they drop one.  This course accelerates in learning pace throughout the term.
Try to keep up but don't take unless you have to, exams are pretty brutal and often
Unless Professor Semmelhack's way of teaching really suited you last semester, I would suggest taking this class!
Use Sorenson's notes and do the practice exams.
Very rigorous, only take it if you are required to.
You will probably take this because you have to. Sorenson will make you enjoy it a bit! That's all you can really ask for!

You're going to have to choose 304B or 304 based on your schedule, most likely. Don't sweat the differences. Both are hard in different ways. It's a pre-med heavy class. Prepare yourself for one of the worst experiences at Princeton... okay maybe not that bad. But if you fall behind, things will not be pretty
it's hard
very difficult!
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303.
descrip: This course begins by discussing the chemical consequences of conjugation and the Diels-Alder reaction. After a coverage of aromaticity and the chemistry of benzene, we then move into the heart of the course: the nature and reactivity of the carbonyl group, a subject that is central to both mainstream organic chemistry and biochemistry. Throughout this course, an effort will be made to demystify the art of chemical synthesis. This course is appropriate for chemistry majors, premedical students, and other students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Boundary Layer Meteorlogy
reviews: The problems are helpful but the homework project is a substantial amount of work. The time I spent on this class (excepting the project) is about equivalent or more than the time I spent on another graduate class.

This course is an excellent introduction to boundary layer meteorology and atmospheric turbulence. The course is very well-organized, with dual emphasis on the analytical tools for quantifying boundary layer motions and understanding phenomena actually observed in the boundary layer.
descrip: This course covers the basic dynamics of the Atmospheric Boundary Layer (ABL) and how it interacts with other environmental and geophysical flows. Topics to be covered include: mean, turbulence, and higher order flow equations, turbulence closure models for the ABL, similarity theories, surface exchanges and their impact on the stability of the atmosphere, the different ABL flow regimes, its role in the hydrologic cycle, the fundamentals of scalar (pollutant, water vapor, etc) transport, modeling and measurement approaches for the ABL, and the role and representation of the ABL in large-scale atmospheric flows and models.

title: Intensive Intermediate Chinese
reviews: Be ready for high expectations but everyone left Chinese 103 and 108 feeling like they improved their Chinese by incredible amounts and had fun in class. Teachers are some of the best people you'll meet at Princeton.

Each instructor is unique in his or her own way, but one thing they all have in common is that they care about whether their students understand the material. The course is rigorous, but the experience is rewarding.

I loved taking chinese this year, especially discussing and having the chance to vocalize and practice. The small class was really valuable, and all the teachers were fantastic. While it is definitely a good amount of work and hard to get an A because so many students come in pretty advanced, I think it's 100% worth it to take!!!
I would highly recommend anyone who is willing to spend time to learn another language to take this course.
It is advantageous to have previous background in Chinese. If one has not had previous background in Chinese, the course may be workload-heavy or conceptually difficult.
Keep up with all the lessons every day. Try and read the chapters before class, otherwise you will be very confused in class.
Make sure to study for the Wednesday quizzes. The Friday afternoon tests are very hard, so definitely study the night before and don't wait until the day of to study.
Seeing my Chinese improve so much over this past year has been really satisfying.  Even though there was less improvement during CHI 108, I still think my Chinese got more sophisticated.
Similar to 103, still takes a lot of time and effort.
TAKE THIS COURSE, IT IS AN AMAZING CLASS.
Take it if you have to
Take it! It's a blast.

Take this class! The teachers are all extremely engaging and really know how to run the class. You will have many opportunities to practice speaking Chinese and will improve a lot, especially if you put in the effort to go to Chinese tables and get to know teachers better. The work is not a lot and learning characters every week is not very hard.
Take this if you want an intense chinese experience
This class is very difficult and requires a lot of out of class work.
This course is hard not because of the content, but because of the grading curve. A's are pretty hard to get. However, you definitely learn a lot and your Chinese will improve significantly.
This course is tough, but you will definitely improve, and the instructors are all there to help you improve. It's a huge time commitment, but well worth it.
best course ever
prereqs: CHI 103 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: An intensive course covering 105 and 107 in one semester for students who have finished 103 which covers 101 and 102. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills and the analysis of grammar. After 108, students are ready for third year courses.

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese II
prereqs: CHI 301 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Following CHI 301, the basic training for classical Chinese, the readings for CHI 302 will be theme-based and focus on important cultural aspects of pre-modern China, such as Chinese concept of life and death, conflict between marriage and romance, and the development of utopian idea, etc. Each theme is consisted of passages selected from Chinese classics and short essays or stories full of wisdom and wit from later dynasties. This course will not only improve your four skills in Chinese language but also enhance your understanding of traditional Chinese philosophy and culture in general.

title: Re:Staging the Greeks
reviews: Fantastic course. You'll learn a lot about theater, staging in the context of ancient theater and how to reconcile that with modern audiences.

If Bryan comes back to teach it, know that the class will be more theoretical than you may initially expect. A lot of time is spent discussing theoretical productions. In the second half of the class, students had to be proactive in terms of making sure whatever they were working on got seen. It was easy to disappear in this class if you didn't force yourself to stay engaged.
If you have the opportunity to take this course, do it. It is essential for any Princeton student with a deep interest in Theater, and will open so many eyes you didn't even know you had.
Take this class!! Professor Doerries is an incredible artist and director and loves his students. Also Athens is great. Also the Greeks are great. Take it take it take it.
Take this if you can. Was incredible. Greek theatre is so awesome. The trip was amazing.
This course is an amazing opportunity -- take it if you have the chance.
This is a creative class, and the work it requires provides a great break from the rest of your academic work.
prereqs: THR 201, 205, 301, 311, or 317 OR significant theatrical experience. By application and audition. During the spring break registered students will take a required study trip to Athens..
descrip: Re:Staging the Greeks, a collaboration between the Theater Program of the Lewis Center for the Arts and the Program in Hellenic Studies, will begin with this acting/directing workshop investigating how to stage ancient Greek plays on the contemporary stage. On Tuesdays, we will study some of the plays, the contexts in which they were first performed, and approaches taken by theater directors over the last few decades. On Fridays, we'll be on our feet, exploring the play's performative possibilities for ourselves.

title: Readings in Japanese Academic Style II
descrip: The second half of the two-semester course, which trains students in reading the particular style of Japanese academic writing. The second semester particularly focuses on academic writings from Meiji to the 1950s, including brief introduction of necessary Classical Japanese Grammar for this purpose. Course conducted in English.

title: Apocalypse Now
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Ethics and International Development
descrip: In this course we read both philosophers of ethics, and development professionals and scholars, and critically examine the interaction of their arguments, values, and evidence. Do people around the world agree on what constitutes a good life for promoting 'development' to make sense? What does the existence of extreme poverty obligate the rich to do? Does the answer depend on practical consequences or on fundamental rights? How do large organizations, especially states and international bureaucracies, influence the ethical behaviors of their employees?

title: Microeconomic Policy
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
prereqs: HIN 301 / URD 301 or equivalent proficiency. See instructor for placement..
descrip: This literature and arts course focuses on Hindi and Urdu literary texts and tradition, using literary materials including fiction, poetry, and creative essays while also focusing on historical and literary contexts. Materials represent a range of genres, topics, and trends. Literary texts are supplemented with film and documentary selections, author interviews, etc. Reading and writing assignments are provided in both Hindi and Urdu- students choose their preferred script. Class time is devoted to in-depth discussion and analysis of materials. Literary workshops and sessions will be organized in connection with the course.

title: Applied Quantitative Analysis
reviews: 345 was a good base, but you seriously didn't learn anything applicable there.  Take this if you really want to be able to utilize R.  It's definitely manageable, even for someone not supre good with math

Definitely take it if you intend to use statistics at all in either independent work or your career, as this course is very applications-focused and teaches you how to analyze almost every conceivable type of data.
Give a good basis in practical application of stats.
Good class if you're interested in and want to learn more about the material. Great for the SML certificate.
Good if you want to learn more about R and regressions. Go to office hours!!
I learned a lot. It helps to have strong motivation to learn stats for social science (e.g., you want to get better at analyzing data).

I would not take it unless statistics is your passion is on the coding and practical side in conjecture with the mathematical and epistemological side. Plus you need to really like this cadre of material, if not, the process will be so boring and the final product of the problem sets and the projects so meaningless as they are objectively insignificant on their intrinsic academic value. If you are passionate about it, know that this course will dismay you even more, keep with it. Always remind yourself that these numbers are meaningless and are not the key to knowledge and understanding the world. They are virtually worth nil without your ability to convey a story. POL 345 was enough if you wanted to just be a consumer, POL 346 will only leave you wanting more and somewhat disappointed, even if you fundamentally love statistics. If you do take it, look for Brandon de la Cuesta, he's worth gold and a gentleman and a stellar, approachable mentor.
Kind of a fun stats class. Lectures and the book can both be a little dry and complex, so I had to ask questions both inside and outside of class. Brandon is an awesome preceptor who cares about us.
Take advantage of office hours.

Take it if you liked 345 - there's a ton of continuity, both in material and students enrolled, and so the course is very tailored to a generally understood base of knowledge. As well, will ABSOLUTELY help with writing quality JP work. This is underrated but is seriously so helpful
Take it if you want to learn about data analysis techniques.
Take it! When you are doing quantitative work for your JP and thesis, you will be thankful
Take it!!!

Take this - it is one of the few classes at Princeton that will truly enable you to understand statistics. I took ORF 245 before this (which was useless), but POL 346 gave me an idea of what statistical analysis is actually like. The final project is really cool, you basically choose your own research question, run the regressions yourself, and come up with results. This class is an accessible way for people to learn statistics, so I highly recommend for all (from WWS/POL/SOC people to ORF/ECO people).
Take this course if you want to improve your stats knowledge for use in independent work (or elsewhere).

This class is hard and is at a much higher difficulty and stress-level than POL 345. Only take it if you are really and seriously interested in the subject matter. Otherwise, I would say it's probably not worth the while.
This is a pretty good course - we learned about some really cool models and the applications were often fascinating. Difficult to get a lot out of without some math background though
This is an excellent course and takes you very far beyond POL 345.  If you want to pick up real data analysis skills this is a must-take.
Very good course for intertwining political science and statistics
Very useful course, take it!
Would definitely recommend for people interested in pol stats! Very interesting and engaging course!

You should absolutely take this class, regardless of whether or not you took POL345. POL345 was mostly the foundational introductory material (often dry and a little boring at times), but 346 is the real deal. You'll learn how to make exciting and relevant models that have interesting political (and any other field, but primarily economics and social science) applications. If you have any prior statistics or probability knowledge, then absolutely take this class. If not, I still think this is a totally manageable (and worthwhile) course if you're willing to put in a little time at the beginning to learn the programming on your own (the course uses R, and most other students will have prior experience with it. But if you have any prior programming experience at all, it's completely manageable in the first week). If you'd like to have a technical JP / senior thesis, the skills you learn in this class are absolutely relevant and would be a huge help. Take it!
prereqs: POL 345 or equivalent.
descrip: In a world awash in data, how can we identify signals amid the noise? This course focuses on developing an intuition for statistics and applying it through data analysis, regression models and a final project. We will wrestle with what makes a good research question, play with data to see how statistical methods can help us make sense of real world concerns, and work at communicating quantitative findings clearly to broad audiences. Particular attention will be paid to applying these techniques in Junior Papers and Senior Theses. Coursework involves using the R statistical platform.

title: Property, Wealth, and Equality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Princeton Atelier - The "Peer" Review
reviews: If you ever get the chance to take a class with Professor Doyle, do it!! He's amazing.
TAKE CLASSES WITH JOHN DOYLE! He will change your life.
Take this class if interested!
The Atelier program is one of the best in the school. Take one if you have time.

This is my second course with John Doyle and I must say: take any course that he offers. He is an incredible teacher and encourages students to think in about theater (and life?) in a freer manner. There is also a huge sense of collaboration and it feels like everyone truly values everyone else in the room. Could not recommend his classes more.
always be ready to ask a question
prereqs: Applications are required; for applications and more information, see the Princeton Atelier course webpage or contact Ellen Goellner (goellner@) with any questions. Ideally, students should have some theatrical experience..
descrip: This course is a practical examination of Henrik Ibsen's epic play "Peer Gynt". Through close examination of scenes from the play, the internationally acclaimed director John Doyle aims to develop a new adaptation. Professor Doyle will lead course participants through the play and, in collaboration with them, try to determine how "Peer Gynt" strikes a modern audience, how the text may need to be adapted, how we might begin to devise a visual and verbal language that will be equal to the immense theatricality of the original.

title: Public Health, Politics & Public Policy
reviews: Great, low-stress course where you learn a lot and discuss important issues. Would definitely recommend taking!

If you are a conservative, beware. The class presupposes that students are liberals, and conservative opinions are literally used as case studies for deception. Otherwise, you will likely love this class! The professors are compassionate and guest speakers were very engaging.
If you are interested in controversial health policies, take the course!

TAKE THIS COURSE! One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton, and Professors Graff and Howard really bring a lot in terms of their life experience to the class. The discussions are always engaging and interesting, and you'll want to do your readings each week. The controversial health topics are fascinating and definitely something that you should talk about and learn about before graduating.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Both professors are extremely the helpful and it was hands-down one of my favorite courses at Princeton. The small class-size made the entire course very engaging and intellectually stimulating.
Take the course! Profs Graff and Howard are amazing, and the topics covered were interesting and relevant to public health and health policy.

Take this class!  You will learn so much, and the workload is very manageable.  There are student presentations during most weeks and a few guest speaker lectures in between.  This class is discussion based, so be prepared to contribute with insights from the readings and from current events.
This course offers a rare opportunity to evaluate challenging issues through a public health and public policy lens. You could not find two more excellent professors.
This was a wonderful class and Professors Howard and Graff were both excellent. I learned a lot and highly recommend taking this if you are interested in public health (mostly within the US).

This was one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Both Professor Graff and Howard have extensive experience in public health and bring super interesting and informative personal anecdotes into seminar. I had no prior experience taking public health classes but just had to take this class after sitting in on the first seminar and loving it. This class attracted people from multiple disciplines passionate about public health so class discussion was very lively and engaging.
descrip: This course will explore health topics from the perspective of population health, politics and policy. Bridging domestic and international health topics and perspectives, the course will focus on controversial and complex health issues. The course will weave examples through various topics to demonstrate how politics and competing stakeholder interests can play a critical role in the public health and public policy response to health problems. The class sessions will be comprised of presentations by the instructors, visiting experts and students. Class discussion and presentation will be core elements of the course.

title: Special Topics in Investment Science - Trading and Risk Management
reviews: Absolutely incredible class. Professor Villani genuinely cares about his students and it is a great way to learn more from someone who has so much experience and perspective. It covers a broad range of quantitative and qualitative topics and is very accessible, even to undergrads. Highly recommend if you have any interest in trading or finance.
Good class, especially if you participate a lot
Great class

Great class taught by a professional, far from all the boring academic classes. If you consider a career in trading or investments, I think this class teaches you more than anything else. You have to like the guy though.
Lectures are insightful. Professor has a philosophical flair.
Project group strongly recommended. Very enjoyable class, Professor Dario is great and fun.

This course does not teach you finance in well prepared manner. Villani talks very random thing that he want to say, and he does not focus on the lecture. However, he has very good intuition, worth taking back home.
great course
descrip: The course explores the modelling, measuring and managing of financial risk - i.e., differentiating between a good trade and a bad one. Emphasis will be placed on illustrating the modelling needs and strategies on the buy side vs. the sell side. Practical applications will be drawn from all asset classes. Convexity and time scale considerations will be addressed and risk management will be discussed with respect to RV and macro strategies. Coursework will focus on assessing risk/reward and identifying market opportunities. Entropy techniques and discretization issues will also be introduced. Guest speakers: experts from hedge funds and banks.

title: Natural History/History of Nature: The Concept of Nature in Classical Antiquity
descrip: This course inquires into the natures of nature in classical antiquity via natural history, cosmology, medicine, ethics, and literature. The following topics are considered: the order and agency of the natural world in Greek literature; the relationship between physis, occult knowledge, and techniques of manifestation; human nature and the tension between physis as a force of compulsion and a norm to be fulfilled; strategies for controlling nature; the relationship between the natures of things and a single ordering Nature; competing philosophies of nature; and transcendance and immanence within philosophies of nature.

title: Politics of Intimacy, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The 17th Century
reviews: Great class. Professor Smith is brilliant and so knowledgeable about the time period. Not a lot of work too for an English departmental British Foundation requirement.

If you aren't interested in the philosophy and history of the 17th century, maybe take a different class if you're just looking for a Brit foundation. Professor Smith is fantastic, though, and this class was very good.
descrip: The 17th century remains the definitive period for modern literature: many poets from T.S. Eliot to Paul Muldoon and Susan Stewart take crucial inspiration from this time. We will explore Donne, Jonson, Herbert, Marvell, Milton and others in the context of the period's volatile intellectual and political currents, but with an emphasis on literary creativity and originality in a number of genres and forms.

title: Translation Workshop: Spanish to English
reviews: Great course that is conducted in English
If you're interested in literary translation and want to practice translating from Spanish to English, then this class is ideal.
TAKE IT IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN LITERARY TRANSLATION! TAKE IT!

Take it if you was hands-on practice translating from Spanish to English! It's not a language course-- more of a writing course --but it's really interesting to see how hard it can be to navigate well between two languages in a way that does the original text justice.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission. Reading knowledge of Spanish..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the practice of literary translation from Spanish to English and an exploration of the questions that the act of translation inspires. After a series of translation exercises, each student will select an author and work to be translated as the central project for the class, and embark on the process of revising successive drafts. Close reading of the Spanish texts is required, as is a deep engagement with the translations of fellow students. Subjects of discussion will include style, context, the conventions of contemporary translation, and the retranslation of classics.

title: Special Topics in MMS - Non-linear analysis of prestressed structural systems
prereqs: Open to Graduate Engineering Students, MATLAB Proficiency Other students need to obtain permission from the instructors.
descrip: This course focuses on non-linear analysis techniques for prestressed structural systems,such as cable nets,fabric facades and technical membranes,especially Newton's and Dynamic Relaxation methods.The problem of shape finding is presented,and the methods of Force Density Natural Force Density Method are developed. Students learn how to identify the most appropriate analysis technique for a specific design problem,develop a deep understanding of the concepts and the numerical algorithms,write their own numerical formulations for the displayed methods in MATLAB and apply their gained knowledge and skills in a project-based challenge.

title: International Monetary Theory and Policy II
descrip: Advanced topics in monetary economics, with an emphasis on open economies. Money demand and currency substitution; price-level and exchange-rate determination under alternative monetary policy rules; real effects of monetary disturbances; exchange-rate policy and macroeconomic stability; welfare consequences of inflation and exchange-rate stabilization; advantages and disadvantages of monetary union.

title: Translating East Asia
reviews: Be aware that this course primarily focuses China and Japan (and not Korea). The class is certainly stimulating though and touches on many interesting theoretical discussions of translation.
Don't take it...
I found it hard to keep up with the readings because they were long and I was pdfing so I often neglected this class for more important ones but it's really interesting!!!
Professor Kern is highly knowledgeable about the field and I enjoyed taking the class.
do the readings and participate!
descrip: Translation is at the core of our engagement with China, Japan, and Korea. From translations of the classics to the grass-root subtitling of Anime movies, from the formation of modern East Asian cultural discourses to cross-cultural references in theater and film, the seminar poses fundamental questions to our encounters with East Asian cultural artifacts, reflecting on what "translation" of "original works" means in a global world where a projected "translation" is often already inscribed within the "original." Open to students with or without knowledge of an East Asian language.

title: Landscape Art in China
reviews: It would be helpful if the student prepares him or herself with the general history of China, from the earliest dynasties to the modern age, otherwise one could get lost as we move through 'themes' rather than periods.
Strongly recommended, but it's a pity that Jerome is retired.
Take excellent notes, try to view the slides ahead of time, and be on the lookout for things that interest you for the final paper.
descrip: A course about Chinese concepts of nature and human nature, theories and traditions of landscape art. Weekly consideration of such themes as replicating and transforming the landscape; submission to/control of nature; landscape as political allegory; pilgrimage and exile; gardens and artists' studios; landscape magic in ancient China; endangered pandas, power dams, and the technology of modern art.

title: Leo Tolstoy, War and Peace, and the Tasks of Literature
reviews: An amazing course with an amazing professor and terrific works by Tolstoy.
An amazing course! Probably not possible to take it again with prof. Emerson, but the preceptors were great too.

Be prepared to NOT HAVE EMERSON ANYMORE BECAUSE SHE'S LEAVING AND I CRIED WHEN SHE GOT OFF THE PODIUM AFTER HER LAST LECTURE
I hope your professor is half as good as she was. :)
Emerson's leaving so idk but even the chance to read this stuff is a pretty worthwhile investment
Figure out a plan for getting the reading done. It is a lot, but it is all beneficial and adds many more layers to your understanding of who Tolstoy is.
Great class, but you absolutely have to leave time to do all the readings if you want to get everything you can out of it.
Great readings, great discussions. A lot of reading, but so worth it.
Greatest class ever. Emerson is retiring so there's no advice to give. Tolstoy is great but you need a great professor as well.
I don't think this is being offered again, but if it is you have to take it. Reading Tolstoy helped me come out of an emotional crisis stronger than before. Also Professor Emerson is the best.
I wish you could take it - Professor Emerson is leaving :((

I'm not sure what the class will be like without Professor Emerson teaching it.. But as an engineer and having this class be one of the first literature courses I've taken here, it was worthwhile and one of the best I've taken!
If Emerson is teaching, this is one of the best courses taught here.
If it is offered again and Victoria is somehow involved, take it!
