It's so unfortunate that Professor Emerson is retiring this year. I wish her all the best, but students who have not had the privilege of taking this course will truly be missing out.
Look at who the teacher is since it won't be professor Emerson
Lots of reading, but absolutely worth it. It's an incredible course (and life-changing in the best case).
Not teaching anymore, but fascinating to study one author so closely. Especially since I like him. Lots of reading.

Professor Emerson is incredible, though I think this was the last opportunity to take the course from her. There is a boat-load of reading, and I think it is basically not possible to do all of the reading unless you read (or start) War and Peace ahead of time. That said, the course is very enjoyable. It's a nice course to PDF, as well - there's only 6 response papers and a final paper.
Read the primary literature it's important and interesting, the secondary literature was kind of optional in my experience.
Sadly, this opportunity cannot arise again.
Since this was the last time Prof. Emerson taught this seminar, you won't have the fortune of reading Tolstoy with her -- but read Tolstoy nevertheless!

Take anything Professor Emerson ever teaches. She is an incredibly special professor. Even if she does not continue to teach this course, absolutely take it. It was the best course I've taken at Princeton by far. Huge amount of readings, but putting in the time will yield a profound and very interesting class. Either way, read some Tolstoy at some point in your life.
Take it
Take it. Tolstoy is fantastic. If Emerson ever teaches again, take her classes. She will inspire you beyond belief.
Take this class! Amazing! Unfortunately it was Professor Emerson's last but hopefully the legacy of this class lives on.
Take this course only if you are willing to commit 5-10 hours of reading a week to it. Otherwise, it is difficult to benefit from.
Take this course!
Take this if you can, but try to read war and peace ahead of time.
This is a great course!!!! They say this is Emerson's last semester, but if someone else is offering it, it will probably still be great.

This is my favorite class I have ever taken at Princeton! Reading "War and Peace" beforehand (ie over intersession) definitely makes the workload more manageable. Rachel is the best, if she precepts again!
This is the best class I have ever taken. Professor Emerson is amazing. Tolstoy has changed my life.
This was an unbelievably great class
Though it may not be offered again by Emerson, it was phenomenally taught 2015-16.
Though it seems Professor Emerson won't be teaching this course again (which is a *huge* pity), Tolstoy is fabulously interesting, whether you like him or you hate him. Well worth taking.
Too bad Professor Emerson is leaving! Should have taken this class this year... If it is ever offered again for some reason, I wholeheartedly recommend it, as it was my favorite class at Princeton.
Too bad it is no longer available after this year. If anyone else teaches it it would still be worth taking but Professor Emerson will be missed.
Too bad you can't take. It was really great.
Try to keep up with the readings. It's hard esp during some of the war and peace weeks, but you'll get so much more out of lectures and precepts
Unfortunately Professor Emerson will no longer be teaching, but otherwise it is thoroughly worth taking.
YES YES
prereqs: Knowledge of Russian not expected. Those who know any Russian are invited to enroll in a English/Russian discussion section, which samples short segments of Tolstoy's prose. Discussion topics (in English) are the same; you will not be 'tested' differently and the work load will not be heavier. Audio recordings posted. Satisfies a COM language requirement..
descrip: An introduction to Tolstoy through his select short fiction and/or drama, critical essays, and all of [War and Peace] in the context of various theories of the novel. Our thesis--which is open to debate--is that Tolstoy's radical ideas on narrative have their counterpart in his radical ideas on history and the self, which, taken together, offer a coherent view of the human condition at odds with most Russian writers and philosophers of his time.

title: Writing Histories of the Modern Middle East: Trends, Topics, Problems
descrip: This seminar has one goal: to help turn historians "of the modern Middle East" into "historians" of the modern Middle East. We go about this task in three steps. Weeks 1-4 discuss four key questions that underlie all history writing: What is history?; the fact; time/periodization; and scale. Weeks 5-10 are three two-week-long segments that introduce three historiographic debates that have been central in the last 2-3 decades and that correspond to the research interests of many Middle East historians: gender, cultural history, and transnational/global history. In weeks 11-12 we discuss pre-circulated first drafts of students' seminar papers.

title: English Constitutional History
reviews: Extremely good course. Gives foundational knowledge for the American legal system as well as offering a vision of how a legal system is actually created over time, what morals it rests on, what actually endures. Also offers a window into the human side of the law, the faces and people and kings who created it. The course is admittedly difficult, especially if Professor Jordan is your preceptor. But if you are up to the challenge, you will learn more in this course than you will in most, particularly about how to be a subtle thinker and an empathetic historian. These are skills helpful to all aspects of life, obviously, and even calling them skills seems demeaning. This is a deeply human course and at its best it nurtures the humanity in us. Best recommendation is to GO TO OFFICE HOURS. Never think you know the material, keep searching, and stay curious.

I took this class because Professor Jordan was teaching it. It's rumored to be one of the most challenging in the department, and not without reason, but it is well worth the effort. Jordan is a great teacher and you would never guess how entertaining a 9am lecture on English legal and political history could be. Don't miss the opportunity to take it!
If students have any interest in this branch of history, I would strongly recommend that they take this course.

One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Before coming to Princeton, this is how I imagined a Princeton class would be like: forcing you to think instead of just know what the readings are, challenging but extremely rewarding. Professors Jordan's lectures are extremely engaging and the material is important and interesting. Highly recommend. I would do it again if I had the choice to build my spring schedule again.
Probably not a course for everyone (lot of legal stuff), but definitely worth taking.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! There is a lot of reading but a course with Professor Jordan is so worth it.
Take it! Take it! Take it!
Take it. Jordan is a great lecturer. Really interesting and fun class.
Take this course. You'll love it. Especially if you don't think you'll love it, you'll love it, so take it. Premodern history CAN be interesting.
Very good course. Would definitely recommend.

Would recommend this to any student with an interest in English history, legal history, or political history. Professor Jordan is an amazing professor and you will not regret it. But be sure to read the assigned texts and pay attention in lecture, as the exams will draw heavily from technical information.
descrip: To explore the development of institutions and theories of government in England from the Norman Conquest to about 1700.

title: Vladimir Nabokov
reviews: Do not even think, just take it.

I don't know how much is here that couldn't be gleaned by a very close reading but if you have only sparsely read him and like him, or are interested at all, his prose is a unique treat. I may only warn that subjectivity in literature critique is a small problem and that after reading the vast majority of an author's, any author's, collective works, you will begin to find him/her's proclivities intolerable.

If you have ever read Nabokov or if you haven't, take this course. Take it for the pure pleasure of reading these fantastic novels. The grading isn't hard at all, it's pretty much a solid A-/A. But you're really missing out if you don't do the readings. I found myself taking study breaks just to read these novels because they're so great.

TAKE THIS CLASS. It's one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. The material is absolutely amazing and the prompts for the papers are really broad so it's fun to write about whatever you want. Professor Hasty is the best and is so approachable. Go to her office hours and try to learn as much as you can from her.
Take it if you have any interest in Nabokov!
Take it, Prof. Hasty is excellent and she will guide you in understanding the monumental importance of Nabokov's work.
Take this course if you are interested in Nabokov.

Take this course if you're any way interested in Russian Literature or especially Nabokov, which you should be, because it's one of the best courses out there! The Professor, which one is the right question, is engaging and thoughtful of the minds of students. Do keep up with the readings and spend time thinking about the essays in advance. Good writing cannot be produced in a day, and there is so much to comment on. Office hours are helpful and very fun! Have fun and don't think too hard, but do think enough. Remember what Nabokov mother said, "To love with all one's soul and leave the rest to fate." Take the course. It will change your life and you will love it.
Take this course! Your writing will improve, and you will view the world with more detail and tenderness.
This course will blow your mind.

This is a solid course, and you should definitely consider taking it.  The texts are heavy, of course, but the actual workload of the class is very manageable.  Keep in mind also that this course is more of an introduction to Nabokov, with minimal time being devoted to a lot of works, rather than an in-depth look a just a few of Nabokov's works.  I went in expecting more of the latter, and was a bit disappointed as a result.
descrip: In 1919, at the age of twenty, Vladimir Nabokov fled "the bloated octopus of state" of his native Russia and embarked on a dazzling bilingual literary career in emigration. This course focuses on Nabokov's masterly writing, which reflects a modernist preoccupation with narrative, temporality, and memory. The Russian and American novels are at the center of our attention, but readings include also a sampling of his shorter fiction, poetry, essays on literature, and the memoir [Speak, Memory].

title: Genetics of Eukaryotic Organisms
reviews: I would not recommend this class for someone who has already taken a genetics class or for people who are looking to acquire practical skills for generating and interpreting genomic data
Read the papers
Read the papers carefully and pay extra attention to the parts that are related to the theme of that lecture.

The department should make this into an actual quantitative course, and move Liz's (and 1 week of Mark's) into the Euks part of Pukes (and get rid of some of Schedule's stuff). I think you're doing that already though...
You can definetely learn traditional genetics, molecular genetics, and genomics a lot in this course.
descrip: This course presents the genetic tools and logical framework used in the study of eukaryotic organisms, from the major model organisms (yeast, Drosophila, C.elegans, mouse and zebrafish) to humans. Discussion and readings frrom the primary literature focuses on basic cell,developmental, and quantitative biology. Material emphasizes genetic approaches building from classical methods to modern molecular genetics and genomics. Topics include suppression synthetic lethality epistasis, mutagenesis, mosaics, transgenics, BS cells, knock-in technologies and cell-type specific gene expression.

title: Zionism:The Intellectual History of Jewish Nationalism
descrip: This course explores why, since the late 18th century, Jews and non-Jews alike have asked if the Jews are a nation and why people answer differently, inviting students to think about the origins of nationalism and the relationship between nations and other groups - religions, 'races,' ethnicities, and states. Learn about those who insisted that the Jews are not a separate nation and consider the different motivations for rejecting the nationhood of the Jews. We will examine the varieties of Jewish nationalisms that arose at the end of the 19th century, including Diaspora nationalism, territorialism, and especially Zionism.

title: Afterlives of the Artists
descrip: We will examine the ways in which Giorgio Vasari's Lives of the Artists<\i> have morphed into modern and postmodern literature, focusing on the novelistic and lyric subversions of the original model. Adjustments to the standard narrative include biographies of wretched artists, artsy dealers, and aesthetically inclined criminals; texts set within the imagined world of a painting; tales privileging the instrument or materials over the artist; and dramatically rewritten or unwritten lives of the usual suspects. At stake here is less the figure of the artist than his or her disfiguration in the service of contemporary literature.

title: Global Justice
reviews: A sometimes awkward mix of theory and applications that doesnt seem to reach far enough in either direction. Regardless, a fine way of getting an EM.

A very useful and interesting class for anyone planning on further study in fields relating to politics, philosophy or ethics, but wouldn't necessarily recommend to anyone studying the topic casually--it's up to you to do the readings, of which there are a fair few, but the material is introductory and while not simple, easy to understand after a little consideration.
Be prepared to  pay attention in lecture. Great class. Interesting material-- good way to get rid of EM and Woody Woo's ethics requirement

Beitz is an excellent professor and extremely supportive towards his students; I strongly recommend his preceptor. The readings are difficult as it is political theory, but it's a great foundational class for Woody Woo and POL concentrators.
Definitely take it if you need a decently easy EM or to fill the WWS core req. Beitz is a pretty cool guy and a good lecturer
Do the readings, because you'll be prepared for the problem essays, and because they're fascinating in of themselves.

Global Justice is a truly fantastic course. The course is separated into two sections: justice in war, and justice in peacetime. Both topics were full of thought-provoking questions. Lectures were clear and organized, readings were a very reasonable length and well-chosen, and assignments were useful for grappling with the material. I couldn't recommend this course more highly.
Go to lecture. Always.
Go to lectures and take notes of important concepts. Discuss your essay outlines with preceptors.
Good ethics requirement.
Great class, interesting material
Great course, would highly recommend, the lectures were absolutely amazing, the readings extremely engaging, and the general structure fair and well-organized.
Hard but useful.
I am neutral on this course--take it if you like theory, but otherwise, don't take it.
I would recommend this course for anyone with an interest in the theoretical aspect of international relations.
It was interesting. Do the readings to get the most out of it.
Pretty good class without too, too much work. Prof Beitz is a very good lecturer, and I loved having David as a preceptor!

Someone else called this 'pie in the sky', which is definitely very accurate. Problem essays really are graded harshly, and final exam was a bit harder than I thought it would be. However, you do learn a lot about global justice from a professor who is very well-known in the field.
Start the problem essays earlier rather than later and take full advantage of precept and professor office hours. Go to lecture!

TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Beitz does an amazing job of summarizing material and also making you think for yourself about it. The readings are amazing if you have time to do them, and if you miss a few he does a great job summarizing. Not an insane workload and incredibly interesting. One of my favorite classes here. David is a great preceptor!

Take it you have to. It's a pretty painless way of getting rid of your ethics requirement if you're WWS, and if you have any interest in ethics at all you probably will find it interesting. But maybe don't take it otherwise.
Take it. Beitz is a very traditional lecturer but he is incredibly insightful and so smart and I loved it. Take it.

Take this class!! Beitz is a great lecturer and the material is fascinating - though sometimes it can be dense, the preceptors are always welcome to discuss anything you might be confused about. Highly recommend taking this if you are unsure about your interest in International Relations, or if you are interested in majoring in Politics but aren't sure what the department looks like at its best.
Take this if you're looking for an interesting course in political philosophy!
There is not a great deal of work in this course besides the two short essays and readings. What you learn here is very valuable and you should take it!
There's a lot of reading, so don't take other reading intensive courses unless you know you can handle the quantity.
This course does an excellent job of stimulating critical thinking on difficult issues.  Participating in precept will help you get the most out of the course.

This course is about international political theory. The first half focuses on 'justice in war', the second on 'justice in peace'. If you're interested in the ethics of war, trade, human rights and morality beyond the state I highly recommend this course.

This is a fantastic class. It's intimidating at first if you've never taken any kind of philosophy or political theory, but it definitely becomes easier and more natural as you go along. For anyone interested in international relations, this offers a totally different perspective on familiar issues, and an important perspective--the one of morality and justice.
This is an awesome class! I would definitely recommend taking it.
This is an interesting class that seems to combine philosophy and politics. The lectures were very clear and interesting and the reading was reasonable.

definitely recommend having a good grasp of politics and current events, very helpful in precept discussion. readings are very dense but interesting and class is very productive. if you're interested, definitely take it. professor beitz is a fantastic lecturer - clear and very thought provoking and provides helpful lecture outlines to more easily follow along
have some experience with the material
poses interesting, philosophical questions- take
take it but a lot of work
descrip: What, if any, norms of justice apply to the institutions and practice of world politics? Topics include "political realism" and skepticism about global morality; just wars and justice in warfare; ethics of humanitarian intervention; the nature and basis of human rights; world poverty and global distributive justice; climate change; democracy and accountability in global institutions. Readings chosen from recent works in political philosophy.

title: Medieval Democracy: Italian City States of the Middle Ages
descrip: In the Middle Ages, dozens of city-states in Italy were governed by citizens elected by the populace (limited to men of property, as was the American republic in its early years). These communes grew out of the anarchy following the dissolution of the Roman Empire in the West and flourished by playing off the German emperors to the north against the Popes and their allies to the south. In the course of the later Middle Ages, many of these cities fell into the hands of foreign rulers or local warlords, but some remained republics well into the modern era.

title: Advanced Syntax
prereqs: LIN 302 or by application.
descrip: How Chomsky's minimalist program has revolutionized syntactic theory and the study of language more generally. Explication and evaluation of minimalist approaches to syntactic derivation and representation, including the role of economy and other principles of efficient computation. One focus will be the empirical basis of these proposals.

title: Introduction to African-American Intellectual Tradition
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar introduces graduate students from many departments to the African-American intellectual tradition. The perspective concentrates on African-America and the African Diaspora, with attention to issues of class and gender as well as race. A broad set of topics, including race, racism, religion, and slavery are discussed. The course presupposes a familiarity with issues in African-American studies.

title: Seminar in Golden-Age Literature - Passing Identities in Early Modern Spain
descrip: The concealment of one's birth rank, ethnicity, and/or gender was a strategy that allowed access to social spaces that would otherwise not have been accessible to certain subjects. On the other hand, the awareness that impersonators were secretly disrupting the natural social order contributed to heightened anxieties among those who felt threatened by social infiltration. This course examines the representation of the phenomenon of "passing" and its responses in the literature of Golden Age Spain. Readings will include more established literary works as well as lesser known books of jokes, treatises, and official discourses.

title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS unless you really want to be math-track or finance. Take it in the fall. Morris is absolutely the worst, and it is really hard.
Decently interesting material that isn't too hard. Terrible lectures. Survive off of readings and precepts and it's not that much work.
Do it for the certificate.
Don't go to lecture. Precept is most important. Might want to read through book. Talk to preceptors and go to office hours as much as possible.
Don't take this class unless you have to.
Don't take this class. If you have to for finance...good luck. Otherwise, avoid it at all costs.
Dry stuff.
Fairly easy technical elective. Not super interesting (except for game theory) but not super difficult either.
Go to precept don't go to lecture
Go to precept.
If you can, switch into Ben Young's precept. Great guy, better teacher.
If you're math inclined, this class really isn't that bad. If at all possible, get Ben Young as your preceptor, he's amazing.
Lectures are insanely boring, you literally only need to show up to turn in homework. Homework can be tricky at times but precepts are helpful.

Lectures don't help
Readings do
Not a well taught class.
Office hours and precepts were the most helpful tools for taking this class.
Only take it if you have to
Only take it if you need it for finance cert. or upper level econ. You won't learn much about economics, just math problems.
Only take this course from Prof. Morris if you don't want to go to lecture. If you don't care, though, it is an easy SA for someone with a math background.
Overall, the course is not especially difficult, but it can be tough to get through, because the lectures and material are not extremely fascinating.
Pay attention to lecture and precept, but also seek resources on your own
Pretty dry but very manageable.

Pretty dull. Take if you're really interested in Micro and like the quantitative aspect (or if you need it for the certificate). Work load isn't too heavy (you can get by without doing the readings). Problem sets aren't too intense. A manageable third class for a COS major, if its any indication.
Probably one of the worst classes I've taken here. Very poorly taught. You're honestly better reading the textbook. Don't take unless it's a departmental.

Professor Morris is a good professor and the class isn't too hard. If you are comfortable with Multivariable calculus, you should definitely take it. In fact, most of the course was just single variable calculus integrated into the principles of ECO 100.
Read the textbook and attend precept!
Relatively easy if you're good at math, but a fairly dry course.
Take this class if you need to either because you are an economics major or you need it for some other requirement.
Take this if you need it as a requirement or if you don't mind doing a lot of algebra.  Otherwise not a bad class.

The course was pretty dry and not very interesting, especially since the lectures are pretty much directly off the lecture slides. The lecture slides are also really unhelpful when it comes to homework and studying for exams.
The lectures are really boring -- try learning the stuff on your own.
This class is dry and uninteresting but you probably have to take it for other econ classes.

This class is mathematically heavy in assignments and more theoretical in the lectures. The professor is very nice, but the lectures are not all that useful for doing well on the homework. The homework is not too difficult, and can be done very quickly if you understand the material. The exams are very fair, and basically test your ability to remember some of the key concepts during the semester. The precepts are arguably the most important aspect of this course, since the preceptors walk through example problems and really make sure that you understand how to apply the material to solving real problems.
This class is really interesting for anyone although you don't really have to attend lectures.  Make sure you attend precept though and try to get Julius Vutz as preceptor because he's very good.
Try to attend office hours as often as possible and refer to the textbook because it can explain some concepts better than lectures.
Utilize precepts, office hours, and the textbook. If possible, read the relevant textbook chapter before each lecture so that the material isn't totally new to you at the lecture.
Worthwhile for the finance certificate.

You're probably taking it for a departmental or certificate anyway. Don't expect anything mind-blowingly interesting. The hardest part is learning how to set up the problems and translate wordy economics stuff into math - so pay attention in precept and get a good preceptor (Mark Li is the best) because you won't learn how to do that in lecture. The rest of it is just basic calculus.
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 175 or MAT 201..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.

title: Techniques and Methods of Social Science
descrip: This seminar has three objectives: 1) to introduce students to different social science research methods (including survey research, experiments, ethnography, historical and comparative analysis, text analysis) and to provide them with an understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of various approaches; 2) to introduce students to the types of research Princeton faculty members are currently engaged in; and 3) to familiarize students with the components of a strong empirical paper and to prepare them to identify a topic and data for their empirical paper.

title: Special Topics in Social Entrepreneurship - Rethinking Social Profit Organizations
reviews: A very interesting class! Get to know your classmates!!

Absolutely take this course. Marty was great and the format of the class was so enjoyable. It grew me as an entrepreneur and made me feel so much more confident in launching a start-up. For sure, my favorite class at Princeton thus far.
Always stay ahead of the readings and work hard in your groups.

Choose your team carefully. Who you're working with, and their reliability, will make or break your experience in the course. Grading shouldn't be rough if you're an active participant, however. You get as much out of the class as you put in, especially in the project. Get to know the instructor and TA!
Definitely take it if you have any interest in business/entrepreneurship
Even if you don't imagine yourself as an entrepreneur, this course is great for opening your mind up to the possibilities and opportunities that exists. You really do rethink social profits.

If Marty Johnson is the professor or Ryan is the TA, you need to take this course. I've never had a more caring/engaged professor/TA while at Princeton, and you will come away from the course with a fully thought out business plan.
If you are independently motivated to pursue opportunities in social entrepreneurship, this is the place to do it.
Not difficult, but will take up far too much of your time for the difficulty of the course.
TAKE IT! You have so much to learn from Marty Johnson. One of the few practical courses grounded in related theory --- one of my favorite classes and a class I'll actually use in my life
Take it. A lot to learn from this class and Marty!

Take this course if you are interested in the social profit sector but ESPECIALLY if you are interested in working on a particular social profit idea. Unlike other classes at Princeton you will be in the A-B range depending on the work you put in. If you do the readings (there are not too many), pay attention and listen in class, and thoughtfully work on your teams social profit venture, you will definitely get a high A.

Take this course if you want to learn a lot of practical business skills and knowledge that can be applied to far more than just the social profit sector. Also, an EXTREMELY easy A so long as you put in a little bit of effort.
Take this course! It's not hard to do well and its a really nice breath of not academic theoretically princeton. very practical
This class is a great way to explore social entrepreneurship, learn about pitching an idea and just get comfortable presenting in general.

To be honest, I was just trying to find a fifth class. But this is the most AMAZING class I've ever taken. It has changed my entire outlook in life and has made me reconsider my plans at Princeton. TAKE IT
Wonderful class! Professor Johnson and Ryan are phenomenal human beings. They love what they do, and you will learn so much both inside and out of the classroom. Really a great choice.
take it!
prereqs: None, except curiosity and a willingness to work on innovative solutions to social challenges..
descrip: A growing number of entrepreneurs are solving social and environmental challenges by creating private 'nonprofit' organizations and projects. This course will explore the challenges and opportunities they face. While the course will cover the styles and competencies that successful nonprofit managers tend to exhibit, it will explore system-wide changes needed to improve the sector's outcomes, including key ways that funders, government, businesses and the beneficiaries of nonprofits can help.

title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
reviews: Excellent course. I would like more extensive feedback on my reading assignments and performance in general, and perhaps a restructuring of the written assignments. Definitely recommend as an easy fifth course if you're interested in the language. It's a very close-knit and fun department to be a part of, and Luis is very 'engracado'. (funny)

I definitely recommend this course if you have a strong foundation in Spanish. It's fun and very manageable. That being said, there are a lot of quizzes and small assignments, and the professor may not remind you about them, so make sure to keep up with the syllabus.
I regret not taking this class sooner. If you are a languages person, or have an interest in learning a new language then take it! I regret not taking it sooner.
I would strongly recommend this course! You gain so much proficiency in a language in just one semester! It is incredibly fun, low time-commitment, and low stress.
If you speak spanish it will be quite an easy course for you. If you don't it will still be very interresting.
Please take this class if you have any interest at all in learning a foreign language.

Portuguese 108 is a blast. If you put in the work, the results will be amazing. The professors are funny and engaging, and the material is relevant. For anyone wanting to set a good foundation for their Portuguese, I definitely recommend this course.
TAKE IT
Take it if you want a crash course in Portuguese! It's a lot of busy work but you also learn a lot in a short amount of time, enough at least to help you get by in a Portuguese speaking country.
Take it! Especially if your proficient in Spanish. Luis is awesome and the class isn't too much work.
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.

title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature and Culture - Albert Camus
reviews: Class is very interesting, and Benhaim is a FANTASTIC professor. He will open your eyes to Camus' works - at to the world at large. Do yourself a favor and TAKE IT!!! (like seriously, take it)
I would recommend this.
Take it but be aware that you are expected to have a high level of french

This class is decent - the material is interesting, and Prof Benhaim is funny and approachable. However, the seminar was too big, too long, and Prof Benhaim tends to go off on 30 min tangents...and those factors combined make it way too easy to zone out. If you need this class for a departmental or a certificate requirement then it's not a bad option, but if you're considering taking it for general interest then there are better classes out there.
prereqs: A 200-level French course..
descrip: This course aims to present and redefine the works and figure of Albert Camus as both one of the most acclaimed writers of the 20th century, and one of the most paradoxical. Through the study of his major works, but also more obscure ones, we will see what confirms his canonical (sometimes sanctified) dimension, and what challenges it. We will assess how Camus found himself often at odds with his own thought and creativity, whether it was through philosophy, politics, or the very act of writing. Gauging Camus's greatest accomplishments and shortcomings, we will consider Camus as an artist always in between, eternally moving.

title: Race and Religion in America
reviews: Do the readings because you'll love them. They're actually super exciting and you'll be really proud of yourself at the end of the semester. Students are self-selecting in this course and that's really gratifying in the discussion and it is only enhanced when you really have appreciated the readings.
Take this course if you have any interest whatsoever!
Take this course! Professor Weisenfeld is an excellent professor and the material is very interesting and relevant. It is a lot of reading but on the whole the course is manageable.
Take this! Professor Weisenfeld is wonderful, and it will be composed of a self selecting group of interesting, thoughtful students
There are a lot of readings, so please do not take this course lightly. It will be fully worth it, though.
This has been my favorite seminar at Princeton. It's a lot of reading, but worth the work.
there is quite a bit of reading that you have to be accountable for but the course is really enjoyable!!
descrip: In this seminar we examine the tangled and shifting relationship between religion and race in American history. In doing so, we explore a broad landscape of racial construction, identity, and experience and consider such topics as American interpretations of race in the Bible, religion and racial slavery, race and missions, religion, race, and science, popular culture representations of racialized religion, and religiously-grounded resistance to racial hierarchy.

title: Physical Hydrology
descrip: This course concerns the role of the terrestrial hydrosphere in the climate system.Topics include the role of land within Earth's climate system,terrestrial hydrological processes,land-atmospheric coupling and precipitation recycling,land hydrological sensitivity to projections of global change (land cover and climate). Model parameterizations for terrestrial water and energy models are discussed and developed based on the underlying physics.

title: Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: A great class-- definitely take it!

Absolutely phenomenal. Incredible. Can't give high enough praise. These were some of the best 2 hours of my week - Coach Dickman is really absolutely amazing. You will learn a whole new relationship with and appreciation for language, and a new life outlook.

CWR classes at Princeton are amazing, highly recommend. It's a great opportunity to experience a different type of class and a different way of thinking. Professor Smith is a good professor, but I might encourage taking with a teacher that is a little more enthusiastic or encouraging.
Definitely take this! Even if you don't think poetry is up your ally, it's a great class.

Did not receive a single positive comment from Monica Youn all semester on my poem. She was sort of disheartening as a professor. I was exposed to lots of new types of poetry and techniques for writing it. Would be a better class with a different professor.
Do it! Very low workload though personal interest in the matter will make the class go faster

I would advise students to actually spend time reading the books assigned to you by Prof Smith. She really wants you to take notice of others' work and to try new things that you see in your own poetry. I didn't do enough of that and I wish I would have. Also, critically evaluate your peers' work. In turn, you will have valuable things to add to class discussion when it is time to workshop.
I would recommend this course for anyone wanting to learn introductory poetry and how to write poetry, but also someone looking for a class that won't occupy too much time in the process.
Its a lot of work for a pdf class. If you are willing to put in the effort and have interest in poetry is well worth taking it. Tracy is great!

Just be open-minded and you get as much as you put in. It's very enjoyable and rewarding if you want to write poetry. Michael Dickman is really funny and nice about comments. I feel he changed the way I view the creative process of writing poetry, in a good way. Granted, you don't get a ton of critical/harsh feedback but that also made it a relaxing 5th class.
Lowkey loved this class. You'll get out of it what you put in. I never wrote poetry before, but still improved a lot. Take it with Dickman
Poetry courses are great! You'll love it!
Professor Smith is great- really pushes you outside your comfort zone, which helps you become a more adventurous writer
TAKE IT --only with dickman
TAKE IT. fun and interesting and low time commitment, especially if you get dickman; he's the best
Take Poetry for your LA requirement as well as to grow as a poet! If you can, try to take it with Tracy K. Smith!!
Take a course with Dickman! He's the best!
Take a creative writing course. They're absolutely wonderful! Professor Youn is really good!
Take it with Professor Dickman.

Take it with Tracy! Unlike other sections, each week you'll read a contemporary book of poetry, carefully selected for content and style. All of them speak to the question of "how does poetry make life more bearable, and worth living?" which revolutionized how I thought about and approached my work. You get out what you put in. And with such an inspiring professor, it's hard not to be inspired/to write a well-developed poem each week. An unforgettable course.

Take this class (I wish I had taken it more than once during my time at Princeton)! Professor Richardson is a great professor, and helps his students to explore different types of poetry while still making the whole process very comfortable. It is very nice being able to see your progress weekly, as opposed to other CWR classes that you may only submit writings to a couple times a semester.
Take this class and put effort into your work. You'll gain more, and enjoy yourself more as well
Take this course! Creative writing classes are always fun. Some of the readings may seem strange, but I still feel I learned a lot. Also, Michael Dickman was a great, inspiring professor!
Take this course! It's a fun and easy P/D/F and will introduce you to the world of poetry. The workshops can be a bit cumbersome, though.
This is a great class to take if you are looking to explore your more creative side and appreciate this art. It's also PDF.
This is a very laid back class. Michael Dickman is very entertaining.  A lot of the class depends on other students in it--so that's a toss-up.
This is an amazing course. Take it if you wanna feel.

Tracy is an amazing professor and workshop leader.  She understands the practical time constraints of this class while still managing to make sure everyone gets something out of the readings and workshops.

You get out of this course what you put into it, so do your best on weekly assignments and put thought into what you write. Try to give thoughtful comments to your peers as well; this improves the quality of the workshops.
You will have a great time in this class and learn a lot about yourself.
a
prereqs: Interested students complete an application (arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app) and include a writing sample of 3-4 pages of poetry. No prerequisites. Application deadline is November 22, 2015..
descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. This class is open to beginning and intermediate students by application.

title: Introduction to Later Sufism (ca. AD 1200 to present)
reviews: (If it gets cut off, the full review is available here: http://pastebin.com/6hY2j0b6 ) TAKE this course if Professor Barry offers it. Don't take Sufism to understand Islam if you don't have a background. However, take Sufism if you want to alter your thinking on yourself, the Universe, and the relationship between the two. Professor Barry is a genius and a true scholar in his various fields. He is also incredibly compassionate and patient, willing to answer questions, re-explain concepts, and make this course meaningful to you. Please please please don't take advantage of the lack of attendance-taking or his flexibility with your particular approach to the papers. He is incredibly bright and wants you to benefit from this course. It is not hard to do well. It is easy to waste this opportunity. If you want to take this as an easy fifth course, by all means, go ahead. Better that you take it than not? maybe a little something will stick with you. But it hurts me that a seminar class had to move to a lecture hall to accommodate the gigantic registration size of the class, and that the room was almost empty by the third week. This course is a gem, Professor Barry is a resource and a guide for life, and this is nothing less than an opportunity. Please don't waste it for yourself or for others.

Although this course may not be offered anytime in the near future, should this course be offered again, pounce on the opportunity to take it, ESPECIALLY if Dr. Barry is teaching. His breadth of knowledge will amaze you. It's also an excellent course to take if you're interested in exploring a relatively unknown denomination of one the world's major religions.
Amazing class with an amazing professor.

Amazing. Dr. Barry was so helpful. I felt like  he was one of the few professors who has really cared about my learning. I went to his office hours, and for the first time at Princeton (I am a junior) felt like this was a setting where students were genuinely intellectually curious about the subject, and that we could have amazing discussions. This was an amazing experience; thank you Dr. Barry!!!

Awesome class. Professor Barry is amazing. Go to every lecture because you will learn so much. Sufism is a difficult concept to grasp but you will get so much out of this class. Go to office hours or ask if you need help, Professor Barry is amazing. Greatest class I have taken so far at Princeton
Barry really knows what he's talking about
Best course!! Unfortunately he is leaving
Def take it!!!
Definitely take it! Very interesting, fun, and rewarding

Definitely take this course. One of the more intellectually engaging courses I've taken at Princeton that challenged my preconceptions without disrupting my work-life balance. It is a relatively low time commitment and grading is rather lenient. That said, grammar, syntax, and style are key, and Prof. Barry will forgive confusion over the strange material more than technical mistakes in your writing. If you put in the work you'll do fine, but don't take him for granted.
Definitely take this.
Do the readings well. They can be difficult to understand. Ask questions, and be wiling to discuss with Professor Barry.
Don't, the easy grading is not really worth the dullness of the lectures and the first graded assignment wasn't given back until after the course ended so I was forced to defensively PDF it.
Easiest A I've ever had, it's great for a 5th class.
Eh, take it for an EM. No other reason to take this course if you ask me.

Everyone should take a Michael Barry class before they graduate. I think you get more out of his class "Afghanistan". Sufism is decidedly more obscure. 
But regardless: #cultofbarry
Go to office hourse, there's so much to learn outside of the classroom!
Good senior spring class
Great class to take, and has a lot of material, that if treated with attention, allows wide insight into Islamic theology and history.
Great course. Professor Barry is a one-of-a-kind academic and intellectual.

I would recommend taking this class. Professor Barry is extremely kind and caring, and even if you do not have an immediate interest in the subject matter, you will definitely learn a lot and benefit from hearing him speak.
I would recommend this course to students looking for a unique perspective on life.
If Michael Barry is ever on Princeton's campus, find a means to talk to him. You will not regret it.
If they could see sense to allow Professor Barry to teach this class again, you should take it.
It's a shame that this class might not be offered anymore. I want to take more classes with Dr. Barry!!
Make sure you do the readings for the papers, and go to office horus.
Michael Barry is one of the coolest professors you could have. He knows all things.
Michael Barry is someone to experience before graduating.

Michael Barry is the best professor I've had at Princeton. He cares so deeply about his subject matter and his students. Letting him go is one of the most shameful things Princeton/NES department has decided to do.
Now that Berry's gone, you're missing out. Shucks.
One of the best courses I've taken. Definitely take it

Professor Barry is leaving so unfortunately you won't be able to take it - if any other course is offered like it with similar subject matter I would take it because Ibn Arabi and his writings are fascinating.

Professor Barry is one of my favorite professors of all time; he is so passionate about such an esoteric subject, and does a great job explaining everything. Definitely take this class if he finds a way to teach it again after the NES department screwed him over.
So sad its over, but take it if for some reason its not
TAKE IT!!!!!!!
Take if you would like to learn about Sufism.
Take it
Take it.
Take it. Easy and super interesting if you actually put in some effort.
Take it. If he is still around.
Take this course if it is ever offered again. Michael Barry is a treasure trove of knowledge
Take this course if you really want to open your worldview and view of self.
Take this course immediately. A very thorough exploration of the concepts of Sufism and extremely enjoyable at the same time.
The content is quite similar to Intro To Early Sufism, with the exception that this course is structured completely around Ibn Arabi.
They will be missing out on the best hidden jewel of Princeton.
This class is as much work as you want it to be. Prof. Barry is a generous grader who won't burden you with a ton of work. His lectures are eye-opening if you pay attention. Take his classes.

This is a very good course dealing with very abstract ideas, something very different from what I was used to coming from an engineering background, so I found the course very refreshing and insightful. Both the papers and the readings were on point, but more than that the lectures were excellent. Prof. Barry makes sure to guide you through very difficult topics such that by the end of the course you have achieved the intellectual maturity necessary to understand the very complex ideas of the Sufi thinker Ibn Arabi. I totally recommend this course and hope prof. Barry can teach it in the future!
You get what you put into it. If you're engaged, you'll learn a lot.
You might not learn as much as you expected. Barry's Afghanistan class is better, in my opinion.
You want to take anything Prof. Barry teaches
a
take it if you could
take it, if you ever get the chance. Prof. Barry is brilliant and warm hearted. he brings more to this university than most
descrip: Popularized through translations of world famous poets like the 13th century Rumi, the Sufi mystical strain pervaded Islamic culture for a thousand years and played a major historic role in furthering friendly relations between Muslims and other religious communities through endorsement of spiritual tolerance. The Spring session of this two-term course addresses the overwhelming influence of the Spanish-Muslim Ibn `Arabi (d. 1240 AD) on all subsequent higher Islamic mystical speculation and poetical literature - as far as India.

title: Latinos in American Life and Culture
reviews: I would advise them to do the readings and engage in the discussions.
I would tell them to keep up with the reading.
It depends on the professor. Unfortunately Princeton dropped the ball and Professor Sarabia won't be here anymore so definitely see who the professor is before you commit..
Keep up with readings and participate in weekly lectures and you'll be set.
Make sure you read. Make sure you do all of your work. Easy A, if you do so.

Professor Sarabia was amazing and it really sucks that you won't be able to have her. I'm so sorry. 

If she ever comes back, take her.

TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Sarabia, WHO IS AMAZING, won't be here next year but the class itself, I'm sure, will still be great even without her. Students will learn so much about the past, present, and future of the Latinx community. There is a substantial amount of reading for each class but it's doable.
Take it!! you don't have to be Latino to enjoy it. You will definitely learn alot
Take it!!!!!
Take the course! You walk away with a better understanding of the issues that affect Latinos in the US.
Take this course! Very interesting subject material
descrip: This course will consider how Latinos are transforming the United States socially, politically, and culturally, even as they themselves change in the process. Topics to be examined include meanings of "Latino" and "Hispanic" as ethno-racial categories, where Latinos fit in the American social and economic hierarchies, cultural identities, immigration and assimilation, the significance of Hispanics' unprecedented geographic dispersal, and their myriad impacts on mainstream music, literature, and language.

title: Embedded Computing
reviews: Find a project you enjoy, because I did enjoy mine. Learn the theory, and while the first unit on DFAs and statemachines does drag on for a while, it became really important on the tests.

I would highly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning about how real time embedded systems work. Professor Jha is very knowledgeable in this field, and takes the time to make sure everyone understands the fundamentals.
If you are interested in this area, it is a good course to take it.
It's a very good course if you work in the field of embedded systems.
It's pretty dull, hopefully will improve in future years.

Right now, this course is a mixture of topics from computational theory, computer architecture and coding theory without any overarching theme. As with any new course, it will take time to fully develop.
Take this course!

The course was very good and the professor was great, but did not always feel super cohesive in the subject matter, since we jumped from one topic to the next, so it felt more like a general exploration of the field, rather than going in too deep into one topic. However, this was the first year it was taught, so I'm sure that will improve by next year.
descrip: Introduction to embedded computing, cyberphysical systems and Internet-of-Things basic concepts; reliability, availability, power/energy consumption, security. Finite-state machines. Sensors and actuators. Embedded processors. Performance/power analysis. Real-time systems. System-on-chip architectures. Hardware-software co-design. High-level synthesis. Low-power embedded system design.

title: Health Psychology
reviews: A lot of work - precept assignments, 2 midterms, presentation, dean's date assignment, and a final. Would not really recommend unless you have to take it
Attend lecture!
Be engaged in lecture. Not a very difficult topic to understand.
Don't take this! But if you do, it's not really that necessary to attend lecture
Fun class to take, but remember to do all the readings. Exams were multiple choice/ short answer/ short paragraph responses.
Generally a good course. Very easy, but good for general knowledge about health in college!
Go ahead, take it, get some insight in neat stuff.
Go to all lectures and take really good notes!
Go to all the lectures because 90% of the exam comes from the lectures, and pay attention to the precept readings. Otherwise it's an easier class to manage than most!
Go to lecture and learn something new! Other parts of the class are not as fun. If you want a pretty laid-back psych class this is pretty good.
Good class, lots of memorization, still interesting and relevant. Teaches you how to have a healthy lifestyle mentally and physically.
Great class to take if interested in health psychology.

Great course! Prof. Brynildsen is amazing. She is always willing to guide students and help them in anything that they need to make the most of the course. She is very kind and completely accessible. I recommend getting to know her! The topic is interesting, the workload is definitely manageable, and the lectures are excellent. I would not hesitate to take it, or to take any course with this professor.
I had to take it because it was a departmental. Other psych majors should take this course. Not a bad course for others as well.

I thought lectures were really boring, the exams were kind of unfair, and there was a lot of busy work. It isn't a particularly difficult course, but if you can find another one that fulfills the requirement, I would. Not very interesting and the lectures were chock full of random studies that I don't think were at all legitimate.
I wasn't super passionate about the topic, but overall the class was interesting without too much work. Just go to every lecture.
I would advise other students to take this course if they have an interest in the topic.
If you are a pre-med student, definitely take this course!

If you have any interest in medicine or if you just want to take a fun course, take health psych! Professor Brynildsen is hands down one of the best lecturers I've ever had at Princeton. Be sure to take copious lecture notes though, especially on the studies she go over because they do come up on exams.

If you're looking for a pre-med psych class, an SA, or a departmental, this is perfect. It's much more time-consuming than you'd expect, but you learn more nuanced approaches to information that "you already know"
Interesting class with very straightforward material. Take if you are interested in learning more about the behavioral side of medicine and the psychology behind it.
Interesting, not-too-demanding SA.
It's a great class to take!

It's easy and great to PDF! If you're going for a grade though I think it would actually be mildly difficult to get an A, there is really no curve whatsoever because exams are very straightforward and everyone studies hard so you'd have to really go to all the lectures or review slides for a while.
Love this course.  Very straightforward and you always know what is expected of you.  You get a study guide for each exam which really helps. If you know that material, you are set.
Make sure to understand the main ideas of each study that the professor describes.
Not a difficult course but you need to put in the time to do well.
Not much work and one of the more interesting PSY courses I have taken.

Straightforward and easy class. Two 5-10 page studies to read and discuss each week and a final book chapter (8-10). Exams are good -- MC and no trick questions! But, material is pretty intuitive and what you would expect, so not necessarily the most engaging.
TAKE IT!  Whether for your department, GHP requirement, or for fun! It's totally worth it! One of the easiest and most interesting courses I've taken at Princeton!
TAKE THIS! This was definitely one of my favorite courses out of the ones that I have taken. Professor Brynildsen is so nice, and the materials are very interesting.
Take if you are interested--most of the material is common sense, so it's a great fifth class!
Take if you're interested in it! Not too hard-- if you do your work you'll do well.
Take if you're interested in psychology, but don't expect to learn anything too in depth.
Take it for a 5th class. Although the deans date assignment might take some time
Take it! And follow the study guide. If you go to lectures and take good notes, you should be fine.
Take it! It's really good, relevant info even if you're not a psych major. Keiko is an amazing person and an amazing professor.
Take it! Pretty easy and not a lot of work. Would be a super easy PDF and requires just some effort for a good grade.

Take it! The material is super interesting, and Keiko is a great lecturer. She keeps it very entertaining and not boring at all. It's also not a terribly large amount of work each week, just attend lecture and you'll do fine on the exams.
Take it. It's interesting and a light workload.
Take it. Just pay attention in class!
Take the course if you are interested in health! Not too tough and pretty interesting!
Take the course, but be prepared to follow the lectures well.
Take this class! It is super interesting. You will have to put in time towards the end of the semester (book chapter, exam, etc.) but that is fine considering what you will learn.
Take this course and go to lecture. It has everything you need for this course and the information is very interesting. The instructor is amazing and makes lectures very interesting.
Take this course if you are Psych or want a fun SA!

Take this course if you're interested in health! Good psychology departmental. A lot of the physiological health effects have to do with stress, so it is relevant to a college student. It's also a nice way to learn about clinical implications of psychology research for students who are pre-med and whose other classes may seem far-removed from clinical applications (i.e. chem, physics, bio at times)
Take this course!

Take this course! The exams are incredibly fair, and the material is interesting if you have any interest in medicine or clinical psychology. It is a fairly low time commitment and Keiko is a wonderful lecturer. The grading is uncurved so you don't have to worry about the large concentration of premeds in the class, and not challenging. You will learn a lot without realizing that you did because the instructors make learning and studying health psychology so painless.
Take this course--it is fun and interesting and you learn a lot about health and how to be a healthy human being :)
Take this if you are at all interested and/or need it for GHP.
This a great course for anyone interested in health or the medical field. All of the exam material is taken directly from lectures. If you attend all lectures, you'll be fine.
This course does a good job being clear and engaging without "dumbing down" the material too much.  Recommend!
This is a great course and very interesting. All topics are relevant to daily life and might even make you think twice about how your daily decisions are affecting your health!

This is a nice, easy course. I'm not sure how much I learned (much of the material was simplistic and intuitive) but Keiko is wonderful and the studies discussed were interesting if you thought about them.
Very cool topics, recommend for anyone interested in health psych at all and not hard work load at all
Very fun and interesting course! Some of it is intuitive but you will learn a lot! Pay attention in class or record the lectures.

Work hard and go to class, it is fascinating - take good notes and go to office hours. You will learn so much about how powerful your mind is - either for positive or negative health outcomes. Absolutely amazing class
take if you are interested!
take it! it's really interesting if you're a human; you learn about your brain and how it relates to your body. it's not much work and all the staff are very nice.
take notes on EVERYTHING
prereqs: One prior psychology course..
descrip: The objectives of this course are to understand the psychosocial processes that influence health and health care delivery. Topics to be examined are the psychophysiological and sociocultural bases of health and illness; pain; adaptation to chronic illness; stress; personality and illness; death, dying, and grief; substance use; health promoting behaviors; patient adherence; physician-patient communication; health care; and medical ethics and utilization.

title: Tropical Biology
reviews: Tropical biology is super interesting. Yves is super cool and very knowledgeable. Pick a system you like for your independent work!

Very fun, but with a high learning curve if you have never done independent field research before (most of the class). Ask a ton of questions and do a draft as soon as you can, because Yves and Ioana can only help you if you ask for it.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester tropical biology program in Panama..
descrip: "Tropical Biology" is an intensive, three-week field course given at four sites in Panama, examining the origins, maintenance and major interactions among terrestrial plants and animals. The course provides the opportunity to appreciate (1) floral and faunal turnover among four rainforest sites (beta-diversity); and (2) floral and faunal turnover along vertical gradients, from ground to upper canopy, at two rainforest sites (vertical stratification). Students carry out individual projects at the sites. Fieldwork is supported by six orientation walks that introduce participants to common orders and families of plants and arthropods.

title: Mechanics of Fluids
reviews: AWESOME CLASS!!

Almost everyone in fluids needs to be in fluids, but I would recommend it even if you aren't in MAE. Jesse's precepts were amazing, and all three TAs (Jesse, Yao, and Clay) had very helpful office hours. I usually found it helpful to read through the psets before precept and then do them afterwards, but they don't take long and can be done Tuesday night if need be. Go to lecture but don't bother with the readings.
Definitely take this course! Marcus and the preceptors are absolutely great and the material is really cool too! Just make sure you understand multivariable calculus pretty well.
Fair
Fluids is really cool material- you realize it applies to everything.
Fluids is solidly mediocre. Befriend the TA's, because Marcus is not very helpful in actually learning anything that will be on exams.
Great course with interesting lectures and topics. Precepts are vital for problem sets.
Highly recommend going to the TA office hours and to precept, as they were incredibly useful (especially with Jesse).
Highly recommend, though its probably required anyway. Marcus is great. Fluids is fascinating
If you're taking this course, it's probably because you have to.  Marcus is nice, not the best lecturer, but the class isn't terribly hard.

The great thing about the two semesters of diff eq offered here is that they both are taught radically differently and with different intents. Stone's section is reportedly harder and takes a lot of time but is more engaging and you learn a lot of out of it and he has support for struggling students. So if you identify learning as a spiritual experience, then maybe his class is better for you. But Yannis' class is designed for people who stick by the book, are in it to build a basic foundation, and are for people who need to just either need credit or "need to know diff eq". That might make it seem like Yannis' class is bad, but that would be hugely disrespectful to what his course offers and to Yannis himself. Yes, the teaching could be better, but this is something Yannis consciously acknowledges that he has a lot of improve on and puts in the effort to do so. He cares a lot. The book is actually great and readable, and makes a good complement to the course. The preceptors and Yannis put in a great deal in having office hours, being responsive to emails, and caring. And the fact that this course is designed to teach "practical diff eq" does not mean that you will learn nothing, and in fact I would say I learned quite a lot. The course is deliberately taught this way. So having said all of this, I was very satisfied actually by what the course offered even if at times it wasn't thrilling. But it is up to you to decide which is best for you and figure out what you want for yourself, and which learning style is "easy" or "hard". "Wait. but how can make those comparisons when you never took Stone's section" well yes, that is true and I will leave your evaluations of such biases yourself.

prereqs: This course is a continuation of CHM 201; also open to CHM 207 students. Students must have an AP score of at least 4,
descrip: Continuation of 201. Principles of chemistry; introduction to chemical bonding and solid state structure; chemical kinetics, descriptive inorganic chemistry; laboratory manipulations, preparations, and analysis. Fulfills medical school entrance requirements in general chemistry and qualitative analysis. Three lectures, one class, one three-hour laboratory.

title: Seminar in Medieval Art - Byzantine and Medieval Manuscripts
descrip: The course explores the fields of Byzantine and western manuscript illumination through categories of medieval books that offer scope for dissertation in both traditions. Case studies of key examples structure the sessions and the reading list. Course bibliography includes both fundamental and recent works; an emphasis on method and historiography in art history's approach to manuscript studies is a focus of the class. The course concludes with a formal colloquium and will include time in both Princeton and New York collections.

title: Researching the Politics of Identity in the Real World
descrip: What does the real world have to teach us about politics and society? A wealth of statistical data often discourages researchers, policy-makers, and non-profit professionals, from ever leaving their offices. Why then should one ever leave their office (or dorm room) to learn about the world? This seminar focuses on the politics of identity as a lens to explore the contributions of qualitative field research methods in understanding causal relationships, developing new theories and adding to our knowledge about politics. We will tackle these questions through classroom discussions and an independent, student-designed field research project.

title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
reviews: Be sure to review lab manuals prior to your first day of lab and meet with AI's if necessary. Sometimes the labs are straightforward and a five minute conversation prior to lab will suffice. Other times, a thirty minute sit down with you AI is necessary to understand all of the intricacies of your experiment. It varies. Start lab reports and oral presentations early. Don't get stuck completing a lab report late one night and then having to rush through and make an oral presentation because you have them due the same day or one day after the other. Do everything in a timely manner.
Can't avoid it - just grit your teeth and hunker through.

Core Lab is honestly not as bad as it is made out to be. It is a large time commitment (7.5 hours weekly in lab or class, plus analysis that you do), but we actually spent less time producing our written & oral reports and poster than we anticipated, and it's not bad when you're actually in the lab. While you do in some instances get to see cool applications of things you have learned in your other core courses, the labs themselves are not particularly interesting or useful. That being said, this course builds some very useful and fundamental skills in oral presentation, data analysis, data presentation, and technical report writing. Choose a partner you don't mind spending a lot of time working together with. Working style compatibility is probably more important, but if you have a good friend that satisfies that requirement, you will enjoy this experience more because you'll be able to sit there and make jokes even while scrambling to finish at 3 am the day of your presentation.
Core lab is great. Be sure to work on analysis during the weeks you're in lab, don't just save it all for the week you're working on the report.

Don't take this course. If you're a CBE, you have to, so make absolutely positive to not piss off a specific professor, especially Benziger, who will then unfairly destroy you for the entirety of the term. Don't expect a shred of fairness in this course, and just grit your teeth and do your best to not break down.
If you're CBE, you have to take this.

If you?re a junior reading this, you?ve come too far. I?m sorry. Just try (somehow) to get the professors to like you early in the course, and you?ll probably survive. Do data analysis as you go, and spend a lot of time practicing your oral presentation and predicting what questions you?ll be asked so you can prepare responses to them.

If you?re a freshman or sophomore in CBE or considering CBE, don?t major in CBE. If you?re interested in environmental and sustainability things, do CEE. If you?re interested in the more physical engineering aspects of the major, do MAE. If you like chemistry, there?s no chemistry in this major?do Chem. If you?re pre-med or interested in bio things, do MOL. If you?re interested in the quantitative problem-solving aspects, do COS. There?s literally no reason to do this major. You got through CBE 245, which was easy but boring, and thought the difficulty level would stay the same while getting to more interesting topics, so you stuck with CBE. Then you took thermo, which was really hard, but you survived it so you assumed you were through the worst. Then you take separations, which is a lot of memorization but is reasonable, so you think things are looking up. You take transport, and it?s really hard but you think you?ve come far enough now that you may as well stick with it. You?ve heard core lab is awful, but you?re ?good at lab things? so you think you?ll be fine. You won?t. This course doesn?t test your lab skills or your analysis skills, but rather how good you are at sucking up to professors and making them like you. It tests how good your karma is, because which labs you?re assigned and which professors are grading them is the most important thing in determining your grade. Switch majors, not just for this class (although this is an awful class), but because nothing about this major is worth it.

If you?re an administrator, believe me when I say this course needs a hard look. This is, by far, the worst class I?ve been put through at Princeton. I got nothing out of it, because the only skills it purports to teach (writing lab reports, giving presentations) were skills I already had. Instead, I spent a whole semester working as hard as anyone to please professors who seem to decide randomly which students to like and help, and which students to make fun of and give D grades to. I know this class is supposed to be hard, and I?m fine with that, as long is students are given adequate help and the grades that they earn, which is not how this class is run. Professors Koel and Prud?homme at least try to be helpful and fair?while they do grade harshly, that?s fine as long as it?s done equally to everyone, which it seems to be. I am amazed, however, that professor Benziger is allowed to teach courses at Princeton. He randomly picks a about 4 students to like and help and give unreasonably high grades to. Everyone else he gives horrible grades with no explanation, asks absurdly hard questions, unreasonable questions in oral presentations. There is no way that a well-performed, well-analyzed, and well-explained lab report should get a score in the low 60s, which happened to several friends of mine. There?s no way that physical questions that the TAs don?t know the answers to should be asked in oral presentations. I?m sure he is very knowledgable, but that doesn?t matter if he refuses to help any of us or actually teach us anything. I got absolutely nothing out of this course except frustration with this department for allowing this class to continue as it seems to have been for years without making any attempt to make it less awful.
Ignore the professors, just get help from the TAs.
Keep on top of data analysis, really do try and do it before the next lab in case you find errors.
Lol its CBE core lab.
Not as rough as expected, but still a rough ride nonetheless

Professors: Koel is strict, but somewhat fair. Be sure to make your references of large font in your presentation and succinct. P'homie: Nicest of the 3 profs. Won't actively help you but more than willingly to answer your questions with straight answers if you need help understanding a concept or apparatus. Benziger: Brilliant man, but has a bit of an ego. Flatter him, and he'll help you. Ask him for help because otherwise, he'll tank you and your grade by asking you graduate-level questions far beyond your capacity. Gives absolutely useless advice and it's ironic how in his presentations, he often does the very things he says not to.
Labs: Some are easy, some are hard. The hard ones are anything to do with dimensionless quantities (like heat transfer, polymer extrusion, fluidized beds). Easy ones include enzyme kinetics, control schemes (not level nor mixing but temp control), distillation, etc. It's unfair that some people will get 4 easy labs, and some people will get 4 hard labs, but sucks to suck. Try to put the minimum work on reports and posters and oral presentations since the grading is a crapshoot. Honestly, the 3 professors will collaborate to determine your oral presentation grade, which means that a professor who thinks you deserve a 95 will cross that 95 out and give you an 85 if the other 2 profs feel that way. It's a shit system.
Written report: You do not have to complete every point mentioned in the handout. Rather, pick a few to focus on and tie together .The other ones, complete (with minimal effort) in the appendices. Talk to your grading professor about what to focus on and what they would like to see. Expectations vary across the 3.
Oral report: Speak LOUDLY, make eye contact, and practice. 50% of your grade is based on how well you exude confidence and dominate that room. Make sure your PPT slides are spotless, because you don't want to give the profs any extra ammo for criticizing you. 50% of your grade is on your data. Like a true scientist, pick and choose your data to show only the best of the best. Otherwise, you will get screwed because what really matters in science, of course, is how well your data looks.
Start lab reports early and ask for help from TAs
Stay on top of your work and be meticulous.
Sucks. The amount of work the profs expect you do is insane. Just grind through it and soon enough it'll be over.

The course is somewhat inconsistent in terms of grading and can be frustrating at times, but the experiments themselves are often interesting.  Make sure you have time in your schedule (would not advise taking five classes - like I did)

This course is a lot of work, but it's not as bad as people like it out to be. Some of the labs are boring, some are really interesting, and a small number are really difficult. Plan ahead and prepare early especially when you have a written report due. Don't stress too much about the course.

Try to find someone in the higher classes to tell you about expectations on lab reports and such, as well as the flow of the class,  I think it helps a lot if you know what to expect from another student and I did not really.
You don't really have a choice, just make sure to start working on the reports early.

You learn a lot about how to present material which is helpful but the grading seems subjective and sometimes effort does not translate into a grade. Obviously you are only taking this course if it is required.
You learn a lot, but you put in a ton of time.
You've made it this far. You've heard the horror stories. It's bad but you'll get through it. Grading is completely subjective.
be prepared to spend a lot of time. meet with the professors and TAs. it'll be fine, and you learn a lot!!! Core lab was actually probably my favorite class this semester
prereqs: CBE 246, CBE 250, and CBE 341 or equivalents..
descrip: An intensive hands-on practice of engineering. Experimental work in the areas of separations, heat transfer, fluid mechanics, process dynamics and control, materials processing and characterization, chemical reactors. Development of written and oral technical communication skills.

title: Latin Language and Stylistics
prereqs: LAT 203 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: A study of Latin prose style through the analysis of texts selected from a range of authors and weekly practice in translation from English to Latin.

title: Intermediate Hebrew II
reviews: Maya Meshel taught this course for one semester only, so this review probably isn't relevant. The class was well taught.
Recommend to take it! It's not that hard to learn as long as you study and take good notes/do the homework. You can really learn if you put the time in
This course depends a lot on who's teaching it and this professor is leaving, so I doubt I can say anything helpful here.
This course is heavily focused on grammar. If you already speak basic hebrew, I do not recommend taking this course and would advise you to skip to advanced courses.
prereqs: HEB 105 or equivalent.
