descrip: This course is designed for students who have completed elementary modern Hebrew language courses, and aims at further developing their reading, writing, speaking and aural comprehension skills. Emphasis will be placed on grammar and syntax, on conversational skills, and on creative writing. By the end of the spring term, students will achieve mastery of the Hebrew verb patterns, and proficiency in constructing complex sentences, and will be able to read and analyze literary works, discuss various media contents, write essays and make presentations.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Thin Film Processng and Fabrication
reviews: Highly recommeded for student intereseted in thin film group, electronic device and semiconductor processing.
I would recommend taking this class for anyone who is interested in electronic devices and fabrication.
If you're going to be working in the clean room on thin films, this is a great class.

It would be a good idea to have some background in EE concepts. Overall, it's a great survey course if you're interested in thin film processing and the semiconductor industry at all. The course covers some of the physics and chemistry of thin film processing, deposition techniques, and vacuum and pump systems. It could get dry at times, but it might be worth it at the end. Professor Sturm has organized this class entirely based on his experiences in the lab. Although it needs some work, I think it will improve in the future. As for homework problems, it would be a good idea to work in groups. Although I didn't have that luxury due to senior thesis and whatnot, I would have saved a lot of time and possibly even understood the concepts better had I worked with others.
descrip: This course examines methods used for thin film processing and fabrication, primarily as used for electronic and optoelectronic devices and/or circuits. Both fundamentals and practical laboratory issues are covered. Topics include vacuum coating, vacuum and pumping technology, chemical vapor deposition, reactive ion etching, epitaxy, cleaning, p-n junction formation (diffusion, ion implantation, annealing).

title: Who Was or Is Jesus?
reviews: Great course! Research papers require a bit of time-- this is not a "blow-off" course, but it is well worth the time.

I liked this course but I would probably recommend a different course with Prof. Pagels. She's an incredible teacher and this course is a little all over the place at times. However, she's always improving the material so I imagine every iteration will be better and better.
I think that this excellent course to take if you are interested in learning more about who Jesus actually was.
If you can take a class with professor Pagels, take it.
Pagels is AMAZING- readings were very well selected and always intriguing discussions but beware of 3 hour length of seminar

TAKE THIS CLASS! Elaine Pagels is absolutely brilliant. Even if you have no background knowledge of Christianity, this course is fascinating. Conversation is class was incredibly interesting as everyone came from such diverse religious backgrounds, from Buddhist, to Muslim, to Christian, to atheist.
Take Pagels.  Read Pagels.  Take Pagels.
Take any class with Professor Pagels, she is fantastic. This class is very limited in the range of material that is covered, so prepare to get very close with the Gospels.
Take anything you can with Professor Pagels, she's magical and the class is a lot of fun, reading the gospels etc

Take the course. You will learn so much no matter what type of religious background or level of study you may come from. The material is fascinating, very well structured, and there is no one more qualified than Professor Pagels to teach the seminar.

This course is very good. Professor Pagels really knows her stuff (this is an understatement), and the way she has this seminar set up makes everything engaging. I learned a ton about Christianity, especially the early, interesting stuff. Take this class if at all possible. One of my favorites so far, if not my absolute favorite.
descrip: What do we actually know about Jesus of Nazareth? We'll look at the earliest sources--both positive & negative, since none are neutral!--the various accounts in the New Testament, as well as what ancient Jewish & Roman sources say: was he an actual person, &, if so, what kind of person--prophet, rabbi, healer, revolutionary? We'll also investigate ancient gospels nearly unknown, since they were censored by church leaders, including the Gospel of Thomas & Gospel of Mary Magdalene. Then we'll explore an enormous range of ways that various people, Christian or not, have interrupted Jesus in art, poetry, theology, fiction, films, & video.

title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema
reviews: A unique and entertaining topic for a course. The movies help facilitate language comprehension.  I greatly enjoyed the course.

Definitely take this course! The movies and discussions are so interesting and engaging. Be sure to speak up in class, participation is really important. Always check the syllabus and rubric for assignments and presentations!!!
Definitely would recommend with the knowledge that it is a lot of work.
Eh. Dont take it if you dont have to. Take 207. Your spanish will improve more in 207

Excellent and fun course all-around. However, the need to notice thematic and technical aspects in the movies and make connections made the weekly process of watching the movie and writing responses / preparing presentations more time consuming that you might expect.
Fun 200 level class

Fun and Gorka is great, but it is a lot of presentations.  If you're the kind of person who needs a lot of time to prepare for presentations, be aware of that.  Also I don't think it's easy to get an A if that's what you're banking on
Gorka is a hard grader but the class itself is low workload. Take if you prefer presenting and short blog posts over long essays

Gorka will give you the same grade throughout the entire course, which can be discouraging if you're really trying to improve. The class is interesting but definitely a lot of work in the second half of the semester.
Great course, please take it, really makes you want to get a Spanish Certificate.

I really loved this class and I felt I got a lot out of it. Gorka has really interesting opinions and is very good at teaching the material, but it's up to you to really watch the movies so that you can participate in class in a way that is rewarding and engaging. I got a lot out of watching every movie twice in order to analyze them more fully, but I think if you do only one viewing the amount of work the class has is more than manageable. Highly recommended as a fifth class!

It's a great course. Take it with Gorka if you can. JUST KNOW THIS: unlike your other Spanish classes, this will not be an easy A. Quite the opposite. To even have the chance of getting an A-, you will be working really, really hard. It's a bit demoralizing when you feel like you crushed a presentation and you end up getting a B, but that's the truth with this class. You cannot PDF it either. That being said, it is an amazing class, and your Spanish will dramatically improve
TAKE IT! Such an engaging class and I improved a ton. And take it with Gorka - he is phenomenal. Best professor I have ever had.
Take it if you have the chance! It's a fun course, and will definitely improve your speaking ability.
Take it!
Take the course.

Take this class. Gorka is absolutely amazing, but do keep in mind that he grades a little harsher than some of the other instructors. Overall this is one of those classes that you can easily get a B  in, but that you have to work really hard to get close to an A. Nevertheless, the movies are absolutely amazing and this was a great way to to improve my Spanish, while also learning a lot about cinema.
Take this course with Gorka! He's a bit of harsh grader but the best teacher who really challenges you and makes you improve your speaking and writing skills.
Take this course, but realize there is significantly more work in the second half of the semester than the first.
The amount of work in the second part of the semester seems ridiculous compared to the first. The movies are usually good. Be prepared to give a lot of presentations and work with a partner.

This class definitely helps improve your spoken Spanish and lets you learn so much about cinema in general. Nadia is an excellent professor who provides really helpful feedback on everything - presentations, discussion posts, compositions etc. Take it!
This course is a fantastic way to practice speaking while learning about the cultures of different Spanish-speaking countries. 10/10 would recommend.
Very great class; the movies are interesting and engaging; very doable if you are semi-fluent (my highest-level Spanish class before this was SPA 107)

Would absolutely recommend this class, especially with Gorka. Great movie selection and generally light workload, but it's difficult to get out of the B/B  zone. Lots of presentations and class discussions so be prepared to speak a lot. Overall, fun class!
if you like spanish at all, take this class, and take it with Gorka; he's a hallmark of the Princeton Spanish department
prereqs: SPA 107 with instructor's permission or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or a satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: A course designed to improve speaking abilities while learning about Hispanic cultures and cinema in context. The course aims to provide the students with lexical and grammatical tools to allow them to engage in formal and informal discussion on a variety of topics informed by the films provided. Additionally, there will be several writing exercises throughout the semester that will help students improve their writing abilities. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of all linguistic skills, especially listening comprehension, fluidity and accuracy in their speech.

title: Economics of Food and Agriculture
reviews: Definitely recommend for ECO majors
Don't underestimate finals.

Great for Econ majors! Straightforward class; interesting material (especially if you're like me and don't give a crap about first-world monetary policy problems aka most Econ classes here); easy psets EVERY OTHER week, straight from lecture notes; not too quantitative. Think WWS/ENV type class in terms of lecture slides with simple facts you have to memorize for multiple choice portions of exams/psets, and occasional simple micro graphs providing the ECO portion of the class. Weyerbrock is also the sweetest professor so don't be afraid to ask her for help or just talk to her!

I took this course because I thought it was easy and would boost my departmental GPA. Well, it did just the opposite, and I had to suffer through a semester of boring lectures for it. Do yourself a favor and find something else. It wasn't easy or interesting.

If you are really interested in this subject, then you may enjoy this class and gain from it. I am not an Econ major and found the Econ principles to not be too difficult, but there is a lot of other material in this course. Lectures are not always the most interesting.
If you love agriculture take it.
Not as engaging but really good content. Take this for a lass-mathy easy B
Ok course, but could be much more proactive.
On the face, this course seems interesting, but it's very dry and boring. The economics department offers a lot of interesting departmentals, take something else.

Silvia is an extremely dry presenter, which makes going to lecture difficult. Unfortunately, she states answers to questions that will be verbatim presented on problem sets and tests in lectures that aren't on the slides she posts. Material is quite interesting though. There's a heavy focus on learning models and applying them, which isn't the best, but we also had a ton of Economist articles which were fantastic.

Sylivia is a gem, the content is a bit boring at times but the professor does a good job of trying to keep it interesting. Not super hard, but not easy. Most important thing is to make sure you attend all lectures.
Take for a chill class but if interested will enjoy it
Take it if you are interested in food system, especially in American food policies and practices
The professor is so sweet and actually cares about our understanding. I think that the material itself was also quite interesting. I would moderately recommend.
This is a pretty good departmental. Not terribly difficult and relatively interesting.
You will get back from this course as much as you put in. If you come to all the lectures and do the readings, you will learn a great deal about important topics in agriculture and food systems.
a
if you need an econ elective, i would suggest taking this class. It was interesting and the material is relevant to current events throughout the world.
take it!
prereqs: ECO 100 required. We will study both theoretical economic models and review empirical papers to help us understand concerns and controversies related to food and agriculture..
descrip: Hunger and under-nutrition are widespread in poor countries while an obesity crisis is growing in rich countries. Rural-urban income inequality occurs throughout the world and farming and food industry practices everywhere have significant adverse effects on public health and the environment/climate. What are the economic causes of these problems? Are agricultural, food, nutrition and environmental policy measures currently proposed to deal with these problems effective? This course uses theoretical and empirical economic analysis to study the agricultural and food sector and related government policies in rich and poor countries.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing wtih the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students/post-docs.

title: Introduction to Engineering Dynamics
reviews: Avoid taking this class with Dogariu at all costs

Definitely not a course to take if it isn't a departmental; it's challenging, and you will need to actually enjoy the material. If you are an MAE, you will have to take it, so it doesn't really matter.
Do not take this class with Dogariu unless you are forced to. It is much more difficult than it needs to be and take a lot of time and commitment outside of classes to learn the material
Dynamics is all the cool parts of physics 103/105 turned into a full course on their own - it's awesome!
Follow along lectures with the textbook else it's easy to get lost.
Go to ben's office hours. and stay on top of the readings.
Go to precept and officer hours.
I mean, if you're MAE, you have to take it.  Force yourself to pay attention in lecture even though it's super boring.  It'll help on psets.  Learn how to use MATLAB early, there's no escaping it.
If Kasdin isn't teaching it, its just not worth taking.
If you take this class, make sure to read the textbook closely and take some notes along the way. That really helped me deeply understand the concepts and intuition behind the class.
It will probably be very different if Kasdin is teaching it again.
Just don't mess up the notation or fall behind and it's a rally easy course
Once you understand the notation differences, this class is just a glorified PHY103. Arthur is not a good lecturer. He just regurgitates info from the textbook.
Problem sets can get very long and tedious. Professor is not good at lecturing so try to learn from the book/precept. Exams are fair.

Professor Kasdin was on sabbatical, so I cannot speak to how the course was normally taught. Not my favorite, but it was Professor Dogariu's first time teaching this course so some difficulty was to be expected.
Super interesting. A new way to think about classic physics problems.
The material is really interesting and I'm sure it's great with Kasdin (there was a substitute this semester, so don't pick based on this semester's reviews).
The materials and problems are interesting and best worked on with a group. Be ready to learn from the book rather than lecture.
The readings are a good complement to the lectures, so doing the reading right before/after lecture is good to reinforce the material.
The textbook is fantastic, but lectures with Dogariu were not very helpful.  Overall a fair course, not overly challenging.

This class is really fun. The material is challenging, but it is very applicable and cool stuff, and an involves a very visual way of thinking. Precepts were a bit of a waste of time, but the textbook is amazing, and it is a great resource for the course.
This course is challenging but very rewarding for effort, don't leave the problem sets for later.
This will be the only time Dogariu is teaching it (hopefully), so Kasdin will be a better lecturer.
You learn really awesome stuff, and why stuff works, but lecture and precept are not great.
You probably have to take this class if youre looking. Grading was really generous if you have Artur, though be prepared to do alot of group work to solve psets
be prepared to do a lot of learning on your own. go through the examples in the book as a lot of what is being covered is in those examples.
prereqs: MAT 201 and PHY 103. MAE 223 or CEE 205 recommended. Freshmen may take the course with the instructor's permission..
descrip: Formulation and solution of equations governing the dynamic behavior of engineering systems. Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics. Two and three dimensional kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies. Motion relative to moving reference frames. Impulse-momentum and work-energy relations. Free and forced vibrations of mechanical systems. Introduction to dynamic analysis of mechanical devices and systems.

title: American Art and Visual Culture - American Realisms and the Perils of Painting
reviews: ART463 is a fantastic course. Initially intimidating for newcomers to art history (especially freshmen) because most students who take this course are junior/senior art history majors, but confidence grows as the course progresses and the class is a supportive atmosphere. Professor DeLue is incredible, generous and smart and willing to work through the research paper formulation with students in office hours and over emails. The topics of this course is interesting, delving into realism as traditionally and untraditionally defined (Georgia O'Keefe, for example). Work load is not too heavy, with readings ranging from 75 to 100 pages a week. Highly recommend (makes me wish I was an art history major!)
Best seminar I've ever taken! Professor DeLue is down right amazing and the course material is very interesting and leads you to redefine all that you thought you knew about American art.
Definitely take this course if you like art history! DeLue is a great professor and she makes it interesting!
Do the readings and engage in the discussions.
I would advise going to office hours and taking in all Prof. DeLue has to offer.

One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. This school can be a real suckhole sometimes, but classes like this remind you that we are at a cathedral of knowledge, and that our goal in life should be to accumulate wisdom, however cheesy it might sound. I got that from this class, and you will too. Prof. DeLue is a great. All in all, 10/10.

Professor DeLue is incredibly engaging, discussions were very interesting (though this may be due to the fact that the class was composed almost entirely of Art majors and everyone was very good about getting the reading done), and if you haven't taken an art class before, this is definitely an interesting course to dive into! The only work is weekly readings (which you should definitely do), one midterm project, and a term research paper
Professor DeLue is the best, and this is a really great course through which to understand American art. One of my favorite courses at Princeton.
Take it!
Take this course! Professor DeLue is wonderful and the subject matter is interesting.
This is a fantastic course: Prof. DeLue is brilliant and kind, the readings are compelling, and the classroom environment is joyful!
While this class was very intense and heavy on the readings, I learned a great deal and really enjoyed the analysis. I would recommend taking it if you have an interest in the subject matter.
take it!
descrip: What is realism? How do works of art capture the realities of existence and experience, history and time? What happens when they fail, or when they do their job too well? With such questions in mind, this undergraduate seminar considers realism in American art, focusing on major figures such as Winslow Homer, Thomas Eakins, Henry Ossawa Tanner, Edward Hopper, and Georgia O'Keeffe. We will examine works of art in terms of their historical contexts and also how they intersect with other fields, including religion, science, and literature. Visits to museums, including the PUAM, will be an important aspect of the course.

title: Classical Arabic Poetry
descrip: This course introduces students to the major Arabic poets and poems from the pre-Islamic period up to and including the Mamluk period. The goal of the course is twofold: to increase the ease with which students are able to read classical Arabic poetry and to expand their knowledge of the various styles, genres and their development. Besides preparing the assigned poems, students are expected each week to put together a brief biographical sketch of the poets we are reading using primary sources exclusively. (This could be done collaboratively) Advanced knowledge of Arabic required.

title: Directed Research II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research II has to be taken before the General Exam.

title: Biological Oceanography
reviews: I strongly recommend this class to those who want to explore the ocean.
Recommend. Bess is an expert and you won't be bored. Expectations are high but workload-to-learning ratio is very much in your favor and you will gain serious academic and professional skills.

Solid survey of topics in biological oceanography, with strong emphasis on phytoplankton and zooplankton. If you're more interested in marine microbiology, take Prof. Ward's other course (GEO417). If you're more interested in fisheries and trophic interactions, look at the EEB catalog. Two aspects of this course that really shine are Prof. Ward's lecturing style and the student presentations on important papers from the literature (though be aware they account for almost half of all the class sessions).
Take this class, take this class, take this class. You learn a lot and Professor Ward is Awesome.

This course is an excellent overview to biological oceanography with worthwhile reading from the scientific literature, and a well-organized and constructive professor.  Student presentations are good practice in interpreting papers and presentations skills, with lots of helpful feedback.
This is an interesting class but Bess speaks so fast and mumbly, it can be hard to understand lectures.
fun, not super stressful class that presents interesting material
prereqs: College level chemistry, biology and physics.
descrip: Fundamentals of Biological Oceanography, with an emphasis on the ecosystem level. We will consider the organisms in the context of their chemical and physical environment; the properties of seawater, atmosphere and ocean dynamics that affect life in the ocean; primary production and marine food webs; global cycles of carbon and other elements; current research approaches. In addition to lectures by the professors, the course will delve deeply into the current and classic literature of oceanography and students will be expected to participate in seminar type presentations and discussions.

title: Exhibition-Making in Architecture
reviews: Take a course with Sylvia--or two or three.
i would highly recommend the class for developing a historical critical position for thesis.
take it!
descrip: This seminar examines the history and theory of exhibition-making in architecture from its origin as a tool in the production of architectural publics in the 18th century to its contemporary aegis as a producer of architectural curators. The history of exhibitions as such is considered in light of the auxiliary frameworks that shape, amplify and subtend them, from criticism to installation design, from the catalog to contemporary social media.

title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)
reviews: Be prepared to do your best to balance your rotations and other courses.
I recommend rotations for anyone choosing a lab to do their PhD thesis in
It's a good chance to know whether this is the lab you want to stay for the next four or five years.
Rotations are a terrific way to learn different scientific techniques, how different labs operate, and the kind of research   environment you want during graduate school.
Rotations are fun
descrip: Students perform research in the laboratories of potential faculty advisors.

title: Music since 1945
reviews: DO IT. Professor Dennehy is by all means one of the most intriguing, succinct, and influential lecturers in Princeton University.

Donnacha is an amazingly engaging lecturer. Quinn is a great preceptor and pretty fun too! Take this if you have interest in music. I went in without any appreciation for serialism or all that other weird stuff, but now I dig it.
Even if you're not sure whether you'll enjoy all of the music covered during this period, take it, as it can change and expand your musical horizons.
I hated modern music before taking this class, and Prof. Dennehy changed my mind. One of the greatest classes I've taken. Absolutely take it if you can, Dennehy is amazing.
Take if you are even slightly interested in music!
Take it!
Take the course!
Take this course if you're at all interested!
This course has a heavier workload than you might expect.  However, I learned so much about the topic and ended up finding the music really interesting.  The lectures were excellent.

This course is a great introduction to avant-garde music for even those with minimal musical exposure. Donnacha is a great lecturer, and helps you to understand the seeming mess that is "modern" music.
descrip: A look at the wide range of musical styles and personalities since World War II, including avant-garde and experimental approaches, the effects of technology, and influences from non-Western and popular idioms. Emphasis will be on listening and discussion, with the goal of understanding the attitudes, objectives and achievements of individuals and groups as well as their interaction with the culture at large.

title: Topics in French Literature and Culture - Rousseau
prereqs: 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: Perhaps no one in the 18th Century has been more influential and more controversial than Rousseau. Indeed he was right when he described himself as "un homme a paradoxes". How can a self-made man who abandoned his children write a treatise on education? How can someone who paints the progress of arts and sciences as symptoms of man's corruption choose the career of an artist, a writer and a philosopher? How can the same man theorize the foundations of political right and confess publicly his most frivolous sexual desires? We will explore Rousseau's writings in light of their historical context as well as their broader intellectual legacy.

title: Word and Image: 19th Century Literature and Art
reviews: Absolutely take this course if you are at all interested in novels or art, especially in the way that they intersect. Rainof is a gem of a professor that cares so much about her students.
Really interesting course with great readings - and Professor Rainof is super nice!
Take if interested in exploring the intersection between art and literature
Take it! Professor Rainof is a gem, and you will learn a lot about actually understanding the art that you see in museums etc.
descrip: This seminar explores the relationship between narrative representation and visual art in the Victorian period. Why do writers describe paintings in novels? Can paintings tell a story? In addressing these and other questions, this course encompasses a variety of forms including novels, poetry, essays, paintings, and illustrations. Subjects for consideration will include: portraiture and character description, literary realism and Dutch painting, depictions of work and poverty, illustrated novels by Dickens, Pre-Raphaelite art and poetry, fin de siecle aesthetics.

title: Economic Development II
prereqs: ECO 562.
descrip: Selected topics in the economic analysis of development beyond those covered in 562. Topics are selected from the theory and measurement of poverty and inequality; the relationship between growth and poverty; health and education in economic development; saving, growth, population, and development; commodity prices in economic development.

title: Posthuman, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Organic Chemistry II with Biological Emphasis
reviews: As this course demands heavy preparation for each exam, I would advise future students to make sure to understand each concept when it is introduced to alleviate the stress before each exam.
Basically 303, but harder. With Semmelhack, expect the same business.
Basically the same as CHM 303 but new material.
Be sure to stay on top of work with reguar revisions of studied lectures and concepts.

DO NOT FALL BEHIND!! Carbonyl chemistry is incredibly important to this course. I made the mistake of not thoroughly reviewing the second exam material, did very poorly on the second exam, and then scrambled to understand what I had earlier neglected. All of orgo is cumulative, so you need to keep up on studying daily and ask questions when you have them.

Definitely don't be afraid of Orgo. It's made out to be really intimidating, but all you have to do is go to the lectures and review your notes, make study sheets, do the p-sets and take the practice tests, and you're set! Take advantage of office hours, they're so helpful and are like a seminar version of the lecture in addition to Q&As to clarify confusing topics.
Do the textbook readings before you dive into the practice exams. Going to lecture isn't too critical... He posts lecture notes online... Stay on top of everything though! You'll get through it!
Don't be too intimidated by the fact that this is orgo. Just study the notes, do all of the practice exams, and you'll be fine.
Don't wait to ask questions.  If you do you'll get too behind.  Go to office hours, the resource center, the professor himself immediately.
Go to McGraw
Good luck.  You know what to expect from 303 I'm assuming, so... You know the drill.

I feel like I put so much in, and still received the average (or right below the average). You should take this class if you enjoyed Marty's lectures last semester. If you can take Sorensen's course, I heard you actually learn something in it, so I would recommend taking that instead.

I really wouldn't recommend taking organic chemistry unless you absolutely have to. They make it rather unnecessarily difficult for students to do well. If you do take it, stay on top of the lecture notes, since those are really important. Make sure to understand the concepts more than just studying to the old practice exams. Also, definitely do the old practice exams, they are great resources, but make sure not to study to the test, since they'll throw completely different things at you sometimes that you'll have never seen on the exam and you won't know how to handle it unless you have the core concepts down first. Also, go to Semmelhack's office hours, they are pretty useful. I would say do the readings as an absolute last, since they aren't very useful at all.

I recommend not underestimating 304B, even if you did well in 303. There is much more material and reactions to be skilled with. Once you slip a little, you'll easily fall far behind. And at least for this year, our 2nd and 3rd exams were pretty challenging.

I would recommend really getting to know your preceptors and lecturers. They can really help you to understand some of these very complex chemical processes and they are all wonderful people. Make sure to understand the basic foundations before you take the practice tests but definitely the best way to succeed in this class is to have a good attitude coming in to the course and practicing a lot.

I'd recommend reading through the chapters in addition to studying the lecture notes.  The chapters sometimes give either more or a different explanation, which can be helpful when studying for midterms and the final.
If your pre-med, seriously consider taking the other orgo class. Learning about the biology side of chemistry is cool, but not well connected at all.

It is a mandatory class for premeds; difficult, but doable if you find study partners and pay attention to lectures. Reading the book is very helpful--make clear, comprehensive notes for exams that will assist you understanding of the material while you write them. Make sure to do the practice tests and problem sets to study, however.
It's orgo. You just gotta do it. Try and learn something
Its definitely not an easy class. The key is to make sure you understand each concept and seek help if you don't from preceptors and professor.
Keep ahead on the work. No room to fall behind.
Keep up with lectures.

Many of you probably don't need encouragement to take this class because it's a requirement of some sort. The lectures are very well done - I never felt like I was missing out on anything because I wasn't taking Sorensen. The labs this semester are generally more involved and interesting compared to first semester. The course tries really hard to let you do well so definitely appreciate the effort

Many people will tell you that Orgo is impossible, and that is so far from the truth. It is definitely more challenging than first semester, but if you ended the semester with a good grasp of the concepts, then all the work you have to do is keeping up with the material each week. Really, orgo is just about practice!
No one really takes it for fun, but it really could be worse - just work hard and you'll do fine.
Not a bad class, if you're ambitious you can take it even if you don't have to. But it is a lot of work
Only take this if you need to.

Organic Chemistry will be hard no matter what, but I think this course can be manageable if you utilize your resources and  devote the time and energy to it. Semmelhack's class seems harder than Sorrenson's, but it has a nicer curve and I enjoyed having Semmelhack the entire year. It's going to be a struggle, but it is not impossible to do well!
Organic chemistry makes or breaks pre-meds.

Orgo is a tough class but very rewarding if you work hard. Professor Semmelhack is a very nice man and willing to help as much as he can. DO NOT shrug off the problem sets just because they aren't graded - they are pretty much the only time you'll really learn and get practice doing problems the way that Semmelhack wants. If you spend as much time practicing as you want to spend complaining about how hard it is, you'll do fine.

Orgo is challenging for sure, but I found this class to be very manageable. Semmelhack is a good lecturer, and there are lots of places to get additional help. The workload was not heavy aside from studying from exams.
People who have to take this course will and those that don't shouldn't. It is really not worth the time unless you absolutely have to take it.

Practice practice practice. Do the problem sets and practive exams. Also READ ORGANIC CHEMISTRY AS A SECOND LANGUAGE. I cannot stress enough how helpful these two books were. Also don't hesitate to bother your TA with questions. Chem grad students can be intimidating but they usually are super sweet and ready to help too. Prof. Semmelhack's office hours are a must-go as well. I really enjoyed this class, it is challenging but incredibly rewarding if you put the time and effort in.
Stay on top of the lecture material and review throughout the semester.
Stay on top of the lectures, and study ahead for the midterms, and the class won't be too hard and you will learn a lot.

Study ahead of time! Make sure you complete the precept problems and do all the practice exams! Don't just memorize the problems, however, because that won't help you much. Understand the material from lecture prior to working on the problems.
Study hard! Don't fall behind...everything is cumulative!!!
Take Sorenson's class.
Take advantage of all materials provided -- take practice exams, precept material, ask questions.
Take it because you need it as a requirement but you better be prepared to work.
Take it only if you have to because it is HARD
Take it with Marty!!
Take only if you have to. Unless you love chemistry or something...
Tests are ridiculous and its so much work and the worst ever but you probably have to take it, you will survive at least
The class is extremely cumulative, so keep up with it as it goes along because it's really hard to get caught up again.

This class convinced me to go into science and likely become a chemistry major. The overwhelmingly large amount of support for students, from review sessions to Professor Semmelhack's weekend office hours, was wonderful. I also thought the material was awesome and beautiful.
I would definitely recommend this course (of course, weigh this recommendation with the fact that I will likely be a chemistry major/might be a bit biased). If you are willing to put in the effort and go to study sessions and do all of the practice tests, you will see results. The material is hard and you will have to devote a lot of time to learning it, but I definitely thought the course was great.

This class is a good extension to CHM 303, and it is very well taught. The material is much more difficult than in 303, so expect to spend more time studying and understanding the material to do well on the exams. The labs are much more interesting, and use the precepts to get a solid grip on mechanisms and problem solving techniques.

This course is an amazing experience. It will give you an amazingly solid foundation in not only organic chemistry but problem solving as well. Semmelhack is a great lecturer for the right type of person, so, if you didn't enjoy his lectures in 303, I wouldn't recommend taking 304B. However, if you did, then this class is even better. Don't take 304B thinking it will be better preparation for biochem. You learn exactly the same mechanisms as 304, but with the addition of very simple biochemical reactions (e.g. polypeptide synthesis, very basic enzyme chemistry)

This course is competitive and takes a lot of time. Only take it if you have a genuine interest in organic chemistry or really need to for your major, pre-med requirements, etc. I would only take it if you absolutely need to.

This is a difficult course that requires discipline and perseverance.  Do all of the problem sets and all of the practice exams.  Do not be afraid to ask for help.  If you put the work in, you will get much more out of the course.
Try to do the problem sets before the key is posted and don't wait for exams to review material.
Very time consuming
Work the problem sets more than the old practice exams because focus on various topics change from year to year.
You have to take it, so go ahead. Henry is great for labs, and Semmelhack is nice and helpful during office hours.
You poor unfortunate souls. Just suffer through it and it'll be over in a semester.
don't take it. take sorenson.
hard content with equally hard schedule with 4 exams a semester.  there are problem sets now which are not helpful.  same lectures as 303
take it if you have to.  otherwise save yourself.
very hard, very time consuming.
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303. Course is open to freshmen..
descrip: The concepts introduced in CHM 303 will be extended to the structures and reactions of more complex molecules, with an emphasis on how organic chemistry provides the framework for understanding molecular processes in biology. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry will be illustrated, as often as possible, with examples drawn from biological systems. Appropriate for chemistry and engineering majors, premedical students, and students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Special Topics in Dance History, Criticism, and Aesthetics - Moving Modernisms
reviews: Definitely take it! Professor Hamera is extremely engaging and will help articulate concepts you've probably never thought about before in ways that are super interesting.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in dance, dance history, or history in general, as it provided a clear connection between dance and American history.
Take a class with Professor Hamera! She is wonderful, and you will learn so much.
Take any class you can with her.
Take this class if you are specifically interested in the history of modern dance.
prereqs: None. No prior dance experience is necessary..
descrip: How did concert dancers and choreographers create and respond to modernity's fascination with mobility between 1900 and 1950? We answer this question by probing ways gender, race, and sexuality shaped ideas of the modern in the dances of Isadora Duncan, Vaslav Nijinsky, Martha Graham, Katherine Dunham, Zora Neale Hurston, and others. Emphasis on dancers in the U.S., including transnational choreographies of African American artists, with comparative case studies from Europe. Special attention to the ways fieldwork informed choreography. Includes trip to NYPL Robbins Dance Division. No dance experience required.

title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
reviews: Always read the textbook and go to precept.

An easy class for those with some mathematical aptitude and a sense for economic reasoning. The course does pick up the pace a little after the midterm though, so don't be fooled by how the first half went.
An easy course, but either attend lecture or read the textbook.
An incredibly interesting course, do the readings and expect a reasonably easy A
Blinder's a very good teacher, and you will be sure to learn a lot in a very short time. Don't make the same mistake I did and save all the reading for Reading Period!
Definitely take  it. It is something every Princeton student should take.
Do the readings! Print off the lecture slides before and annotate them with what Blinder SAYS.

ECO101 is exactly what you'd expect, an incredibly straightforward, well-tought introductory economics course. Blinder gives very clear and informative lectures and the course will give you basic literacy in topic in economics. If you have the time in your schedule, I think this is a great course to take!
Easy course, somewhat interesting.  I would definitely recommend as a 5th class
Easy if you've taken Macro in hs.
Even if it isn't mandatory, if you have not taken an Economics Course before, this is a great introduction to the material.

For an introductory course, this class moves extremely fast and covers a lot of ground. However, Professor Blinder is a good lecturer and will keep your interest. The Problem Sets aren't extremely difficult either, but will stretch your knowledge of what you've done in class. Pay close attention in lecture and precept and you should come away with a great store of knowledge for future economic pursuits.
Go to lecture you won't regret it. Blinder is an amazing professor with a lot of experience.
Good class and good for a basic understanding of economics.
Good course. Blinder presents the material clearly and his lectures are easy to follow, but  not always necessary if you are reading the book.
Good introductory class; not a lot of work but interesting
Great class, great professor

I have to say it was rather difficult taking the course as a COS major who probably did not put in sufficient time. The lectures and textbook match well and are very helpful. It is really important to stay on top of the course, form study groups and review frequently. Not a difficult course but requires practice and review.
I love this class. If you have the opportunity to take it with Blinder, do. Just do the readings and go to class and the tests are easy.
I would recommend taking this if you need an easy SA.
I would recommend to anyone looking to learn more about economic policy in general and the recession
I would say start and maybe even finish the book a little earlier than reading week or finals week.
Interesting course, very generic. Little algebra involved but pretty easy class.

Interesting, useful, and engaging.  Not hard to keep up with the course if you do the readings and the problem sets.  Professor Blinder is an excellent lecturer and his book accompanies the class very nicely.
Interesting, would definitely take it. No prior economics knowledge needed. Do the readings!
It's a good course especially for those students who haven't taken any economics class in high school. It's not very hard but it has enough reading each week.
Just go to lectures. He is a great teacher, there is a lot too learn, and it is not too hard to grasp if you put in the time.
Keep up with psets and readings and concepts, as everything builds on top of each other.
Lecture isn't ideal, but the readings are really good. Overall would recommend as a good intro into Macroeconomic

Make sure to do the readings and spend adequate time on the problem sets. Concepts matter more than anything, so make sure you understand what is going on. The math is not difficult, don't stress about it.
Make sure to keep on top of the work and understand how each chapter is building upon the idea of GDP and price level. The course boils down to those to concepts (mostly GDP).

One of my favorite classes here! If you have taken macro before, I'd still recommend taking it just to solidify stuff. Prof. Blinder will push you to understand things more deeply and to be able to think for yourself about these topics. Make sure you don't slack on the weekly readings though!! They are definitely worth the read and can raise interesting questions for you to bond with your preceptor over (or bond with Google?whatever floats your boat).
Pretty bad not gonna lie
Pretty easy course, PDFed but probably didn't need to

Professor Blinder is great. Go to lectures/precepts and read the articles and his book (the textbook is pretty unnecessary). You'll find yourself with a greater understanding of the world and especially the 1008 financial crisis. Also, if you can be in Blinder's precept, you are extra lucky.
Read all the readings. They help form a true understanding of the course.
Read the textbook. Review the slides before finals.
Reading the textbook is probably more useful than going to lecture.
Really great intro econ course. The lecture powerpoints are online but go to lecture because most of what he says aren't on the powerpoint.
Review material every week.
Skim the readings; they're very useful, but most of it is lecture material anyways
Solid introduction to the big picture. If you are choosing between 101 and 100, take 101.
Stay on top of the readings! I felt fine with the problem sets, but I had to catch up on readings for the midterm and final because I had gotten behind on some of them.
Study and you'll be fine
TAKE IT WITH PROFESSOR BLINDER!!! He's so cool and his lectures are super well structured and interesting.
Take class
Take if you are interested in economics, as this course gives a good fundamental understanding. Difficult if you get behind on the readings
Take it
Take it with Blinder.
Take it with Bogen instead. Blinder is a great guy, but his p-sets and exams are not well prepared, tbh
Take it!!!! Prof. Blinder is absolutely phenomenal!
Take it. Not too much work.
Take it. The content itself is very interesting and offers you a good start for further economics studies. If it is with Prof Blinder, you really don't want to miss the fun.
Take this course with Blinder-- he focuses on current events and truly makes you feel like a more informed citizen.
The class isn't overly difficult. Just pay attention and be willing to learn. There is a wealth of knowledge.
This course is an easy distribution requirement or introduction that does a good job of covering some important basics of how the economy works, especially with real-world examples in mind.

This is a great and very interesting course. Make sure you take it with BLINDER. There are not too many problem sets and the material is relatively easy. DO ALL THE READINGS - seriously it won't take that much time and the articles are actually quite interesting.
This is a very well taught introduction to the basics of macroeconomics, and a great way to understand what is happening with the economy. Take it!
Very good.

You'll come into this class thinking you know a lot about macro. However then you'll meet Alan Blinder and you'll be blown away by how much you don't know and how you are a simple little potato next to him. By the end of the course you will have blossomed into a bigger potato more full of macro knowledge.
not bad
ok
stay on top of readings! for psets and finals
understand the material as you go; it all buillds upon itself.
prereqs: ECO 101 is offered both terms and may be taken before or after (or simultaneously with) ECO 100..
descrip: Analysis of the operation of the national economy, with emphasis on the causes and consequences of recessions and booms, inflation and unemployment - and possible policy responses to each. Attention is also paid to the banking and financial systems, the financial crisis, and international influences on the U.S. economy.

title: What Makes for a Meaningful Life? A Search
descrip: See website

title: Culture and Society in Late Imperial China: 1000-1900
reviews: Make sure to do the readings (most but not all) and attend all lectures. If possible try to get the "big picture" for each era covered in the course to better prepare for papers.
NA, course not offered again.
Please please please do all the readings and pay attention to every word Professor Elman says.
descrip: A survey of the major cultural and social developments from early Song to high Qing which have particular relevance for understanding China in its modern predicament. Emphasis will be placed on the interplay between ideas and society, growth of new social institutions, and the emergence of classical elites and religious groups.

title: American Economic History
reviews: Attend lectures. Not only are they interesting but they are crucial for the exams. Bogan doesn't just read the slides so it's important to take notes. Do the readings - they are essential for the exams and also quite interesting!

Do as much of the readings as you can!!!! This can be a tough class if you don't and an AMAZING class if you do! I consider this one of those "classes of a lifetime" because even if you aren't an econ major, it's got so much worthwhile information. If you're gonna take it, put some effort into it, because that's how you'll get the most out of it!
Don't take this for Bogan! Take it if you like history. This is a history class not an econ class.
Get into Bogan's precept if you can! She knows her stuff.  Not a super easy course, but doable, and worth learning about!
Great course! Great HA. Exams are actually hard though, so don't underestimate them. Regardless, you will learn a lot!

Highly recommend this class. Definitely my favorite econ elective that I have taken. Bogan is an amazing lecturer and she explains every concept in great detail. She is also amazing at office hours and truly cares about her students.
I would advise anyone interested in economics to take this course. The history is quite interesting, however, this course is mainly one of economic application.

I would highly recommend the course for any economics major especially; I was able to gain a much deeper appreciation of American history and relate previous patterns to modern business and economic issues.
If you are interested in American economic history, I recommend this course but only if Professor Bogan is teaching it.

If you enjoy History and Economics, this is an enjoyable class that is taught well by Prof. Bogan. Be prepared, however, to have quite a bit of reading and preparation to do throughout the semester. Like Prof. Bogan said at the beginning, don't take this class just because you had her for 
Micro or Macro and like her; you should really enjoy the history of the material.

If you like history and are good at memorizing lots of facts, this is a good Econ departmental for you. Don't underestimate the amount of work though - there are 50-250 pages of reading per week (more usually closer to 100-150), weekly writeups for precept (you get full credit simply for doing them, but they still take time), and a presentation that is quite time-consuming in the week leading up to it. Be sure to go to preceptor (I had Yu and really liked him) and Professor Bogan before your presentation - she especially will be really helpful in giving you lots of information. Also try to do your presentation early in the semester - you're partially graded on audience participation and people are just much more engaged earlier in the semester than they are later.
It is a challenging course with lots of readings. Only take it if you are interested in history and willing to put in time.
It's a relatively easy econ elective as econ electives go, and the material is interesting and applicable to other classes. Bogan is a boss.

Make a study group for the readings. Know the highlights.

Know all of the diagrams. Go to Bogan's office hours.

My recommendation is to take some time every week to review lectures from that week and to actually do the readings--staying on top of the information allows you to get so much more out of the course, and it makes finals week a lot easier.
NIKHIL GUPTA. Get him as your preceptor and the course will be exponentially better.
Nikhil Gupta was one of the best preceptors I've ever had. He is a true gift.

Non-econ majors: Save yourself some time and find another HA.
Econ majors: Serious consideration as a "two bird with one stone" strategy, both fulfilling a departmental and an HA.
Everyone: The class presentations were perhaps the most interesting part because of the mandatory 25 minute presentations for everyone. The lectures were solid, though you could get by without them since the slides are posted, however, you'd miss out on the secret sauce that Bogan says that's not on the slides. Exams are hard and graded very harshly. Study the course packet very thoroughly.
Not good. Not terrible. Find something else to do with your limited time here.
Recommend, do the readings
Take it - you'll do well if you study
Take it if you are interested in Economics and History and are prepared to do a lot of reading and study a lot.
Take it! It's not an easy A, but the course load is reasonable and you learn a lot. You can get away without doing much every week, but it'll be hard to catch up for the midterm/final.
Take the course. If this class is not particularly interesting to you, find another class that professor bogan teaches and take it.
Take this class!

This is a good Princeton economics class. Not super hard, Bogan is great, works for HA, departmental, and finance certificate, and plenty of athlete and fratty meatheads in it. Readings can be a lot, but that's assuming you do all of them! Overall, I would recommend.
This is a good course.

This is a great class if you want to learn more about US history through an economics lens, especially the Great Depression and Great Recession. There's lots of reading, but they're all super interesting. And go to office hours!!!
This is a tough class but worth it, especially if you are interested in American history or economics. It is also very objective, if you work hard you will do well.

Typical Bogan class. If you like her throw-facts-at-you teaching & straightforward examination style, this will be right up your alley. If not, as was the case with me, I still really enjoyed the material. It's history seen through the lens of economics, with some macro graphs thrown in for good measure. Be warned that there is a lot of Pequod reading, and textbook reading too if your history is a little rusty.
Very interesting class but NOT AN EASY A. Good overview of american economic history. Lots of material
keep up with the reading as best you can
take it- its a great course, not too much work
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. These are firm prerequisites, NOT co-requisites. This course counts towards WWS disciplinary perspectives requirement..
descrip: Modern economic theory is used to analyze growth and fluctuations in U.S. output from colonial times to the present. The course examines the role of labor markets, property rights in land and labor, financial institutions, transportation, innovation and other factors in economic growth. Before examining twentieth century fluctuations, a week is spent on business cycle theory. Then particular emphasis is placed on The Great Depression and its relationship to the recession of 2007-2009.

title: The Arts of Ethnography: Theory and Technique in Anthropological Writing
prereqs: Some experience with anthropological research and writing is expected. If in doubt about your preparation, please contact instructor..
descrip: How do anthropologists transform field experiences into ethnographic texts? This course explores the narrative, descriptive, and interpretive conventions that inform ethnography, with a strong focus on the practice of student writing. We will examine how research experience is transformed as it is written down, both during and after fieldwork. For ethnographers, what counts as evidence and expertise? How do they use literary techniques (voice, address, technical language), and other artistic/expressive modes? Weekly journal-writing and work-shopping are opportunities to think through your independent work in a creative, collaborative space.

title: Research Seminar in American Political History
descrip: This course is an intensive research seminar on the political history of the United States from the Revolutionary era to the present. Students work closely with the instructor and with each other in defining and developing original research topics, and then in drafting and revising research papers. During open weeks, we cover readings that either discuss or exemplify changing trends in the writing of American political history. Emphasis falls on the history of formal politics and government, but topics may include matters such as political culture and the interplay of government and social movements.

title: Special Topics In Urban Dance - Style and Tradition in Hip-Hop Dance Culture
prereqs: Please visit the Dance program website for application information (http://arts.princeton.edu/academics/dance/dance-courses/).
descrip: This advanced studio/seminar topics course explores the artistic, social, and cultural implications of hip-hop dance through an intensive focus on the concept of style. Using master classes, academic study, and embodied practice in the studio to develop a physical understanding and detailed social analysis of four specific hip-hop dance genres, we will explore the distinctive cultural influences that shaped each of these diverse forms, as well the deeper movement principles that they share. These principles will then be placed in the larger historical, political and performative context of the Afro-Diasporic experience in the Americas.

title: Topics in Germanic Literatures - Nietzsche and Modern European Literature
reviews: Take this class! No matter what your concentration, Professor Jennings will help you see literature in a different way, and Nietzsche might just change the way you see certain things in your own life.

The readings are exciting and Michael Jennings is an enthusiastic, demanding and helpful teacher. A lot to read but it is worth reading all these books. Fascinating opportunity for those who want to cross philosophy with literature, or want to develop their knowledge of modernist literature.
descrip: The course examines the philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche as an important progenitor of the European modernist culture that arose in the period of urban capitalist modernity, roughly 1870-1930. Particular emphasis will be placed on a series of textual encounters between Nietzsche and such authors as Gide, Mann, Lawrence, Rilke, Yeats, Musil, and Malraux; their readings and rewritings of Nietzsche lent decisive impulses to the formal and thematic concerns of modernism.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: If you dont like the brief or dont find the professor to be challenging enough, make sure to challenge yourself. talk to external resources and set your own parameters. I think that students that were overwhelmed or not interested in the studio suffered most when they relied on the professor to push the success of their projects.

It is important to realize early on that it will be more beneficial to set one's own constraints/limitations in order to carry out the project. The loose flexibility of the course and the lack of instruction will lead to a great amount of confusion and frustration.
descrip: Part two of a two semester sequence in which fundamental design skills are taught in the context of the architect's wider responsibilities to society, culture and the environment. Students acquire a command of the techniques of design and representation through a series of specific architectural problems of increasing complexity. Both semesters are required for three-year M.Arch. students.

title: Introductory Physics II
reviews: Be prepared to solve a lot of problems. Go to the reviews sessions. Participate!

Course is rigorous and fast-paced; keep up with readings and if the problem sets are giving you trouble, attend the McGraw help sessions. They are exceedingly helpful to check-answers and get assistance.
Do the problem sets; it will help you always. Practice problems are also your friend.
Don't be afraid.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take unless you have too, the course is stressful

Don't take. Horrible. Would not suggest unless changed, but its probably required if you're looking into it. Try to get a decent preceptor that helps you out. Dr. Visnjic was terrible unless you like being treated like a kindergardener.
Dr. Visnjic and Prof. Calaprice explain problems and concepts very clearly. Make sure to ask them if you are confused about anything.
Go to McGraw on Sunday nights in Jadwin. It'll save you so much time and understanding on the HW.
Go to office hours if you need help. The instructors are wonderful and are very helpful if you are struggling.
Good class for pre-med students. Would recommend this over PHY103/104 because you will learn most things you will need to know on the MCAT, without going into unnecessary depth.
Good course, lots of work, but I learned a lot.

I'm guessing if you're taking PHY102, you're taking it because you have to. It's not horrible but it requires constant work every week. Make sure to stay on top of your psets and quizzes and go to office hours!!!
If you have to take it, take it. It's fine.
It's an easy class and you will actually learn physics. Demos are awesome and as long as you pay attention in class / do (some) of the readings, it doesn't take too much time/effort to do well.
It's fast-paced, but if you do all the work and take advantage of the numerous resources available, you'll be totally fine!

It's the best science class I've taken at Princeton (premed humanities student with no background in physics from high school). Visnjic is an amazing lecturer?has a real knack for teaching and clarifying difficult concepts. It's fair, not impossible. Learned a lot. Better than 101.
Lectures are fine and precept instruction is good. The material isn't too challenging, but time passes slowly in labs.
Make sure you do plenty of practice problems. Final exam covered too many detail-oriented things--not necessary in my opinion. You can teach yourself from the textbook essentially
No particular reason to take this if it's not a requirement, but it is a good quality course.
Nothing by itself is hard to learn, it is just a lot of work. Be aware that you are competing with pre-meds.
Only take this class if you need to for a requirement.
Take if premed only. (or if you need to)
Take it if you have to - and if you do, work hard throughout the entire semester. Every problem set, every quiz, every lab really adds up!
Take it if you have to, otherwise no.
Take this if you need to. A wider range of topics than 101 (that I think are more interesting). Go to McGraw study halls.
The course is pretty low key especially after fall semester. There is a fair amount of work, but the material is pretty interesting especially after the midterm.

This class will seem like a lot of work for little reward, unfortunately. What helped me engage with the material was going to McGraw and discussing with my peers and with the tutors, since that helped me actually understand the material, but unfortunately for now, the class seemed pretty based on rote learning, not engagement.

This course is a fair amount of sheer class hours. PHY 101 is similar in format, but not in content. Most of the learning comes from doing the problem set and mulling over the questions. Office hours are very helpful. Labs are tedious, just as they were for PHY 101.
This is a good course to take. Visnjic was a good professor but you're going to have to put  in time and work. If you're pre med, still take it
You're taking this class because you have to. Brace yourselves for tediousness.
go to office hours.

great lectures, not hard to get a good grade in this class because it's set up well. 
calaprice was kinda harsh and inconsiderate, but knows his stuff
keep up to date, go to office hours, teachers are super helpful
stay on top of the quizzes--thats the secret to a good grade
stay on top of the readings and practice problems,
prereqs: PHY 101.
descrip: This course presents an introduction to the fundamental laws of nature, especially optics, electricity/magnetism, nuclear and atomic theory. These are treated quantitatively with an emphasis on problem solving. The laboratory is intended to give students an opportunity to observe physical phenomena and to gain "hands-on" experience with apparatus and instruments.

title: Orchestral Music: Analysis and Performance
reviews: If you are in PUO and the music for the concert is interesting, definitely take this course! This semester we explored all Beethoven symphonies, Shostakovich 5, and tone poems by Strauss. We also got to go to the Metropolitan Opera to see Strauss' Elektra!
Ruth is great.
TAKE THIS CLASS, RUTH IS THE BEST!!!
Take this course! Ruth is a fantastic lecturer and very understanding. She really cares about the students, and the work is very minimal.

There are so many reasons to take this course!  There's very little work besides the final paper, which is short and only a small percentage of your grade, so it's an easy fifth class.  There's a cool field trip to the Met, and Ruth is a really great teacher and a wonderful person.  It's nice getting to know some people from PUO too.
This is an amazing class! Ruth really does care about the students a lot, and you will be surprised by how much you can learn about how to analyze music.
prereqs: Open to members of the Princeton University Orchestra..
descrip: Using the Princeton University Orchestra's spring 2015 concert repertory as the primary focus material, this year's course will explore the composers Beethoven, Mahler, Strauss, and Shostakovich. The core repertory is Beethoven's Seventh Symphony, Mahler's Das Lied von der Erde, Strauss's Tod und Verklarung, and Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony. Lectures and discussions will explore composer biography, historical context, and music analytical insights for each work.

title: Schools and Society: Race, Class and Gender in U.S. Education
reviews: Good class to take if ever offered again.

I think that this was a one-time class offering, but if Professor Lovelace ever taught this again, I would very highly recommend it! Each week covered a new and interesting aspect of education (from a perspective of gender, class, discipline, race, etc.), and it was a super interesting class with a great professor. Not too much reading (manageable), and the assignments were spaced out nicely throughout the semester.
I'd recommend this course to anyone with an interest in education who doesn't require a lot of structure in the classroom to succeed.

It's a shame that Professor Lovelace is only here for the 2015-16 school year. Her course was fantastic, and if this course is offered in the future by another Professor than I strongly recommend it. Great sociology elective for concentrators, but also accessible for non majors. The way it was structured this time, it would have been a fantastic PDF.
Loved this course!!!
Take it if you're at all interested in the subject matter.
Take it! Though we were lucky enough to have Professor Lovelace, the coursework is interesting no matter what.
Take it.  Professor Lovelace is a good teacher, the readings are good, and as long as you have a dedicated group of students, the discussions will be good as well.
This course is amazing. If it is taught again, take it!
Well Professor Lovelace won't be here next year :( but this was a really great class so if there is ever a class of similar structure then take a chance and maybe it will be as good as this one.
take the course! Professor Lovelace rocks.
descrip: This course uses sociological methods to examine the roles that race, class, and gender play in the making of U.S. educational systems. We will explore the challenges of schooling in an increasingly diverse society, devoting great attention to the complex factors that produce inequities in P-16 education. We will also interrogate many assumptions and themes that dominate contemporary discussions of U.S. education, including merit, school discipline, and college access. The course introduces students to leading approaches to the sociological study of education and offers fresh perspectives on pressing educational issues facing society.

title: Intermediate Twi II
prereqs: TWI 105.
descrip: This course expands on the language skills acquired from TWI 105 and continues to focus on the communicative approach to studying the language. It includes specific socio-cultural settings and events. Speaking, reading, writing and listening continue to form an integral part of the course and students will build on their grammatical skills. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Novice High and Intermediate Low.

title: Formal Political Analysis I
descrip: A rigorous introduction to choice theory, social choice theory, and non-cooperative game theory. The course serves as the first formal theory graduate course and draws on mathematics at the level of POL 502.

title: Epidemiology
prereqs: This is a required course for graduate students in the Health and Health Policy certificate program..
descrip: Course covers the basic concepts and methods of epidemiology and demonstrates how these can be applied to improve population health and reduce health inequities. Topics include: measuring the health of the population, understanding the causes of poor health, developing interventions for improving health, translating evidence into practice, and evaluating the impact of policies and programs. Key epidemiological concepts such as association, bias and confounding are covered, as well as the main epidemiological study designs.

title: Advanced French Theater Workshop
reviews: C'est pas un cours ou on revise la grammaire. Ne prenez pas cette cours si vous voulez vous assoir dans une salle de classe et ne pas prendre des risques!
Fantastic course. Florent is a riot and I think every French student here should take a class with him at least once.

I highly recommend students taking this course appreciate the marvelous opportunity it provides Princeton students with to be children of illusion and pursue the expression of self through deep appreciation of French theatre and acting.
I would definitely recommend this class!

I would recommend this class to students who have a strong grasp of French and who would like to widen their textual repertoire. Professor Masse is very dynamic and inspiring, and his course will expose you to fascinating niches in French theater. Classes are sometimes a bit unorganized.
Prof. Masse is great. This course is usually not too difficult, but at specific times can require a lot of work. If you're comfortable with acting, this is a really enjoyable course.

TAKE IT!!!!! Such a great class!! Prof. Masse is an incredible teacher and will teach you so much about French theater and acting skills. I went in with zero prior theater experience, but found myself feeling right at home immediately. Strongly recommend!!

Take it if you are interested in theater and have a basic command of the language. It's an amazing course with an incredible professor and a great way to improve your french skills without having to take a course devoted to the language.
Take it if you want to improve your accent/knowledge of French theater. You won't learn that much about how to act specifically.

Take it! Florent Masse is amazing and the course is very dynamic. Quite a bit harder than 211 because of the faster pace, but you'll be alright! Do take 211 first, if you're not a (near) native speaker though.
Take this class if you have an interest in French theatre... or even if you don't!
Take this class! Perfect for language learning or for maintaining speaking skills.

The theater component is much more heavily emphasized than the linguistic or literary component. I have mixed feelings: it is fun to act in the plays, but there is very little other learning that goes on.
This course was fun! Definitely better for learning french than for learning how to act.
take this class, sheeple
prereqs: Professor's approval and/or one two-hundred level French course (preferably FRE/THR 211). To schedule an interview, interested students must contact the instructor at: fmasse@princeton.edu..
descrip: Advanced French Theater Workshop is a continuation of FRE/THR 211, French Theater Workshop. Students focus their work on three French playwrights: one classical, one modern, and one contemporary. The course will place emphasis on refining and improving students' acting and oral skills. It will culminate in the presentation of the students 'Travaux' at the end of the semester.

title: The American Dance Experience and Africanist Dance Practices
reviews: Definitely take if you're looking for a fun, interesting course and if you have a lot of energy.
Definitely take this class! A great senior spring class because you learn a lot about another form of dance, and it's a lot of fun.
Enjoy it! It's honestly just a time of fun, relaxation, and dance. Don't be intimidated if you have no dance experience!
Great class to take in senior year! Highly recommend.
Great, fun course! Very chill.

Hands down one of the best courses I have ever taken at Princeton. Every time classes ended, I wanted to stay longer because of how fun and enlightening class is. Mama Dy truly teaches the art of African dance and the legacy, history, and meaning behind it.
Highly recommend! No dance experience necessary, great sense of accomplishment at the end, learn so much about African culture.

I know that most people give very good review, but I actually had a mixed experience.
I thought that the studios in general were very interesting and I very much enjoyed the drumming. I thought, however, that sometimes the manner of feedback felt overly critical to me which made it hard to feel free and really explore in my dancing.
In addition, I wish there was a more scholarly approach to the dance, at times, and to how it related to life rather than speculation.

Really, I wish that I had taken another class, because I felt like there were tenuous comparisons which were often made without evidence or a wider scholarly conversation, which is what I was interested in as well as the dancing. Also, I sometimes (but not always) felt judged in my dancing, which diminshed my experience of the course. This could have just been me, because I know other people who loved the experience.
The papers were 4-5 pages single-spaced, and I felt like I was making things up sometimes because of the prompts.

However, I really enjoyed the guest lecturers, especially for swing dance.

It is a very fun class and you learn a lot about dance and how African dance has evolved and influenced American Culture. This was my first dance class at Princeton and it was phenomenal. I would recommend anyone interested in Dance to take this class.
This class is absolutely incredible- I made friends, loved Mama Dy, and had an absolute blast learning about African dance practices.
This course is a lot of fun, and most of the class time is spent on dancing, which is great. Skill with movement varies broadly across the course, and lack of skill (like me) is not an issue.
take it! SO FUN, keeps you from a dull day, and always makes me in a better mood coming out of class. prof. is amazing.
prereqs: Some form of social dancing, good, natural movement aptitude, or former dance training. This is an OPEN ENROLLMENT course..
descrip: A studio course introducing students to American dance aesthetics and practices, with a focus on how its evolution has been influenced by African American choreographers and dancers. An ongoing study of movement practices from traditional African dances and those of the African diaspora, touching on American jazz dance, modern dance, and American ballet. Studio work will be complemented by readings, video viewings, guest speakers, and dance studies.

title: Topics in Economic and Organizational Sociology (Half-Term) - Institutional Analysis
descrip: The analysis of institutions is central to sociology, but it comes in many forms. This seminar considers contrasting perspectives in the analysis of institutions in the state and the economy as well as in civil society and the public sphere. Throughout, we ask in what ways institutions matter and how they develop and change. Although much of the work is historical, recent changes in institutional structure and problems of institutional design also receive attention. The role of law is a particular focus.

title: Taboo and Transgression
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in International Relations - Human Rights
descrip: This course looks at human rights as a public policy issue.
