It considers debates over the definition of human rights; the possibilities and limits of humanitarian intervention; the ability of human rights activists and international actors to undermine dictatorial governments; and the impact of the laws of war. We will consider historical and contemporary cases around the world, including the Armenian genocide, the Holocaust, Bosnia, China, and more.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Civil Liberties
reviews: I strongly advise taking this course if you have any interest in constitutional law or the Supreme Court. As opposed to Constitutional Interpretation, this course is traditionally much smaller which leads to more rewarding class discussions.

I would highly recommend this course. The grading is fair and Professor Whittington is approachable. You'll miss out on a lot if you skip class, because the course is largely discussion based and lectures aren't posted on blackboard. However, the material is engaging and the discussions are very interesting.

I would recommend this. If you put the work in and are intellectually invested in the class, not difficult to do okay grade-wise regardless of what major (science or humanities) you are. Even if you PDF, make an effort to pay attention in class because the material is interesting. Class by Prof. Whittington different from class by Robbie George, according to what I've heard from friends who've taking Prof. George's class.
Take it with Whittington.

Take this course if you get the chance, especially with Whittington. It's an utterly eye-opening look at how Americans' interpretations of rights have changed (drastically) over time, and no preconceived notion thereof comes out unscathed. Whittington gives you exactly what he wants you to know, no more and no less, but is immensely helpful and responsive and happily elaborates (off the top of his head, without fail) upon request. The readings are also very interesting and unexpectedly manageable, unlike many other politics classes that "carbo-load" by giving comical volumes of reading that are never used.
descrip: An exploration of how the United States has grappled with the limits on government power. The rights of individuals, and the justification for the use of force from the founding period to today. Topics include religious liberty, free speech, economic liberty, equality and personal autonomy, and security issues.

title: Advanced Screenwriting: Writing for Television
reviews: Absolutely take this class if you love television and want to create your own show and write your own pilot. You learn a ton over the semester, watch some really great stuff, and end up with a finished 60 page script and an idea for a TV show.
Attend the classes, take the work and critiques seriously, watch the materials he recommends and participate in class! Don't be afraid to speak up!

Great, helpful professor. Nice to have a completed pilot script at semester's end. Class could've had maybe a little more content, apart from workshopping. Most of the time was spent watching a pilot/movie in class and doing a quick, 5-minute discussion about it afterward, with a good 30-40 minutes left over in the class, forcing us to end early.

I took this course as a fiction writer trying to branch out. It was really useful; I learned more about plot and scene-structure than in any other creative writing course at Princeton, useful for screenwriting but applicable to many other aspects of storytelling!
This is a fun, interesting class!  However there is a lot to accomplish with writing a whole 60 page pilot, so we don't get into too much detail about how to write a scene well / structure it.
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they would like to take the course and optionally a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre. Please note this course CANNOT be audited. A prerequisite of 2 prior CWR courses. Application deadline is November 22, 2015.
descrip: This advanced screenwriting course will introduce students to the post 1990's "golden age of television" and outline the differences between writing for film and a scripted TV series. Students will be required to watch a television pilot each week and engage in an in-depth discussion about its structure, pacing, character development, etc. Each student will formulate and pitch an original series idea and write their own pilot, (50-60 pages) due by the end of the semester.

title: Physics and Chemistry of Earth's Interior
reviews: A fun and interesting class with a relatively low work load. You'll learn a lot.
Get help early if you get stuck on any assignments. Tom is always willing to help, and chances are he'll explain everything in just a few short minutes.
Good course.
If you are a GEO major focusing on geophysics and geology, this is a great course to take.
This is a really great class to take to get a better understanding of Earth structure and the processes that make it. Work on problem sets with other people and keep up with the lecture material.
prereqs: One year of college-level chemistry or physics (preferably both) and calculus..
descrip: The Earth is a system whose past and present state can be studied within the framework of fundamental physics and chemistry. Topics include current concepts of geophysics and the physics and chemistry of Earth materials; origin and evolution of the Earth; and nature of dynamic processes in its interior. One emphasis is to relate geologic processes on a macroscopic scale to the fundamental materials properties of minerals and rocks.

title: Shakespeare II
reviews: Cormack has a very in-depth style of language analysis, and he expects the same level of significant extrapolation in class assignments. Not exactly the course to take if you're somewhat skeptical about exactly how much meaning Shakespeare packed into every word he wrote.

Great Lectures (the best part of the course is listening to Bradin make the poetry of Shakespeare dance). Its William: best writer the world has ever known. And The lectures are amazing:Bradin is an absolute master by sea. Go to Office Hours if only to talk to Professor about movies- he's willing to talk about anything and he's incredibly nice.

I would definitely recommend this course for anyone who genuinely enjoys reading Shakespeare. Lectures and precepts were engaging and challenging, and I feel like they gave me a much better grasp on the Shakespearian canon
If you're at all interested in Shakespeare, absolutely take this course.
Professor Cormack is really nice and I really liked the course, but lectures were sometimes a bit hard to follow. Shakespeare is sooo great, though, so you can't go wrong.

Really be prepared for the reading, and be vocal if assignments are due at a weird time etc. because he's not super in tune to the pace of Princeton.  But this is a really enlightening course.  You'll really learn how to understand/appreciate Shakespeare.  It's not something to take on a whim though if you're not going to really engage in the course. But you will really learn and grow a lot.
Start the papers early and be ready to revise many times
Take it! Professor Cormack is great, and Shakespeare is brilliant as well. You will feel very knowledgeable about Shakespeare's plays after this course (though it can get quite abstract at times).
Take the course if you're particularly into Shakespeare or English lit with intense analysis. Don't take it for an easy LA.

Take this if you want to get a deeper understanding towards Shakespeare and his late texts, but also be honest with your preceptor and Professor Cormack about your level of understanding Shakespeare and your exposure to it thus far.
descrip: This class covers the second half of Shakespeare's career, with a focus on the major tragedies and tragicomedies/romances.

title: Stochastic Calculus
reviews: Excellent course, which covers a good scope of material.

The knowledge in probability theory is a must. Attending all the lectures and doing all the assignments are strongly recommended for the students who do not have prior knowledge in stochastic calculus.

This is my favorite course that I have taken at Princeton. Ramon's lectures give good insight and are extremely clear. I strongly recommend this to all interested in math. Undergraduates who have taken ORF526 should definitely consider this class.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ORF 526 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to stochastic calculus based on Brownian motion.Topics include:construction of Brownian motion; martingales in continuous time; the Ito integral; localization; Ito calculus; stochastic differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; martingale representation; Feynman-Kac formula.

title: Politics in the Age of Digital Media
reviews: Good course. Would recommend!
Great course!! Though, unlikely to be taught again because visiting professor
N/A but I would certainly recommend it if it were to be offered again in a form similar to that which Prof. Kim taught.
This course was very enjoyable. Professor Kim was very helpful throughout the course, and the course was well-organized. Overall, I would definitely recommend it!
You should take this class. One of the few classes at Princeton where you actually come away with new and interesting information. Completely manageable and very interesting
descrip: This course is a seminar designed for advanced undergraduate students and graduate students who have an interest in the role digital media play in politics. Through this course, students have opportunities to examine the role of digital media and its implications for political communication with the enduring "big" questions that have been raised in the study of politics in a democratic society. Topics include information abundance and misinformation, partisan outlets and polarization, data analytics and microtargeting in election campaigns, "new" types of group politics exemplified in MoveOn, Tea Parties.

title: Themes in Islamic Culture - Middle Eastern History
descrip: This semester the course will be a chapter and paper clinic. Each participant will be expected to submit at least one draft chapter or paper to the seminar, and will receive intensive comments and suggestions on both form and substance from the other participants and the instructor. Chapters and papers may relate to any period or aspect of Middle Eastern or Islamic history.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: Systematic Ethics - Selected Topics in Ethical Theory
descrip: Selected topics in Ethical Theory.

title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
reviews: Difficult course material but Prof. Sondhi is a great lecturer.  Strong background in quantum is definitely required, and the weekly  homework assignments require a significant time investment
For those who had only basic quantum mechanics background, it is worth taking.
Nice course to take if you are prepping for field theory or want to learn about some advanced topics in QM
Take it if Sondhi is teaching. He is a wonderful man and a great professor. Just be prepared to learn A LOT.

This course is good for students looking to put some of their quantum mechanics knowledge to use in a variety of theoretical applications. Covers a wide variety of essential physics topics not covered in PHY 305 or QFT. Although the course is not not terribly demanding, the final project is rather interesting and rewarding.
descrip: This is a one-semester course in advanced quantum mechanics. The emphasis is on systems with more than one degree of freedom: dynamics, mixed states, entanglement, measurement, coherent states, decoherence, resonance, exchange, Hartree-Fock, Dirac equation, other topics.

title: Special Topics in Operations Research and Financial Engineering - High Frequency Markets: Models and Data Analysis
reviews: Really tough course but would recommend if you are interested in HFT
Would recommend if you are interested in the math / stats in high frequency trading. A lot of the material is hard to find unless you enter the industry!
prereqs: ORF 309, ORF 405.
descrip: The goal is to discuss mathematical models surrounding electronic trading. It enables students to converse with the practitioners involved in high frequency markets, whether it be for trading, regulatory or other purposes. At the end of the course, students are expected to understand actual problems agents face on electronic exchanges and the mathematical tools used to deal with them. Emphasis is put on making the students comfortable with real high frequency data and surrounding models. The coding skills required are mild. We will code in R to be able to prototype ideas quickly and to leverage pre-existing statistical packages.

title: Analysis III: Integration Theory and Hilbert Spaces
reviews: Difficult class, but interesting introduction to measure theory and Lebesgue integration. Take it for the continuation of the Stein sequence.
Fun course - finally delving into justifying things taken for granted like interchanging order of integration, fundamental theorem of calculus, etc.

How can you not know real analysis: measure theory, the Lebesgue integral, Hilbert spaces, and L^2 / fourier theory?!?!? Anyone interested in analysis should take this course.

Mihaela Ignatova was a very nice professor and made the material attainable.

If you are considering taking this course, it is probably because you have taken Analysis I and/or Analysis II. If this is the case, you have enough to be able to handle this course, and you should definitely take it. We use Stein's Analysis III book, which is simply the flagship book in the introduction to Measure and Integration Theory texts. Problem sets will be hard, sometimes very hard, but never impossibly hard. Go for it!
Memorize all the proofs. Find people to work with. Ask questions.
Solid class, I think Prof. Ignatova made it easier than usual but then curved it more harshly.
Take it.
Take this class if you want to learn Measure Theory and Lebesgue Integration! Otherwise, you will be bored.

Take. Critical stuff to know as a math major, especially if you're interested in analysis. Don't know who will teach it in the future, but Prof. Ignatova was good.
Stein's book is also an absolute pleasure to read.
The material is pretty interesting, but nothing fascinating. The psets were on the easy side for a math class, but be warned that Ignatova's grading curve is pretty harsh.
prereqs: MAT 215, 218 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of Lebesgue integration in n-dimensional space. Differentiation theory. Hilbert space theory and applications to Fourier Transforms, and partial differential equations. Introduction to fractals. This course is the third semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Defense Policy Analysis
descrip: Covers types of analytical frameworks for evaluating military issues. Methodologies range from simple quantitative methods for understanding combat to structured use of military history to defense budget calculations to simple assessments of military tech. Address 7 topics: terrorism, modern air-ground warfare; infantry combat including guerrilla war, peace enforcement, urban warfare, mountain & jungle warfare; missile battle/missile defense; military transport, supply, logistics; effects & implications of weapons of mass destruction; budgetary & econ. issues in defense planning; military tech., future of warfare.

title: Elementary Hindi and Urdu II
reviews: Take it!!! Hindi is a beautiful language and Robert is an outstanding instructor who I'm so happy to have gotten to know  this year.
Take it. Robertji is great and super helpful. Even if you don't have a particular interest in the language its a good one to take. Also, it's only 4 days a week.

Take this course if you want a fun, relaxed language course without too much work. Learning Hindi was really great, and Robert-ji is a great teacher! You definitely get out of this class what you put in.
This is a great class. It can be hard if you have no experience with Hindi.
you have to really be interested in it to do well. If you don't have a general background in the language, be prepared to work hard.
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course provides the second semester of training in Hindi and Urdu, allowing students to acquire linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Equal emphasis is placed on both Hindi and Urdu, including writing systems, vocabulary, and culture. Course will focus on using language for communication. Students will be able to read and write both Hindi and Urdu scripts, communicate in social situations, and narrate in all three time frames: past, present and future. Classes are interactive.

title: The Romantic Period - Romanticism & the Inventions of Childhood
descrip: How is childhood "invented"? Children have always been, and we have all been children. But it wasn't until the late 18th C. that "childhood" as a distinct category of consciousness really took shape, and Romanticism is credited with "inventing childhood" in these terms, with a particular interest in children's (sometimes unknowable) inventions. Our readings span "Long Romanticism" and along the way take up questions of gender and sexuality, race and culture, poetic form and imagination, narratology and temporal ventriloquism. Literary adventures (poetry, stories, novels, essays) are enhanced by some critical and cultural reflections.

title: Discipline
descrip: See website

title: From Pandora to Psychopathy: Evil from Antiquity to the Present
reviews: A course that raises stimulating questions, but perhaps not quite as fulfilling as I would have hoped it to be.

A great class if you are interested in learning about the different perspectives of Evil. The readings aren't long, but they can sometimes be difficult to grapple with. Overall good course if you are looking for a distribution requirement or need a light workload 5th class.
A very interesting course.  Readings are not too long and interesting.  Only two papers to write.
Amazing class. Extremely enjoyable- great range of readings from classical philosophy to psychology. Go to lectures - they are great.
Amazing course! Sometimes readings are very philosophical and hard to get through, but totally worth it!
An interesting and engaging course, sure to improve the longer it is taught

An interesting class focused on discussion and actually thinking through and coming to terms with various historical philosophical ideas. Low workload, but lectures and participation in precept are a must if you want to actually get anything out of this course.
Attend precepts and you should be fine.
Be prepared to do a lot of reading. I like how the class wasn't forcing any ideas on you, but rather encouraged you to come up with your own ideas.

Be prepared to read a lot, because what is to be gained from this course is found in the wonderful readings that are assigned each week. This is also a class in which its possible to skip out on lecture and keep a pretty good grade since most of the content isn't really "tested," but I would strongly encourage you to show up to every one. Professor Wildberg asks pertinent questions and makes these philosophical topics really exciting and relevant to aspects of daily life (even if they're sometimes frightening).
Best EM out there for the course load.
Consider taking if you need a distribution requirement. It was pretty easy
Course is structured strangely (all over the place). Easy.
DO IT. It's and easy and yet very interesting class.

Definitely consider taking this if you need an EM distribution requirement. It's interesting to consider evil from different perspectives, and it forces you to reconsider things you thought were "evil". Also, not too much work.
Definitely take it if you're interested in evil, but consider it's a lot of reading some weeks. And the papers add up to be 75% of your grade.

Definitely take the course!! Professor Wildberg is a great lecturer that really cares about what the students have to say, and the material is very interesting and not that heavy at all. You really don't need to have taken any philosophy course/have any prior knowledge on the topics at all.
Definitely take this class if you have the opportunity, it's very thought-provoking and the workload is no trouble.

Definitely take this course if you can! The readings are not only appropriate for the time period we are given, but they are also philosophically and historically relevant. Both the professor and preceptors are excellent.
Definitely take this course.
Do not miss the guest lectures, you will regret it, and do the readings- they are actually pretty enjoyable.

Do not take this class if you are going to take it lightly. Do the readings, and prepare to think long and hard about the matter at hand. It is one of tremendous import, great fascination, and endless inquiry. It has trouble, bedeviled, and perplexed humans from time immemorial, but our reckoning with it now will in large part determine its mastery over us in the future.
Do not take this course for a grade unless you're prepared to read a lot of dense reading and to write 12-15 pages on philosophy without any guidelines. Not a very interesting class.
Do take this course. It's quite interesting and not too difficult to get a good grade.
Easy to pdf, interesting if you want to go to lecture.
Get into Caroline's precept! She's great. Overall not too time-consuming glass, granted had I put more time in, I probably would have gotten more out.

Good if you're looking for a distribution requirement; not demanding. The readings are either interesting or, if not, able to be skimmed.  DON'T waste your time reading the intros/prefaces/whatever. Go to precept and try to motivate yourself to go to lecture, but you'll be okay if you don't go to lecture, especially after the midterm because there are no material-heavy assignments after that.
Great EM that's interesting and not very time consuming

Great class to take for EM distribution! Workload is very limited and readings are pretty short. You can get by with skimming the readings and paying some attention in either lecture or precept. Lectures are filled with interesting information that Wildberg presents well.
Great fifth class; no philosophy experience necessary. You can get along without doing the readings after the midterm
I really enjoyed the course and what we actually learned. Take for an EM.

I strongly recommend this course! There are so many interesting readings and discussions, and it definitely helps with seeing evil in a different perspective. I learned a lot, it was a relatively light workload (aside from the final paper and the midterm), and the course was overall a lot of fun!

I think this class is great. Whatever you do it is amazing:
1. If you want to do nothing that is totally possible and you will get your distribution (very-too easy class)
2. If you want to also learn something this, I believe this is one of the most interesting topics of all time. Professor Wildberg is not the best lecturer, but he is good and cares a lot about the class. The readings are very good and you get an intro into philosophy. 
Strongly recommend!!!!!
I would advise them to do all of the readings, since they were each very interesting.
I would encourage them to take the course.
I would recommend this class!
I would recommend this course for any student who is interested in the topic of evil. The course provided a nice introduction to the topic without being too challenging or confusing.

I would say that overall it is a pretty easy class to get through and there really is no need to pdf although you can. You must go to precepts though because they do take attendance and grade you on showing up and speaking. The readings are extremely interesting as well as the lectures but you do not necessarily need to do the readings or go to lecture in order to pass. You should read a few before the midterm though.
I would say that this course has really interesting potential, but a lot of the depth and close reading is up to you.
I'd recommend it as painless and interesting EM, some interest in philosophy advisable.

If you are looking for an introduction to philosophy or a challenging course, this isn't the place. But if you are cool with a pretty chill survey course, go for it. Don't expect to leave with a solid grasp of the origins of evil, though. If you are okay with not walking away with much concrete knowledge, then go for it.
If you don't spend a ton of time on every single topic, find one or two that you really enjoy, and try and really learn and get a feel for the philosophy.
Interesting class, not a lot of work. A bit useless because no real-world applications, but interesting theoretical debates nonetheless.
Interesting course. Super easy PDF. Highly recommend
It will get you thinking about evil a lot, I spent a ton of time with my roommates thanks to this course. Insightful as long as you are engaged.
It's a pretty easy but interesting course
It's an interesting course with pretty good readings that were not too overwhelming. Did not attend class and still did fine as long as you do the readings and attend precept.
It's fun, engaging, and intellectually stimulating. I definitely recommend.
Its interesting, but hard to understand and sometimes tedious
Know about philosophy before entering the class and it will be a breeze.
NOt particularly
Not a lot of work.  2nd half of the course is a lot more interesting than the first half, unless you are really into the philosophical texts.
Not much work, easy PDF class. Material is interesting.
One of those 'meh' courses. Easy PDF.
Professor Wildberg is amazing!!!
Read all of the assigned readings before lecture and sit in the front. Honestly, an amazing course and a great way to fulfill the E&M requirement (especially for CBE majors)! I will miss it!

Read everything before the mid-term. After the mid-term, focus on the readings that mean the most to you since for your final paper, you'll probably only use the readings that most resonated with you.
Readings can be tough, pay attention in lecture if you do not do all the reading.
Really enjoyable class - great readings and very low workload. This is an excellent choice for a distribution requirement.
Really interesting course that requires very low commitment. Prof. Wildberg is really chill.
Relatively low-key and very self-driven. 10/10 would recommend
Relaxed and interesting course
Solid course.
Sometimes the readings are difficult to read, but be sure to at least skim them to get a concept of the author's main arguments.
Super chill, interesting content

TAKE IT. Be aware that the workload can be tough around dean's date and midterms. At other times the workload is very reasonable. Professor Wildberg is an excellent lecturer, especially on this topic. I'd highly recommend this to anyone trying to fill their EM, and even if you just have a free class to fill. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
Take class
Take for an EM requirement.
Take it as an EM! Easy and also interesting!
Take it for an interesting EM, and write a fun paper!
Take it if you want an interesting class that does not require a ton of work!
Take it if you want and easy P/D/F class
Take it if you're interested in discussing evil and what it means or how it pervades our everyday lives
Take it!
Take it! Do the readings, You get as much out of the course as you put in.
Take it.  It's very easy and sometimes interesting.
Take the class.
Take the course if you're interested. The course is not so hard but if you make any effort to grapple with the materials you will get a lot out of it.
Take the course! Definitely! Professor Wildberg is great, and the course is very doable.

Take this class if you need an EC credit and don't want to have to take a philosophy class on one topic. This class was really enjoyable and made me challenge my own way of thinking in a way no other class here has done .
Take this class if you want to engage with some very big questions and big authors. It has a reasonable work load and was worth while because of the readings and lectures.
Take this class. VERY VERY easy and interesting
Take this course if you are interested in looking at the broader perceptions of evil throughout history rather than a specific answer to the question of what is evil.
Take this course if you want to earn about theories about evil. Some readings are dense and confusing but Professor Wildberg cares a lot and this is a relatively interesting course.
Take this course only if you need to fulfill a distribution requirement. This course is very challenging.
Take this course. It isn't very difficult, but the material and thinking involved is invaluable.

Take this course. The grading is fair and the material is absolutely so interesting. Wildberg is so kind and approachable (not to mention brilliant) and his lectures are incredibly well organized. Try to get in his precept.
Take this for an easy distribution.
Take this if you are interested in the readings.
Take this if you're looking for a good, low-time commitment distribution requirement.  Lectures are very good, and the material is very interesting, so it's good all around
The work load is very manageable, but still make sure to read materials thoroughly and take good notes.
This class is engaging and is a lighter EM, and a lighter 4th class in general. you really do learn a lot about evil, and I think is very beneficial for any student.
This class is really interesting, reading is relatively light, not a lot of work, great to PDF but you could also work really hard and probs get an A.

This course is a fun one to take. There isn't a lot of work during the actual course other than keeping up with the readings and even that isn't difficult. Most of the discussions in precept are entirely opinion based so you for the most part only need a general idea of the readings. The midterm was interesting and not difficult and for the final essay it was nice to have so much freedom to choose a topic.
This course is a good way to fulfill an EM distribution, and was generally interesting.
This course is fun and interesting!
This course is honestly not too bad. The professor keeps the reading to a minumum, and seriously there's hardly any, and tries to keep you engaged with the topics.

This course is what you make of it. I personally did not have a lot of time to devote to it due to other commitments, and as a result felt that I did not get as much out of the readings as I could have. One can do well in the course without putting in a huge amount of time, but this will not necessarily lead to a fulfilling experience.
This is a fun course in which you will be exposed to some interesting theories.  You will get out of this course whatever you put in.
This is a good course to fulfill your EM requirement, as it is not extremely demanding and covers interesting and engaging material.
This is a pretty easy class that is relatively interesting with a minimal workload.
This is not a classics course! It is a philosophy course! Can be very very boring if you're not interested in philosophy. The precepts are good, but everything else is very boring.

This was an excellent course and a great way to survey various philosophical and religious traditions while focusing around a common theme. While some of the discussions were overly brief, overall the course engages well with an interesting and compelling central topic.
Very broad, quick pace, interesting but does not get in detail
Very easy course. Minimal work. Somewhat interesting. Guest lectures were cool. Final paper was fun to write. Caroline Mann was a very good preceptor.

You learn about a lot of important philosophers and traditions, and the purpose of the course is to get at an answer to one of the "big" questions in life (what is evil, what is its source), so it's very thought-provoking and definitely worth taking.

You obviously have to take this class. I did the most minimal work possible and still loved the material and lectures. Christian (prof Wildberg) is like a story teller and he gets you thinking. He literally just wants to make sure you try to think about the class and the material, and just cares that you make an effort to explore it. Best, most fun, most engaging, and easiest class I have taken.
do the readings and go to lecture
good class for EM distribution
good class, take it!
good distribution, limited work.
if you enjoy philosophy then this course will be a perfect fit for you. I you don't then take it and learn!.
make time for the readings if you can. actually try to think about how the ideas could impact you and the world.
take the class
the lecturers are amazing. he is a great lecturer. take it!! prof is amazing

this course is a good overview on different conceptions of evil, which was a topic I really enjoyed. Also, really good, interesting class for those of us in the humanities who already have more reading than we can handle.
descrip: This lecture course introduces students to the ways in which humanity has grappled with the existence of evil. The focus lies not on natural evils (such as earthquakes and epidemics) but on moral evil, in particular on the critical examination of the many theories and explanations of human wickedness. The course is highly interdisciplinary. It will take into account not only the literature and imagery of various genres and periods, but also feature invited lecturers from Religion, Philosophy and Psychology to empower the class to evaluate and critique contemporary views and prejudices about the nature and origin of moral evil.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Reading Literature: Fiction
reviews: A good intro fiction class!
Definitely take this course! Chihaya picks amazing books, and Ian Davis is an awesome preceptor! LOVED the books
Do the readings, engage in lecture, and you will have a great time in the course.
Great books and precepts are awesome.

If you are an ENG major looking for a 200 level course, take this. 
If you are not an ENG major and just looking for an interesting course, take this. 
This class is really well run, taught, and thought out. The book choices are incredibly thoughtful and aim to teach and guide rather than instate. Chihaya is a great lecturer with interesting ideas and makes you want to be a better reader yourself.
If you want to read really cool books and learn how to really read well, this class is wonderful. You get to investigate fiction, and Chihaya is wonderful.
Please take a class with Professor Chihaya. She is wonderful. Keep up with readings! Talk to your preceptor...discussions will be more enjoyable if you participate.
Read the novels! You'll get so much more out of lectures, and they're really good books.
Really great material! Devote a lot of time to the course, but worthwhile if you put in effort
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT! Professor Chihaya is amazing and this is a good opportunity to read and study great books! Try to get into her precept if possible.
Take the course! Chihaya is amazing and the readings are varied and really interesting.
Take this course even if you are not an English major. It's a really fun course. If you don't mind the book-a-week format, then I definitely would recommend. Professor Chihaya is great.

The novels in this course and the ideas we study are truly incredible. This class was SO intellectually stimulating if you do the reading. Don't let the title or the fact that it's a requirement for English majors turn you off. Professor Chihaya is a great lecturer and really wants her students to feel good about the class. Same with Ian the preceptor I had.
You'll be reading one book per week so if you anticipate having a strong workload in other classes, be ready to be behind on readings.
prereqs: Prospective concentrators are required to take ENG 200 and one course from the following: ENG 205, 206, 207, 208..
descrip: The making and interpretation of fictions are among our everyday activities, whether or not we realize it; however, we don't always consider what "fiction" is, or what it means. This course will introduce students to the diverse and specific forms fiction takes in literature, with emphasis on the novel and film. We will interrogate the act of creating fictions, and the impact a fictional world can make on a reader. Along the way, we will continually consider two deceptively simple questions: what does fiction do to us? What can fiction do for us?

title: Independent Study
prereqs: Students MUST fill out the Independent Research Project Proposal form and get it signed by the advisor & the dept rep. Hand in to E-211 E-Quad by the first week of the semester..
descrip: Independent research in the student's area of interest. The work must be conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and must result in a final paper.

title: Imagining Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Statistical Learning and Nonparametric Estimation
reviews: Great Course

I'm not an orfe student and I definitely recommend it.  Course is self contained so does not require a significant math background, although you certainly have to pick it up quickly.  Fantastic course overall and I got a lot out of it.  Be ready to work though, problem sets are long and difficult, albeit very interesting and rewarding.
It is a really hard class but I definitely recommend taking it

It's not an easy class, but a very rewarding one. Expect to put in a lot of effort, but also learn an incredible amount. Professor Liu is THE BEST professor I've had at Princeton, and the material is very exciting and up-to-date with modern research. I couldn't have asked for anything more. Anyone interested in machine learning should definitely take this class.
The course is very demanding.
This course is very helpful. Strongly recommended.
You should take it.
prereqs: ORF 524: Statistical Theory and Methods or instructor's approval..
descrip: A theoretical introduction to statistical learning problems related to regression and classification. Topics covered include: Principle Component Analysis, nonparametric estimation, sparse regression, and Classification and Statistical learning

title: Building Real Systems
reviews: A fantastic course! Make sure to work steadily throughout the semester (even if you can only go into the lab for a few minutes). Think throughout the semester about what you want your personal project to be; my biggest advice would be to make the project iterable (rather than one big thing).
Best ELE course!

Car Lab really does make being an ELE worth it. Everything we've learned in the previous classes comes together, plus you get to build anything you want! The amount of freedom and joy that students get from working on a semester long project is truly exceptional. The help and support is there, and at the end you really feel like you've made something amazing.
Carlab is love carlab is life
It is a fair amount of work, but very rewarding. Not as bad as many would have you believe. Most enjoyable ELE class up to date.
Its a shame you essentially have to be an ELE major to take this course - it really is awesome. If you are able to - take it.
Most people that take it have to take it.  You will spend countless nights in the lab, but it is all worth it in the end. Take it!
Of course you have to take this class as an ELE major. Honestly it might be worth taking even if you are a COS/MAE major.

Of course, car lab is a required course for you. In car lab, you will have three modules: Regulating your vehicle to a fixed speed, having your vehicle follow a track using a camera, and an independent project. Take steps to minimize the amount of time spent debugging (Write and document code very clearly, test your hardware boards, etc. ) because debugging takes the majority of the time. Do not do junior independent work at the same time! Finally, you should try to take two easy distribution requirements this semester.

Of course, if you are ELE, you have to take this anyway.

GET THINGS DONE EARLY! And don't complain about a tight schedule, especially for the Line Follower. It makes the final project much easier if you have more time to pick and order parts.
Start early, work often. Don't get too frustrated, even if it is the 11th hour. Take deep breaths when everything inevitably breaks.
TAKE IT!!!!!!
Take it if you're ELE or a super-enthusiastic COS major.

Take it with the mentality that the loads of time you're spending is not actually work. You're going to enjoy so much of it. Yea the debugging of hardware sucks, but thats a part of this major. Once you overcome them you will be a champion.
Take this class if you are an ELE major and have to otherwise it's a lot of time and work that you aren't used to.

The key to doing well in Carlab is starting early. Everyone will tell you this, but it is the greatest and truest advice. Start early on every single project, because random unforeseen problems will come up at the last minute and you will have to spend hours and hours debugging before the deadline. This is especially important for the independent project because you need have an overall idea of what you want to deliver and what parts you need to order before you can start working. These are crucial weeks, and if you don?t plan well ahead of time, it can cut into time that you could be working on your project.
Think about what you want for your project early!! And make sure you don't bite off more than you can chew; mechanics are hard, and we aren't MAE majors!

This is an awesome course. Most likely you're ELE and you have to take it. But if you are on the fence at all (and you're from a different major), do it. It's fun, scary, frustrating and amazing. You definitely learn more than you even think you could. Yes, it is very time consuming but there are only about 5 lectures throughout the course of the semester and the rest is just work in your free time. So don't worry about the scheduling of the labs or anything.
You have to take it anyway

You probably have to take this class, so the only advise I have is that you should take a light semester in terms of other classes so that you have time to spend on your car, which you will really want to because it will be incredible fun. Really look forward to the class, as its just amazing and will actually make you feel like an engineer. Also, if you have a good partner, then that'll help a lot, but regardless, try to have a clear division of responsibilities with your partner and dont leave things till the end at all.
prereqs: ELE 206 and ELE 301. Permission of instructor..
descrip: Comprehensive, laboratory-based course in electronic system design and analysis. Covers formal methods for the design and analysis of moderately complex real-world electronic systems. Course is centered around a semester-long design project involving a computer-controlled vehicle designed and constructed by teams of two students. Integrates microprocessors, communications, and control.

title: Intensive Elementary Arabic II
reviews: Avoid Anita. She will only frustrate you when learning how to speak the language, and she tends to teach grammar topics incorrectly and then have to reteach them differently. She also does not offer any feedback on oral assignments, did not grade our midterm assignment, and gets extremely frustrated with students who ask about how they're doing in her class. If you were in 101 like me, do not move up to 104 (unless a different instructor is teaching the course), and stick with 102, where you will actually learn Arabic and be treated fairly.
Be prepared to work a lot. Many hours- not necessarily hard work, just tedious

Consider that this is a very challenging course and you most likely will not become fluent anytime soon. Princeton's Arabic department just isn't very good, and I think this is a pretty widely believed opinion. I hope that the department can add more native Arabic speakers to its number.
don't take this class

i really like arabic as a language but b/c its so hard you really need to make sure you have a good teacher. i would recommend nancy or greg. tom wasn't very awkward and mumbled in drill - not confident in his speaking ability. anita wasn't very helpful and didn't really help if you said that something in the class wasn't going well.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 103..
descrip: A continuation of 103. The second semester of a full-year language course designed specifically for students with a strong background in another Semitic language; those who have considerable experience in learning foreign languages; or students of Arab heritage who have not had training in reading and writing Arabic. This course is normally followed by ARA 105; students who perform very strongly in this course may be able to test into ARA 107, with the permission of the department.

title: Intensive Intermediate German
reviews: A great class with great professors, but be prepared for an incredible amount of work. This class kind of consumed my life. That being said, you will definitely come out of it with improved German.
Be prepared to work very hard and you will be justly rewarded!
Definitely manageable as a double course!  Would recommend taking 3 other courses at the same time.  Great way to fast-track your German, and I would also recommend going to Munich if you can!
Definitely take this! You get two credits, and I would say it's definitely less work than two classes would be.

I would advise them to do DerDieDas regularly, and only allow themselves to spend a set amount of time on it. I would also advise them to try to keep up with the required films and readings, and to take advantage of all the materials they'll get for test prep.
It takes a lot of time and it is a lot of homework but it is a rewarding language class. I took it mainly for fun :).

It's quite a lot of work and a lot of class each day, so be prepared to really invest in it. However, at the end of the semester you'll find that your language skills really have improved a lot, so I definitely thought it was worth it.
Now that this class is on the Der Die Das curriculum, I highly highly highly recommend it. If Rankin is teaching it especially, but even if not the German department is fantastic.
Stay on top of the vocabulary and grammar, Do the DerDieDas activities, they really help!
TTTAKE IT!

Take this course if you are at all thinking about wanting to get better at German! I know it's a double course, which may be discouraging, but it really isn't that much more work than a regular course! Take it, you will not regret it. Both Angi and Carolina are awesome, too, if you happen to have them as professors. And the rest of the German department is wonderful as well.
Take this! It is very fast-paced but I've learned so much. It's about 1.5 classes worth of work.

This class does not have too much daily homework, but you need endurance to keep up with the work steadily over the course of the year. Each day builds on the next. German is a very worthwhile and beautiful language, and GER 1025 was for me the perfect pacing, as well as combination of speaking, listening, cultural exploration, and writing.

This class is a lot of work, but what you put in is what you put out. You will learn a lot of German, but be prepared for at least an hour of homework per night in addition to the hour and 20 minutes of class and other projects from time to time.

This course is absolutely worth it. The teaching staff is excellent and the material, while challenging and stimulating, is presented in a very comprehensible way.
The addition of the extra texts is gradual and the workload is manageable. Perhaps the most valuable aspect of this course is chance to develop your speaking skills with classmates of a comparable level who challenge you to better your own skills. Put in the work and you will be amazed at the rewards you reap. Don't believe me? I could have written this entire review in German after 6 months of learning the language.

This course is wonderful, but it takes a lot of time. Be prepared for three hours of class work five days a week. You have to stay on top of class and the homework on a daily basis, or you will quickly fall behind. Embrace every chance you have to speak, think, or read German, and you will be amazed at the results.

This is a really good course, and I felt like I learned more than I thought possible. At the same time, I don't think my ability to speak/write/read German improved as much as it did in GER101, though that might just be a function of the general learning progression for new languages. Maybe because I felt like my progress was slowing down, but I felt a bit less impressed by this course than I did by GER101.
This is an amazing course with great instructors. The readings are interesting, and classes are always fun. Be prepared to do a lot of daily assignments, though.
prereqs: GER 101 and permission of instructor. Enrollment by invitation only, following an interview with the course instructor; interviews are normally offered to students in GER 101 attaining a grade of A or A-..
descrip: Intensive training in German, building on GER 101 and covering the acquisitional goals of two subsequent semesters: communicative proficiency in a wide range of syntax, mastery of discourse skills, and reading strategies sufficient to interpret and discuss contemporary German short stories, drama, and film. Intensive classroom participation required. Successful completion provides eligibility for GER 107 or, in exceptional cases, for 200 level courses. Participants are eligible to apply for Princeton-in-Munich (107-G), June, 2016.

title: The Politics of Development
reviews: Amazing class - my favorite class so far, I would say. The material/lectures are very well-organized, grading (though not easy) is fair, and the readings are super interesting. TAKE IT! It will change your view on the world!
Fantastic course. Lots of reading but the readings are enjoyable.

Great comparative politics course, especially with Professor Kohli! Offers a great overview of several developing regions (Latin America, East Asia, Africa, and India), with a thematic focus at the end. Substantial, but manageable amount of reading
Great course, a lot of reading.
Great course.

I highly recommend this class for anyone interested in understanding why the world is the way it is today.  The class is fundamentally about how countries across the developing world have taken various approaches towards achieving economic development, and Professor Kohli does a terrific job of presenting all of this important information in an orderly and manageable fashion.  One of the best classes offered at this school.

If you are interested in development and the course listing appeals to you, take it! Professor Kohli literally wrote the book on a lot of the material and you will learn a ton about different regions of the world and how they have developed economically and politically in the last 100 years or so. Definitely a solid class!

If you are interested in the subject of developing countries this class is very well taught. Atul is kind and very knowledgeable. I had an overall good time! My only critique is the workload which can be intense as he only gives you a weekend to write major papers.
If you have a deep interest in the subject matter, or are interested in learning more about developing economies and politics in the aforementioned regions, definitely take this course!

If you're at all interested in development, I would highly recommend this course, as you get a terrific balance of the broader questions asked in the study of development as well as specific country cases that give you the tools to explore those questions.

If you're interested in development, take! Taking as an unrelated major, it was challenging but super interesting - combines a bunch of disciplines as is very real-world. Kohli makes the class though, Idk about other professors.
Kohli is a super awesome professor if he's teaching!  Nicest guy ever and definitely make the effort to be in his precept.  Super heavy on readings, but very worthwhile! Keep up with readings.
Professor Kohli is phenomenal and the subject material is super interesting.
Really good class with a great professor!
Take it, very interesting, don't be put off by Kohli's quietness, he has a lot of interesting things to say.
Take this class with Professor Kohli
Take this course! You will develop a new perspective on the world and how we should think about developing nations.
The course is very informational and covers a large scope of material.  You will take a lot from it.

This course was my absolute favorite this semester. It is a ton of reading, but they're all very interesting. The assignments are really intense, but there are only 3 (one final) and if you've done the readings, they're manageable. If you stay on top of your readings, you'll love the course.
Very interesting class if you're interesting in the developing world.
descrip: This course will focus on the state's role in promoting economic growth and distribution in the developing world. The core organizing question for the course is: why have some regions of the developing world been more successful at industrialization and/or poverty alleviation than other regions. The students will learn about the patterns of development in Asia, Africa and Latin America, with special attention to such countries as China, India, South Korea, Nigeria and Brazil. General challenges that face all developing countries -- globalization, establishing democracy and ethnic fragmentation -- will also be analyzed.

title: Byzantine Art and Architecture
reviews: An interesting class, worth the time
Go to lecture and take reasonably good notes. A good, not-too-difficult class.
I would advise to take good notes.
Take it if you're interested in learning abut Byzantine art, mosaics, and churches.
descrip: This course introduces the student to the art of the Byzantine Empire and its aftermath from ca. 800 to ca. 1600. Byzantine art has often been opposed to the traditions of western naturalism, and as such has been an undervalued or little known adjunct to the story of medieval art. In order to develop a more sophisticated understanding of our visual evidence, this course will stress the function of this art within the broader setting of this society. Art theory, the notions of empire and holiness, the burdens of the past and the realities of contemporary praxis will be brought to bear upon our various analyses of material from all media.

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: (Half-Term) - Proposal Writing
descrip: This six-week course explores the different elements of putting together a proposal for external funding. It is co-taught by members of the anthropology department. We will explore 1) how to formulate a question, 2) relation of question to theory, 3) relation to existing scholarship, 4) significance, 5) budget, and 6) coherence.

title: Seminar in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature - Writing the People in 19thC France
descrip: What is the people? Much of nineteenth-century literature is an effort to confront this urgent political question after the Revolution, and to give shape and voice to this amorphous new sovereign. At once ubiquitous and intangible, the people is an unsettling power that modern writing seeks to name, express, silence, or shape. This course examines some landmark novels (by Hugo, les Goncourt, Sue, and Zola) and social analysis (by reformers, hygienists, and intellectuals) at the crossroads between politics and aesthetics. Critical texts by Marx, Chevalier, Ranciere, Foucault, T.J. Clark, Lefort, and Rosanvallon.

title: Dance Technique and Anatomy of Movement
reviews: It's a bit of a time commitment, but very valuable for long term understanding of your body, and how to care for it.
Take it!
This class isn't your typical dance class; it felt more to me like yoga versus doing actual choreography, so if you are expecting actual choreography, don't take this class.
don't do the homework unless they badger you about it. you'll pass no matter what. stuff you learn is very interesting, but six hours of class each week is quite a lot. do take it.
required for dance department students.  fair class but very slow and has a HUGE range of levels
prereqs: Must have taken DAN 207, 209, 219, 220, 319, 419, 420, 431, 432 or equivalent dance experience..
descrip: This course provides laboratories and cross-genre dance technique to facilitate a somatic understanding of kinesiology. Students identify limitations and expand individual expression. Technique class will integrate ballet and modern techniques while emphasizing values of exploration and risk-taking. Movement labs will integrate research in functional anatomy/kinesiology and diverse systems of somatic education to understand both the potential of neuro-motor development & physiological systems. Classes will provide freedom of exploration in all genres of dance and give students knowledge to strengthen physicality and movement repertoire.

title: From DNA to Human Complexity
reviews: A great STL - not that hard and very engaging. You don't have to go to lectures to pass (the lecture slides are sufficient) but the lecturers are all very engaging and knowledgeable.
A much easier course for the students who have already taken AP Bio. For those including myself who had not it was definitely a challenge but very fascinating. Would recommend

Definitely take this class! It is among the few courses I've encountered at Princeton in which the professor(s) actually care about ensuring that you understand the material. The material is relevant, and is great for people who would like to know more about the role biology plays in daily life
Focus during lecture because the slides dont have all the info written on them and study hard for each exam - non-cumulative so that's great!

For the exams, swallow the powerpoint slides whole. A lot of brute memorization, but also make sure you really understand the processes that are discussed in class. The lab TAs are so helpful, so ask them anything!
Good STL! Very interesting topics and lab is actually pretty cool. Not especially difficult, particularly with some high school science background.
Good for those with limited experience in biology.
Great course if you are interesting in this material. Prepare a lot for exams, otherwise the homework is not bad at all and I learned a lot of interesting things!
Great lab class! Labs are fun and engaging, and you actually learn a lot, especially for someone that has little to no experience with biology or labs.

I definitely recommend this as an STL, especially if you enjoyed AP Bio. I am majoring in English and I'm pretty bad at science, but this class was interesting, very relevant, and not that demanding. You don't really have to have prior knowledge, but general interest makes it better. Labs are short and kind of fun. I recommend PDF but you probably wouldn't even get a bad grade without the PDF option.

I highly recommend this course as an STL for humanities majors. While it helps to have taken AP biology, it seems like most students find it to be a pretty manageable class with minimal workload; that said, you learn a lot as well. You'll learn about the molecular processes and functions and extend the discussion to current events and issues. Great class!
I would recommend that other students take this course if they are looking to learn about biology from passionate and engaging professors.
I wouldn't recommend this class as an easy STL requirement.

If you're motivated to learn molecular biology, take this course. The lecturers are great. But don't expect this course to be a walk in the park. You have to understand concepts that aren't necessarily explained thoroughly during lectures to do well on tests! Study hard. PDF.
It is a good P/D/F. The midterms come harder than expected.

It's a good intro course to take for a distributional requirement. I didn't find it difficult at all. The quality of lectures does vary depending on who is leading them. Honestly, Heather was my favorite because she said what she had to say. Eric, although he's really passionate, tended to go on a bit.
It's a great STL. The labs are really fun and educational! If you have a good lab partner it's even better! the tests are definitely hard but the lectures are interesting
TAKE THIS COURSE! Fun, interesting, relaxing STL. No need to PDF unless you want to put literally no effort in.
Take if you are uncertain about your expertise in bio, moves slowly, covers general topics
Take it! The best lab that I could think of. The instructors are fantastic.
Take!

This class was great. I am glad that it was not a joke in terms of workload so that the students who were taking it showed a much higher level of engagement than what I imagine occurs in other STL courses. The material was fascinating and presented in a clear way by some of the best professors I've had here. It was also super well organized and structured in terms of the labs, workload, exams, etc. Thank you everyone involved.

This course is amazing if you want an introduction to molecular biology! Lectures were fantastic and all three professors were great. Labs were a ton of fun and overall the course wasn't too difficult.

This is an awesome way to learn about MOL without being in a crazy competitive and intense environment. I loved this class, and would highly recommend it to anyone who needs an STL...OR even if you don't. The material is fascinating, and the concepts are broken down in such a clear way, yet it doesn't feel like you are babied or learning simple material. This is a great class if you liked science in high school but then were scared off by science at Princeton.
good class
descrip: This lecture and laboratory course will acquaint non-biology majors with the theory and practice of modern molecular biology, with a focus on biological topics of current public interest. Topics include: structure of DNA, RNA, proteins, genomes and an overview of state-of-the-art technologies including cloning, recombinant DNA and PCR. The course will address how recent scientific advances affect issues relevant to human biology including forensics, stem cells, molecular evolution and the genetic basis of human traits and behaviors such as obesity and aggression.

title: The French Enlightenment
reviews: Be prepared to read a lot of political philosophy.
Do the readings and pick out certain parts that are of the most interest to you. Engage with the texts and place them in relation with the other writers of the time.
Prof. Bell is an incredible teacher and knows a ton about a lot of different topics. Definitely go to office hours just to talk to him. It will hep you enjoy the class more.
The topic of this course should be part of general knowledge, and deals with issues that are still very relevant nowadays. Definitely consider taking it.
This is an amazing class.  Highly recommended!
descrip: The French Enlightenment was one of the most intensely creative and significant episodes in the history of Western thought. This course will provide an introduction to its major works. Each class meeting will consist of a two-hour discussion, followed by a 45-minute background lecture for the subsequent week's readings.

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - American Environmental History
reviews: A three hour seminar (more like lecture/discussion between the professors) was kind of long for this class. It could have probably been shorter. However the content was interesting, and the professors were entertaining.

If you're interested in the material but have trouble finding time to read the books on your own and want a manageable work load, then take this class.  I really really like the Poppers.  They're a rare breed of professor in that they really genuinely care about their students.  They want to be there as mentors.  And for me, that was the best part of the class.  The books that you read are also really important in thinking about environmentalism and are overall really fun to read!
descrip: Explores the diverse connections between America's national development and natural environment. It examines how the U.S. originated, then expanded to cover a continental land mass, and the ways that expansion changed the nation. It analyzes how, why, and with what consequences major parts of the U.S. economy--for instance, farming, energy, services and government--have grown or in shrunk. It looks at how and with what results the U.S. has incorporated different ethnic and racial groups. It shows how, why, and with what outcomes it has historically globalized and conducted its foreign policy, and offers insights into current landscapes.

title: Natural History of Mammals
reviews: Be prepared to work a lot.

From studying zebra vigilance to conducting a giraffe census with teams of Kenyan schoolchildren, this course was absolutely incredible! Intensive field work learning about African mammals and great classroom lectures and discussions as well. Dan is an amazing professor and cares a lot about his students. Definitely do the field semester abroad in Kenya.

I strongly recommend the tropical biology and sustainability program in Kenya. You will leave this course with many applicable skills, and you will learn, and digest, an incredible amount in three weeks. You are always given a choice of projects so that you can really tailor your work to your interests, and the professor is extremely dedicated to the course and dedicated to your understanding of the course material.
If you're considering spending a semester at Mpala, you can handle working hard and being outside, please, please do it.

This was one of my favorite courses as an undergraduate. The course material was comprehensive in the field of Behavioral Ecology, and the lectures and projects provided an in-depth understanding of the subject. Most importantly, I learned how this science can be applied to a career in conservation and gained experience with leaders in the field.
prereqs: EEB 211, and EEB 321. Permission of the instructor is required for non-EEB majors. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: Introduction to concepts, methods, and material of comparative natural history, with African mammals as focal organisms. Perspectives include morphology, identification, evolution, ecology, behavior and conservation. Observations and experiments on a variety of species in different habitats and at a range of scales will provide insights into the adaptive value and underlying mechanistic function of mammalian adaptations. This course will be taught in Kenya at the Mpala Research Center and nearby field sites.

title: Britain 1815-1945: Empire, Democracy, and War
reviews: Definitely take it.  She's a great lecturer and the readings are wonderful.

I highly recommend this course. Attend all of the lectures because they're awesome. Even if you're not a history major, this is a great class to understand how to be a good historian from one of the best in the field.
I recommend. Only problem is that it can get on one's nerves as it covers a very large period of time and incredible specificities are required to be known
Only take this course if you really love history.

Prof. Colley is a great lecturer and the subject matter was interesting, at least to me?you don't really learn about British history in high school. She was also a great preceptor, but I was annoyed that she was absent during three precepts?if any student missed three precepts in a class they'd likely fail so a professor doing that is pretty disgraceful.
Take it! Interesting and not too hard. Great precept!
Take the class if the subject is of interest. The workload is manageable, though what you get out of the course really depends on what you put in. The lectures are very good.

This is a pretty standard survey into British history in the time period listed. Colley is extremely well versed and organized--her lectures are very easy to follow. If you're interested in learning more about the topic--take it
great content, Colley is very good lecturer
this class was very interesting and I enjoyed the lectures, but would recommend only as a history departmental requirement
descrip: Since Britain's empire already contained a fifth of the globe's population in 1820 and--on paper--reached its widest extent in 1945, this course embraces both national and global history. We explore how the UK became the prime economic and imperial power, and look at its competitors and those resisting it. We look at Britain's social, cultural, intellectual, gender, and political workings, relations with Ireland, and at the impact of world wars. We consider the ambiguities of world power status and the meanings of national decline.

profs.name: Dunia Catalina Mendez Vallejo, Course Head

title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style
reviews: 307 gives you the opportunity to practice speaking in class discussion and do some interesting written and project work, class time covers topics related to sociolinguistic patterns in spanish and is interesting content.
A course keep your Spanish from getting too rusty, but not really a course that will greatly improve your Spanish. It also isn't hugely stimulating.
A great course for developing language skills!

Engage with the material and ask for help or to even further develop your idea! The course is designed to make you ask questions and search for linguistic differences you otherwise might not have noticed.
If you're interested in learning more about the details of the Spanish Language and its linguistic roots, definitely take this class! You'll very much appreciate the class discussions.

It is not the most interesting Spanish course I have ever taken. Unless you are interested in linguistics, specifically language acquisition and language change, I would recommend another Spanish course. If you do find yourself taking it, make sure you stay on top of the coursework (which is more than manageable) and talk to Dunia before you turn in ANYTHING. She loves to give constructive feedback.
It really helps you realize that Spanish is contextual and certain situations require different forms/registers of application of the language.
Material is kind of dry, it's a linguistic take on Spanish. Not too much work though -- less than 207 is you're looking for a benchmark.
Take it--great class, very interesting, and very helpful in developing as a writer and speaker of Spanish.

Take other Spanish classes. The work isn't spread out well - basically you're swamped for 3 weeks of the semester and your Spanish won't improve much. The material is not interesting and the curve is not generous.
Take this class if you want to learn more about how to use the Spanish language, but don't expect it to be the most thrilling course you take.
Take this class! It may not be the most interesting Spanish class you will ever take, but it is a solid language and culture course.
Take this course!
The language classes I have taken at Princeton are the most fun because of the professors.  At least in Spanish and Portuguese, they are all awesome.
This class is pretty easy and is really what you want to put into it. If you want to get better at speaking and writing in Spanish, I think you definitely can if you apply yourself.

This class was wonderful for learning about different aspects of Spanish linguistics and culture. It is a very managable amount of work, and all very interesting. The final essay is a group project, which is a bit unfortunate, but it is a very reasonable length, like 5 pages. Other than that, everything is very straightforward.

I very much enjoyed this class, and highly recommend taking it!!

This course is great if you're interested in learning about what role the Spanish languages plays in different countries around the world. If you're looking for a literature class, this is not for you, but if you're more interested in the cultural aspects of language, it is well worth it.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course. Students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score can take the course with instructor's permission..
descrip: SPA 307 is an advanced language course. Its main purpose is to develop and reinforce accuracy and fluency in both writing and speaking Spanish. Students will also learn to identify linguistic features that characterize different genres, as well as social and cultural factors that aid in the interpretation and understanding of different texts and types of speech. More specifically, the course aims at providing the tools for discourse analysis, raising awareness of the social and ideological values that permeate discursive practices, and developing autonomy and proficiency as an advanced learner of Spanish language.

title: Random Heterogeneous Materials
descrip: Composites, porous media, foams, colloidal suspensions, geological media, polymer blends, and biological media are all examples of heterogeneous materials. Often the microstructure of such materials is random. The relationship between the macroscopic (transport, mechanical, electromagnetic, and chemical) properties and microstructure of random heterogeneous materials is formulated. Topics include statistical characterization of the microstructure via n-point distribution functions; percolation theory; fractal concepts; sphere packings; Monte Carlo simulation techniques; and image analysis of microstructures; homogenization theory; effective-

title: Gender and the Social History of the Pre-modern Middle East
descrip: This course offers an introduction to pre-modern Middle Eastern social history focused on gender and women's lives. Proceeding chronologically from late antiquity through the eighteenth century, we will use secondary scholarship and primary sources (including legal and literary texts, court records, and letters) to examine pre-Islamic and Islamicate ideas and practices surrounding male and female modesty, mobility, honor, kinship, social ties, access to property, legal status, and sexuality; how these ideas and practices shaped men's and women's experiences within households and in the public sphere; and how they changed over time.

title: Game Theory
descrip: This course will provide a broad treatment of game theory and its applications, particularly in economics. Coverage will include such topics as: common knowledge and rationality, refinements of Nash equilibrium, auctions, bargaining, mechanism design, dynamic games, and reputation. This follows up on the introduction to game theory provided in the microeconomic sequence.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Architecture, Globalization, and the Environment
reviews: Absolutely consider taking it if you are even slightly interested in environmental issues. This class introduces you to a variety of reasons why architecture matters so much to our environment and our society. Initially I was only interested in the environmental aspect of the course but ended up enjoying all the lectures. Prof da Costa Meyer is fantastic in presenting the material in an impassioned manner about the intersection of architecture with sustainability, social issues, vernacular style, cultural heritage, etc. You will walk away from the class deeply concerned about our environment if you are not already so. However, this class does not give you the solutions to these problems. To solve the complex, urgent problems presented in class, we need actions on the part of conscious and responsible citizens. That is what the class can teach you and leave you in the long term.
Go to precept, make sure to participate, lectures are pretty great.
Good course to take.
Great class, Professor de Costa Meyer is very passionate about the subject and it shows in the lectures.
Interesting class if you are concerned about the intersectionality of many topics.
Love this class! I struggled a bit because I didn't keep up with the readings, but Professor da Costa Meyer is fabulous!
Take this course! Not hard before reading period, every lecture is really interesting and you learn a lot about topics that are relevant to everyone today.
Take this course! Professor da Costa Meyer's lectures are always interesting.

The class is a lot of work but you learn so many interesting things in the class. It's definitely not the best PDF class but I learned so many things about a wide variety of topics I would have never explored before. I would almost say it's worth the final and the final paper.
This is a really interesting and engaging class. Professor da Costa Meyer is a fantastic professor.

This was one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Professor da Costa Meyer is one of the most encouraging and supportive professors I have ever had. This course provided an engaging overview of how politics, environmentalism, and architecture intersect. Professor is thoroughly dedicated to social justice issues so anyone interested in inequality, the environment and architecture should definitely take this course. The lectures exceeded my expectations. The professor struck an excellent balance between providing necessary background information and contextualizing the course materials with challenging dominate narratives around the issues covered in class. Professor da Costa Meyer tried to encourage people to participate in lecture and made sure that everyone had a chance to share their ideas in precept.
Very interesting and informative.
definitely take, interesting course that connects the three topics
loved it. 10/10 would recommend
this is a great class!!! prof is great, super engaging and genuinely cares about students and got to know everyone!! topics and super interesting, great for LA and applicable to real life stuff.
very interesting class, especially for an LA. 15 page paper and final at the end were a little much but overall good class take it!
descrip: This course analyzes contemporary architecture and its relation to climate change and to social problems having to do with urbanism. Special attention will be paid to the erosion of public space, whether it is due to gentrification, gated communities, outright segregation, or to the devastating impact of war in urban zones in many parts of the world. We will study issues of sustainability, as well as climate justice and environmental racism. Architecture's complicities with regard to global warming and its squandering of fossil fuels are central to our approach.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Behavioral Economics
descrip: This course explores a variety of policy-relevant insights from experimental economics and behavioral economics.
