We talk about the experimental methodology to uncover facts, and we look at a number of experimental studies, both from the lab, but mostly from the field, to see when and under what circumstances behavioral mechanisms matter for policy. Topics include, for example, incentive design (including non-financial incentives and loss-aversion), charitable giving (altruism, public goods), malleable preferences and framing.

title: Studies in French Language and Style
reviews: Do all the readings so you can understand what's happening in class! They're actually really interesting.
Do the readings!

Even if you're not into science fiction and mystique (I'm certainly not), you should take this course for the insight into the more bizarre elements of French culture. If you are not convinced by that, then you should take this course for the professor, Florent Masse, who brings an incredible energy into the room. Especially if you are looking to hone and practice your oral French, this class is an optimal choice due to the breadth of content that is discussed and its small size, which allows for the class to run at a comfortable pace.

FRE 207 was a great course. It definitely was a step up in work and intensity from the FRE101/102/107 sequence, but worth it. I saw myself grow a lot as a French speaker this semester, and it was interesting to begin doing more text analysis and work beyond grammar in class.
Great course! Doing all of the readings and watching all of the movies can be time-consuming, but the discussions were very entertaining and helpful for improving language ability.

If you love French and already know a bit but don't want to take a very time-consuming course, then this is for you. Pick the section with Florent Masse, he is probably one of the most interesting people on campus and he will make class so much fun to go to! This course is an enjoyment.
It can be challenging and keeping up with the grammar is a bit hard, but it's a good class overall!
It is really helpful to do the grammar exercises throughout the semester.
Take it take it take it. It's very fun and not super demanding at all. You'll improve your French and engage with a lot of very fun, yet important works.
Take it!
Take it!  Professor Warwood is the nicest professor I have had at Princeton, and I loved the class!  The readings and films are super interesting.  The workload is about the same as 108.
Take it, the readings are awesome and you won't regret it
Take this class! Readings and films are fun. Constant work, but never too much or too difficult.
Take this with Florent Masse. No exceptions.
Take this with florent if he's teaching it again. he's fantastic and hilarious and you will greatly improve your french!
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion. Film series. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.

title: The Everglades Today and Tomorrow: Global Change and the Impact of Human Activities on the Biosphere
descrip: See website

title: Princeton and Slavery
descrip: Research seminar focused on Princeton University's historical connections to the institution of slavery. The class will help develop a vibrant website that details the slave-holding practices of Princeton faculty and students, examines campus debates about slavery, and investigates whether money derived from slave labor contributed to the early growth of the school. Class will meet in Mudd Library.

title: Geological Constraints on the Global Carbon Cycle
descrip: This course explores global geochemical cycles through the use of simple numerical models. Topics covered range from box models of the geologic carbon and oxygen cycles, planetary thermostats, and atmospheric oxygenation, to box models of Cenozoic seawater chemistry (Mg and Ca), to 1D diffusion-reaction modes of the dynamics of carbon and oxygen in sedimentary systems. Previous coursework in differential equations and MATLAB are highly desirable but not absolutely necessary.

title: Approaches to American History
reviews: A really good prep class to take if you are considering the History concentration. Ronny Regev and Alec Dun both are great teachers and great people to learn from (I had Ronny as my preceptor and really enjoyed it). Highly recommend this course.

Definitely keep up with the readings - you'll thank yourself later when you're writing the essays. Go to every lecture. They're super interesting and you get to learn from some awesome professors. Go to office hours for help with essays. The professors are super helpful and very willing to help you develop arguments.
Difficult but rewarding. Only take if you are willing to put in the time to engage with the material.
Excellent course, the reading load isn't too bad. A variety of history professors lecture you, so you get a good introduction to the department.
Great class for history majors! Readings were long. Be ready to talk in class.
Make sure you really are interested in the topics.
Super interesting topics, but unless you go to office hours you won't get much guidance about how to write papers
Take it--it's a great class and super interesting!
Take it.
Take this class with Ronny. She does a great job in precept.
The readings are a lot but if you piecemeal them, go to office hours and do your best to improve on the essays, you'll do great. Literally, only three essays. Can't beat that.

This course is very good. The lectures are fantastic because you get a nice sampling of different professors and see a range of the different styles of the department and discipline. The readings can get a little dry and long, but they are not so bad that you cannot quickly catch up in time for the essays. The essays require a different way of writing, but you get used to it, and will hopefully see their merit. I highly recommend the course to potential history majors.
This is a difficult course. Keep up with the readings and pay attention during discussions.
This is a great course. Go to the lectures. They may not really matter at all in terms of your performance in the course, but you'll get to get to hear some of the departments' best professors.

This is a must-take course, even for non-majors! The lectures are incredible - each week, a different professor in the history department lectures on a very specialized topic regarding either the Little Rock Crisis, Salem Witch Trials or Denmark Vesey conspiracy (the three main units). It's a great way to preview the department as a whole and choose which future history courses you might be interested in taking! In terms of work, the reading is manageable as long as you don't fall behind. And even if you do (like I did), it's not impossible to catch up in time (and do well) for the essays.
lots of reading. when essays are about to be due, it can be very stressful
prereqs: First priority is given to Sophomores then Freshmen..
descrip: A useful introduction for potential history concentrators, particularly those interested in a course focused on the methodology and practice of writing history. Students will immerse themselves in documents from three critical historical events: the Salem witch trials, the Denmark Vesey slave insurrection conspiracy, and the Little Rock school integration crisis. We will stress interpretation of documents, the framing of historical questions, and construction of historical explanations.

title: Fundamentals of Queueing Theory
reviews: For a student who understands ORF 309 well, this class is essentially just an extension. However, there isn't a good set of lecture notes like 309 which is a bummer. Psets are still doable just through the lecture notes, just more tedious.
I really liked doing the problem sets! No need to go to lecture.

If you are interested in applications of ORF 309, then this is a good course to take. Professor Massey's lectures can be slow at times, but he is very patient and understanding in explaining material. Given the significant time commitment required for the take-home midterm exam, seniors may wish to consider taking an alternative course that will not take as much time away from thesis work during spring break.

If you liked probability then this would be a good course to take. It is both conceptual, you develop some more probability theory along the way, and computational, you do simulations of queues with different parameters. Be aware that this course is rigorous but adequate help is available through the office hours. 
It also gives a nice overview of Operations Research through the use of queueing theory which has applications in managing limited resources to meet the demands of the users with acceptable quality of service.
If you really liked ORF 309, I'd look into taking this class.
If you're interested in the material, take it! The class is challenging and the problem sets take time, but it's challenging in a fun way.

It's an extremely interesting field. This is probably one of the most interesting course I have taken in the ORFE department. However, be aware that this course is very HARD and students in this course always get almost perfect score on assignment, so make sure you do that as well.
It's sort of like 309 but much drier.  Massey just reads off the slides.  The difficulty is fine, but everyone gets nearly perfect on everything so the curve is no good.
Professor Massey is so intelligent and is so crisp about the material that anyone with interest in applications of mathematics and queuing theory would enjoy this class.

STAY FAR FAR FAR AWAY from this course, no if's and's or but's about it -- Massey is an awful instructor and the class will be a complete and utter waste of time. Use this time instead to learn something useful (like COS) or fun (like studying for Ramon's probability theory class)
prereqs: ORF 309.
descrip: An introduction to the fundamental results of queueing theory. Topics covered include the classical traffic, offered load, loss and delay stochastic models for communication systems. Through concrete examples and motivations we discuss the theory of Markov chains, Poisson processes and Monte-Carlo simulation. Fundamental queueing results such as the Erlang blocking and delay formulae, Little's law and Lindley's equation are presented. Applications are drawn from communication network systems, inventory management, and optimal staffing.

title: Hispanic Studies: Introduction to Cultural Analysis
prereqs: Another SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission..
descrip: An introduction to the analysis of contemporary cultural texts (narrative, poetry, film, photography) from Latin America and Spain, with the support of various theoretical ideas. The course's main objective is to provide students with a set of strong conceptual, analytical and linguistic skills, which will be of great help in 300-level literature/culture courses.

title: Peacemaking
reviews: If you're interested in the topic, take this course! Professor Nash is an expert on peacekeeping (he was a commander of U.S. ground forces in Bosnia during the NATO intervention) and you will learn a ton. He's a great guy, and very funny. You should get to know him.
Make sure you spend enough time on the readings to be able to engage with them in class, not just regurgitate them.

Professor Nash is an interesting character and it is worth to get to know outside of class. The class itself can be redundant. If you're interested in post-1990 peace operations (= armed state-building), it can be rewarding. But in-class discussions were not always of the highest quality. But in the end, I feel I have learned a lot about the subject matter.
State your opinion clearly and honestly. This class works best with debate on the issues, so offer something to make that debate happen.

Take it. General Nash is a phenomenal teacher. The case studies you dive into are interesting but most of all, General Nash is himself a treasure trove of information. His prompts are sometimes vague, so it's often up to you to take the initiative. But if you're willing to put in the work, you'll gain a lot out of it.

Take this course. General Nash has some great stories and awesome insights. This course is a reason why you chose Princeton over other schools - it's to meet professors like Nash. Overall, the class made me really think about peace operations in the world as well as war itself. It made me challenge my views and reformulate them. Some readings were a bit boring, but overall, they were very useful. Professor Nash changes the curriculum each year to get rid of some readings and include better ones, so this class should definitely be a great class yet again. The papers are very doable, and they will help you understand the material even better.

There are better, more interesting courses, seminars to take. Unless you need it for WWS requirement, I'd advise you go somewhere else. Particularly if you're not WWS, a lot of the conversations will be boring for you.
descrip: This seminar will assess the history, objectives, and effectiveness of international peace operations including peacemaking, peacekeeping, peace enforcement, and peacebuilding efforts. Informed by current and recent operations in places such as the Balkans, Africa, and the Middle East, the class will assess progress by the international community in its ability to respond effectively to the political, economic, and social transitions in post-conflict societies. The seminar will also study the development of U.S. policy toward peace operations.

title: Energy and Commodities Markets
reviews: Feel like this might be different from Carmona or Sircar's version. But I feel like this is an excellent combination of qualitative and quantitative components. You get to read very influential papers! And Professor Lautier is very charming.

I don't this course will be taught by Professor Lautier again because she is a visiting professor. But if it is, I would recommend it. She was a good lecturer and I can honestly say I have a deep understanding of the functioning of energy and commodities markets.
I'd recommend to take this course if you are interested in energy and commodity markets and you want to know more of the economic functions of the markets.
Take this if you are an ORFE major and at all interested in commodities. It would be good to have already taken ORF 335 before this, but not necessary I guess.

The professor is visiting so it's very likely that the class will be very different in the future. Psets were harshly graded, especially given that she hardly provided any actual examples in class and then expected us to know how to carry out the calculations and how to comment on papers. Very non-transparent grading. Mostly Master of Finance students, with a minority of ORFE undergrads. Professor wasn't very helpful during office hours.
prereqs: ORF335 or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course is an introduction to commodities markets (energy, metals, agricultural products) and issues related to renewable energy sources such as solar and wind power, and carbon emissions. Energy and other commodities represent an increasingly important asset class, in addition to significantly impacting the economy and policy decisions. Emphasis will be on the term structure of commodity prices: behavior, models and empirical issues

title: Tropical Agriculture
prereqs: EEB 211 and EEB 321. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: Kenya has some of the most diverse set of crops and farming systems in Africa allowing students to compare productivity, diversity, and ecological processes. Students will spend their time exploring the varied agro-ecosystems, crops, livestock, climates, and soils under which agriculture is practiced in Kenya. The course includes key readings and discussions, intensive field sampling, GIS applications, and modeling. In addition, students will be exposed to the various ecological processes and ecosystem services provided by or interfered with by agriculture. Limited to students in the Tropical Biology and Sustainability Program in Kenya.

title: Optimal Learning
reviews: Although I was interested in the applications of operations research and machine learning, I found that the course taught concepts in an unusual way. You do learn about the process of information collection and decision-making, and the final project really allows you to actually come up with cool ideas. Also, the problem sets don't take up a lot of time at all.

Although Professor Powell claims that the course is somewhat similar (in terms of workload) to 245, this really reminded me more of 307 (in terms of the material, assignments. and project). Powell is a great presenter, though, and incorporates his own experience working on learning problems for various industries. Overall, this is a good course that teaches you how to think about decision making and problems, and while the final project is time consuming and can be extremely frustrating, it's good preparation for independent work/thesis. The programming component isn't too heavy (just consists mainly of modifying a few lines of code in MATLAB), and you don't need a programming background or be good at theory to do well in the course. The notation and the way information is presented in the book and in lecture can be off-putting at times, but just focus on understanding the underlying conceptual themes. Great team of preceptors too!
Do not take this course unless you are very good at notations and coding.
Don't take unless have to
Easy departmental but not the most exciting subject. A lot of vague assignments
I would still take it because its an easy departmental, but don't take it for general interest.
I'd recommend taking it. Requires basic background in MATLAB and probability.

If it were only the first half, I would say this class is one of the coolest I've ever taken. After having been through the second half, however, I just cannot reasonably recommend this class to anyone. With no guidance in the second half and nearly no responsibilities to have, you end up having a massive headache over just how asinine the class can be the day before your reports are due.
If the material sounds interesting, take it. The project is a good way to engage with and apply the material to a real-world problem.
If you like Matlab, take it
Interesting material although the course moves fairly slowly.
It's a pretty easy class, Powell's teaching is a bit confusing at times but he's really nice.  Workload isn't too bad except for the final project at the end.
It's not an easy course and there is a lot of notation and subtleties to put up with, but it's a fascinating field with many real-world applications.  Worth taking
Not hard for an ORF departmental, not the most rewarding though.

One of the easiest ORF departmentals. Relatively interesting, but Powell makes a LOT of notational mistakes. You'll spend most of your time trying to decipher handwriting than learning. Honestly, you could learn an equivalent amount by buying the textbook and reading it-- it's a good one. Powell is a character so be ready to deal with him.

Optimal learners: be prepared for some funky junky notation. If you're able to get past that and some garbage Matlab code, you're in to learn some actually cool material. The class isn't bad: just be prepared to be not too sure what you've learned until the end of the year, when you have to write the humungo paper.
Somewhat interesting, but not sure what takeaways are...?

Start the project early and go talk to Professor Powell if you have any questions about how to do the logistics. Read the book, most problems on problem sets come from there and help with the midterm.
TAKE IT FOR INTEREST!
Take a look at the syllabus and decide if this class if for you. Pretty stats-heavy and a lot of independent work required for project but definitely doable!

Take it if you want a relatively easy ORF departmental that has the chance of high variance on the grade you will receive based on the lack of practice exams and arbitraryness of final project grading
Take it if you want to get a Bayesian perspective. You are unlikely to ever use the things from the class.
Take this course! It isn't too hard, Prof Powell is very nice and applies the material to a range of industries and subjects.

The class is one of the more forgiving ORFE departmentals. It is a very new and interesting field and Professor Powell knows a lot about this field. It is also highly applicable to the real world. The second half of the course was focused on the final project and the lectures weren't super useful at that point. The concepts I learned in this class have stuck, but a lot of the mathematics behind the concepts have gone over my head. The textbook and lectures are a bit dry.
The project part of this course was solid.
The subject matter is interesting, but the class can be disorganized.
This class was disorganized and hard to follow but the material is fantastic.
This course has interesting applications, but the course itself isn't very interesting. The course overall wasn't very much work until the very end.

Wait until the book is updated with the second-half material. It is a new and interesting field, but the course is still either trivial or way too difficult -- it hasn't reached that mature state of being ideal for undergrads, yet.

While it seems like this course is not too much work and interesting, don't fall for it.
It could be interesting, but most of the class time is spent figuring out what all the notation means. The final project has potential, but there was no guidance from Powell. We basically got all of our help from the TAs (I love Xinyu).
Also the fact that there is a final exam after the final project is not appealing.
good class to teach you a new perspective on decision-making
prereqs: ORF 245 and ORF 309.
descrip: Optimal learning addresses the challenge of collecting information efficiently when information is expensive. Applications include topics such as finding the best price for a product, identifying the best treatment for a disease, tuning the parameters in a bidding policy, or choosing the best player for a sports team. Students learn how to formulate a learning problem, identify a belief model, and quantify the value of information. The course covers online and offline learning problems, and introduces students to a range of policies for collecting information.

title: Beginner's French II
reviews: 102 focuses more on grammar and it is really important to learn that. It helps you to make some difficult sentences.
A fair course. Take it with Meghan, she's a great instructor.
Definitely take it. French is very manageable and interesting for those needing a language.
Do independent work to get the most out of this class.

Do not let assignments get away from you, and do what is assigned. It will help you out so much in the long run. And don't be afraid to talk to everyone you know in the language, it's the only way you're going to get better.
Do your work daily and you'll get a lot out of the course.
For grammar, the course pack and in-class presentations are more useful and comprehensive than the textbook.
Good course, well taught.
I HIGHLY recommend taking this class with Meghan Gottschall. She has made this class a wonderful experience.

I believe that taking time to practice speaking French is very important. Not only does it improve your pronunciation, but it also trains your mind to think in French and to recognize correct grammar on the spot.
I will recommend this course, but one should keep in mind that the overall experience is very dependent on the professor you're assigned.
If you put in the work, you can definitely use this as a GPA booster. 5 days a week is rough, but classes go by kind of quickly because it's a very informal classroom setting.
If you want to learn French, take this course. I'm a senior and I took Beginners' French for fun this year. Well worth it, loved it.

It's a fun course. If you get Megan, it's even better. French classes at Princeton aren't the most difficult, despite the nuances of the language, however, if you expect to be fluent, you have to put the time into it.
Review FRE 101 several times throughout the semester.
Stay on top of the textbook exercises - class time is a lot more useful if you have somewhat of an understanding of what is being covered.
Take this class!  You will learn more French that you would think possible in the course of four months and have a lot of fun at the same time.
Take this course! French classes are fun, interesting and very interactive. They can slightly challenging sometimes, but I enjoy this class to much to give up French.
Take this course! You learn so much, and even if you do not have to fulfill a language requirement, this course teaches at least 3 new tenses for verbs, which broadens your vocabulary 3 times over.
Take this if you love French!

This is a very standard level 2 language course. Make sure to keep up with the homework assignments by dedicating about 1 to 1.5 hours each night. The grammar rules really start to accumulate at the second level, and it can become confusing to keep track of all of them at the same time. As such, it's essential not to fall behind. Be warned: there is substantially more work in 102 than in 101, and it does become more challenging. Expect to do longer writing assignments, such as compositions and press reviews.

This professor/course combo was definitely very helpful in improving my French, but you do have to take it seriously and do have to pay attention to subtleties, which sometimes are not stressed as much as I would have wanted.
You'll get as much out of this class as you put in, and there's a lot to be learned.
You'll learn lots of French.
prereqs: FRE 101 or Permission of Instructor. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless FRE 102 is successfully completed..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to enable you to achieve intermediate communication proficiency in French. All four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing will be actively practiced in realistic communicative situations, through a variety of activities designed to help you strengthen newly acquired vocabulary and grammatical structures. You will learn to talk about events and people, construct narratives in French and develop reading and writing skills that will be a foundation for literacy in the target language. There is a wide use of authentic material from France and the Francophone world throughout the course.

title: Econometric Research Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Directed Research I
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research I is normally taken during the first year of study.

title: Into the Deep Past
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Asset Pricing II: Stochastic Calculus and Advanced Derivatives
reviews: Do all the problem sets yourself. Good practice.
I recommend you taking this course.
Theoretical course, but offer some useful insight about financial mathematics. Take it if you don't have any other better choice.
descrip: Course covers the pricing and hedging of advanced derivatives, including topics such as exotic options, greeks, interest rate derivatives and credit derivatives, as well as covering the basics of stochastic calculus necessary for finance. Designed for Masters students.

title: History with Objects and Landscapes
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators.
descrip: Do you ever wonder how and why the objects and landscapes you pass every day or see from a plane got to be as they are now? This seminar teaches you how to "read" things and built and unbuilt landscapes, and how historical archaeologists, anthropologists, historical ecologists and historians have used the material realm to understand the past in ways they could not through written records alone. The course is local and global in focus, covering different epochs of human societies in Princeton, its environs, and the broader world. You will be able to practice new material literacy skills in field trips and in projects for public audiences.

title: Utopia at 500: The Promise of Fiction
descrip: See website

title: Calculus II
reviews: A good course. If you're taking it, it's probably because you have to (I'm a BSE student, so it's required). My professor was Adam Levine, and he was pretty good ? I would be happy to have him teach me again in the future.
Attend classes

Attend every lecture and do the psets in a timely fashion in order to stay up to date with the material (this course moves fairly quickly). Also attend the weekly review sessions; they're immensely helpful for the psets and exams/quizzes.
Be prepared to teach yourself a lot of the material. It is good to have taken BC calc in high school, because some of the material is very hard to grasp if seeing it for the first time.
Come into the course ready to work and engage with the material. If you do, the lessons will come naturally to you and you will better appreciate mathematics.
Definitely go to McGraw study halls the minute you start struggling!

Definitely read the math textbook, and study A LOT for the midterm and quizzes (and the final as well I'm sure!).  Also, the class starts off easy, then gets really difficult, then gets easy again, so don't be discouraged.
Do not be afraid to ask questions in class! All of the professors are encouraging and like to be asked questions!
Exams make up a very large portion of the grade for this class, so make sure you do all the homework as well as any supplementary problems that are provided so that you will be prepared.
Find a group to work on problem sets with
Get Adam Levine as your lecturer!! And attend the review sessions (Javier is great!)
Go ahead and take it. It's challenging and interesting.
Go over the topic prior to class sessions! You will understand better
Go to weekly review sessions (if they still offer these) and ask questions. Review sessions help tremendously with homework.
Good course if you like math but definitely not easy. Study a lot for the mid term.

I consider myself bad at math and was very turned off by taking 103, but found this course to be much better than 103.  Adam Levine was far superior to any 103 professor, and the material and exams were more manageable and fair.
I don't like the math department
I enjoyed it, but I'm definitely a math person. It wasn't easy, but if you work at it you can get an A.
I would recommend taking this class if you enjoy math and want to develop your calculus skills.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in math or need to take it for a distribution requirement. If you do not like math then this will probably be a hard class, the pace is pretty fast.
IF you have BC credit, go to 201. If you have AB credit, DON'T take 175 unless you're positive you don't want to do science stuff...

If possible, try to study for the topics beforehand and solve practice problems. It will pay off trmendously! Adrian Banner has his lectures up online. If you watch those, take detailed notes, and solve lots of problems, you will be saved a tremendous amount of stress. Learning in the actual pace of the 104 classroom just might not work for you. Kudos if it does, but if not take my advice into consideration. Especially if you're in the summer and have time before classes start.

It is easy to fall behind in the course and this is a problem since new material builds on previously learned concepts. Use McGraw individual tutoring or go to office hours to make sure you do not fall behind. Overall good course, take if necessary.
Keep up with the readings, drill problems, and do the 'theory' questions at the end of each chapter WHILE ITS BEING REVIEWED IN CLASS. NOT A WEEK BEFORE THE MIDTERM/FINAL
Make sure you attend review sessions and office hours.
Make sure you brush up on your trig identities before taking the course.

Math is necessary, and if you are deciding between 104 and 175 I definitely suggest 104. The professors are nice, the material is challenging, and you will come out with a deeper understanding of the material.

Mr. Levine is brilliant and the class was structured fairly.  Problem set every week, two quizzes and two exams.  It moves very fast at times, but is not impossible if you can keep up with the problem sets and reading the textbook.

Office hours are key. Doing the problem sets and going to class was not enough for me to be bale to do well on quizzes and exams. It required a lot of practice problems and fleshing out topics during office hours.
Only recommend if you're interested in math or need to take it
Perfectly fine as a prereq for other classes/majors etc.. If you put the work in you'll get a good grade, if not then you won't.
Practice a lot of previous years' tests. It's crucial.
Put in as much work outside of class as possible
Sometimes hard to keep up but it's not that hard to catch up.
Take if required. GO TO OFFICE HOURS AND READ THE BOOK.
Take it if you have to take it, otherwise it's not particularly fun.
Take it if you love math. Know that you will have to put in more work if you didn't have Calc BC in high school, and make sure to work through all psets.
Take it with Professor Levine if you can!
Take the class if you like math!
Take this class but purchase the Calculus Lifesaver by Adrian Banner, it will save your life and make the class much fun.
Take this course as a good preparation for more advanced maths study.
Take this course with Adam, he's great! It'll be hard work, but if you go to lectures and don't procrastinate the problem sets you'll do well and might actually like it!
The course is rigorous and well-taught. Like any other course, you get out what you put in.
The lectures are pretty much directly out of the textbook. If you're not understanding either of them, look for third party videos like Khan Academy or PatrickJMT.
The material is very interesting and occasionally enjoyable, and the professors don't stand between you and the material, instead they do a decent job of running the knowledge over to you.
The tests are manageable. Just attend all precepts and take good notes! Oh, and practise, a lot.
The worst

This class is difficult and will be a large portion of your time. Go to class and get started on the p. sets when you can. Adam Levine is an amazing professor. If you are going to take this course, you need him.
You can't learn 12 weeks worth of material the night before the final, trust me.
do not take if you don't have to.
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Continuation of MAT103. Topics include techniques of integration, arclength, area, volume, convergence of series and improper integrals, L'Hopital's rule, power series and Taylor's theorem, introduction to differential equations and complex numbers.

title: Descartes, Spinoza, and Leibniz
reviews: Definitely take this course, or any course with Daniel Garber! He is a phenomenal lecturer and the work load is perfect, but be prepared to engage with complex philosophical systems that will leave you thinking that you don't understand much. Don't be afraid to ask questions and go to his office hours.
Do the readings several times, and take plenty of notes.
Good readings. Lectures are a bit boring.
Great course. Readings are dense, but so is any philosophy course. Papers are not too bad. Less argument based and more focus on analysis.
Great if you're interested in early modern continental thought.
I would advise that students utilize office hours and reread the difficult texts.
It's a great course that covers continental rationalism. I took the course without any previous philosophy experience and had a semi-difficult time, but the topics covered were very interesting.
It's a great course.The readings can be a little dense, but duh, philosophy. They can take time to get through but accounting for that it is fairly manageable.

Readings are not intense, but unless you are interested in questions of epistemology and metaphysics amongst rationalist philosophers from 1600-1750, you might find the class extremely boring and you might be unable to get excited about the often technical readings.
Take it!
Take this course!! It will open your mind. But, also I would recommend taking this course after you have taken an easier philosophy course.

Take this course, even if you don't have prior experience in philosophy! The reading can be confusing, but they are short, and the most important points are summarized clearly in lectures and precept. There are clear expectations for written work. It is very possible to succeed and learn interesting things.
Take! Definitely worth learning about these great philosophers.
take it if you have genuine interest in the topic...for distributional requirements there have to be easier courses!
descrip: Reason over Sense, Mind over Matter: Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz and others. In this course, we will be studying two main themes in the history of early modern philosophy: the relation between reason and the senses as sources of knowledge, and the relation between mind and matter. The central figures discussed will be Descartes, Spinoza, and Leibniz. Other figures treated my include Hobbes, Pascal, More, Malebranche and Berkeley.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - Writing Autobiography
reviews: Definitely try to take a class with white/cwr class if you can!
Edmund White is a wonderful person to be in the classroom with for a semester. Take this class. Such a great experience to get to know people, work on your writing and work with a wonderful man.
Edmund is the best - definitely take a class with him if you can!
I recommend it for anyone who wants to think about their lives while enjoying a great class with a legendary man.
Professor White is so sweet! It's fun to write about yourself, so you can't really go wrong with this course
TAKE IT
Take, Take, Take! You won't regret it, I promise!
prereqs: Interested students should complete an application (arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app) and include a writing sample of 3-4 pages of prose. Prerequisite: One 200-level fiction course. Application deadline is November 22, 2015..
descrip: In this course students will read autobiographical fragments that reveal a whole gamut of possibilities, from carefully documented memories to novelistic elaboration to wholescale invention. The real work of the course, however, will be creative. Students will explore their own lives through various devices and discover that the truth is never elemental but can be released through literary strategies. During the semester each student will write either one long autobiographical piece or three shorter ones.

title: Climate Change: Impacts, Adaptation, Policy
reviews: A must-take course, a great, doable STN for people from all departments. This is the type of class to take for the professor. You'll learn a lot about international treaties and policy, and you'll get a rich understanding of the complexities of climate change and the many approaches to mitigation and adaptation.

As a Geosciences major who is very interested in getting into the field of climate policy, I think this is the most important and useful course I have taken at Princeton. Professor Oppenheimer is an engaging lecturer with first hand experience of the topics discussed, and the writing assignments really reinforce the readings and help you understand the current decisions being made in international climate agreements. Would 100% recommend!
As a geo major, this course was a bit slow.  I don't regret taking it, but it could be structured better/more up to date on current issues.
Definitely take this course! SO SO interesting and Professor Oppenheimer is amazing.  You will learn so much and from one of the experts in the field.
Fairly easy Geosciences departmental. Professor Oppenheimer is a great lecturer.

If you are interested in the material and can self-motivate to stay engaged though a course in which you can do fairly well with minimal effort, definitely take it! Professor Oppenheimer is an authority on climate change and it is a crucial topic.
Take it
Take this class! It's a very easy but informative class and the professor is great!
This course is very little work and FASCINATING!  Highly recommend.

This is an amazing class. Michael Oppenheimer is a great lecturer and brings current and relevant material every day. Really easy as well with little day to day work, 2 5pg papers, midterm, and 10pg deans date assignment. Would 100% recommend even without any background in environment or policy!

Very good class! The workload is light, it's really not very often necessary to do the readings (especially the more dry technical readings), and the material is typically pretty interesting and relevant.
prereqs: GEO 202 or permission from instructor. Basic knowledge of climate system and climate change, descriptive meteorology, the carbon cycle is assumed..
descrip: An exploration of the potential consequences of human-induced climate change and their implications for policy responses, focusing on risks to people, societies, and ecosystems. As one example: we examine the risk to coastal cities from sea level rise, and measures being planned and implemented to enable adaptation. In addition, we explore local, national and international policy initiatives to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions. The course assumes students have a basic background in the causes of human-induced climate change and the physical science of the climate system.

title: Statics of Structures
reviews: Branko and Becca are two of the most approachable instructors I have had at Princeton. Make sure to take advantage of their plentiful Office Hours to ask clarifying questions on the homework and any other concepts you are struggling with. The last 3-4 weeks of class are certainly the most challenging.
Branko is a great professor and the preceptors are also really great.

Branko's one of the best teachers I've had, and his TA (Becca) is fantastic. If you're MAE and between this and finite, you'll probably have a much better time taking this course. If you're considering doing serious mechanical design work, you might want finite, but it's also something you can pick up in design classes. (From what I've heard it sounds like the increased utility of what you learn in finite isn't worth the experience of taking the class.) Would definitely recommend statics.
Can be a difficult class, but not too bad if you put the time in. Go to office hours!!! Branko is so helpful and patient. Also going to lecture pays off.
Definitely go to class, and if you pay attention the class will be a breeze. Stay on top of your problem sets, and always go for the extra credit!
Definitely take this course if you're MAE
Definitely take this over finite if you're MAE. Branko's lectures are interesting and informative, so try to go to them if you can.
Enjoyable class! If you are MAE, it is a great alternative to finite.
Give time to the problem sets. The idea of a non-curved class at Princeton is intimidating, but this course is very manageable if effort is given on a weekly basis.
Go to every lecture especially the last three weeks of lecture
Go to lecture, it's worth it!
Great CEE departmental because Branko is fantastic. Material is dry though.

I would recommend taking this class. However, make sure you stay on top of the material. It builds very fast and even though you may think you know what's happening, you could miss one class and fall behind a lot.
If this is fulfills a departmental for you, take it!! Branko definitely makes the 8:30 class worth it.
If you're MAE, don't take this course!
Incredibly boring class, but professor is solid.
Just a rehashing of solid mech.  Take it if you have to do so.

Just stay on top of your work. Although the class is at 8:30 in the morning, if you do not go you will very surely fall behind. Make sure you go and take the homework seriously, because they really prepare you. Also, take the course!
Lecture is super early, and sometimes getting enough sleep to stay functional meant missing class; make it to at least one lecture or one precept for every topic and you will be okay.

Solids Jr. for engineers and Bridges On Steroids for nonengineers - this course would be only mildly interesting and forgettable if it wasn't for an incredibly talented and dedicated teaching staff. Branko's the goddamn man - he's as engaging as he is brilliant - and Becca cares the most about the students of literally anyone I've ever met in three years here. If Becca's still part of the course when you take it, thank your lucky stars - you're in for a great semester. 

DO YOUR PROBLEM SET REVISIONS EARLY
Take it!
Take it! It's one of the best-taught classes at Princeton! The 6 hours of class per week may seem daunting, but no readings and relatively light workload. You'll learn a ton and love every minute!
This course is well taught, but don't treat it as something you blow-off during a heavy semester making it not fun.
Try to go the the lectures towards the end of the semester. The beginning is deceivingly simple but it gets more complicated and you won't realize it unless you attend lectures.

When you make a class at 8:30AM four times a week you can't expect to have good attendance. Take it if you have to. Great professor but annoying course because of its time, lack of a curve in the class and waste of knowledge for MAEs (I thought this would be like a solids part II but it ended up being "Learn how to look at a bridge".)

hard class with a lot of material covered, but Branko is a great professor who truly wants you to understand the material and do well in the class-- so take advantage of opportunities to talk to him, to fix your mistakes, to improve your grade!
take it over finite
prereqs: CEE 205 or MAE 223.
descrip: Develops notions of internal forces and displacements, and instructs students how to design and analyze structures. Presents the fundamental principles of structural analysis, determination of internal forces, and deflections under the static load conditions, and introduces the bending theory of plane beams and the basic energy theorems. The theory of the first order will be developed for continuous girders, frames, arches, suspension bridges, and trusses, including both statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Basic principles for construction of influence lines and determination of extreme influences will be presented.

title: Greek History - Methods and Problems
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to central topics and methods of Greek history, offering a chronological overview of periods and significant developments; a survey of research tools and specialized sub-disciplines (e.g., epigraphy and numismatics); as well as important theoretical approaches to the study of the past (e.g., positivism, or the Annales School).

title: Advanced Questions in Photography
reviews: It definitely helps to have taken a prior course in photography, preferably intermediate.
Take if you are interested in developing further as an artist! This class will help you think more deeply about the conceptual side of your work.
Take it if you want to improve your photography!
descrip: This studio class will examine the intersection between actual photographic documents and the processes involved in their making, from constructed psychological textures to lighting and lenses. Classroom discussions and lectures will focus on the work of artists who manipulate their images in subtle and overt ways, such as Miroslav Tichy, Collier Schorr, Oliver Chanarin and Adam Broomberg, and Sharon Lockhart. Students will be expected to engage in research and discussion on these topics as well as produce a substantial body of work for presentation and final critique.

title: Introduction to Dance Across Cultures
reviews: Be prepared for lots of readings and really hard 3-hour chunks. This class is not a joke!! You'll also need time outside to observe a dance group so be prepared to go out of your comfort zone, most likely.

I highly, highly recommend this class! I can't tell you how glad I am that I took this course. Professor Hamera is amazing. She is such an expert in this subject matter, and she cares so much about her students and their well-being. She is also just an incredible person. I learned so much about dance, writing, ethnography, the world, and life. This class is really great since you get to write an ethnography about a dance group, and I found this rewarding and engaging in so many ways.
One of my favorite classes at Princeton!
This course is a great introduction to dance forms from an anthropological perspective and the ethnography is much less scary than it might initially seem.

This is not a PDF only dance course! To be honest, I almost walked away as soon as I found that out, but I am SO glad I didn't. This has been one of my favorite courses at Princeton. The grading is also very fair, and the assignments are fun. Take this course!
prereqs: No prior dance experience is necessary to succeed in this course..
descrip: Bharatanatyam, butoh, hip hop, and salsa are some of the dances that will have us travel from temples and courtyards to clubs, streets, and stages around the world. Through studio sessions, readings and viewings, field research, and discussions, this seminar will introduce students to dance across cultures with special attention to issues of migration, cultural appropriation, gender and sexuality, and spiritual and religious expression. Students will also learn basic elements of participant observation research. Guest artists will teach different dance forms. No prior dance experience is necessary.

title: Honors Analysis (Single Variable)
reviews: A very solid introduction to analysis (and Stefanos was incredible). Strongly recommended if you've any interest in the beauty of mathematical proof.

Do some reading beforehand if you have no introduction to proofs- the more experience, the less stress you will have during the semester. And do take advantage of all the resources- they were vital for me, and I think would be useful for anyone who wants to get the most out of the assignments
Excellent course to take as a freshman. Great foundation for rest of college.

I really recommend the material of this course to anyone?sciences or humanities. I know MAT 215 is seen as an "intimidating" course, so maybe some selected elements of it could be taught more generally (though I think one needs the full class for the best experience). For instance, perhaps some principles of this class could be incorporated into writing seminars, since the material fosters logical thought and cogency. After all, both are about presenting and structuring one's arguments in a clear and convincing manner for the reader.

I'm really happy I took this course, even if I'm not going to do the best in it gradewise. It is super interesting and completely worth the difficulty and pain if you enjoy learning about the fundamentals of math. Be prepared to have trouble, to go to office hours, etc. Try to find a group of people to work with early on in the semester, it gets a lot harder as the semester goes on.

If you have free time you'd like to fill, take this course, even if you're not a math major (I wasn't). It's very, very difficult, but very, very rewarding - this was my worst class this semester academically but my favorite class to take.

If you like math/learning about how to write proofs, definitely take. Aretakis is awesome professor, very funny, focuses on deep understanding of material. I have taken 201/202 before, this class is so much more awesome, way different than stuff learned in those classes/in high school. Kind of hard, book proofs are hard to understand, Aretakis describes them very well.
Stefanos was a great teacher. This course was manageable.

TAKE IT, and do not be intimidated. MAT 215 is tough, but the work is worth it. I took it as an econ major with no math background beyond 201/202. Even if you are not one of the gifted MAT or COS majors, you can do well as long as you put in the work.

 It essentially explains the building blocks of math (what the real numbers are, what it means to count, limits of sequences and series) and basic calculus (derivatives and integrals) in a way that clarifies all of the math that you have learned up until this point in your life. This is the only course I've taken at Princeton where I can honestly say that I've gotten smarter over the course of the semester.

Take this class if you are prepared to dedicate the proper amount of time to it. Stefanos is a very good teacher, but this class requires a significant amount of work. As a junior ORFE major who did well in all ORFE core courses, this class was an extreme challenge and forced me to think in creative ways. I always attended problem sessions and worked with other students on the problem sets. I also think what you get out of this class depends on the amount of effort you put into it. With that said, if you put in the effort, this class will teach you to think rigorously about mathematics and also how to write good proofs. Very much worth your time.
Take this course if you're a boss.

This is a very challenging course especially for someone who does not specialize in math nor has taken any proof based course before. Ask for help early and make friends in the class early! Work with people.
You get out of this class what you put into it.
descrip: An introduction to the mathematicsal discipline of analysis, to prepare for higher-level course work in the department. Topics include rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Rieman integral, conditions for integrability of functions and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.

title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering
reviews: Good
If it's a requirement, sure. Otherwise, just stop by for the seminars that are interesting for your particular field (they send out announcements about the topic each week).
Make the most of this required course - you'd be surprised how much you can learn especially from talks that are outside of your specialty area.
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political theory, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Public Finance II
descrip: The course presents recent developments in the theory of social choice, fairness, equality of opportunity, inequality measurement, well-being measurement, and their applications in public economics. Recent developments in the analysis of collective risks, future generations, fairness in taxation, behavioral economics, and interdependent preferences are covered.

title: Acting and Directing in Musical Theater
reviews: Be on top of your scene and find time to meet with scene partner out of class.
Great for musical theater lovers with lots of singing. Grab the bull by the horns with this one and enjoy yourself!
Have to set apart time outside of class to work on songs/scenes, but it's worth it if musical theater is your thing!
If you love musical theater, take it! And it's so cool to get to work with such accomplished professionals! Awesome class!
So much fun! Loved the work that was done. Ethan is a wonderful human being.
This is a very good class, however you may not do as much as you wanted over the course of the year.
take it!
prereqs: THR 201, THR 301, THR 311, THR 335 or THR 411 or MUS 241 or significant experience in the musical form. Please contact the Program Director, Tim Vasen for more information at: tvasen@princeton.edu.
descrip: A practical, hands-on introduction to acting and directing in musical theater. The course will require students to prepare songs and scenes from selected musicals with an eye to how best to approach the particular challenges the scene presents.

title: Intermediate Japanese II
reviews: Expect a lot of hard work.it is tough, but worth it!
Great as always! Take this class if you love Japanese! Matsui sensei is awesome
Same amount of work as 105, and definitely less than 101-102. Focus on reading, which makes it much more interesting than simply grammar. Matsui sensei is amazing!
Well, you are probably taking this at this point because of the requirement, if you have good luck and stick with it.

You're most likely taking this course to finish your Japanese language requirement, so there's not much choice you have in taking it. Don't worry, it's essentially the same thing as 105 in terms of work. It's slightly harder as the semester goes on and you switch from Nakama to Tobira, but the Sensei's are cognizant of this and respond accordingly.
prereqs: JPN 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: The course aims at a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points covered in JPN 101, 102, and 105. It is also intended to give students advanced vocabulary and expressions through aural-oral drills, readings, and written exercises. Emphasis will increasingly be on reading, but oral work will still comprise fundamental aspect of the course.

title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Current research and issues in sensation, perception, and cognition. Ongoing research by seminar participants, research methodology, and current issues in the literature will be discussed.

title: Topics in Labor Economics
reviews: Interesting course for applied microeconomists.
Interesting course on Labor Economics topics, could be recommended even to people mildly interested in Labor due to the variety of topics that may be tangent to other fields.

The course is a good overview of many classic labor economics topics, such as discrimination in the labor market, trade unions, unemployment insurance, etc. If you would like to do research in the field of Labor Economics, you need to take this class. The workload is light.
enjoy :)
descrip: The course surveys both the theoretical literature and the relevant empirical methods and results in selected current research topics in labor economics.

title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: Amazing class. Even if you're not interested in  tech or business, the class is just so different from any other class at Princeton and is absolutely fascinating. Professor Kuenne's personal experience and wisdom is phenomenal. It's worth it to just take it for the guest lectures - the amount of highly successful and talented people with a ton of wisdom that come through for those lectures is absolutely unbelievable.
Amazing course, must-take if interested in entrepreneurship. Quality of students you will meet and get to know in the class is also top-notch.
Best class I've taken at Princeton, take it if you can.

Dont graduate Princeton without taking this course. Its life changing and really taught be how to be a leader, which was something I really didnt expect. Its like a Business 101, and Prof Kuenne is fantastic and really cares about the class. He also has really interesting guest speakers come in. Overall, you will graduate the class having learned a lot. (The stress on class participation is a little crazy with someone writing down every comment you make and grading it, but that greatly improves the lecture experience...)

Fantastic course - would highly recommend (especially if you have no background in entrepreneurship like me and are eager to learn more). Participation is very important and a little intimidating with lots of seniors
Great course. Kuenne is a great speaker and offers so much. This course is very well-orchestrated. It feels almost luxurious, which makes for an ideal learning environment.
One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton and absolutely the best of the 4 EGR courses I've taken. A MUST TAKE. Professor Kuenne is fantastic and really cares about his students.
One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Not only is Professor Kuenne is a great teacher, but this course is a unique offering in a field that few would otherwise be able to study here.
One of the best courses at Princeton. Lectures are awesome, guests are inspiring, readings are really interesting.

One of those courses you just have to take. EGR 491 is incredible - it'll teach you a lot of real, practical skills if you're even considering being an entrepreneur. Professor Kuenne is also really invested in teaching this class - take it with him while you can!
Professor Kuenne is an excellent professor and the coursework is very interesting- definitely take this class!!
Really good class. Teaches you a lot about making tough decisions and building a company from an idea. If you take this class, be creative!
TAKE IT. stay engaged

TAKE THIS CLASS. It doesn't give you a distribution requirement, but it is really interesting material, structured like a business school class with case studies. There are a lot of amazing guest lecturers and Prof. Kuenne is wonderful. Really interesting material as well! As far as advice, expect to have to do all of the readings and be ready to discuss them. 30% of your grade is participation and they take that pretty seriously.

Take it if you love entrepreneurship as you will get to test your thinking, take it if you aren't excited about entrepreneurship as it will give you a chance to embrace it, take it if you're an engineering person who wants to gain more business exposure and take it if you're a humanities student searching to gain more practical skills. In essence, please just take it!
Take it. Embrace yourself for the most cut-throat competition you will ever see in Princeton classes, and learn a great deal from Kuenne.

Take this class if you are willing to contribute in class and like to share your opinion! I loved this class and learned a ton, but then again I put a lot into it. Definitely one of the most applicable courses I have taken at Princeton (and if you are considering business school at all, then you need to take this class).
Take this class if you have any interest in entrepreneurship.  The workload is not heavy, but it is incredibly engaging.  One of my favorite classes at Princeton!

The first thing that comes to mind is the try-hardedness of so many students. It's a bit of a contentious atmosphere and while class discussion is engaging, it's not the most friendly. This is due to the type of person who takes the course and the participation grade (and lack of pdf option). Otherwise, I find the course exceptionally interesting and helpful. The readings and speakers are great. I often find that the readings are more insightful than most class discussion comments but there were (in my mind) about 5-10 of 50 students who said really insightful things that contributed to my learning. The professor moderates the discussion well. The graded assignments (group project in wk 3, midterm paper, partner presentation and paper final) are graded toughly, but are not that hard and are a good application of the things learned.
There are few courses at Princeton in which you get to learn from so many CEOs and people changing the world. Take it.

This class is amazing. Kuenne is great, and the class discussions are lively and so interesting. You do not need any pervious experience or knowledge to do well in this course- just be ready to engage with the readings and concepts. I am so glad I took this course, I feel like I learned so much about technology and entrepreneurship.

This course is most beneficial to students with a heavy background in business and finance coursework and some accounting coursework. It uses the case study method so there is very little instruction from the professor; it is more like guided discussion.  Be advised, participation grade is a hefty 30% which indirectly causes the majority of classes to be hijacked by [uninformed] student comments.  If this is the only entrepreneur class or you have significant business background, take it; otherwise, consider an alternative with more instruction.

This was fantastic course and definitely one of my favorites at Princeton. It taught me valuable skills, like thinking on my feet in a food fight (in-class debates), creating the best argument I could out of incomplete information, and creating a compelling pitch. I also greatly appreciated Professor Kuenne's investment in the class and the students, and his willingness to be vulnerable and share some of the difficulties that he faced as an entrepreneur.
yes! its sort of intense in terms of participation but it keeps you on your toes!
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application bit.ly/ELE491App, deadline is December 7..
descrip: This hands-on course introduces students to analysis and actions required to launch and commercialize a tech company, through the use of Harvard Business School cases, visits from entrepreneurs, and two "field assignments". You will learn conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques for evaluating technologies, markets, and commercialization strategies. Additionally, you will learn how to attract and motivate the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners and venture capital), prepare business plans, structure relationships, refine product-market fit, and create and grow enterprise value.

title: Crises of European Subjectivity, 1945-1961
reviews: I'd highly recommend this course to anyone interested in continental philosophy in general, or particularly in some of the best philosophical responses to World War 2 and the Holocaust. Several of the authors on the syllabus are beautiful and inventive writers (unlike many of the philosophers usually taught at Princeton). Professor Hoffman-Schwartz stays close to the texts and offers clear and interesting analysis.

If the topic is of interest, so long as you are okay breaking your head over very technical and very dense readings, then take the course. Don't expect easy intellectual history. You will seriously engage with texts. If you're up to task, you could gain a lot.

Take it if you are willing to really think and to work through a text slowly and patiently. The readings and concepts are difficult but well worth the effort. It is helpful if you can read German, as the German texts are referenced fairly often in seminar.
This is a really cool and fascinating course. Highly recommended to German majors, or anyone interested in the thinkers on the syllabus.
descrip: This course examines the crisis of European subjectivity in the wake of WWII and the Holocaust. Such a crisis implicates not merely the concepts of Europe and the subject, but the very concept of the concept and thus entails a transformation of thought itself. Topics include crises of the subject and the human; the question of technology; the Franco-German relation; the Cold War; decolonization; exile and emigration; essay, aphorism, and lecture as anti-systematic modes. We will do intensive readings of texts from seven authors: Theodor Adorno, Hannah Arendt, Maurice Blanchot, Paul Celan, Franz Fanon, Martin Heidegger, and Jacques Lacan.

title: Topics in Recent and Contemporary Philosophy - Bias and Objectivity
descrip: An examination of some recent philosophical work on the topics of bias and objectivity.

title: Networks and Ecologies: An Interdisciplinary History of Environmental Design
reviews: Architecture, environment, and visuals.
Interesting topics for those interested in environmental studies, art history, and/or architecture!
well you cant take it, but if you could, you should!
descrip: The figures of network and ecology have been essential for visualizing social and natural systems. They have also been essential to innovation in design, and fostered connections to the natural and social sciences. This course will discuss the history of architecture in the 20th century through these connections, and trace a broad epistemological shift towards systems thinking - a mode of thought based on interdependence, feedback loops, and emergence, and rooted in interdisciplinary methods. The course does not require knowledge in any of these fields; it will also familiarize students with recent concepts examining environmental challenges.

title: Ancient Greco-Roman Medicine: From Hippocrates to Galen
reviews: Amazing course! Would have never guessed the context to be this interesting. Very anthropologically-oriented.
DO IT! Also pay attention because it is a history course and details do matter
Good class, workload is not crazy, but make sure you study the details (dates, names, etc) for midterm and final.
I really enjoyed this class. Interesting subject material, and great discussions. If you're looking for an HA, like I was, this is a great option.

I took this course knowing that I was going to PDF it. Looking back I wouldn't have. I still attended all the mandatory lectures and did the weekly assignments. With only a little studying, I did well on the material. This class would be a good one to take for a grade if you are on the fence. Also, do the reading! It is not totally mandatory to pass the class but the class is so much more rewarding if you are able to participate in discussions.
I would highly recommend taking this course! The professor is excellent and the material is really interesting.
I would say keep up with the readings because you will get left behind.
It had more memorization than I would have liked but overall course was not TOO bad ya know.
Mostly you only need to read the primary sources.
Participate in class and do all the readings! The texts are very interesting (especially the primary readings). Take it especially if you are pre-med looking to fulfill the distribution requirement!
Review lecture slides before exams!
Stay on top of your readings. Read them all. They are interesting, so they aren't difficult to get through. But sometimes they can be lengthy, but make sure you read them all.
Such an interesting class - Professor Holmes is devoted and intriguing, and if you are interested in medicine/classics then definitely take this! Worth the work
Take it if you're interested in health / nutrition. The grading is fair, the lectures are interesting, and the discussion is thought-provoking.
Take notes on the readings, it'll help on the midterm and final which are pretty specific

The readings themselves are interesting in my opinion. I'm not the kind of person to memorise dates or specific names of texts that authors write. If this course were a paper-based course I would have enjoyed it a lot more, and I thought this course was initially a paper-based one, which is why I chose it. Instead I had a 5-exam Spring semester, which wasn't fun. Definitely consider taking if it becomes a paper-based course though. Some of the readings are very interesting. It's also a reasonably interesting PDF-able class

This course is awesome. The readings are really interesting, and you learn a lot about the history of medicine. Professor Holmes is also a phenomenal lecturer, and after this course, you really start to understand some of the fundamental issues and questions that arise in contemporary medicine, too.

This is a great course - Prof. Holmes is awesome, very knowledgeable about the subject, and lectures well. The material is very interesting and pretty unique. The only caveat would be that the work required is a little high if you're looking to take it as a PDF, but it's worth it.
Would strongly recommend this course if you are willing to do the readings. I learned a lot and enjoyed the class as a premed.
great professor, readings can be quite boring but discussions are fun.
stay on top of your readings, make outlines of each throughout the semester
descrip: This course is for undergraduates from all backgrounds with an interest in ancient Greco-Roman medicine and the historical roots of contemporary biomedicine. We will examine how a medical tradition forms around the body as an object of knowledge and therapy, paying close attention to socio-historical context. We also explore issues that remain relevant to medicine, such as the construction of scientific authority, pain and knowledge, error and chance in medicine, narrative and disease, the "naturalization" of cultural categories, the privileging of anatomy, and body-mind interaction. Reading from primary and secondary sources in translation.

title: Applied Game Theory
reviews: I would not recommend this course to non-math majors.

Prof. Abreu is one of the best professors I've had at Princeton. He really cares about helping students understand concepts. This course is focused mainly on his own research, but they are very interesting. We also have a variety guest lectures, and it's a great way to get a taste of the research world in economics. Despite the term paper and finals, the workload is very manageable. And I feel very comfortable asking for help!
Take 418 first. If you like it, then ECO 488 is for you. Compared to 488, it is a bit more technical and the models are more interesting and relevant.

This class is not very structured. I imagine that it is very similar to a graduate-level seminar. As a result, I would recommend it if you are thinking about going to graduate school. There are plenty of resources to get through (the preceptor Ben Young was fantastic btw). You'll learn about a lot of interesting topics and develop a better ability to read and evaluate papers. These are good skills, but without a doubt, the class is difficult.
You will be able to learn some of the cutting-edge topics in game theory! Awesome!
prereqs: MAT 175 or higher, ECO 202 or ORF 245 or equivalent, ECO 418 or MAT 308 or equivalent, ECO 310 (waived if ECO 418 has been taken or with instructor's permission).
descrip: This course will explore in some detail a diverse range of applications of game theory drawn from a wide variety of fields in economics. The latter include finance (no trade theorems on the one hand and bubbles and crashes at the other extreme), industrial organization (oligopolistic collusion), information economics (herd behavior), behavioral economics (time inconsistency and procrastination, self control and self confidence, psychological games and applications to issues of fairness, and feelings of guilt), matching markets (resident matching with hospitals, school choice and kidney exchange), auctions (design of spectrum auctions).

title: The Philosophy of Physics - Philosophical Issues about Space and Time
descrip: Philosophical issues about space and time -- from the early modern period to the present. Some of the issues covered include: substantivalism vs. relationism, incongruent counterparts, spacetime symmetries, apriori knowledge, non-Euclidean geometry, conventionalism, and the hole argument. Readings are drawn from Descartes, Newton, Leibniz, Berkeley, Kant, Poincare, Reichenbach, Earman, and Maudlin, among others.

title: Topics in Cinema and Culture - Latin American Film - Poetics and Politics of the Third World
reviews: A LOT OF WORK. A LOT OF TIME COMMITMENT. DO NOT TAKE.

Excellent class for those interested in Latin American film and especially recommended for native speakers (though the majority were not). Professor Guerrero is very dynamic and clearly knowledgeable in his field as well as very fair. A great upper level Spanish class.

If you have the language skills, this is a great class. The class goes over issues of politics, communism, nationalism, gender, historic memory, poverty, and economic and sexual hierarchy. There's something for everyone and all the films are really good.
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission..
descrip: An exploration of a series of critically acclaimed contemporary Latin American films, accompanied by readings that provide a theoretical and historical framework for its analysis. Topics to be discussed, among others: subalternity and the Third World; sexual and racial politics; postcolonial poetics; genocide; cultural hybridism and mestizaje; dictatorship and populism; biopolitical fantasies.

title: Cell and Developmental Biology
reviews: A fairly good revamped MOL 348 class that involves more critical thinking than before. However, given that it is a new course it was frustrating to have little material to practice off of and the exams tend to be lengthy.
Be prepared to participate! Ask questions! Don't be shy.
Best MOL core class I've taken.

Cell, and specifically developmental, biology is really, really cool! Professors Davenport and Burdine are wonderful and very passionate about the material. There is quite a bit of information to memorize, but this class definitely forces you to synthesize information and apply what you have learned. Again, really cool and fascinating course!
Don't miss lectures, and try to do the problem sets yourself (it will better prepare you for exams)
Don't take it, unless you have to!
Don't take unless you have to.  Try to get in a course between MOL214 and this-- the jump is huge, and unless you're ready to memorize a ton of information, take another class.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture and participate in precept. The material isn't too hard but it can pile up at times if you don't stay up with the readings.
Go to lecture and read the textbook; the exams are heavily memorization based so make sure to really understand and memorize everything you learned.
Great Course! Super interesting!
Great class but keep up with the work
I liked it. take it if you have to or if you think it may be interesting
I would advise the students to do the readings that are recommended because they are very important for understanding the course.

If you have to take this course I am sorry for you. The only good part was Danelle as a lecturer. The rest was sub-par. For those who do not have to take this course for their major I would suggest not taking it at all. It is a huge waste of time.
