If you're not intimidated by a lot of memorization, definitely take this course. It's really cool and gives a great intro into development.
It is a good MOL departmental.
It is a very interesting course and you will learn a lot if you put in the work. If you're interested in developmental biology it is a great course to take.
It's not as bad as people say.  It's fascinating stuff. Take it.
It's not as bad as you think.
Keep up with regular review. There is a lot of material and content builds up quickly. As a result, being organized and studying early are important for improved performance.
Lots of memorization. Not very interesting material. But it is a very organized course.
My own experience from working in a lab made me understand and solve the problems better for this course. Maybe it's a good idea get some lab-experience before taking this course.
One of the most important things to practice before exams is connecting details of a particular topic to each other.
Pretty good class, a little heavy on memorization, and a lot of advanced info. in biology, but worth taking.
Read the textbook.
Seems to be greatly improved from previous versions.
Stay up with your material. And ask clarifying questions along the way if you wish to master the material.
Study ahead of time! Pay attention to the learning goals as a way to study for exams. Ask questions and go to office hours. This will be a challenging yet worthwhile course for you.
Take it - keep up with the readings and be sure to meet with the professors to go over material you don't understand!
Take it because you have to.
Take it if you enjoy biology.
Take it if you have to.
Take it instead of genetics or biochem

The course is not the most interesting. Mostly memorizing facts and learning how to interpret biological results. The course is just not so well-taught. Maybe they will make it better next year, but every year they get this complaint and try to fix the course by changing it and it doesn't seem to me that they have figured it out yet.
The course was good--challenging, but also rewarding. I feel like I learned a lot!
This course is a serious time commitment, but if your looking to learn about cell biology or development I would highly recommend it.

This is a good course if you are interested in biology, regardless of whether or not you are required to take it.  The professors are genuinely caring and invested in your learning experience, and the information is very interesting, especially after having taken a lower level MOL course.
This is a great class, you will learn a lot
This is an interesting course and the professors really care, but they sometimes speed through the material. Be very diligent about the readings.

This is one of the most challenging, yet engaging classes I have taken at Princeton thus far. Davenport and Burdine are so passionate about making this class less of a menace and more of what it really is: an introduction to exploratory developmental biology. Take the time to do the reading, work alone on problem sets until you check, and talk to your TA. Also, make sure you study well in advance as the exams are challenging. Also, use the problem sets as a template for the You Be the Scientist Questions.
Work hard from day 1 - this is an eye-opening course that informs you about fundamentals of cell and development - you will enjoy this so much!

Work on the homeworks with other students. It's really helpful, even if you're just checking over them with others. It's a well-structured course, and the material is very interesting, even if there is a lot of it.
You probably have to take this course. Try to enjoy it, pay attention in lecture, take good notes.
You'll learn a ton! It's actually a fun and useful class. Professors Devenport and Burdine are as nice and helpful as they come.

can gain a pretty good, broad understanding of how all the things we learned in mol bio come together in cellular organization; more importantly, can get more exposure to the scientific methods used to obtain the knowledge
demanding course, but you probably have to take it
only take if you have to
recommended
prereqs: MOL 214/215 recommended for undergraduates..
descrip: The mechanisms that underlie development of multicellular organisms, from C. elegans to humans, will be examined using biochemical, genetic and cell biological approaches. The course will investigate the roles that gene regulation, cell-cell communication, cell adhesion, cell motility, cell death, signal transduction and intracellular trafficking play in the commitment, differentiation and assembly of cells into specialized tissues.

title: Topics in Social and Personality Psychology - The Self
reviews: I thought this was a very interesting course and learned a ton, and I'm super glad that I took it. Definitely one of my favorite psych classes in terms of material. It did get kinda tough to sit through sometimes, which I suppose can happen for a seminar. But there was a lot of reading, and discussions got a bit dry sometimes.
Only take this course if you are prepared to dedicate a lot of time to readings.

Really interesting class on the self! Touched on really cool topics related to the self from a variety of angles and I have completed the course feeling like I can talk about the psychology of the self in relation to neuroscience, social psychology, and developmental psychology! Take it if you want to be a part of a smart, fun discussion on a weekly basis!
Take this course! You won't regret it. You'll learn a lot about yourself and human behavior that you can't miss.

While the subject of this course is interesting, I would only take this course if you enjoy a class that is predominantly discussion among other students about the scientific papers for that week. Professor Tamir is great, but hopefully the course is re-structured so that students can learn more from her and her knowledge of the field instead solely relying on the readings assigned.
descrip: In this class, we'll explore the topic of the Self from the perspective of experimental psychology and social neuroscience. Throughout the course, we will consider both theoretical and methodological issues relevant to the study of the Self, at three complementary levels of analysis: 1) Brain: How does your neural hardware contribute to your sense of Self? 2) Individual: What is the content and experience of the Self? How does the Self affect how we take in new information? 3) Group: How does the Self contribute to our understanding of other people? How do social and cultural contexts influence the Self?

title: Topics in Comparative Literature - Performing the Planet
descrip: An examination of how literature and the performing arts represent and interrogate climate change. The relationship between the human body and the earth, as seen in Classical Drama, early depictions of the New World, texts by early naturalists. The emergence of technologies of seeing and their effects on theater and dance. The relationship between conceptions of the internal body and the body of the earth (geology, landscape, maternity, the microbiome, the Sublime). Environmental theater, eco theater and dance.

title: Senior Project with Design
reviews: Working in a group is really nice if you can. It's great during report-writing time and helpful for motivating you to work on it throughout the year.
descrip: Similar to 444 with the principal difference that the team or group project must incorporate aspects and principals of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior project with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Islamic Thought and Society, 18th-20th centuries
descrip: Using primary sources in translation, this seminar introduces students to the thought of key Muslim figures active between the 18th and the 20th centuries. What are the legal, theological, and other traditions with reference to which their writings are to be understood? How do we relate their work to the social and political contexts in which it was produced? How have the questions to which they were responding changed during this time?

title: Media Spectacles, Scandalous Citizens and Democratic Possibilities
descrip: Our contemporary mediascape is saturated with spectacle and scandal. In this class, we take this observation and examine, not only the logics that undergird these discursive events, but also the intimate connection between media spectacles and scandals and the regulation of non-normative bodies and speech. This class will examine the manner in which non-normative subjects and practices are hyperembodied, surveilled, stigmatized and disciplined through practices that often cast them as outside of a democratic ethos. Spectacles that might be examined include Gamergate, Trigger Warnings, Black Lives Matter, Civility, and Campus Sexual Assault.

title: Seminar in Modernist Art and Theory - Brutal Aesthetics
descrip: Modernism teaches us how to survive civilization, Benjamin once speculated. After the horrors of World War II this project became a necessity. The seminar examines artists and theorists (e.g., Bataille, Dubuffet, Jorn, Oldenburg) who attempted to start again from scratch through different turns to the brut and the brutal, the animal and the outsider. What might this "positive barbarism" teach us about how to respond to emergency in our own time?

title: Biochemistry
reviews: DO NOT TAKE IN THE SPRING WITH PETRY. It's just memorization coupled with extremely dry, boring lectures that put you to sleep, and this is coming from an insomniac.
Decent interesting material and not too demanding workload-wise. Be prepared for lots of memorization come exam time.

Do the problem sets and ask questions in precept. Really try and figure out concpets each lecturer wants you to get really good at or understand in depth. Long questions about these show up on every exam.

Honestly, take somewhere else if you can afford to do so. It was cute how they tried to incorporate research papers for various lectures, but in the end these papers were just extra burden (i.e. more memorization for exam). You'll find yourself spending TOO much time having to memorize microscopic menial details?and even those details won't appear on the exam because they'll test you on some other insignificant details. No regard for overlapping themes in this course (which would ideally help you prepare for the MCAT if you're taking this because of pre-med). In the end, you'll just get angry at yourself for not having memorized whatever extraneous facts they choose to include on exams.. Also, be prepared to do lots of math. Bottom line: math and memorization in one. Not sure how this one compares to the fall course, since this was first time biochem was offered in spring.

I certainly learned a lot in this class. It's standard material that anyone going into biology/medicine ought to know, so I really appreciated having learned it. It helps a lot if you're personally interested in the topic. Workload was very manageable.

I understood the lectures very well when listening to it for a second time with the slides in front of me (slides not provided before lecture) so I could outline the lecture. Most often very organized, but may be difficult to follow in realtime.

I would not recommend this course to the general student. If you need to take Biochem, I have heard that the Fall course is much better taught. If you do take this, be prepared to do a lot of learning on your own.

I would recommend that fellow chemistry majors take the course that is offered in the fall, since I have heard that that class is amazing and I didn't feel like there was enough focus on chemistry in this class. If you need to take biochem and are unable to take it in the fall though, this is not a bad alternative.

If you need to take biochem for your major/because you're a premed, go for it. It's a well-structured class, and in addition to learning biochemical pathways, you also spend about half the time learning concepts important for any biological lab work. For those of you planning to take this concurrently with CHM304/304B, I did it and it was definitely very reasonable. There's definitely a fair amount of memorization in this course, but that's just the nature of the subject. For exams, study the lecture slides, and use the textbook as supplementary material.

If you wan't a course a lot like MOL214 then take this. A lot of memorization, cool assays to learn about, and super nice instructors. However, if you actually want to learn material in depth, go over the chemistry, and be better prepared for the MCAT and other classes, take the Fall class. This class dilutes a lot of material and skips some key concepts.

If you're considering taking it in the fall, do it! Both Professor Cristea and Professor Petry are very nice. Make sure to take problem sets and readings seriously, they really are essential to learning the material and doing well on the exams.
Ileana is amazing. One of my favorite professors. Total sweetheart. Sabine is great too. Super dynamic team. The material is taught excellently. Exams suck.
In the spring, with Prof. Cristea and Petry, this course seemed easier than in the fall. It's still a fair amount of work and memorization, but it wasn't a particularly demanding course.
Its a good course.
Less metabolism, more modern biochemistry and bioengineering. Take if this applies to your interests.
Only take if you have to.
Review the lectures, stay on top of the material.
Take it fall semester if you can, and after organic chemistry.

Take it for a requirement, but that's about it. If you're interested in MOL, there are more interesting MOL courses. If you're interested in chemistry, this more heavily MOL oriented than you might expect.
Take it in the fall, joke of a course in the spring. This course is just memorizing, spitting it out, and forgetting it. Really boring.
Take it in the fall. Please. Just take it in the fall if you can.

Take it with Huston, it's better taught and the curve is likely more forgiving since this semester will tests with sky high averages. You will walk away with a better overall understanding of the integration of biochemistry if you take it with Huston. Cristea's a good lecturer, but definitely not Petry.
Take this course in the fall if you can.
Take this course! You will learn a lot and the information that you'll learn is very valuable.
Take this in the spring only if necessary. I've heard the fall is *much* better so just heads up. Still fine class though.

This was a good course (much better than MOL 214).  Lectures are very fast-paced, and both Professor Cristea and Petry do a good job of explaining the material.  Lots of memorization (as one would expect), but the material is very interesting.
Would advise taking in the fall, this term seemed a little bit disorganized.
You have to take this class if you're in mol or pre-med, so not really an option here. This class is hard as balls, but it's definitely really interesting. One of my favorite science classes so far.
don't get behind, but if you do, focus on lectures
recommended
take it if you need to or have interest, but don't take it with more than one other hard class
prereqs: MOL 214/215 and CHM304/304B. CHM304/304B may be taken concurrently..
descrip: This course focuses on the fundamental biochemical principles that underlie cellular function. An emphasis will be placed on protein structure, function, and regulation. Additional topics covered will include metabolism and catalysis, and cutting-edge methodologies for studying macromolecules in health and disease systems.

title: Thesis Studio
reviews: As it stands at present, I would suggest students forego thesis if they are not confident in their own academic passions and interests . . . or risk being subsumed into a thesis process that amounts to chasing one's tail.
Don't listen to Liz, do your thing.
I recommend a partnered thesis for the benefits of continual discussion, critique, and the motivation that teamwork brings.
Set the statement aside and start doing actual work and then come back to it once you've produced something
Settle on a direction early with the expectation that it will change. Listen to and acknowledge criticism directly.

Try to have a project at declaration - it'll help with the structure of the rest of the semester. If you can avoid fumbling for 2-3 weeks before midterm there will be plenty of time to develop throughout the semester and the end can be a nice coast into the final. 

Listen to Liz et al. from the beginning - it's impossible to tackle every aspect of your idea for thesis and she will help you arrive at a manageable project in which you can engage other aspects as well.

Do something you like that you haven't explored before, it should be fun.

Don't forget with advisors you can always ask other faculty to give you a desk crit!
Try to meet with your advisor every week!
prereqs: One course is required for all M.Arch. students. Completion of Pre-Thesis Workshops is required for entry into Thesis Studio..
descrip: The Master of Architecture Thesis is an independent design project on a theme selected by the student. The student begins with a thesis statement outlining an area of study or a problem that has consequences for contemporary architectural production. Marking the transition between the academic and professional worlds, the thesis project is an opportunity for each student to define an individual position with regard to a specific aspect of architectural practice. As an integral part of the design process, it is intended that the thesis project will incorporate research, programming and site definition.

title: Creativity, Innovation, and Design
reviews: A fantastic course. Take it! So much interesting content. I really feel I have developed as a critical problem-solver. My design thinking skills have been greatly expanded. Derek Lidow is a great professor. He really know his stuff! The labs are a lot of fun. With the final project, you get a chance to really impact the University. The class does take a fair amount of time, but it's very worth it.
An absolute must! Amazing class, amazing labs - overall great experience. Make sure to take it with Professor Lidow though - he's a boss.

Awesome course, not just for engineers or entrepreneurs (although some of the readings do focus on entrepreneurship). For the second half of the course, you get to tackle a problem at Princeton and potentially have a large impact on campus. At the same time, realize that solutions to this project do not need to be complicated or have wide-ranging implications; sometimes, the simplest solution is the best solution.
Be open-minded and ready to break the status quo
Best course I have taken here at Princeton and perhaps the only course which has changed my life and career trajectory. TAKE IT PLEASE!

Class gives you a foundation in design thinking and helps you understand your own creative ways. Excellent class that sets me up with many important frameworks for entrepreneurial thinking. It a long time in class every week -- 5hrs   doing the readings and the journal every week. It takes time but its worth it. If you're interested in entrepreneurship or getting to know your creative self on a more intimate level, take this course
DO this because you should push yourselves.

Definitely take this course. You will quickly learn that creativity is a skill that you can learn and get better at with practice. After taking this course I see the world in a different way - I am much more observant and find myself having creative ideas all the time.
Great class, come in with an open mind and you might learn a lot.
It's a really unique course taught by a true expert. Take this course if you have the time!

One of my favorite courses I've taken here. Some things still need some work, but overall teaches valuable things that any Princeton student should know before graduating. Really shows you how to think in a different way. Good introduction to design-thinking.
Prepare to spend a lot of time on the group project.
Really broadens your horizons and forces you to expand your thinking.
Really loved this course. Took a lot of time, but made my Spring a great one

Sheila is very charming and welcome to doing things better. This class is a quarter business case studies, a quarter "how to be more creative" and a half actually trying to test your limits. It CAN occasionally feel lovey-dovey but by the end it's really all quite useful stuff!

TAKE IT. TAKE IT. You learn so much about yourself, and you actually have the opportunity to make real impact on Princeton by coming up with a solution to a real-life problem and pitching it to top University officials!! And its SO applicable to every field of study!!!

TAKE THIS CLASS IT IS THE BEST COURSE YOU WILL EVER TAKE AT PRINCETON! not just because the material is great but because it allows for a lot of introspection to figure out who you are as a student/ person/ designer.
Take it!
Take it! Come in with an open mind and be prepared to learn to think and work in new ways!
Take it! Fun, interesting and not too hard!
Take the class, it's really fun and engaging and you'll gain as much as you put into it.

This class is great for those looking to learn about design thinking, and generally how to think creatively and all of the cutting-edge consensus on the topic. Sheila is a great professor that is also very understanding.
You get what you put into this course. It's different and will teach you skills that are otherwise ignored by most other Princeton courses. This is a great course for anyone.
descrip: The class mission is to give students an understanding of the sources and processes associated with creativity, innovation, and design - three interdependent capabilities essential to our own well being, as well as to the well being of society. We will study the internal and external factors that relate to our own ability to create, innovate, and design. We will also understand the factors that impact a group's ability to act creatively, to innovate, and to produce practical and appealing designs. The class will consist of readings and case studies as well as individual and group projects.

title: Disability and Difference
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Czeslaw Milosz: Poetry, Politics, History
descrip: Polish-American poet Czeslaw Milosz won the Nobel Prize in literature in 1980. In this seminar, which combines textual analyses, history of literature and intellectual history, we will speak on the basis of his major works (and some of his contemporaries - Seamus Heaney, Joseph Brodsky, Derek Walcott), about World War II, Polish-Russian relations, global dominance of English-language poetry, growth of high culture in the United States, and the decline of exile.

title: Crisis and Critique, or: What is Critical Theory Today? (Half-Term)
descrip: In this seminar students examine traditions of political thought which radically challenge mainstream conceptions of liberal democracy and modern capitalist society. We pay particular attention to the question in what ways such challengers adopt political, economic, and cultural strategies to bring about fundamental change. The seminar concentrates on the early twentieth century to the present.

title: Human Genomics: The Past, Present and Future of the Human Genome
reviews: A lot of people got scared off at the beginning of this course, but it ended up being really interesting and not as overwhelming as it first seemed. It combined the topics of computer science, biology and genetics very well. I would recommend this course to any person interested in genetics, but a good background in biology is advised.

As long as they provide reference material next year for you to read before or after lecture, I would recommend this course.  It was really hard/odd not having a textbook to turn to when we didn't understand something.  PSets are really time consuming if you don't know how to use R.  Clair is super helpful and nice about this though, so go to office hours if you're having trouble!  Also, the material is really interesting!!

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. It was pointless. I finished it and know almost nothing more than I knew at the beginning, yet still went through a lot of frustration trying to solve the psets. I thought I wanted to study genetics yet I am not even sure now. Please don't take this. 
More reasonable note - I can see how this could improve but there needs to be a loooot of improvement. In all honesty the professors are pretty good.
Follow the lecture, but do not be afraid to do outside research.

I think next year this class will improve a lot. If you have a strong interest in genomics and evolution, this is a fairly good class. You need to know how to use R to take this, otherwise problem sets will be an extremely arduous task.

Interesting material, I just think that it was a bit unorganized at times, with pset levels always changing and many times the psets/exams were too challenging to complete based on what we covered in lecture. But if genetics is something you're interested in, I'd recommend this course
It is basically necessary that you have an understanding of COS/ R to be able to do the problem sets (at least to be able to do them in a timely manner)

Rather unorganized as it is right now. Cool, diverse course material. But not knowing what to expect when it comes to problem sets/exams makes it stressful. Maybe it'd be better after a few semesters.

The course was not well structured this year.  If you think this is something you'd be interested in, then register, but make sure to have a back-up option in case you realize in the 1st week or 2 that the course is again poorly structured.
This course was sometimes very disorganized, but worth taking because it's really cool stuff. Do your problem sets together.
prereqs: One or more of the following courses: EEB 211, MOL 214, COS 126 or ISC 231/2.
descrip: The completion of the human genome and the continuing effort to sequence tens of thousands of human genomes is yielding unprecedented insights into human biology and the evolutionary history of our species. We will review the key advances enabling researchers to decipher the structure and function of the human genome as well as the genetic basis of variation among individuals and populations. Topics include the evolutionary origins and current structure of human populations, methods for detecting genomic features, cancer genomics and mapping the genes and variants underlying population-specific adaptations and disease susceptibility.

title: The Philosophy of Aristotle - DeAnima Book II
descrip: An exploration of Aristotle's De Anima book II, with special attention to his definition(s) of the soul, and discussion of perception.

title: International Political Economy
descrip: An introduction to the subfield of international political economy, covering basic topics in the politics of both trade and finance.

title: Hogs, Bats, and Ebola: An Introduction to One Health Policy
descrip: See website

title: Empires of the Ancient World
descrip: See website

title: Complex Analysis with Applications
reviews: Don't take it with Aizenman, but the material on its can be interesting
Good class for learning topics in Complex Analysis in a slightly less rigorous format than the math major course

I personally put in a fair amount of time into this course, but the hours paid off. It helps to get at least one buddy to work on problem sets with and revise for the exams. It's a fun applied class. I have to admit I didn't get as much theoretical treatment as I would have liked, but I still learnt a lot, and in the end am glad that I didn't get too much theory because I had enough trouble juggling other courses with this.

If you are trying to decide between MAE 306 or this course, I'd suggest this course. You'll find it much more rewarding, with a professor who really cares about teaching and learning for the sake of learning (ask him plenty of questions during and outside of class!!!!). The material itself is also presented in a way that you actually get to understand the fundamentals of these mathematical concepts, which I feel is more rewarding in the longer run.
It's not a super hard course and it gets the complex analysis requirement out of the way - I would recommend it.

Professor Aizenman is better in office hours than he is in lecture, so you may find those more helpful. He really does care, so talk to him if you need to. This course is a really nice mix of theory and application. It is enough proofs to give you the intuition without getting bogged down in the details, so don't worry if you haven't done proof-based math before. Proofs are not the emphasis. The applications at the end are super interesting, so stick around for those.

Read the Brown and Churchill book and you will be fine. Going to lecture isn't worth your time (I'm not promoting skipping for the sake of skipping--rather you should go to the library, sit down, and read the book or do practice problems...)
Take this course for a moderate complex analysis class. Don't take it for an in depth understanding of complex analysis.
Very useful course. Take it if you're in engineering or sciences.
prereqs: MAT 201 and MAT 202 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of functions of one complex variable, covering power series expansions, residues, contour integration, and conformal mapping. Although the theory will be given adequate treatment, the emphasis of this course is the use of complex analysis as a tool for solving problems.

title: Love and Death on the Japanese Stage
descrip: Love and death are staples of Japanese stage, as in many dramatic traditions. In traditional Japan, they take on a particular coloring, in response to specific cultural conditions and because of long-established and sophisticated conventions of performance. In this course we study how those conventions of performance depict and articulate these fundamental experiences of life. We study the ways gender and religion influence ideas about love and death, and how political change is reflected in dramatic performance. The course is "hands-on": students will learn some songs and performance techniques used in classical Japanese theater.

title: Cryptography
reviews: For the topic of cryptography, you either like it or you don't. This course provided a lot of insight into the details of modern crytography.

I recommend this course to students who are interested in math and computer science. However, the course is a theoretical one and does not have programming and projects, so if you are looking for a more practical course, you might want to take InfoSec

I thought this class was a lot of fun! The psets were fun and I learned a lot from them. (Each took 5 hrs to TeX and 5-7 hours to do, and I've taken proof-based math classes before.) Zeev is a decent lecturer. One complaint is that the class was surprisingly easy in some aspects: on a pset, two problems would often be very easy (as in, doable in 10 minutes) and one problem would be very hard (as in, tricky proofs on which I was stuck for 6  hours). Another complaint, which is not the fault of the class, was that crypto is very repetitive. Halfway through you'll realize it's all reductions, all the time; a lot of the proofs and constructions will be similar with slight variations (often involving XOR and hardcore bits); and you spend a lot of time *breaking* schemes rather than constructing new ones. The reductions are not particularly beautiful (do beautiful reductions exist?). So, mathematically, it's not so enlightening. Provable security is a relatively new field though, with interesting assumptions, so it's worth learning.
If you like crypto, take it.  Otherwise, probably no.

It helps to have some Number Theory background, conversely you can perfectly get by without any knowledge of the application of cryptography, honestly you will not know much about application even after taking the class, but if you enjoy theory it's a relatively painless math class.

It will be a little demanding with LaTeXing the assignments but you learn a lot. Having a math background and being comfortable with the notion of proofs etc will help a lot. Most of the course is getting used to the definitions etc, its not hard otherwise.

The course was well-taught and interesting. My main complaint is that the material felt very repetitive, even though it wasn't, because of how similar all the definitions were. If you're interested in cryptography -- especially from the standpoint of complexity -- then take this class. Otherwise, probably don't.
The difficulty of this class is slightly overstated - it's pretty much just a normal math class. Definitely take it if you like reduction type proofs.
The problem sets are quite like math problem sets; math majors will probably find this class relatively straightforward.

This is a fairly challenging course with a lot of proof based math.  Would not recommend for a 5 course semester, and especially not if you did not get an A/A- in COS 340.  It's graded against a class of 1/2 math majors and 1/2 cos majors, so the curve is challenging.  Zeev Dvir is an okay lecturer, Holden is a great TA.
prereqs: COS 340. Interested students that did not take COS 340 but have a strong math background should inquire with instructor. Please email the Asst. Prof. Zeev Dvir at zdvir@princeton.edu if you have any questions..
descrip: An introduction to modern cryptography with an emphasis on the fundamental ideas. We will survey both the basic information and complexity theoretic concepts as well as their (often surprising and counter-intuitive) applications. Topics covered include private key and public key encryption schemes, digital signatures, pseudorandom generators and functions, chosen ciphertext security, and some advanced topics.

title: Advanced French Language and Style
reviews: Be prepared to write a lot, but not to always get a lot of good feedback. It helps with writing but not really with speaking or reading.

Don't underestimate the workload. It's not hard, but very time consuming, and there are papers (short) due every week. My writing improved the most, but there are lots of opportunities to speak in class.
Great course, interesting and fun assignments - only drawback is the early meeting time.

I would recommend that other students take this course if they want to improve their written French and learn about different styles of writing. For anyone interested in creative writing in French or literary review, this class would be extremely helpful.
This class is about constant writing - an assignment every week or two weeks. The teacher is new, but nice, and is learning to improve as she goes. I'm sure next semester will be better.

This is a great 300-level french course. Although there are a lot of writing assignments, the reading is very light. The prompts for the writing assignments are also very interesting, and you'll get a chance to try out a wide variety of writing styles and genres. In fact, a large portion of the course is devoted to creative writing, so it's quite enjoyable.
prereqs: A 200-level French course or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: To improve spoken and written French through attentive study of French grammatical and syntactic structures and rhetorical styles, with a variety of creative, analytical and practical writing exercises, and reading of literary and non-literary texts.

title: Computer Networks
reviews: A decent course with a lot of potential. The material is important for every computer science student to learn. The lectures moved slowly and the assignment could use some tweaking. But it seems like Professor Feamster has taken an active interest in improving the assignments and listening to student feedback. A good option for a systems requirement as it is a totally manageable workload (only 4 assignments).

A must take course for every CS student and even non CS student. By taking this course, you understand what happens behind the scenes when you go to a website like google.com. It will help you understand what the internet actually is and how amazing it is that it works on such a large scale.

Assignments are just debugging and generally little can be learned from them. Lectures uninspiring and often vague. Exams not hard but are tests of speed not understanding. The material is teachable in 1/5th of the time if the class was more effective.
Be ready to self-learn the material - all of it - before lecture. Also, it'll take you almost as long to figure out how to do the assignments as doing them if you don't have a systems background.

Course was not what I expected it to be. A lot more high-level than I thought it would be. Assignments were somewhat unclear and unstructured, but they will definitely be improved for the future since they were new assignments this time around. Midterm was long, so be prepared.

Do not take the course in its current format. The coordinators have a long way to go before its worth your time. If you are interested in Networks, you are better off watching an online video / course series (there are several), as that is how you will learn most of the material at the moment anyway. Very disappointing.
Do not take this course. There are better systems classes out there to fulfill requirement. With that being said, you do learn critical information about the structure of the internet.
Don't take this course in the current format

Great class. Thorough and interesting real-world assignments (in C, Go, Python, and Apache Spark). I dislike systems but I really liked networks because you can see how the whole system is designed from almost first principles and logically motivated (connecting points, then local networks, then larger networks, then figuring out how to get things from one place to another, then solving congestion issues...). And yes, I can *finally* answer (in detail) the question "what happens between typing 'google.com' into my browser and seeing the page load?" (In short: DNS queries, TCP handshake, HTTP requests, multiple back and forths, lots of complex routing.) Honestly I'm amazed the internet works at all given the massive complexity of protocols and physical/software systems needed.

I guess it's good material to know, but Feamster doesn't teach the material very well and the whole class felt a bit convoluted. The assignments were just revamped this year and were very poorly designed. Maybe P/D/F it or wait for a later offering if you have that option.
I really enjoyed this class. If you are interested in how the internet works or how your computer communicates with other devices you should take this. The assignments are large but very manageable

I would definitely recommend this course if you're interested in systems or networks. The material covered is modern and relevant, and Feamster is pretty engaging. However, the assignments are a fair amount of work, so make sure you have a good partner and can devote a solid amount of time to this course, especially on the weeks before they're due

If you struggled with cos 217 and/or other systems classes, I don't think you will have a good time with this course. Often, there were pieces of information critical to finishing an assignment that I felt were very difficult to find in any of the course materials, or the recommended documentation of Unix or Go. In addition, exams have the same format of cos217 (they are equally, if not more difficult), which I feel requires you to have a thorough knowledge of very obscure details of the course.

However, it is worth noting that my performance in the course was below average, and I'm sure some students who liked 217 will not agree with my criticisms. If that is you, don't hesitate to take this course - I found it to be less time consuming than 217, but more stressful for the aforementioned reasons.
Interesting content, but poorly taught. Assignments are pretty long and there is not much help available.

It's a decent and easy Systems course. I wouldn't say I learned a whole lot of useful things in this class, however. Unless you're particularly interested in Networks, you probably could find better courses to take.

Learning from the lectures is limited. Prof Feamster engaged in more discussion than I liked and we rarely covered everything we had scheduled. The course does give you a general idea about computer networks. Some new assignments have poorly written instructions. I hope there will be improvements. But the assignments are relevant to the course content. Overall I believe you can learn more from other resources than from this class.
Lectures are disorganized and often behind schedule and problem sets need proofreading. Self-advocate to do well.

Lectures were pretty dry -- not the most engaging/organized lecturer. Assignments were better than previous years (not as much C), but still somewhat 1.0. Could improve in years to come. Overall, not a terrible departmental, but not stand-out either.
Make sure to look at the piazza post before you start the assignment or you may spend a couple of hours looking for a bug that turned out to be the instructors' faults!
Maybe wait until this course gets a chance to get used to its assignment transformation. Maybe give it a year or two.
Not bad. Don't fall behind
One of my favorite computer science classes at Princeton; highly recommended if you want to understand how the Internet really works.
Put off taking this class. It might improve/get more organized as the profs gain more experience, but right now it's a bit of a mess.
Strongly recommended. Essential knowledge for CS grads nowadays.
Super super interesting material. Super interesting assignments that are nonetheless terrible because they were poorly made. Should be fixed by next year.
Take it, but beware of the assignments.

Take this class if you are interested in networks.  Professor Feamster is really knowledgable and has a lot of experience with computer networks and networking.  The assignments aren't too terrible as long as you get started early.

The assignments in this class suck. You will be hunting Piazza for answers and crying yourself to sleep as you waste time on stupid things that don't help your learning. Cool concepts though. Just the assignments... super annoying at times.

The assignments were new this semester, so read the reviews here carefully. The biggest issue with the assignments was in their clarity of expectation, which is something I am sure will be improved with time. The course itself will teach you a lot about networking and will be valuable if you are want to learn more about systems and how they operate.
The assignments were redone this semester (Spring '16) and they were god awful. Do not take this course for at least a few semesters while the instructors get the assignments sorted out.

The content in lecture and precepts is interesting and will give you a good understanding of networks and the Internet. The assignments have recently been modernized so there were a lot of kinks that needed to be worked out, which caused them to take a long time to complete.
The instructors were not very helpful and fostered a negative attitude.
The new assignments added a high degree of uncertainty to the course. Wait a year or two until the assignments are better defined and more reasonable.
The topics covered are very relevant to the industry and are things you really should know. However, the overall course feels very disorganized.

This course was pretty boring and the assignments were tedious (read not difficult but time consuming because you have to read a lot of documentation). But if you want to learn about  the way the internet works it's really your only option. If you're looking for a systems class this class is almost no work for most of the semester.
This is a rather time consuming and difficult class, and it is still not polished, so a lot of the difficulties are unavoidable. Think twice.

This was one of those classes where you put in a lot of time and the work is sometimes tedious but can be rewarding at the same time. 

In terms of lectures, Feamster does emphasize a more discussion based format, which only partially worked for me. His additional youtube videos proved to be extremely concise and thorough explanations that completed class time.

Assignments were definitely the meat of  the course. They were programming intensive and required long term planning. I think I improved in C and learned spark, scapy and Go. I have to say that the guidance was sometimes spotty.
Very interesting class and IMO very important for COS students to take as you learn all about computer networks and how the internet and other communication networks work.
Watch the videos as opposed to listening in lecture and start assignments early to avoid last minute confusion without office hours.

What you will learn a lot of:
(1) Stack overflow scavenger hunt skills: The lectures (more on that in a bit) do not cover stuff required for assignments, and a lot of the assignments just tell you to go look up the documentation of some tools that were not mentioned in class at all. A lot of time is just time is just playing scavenger hunt on stack overflow.
(2) Mind-reading. Assignments are usually poorly written. In one assignment, there were comments in the provided code that contradicts what the instructions said. When someone asked him on piazza, he said something like, "oh, the comments are a rough guide only". And his given code can't even compile, which makes me wonder if he actually bothered to run his code to make sure his assignment actually runs. (I'm looking at you, Arpit Gupta)

What you won't learn that much of: Computer Networks.

Sure, Professor Feamster has good videos on youtube which cover everything you need to know. His lectures are a different story, usually extremely disorganized. He will say he would cover 3 topics today, but he will spend almost 50 minutes on the first topic, realise he is out of time, then speed through the next two topics faster than a ping to Google.com. And then he'll tell you to watch the videos for stuff he didn't get to cover. So, moral of the story, just don't take the course, and enjoy his youtube videos which teach you everything from the comfort of your living room.
dont take it unless they fix it.
prereqs: COS 217.
descrip: This course studies computer networks and the services built on top of them. Topics include packet-switch and multi-access networks, routing and flow control, congestion control and quality-of-service, Internet protocols (IP, TCP, BGP), the client-server model and RPC, elements of distributed systems (naming, security, caching) and the design of network services (multimedia, file and web servers).

title: Topics in Arabic Language and Culture - Selections from the Abbasid Period
reviews: This is a good course to strengthen your Arabic. It is interesting, without being too much work.
Very challenging course, but if you're willing to put in the time for homework assignments (~6hrs/weeks) and go all in, you're control of classical/medieval Arabic will improve tremendously.
prereqs: Successful completion or ARA 301 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Introduces the conventions of major genres of history, belles-lettres and religious thought of the Abbasid era (750-1258 CE). Primary emphasis on reading comprehension and developing confidence in approaching classical sources. Conducted in Arabic, apart from translation exercises, and will also develop skills in writing, through projects, and speaking, through discussions and presentations. Course is divided into one or two-week units, focusing on excerpts from major texts. Students to complete major reading/writing project on a text of choosing.

title: Advanced Turkish: Selected Readings in Historical and Literary Texts
reviews: If you've gotten this far, there is no reason not to take 305.

Professor Hatemi is excellent, and she really does care about the students in her class. She is incredibly willing to help students who are struggling and is certainly someone who will go the extra mile to make sure students are engaged.
Professor Hatemi is the CUTEST and most helpful teacher I have ever had. Take it
Take it if you want to practice your modern Turkish, and are not a native speaker.
prereqs: Students are expected to have a sufficient command of Turkish language intermediate/upper intermediate level) to fulfill the reading and writing assignments. See instructor for further information..
descrip: This course introduces a wide variety of reading material (newspaper, memoir, letter, short story, diary etc.) to strengthen students' abilities in understanding and evaluating modern Turkish texts. Information on selected authors and their works will provide a general view on the Ottoman/Turkish cultural, literary and historical panorama. The analysis and discussions of the texts in class will serve to build fluency.

title: Introductory Printmaking
reviews: Absolutely take this class if you are at all interested in art! Note that it can be extremely time consuming, depending on how much work you decide to put in the class, but it was probably one of my favorite classes that I've taken here and a really unique opportunity to learn about a less commonly taught art form.

Be prepared to spend many hours outside of class working, but it's so worth it -- 11/10 would recommend. You really grow close with the medium in a way that you don't feel with drawing or sketching. I learned a lot about working with mediums.

Daniel is a wonderful lumberjack who will teach you all the basics of printmaking. Be prepared to devote time to this class and be in the studio for hours, but you'll really get to know your classmates and get a lot out of it.
Take this class!  Even if you are not interested in printmaking, try it.  It's a great learning experience and the instructor is very encouraging regardless of your artistic level or skill set.
This class requires a huge time commitment, but is really worth taking and Daniel Heyman is a great professor
prereqs: MUST have taken: Any one 200-level VIS course..
descrip: This course introduces techniques of copper plate etching, and relief printing. Assignments focus on applications of various printmaking techniques, while encouraging independent development of subject matter. Critiques will occur throughout the term. Students are encouraged to draw regularly outside of class to cultivate themes and content applicable to their prints. Field trips to the University museum and the library's graphics collection will complement class work. Additional independent workshop hours required.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Systems and Analytics of Big Data
reviews: A chill, enjoyable seminar that I definitely recommend.
Do some extra leg work to pick good papers. Good opportunity to discuss something you care about with others who aren't familiar; they can ask questions you aren't thinking of.

Good class if you are interested in systems and big data, but be aware that the course content will be heavily dependent on the interests of the other students in the class, so it can get a little scattered and esoteric depending on the amount of background knowledge you have.
Plan for projects early.
descrip: The goal of this seminar is to selectively read and discuss classical and recent publications related to big data. Example systems topics include MapReduce, key-value stores, globally distributed storage systems, large-scale systems for graphs and streams. Data analytics topics include feature extraction and learning, ontology construction,dimension reduction, summary data structures, clustering in high dimensional space, deep learning and knowledge base or large datasets.

title: Mathematical Tools for Neuroscience
reviews: Ask questions if you have them! Prof. Pillow is great, and this class is great if you want to understand how math is applied to the biological sciences.
Attend lab every week and complete the problem sets early. It is the only way to succeed in this course.

Definitely take it, if you're interested in a practical application of probability, statistics, linear algebra, etc. Especially if you have experience with linear algebra/probability/statistics, this class will show you some really cool applications of those concepts.

Definitely utilize lab hours! Although they take attendance, you can stay for as long as you like. I suggest staying the whole time because you never know what problems you will run into for your code!

For the first time through, the course was decent. If you do not have the math background, the learning curve can get a little steep depending on the person. However, the stuff near the end, even for those who had seen it, was a little tricky for everyone. But, overall, it is a good course and I encourage all to take it. Pillow really cares about what he is teaching and I am sure he will improve the course greatly.
Give yourself lots of time to complete problem sets.

Good if you want to learn technical skills to analyze neural data. Easy programming wise for a COS major, and good review of concepts if you've taken linear algebra, stats, and diffeq. You learn some new things. Homeworks take more than a few hours each week, so be prepared.
Great course for any Neuroscience major! Very applicable to the understanding of analytic toold used in neuro research.

I would recommend taking COS 126 and MAT 202 before this course so you have basic programming and math background to make this course much easier. Although the description of the course says these are not necessary, they don't do a good job of explaining this background. Luckily I had this background so the course was actually pretty fun but I know a lot of other people were struggling on the psets.

If you have linear algebra and coding in your background, you'll find this really easy. If you have neither, it'll be brutal. Would recommend taking linear algebra, at least one COS class, and probability/stats before taking this class. As far as TAs, Alex Song is the best in terms of availability, but Alex Piet is the best at explaining things. I didn't find Adam Charles particularly helpful for answering questions. But honestly, wouldn't recommend it. I don't feel like I learned anything for it. I needed it for the NEU major, but if I didn't have to, I wouldn't take it.
It can be a challenge, especially if you've never coded before, but it's taught well. Go to office hours/precepts! The TAs are super helpful.
Labs are helpful.
Lots of stats in Matlab
Take advantage of lab time and office hours!
Take it!

Take it!  Go to all the lab sessions you need and do it there.  (preferably not monday night)
use the hints from piazza
Take it!!
Take this course if you need the neuro requirement. You'll learn a lot about coding if you're not already a pro. Go to every single lab section you can make.
The assignments take a while, but the material is interesting and you learn a lot. It's easier if you have some knowledge of MATLAB (or just coding in general) going in.
The concepts are very interesting, but course suffers from a lack of organization.

The problem sets will take a good chunk of time (10-15 hours per week), but if you start early and work with classmates, you will get a lot out of this class! Also, Dr. Pillow is an excellent lecturer and a great, compassionate person. I would definitely recommend taking any class with him!

This class is incredibly helpful, rewarding, and engaging. This is a required course for Neuro majors, but I would suggest it for anyone looking for a mathematical toolset for Neuro and other sciences. Neuro certificates should absolutely take this course. Unlike other math courses, you'll actually learn how to use the tools and not just struggle to keep afloat. It is very applied and it will be immediately helpful in your future research work. I also learned MATLAB through this course (had almost no exposure beforehand). Now I feel very comfortable coding in MATLAB. All around excellent. One of the best courses the department has to offer.

This is a great course which teaches a lot of material. I think it is very interesting and very doable since there are only homeworks. They are quite challenging but you get help in lab and work with others so it is actually quite doable. Overall a good course, learn a lot and low stress. Professor Pillow is a great and devoted teacher.

Unless this class is significantly improved, don't take it unless you have to.  You are better off taking linear algebra in the math department.  There is very little neuroscience, despite the course listing.

Would recommend this course. Pillow is very enthusiastic and great to talk to. I found the material (mainly linear algebra and probability/statistics stuff) very applicable and interesting. No exams makes for much less stress. The psets are great at helping you understand the concepts and the lab tas offer a lot of help with them. I would recommend having coding experience and some background in probability and statistics, but this course is doable without that I'm sure. Overall the course is great and not too difficult.

You have to take this course if you're a neuro major. It isn't that difficult - always go to lab to get your psets done - and the lectures are fairly interesting. If you don't have a strong background in math, it may be a little overwhelming at times, but going to lab will help you get through it.
make sure you go to as many lab sessions as possible, and meet with the TAs if you have any questions because they are really helpful
take it
prereqs: Students should have already taken the math prerequisites for the neuroscience major. Linear algebra and some programming experience are helpful, but not required. We do not assume experience with Matlab, but some basic familiarity would be helpful..
descrip: This lecture course will cover mathematical, statistical, and computational tools necessary to analyze, model, and manipulate neural datasets. A primary goal of the course will be to introduce students to key concepts from linear algebra, dynamical systems, and probability and statistics, with an emphasis on practical implementations via programming. Lectures on each topic will focus on relevant mathematical background, derivation of basic results, and examples relevant to neuroscience. The course will include problem sets based on the MATLAB software package.

title: Ethics of Persuasion, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Soviet Culture, Above and Below Ground
reviews: An amazing class with an equally amazing and engaging professor. Take it as soon as you can
Favorite class at Princeton
One of the best classes I've taken in Princeton.
Take it! interesting material and amazing professor
Take this course. It's a very manageable workload but super engaging and a ton of fun.
Take this course. There are great readings and points of view about the Soviet Union you'll probably never be exposed to in any other way.
Take this course. Very interesting and a reasonable workload.

This is a class you have to take at Princeton. Even if you don't think you'd ever be interested in Soviet literature/history, take it anyway. Reischl is incredible, the readings are fun, and the assignments are manageable.

This must be on your list if you are interested in Russian/Soviet culture. Professor Reischl is also one of the best organized and most thought provoking lecturers I have had at Princeton. The amount of reading can be high on some weeks, but it balances out over some weeks which are much lighter.
descrip: This interdisciplinary survey explores Soviet literature, art, theater, and film after the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917. We will explore the works of avant-garde authors and artists, official writers and painters, authors who wrote "for the desk drawer", and those whose creative works were circulated in the underground. In our analysis of Soviet artistic production, we will focus on major cultural topics in and around the increasing pressure of shifting political landscapes, ideology, propaganda, the publishing market, and the role of the writer in Russian society.

title: Advanced Russian through History and Culture
prereqs: RUS 208, or permission of instructor (kblank@princeton.edu)..
descrip: The course aims to improve students' proficiency in reading, speaking idiomatic Russian. The textbook contains articles on 20th century scientists, writers, artists, composers who were born in Russia and lived there before moving abroad where they became famous (among them Alexander Alekhin, Vladimir Nabokov, Sergei Rachmaninov, Nikolai Roerich, Igor Sikorsky, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Mikhail Shemyakin and others).

title: Projects in Vocal Performance - Vocal Chamber Music
reviews: Knowing how to cite read music will be helpful but it's not required. If you do not have this skill and you still want to take the course, you should definitely take it.
Loads of fun and great bite-sized introduction to Opera- take 219 next semester!
MUS 214 sections vary greatly in difficulty, rigor, and time commitment. Make sure you are deeply interested in the course material/ want to work with the professor offering the course.

Please take this course if you are a singer or a pianist looking for experience in accompanying vocalists. Both Prof. Rearick and Prof. Cappon are wonderful human beings who are very flexible and understanding. The repertoire selection (from Mozart to Wolf to Strauss) is excellent, and many of my fellow classmates who had never sung in German now have a very solid working knowledge in diction.
Practice; show up prepared, and appreciate the feedback the instructors give you.  Everyone will be happier that way.  Even if you practice, it's still a really easy class.
TAKE THIS IF IT IS EVER OFFERED AGAIN
Take it if you like to sing
The professors care a lot, and are wonderful to work with.
This specific course probably won't exist again for a while but 214 is always a blast regardless of what it is focusing on.
take it -- if you sing, why not?
prereqs: Auditions will take place in December 2015. Check Music Dept. website for details or contact gsmith@princeton.edu.
descrip: A masterclass format, with each student attending two 90-minute meetings per week. Students will select from one of two tracks for the course - on track, led by Professors Kellett and Pelletier, which focuses on the preparation of 'Opera Scenes' and the other on German Lieder, led by Professors Cappon and Rearick.

title: Advanced Physics (Electromagnetism)
reviews: A nice E&M class to take. I think it's less work than 105.

Be aware that many PHY 105ers drop, so you'll be taking this course with a lot of people who are really good at physics. The curve is not forgiving and homework/tests are more harshly graded than they were in 105. However, the material is also much more interesting than in 105 in my opinion. Cool class, just be aware of the grades!

Definitely take this if you are interested and good at physics and are considering pursuing it here. While you will learn the material on a basic level in 104, I know a few people who regretted not taking 106 instead of 104. That said, 104 is the easy route.
Definitely worth it! Take over 104
Enjoy the labs! Just focus on understanding the big ideas and main flow of what's going on in lectures; don't worry about understanding minutiae of proofs until you work through it in the textbook.

Go into this course, knowing you are going to be surrounded by the most rigorously trained math and science students at Princeton. A lot of work to even get ahead. But if you put in the time, and go to office hours, the instructors/professors will help you. Might not get the best grade at the end, but worth it, in my opinion. Worth it if you are considering majoring in physics.
If Meyers is one of the teachers, then take the class -- he is excellent! Giombi is good too. Some of the material is covered multiple times, but that's my only major complaint.

If real physics interests you, this course is a must-take. The relativistic treatment of electromag is fascinating and very different than the AP approach. Giombi and Meyers are also an excellent pair.
If you took 105, I definitely recommend continuing on with this course even if you are unsure about being a physics major.
If you're going to be a physics major, this course is a must!

If you're interested learning about electricity, magnetism and optics in depth then take this course. If you just need it as an engineering pre-rec and don't want to devote too much time to physics maybe take 104.
It is a very good introductory to electromagnetism. Take it instead of PHY 104. The relativity part is really nice and you learn a lot. Do the reading, go to lectures.
Lectures can get a bit boring, but the demos are very engaging. The problem sets are fun and the textbook is very beautiful. overall, it's a great course.

Special Relativity   electrostatics = magnetism??? That was the most exciting thing I learned in this course. It is unique from other courses in this approach to magnetism. And truly gets to the heart of the subject. I highly, highly recommend this course, whether you have no experience with e and m or if you have a 5 on the AP exam. The course goes so far beyond AP level and gives a lot of emphasis on derivation of formulas, rather than memorization. If you are interested in gaining a firm grounding in the subject of electricity and magnetism, I would definitely recommend this course!
Take it. You will not regret it.
Take this instead of 104. 104 is bad, this course is better.

This class is the EM equivalent to 105's mechanics; however, even though the material itself in this class is probably harder, I found this class to be a bit more manageable than 105. Prof. Giombe and Prof. Meyers do an excellent job presenting the laws that govern the sometimes unfamiliar world of electricity and magnetism, and introducing the physical theories that link these two phenomena together. If you are fascinated by physics,  willing to accept a pretty sizable work load, and want to gain a deeper understanding of EM, then absolutely take this class.
This is a great class to take after 105 and just as interesting, if not more so.  But I definitely didn't do nearly as well in this class as I did in 105.

This is a great class. The exams are hard, but you will have a much deeper understanding of the material. Meyers is a great lecturer, Giombi is great also, and the Purcell book is actually a great read!!

This was personally my favorite course I have taken so far.  It presents a very unified approach to understanding electromagnetism.  I really liked how they explain how the formulas were derived, and not just telling you what the formulas are.  I strongly recommend this class for all physics majors and anyone who has a general interest in rigorous science.
Thorough treatment of E&M, but I can't say I especially enjoyed the course.

Unless you hate physics with a passion (and I hate proof based math, so I can understand), at least try out this course for the first two weeks during shopping period, and then drop down if you don't like it / think it's more work than it's worth. Having helped my PHY 104 friends with homework   studying in the beginning, I found this course to be much more satisfying conceptually than PHY 104 in the presentation of physics ideas and concepts. I am an aspiring astrophysics major who was insistent on taking the most advanced physics classes possible, so I'm probably biased, but I will say that I came in never imagining I could find E&M interesting, but PHY 106 changed that for me entirely. Professor Giombi doesn't quite get the wonder of this class across, but Meyers and Purcell (the textbook) sure do, and I actually enjoyed this course a lot more than my astro course that I took concurrently because the presentation of ideas and engagement with the material was so amazing (which totally went against years of my experience with both subjects), so that should say something about this course even if you distrusted my opinion as a physics person. 

Go to Meyers' office hours if at all possible, and if you can't make it in his time slot, make an appointment! Try to at least attempt/look through all the problems in the pset before going, so as to have clear questions to ask him and make the most of his office hours. He's really great at guiding you through the problem so that you're the one thinking and talking through it, while still managing to provide guidance and highlighting where your train of thought is leading you astray in the homework. And try to do questions from Purcell's Problems section of the book - the answers are in the back.
take this class if you like physics! it is manageable, and prof meyers and giombi are awesome!
you should take it if you took 105 and loved 105.
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105..
descrip: This course features the classical theory of electricity and magnetism, with emphasis on the unification of these forces through the special theory of relativity. While the subject matter is similar to that of PHY 104, the treatment is more sophisticated. The topics also include DC and AC circuits and the electromagnetic behavior of matter.

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: Senior standing is required for enrollment in this course..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. A student may propose a topic and find a faculty member willing to supervise the work. Or the student may select a topic from lists of projects obtained from faculty and off-campus industrial researchers, subject to the consent of the faculty advisor.

title: Metaphysics
reviews: Do the readings, and participate in preceps.
Easy course--good for completing a distribution requirement. But don't take the course unless you are interested in the subject, as the lectures can otherwise become very uninteresting.

Fantastic course. Really interesting survey of philosophical views on big questions about time and the nature of existence.  Forced me to think critically about everything. Not too much work either. Highly recommend to anyone.
If you like philosophy, then this would be good

Overall, course material is interesting and thought-provoking, and this is definitely a good class to take to learn about the central issues of metaphysics. Not too bad, even if it's your first philosophy course. If you can do the readings without getting too confused, then don't go to lecture. It will be a waste of time as you are being given the same information in a less engaging manner.
Take it!
The topics are generally interesting, but more or less engaging depending on the professor. Not an amazing class, but makes you think about some cool topics.

This course is not too hard, the topics are interesting and there is not a lot of reading, but the readings that you end up doing are comprehensive and important to the subject material and main philosophical debates. The professor is also very chill and his lectures are quite fun and more useful than I would have expected.
This is a fascinating class that will have you questioning previous arguments that you may have blindly accepted on topics such as time travel and personal identity.
You don't need background in philosophy to take this course. I'd recommend
take it if you have to
the material is cool. The lectures aren't great, but if you pay close attention, professor Kment really knows what he's talking about and you can still get a lot out of the class
very little work - good PDF
descrip: A survey of central issue in metaphysics, such as: What is time? Is it true that the past is fixed and immutable while the future is a branching tree of alternative possibilities? Or could we in principle change the past? What makes a certain object at one time identical with a certain object at a later time? Are human beings truly free, or are their actions determined by factors beyond their control? Or both?

title: Honors Linear Algebra
reviews: Definitely take this course if you took 215. In many ways, I found it to be a more enjoyable class.
I liked 215 much better. This class focuses more on the computations.
MAT 217 is an algebra course, so it's a different flavor than 215. If you roughed out 215 and are looking for something different, 217 is the class to get you back.
Start p-sets early and collaborate on hard problems. Get McConnell for sure, and go to his office hours!
Take MAT 202 like class, I recommend MIT open course linear algebra before taking this class. Otherwise, you will miss a lot of intuition.
Take it if you want to be a math major.

Take this class if and only if you know you'll be able to devote the time to it. I found that for myself (a student who is good at MAT/COS-type classes), I needed at least a full day to focus on the problem set (or spread the work out across several days)

The problem sets are bad, I would say to start early but often you don't learn all of the material until two days before they're due. The exams are WAY too long for the time allotted. You won't be able to do well on it, so rush through things and try to get more points than your peers.

This course is the natural continuation of 215, which will prepare you well for it in terms of building mathematical maturity. Expect the time commitment to very substantial--on the order of 20 hours per week if you want to get the most out of it. Depending on the student's affinities, it may be more or less challenging than 215, as Algebra is very different form Analysis. Collaboration will make the problem sets go faster, but may make life harder come exam time. Finally, studying for exams by doing previous exams may not be helpful, as the material varies from year to year and so do the types of problems presented on the exams.

Wonderful and intriguing class. Make sure to get a very strong grasp of the basic computational material early to lay the groundwork for the theoretical stuff. It might also help to read ahead about stuff like determinants and eigenvalues to help motivate the computations, but that's up to you.
Work together on the psets, and start them early.  If you don't get something, consult the book or go on piazza.
descrip: A rigorous course in linear algebra with an emphasis on proof rather than applications. Topics include vector spaces, linear transformations, inner product spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, Jordan form, the spectral theorem for normal transformations, bilinear and quadratic forms.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Federal Budget
descrip: This course covers how the Federal budget process is supposed to work and how it actually does work. Topics include: (1) institutions, processes, and definitions; (2) history of budget outcomes; (3) the current state of the Federal budget process; (4) the role of uncertainty in budgeting; (4) the role of politics in budgeting; and (5) the budget's short- and long-term fiscal consequences. Students are required to do one or more policy memos.

title: Photographic Imagination, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Latin American Literature and Ideology - Memory and Human Rights in Latin America
prereqs: At least one advanced course beyond SPA 209 strongly recommended..
descrip: This course explores the role of human rights, memory, and political violence in contemporary Latin American cultural production. What does it mean to "represent" violence through language and images? How is truth constructed? What is the relationship between the act of witnessing and the law? Is the marketing of memory and trauma through museums and memorials weakening the political force of the collective struggles for justice and truth? These are some of the lenses through which we will read and interpret works in film, literature, art, theater, and photography from the Southern Cone, Peru, and Mexico.

title: Human Nature: A Multispecies Relationship
reviews: Do it.

I don't know if this course will be offered again (Eben is a visiting professor), but it was of the most interesting interdisciplinary courses I have ever taken. Highly recommended, just be aware that anthro readings are par for the course.
Super interesting course, not a huge workload. It works well since this year there were students from all different backgrounds.
TAKE IT
Take it! Be open to changing how you think about things.
Take this course if you can! Even if you're not in either department.
This class probably won't be offered again, but if it is you should take it.
This is a class that you need to take if you are at all interested in the intersection of the humanities and science. Or just if Professor Kirksey is teaching a class, you should probably take it.
prereqs: This advanced course is interdisciplinary in nature. It will be designed for students with some background in anthropology and/or the biological sciences..
descrip: Human life is shaped by diverse critters, technologies, and chemical ecologies. Multiple other species - like rice, bees, tulips, and intestinal flora - all make us who we are, and vice versa. Upending conventional knowledge, we will ask: Did humans domesticate cattle and cereals, or did these species change us? If the modern sciences of biology, chemistry, and cybernetics changed what it meant to be human in the 20th century, new transformations to the human condition are on the horizon with emergent findings about "jumping genes", epigenetics, and the microbiome.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Economic Causes and Consequences of Inequality
descrip: The course covers trends in income and wealth distribution of U.S. and other developed countries, from both empirical and theoretical perspectives. The first part covers the main facts about the evolution of different measures of inequality with special focus on the very top of the distribution. The second part discusses possible drivers of these trends, including skill-biased technical change, wage polarization, globalization, superstar effects, rent-seeking, intergenerational mobility, 'r-g' and lifecycle saving vs. inheritance. The third part discusses consequences of changes in inequality.

title: Corporate Finance
descrip: Introduction to corporate finance covering theories and empirical evidence about principal-agent models of firm managerial structure, takeover bids, capital structure, corporate governance; regulation of financial markets; financial markets and institutions with a focus on asymmetric information, transaction costs, or both; dynamic models of market making; and portfolio manager performance evaluation. Pre-requisite: ECO 525.

title: Topics in African American Literature - African American Literature and the Law
descrip: A historical overview of black literary expression from the 19th century to present day. Will emphasize a critical and analytical approach to considering the social, cultural, and political dimensions of African American literature.

title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Social Psychology
descrip: Introduction to graduate level social psychology for first year graduate students in psychology. This course will serve as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.

title: Tropical Ecology
reviews: Yes, take it!
