descrip: This intensive three week field course takes place during January in a suitable tropical locality. Readings, discussions, and individual projects. The content and location are varied to suit the needs of the participants. Students provide their own travel funds.

title: Soviet-Satellite Relations and Russia's Conflict with Ukraine
descrip: See website

title: Instrumentation and Performance
descrip: The course is a study of the characteristics of individual instruments, including extended contemporary techniques and writing arrangements for chamber ensemble and for orchestra. Special attention is given to problems of combining voice and instruments. The arrangements written for this class are performed by the Composers' Ensemble at Princeton and the Princeton University Orchestra, and problems of performance involving notation, rehearsal, and conducting are dealt with.

title: Nonlinear Optics
reviews: Take it.

This was exactly what I expected from a graduate elective course. Lectures were intellectually stimulating, the course structure was fluid, and there was an emphasis on independent learning. Add in a knowledgeable Prof (who also incorporates his sense of humor) and you have a solid course.
prereqs: ELE 351 or ELE 352 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Introduction to nonlinear optics, second harmonic generation, parametric amplification and oscillation, the electro-optic effect, third order nonlinearities, phase-conjugate optics, photorefractive nonlinear optics, solitons.

title: Dynamical Logics in Architecture
descrip: This course is designed as a workshop in architecture derived from material logics. Students will engage in a series of intensive design projects organized around exploring the new implications of the relationship of the part to the whole, force integration, analogue modeling, mass customization, the generic, etc. Ultimately, each project will work through the architectural performance of the complex interplay between material organization, program and form. The primary emphasis of the course will be the development of individual design/research projects, supplemented by background readings.

title: Memory, Trauma, Accountability
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of reading, but definitely take the course; the discussions are consistently high-quality.

Do the readings and watch the films. They are some of the most interesting materials you'll encounter here. Otherwise, Professor Borneman always has something interesting to say, so participate in discussion too.
Only take if you are interested in the material, otherwise the readings are dense and uninteresting.
Take it! Stay on top of the reading and have fun with it.
descrip: We focus on how humans deal with traumatic loss through three major approaches to memory: psychoanalysis (Freud), social organization (Halbwachs), associative temporalities (Sebald). We examine genres in which the memory of loss is retained or displaced. How is a traumatic past experienced individually and collectively? We consider memory from different cultural landscapes and theoretical perspectives. A better understanding of the memory of loss, and the social forms and histories in which this memory remains active, will improve our approaches to cultural observation, documentation, analysis, and interpretation.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: The senior thesis is an independent study for individual students. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Students develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Students develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Students submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Biology of Coral Reefs
reviews: This course is the best part of being in Panama. It's incredible and you will learn so much. If you go to Coiba, be prepared for no wifi or cell service and MAKE SURE TO BRING but repellent and LONG SLEEVES and LONG PANTS (to prevent being bitten to death). You will thank yourself for this later.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: This field and lecture course provides an in-depth introduction to the biology of tropical coral reefs, with an emphasis on reef fish ecology and behavior. Each day begins with a lecture, followed by six to eight hours on the water, and ends with data analysis, reading and a discussion of recent papers. Students learn to identify fishes, corals and invertebrates, and learn a variety of field methods including underwater censusing, mapping, videotaping and the recording of inter-individual interactions. Each year group projects will vary depending on previous findings and the interests of the faculty.

title: Constraint in Modern European Fiction & Poetry
descrip: A study of 20th century writing in European languages relying to some degree on the principle of constraint or 'strict form'. Queneau, Calvino, Mathews, Perec, Roubaud and other members of Oulipo will constitute the central focus, but depending on students' linguistic competences works by e.g., Harig, Kharms, Nabokov, Cortazar may be included. Attention is focused on underlying principles as well as on practice and product.

title: Jazz Theory through Improvisation and Composition I
reviews: If you like jazz and want to learn more about jazz theory, I would strongly recommend taking this course as it will expose you to a new way to think about jazz.
It's more theoretical than perhaps improvisatory, but worth taking nevertheless to know about the harmonic aspect of jazz.
Practice piano and ear-training even when not assigned.  It becomes extremely important for the final, but will catch you off guard if you are not keeping up on your own.
Take for a chill semester.

Take it if you're interested in jazz or music theory! Professor Bowen is incredibly knowledgeable, and the class is a great time. You get to write your own compositions and play everyone's pieces with your own instruments in class.
Take it, especially if you have any interest in jazz and a decent theory background!
prereqs: MUS 105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: An exploration of the melodic, harmonic and rhythmic principles of the bebop paradigm. The course includes analysis of representative works by various jazz masters and will place a strong emphasis on student projects in improvisation, transcription, analysis and composition.

title: Special Topics in Computer Science - Introduction to Deep Learning
reviews: An excellent, highly applied introduction to deep learning and foundations of ML. Learn how to build neural networks to perform tasks like object recognition, and actually understand what's going on under the hood, too!
Definitely take! You learn a lot and it's not too difficult.
Good introduction to deep learning, but it requires you to learn most of the material on your own, because lectures are hard to follow otherwise.
I wouldn't recommend taking this class if Yingu's teaching it.  If you really want to learn DL, read the text book on your own and try some tutorials from any one of the open source DL packages.
It is an interesting topic, and a good way to learn about machine learning. It is a significant time commitment though, so plan accordingly.
Not worth a course slot -- you can easily learn this material on your own.
Take it. Interesting introduction to deep learning.
i think the course is different every year so i would take it if it is offered again.
prereqs: COS 340.
descrip: This course is an elementary introduction to a machine learning technique called deep learning (also called neural nets), as well as its applications to a variety of domains, including image classification, speech recognition, and natural language processing. Along the way the course also provides an intuitive introduction to basic notions such as supervised vs unsupervised learning, linear and logistic regression, continuous optimization (especially variants of gradient descent), generalization theory and overfitting, regularizers, and probabilistic modeling.

title: Sustainable Development in Practice
reviews: Again, if you are considering studying abroad in Kenya, please do it. This course in particular is a lot to process (on a social/emotional level more than an intellectual level) but absolutely worth it.
Be prepared to spend long hours in the field and analyzing data, but it's worth it!

For Sustainable Development majors, those intending to work in the non-profit or development sector, or anyone interested in complex systems, this course is a must. This course provided an opportunity to apply much of the theory that you learn at the campus level, and solidifies concepts through challenges that you will encounter in the field.

From visiting schools in Sauri, Kenya to interviewing mothers about food security in Karamoja, Uganda this course  changed some of my world views. Great opportunity to learn about sustainable development directly from the people affected. I highly highly highly recommend the Kenya field semester abroad

I would strongly recommend the semester abroad to other students. The Sustainable Development in Practice course was one of the most interesting courses of the trip, and you have an incredible opportunity to interact with community members on a very personal level. You will leave the course with very applicable skills which you can apply outside the field of sustainable development (especially in terms of collecting data in a social science setting).
prereqs: EEB 321. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: This course studies the theory and practical application of sustainable development in East Africa. Students learn about the administrative and sociopolitical structures of Kenya, history of the United Nation's Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and the agriculture, education, infrastructure, water, and health issues in urban and rural areas. Discussion with communities, field work, practical problem solving, GIS tools, e-tools, modeling, and understanding local constraints form the foundation for this course.

title: Microeconomics Theory Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: El Genero Negro: Crime Fiction
reviews: I would take it if you are looking for a 200 level spanish course. The material is interesting, and Price is a good and fair professor.

If you are at all interested in Spanish and the arts, I would highly recommend taking this course.  It is an incredibly enriching experience.  Attend all class sessions, read and watch all the works, take advantage of every written assignment as a chance to grow--and enjoy it all!

Take it if it's with Rachel Price. She's very kind, interesting to talk to outside of class, and a good professor. It's an interesting course if you like talking about themes in Latin American literature.
Take it it is super interesting
Take the class if you want to keep up your Spanish skills without being incredibly stressed over the workload. Professor Price is interesting and nice to work with.
Would recommend!

absolutely loved this course. not a super heavy workload and professor price is phenomenal. I took this course wanting to take focused on culture rather than grammar and I loved it. you get as much out of this course as you put into it. if you aren't engaged this course could be a bit dry, but if you put effort in professor price will make it worth it.
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher; or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course is an introduction to crime fiction from early 20th-century "locked room" mysteries to 21st century narco-narratives. It examines short stories, novels, films and critical writings about detective and crime fiction in Latin America and Spain. Topics include the genre's links to high and low literature, to film and to historical contexts such as immigration, state crime, drug culture and globalization. Authors include Roberto Arlt, Maria Elvira Bermudez, Adolfo Bioy Casares, Roberto Bolano, Jorge Luis Borges, Alicia Gimenez Bartlett, Leonardo Padura Fuentes, Ricardo Piglia, Fernando Vallejo, and others.

title: Korean Cinema
reviews: I definitely recommend this course for other students who are interested in East Asian film!
It's a really fun class. Not too hard. Professor Chung is chill, but he likes to talk so the seminars go by decently quickly.
Loved this class. Prof. Chung is an amazing professor.
Manageable workload, although not as easy as everyone says. Take it if you are actually interested in Korean culture.
Steve Chung is amazing. Definitely take this class if you're at all into film or even if you're not.
Take it! It's a good class. Most of the movies are really fun also.
Take this class! Watch some awesome movies and have some great discussions
Take time every week to do readings before watching the films. Readings really illuminate the film content.
Watch the films. They're worth it. Also, form your essay idea early.

Would highly recommend any course taught by Professor Chung. You might not enjoy all of the films covered by this course but the class itself makes even the less enjoyable ones interesting to think about.
descrip: Offers a broad historical examination of Korean cinema from both sides of the DMZ. We start with some rare surviving colonial period films and work our way to the very recent films of the "Korean wave" era. Our thematic focus will be post-coloniality, ideological division, war, national reconstruction, democratization, and intensified global capitalism; our critical focus will be on problems of nation, class, and gender. At the heart of the work for the course will be attention to the films themselves, where we will try to account critically for shifts in style and form.

title: Systematic Ethics
reviews: Definitely take it! Sarah McGrath is an incredible professor, and if you are at all interested in metaethics or epistemology, this course will teach you all you need to know
Take with Prof. McGrath!
Very good introduction to metaethics.
prereqs: One prior course in Philosophy.
descrip: A survey of major problems and developments in twentieth century metaethics, from G.E. Moore to the present.

title: The Resource Curse and Development in Africa
reviews: A little bit

I would take this course if you're looking to learn about new perspectives on development, governance, conflict, and resources in Africa. It isn't a lot of work so it's a good way to learn something new without too much stress.
Take the class it is very fulfilling whichever way you look at it
Take this course, it is extremely interesting and the workload is entirely manageable. The instructor is also an expert in his field and clearly knows what he is talking about.
This class was awesome, I loved it!
This class was great, ask for clarification on the papers but overall an excellent class.
Very chill class - take if you are interested in learning more about development and its pathologies
Wouldn't recommend.
descrip: This course examines the relationship between natural resource wealth and development in Africa. The dominant discourse on resource wealth on the continent has largely been associated with the resource curse. The construction and reproduction of the resource curse thesis is explored, particularly against the backdrop of the recent resource boom and scramble on the continent, and the changes that have occurred in Africa's resource-rich economies. It seeks to address the following questions. Is resource endowment inimical to development in Africa? What causes the resource curse in Africa? How can the resource curse be overcome in Africa?

title: Contemporary Art: Trying Out Positions
prereqs: Interested students should contact the professor [jscanlan@princeton.edu] to arrange an interview..
descrip: Artists have long deployed language as a kind of satellite hovering in the vicinity of their artworks, influencing their reception. The style and method of this language varies greatly and does not always match the accompanying work. This studio seminar will engage students in contemporary art theory and practice by taking up this critical aspect of its making: The artist producing language that stakes out a position in relation to their studio work. Focus will be on five artists: Marcel Broodthaers, Andrea Fraser, Adrian Piper, Frank Stella, and Peter Fischli & David Weiss, four of whom will have a major presence in the vicinity this Spring.

title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
descrip: Electronic structure of crystals, phonons, transport and magnetic properties, screening in metals, and superconductivity.

title: The New Testament and Christian Origins
reviews: Definitely definitely take it but be prepared to approach your faith differently
Do the text book readings as much as you can.

Go to lecture and ask questions. Gager is really awesome to get to know and he is really engaged. Do not feel shy about asking for help and make sure you ask for assistance with the major assignments because they are are not your usual papers. Also, beware that Gager is a pretty harsh grader but it will all be good at the end.
Great class that causes you to think a lot. I had a lot of background in christianity and it caused me to look at it through a new perspective.
I would advise another student taking this course to read the Bible prior to taking this course, so that they can have a more fully-formed view of Scripture and participate more in discussions.
Must take class if you are at all curious about Christianity and its start. I am not religious and I found myself intrigued beyond imagination. Easy 5th class for BSE as well.
Not too much work, easy to not pay attention at all but fall behind. For final you need to catch up a lot.
Participate in precept

Run, don't walk, and take this class. If you're Christian, if you're atheist, if you're Jewish, if you're Muslim, if you don't know, take the class. It will challenge and enlighten you. Cannot recommend this high enough. Pure intellectual bliss.
Take it! It will challenge whatever preconceptions you have, whether you have been a Christian for years or don't know much about Christianity at all.
Take this course! It makes you see the world and culture in general in a different way!
The course is worth taking and really challenges the way you think about the New Testameng while also making you better understand it.
Try to participate in precept! There can be a bit too many readings sometimes but make sure you keep up with at least the textbook stuff
descrip: To trace the origins of Christianity from its beginnings as a movement within ancient Judaism to its gradual transformation and emergence as an independent religious movement in the Roman Empire and beyond. To read the New Testament with a critical eye, i.e., as a collection of documents illustrating differing emphases and stages in the growth of early Christianity.

title: Beyond Comparison
reviews: Intellectually involved, you must do work and write weekly response papers that Naphtali really critiques. Only take this if you are willing to put work into it. It ends up challenging you to become a better thinker and writer so overall it ended up being a good course.
Interesting; at least try it out. Particular style of learning
Take this course if it is offered, regardless of your major.
Taking with Prof. Meshel was amazing

Very productive, in-depth class discussions. Thought-provoking (if slightly dated) readings dovetailed very well into seminar discourse. Definitely focused more on theory than actual myth... contrary to initial impression given by course description and syllabus.
take this class if it is offered in another semester! Or take a class with Professor Meshel.
descrip: What does it mean to compare two or more religious phenomena? What are the goals of such studies, and what makes a comparison compelling and useful? We will learn about some of the most important comparative approaches within the study of religion, with a particular focus on the analysis of the categories 'ritual' and 'myth.' We will then carry out our own comparative experiments in which we will observe the slaying of dragons in India and in Europe, and follow the trail of a murderous act from the ancient Near East to the Americas.

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences
descrip: A survey of fundamental papers in the Geosciences. Topics include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes, igneous petrology, mantle structure, sedimentology, seismicity and polar environmental and geological processes, including glaciology.

title: Intermediate Sanskrit II
prereqs: SAN 105 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Strengthens Classical Sanskrit grammar and vocabulary and builds knowledge of South Asian religion and culture through reading selections from Sanskrit epics, narrative, pre-philosophical, didactic, and poetic texts. Together with SAN 105 this course provides students an introduction to the major genres of Sanskrit literature. Requires Sanskrit 105 or permission of the instructor.

title: Practice Teaching
prereqs: Admission to the Teacher Preparation Program is usually required. Application for fieldwork placement must be made in advance. Completion of Pre-professional portfolio..
descrip: Supervised practice teaching (a minimum of 12 weeks) in a secondary school. Teaching is done under the supervision of an accomplished teacher and a program staff member who regularly observe and discuss the student's practice teaching. Students gain firsthand experience in developing teaching strategies, planning and implementing instruction, assessing student learning, and classroom management. Must be taken concurrently with TPP 401.

title: The Greek World in the Hellenistic Age
reviews: Annotate the readings as some of them can be really dense.
As long as you keep up with the readings, which were never too long, it is easy to keep up in the course, and it's a really nice way to get an HA.

Chose preceptor wisely, Gygax is wonderful in smaller settings.  His lectures can be a little confusing or boring in delivery (but obviously he is very passionate about the topics).  Talking to him one on one or getting him as your preceptor is the best way to stay engaged. Very interesting course overall.
Go to lecture!  The readings are interesting, but not always essential.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in ancient history. The material is accessible to anyone regardless of prior background in the field, the workload is quite reasonable, and the presentation of the lecture material is superb.
I would recommend this course just because of the Professor, Domingo is a great guy who truly wants you to learn the material and interact with it, not just memorize it.
I'd recommend this as a relatively easy HA that will help you to understand a time period that is not often taught and even less often understood.
If you have an interest in the content then take it, but make sure you go to lecture and take good notes. A great class to PDF if you don't mind just showing up to lecture (readings aren't necessary)

If you're at all interested in taking this course, do it! Prof. Domingo is great and he clearly has a lot of passion for the material. Readings are interesting and assignments are reasonable. If you're thinking about it, don't hesitate!

In retrospect, I'm not sure I would have taken this course had I known what it would be like. It has a decent, though not overwhelming, amount of reading, and the precepts were generally good, but some of the lectures were pretty painful/rambling - which is unfortunate, because Professor Gygax seems very nice and is obviously an accomplished scholar. If you are very, very interested in military or Greek history, I wouldn't discourage you from taking it; as for others, I might suggest shopping before you commit.
It's an interesting course!! Take it if you're interested in the subject matter.  Just make sure you go to the lectures -- that's where all the important information gets told!
It's an okay course, definitely not the best history class that I've taken at Princeton. If you take this, go to your preceptor's office hours as much as you can.
Make sure you do the readings otherwise you will be lost.
Take it if you are interested in Ancient Greek history!
Take it, Professor Gygax is awesome.
Take the class seriously and just go to class. If you go to class and write notes you should be fine. Pick a good preceptor as well!
Take the class!
Take the class! Not that difficult, but super interesting and enjoyable.
Take this class!
Take this course! It's a lot of fun, not too time intensive and very interesting.
Take this course.

Terrible lecture, very hard to keep up without previous knowledge, you'll spend all your time memorizing tiny facts that you won't remember a week after the exam. There are so many better HAs out there.
The professor is very engaging and a good teacher. Very good course and recommend it.

This course is great if you're interested in people/culture/art/society, especially of the ancient variety. Also, Professor Gygax is one of the kindest, most helpful, most interesting, and most HUMAN professors I've ever met so I would highly recommend going to office hours to talk about the course or anything at all.
definitely take it if you find ancient history interesting
go to lecture and take notes
descrip: The Greek experience from Alexander the Great through Cleopatra. An exploration of the dramatic expansion of the Greek world into Egypt and the Near East brought about by the conquests and achievements of Alexander. Study of the profound political, social, and intellectual changes that stemmed from the interaction of new cultures, and the entrance of Rome into the Greek world. Readings include history, biography, and inscriptions.

title: Studies in Later Persian Literature 1200 - 1800 A.D.
descrip: Course acquaints students with the literature of the second great classical language of Islam and its legacy of epics, chronicles, lyric poems, mystical writings and imaginative tales from the traditional Persian-speaking world - including not only from present-day Iran, Afghanistan and Tajikistan but also from Anatolia, Central Asia and the Indian sub-continent. Continuation of NES 539. Treats the literature from 1200 to 1800.

title: Toward an Environmental History of the Mediterranean
descrip: The aim of this course is to introduce students to the central themes of medieval and modern environmental history and to the types of evidence that historians and scientists use to address the questions that arise. It will also serve as an introduction to a significant emerging cross-disciplinary field, that of "science and history." Focusing on the Mediterranean world from the Romans to the end of the Ottoman empire, the course provide students with a thorough overview of the environmental problems of the Mediterranean world and will also have a strong methodological focus.

title: Topics in Music from 1600 to 1800 - Mozart and Da Ponte
descrip: The seminar focuses on the sources, analysis, theatrical traditions, reception, and contemporary staging of the three operas that Mozart composed in collaboration with Lorenzo Da Ponte. Participants have an opportunity to see Le Nozze di Figaro at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Senior Independent Work
descrip: A one semester study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written report required.

title: Travelers, Tourists and Pilgrims
reviews: Better for people interested in sociology.
Could be okay.
Definitely recommend this class.

Do not take this course. It is boring, irrelevant, and is full of stupid tautologies that you probably already know. Are you interested in attending two lectures on "souvenir theory", where you'll hear the Professor ramble about the 'lifetime of a souvenir'? If so, take this course, but don't expect much. It's an extremely easy, extremely simplistic SA full of facts that any person with a high-school diploma probably already knows.
Fun class to take. Not too much work with interesting topics.
Go ahead, take
I was bored, but that may be because I never went to class (still getting a B though)
I would suggest talking out the concepts with a stud buddy for exams. This will help solidify information and give good preparation for essay questions on exams.
If you have any interest in traveling or the world in general, take this course. It's an incredible and not too difficult way to learn about other peoples and how we all relate.
Please take it, Professor Johnston is very approachable and knowledgable and if you have ever traveled before, this will make you think about it in a new and interesting way.
Take it if you need a SOC course and are at all interested in studying travel.
Take it! Manageable and interesting
Take this class if you like traveling in general!

Take this course if you have any history of traveling or interest in tourism. It was so interesting to see both sides of tourism and its effects on culture, as well as the social science behind it. There is a lot of reading but minimal work.

The readings are very important and so is going to class. Have a reason for taking this class, and hold onto until the end. During the semester, you question taking the course, but after taking it, it's very very rewarding.

This course is not too challenging, and is interesting for the most part, but it gets repetitive. The readings and the course work is not too much but be sure to keep good notes for the midterm and final.
This course was a lot of fun, and Professor Johnston was great. I would recommend this course to anyone interested in travel and tourism.

This is a fantastic course of an understudied area. You come away with ideas that change your approach to travel but also to a variety of other fields. You should definitely take it. Grading is fair and lectures keep your attention

This is a very manageable course. Make sure you get around to all the readings by the time you have exams. Probably most important, go to every lecture because there is a ton of information covered that is not on slides or in readings. Engage with this course a little and it should be pretty easy.
Very interesting course but not an easy A, it's a lot of reading if you do it every week but it's all interesting.

Was really surprised by how much I ended up liking this course, given I took it for a departmental... There's a lot to be learned and the way it's taught is interesting but not too challenging. Good class.
do the reading and go to lecture
prereqs: Other 15% = Weekly Response Memos (4 total)..
descrip: Travel has always been a central aspect of human life. Today, tourism is one of the largest industries in the world. In this course, we will investigate the history, structure and consequences of tourism as a global industry. We will also examine why people travel, how they travel and what they actually do while "on the road." Throughout, we will use tourism as a lens to engage broader sociological ideas and concepts, including modernity and post-modernity, consumption and cultural commodification, the construction of social inequalities, as well as issues of authenticity, identity, and globalization.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced French
reviews: Absolutely take this class. Rachel Hart is one of the most committed professors you will encounter at Princeton. The workload is very reasonable, it's honestly much more time in class than out of class. I came out of this class with the ability to speak very well in French. I did very little homework outside of class, because that's just how thorough the class time is. I can't possibly speak highly enough of Professor Hart; she is an amazing professor, and now I honestly consider her a friend (a friend who is way smarter and more capable than i am, that is). Take it!!!

Absolutely, 100% take this course regardless of your background or interests, especially if Rachel Hart is teaching it again. She's wonderful, the perfect language professor. The workload isn't significantly more difficult than 101, but your French will improve dramatically. 80 minutes every day seems like a lot, but honestly I've barely noticed the length all semester. I can't recommend it highly enough.
Completely worth it! Rachel Hart is the best professor you could ever ask for. This class was the first time that I didn't dread going to a language class.
Definitely take this class if you have a genuine interest in French. I found my language abilities improving drastically in this class, and it was very satisfying.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking to become fluent in French. I would not say that I am fluent in French yet, but for only my second semester of the language, I am pretty impressed! Just the fact that it is an hour and a half was actually really helpful, even if it seems like a drag. It's an extra 30 minutes everyday listening the language, which is really indispensable!
TAKE THIS COURSE! Rachel is incredible at teaching French and creating a manageable and efficient curriculum.
TAKE THIS COURSE.
Take all the classes you can with Rachel Hart. My favorite language teacher ever!
Take it!! It's actually a lot of fun!

Take this class!! It's not very much work (outside of the 1.5 hours a day that you are in class), and your abilities will greatly improve. You will also get pretty close to the people in your class, and, for me at least, it was a wonderful community where I felt really safe to make mistakes, which is super important in a language class. Overall FANTASTIC class with a FANTASTIC teacher.

Take this course if you get into it. Rachel is amazing and really helps develop your French. It's rare that a professor is both lax and effective, but somehow, in a super intensive course, she made it really engaging. If you want your French to improve (and a chance at going to Aix in the summer) take this class.

This is a fantastic course.  It does move rather quickly, however, Rachel is a fantastic teacher.  Make sure to stay on top of your work but doing that and engaging in the class time, you will have a great time and greatly improve your french skills.
Treat this class like it is your most important class. It is so hard but so worth it.
Try to keep up with the homework, even though there is quite a lot of it. It really helps when the time comes to take tests.
prereqs: FRE 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: FRE 102-7 is an intensive double course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Focus will be on reading and listening comprehension, oral proficiency, grammatical accuracy, and the development of reading and writing skills. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be introduced to various Francophone cultures through readings, videos and films.

title: Dynamics of Stellar and Planetary Systems
reviews: I strongly recommend taking this course.

This course is on a cool and interesting field of astrophysics.  The lectures were very formal and somewhat tedious and often difficult to follow.  If you can learn through that process then this class will be great to take from this professor, otherwise just reading the textbook will help you learn just as well as the lectures.
descrip: Galactic structure, morphology and dynamics. Equilibrium and stability of stellar systems. The gravitational N-body problem, relaxation, dynamical friction, and the Fokker-Planck equation. Encounters and mergers of stellar systems. Spiral structure. Elements of planetary dynamics and celestial mechanics.

title: The Novel and Romance
descrip: "The novel" has been defined since its establishment as a literary genre in tension with both "romance" and "history." This year's seminar interrogates this definitive tension among narrative genres through readings in two forms of historical romance that were central to the development of the modern novel, even though they are often considered peripheral: chivalric and gothic. Critical readings accompany and guide our readings in narrative.

title: Russian Folklore
descrip: Explores Russian oral traditions and oral literary genres in English translation: Traditional life-cycle and seasonal rituals and songs associated with them; superstitions, charms, oral narrative poetry (byliny) and prose (skazki); chastushki, jokes; present-day popular culture; and relationships between folklore and literature. Focus on the role and meaning of Russian folklore as expressive culture and how it informs contemporary society.

title: Princeton Atelier - Waking the Dead
reviews: Strongly recommended if offered again, both professors are very knowledgeable and talented and the you get to work closely with a lot of other very talented students.
Take it! The Atelier course I took was super-weird and really exciting. I became a better artist and got to engage with forms I don't usually get to engage with!
Take it.
The students didn't have any input for the first half of the semester, but by the end we were doing things.
Try it out.
take the course!! You'll get to try new things artistically while working alongside other incredible students and instructors.
prereqs: Students from any discipline interested in using history and art as catalysts for a multi-media theatrical performance investigating the interaction of death and art are encouraged to apply. Students should be open to learning how to collaborate and learning how to transform a creative process into a production. The final collaborative production will count 80% of students' grades. A brief application is required: arts.princeton.edu/atelier.
descrip: Two storytellers, working in different mediums, combine their processes and approaches to narrative to meditate on mortality. Graphic novelist Kevin C. Pyle and Jennine Willett, Co-Artistic Director of Third Rail Projects, a dance theater company known for immersive works, will collaborate with students across multiple disciplines to integrate movement, images, and text into a new story-telling format. The course culminates in a theatrical experience that will incorporate projected imagery, art installations, text movement and immersive elements.

title: Politics of Inequality and Redistribution (Half-Term)
descrip: Study of policy preferences, differential rates of political participation, voting behavior, legislative process, political communication, urban politics and role of race in US political life are central to study of inequality in politics. Though the American case will feature prominently, we will approach issues from a comparative perspective. Thus the course provides introduction to comparative study of welfare states and political economy of advanced industrial countries, including regulation of labor markets and relationship between wage inequality, income distribution and policy preferences for redistribution and social protection.

title: Experience of Consumer Culture, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in German Intellectual History - Mysticism and Modernity
descrip: So-called 'mystical' forms of thought and experience have played a major role in the history of modern philosophy and literature from Hegel to Lukacs, Heidegger, Bataille, and Derrida, and from Novalis to Musil, Celan, Bachmann, Klossowski, and Cage (to name just a few). In this seminar we first read key medieval and baroque texts. Based on the class discussion and on individual student interests, we then look into the ways how these texts have been read by 19th and 20th century authors and explore the impact they had on the discussion of modern concepts of subjectivity, affect, and agency.

title: Race Is Socially Constructed: Now What?
reviews: A word of advice to you: TAKE THIS COURSE.  Seriously.  You will learn so much, from so many different perspectives, and it will help you understand, and educate, your own perspective as well.

Always do the readings and take your time with them! A lot of this material is important not just for the class, but for your own personal life so it's really worth your time to take it slow with the readings. You'd be surprised how much you'll actually learn about yourself and your environment in this class.
Amazing course. You are doing yourself and the world an injustice if you choose NOT to take this course. Trust me, take it.
Be sure to attend lecture, and make sure to review notes to prepare for pop quizzes.
DO NOT DO YOURSELF A DISSERVICE BY NOT TAKING THIS CLASS--- TAKE THIS CLASS IT WILL CHANGE THE WAY YOU THINK, SEE AND FEEL.  You will learn so, so much about race and social issues in our country.
Definitely do it!!!!!!

Despite being a senior in my spring semester, I still felt compelled to give this class my all. I could see how much Professor Benjamin invested into teaching the class, so it was only right that I give her the same time and energy that she was giving us. It was annoying at times, but it was worth it. I'm definitely not upset that this was one of the last courses I took during my Princeton career. Take it if you're willing to put in the work and really engage with the materials!
Everyone should take a course like this. It's a good course but so much talking in circles by Prof B, she could say her lecture in 5 minutes.

Everyone should take this class. Not only are the lectures great and the coursework light, but you learn so much about your own life. You explore such interesting topics that teach you so much about race and ethnicity. TAKE IT.
Fascinating class- opens your eyes to the world around you.  Its a really important life course for students in humanities and sciences alike. Not an unmanageable amount of coursework.

GREAT CLASS. Really made me think about the world in another way. There aren't a ton of assignments, but a fair amount of reading (~150-200 pages a week). Don't let the reading discourage you from taking the class, however. I generally found them to be interesting and easy to get through. Don't expect this to be an easy A, but take it to become a better, more informed individual. This class has been one of the most formative of my Princeton career and I sincerely think every student should take it. Ruha Benjamin won't be teaching this for the next few years, and I don't know how that will affect the quality of the class, but regardless the content is A . Definitely recommend.
Go to all the lectures; they're super interesting and eye-opening!
Great course that every Princeton student should take. All it takes is going to lectures and reading some of the important chapters in the text, and its an easy course.
Great course that you must take. Not too much reading, but definitely not an easy A. The course is also pretty hesitant to challenge it's own beliefs.
Great.
Highly recommend!
I would highly recommend taking this course. The readings and the lectures have taught me so many things that I didn't know before. Great introductory level course for freshmen and sophomores.

I would strongly recommend taking this class if you are looking to fulfill your SA distribution. The workload is not too intensive (although the final paper is more work than most final papers for other classes), and more importantly, the lectures and subject material were very engaging.
I would urge every student at Princeton to take a course like this. It prompted very important realizations to be made, and I think every person would get something out of this course.
I'd recommend for students to engage in precepts as much as possible; not only are they interesting but they help cement a greater understanding of course concepts.

If you're choosing between taking this course and taking another course, choose this one. If you're a senior searching for a fun course to fill a spot in your schedule, your search has come to an end. This course is work, but it's very manageable, and it's well worth it for the reward of profound understanding of an important topic.
It's a really important course to take. You will learn things that will change the way you view a lot of American institutions
It's challenging but one of the most rewarding and relevant classes I've taken here. Ezelle is an excellent preceptor, get him if you can!
Just take a course on race. Just do it.
Keep up with the readings!
Keep up with the readings, and review weekly for the pop quizzes.

Make sure to do all of the readings and pay attention in lecture because this will be helpful for the three pop quizzes throughout the semester. Readings are not overbearing at all and actually very interesting. A very engaging and applicable course for anyone interested in sociology or looking for an SA. I highly recommend this course
Must take this course. Professor Benjamin is excellent and the material is eye-opening.
PLEASEEEE take this class. Everyone at the university should take this class.

Please please always question what you know about race and never stop discussing it. The key is to find a respectful way of doing so, not censoring speech altogether. I don't think I can recommend how to do so in this review, but I would highly recommend everyone to take a class on race and note how topics of race/racial domination might be uncovered in areas of study not explicitly related to race. If nothing else, you gain practice in challenging your assumptions. Our society, our souls, and our minds will benefit so much from doing so.

Please take it. The topic is so so so important for what is going on on campus right now and for what is going on in the US. Even if you think talking about this material will make you uncomfortable (actually, ESPECIALLY if talking about this material makes you uncomfortable), you should take this class and learn to engage in conversations outside your comfort zone, because that's why you came to Princeton. Professor Benjamin is one of the best lecturers I have had a Princeton and I do not regret a single moment in her class.

Professor Benjamin will be gone. She did recommend Prof. Kesson's class on Aesthetics. If you take a class on race consider whether you can be challenged and will feel comfortable expressing your opinions.

Read closely and take good notes - hugely helpful to learn material by talking about course concepts with peers since one of the main goals of the course is to change the social constructs that exist around us !

Really interesting course which will make you scrutinize race and practices of equality in our society. While the course is relatively fair, expect the first quiz to be brutal and precept discussions to be possibly dominated by a few passionated individuals.

Regardless of your opinions about discussions on race in the current climate, take this course. It's illuminating for those who already agreed with its general principles and positively challenging for those who don't.
Ruha is an amazing lecturer, everyone should take this course. I would be intentional about your choice of a preceptor though.

Ruha is fantastic! She's engaging and keeps you having aha! moments the entire time you're in the room with her. Her lecture is long but it flies by with the knowledge she's imparting. ABSOLUTELY take this class if you can, it's a good eye opener for anybody about our world today and will have you making tiny realizations about your place in it using her tools long after lectures finish.
Study for the quizzes which happen in weeks 4, 8 and 12. Other than that the course is straightforward, make sure to do your interviews early
TAKE THIS CLASS. Most impactful class I've taken at Princeton hands down. This course will completely change the way you see yourself and the world around you.

TAKE THIS COURSE!! Professor Benjamin is the best professor I've had in my 4 years at Princeton, and this is definitely one of the best course I've taken. More important, this is the course that I think has affected me the most, changing the way I view the world. I knew very little about race in America before I took this course, and I came out knowing so much more and really being mind blown by some of the things we learned. The assignments are all extremely relevant to your life, and help enrich your understanding of the concepts we learn in class. Best course ever.
THIS WAS THE BEST COURSE EVER
Take it if you are interested in the subject; prepare to have your current ways of thinking challenged. Good intro class.

Take it! This is the kind of course that should be mandatory for all students because it is so enlightening. College is supposed to be an experience where you learn so much more than you could in high school and this class is the first class I have taken while here at Princeton that has actually done that for me. I learned so much about this country and within the first week (!) you realize how much we are not taught in an effort to hide the realities of this nation.
Take it, it will change you.
Take it. You will learn an essential narrative that APUSH didn't teach you and come to understand a lot about why our country is the way it is. You will be given tools to change it.

Take the course! Just make sure to do the readings in time for class, and to work with your preceptor so you won't have any surprises with grading. No matter how knowledgeable you were on these subjects already, you will definitely learn something.  This is the type of class that will arm you to be the type of adult who can go out into the world and relate with others/understand your own experiences better.
Take this class! By far the most interesting class I've taken that will actually be immediately applicable to your life.
Take this class! It's really wonderful! Professor Benjamin is great and the assignments are fun!

Take this class! Professor Benjamin is excellent, and this class has been so beneficial to me as an international student coming in with only limited knowledge of race in America. Choose your preceptor wisely.
Take this course and change the world!
Take this course!! Literally so necessary for being a good citizen of this nation.

Take this course. Professor Benjamin is an amazing lecturer who will keep you very engaged during lecture. The course is a great way to learn more about the history of race in the U.S. for both people who have studied race in America before and those who have not.
Take this! One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Incredibly relevant
The readings may look like a lot (and they are) but they are so interesting that you will actually look forward to them. So do not let the course load deter you, even if you are a senior.

This class is phenomenal but just warning you, if you've taken any AAS class before, this will be pretty basic. Definitely didn't blow my mind as much as it is reputed to, but that's only because this wasn't the first time I've read about race etc.
This class is serious. The material is engaging but this class will really kick your butt. Make time to do the papers, you'll enjoy them more.

This course is phenomenal. Professor Benjamin is earnest, honest, and engaging. One of her goals is to get you to learn how to look at the world through a sociological lens, and her lectures--all of which involve active student participation--reflect that. Definitely take it!

This has been by far the best, the most important, and the most relevant class I've taken at Princeton. No matter who you are or what your background is, this class will force you to challenge your models and conceptions of society, and to question why you hold certain beliefs and certain perceptions. It presents you with the uncomfortable and truly leaves you a more aware and self-reflexive person.
This is a wonderful class. It will help you see race more clearly in the world, and give you tools for fighting it.
This is an incredible course!  Professor Benjamin is so elegant and eloquent and intelligent.  And the material of the course is so incredibly important and relevant.  Definitely take it.
Well-taught course. Challenges you to reevaluate your beliefs about race, and provides a great background for the current civil rights movement.
if the class interests you I would take it- be prepared for a good amount of reading.
just take this. eye opening and engaging
take it take it take it
descrip: The truism that "race is socially constructed" hides more than it reveals. Have Irish Americans always been white? Are people of African descent all black? Is calling Asian Americans a "model minority" a compliment? Does race impact who we date or marry? In this course, students develop a sophisticated conceptual toolkit to make sense of such contentious cases of racial vision and division as the uprising in Ferguson. We learn to connect contemporary events to historical processes, and individual experiences to institutional policies, exercising a sociological imagination with the potential to not only analyze, but transform the status quo.

title: Mythmakers, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Buddhist Art and Material Culture: The Virtues of Objects
reviews: Professor Huntington is stellar at responding to emails and helping with any questions! Great with extra help outside of class, including essay questions.
Take this course if you have some prior understanding of Buddhism.
The readings are challenging if not inaccessible.
descrip: When one understands the central role that art objects play in Buddhist ritual life, conceptions of 'art' and 'object' are fundamentally transformed. Such items are not passive collections of material, but active mechanisms in the complex world of lived religion. The course is organized around several major themes, including relics as quintessential objects, rituals for the consecration and deconsecration of constructed artworks, and interactions with images during daily rituals. Buddhist traditions from all across Asia are addressed, including those of India, Nepal, Tibet, China, Japan, Sri Lanka, and Thailand.

title: Bible Now: The Bible in Contemporary Israel
reviews: Definitely take Hebrew, it's a really amazing and thought provoking language (it is also the Holy language too)
prereqs: Successful complete of HEB 107 or equivalent, or instructor's approval..
descrip: For students with a solid grounding in Modern Hebrew. Develop proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Special attention to mastering complex grammatical structures, different registers, idiomatic expressions, and overall fluency. Enhance understanding of Israeli arts and letters by examining the manifold ways in which Biblical texts echo in contemporary Israeli cultural productions. Through texts, films, television serie and programs, popular songs, music videos and other contemporary media contents, become aware of the ongoing and constant dialogue between contemporary Israel and Biblical texts.

title: Field Methods in Linguistics
reviews: Definitely take this course! I not only learned a lot about linguistics, but I also feel like I grew a lot as a person and widened my worldview.
It is too bad Kyle is not going to be at Princeton next year. He has been one of the best professors I've had here!

Not sure when this class will be offered again, and no two classes will be the same because the consultant and language X will likely be different. If you like puzzling over languages, you'll find a field methods class interesting!
Probably won't be offered with the same instructor, but field methods generally is a fascinating topic! Really enjoyed this course.
Take it!!
This class is a lot of fun if you're interested in linguistics and learning about a different language.
descrip: In this course, students learn both the logistical components of doing field research as well as tools for conducting effective elicitations with native speakers, including background in linguistic typology and methods for elicitation. To develop these skills, approximately half of this course will be dedicated to linguistic elicitation with a native speaker of the language chosen for the semester. This course is designed to be beneficial to students interested in pursuing both documentary/descriptive linguistic work as well as those interested in incorporating linguistic data into research in theoretical linguistics.

title: Tonal Syntax
reviews: Challenging, but really helped me understand music better at large. Be prepared to spend lots of time on the weekly assignments.
Great class; be prepared to work at understanding what's going on.
Unless you are interested in composition for classical piano, there isn't a reason to take this course. Even music majors should not be required to take this at the expense of another music class.
Worth taking...but you have to take it if you're a music major anyway.
You into music deeply? Take it.
prereqs: MUS 205.
descrip: Counterpoint in the style of Johann Sebastian Bach.

title: 21st Century Latina/o Drama
descrip: See website

title: High Energy Astrophysics
descrip: Selected astrophysical applications of electrodynamics, special and general relativity, nuclear and particle physics. Topics may include synchrotron radiation, comptonization, orbits and accretion in black-hole metrics, radio sources, cosmic rays, and neutrino astropysics.

title: Roman Art
reviews: In terms of workload, this is a fairly chill endeavor.
It's a great course for anybody with an interest in ancient art.
Make sure to be at all of the lectures, they will develop how to approach viewing and analyzing art in a way that the readings will only touch on.
Not the most exciting course but Koortbojian is a great professor
Really delightful class.  Not too much effort, especially if you're sort of familiar with Classical art already.
Take this course if you enjoy viewing the art itself rather than taking into account the history of said art.
This is an awesome course, readings are very optional, you will learn a ton about Roman Art. Just make sure you go to lecture and precept and pay attention!

Very interesting course. It really encouraged me to consider that Roman art, and ancient art in general, can be much more interesting than one might think. Would recommend for those in the department or just looking to take an art history course.
descrip: The course provides a general introduction to Roman art. It discusses various artistic media--portraiture, historical relief, etc.--and highlights important works. The goal is an attempt to understand the significance of the imagery that the Romans produced, which embellished all aspects of their world - that is, to understand the role of artworks in the Romans' lived experience.

title: Moses and Jesus in the Islamic Tradition
descrip: The course will focus on the changing representations of the prophets Musa (Moses) and `Isa (Jesus) within the Islamic tradition. Course materials include readings in translation from the Qur'an, hadith, Sufi poetry, the popular "Tales of the Prophets" as well as modern Islamic texts on social justice, and novels. We will examine the ways in which these prophets, while recognized by Muslims as foundational figures in Christianity and Judaism, played and continue to play a prominent role, as monotheistic prophets and as religious examplars, in many diverse aspects of Islamic thought and practice.

title: Japan Anthropology in Historical Perspective
descrip: The course concerns Japan studies in the context of theories of capitalism, personhood, democracy, gender, and modernity. The thematic focus this term is on health and medicine as they intertwine with social and cultural processes. Topics include: cultural variability of diagnosis and bio-medical practices; how biotechnologies shape and are shaped by social relationships; the containment of medicalization by received notions of kinship, gender, and national identity; conceptions of life itself; and models of public health and the containment of harmful behavior. Reading selections include material on Japan, China, and India.

title: Portfolio Theory and Asset Management
reviews: Definitely take this class if Yogo is the professor.
prereqs: FIN 501 and FIN 522..
descrip: Covers a number of advanced topics related to asset management and asset pricing. Topics include mean-variance analysis, CAPM, APT, market efficiency, delegated money management, stock return predictability, bubbles and crashes, social interaction and investor behavior, security analysts and investor relations, and mutual fund performance and organization.

title: General Plasma Physics II
reviews: Required information for generals so....
This course is necessary for students who want to work on plasma physics.
This is a necessary course.

Very good course, but it is one that you really need to allocate the proper amount of time to, because a lot of material is covered. Nonetheless, I feel much more knowledgeable about the field of plasma physics after taking this course
descrip: This is an introductory graduate course in plasma physics, focusing on magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) and its extension to weakly collisional or collisionless plasmas. Topics to be covered include: the equations of MHD and extended MHD, the structure of magnetic fields, static and rotating MHD equilibria and their stability, magnetic reconnection, MHD turbulence, and the dynamo effect. Applications are drawn from fusion, heliophysical, and astrophysical plasmas.

title: Movements for Diversity in American Theater
reviews: A great course for those looking for work that is both engaging, critical, and often, hands on. Brian Herrera is exceedingly funny, provocative, and provides very critical class discussions. Material drawn from shows outside of class was also well-chosen, fun, and very relevant. Highly recommend!
Everyone should know about these issues and discuss them in this way. Additionally, there is not much work so there is more time to engage critically with the subject matter.

I would encourage anyone who is interested in the arts to take this class. I'm not personally a  member of any theater groups, but I did not feel out of place at all, since Professor Herrera works to ensure that everyone's on the same playing field when it comes to lingo, prior knowledge, etc. Since this was the first time he taught it, it wasn't super structured, which was great for me since some of my other classes were a bit tough this semester, but I'm not sure if it will remain that way the next time he teaches it. Either way, I recommend it - Professor Herrera is great!
Not sure if this course will be offered again, but I really enjoyed it and Professor Herrera is a fantastic professor!
TAKE IT, or any class with Prof. Herrera. Before he is a professor and brilliant academic, he is a phenomenal mentor and friend. He's so warm and always willing to help out or be present for you.
Take this course! Professor Herrera is amazing and I was lucky enough to take it was a bunch of other amazing students who really created thoughtful discussions in class.
be prepared to do activism work!
descrip: Theater artists routinely bend, twist and break all kinds of rules to create the imaginary worlds they bring to life on stage. Why, then, has the American theater so struggled to meaningfully address questions of equity, diversity and inclusion? In this course, we undertake a critical, creative and historical overview of agitation and advocacy by theater artist-activists aiming to transform American theatre-making as both industry and creative practice, as we connect those histories with the practices, structures and events determining the ways diversity is (and is not) a guiding principle of contemporary American theater.

title: Introduction to Movement and Dance
reviews: Aysnley is so fun, take the class!
Definitely take the class.
Definitely take this before you graduate! Very interesting
Enjoy the class
TAKE IT!!!!!!
Take it if you want to dance. Don't take this if your only goal is to get an easy P. Unwillingness to dance can make it a less beneficial class for everyone
Take this class, it's a lot of fun!
Take with Aynsley she's great
descrip: Designed for people with little or no previous training in dance, this class is a mixture of movement techniques, improvisation, choreography, observing, writing and discussing. Using tools from Laban Movement Analysis, students investigate their own movement patterns and delve into many facets of dance and the cultural questions surrounding it. We explore the role of dancer, choreographer, audience member, and critic in relation to such topics as aesthetic questions, politics, identity, religion, and complex views of the human body. We also look at movement and embodiment in our daily lives.

title: Molecular Evolution
reviews: Don't take this class unless you want an easy attempt at an A where you don't really retain much info.
Great class, 3 hour seminars can feel long, you get more out of the class if you do the readings
It is a good class to fulfill the EEB evolution requirement. Not a ton of work but definitely dense readings.
just participate. I think this was her last year teaching the class though...
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215, or CHM 236..
descrip: How and where did life evolve? This advanced seminar will discuss the evolution of the molecules that sustain life (DNA, RNA and proteins) at both the micro and macro evolutionary levels. We will explore the role of these molecules in the origin and continued evolution of life. Topics include the origin of eukaryotes and organelles, comparative genomics, the microbiome, and human evolution. One three-hour seminar. Note that students new to either evolution or genetics should take 309 instead.

title: In the Groove: Technology and Music in American History, From Edison to the iPod
reviews: Definitely take it if you are at all interested in music. I learned so much about the music industry and the mechanics of recording. Professor Thompson is an excellent lecturer, and both Professor Thompson and Dr. Regev are very accessible and respond to emails quickly. 10/10 would recommend.
Definitely take this if you are interested in music or history or both. Professor Thompson is great and the lectures and readings are interesting.

I highly recommend taking this course if you have an interest in records, music, the phonograph, or anything relating to the history of audio recordings. It covers everything from the business dictation machine to the early hip-hop artists of Jamaican sound systems. The lectures are interesting and incorporate audio samples and images to explain the history. My preceptor, Ronny Regev, posed a lot of thought-provoking questions relating the historical readings to our own lives. My only word of warning would be not to take the course if the material doesn't interest you, or if you are just interested in American history in general?this course is definitely specialized in its focus and does not cover much outside of phonograph/recoding history (which is admitedly quite a lot!!)
If it looks interesting to you, then take it. The beginning topics are a little boring

If you are already interested in music, this is a good course for you, but if not, I wouldn't say that this course would be particularly engaging if you are not already interested in its subject material.

TAKE THIS CLASS! This was seriously one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton (and I'm saying this as a senior, so that means a lot). The course topic is very interesting and relevant to modern day. Professor Thompson has such a great personality, and her lectures are always engaging and entertaining. There is a lot of reading, but since all of the texts are from the 20th century and beyond, they aren't archaic and are actually easy to read, unlike the readings of other history classes I've taken.

Take it if you have any interest in music! The material covered in the course really changes the way you think about how technology and music interplay in culture. Professor Thompson is great and knows what she's doing. That said, some of the material may seem a little too specific for general knowledge and applicability.
Take it. Easy class, decently interesting.
Take this course! You will learn so much about the history of music and also engage with cool historical artifacts. Thompson is a great professor. Highly recommend!

Take this course. It was an extremely interesting look at American history and Professor Thompson is really excited in the material and that excitement transfers well to her students. The readings may be a little on the heavy side though, but you can skim and get the main points of most of the readings and do fine.
descrip: When Thomas Edison invented the phonograph in 1877, no one, including Edison, knew what to do with the device. Over the next century Americans would engage in an ongoing dialogue with this talking machine, defining and redefining its purpose. This course will track that trajectory, from business tool to scientific instrument to music recorder to musical instrument. By listening to the history of the phonograph, and by examining the desires and experiences of phonograph users, students will perceive more generally the complex relationships that exist between a technology and the people who produce, consume, and transform it.

title: Latin: An Intensive Introduction
reviews: A TON OF WORK AND TIME NEEDED
Be ready to put in a lot of time.
Be ready to work a lot! A good class, but quite time consuming.

Definitely take it! It saves time over taking the year-long course. It is a bit time consuming but totally manageable if you do a little bit every day and don't get left behind. I recommend reading all the short stories, Sententiae Antiquae and Exercitationes, even if you don't get to them in class.

I would encourage students interested in Latin to definitely take this course. Being 5 days a week, it is truly modeled to encourage language acquisition. Being taught by Professor Kaster, you will get no better introduction to Latin.

Really tough, but also the most enjoyable language class I have taken at Princeton (this is the third language I have taken here). You can get by without doing *all* the work, but that said, it is a pretty big time commitment and it's well worth the investment!
Take it if you're interested in Latin. Definitely a ton of work, but it's worth it.
Take it!

Take take take! The workload is about the same as Greek 101, even though this is an accelerated course, and is definitely manageable. Latin is an extremely useful language for almost every field in the humanities, and even if you don't continue on to 105, you will not regret having learned the basics of the language.

Take this if you really want to become proficient in Latin very quickly. I am amazed at how much I learned during the semester considering I came in with no Latin whatsoever, but I did have to bust my butt just to get by on the quizzes and exams. The quizzes are no joke and you need a lot of stamina and commitment to get through a quiz every Monday at 9 AM. This class will also drastically improve your English grammar and think about language in a level of detail that I definitely didn't before. If you're prepared to commit, this class will be a great experience!
The course is well-designed and excellently-taught, but one has to be prepared for the fast pace of progress.

This class is excellently taught, but only take it if you have time. It is difficult and time consuming. You will probably get a firmer grasp of concepts by doing LAT 101-102 instead of 103, but if you think you're up for the challenge, it is very well taught.
This course is very intense and very hard. There are two to three hours a night of intense studying.
This is an excellent class and I would recommend taking this class if you're at all interested in Latin and/or the Romans.
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to the Latin language: LAT 103 covers the material of LAT 101-102 in a shorter time through increased class time. Students completing the course will be prepared to take LAT 105.

title: Physics of Plasma Propulsion
descrip: Focus of this course is on fundamental processes in plasma thrusters for spacecraft propulsion with emphasis on recent research findings. Start with a review of the fundamentals of mass, momentum & energy transport in collisional plasmas, wall effects, & collective (wave) effects, & derive a generalized Ohm's law useful for discussing various plasma thruster concepts. Move to detailed discussions of the acceleration & dissipation mechanisms in Hall thrusters, magnetoplasmadynamic thrusters, pulsed plasma thrusters, & inductive plasma thrusters, & derive expressions for the propulsive efficiencies of each of these concepts.

title: Topics in Modern Italian Cinema - New Italian Cinema: New Media (in English)
reviews: Definitely take this course! The quality of teaching of Professor Marrone-Puglia, Professor Riotta, and Professor Dossena is exceptional, and the lectures and precepts are both fun and engaging. You will learn a lot and enjoy the course while doing so!

Great course to take, if any interest in Italian culture or cinema in general. I took it as an intro to cinema, and loved it! Great senior spring class, too, or anytime. I only wished i had taken it earlier, for many reasons! Riotta is incredible, and so is Marrone-Puglia. Guest lecturers/Princeton film festival in spring is incredible 2!
Low pressure 300-level class
Take this if you're into Italian politics. Don't take it for the cinema
This course is fun and interesting!  Papers are very open-ended, which can make it  a little difficult to choose topics to write about, but gives a lot of creative freedom.

This is an amazing course. You should take it if you're interested in film or modern Italian/world history.  The teachers are all fascinating, kind people, and you learn a lot without having to do too much work.
prereqs: No knowledge of Italian is required to enroll. Course open to freshmen. Precept P99 is in Italian..
descrip: This course looks at the way Italy has expressed its cultural, political, and social individuality in major cinematic works from 1968 to the present. Directors such as Bertolucci, Moretti, Tornatore, Ozpetek, and Benigni offer a panorama of a generation of filmmakers that has contributed to the renewal of Italian cinema. Topics will be drawn from current issues, and will include the Holocaust and questions of memory, terrorism, political violence, migration, gender ideologies, the Mafia. Emphasis on film style and techniques.

title: Advanced Electromagnetism
reviews:
A very disappointing aspect of this class is how little Romalis seems to care.  Lectures are useless and TA's don't help with anything.  He doesn't even respond to emails and will never help you with anything, even if it's just about logistics.

This class can make students feel cornered and alone.  I expect to well in the class, but I stopped going to lectures because they were so bad and just read the textbook; this is generally enough.  The class could be much better if taught by a different professor.  If Romalis is still teaching it, skip it if you have the option.
Any physics majors should definitely take this class as early as possible. As for non-physics majors, unless one has an active interest in classical physics, this course has little to offer.
Do lots of practice problems for exams.
Don't take it unless you have to.
I would encourage students to remain up-to-date with their readings and to attend Prof. Romalis' weekly office hours.

If you are a physics major, you have to take this! If you're not, but you're interested in E&M, PHY 304 is a great choice! It can be a fair amount of work, but very manageable (especially for anyone who has taken PHY 205, this course takes less time).

If you're a physics major, you probably will need to take this course. It's not my favorite physics course, partially because the subject isn't that interesting to me. But I encourage you to go into this class with a positive attitude because spending a semester working with fields and EM stuff will really help to strengthen many important fundamental skills you will need as a physicist. So, take advantage of this opportunity to learn even if the class is difficult and the professor isn't too great.

If you're taking this class then its probably for a departmental. Have a studying strategy especially if you can't follow lectures or find them confusing. The textbook is excellent to self-study from and the psets are valuable!
It is a quite good course. Prof. Romalis is very nice during office hours and the exams are reasonable
Only take this if you have to. Not at all enjoyable. Romalis does not have a good lecture style.
Romalis sucks in lecture, but he's really helpful one-on-one. Take advantage of that.
Standard course. Pretty good; it'll teach good things.
Take it if you want to take it.
This class is on the same level as the other 300 level physics class, so expect a decent amount of work.
This course is difficult and moves quickly -- covering basically all of Griffiths' text. Don't get behind and work with friends on the problem sets. Lectures are basically just reinforcing the text.

This is a challenging course. Exams can be difficult depending on how well you can recognize the right approach to a new problem, psets are about what you'd expect from a 300-level physics class. Romalis isn't great, but he's reasonable and is helpful if you go to him one-on-one.
Truly painful.

Well, if you are taking this class, you probably are required to take this class.

It is a great comprehensive look into Maxwell's equations as they apply to problems in general, going very deep into the classical theory. I would even recommend Electrical Engineers to take this course, as it is enlightening to see the physics behind the circuits.

Work hard and try to study well early on to make the most out of it. It's a tough class with cool material and really difficult problem sets, but when you become able to identify each problem you'll have a much better time with it. Prof. Romalis is friendly and approachable, so don't hesitate to ask him.
You're likely thinking of taking this course because you have to as a department. If you do have to - good luck. If you don't have to - don't take this.
prereqs: PHY 104 or PHY 106 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Electromagnetic theory based on Maxwell's equations. Electrostatics, including boundary valve problems, dielectrics, and energy considerations leading to the Maxwell stress tensor. Magnetostatics and simple magnetic materials. Electromagnetic waves, retarded potentials and radiation. Familiarity with vector calculus is assumed.
