title: Graphic Design
reviews:
Absolutely loved this class. It has a strong focus on Typography, so might not be everyone's cup of tea. 
Can be time consuming too. But I think it really changes the way one looks at things.

Alice is a great instructor who clearly has a lot of experience practicing what she teaches. If you think you have some interest in graphic design (especially typography) definitely think about taking this course. It is a decent time commitment though, so if you want to actually get the most out of this course keep in mind that you can't treat it as a secondary class.
I would take this course if you're really interested in typography and layout (work a lot with indesign). If you're looking to learn about adobe photoshop or illustrator, this is not the place.

It's a great course, but it can be VERY time-consuming because you will be working on several projects simultaneously for pretty much the entire semester. As the other reviews note, the course has a lot to do with typography. You get to spend a few days at the letterpress setting your own type, which is pretty neat.

TAKE IT! But don't expect an easy A - it's a ton of work and Alice really pushes you to think critically. I find that the quality of your work depends a lot on the quality of the students in the class since the entire class is critique based. Warning - this class is 90% typography not general graphic design
Take this class if you want to know more about typography and are interested in design.
This class is extremely time-intensive, but you will learn a lot - definitely take it if you are interested in typography.
descrip: This studio course will introduce students to the essential aspects and skills of graphic design, and will analyze and discuss the increasingly vital role that non-verbal, graphic information plays in all areas of professional life, from fine art and book design to social networking and the Internet. Students in the course will explore visual organization through a series of focused, interrelated assignments dealing with composition, page layout, type design, and image. Hands on production will include an array of do-it-yourself printing and distribution technologies, from letterpress and mimeograph to photocopying and websites.

title: The Ancient Egyptian Body
reviews: If you have a genuine interest in Egyptian art or archaeology, definitely take this course.
Take it if you even have a slight interest in Egyptian art. Professor Vischak is great and she will make you have a deep understanding and appreciation of the realm of ancient Egyptian art.
Take it if you're interested in the topic because it's fun.

Take it! Whether younhave an interest in the topic or just want to fulfill a distribution, you won't regret taking it. Prof. Vischak is amazing. The workload is pretty much just a couple readings a week   a final paper   a take home. No midterm.

Very interesting course. Would strongly recommend.  Take home is a hard, so don't let it blindside you.  Start it as soon as you get it, as it will take you the majority of the three days (assuming you get full nights of sleep).
descrip: In this course we will examine ancient Egyptian art and architecture (primarily from the pharaonic period, c. 3000 BCE to c. 1000 BCE) using the body as a visual and conceptual theme. Utilizing art historical and archaeological methods, we will analyze sculpture, relief, painting, drawing, and architecture, as well as objects used to adorn and encase bodies both living and dead, emphasizing the context and interrelationships of these materials as they relate to the body and the corporeality of Egyptian society and culture.

title: Environmental Chemistry of Soils
reviews: If you are interested in contamination in soils and sediments, this course would be a good choice.
Satish is great. It's tough to find structure in the course second half of the semester, but it's all generally interesting stuff.
Take the class if you like dirt.
Take this course! Professor Myneni is a great professor and you will learn a lot in the course.
This course is tough, but ultimately very rewarding. Ask a lot of questions to check your understanding.
This is an excellent course for anyone interested in soil chemistry and the fate of pollutants in the environment. Would highly recommend.
prereqs: Prerequisites: CHM 331, or any other basic chemistry course..
descrip: Focuses on the inorganic and organic constituents of aqueous, solid, and gaseous phases of soils, and fundamental chemical principles and processes governing the reactions between different constituents. The role of soil chemical processes in the major and trace element cycles, and the biogeochemical transformation of different soil contaminants will be discussed in the later parts of the course.

title: Dynamical Systems
prereqs: For advanced level Juniors and Seniors. Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will discuss new Variational Methods for the study of Hamiltonian Dynamical Systems, with a view of obtaining results about Arnold Diffusion.

title: Seminar in American Politics - American Political Development
descrip: The study of American political development provides a vehicle for exploring how American democracy has come to assume its present form. It emphasizes the intersection between institutional incentives, institutional and "state" development, and political agency. This course will examine what we mean by a "state," and how institutional "development" provides a set of analytically distinctive problems for political actors. This class will seek to identify historical patterns, engage literature that seeks to explain political outcomes over time, and address questions about methodology and evidence.

title: Molecular Spectroscopy
reviews: Come in with an idea of what you want to learn and relay it to the professors. They want to teach you something that you will find useful for your work or research.
If this course is being taught by Scholes, it will be time-consuming regardless of your background. This course isn't a waste of time.
descrip: A survey of modern photophysics and experimental methods at the forefront of the field. Topics covered include energy/electron transfer, line broadening and its implications for chemical dynamics, nonlinear optical spectroscopy, and single molecule spectroscopy.

title: Topics in Ancient History - Athenian Democracy and Its Critics
reviews: I know it's technically open to non-Classics majors, but you're going to want a solid foundation of Greek History. If you apply yourself you will definitely learn something, and any Domingo course is worth taking!
ITs a cool class. Not too much work but still stay engaged with the class

Since it is a 300 level seminar there is a fair amount of reading.  Necessary to do the readings because that is what the 3 hour discussion will be about.  Professor Domingo is wonderful at leading discussion and getting the students stimulated.
TAKE THIS CLASS - THE PROFESSOR IS WONDERFUL
descrip: This course will examine the origins, evolution and organization of the democratic system in Athens, and address some of the most controversial questions about the topic: To what extent was Athens democratic? What were the links between Athenian democracy and its aggressive imperialism? What are the similarities and differences between ancient and modern ideas of democracy?

title: Neuroimmunology: Immune Molecules in Normal Brain Function and Neuropathology
reviews: An interesting course--a great chance to get practice reading scientific articles and generally engaging.
Class is entirely student presentations - this works very well when the students are prepared, other times not so much.
Definitely take it, but only if you are interested in the material. Otherwise it is much too detailed.

I strongly recommend this course! Professor Boulanger is a great person and puts a lot of heart into teaching this course. As long as you put time and thought into reading the papers, this course will make you a stronger scholar with a greater love for academic research.
Strongly recommend.

Take it! Start the readings early to give yourself plenty of time to read them. It is talking about papers for 3 hours, based on student presentations, and some definitely present better than others. Dr. Boulanger is phenomenal. You will learn a lot about how to analyze and critique scientific papers and judge the validity of the science.

Take it!! What a great course to learn about the brain, immune system, and about critical analysis of science. Probably one of my favorite at Princeton so far. Start the final paper early! Be warned: the style is student presentations for 3 hours so if you have bad lecturers its hard to pay attention. However,  Professor Boulanger frequently interrupts with little comments and thoughts, and she will really make you think twice about the science you just read. Highly, highly recommend this course.
Take this class! Fascinating and not too much work
Take this class! Read every week and do a thoughtful critique, and then participate in class. There is a lot to learn if you listen. It's not too hard if you have background in neuroscience and MOL.
This course is extremely interesting and has matured my analytical skills towards primary scientific literature. The environment is encouraging and receptive to all questions.
This course will definitely improve your primary article reading skills. Definitely would recommend!

This has been my favorite class in three years at Princeton. It finds the perfect balance between being engaging yet accessible. The work is interesting and rewarding and never overwhelming. The process of making a 3-hour partner presentation is not nearly as intimidating as it sounds. Dr. B makes it very doable and not stressful whatsoever. She is without a doubt one of the best professors I've had. She finds the right balance between providing interesting insights into the field without overwhelming students with information. This is a must-take class if you are MOL or NEU or if you even have a passing interest in either field. The information is entirely accessible if you have taken MOL 214 so don't be scared off just because it's listed as a 400-level MOL seminar. This is the first class I've taken where I wish it met again over reading period just so that I could learn more about the topic. Not sure what I can add to convince you to take this, but know this is one of the best courses offered at Princeton and will make you a better scientist. Reading primary literature critically is now a breeze thanks to this course.
prereqs: MOL 214 / EEB 214 (Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology)..
descrip: In this course, we will explore the diverse and complex interactions between the brain and the immune system, from the perspective of current, cutting-edge research papers. In particular, we will focus on the molecular mechanisms of these interactions, their role in normal brain development and function, and their potential contributions to neurological disorders including autism. In the process, students will learn to read, critically evaluate, and explain (in written and oral form) the content of articles from the primary literature.

title: Planning Theory and Process
descrip: Introduction to the theory and practice of planning. Analysis and discussion are devoted to planning models, planning decisions, and alternative planning roles. Focused study of comprehensive and strategic planning, community participation, new urbanism concepts, equity concerns, and planning at local, regional, and state levels.

title: Race and Politics in the Age of Obama
reviews: I would not take this course. An easy A but I did not feel like I was challenged and did not think the environment was healthy as it was very intimidating to offer opinions.
I would recommend that the person not hesitate to participate in precepts on issues that may be sensitive. Professor Stephens was good at being objective.

I would say that if you're interested in AAS and POL then go for it. Definitely won't hurt. I wouldn't call this a must-take class but there are definitely concepts of which are interesting to learn and discuss. It is also nice that the class is relatively small so you have a chance to express your thoughts in both lecture and precept.
Take it! This class covers concepts, ideas, and issues that happening in real-time in our country.
Take this course if you need an easier class that is still pretty interesting. Take good notes in class.

This course is a standard amount of work and even the readings, to me, didn't feel like a chore but offered a lot of interesting information.  Professor Stephens will challenge you with her grading and assignments, and it's worth it.

This course is incredibly important and can help you become a better-informed American citizen. I think if you don't take this class, you should at the very least take a related class on race and its intersection with politics/public policy in America. This course transformed the way I conceptualize a just American society and helped me understand the need for liberal racial policy to redress years of institutional oppression endured by minorities.

Take the class, or something similar.
descrip: This course examines various political controversies that surround the role of race in American society. These controversies and issues affect public opinion, political institutions, political behavior, and salient public policy debates. Thus this course will assess and evaluate the role of race in each of these domains while also examining this historical antecedents. Special attention will be devoted to the nature of contemporary racial attitudes, given the election of the nation's first black president.

title: Laboratory in Principles of Neuroscience
reviews: I highly recommend taking this course, doing the readings, and coming up with your own independent project based on the animals you dissected in class. I found it to be the most rewarding class that I've taken here at Princeton.
It's a pretty good, well-designed course ? you'll learn a lot about experimental techniques in neuroscience. Take it! (but you'll probably have to anyway)

Really cool experiments that you can brag to your friends about. I like the assignments, but grading felt very arbitrary. I often felt that I put in about twice as much time and effort as my colleagues only to receive a lower grade with very little indication as to how I could improve in the future. I never knew exactly how much work I needed to put into data analysis. I put in a ton of effort but there wasn't really a direct correlation between my effort and the grade I received. This made an otherwise great course somewhat frustrating
Really recommend this course for all students interested in lab work. The equipment is top notch and the instructors really helpful. During the whole course the students are very independent.
TAKE ITTTT - you'll enjoy most of the labs and become invested in what you are doing there. In other words, you won't just be going to class for a grade or to get info.
Take it if you have to.

Take it! If you are a science major, the skill sets you will learn in this lab course will prove invaluable to conducting independent work moving forward. Even if you are not, this course will help you better understand the valuable history of neuroscience as well as the way in which science is conducted beyond lectures and textbooks.
Take it! Whether you have to or not, it is very interesting, very enjoyable, and Alan's bits of cultural wisdom are always entertaining.
Take this class after taking NEU 301 because that knowledge will assist you with having more thorough conclusions to draw from your figures, etc.

The labs are not too difficult and Anthony helps out a lot if you have any questions. Thankfully there are no tests and you just need to complete lab figures and lab reports which are relatively simple.
This class can be frustrating. Data collection is hard.
This is a less stressful course than it seems. If you don't get data in lab you can get from others and the figures do not have to be too intense. It is a lot of time even out of class and lab.
This is a very nice lab course which will give you first experiences with electrophysiological methods. The workload seemed quite appropriate to me.
Try to take it sophomore year before you join a lab!
You have to take it, but you'll be glad you did.
You will grow a lot as a scientist in this course as long as you take the time to be creative in the questions you ask as well as rigorous in the statements you make on figures and reports.
hang in there bud, anthony and gelperin are nice

take this class! it's a fun lab and so many cool dissections. taking data can be frustrating but also really satisfying. the final project is likewise a bit frustrating but so cool to actually see your own independent results
prereqs: Course open to students completing requirements for the Neuroscience Major, Neuroscience Certificate and other students with the permission of the Instructor..
descrip: This course is designed to introduce undergraduate students to modern methods of analysis applied to single neurons, the synaptic connections between neurons and the dynamics of networks of neurons underlying learning and decision making. The course will include mammalian cellular and system neuroanatomy and the influence of experience on the production of new neurons. Students will learn modern methods of microscopy and the application of optogenetic approaches to analysis of neuronal function. Basic neuroscience concepts will be studied using both invertebrate and mammalian CNS preparations.

title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation II
reviews: Definitely take this class if you want to continue Russian.
I would recommend finding a quiet place to practice Russian aloud. It was very helpful for classtime.
Take it. Your russian will improve and the content is more interesting that RUS 207
The class requires a decent amount of time commitment for daily homework and practice, but it's a good and interesting class for learning and practicing Russian language, discussion and culture.
The day-to-day homeworks and tests take more time than expected
This course was good because we studied 20th century Russian poets. But I felt that the pace of language study was very slow.
prereqs: RUS 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 207. Discussion of some samples of 20th-century poetry and the poets' biographies; review of selected grammar topics; work with two movies.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: I'd try to read any kind of literature that relates to the course as a theoretical background, as well as looking at previous projects produced by other studios. Representation is a special topic in this studio, so I'd pay close attention to instruments and tools needed to experiment with this.
i think the studio is incredibly useful for the thesis preparation as you are able to find a topic that could be very interesting for you to develop later on.
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architectural design in the intersection of materiality, technology, sociality and politics; taking into account its capacity to rearticulate physical environments and social organizations. Projects are intended to explore the role of architectural apparatus to intervene daily urban enactments, by the development of a broad range of architectural devices: including buildings, urban districts, landscape and the interactions that bring them all into shared performances.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem in civil and environmental engineering. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a two-semester study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Beginner's Spanish II
reviews: Anais is the BEST professor, take it with her! She's energetic, funny, and amazing.
Anais is the best instructor!
Anna is super friendly and helpful. No complaints.
Basically the same kind of class as Spanish 101.
Be engaged in class

Be prepared to use a lot of time outside of class to improve your language skills. But aside from that, this course is fun and interesting. Your foreign language classmates will be some of your closest friends and you will work closely with the professors. Don't be afraid to be behind or incorrect in your language use; just be open to learning at all times and you will see vast improvements.
Definitely get into the section with Anais

Do not fall behind - it will be very hard to catch up. Review your stuff from 101 and actually do the everyday readings. Keep up to date and start studying for the exams early. Squeezing in at least 20 mins of Spanish everyday can be very helpful.
Do the book work it helps to learn the language easier

Do the homework and review your notes everyday to avoid putting yourself in a hole in the future. Speak up as much as possible in class to boost your class participation grade and help out with your speaking skills which are critical for some of the projects.
Don't fall too far behind.
Engage in class constantly.
Get Anais!!
Good class to take if you are interested in Spanish or need to fulfill your language requirement in general.
Great fun, gentle intro into Spanish. Expect the course load to pick up a bit from Spa 101 but very manageable.
Great opportunity to really learn Spanish
Hands down the best teacher who teaches Spanish 102.
Have fun with the class and be sure to read the book.
Highly recommend taking Professor Zetterstrand's section of the course
I think the course is great. Very engaging and it helps you really start to develop your skills.

I would definitely recommend taking Spanish. It's a very important language, especially for Americans. College is a really intensive important class to learn it in. This class is a great opportunity for that.
I would definitely take the course. It is a decent amount of work but your language skills will definitely improve.
I would highly recommend the Spanish department to anyone interested. It fostered an interest for the language and culture in me that I would never had guessed I would have.
I would really recommend taking this class if you are interested in Spanish! I learned a lot in just one semester.
If at all possible take this class with Adriana Merino.  It is a good way to learn spanish or work towards fulfilling the language requirement.
If you are taking this course and have a different instructor, I am sorry that you are missing out
If you don't understand something, always email your professor. They're always willing to help.

If you treat this course as a requirement, it will obviously seem difficult, but if you are motivated by a wish to learn a new language and appreciate a different culture, then you will enjoy every bit of it
It's everyday but not to time consuming. I recommend taking with Anna
It's required after 101. So yeah.
It's required. Do the assignments, practice out of class every now and then, and you'll notice a big improvement.
Just Spanish.
Just study a bit every day or else it will become overwhelming VERY QUICKLY.
Le Anne is a really nice and funny teacher, try to see if you can get her as a lecturer.
Learn vocab before class Stay engaged and participate.
Make sure to get Adriana Merino as your instructor, she is really fun!
Make sure to spend ample time outside of class to review vocabulary and grammar in order to keep up with the pace of the course.
Please get Luis if you can. He teaches Spanish that is actually useful in the real world, not just in a classroom or on an exam.
Put in the necessary work and you'll be more than fine.
Read the textbook ahead as that is key to understanding the class
Standard language class here at Princeton - very enjoyable with a steep learning curve. Take this with professor Merino if possible!
Study the vocabulary and grammar in the context of speaking and writing. It will help improve these skills, and make learning the language much easier and more fun!
Study vocal daily
TAKE THIS COURSE WITH ANAIS

Take each accion assignment as a practice exam for the test and quizes. Log your difficulty so you can save these questions for class and leverage the style of the class. Professors in the languages want you to excel and do well.
Take it with the right professor and with the right attitude.
Take it!
Take this class with Professor Lage! She is amazing!
Take this course!
There's nothing I can really say pertaining to how other students can pass besides doing the work and regularly studying.
This course is engaging, fast paced, and rigorous but noticeably improved my language skills in just one semester. Definitely a lot more engaging/interesting than SPA 101.
This course takes up a lot of time but is really worthwhile.
This course will further enhance your ability to speak, write, and read Spanish.

Try to get Anna Alsina Naudi as your professor, she's great and a very fair grader. Also, in general, be prepared to do some homework every day and complete group assignments and presentations. This class will be fine if you keep up and put a little effort into it.
Try to remember vocab words as you learn them in class.
absolutely take this class with Anna. she is the coolest and bestest
amazing
get work done ahead of time!
none
put in the work for all the homework and presentations and you will be fine! Great way to learn spanish!
she was super nice and helpful
yeah can take it. a lot of work
prereqs: SPA 101. No credit given for SPA 101 unless followed by SPA 102..
descrip: The second course in the elementary Spanish sequence for students with little or no previous knowledge of the language. With its emphasis on the four basic skills (speaking, writing, reading, and listening), SPA 102 continues to provide students with the linguistic, communicative and cultural foundations to engage in basic daily life interactions in Spanish. Hispanic cultures are introduced through a variety of texts, including readings, music, art, video clips, and film. All of these sources provide the basis for classroom activities.

title: Drug Discovery: From Snake Venoms to Medicines
descrip: See website

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Poverty and Public Policy
descrip: This seminar will provide a survey of trends in U.S. poverty and how public policy has responded over time. Examines the range of benefits and services that comprise the social safety net, including refundable tax credits, housing subsidies, nutrition programs, cash assistance, and Social Security benefits. Also reviews past and current debates over the effectiveness of these programs, with a particular focus on welfare reform. Assignments are designed to provide students with practical experience in how to present ideas to policymakers and a broader public audience.

title: Molecular Modeling Methods
reviews: A nice course.
Definitely an interesting class. The Psets will take a fair bit of time and often require using computers in the Equad. Some thermo/quantuum background will be very useful

Great class! If this is ever offered again and you have any inkling of being interested in modeling, I would highly recommend this class. It is a relatively small workload and the material is very different from anything you have previously experienced.
Great course, take it

Great elective! Super cool to see how COS and CBE intersect and I thoroughly enjoyed how this class is set up. You are taught a lot of things in lecture but are only asked to do the more fundamental things for psets. As a result, this class is pretty low stress but you still have access to explore more advanced material if you find yourself interested. TAKE IT.

I came into this class expecting to do more programming/modeling, but the focus is more on theory (though there are aspects of both). At times the material is quite difficult, and it feels as if you need to know all of quantum/thermo/etc. in order to fully understand what is being taught. However, the problem sets are very manageable despite the difficulty of the lectures. Overall, I thought the class was instructive and enjoyable, and I would recommend it.

If you do not understand something, be sure to reach out to the AI. The AI for my semester was extremely helpful and flexible with meeting times and made things much more understandable if you weren't able to understand the concepts from the notes. Otherwise, give yourself enough time to get the work done. This involves giving yourself enough time to figure out applications you've never use before--HyperChem--and doing calculations within these applications.
If you're interested in computational modeling, take this class! Problem sets are reasonable in length, and teach the material well.
The best CBE class I've taken so far!

The more background knowledge you have of physical chemistry, the more you will take away from the course. But the course is designed so that everybody will learn something, and the assignments are geared that way. Overall it's a good course: Prof. Thanos is a great lecturer and Joey, the TA, was very helpful for students who asked for it.

This course provides a clear and concise introduction to a variety of computation methods of study. The material coverage is fairly broad with respect to the modeling topics covered, and basic background is provided to facilitate understanding. This course is introductory and thus those with experience may have repetition of material, but the application of the material in the homework and project is useful nonetheless.

This is a good class if you're looking for a not too hard distribution. As someone who's never even been exposed to molecular modeling, I really learned a lot. Professor Thanos understands that his students come from different backgrounds and tries to explain all the concepts from the very basics, but even then, some of the math went over my head. The psets were reasonable and we had a super awesome AI but would still recommend working in groups.

This is a great class for someone interested how to apply computer science to chemistry. I would suggest reading up on some elementary quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics so that you can follow the lectures more easily. Professor Panagiotopoulos lectures well and is also very helpful over email.

This is a great upper-level CBE course. Not too much work, and very applicable. Thanos really cared about his students learning. Sometimes I felt lost during lectures since Thanos delved deeply into quantum in lectures, but then the way we needed to know them for the problem sets was minimal.
This is a really interesting and well-taught survey of molecular modeling methods! The material can be pretty difficult but the problem sets are really reasonable and the TA is super helpful.
prereqs: COS 126 or equivalent, and MAE 305 or equivalent..
descrip: This course offers an introduction to computational chemistry and molecular simulation methods. Computational chemistry involves using quantum mechanical models to obtain the electronic structure of atoms and molecules. Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics methods use input from quantum chemistry and empirical potentials to obtain equilibrium and non-equilibrium properties of fluids and materials. As computer power continues its exponential growth, these methods find increasing applications in engineering, chemistry, physics and biology.

title: Questioning Post-Medium Specificity in Architecture
reviews: Don't waste your time. You may think that Michael is "super cool" but you will not get anything out of this course. The few times that something intelligent spewed out of Michael's mouth were not worthwhile compared to the vapid, rambling, unfocused stream of consciousness that was the rest of the course. I highly recommend not taking this course.
I would encourage other students to begin working on the production of their objects as soon as possible so that they can develop through actual trials.

The framework(s) of the course and the potentials for producing work far exceed the classroom environment, which can be inattentive at best and entirely distracted at worst, given the wrong group of students.
i would highly recommend the class for students who wants to start a small practice
descrip: This course explores post-medium specificity in architecture and the potential consequences for architectural thinking (a.k.a. the quote-unquote discipline) through representation. This is a design seminar with an emphasis on experimentation and the integration of diverse analytical methods. The results are hardly predictable. The format of the course will combine a seminar and design workshop - our readings/discussion are in the service of hands-on experimentation.

title: Digital, Spatial, Visual, and Oral Histories
descrip: The course focuses on digital history as a way to integrate different unconventional and conventional sources and approaches especially oral, spatial (maps), images (photos) and netbased data. Digital history allows for the combination of, for example, spatial history (through the use of Geographic Information Systems or GIS) with oral history in a single multi-dimensional, multimedia, and interactive platform (a blog or webpage). Oral history can be used to recapture the history of individuals, groups, and phenomena that conventional written sources (written by the elite) have erased.

title: Bioethics: Clinical and Population-Level
reviews: For those even remotely interested in the topic, this is a fantastic course! I went in without any prior experience with the topic, and I found the course extremely engaging. Professor Frick is a great and approachable professor. He comes to class extremely prepared, and he pushes each student to contribute and expand their thinking. Definitely take this course if you have the chance!

TAKE IT. It's fascinating topics, and there's a bit of everything for everyone: medicine, public policy, personal identity, etc. etc. And really, you get to think about vaster philosophical issues by discussing these specific questions. If you love moral philosophy or are simply looking for trying out philosophy, go with this. You don't need prior experience, Professor Frick is amazing and keeps in mind that some people haven't done this kind of things before, and the workload is definitely manageable.
Take this course. It'll challenge your views, whatever they might be, and it'll introduce you to a new way of thinking through bioethical dilemmas.

The course description is somewhat misleading. I thought it would be a little more policy-centered, so it wasn't quite what I was looking for. The class really depends on the students and how much they participate. Content is interesting but heavier on the philosophical problems in theory/the abstract than in application for the first 2/3 of the class. Prof. Frick is very supportive though!

This is a difficult course but SO worth it. Originally had only taken it for my certificate program but the discussions in class and Prof. Frick's knowledge and wisdom is inspiring. I learned so much about relative population and bioethical issues that inform my understanding of what's going on in the world today and the real ethical dilemmas many doctors and scientists face.

This is a really good (albeit challenging and involved) philosophy seminar class! Prof. Frick was such an attentive, well-prepared and thorough instructor. I have never been in a more effectively structured and content-rich seminar as Prof. Frick's. Prof. Frick really cares about making each class as meaningful and effective as possible, so he consistently asked us for feedback. He tried really hard to make sure each of us participated actively in the course and got as much out of it as possible in terms of both philosophical knowledge and applications to our other areas of study and life. Assignments were fair and not overwhelming in number, albeit challenging and thought-provoking! Not an easy class, but very meaningful and worthwhile!
This is a serious philosophy course and is not advisable for students with minimal prior experience in philosophy courses.

This is such a great course if you're interested in philosophy and medical ethics! It really challenges some of your intuitions on pertinent topics. Anyone planning on going into the healthcare sector would be missing out if they did not take this class.
descrip: This seminar aims to introduce students to a range of philosophical debates in clinical and population-level bioethics. Among the topics in clinical bioethics that we may discuss are physician-assisted suicide and euthanasia; abortion; and the ethics of genetic enhancement. In population-level bioethics, questions we may discuss include the definition and measurement of health; cost-effectiveness and disability-discrimination; the significance of health inequalities; personal and social responsibility for health; treatment vs prevention in the fight against HIV/AIDS; and standards of care in clinical trials in the US and abroad.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Modern Brazilian Literature and Culture
prereqs: POR 208 or POR 207S or instructor's permission..
descrip: Brazilian Amazonia is one of the richest areas in the world today. This course intends to explore the past of this region in a global perspective. It analyzes its birth in the 16th century in the context of Spain and the Spanish Empire; its involvement in 17th century international conflicts (the War of 30 Years); and its role in Atlantic and transoceanic history. Letters by Jesuit Antonio Vieira, one of the most significant writers in Baroque Europe, and the music of Carlos Gomes, the greatest Latin-American opera composer in the 19th century, will help us to imagine and write a global history of this fascinating part of the world.

title: Introduction to Graph Theory
reviews: GREAT COURSE IF YOU HAVE ANY INTEREST IN GRAPH THEORY
Highly recommend, Prof Seymour is great.

I think that I can generally determine the quality of a math course by the ration of how much I learned to how much it seemed like I was learning, and I probably learned more in this class than in any other one this semester, even though it always seemed easy.

I usually started problem sets the day before they were due and they took about six hours, but they do get harder later on in the course. Go to lecture! Seymour gives you graph theory intuition that is hard to develop elsewhere.
If you are not a math major, make sure you have a strong understanding of proofs before starting the course.

If you're feeling the graph life, then you should take this course. Seymour's a graph legend, drawing (V,E) since the day he was born, but his lectures require you to pay major attention during class. Also, a lot of people say the problem sets aren't hard: not sure what they've been doing this semester. The beginning few are mad easy, but they pick up VERY quickly after second half of the semester. Overall, take the class if you're into detail-oriented proofs and graphs; otherwise, I'd given this a solid pass.
Not as much COS application as I thought there would be but concepts and ideas still interesting.

Professor Seymour is THE Original Graph Theory Dude?; a couple clicks from the Graph Theory wikipedia page gets you to his almost instantly. It's insane how much he's done for this field, and the best lectures are the ones where he gets to talk about the proofs behind The Big Theorems. Oh, and go to Office Hours if you can!
Take it if you're interested. There's weekly problem sets so the workload is quite balanced throughout the semester.
Take this class if you like learning how to think
Take this course, it is relatively light compared to the material
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204 or 217 or equivalent..
descrip: The fundamental theorems and algorithms of graph theory. Topics include: connectivity, matchings, graph coloring, planarity, the four-color theorem, extremal problems, network flows, and related algorithms.

title: Modern Latin American History Since 1810
descrip: Course examines interactions between states and citizens since Latin American independence with an additional consideration of the region's integration into global economic and political systems.

title: Advanced Persian: Iran through Film
reviews: Great class!  The film selection is really interesting and class discussions will help your speaking ability a lot!
I recommend students take this class if they want to improve their speaking, writing and listening skills, and if they want to gain a greater appreciation for Persian language and culture.
If you've already taken Persian, you know how incredible this teacher is. The films you will watch are amazing.

Take it!! As you've probably learned, Amineh is one of the best professors out there. Great class, watching an interesting Iranian film each week and discussing it in class. Helps both your spoken and written Persian.
prereqs: Successful completion of PER 105, or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will engage students thoughtfully with modern Iranian society and politics through documentaries. Each week, students will watch a documentary and prepare for a lively in-class discussion of the issues. Students will be heavily exposed to colloquial Persian.

title: History of Architectural Theory
reviews: I highly recommend this course.
If you like to read take this course.
If you're not in architecture, don't take this course. If you're in architecture, you will probably need to take this course, but keep your expectations at rock bottom.
Take this class if you are interesting in the material.
prereqs: Course open to undergraduate and graduate students. Of particular interest to art history, history, and architecture students. No prerequisites, but HIS 211, ART 333 and ART 322 are strongly recommended as background..
descrip: This course offers a history of architectural theory, criticism, and historiography from the Renaissance to the present, emphasizing the texts, media and institutions that have supported architecture's claim to modernity since the late 17th Century. Architectural thought is examined in its social and cultural context as it relates both to the Western philosophical tradition and to design method and practice.

title: Being and Doing: Dance for Every Body
reviews: A very relaxed course that is different from other classes here at Princeton. The commitment is not big and the class is very fun.
Go into this class with an open mind and a ton of energy. You won't regret it

I can't encourage you enough to take this class, especially if you're a senior. Professor Vandenbroucke's energy and enthusiasm is absolutely amazing. It is easy to get engaged in the class and once you do, it is a ton of fun and can easily become one of the best and most memorable classes you've ever taken at Princeton, like it was for me.
I would definitely recommend this course. It is amazing and teaches you to think in a new way.
If you have questions about yourself in relation to your own reality and that of those around you, this is excellent,

TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. Aynsley is the most wonderful human being, and you will learn so much in this class. Pleaaase don't take this as an easy PDF course. If you actually put thought and energy into this course, you will get so much out of it. It's not a hard class at all, but challenge yourself to do things that are outside your comfort zone. Because there's so much to be gained from this class if you just challenge yourself a little.
TAKE THIS CLASS.

Take it! It's not a course that focuses on choreography or the traditional definition of dance, but it will make you be more comfortable with movements and you'll meet and become friends with incredible people. Including Aynsley whose simply amazing.
Take this class!! Bring an open mind :)
Take this course. Aynsley is fantastic! The class is more than just dancing, it really helped me relax with my other courses.
This class really helped me fit into Princeton. I loved the way that Aynsley taught the class. She has made me become a more aware person: aware of others and those around me.
This is a GREAT course to take! Aynsley is the best.
This is a fabulous class and Aynsley is amazing. Be ready to let yourself go a little and really embrace the environment.
You get to really explore your body, and so all the silly little things you want in a judgement-free zone. What you get out of the class will ultimately depend on how hard you push yourself.
descrip: This studio course is open to everyone. We'll use dance as a way to deepen our self-knowledge and engagement with others as we search for a relationship between being and doing. We'll explore embodiment tools from ecstatic dance, yin yoga, and improvisation to establish a personal practice and delve into dance as meditation. We'll examine genre-bending performances occurring outside of theaters and study how dance reflects and can change (and whether it should try to change) contemporary issues, taking up such topics as power, class, race, and gender. Students invent final creative projects of their own design.

title: Sedimentology
prereqs: MAT 104, PHY 103, CHM 201 or equivalent..
descrip: This course presents a treatment of the physical and chemical processes that shape Earth's surface, such as solar radiation, deformation of the solid Earth, and the flow of water (vapor, liquid, and solid) under the influence of gravity. In particular, the generation, transport, and preservation of sediment in response to these processes is studied in order to better read stories of Earth history in the geologic record and to better understand processes involved in modern and ancient environmental change. Taught in parallel with GEO 370.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: Literature and the Arts
reviews: DEFINITELY TAKE! Do not be intimidated by the reputation for long readings. Though there is a lot of reading, it is so worth it. You will leave this course so much better equipped to take on almost any humanities class. Now when I read a book, an article, or anything, I have a much better grasp of the allusions and references. I feel that I have been incredibly enriched intellectually by this class.
Definitely do all the readings! It's difficult but you won't get much out of this course unless you put in the work.

Definitely take it! Yes, it's a lot of reading, but so worth it. I can know officially said I've read through all (almost all) of the texts of 2500  years of Western culture. Plus the professors are amazing- in addition to being so knowledgable they really care and are eager to help. My favorite part was growing so close to all the other students, or at least the ones in my precept. We've had HUM brunches, lunches, and parties.
Definitely take this course. It will change everything about how you see the world.

Don't be tempted to slack off even if you are a veteran from first semester.

Texts are different flavor from first semester, but still good.
HUM is challenging but wonderful.
I would tell them to take it and fully immerse themselves in the entirety of the course.

If you took HUM first semester, I think it is definitely worth it to finish out the year. However, since the spring semester moves into more contemporary works, I think that the course is not able to encompass as broad a range of ideas. Take it if you are ready to commit to another 26 books and another 5 essays and another 4 months, but if not, take a look at the course offerings because there are hundreds of other classes that are equally/more stimulating.
It's tough and it's awesome.

Only take this course if you have strong intentions for classics or literature. It is a huge commitment, and if you are not dedicated to it you will be stressed out the whole semester for a very surface level understanding of bunch of texts.

Somehow even better than the first semester. If you've finished HUM 216-217, take 218-219 for a wider, richer world of readings, for the art and music lectures, for political philosophy, and above all, for the same, unparalleled level of engagement from the amazing faculty, mentors, and peers so special and unique to HUM. Yes, the essay prompt could be more interesting, and the lectures are often too short to be fully satisfying. But that's why we complete the sequence - we know this is just the beginning to Princeton humanities have to offer, and all the conversations and relationships HUM has begun for me are a testament to that. I'd take it again if I could!

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! You'll need to plan ahead and work hard to stay on top of the readings and papers, but the lectures and precepts are amazing and these books will forever change the way you think about yourself and the world.

TAKE THIS COURSE. It will change your life and the way you think about the world. Yes, it's a lot of reading, but the intellectual stimulation and analytical thinking skills you learn in this course are so, so worth it.

Take it! These are all books you will read or will wish you had read. It is rare that a college freshman's taste is as expansive as this course's, so take it, read everything (the liked and the disliked) with the guidance of a lovely faculty.
Take this class! It will not only broaden your understanding of western civilization but it will also pave the way for you as scholars.
Take this course (both semesters are a must). Be prepared for a LOT of reading, but really great discussions with classmates and professors.

Take this course, it will change your life and the way you think. Every hour you spend reading will be worth it, you will fully immerse yourself in a community you can't find in any other class, and these professors are some of the most insightful brilliant people you'll meet. You can handle it, whether or not you have experience, whether or not you're a humanities major or an engineer, whatever the reason - you can get through it, and you will thank yourself for the immense growth you will experience as a student and as a human being through the HUM sequence.
The HUM sequence is awesome, If you decide to take HUM, I would recommend starting the readings early.

The level of my recommendation depends on the professors. If Rentzou or Morison or Marchesi or Reimitz teach again, take it. People generally have very high opinions of Feeney and Schor as well. Precepts went very well this semester-the professors sent out emails beforehand with some questions/passages to focus on, which was really helpful. However (albeit somewhat depending on the professor), lectures were less impressive this semester than last, due to an over-emphasis (I felt) on historical background.
Still, the readings were generally intriguing, and the people in this class will definitely stay with you. Take this class not because you want to be able to slap 'HUM' on a resume, but because you want to become part of a community that struggled through papers, tried to find the deeper meaning behind a text (or two, or thirty), and realized that despite how overwhelming everything seemed at the beginning of the semester that they /could/ and /did/ get through it, smarter and wiser and better people, together.

The secret to getting the most you can out of this course: You Should Do All the Readings. How is this to be done, you ask? Well, since the reading load is around 2-3 books per week due on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, that last Thursday book can easily sneak up on you even if you have already read the Tuesday book over the weekend. The way I circumvented this problem was by tricking myself into thinking all the books were due Sunday night, so that I read them all during the prior week (which also allowed me to catch up/ postpone readings--yet still get them done by class time--if I had an exceptionally hard week). Not saying this is the best way, but in order to appreciate what this whole course is about/ not be bored in lecture and precept you should do the readings. Also, secret 1a is to always come to precept with a few points/ passages you want to discuss--not because that will impress your teachers, but because it will a) allow you to test out ideas for your essay and b) keep you engaged, interested and learning in precept.

There's no question that HUM is phenomenal, and I have benefited tremendously from the course. My only concern is how much of my freshman year schedule I have devoted to HUM, without experimenting with other disciplines, getting more of the distribution requirements that won't come to me naturally, trying to maintain foreign languages I've studied, or coming closer to choosing a major.  I think I will only feel regret for taking HUM if I really feel that I haven't tried enough different courses at the end of next semester.
This course changed my life. The readings, the professors, the community of other students--if you're willing to give this class a large chunk of effort, it will reward you well.

This course is unlike any I have ever taken. If you are willing to think critically, take intellectual risks, maintain an open perspective, and invest time into the study and appreciation of literature, then you will find the course to be transformative. Do not take HUM simply to fulfill a distribution requirement. Take it if you are inspired by the storytelling process and are committed to joining an enduring conversation about pivotal works from the past. The dedicated team of professors is a reason in itself to take the course. I walked away from every lecture and precept overflowing with new convictions, questions, ideas, and passions.

This course is wonderful and eye-opening and brilliant. There is a LOT of reading but the interaction with such amazing professors makes it definitely worthwhile. The texts are also extremely interesting and worth reading.

This is assuming you've taken the first semester. If you haven't, don't start with the second semester. The first semester is better and the second semester will make much less sense without it. The second semester is still worth your time, especially if you enjoy literature and/or political philosophy. The readings are harder this semester- be prepared to spend more time on them, or to not do them all. But even if you dislike lectures and precepts (which was me this semester) the books are well worth your time and engagement, and will challenge and change you all on their own. But if you only like classics, and you know that already, the second semester isn't worth your time.
prereqs: Students who wish to enroll but who did not complete HUM 216-217 in fall term 2015 should email Lin DeTitta, ldetitta@princeton.edu..
descrip: This team-taught double credit course examines European texts, works of art and music from the Renaissance to the modern period. Readings, lectures, and discussions are complemented by films, concerts, museum visits and special events. It is the second half of an intensive interdisciplinary introduction to Western culture that includes history, religion, philosophy, literature and the arts. Although most students will have taken 216 - 217, it is possible for freshmen and sophomores to join at this point.

title: Religion and Public Life
descrip: Presentation and critical discussion of empirical research in progress by participants. Focuses on the use of social science methods in the study of religion and on applications of recently published work about religion and society. Includes an emphasis on religion and public policy in the U.S. and in comparative perspective.

title: Algebraic Geometry
descrip: Introduction to affine and projective algebraic varieties over fields.

title: Topics in Discrete Mathematics - Forbidding induced subgraphs: structure and properties
prereqs: Undergrads must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: Over the course of the semester, we discuss theorems and conjectures about graphs with certain induced subgraphs forbidden. Among others, we cover the following topics: perfect graphs, claw-free graphs, algorithms for detecting induced subgraphs, and the Erdo-Hajnal Conjecture.

title: Sedimentology
reviews: Definitely take the course if you are interested in rocks/earth science - I have probably learned more in this class than any other class this year.  It might be hard to take this class along with COS126/MAT202/ other weed-out courses, but if this is your hardest class for the semester it is certainly doable.  If you plan to go on in the geosciences, this course is also super important. So just take it!
If you're considering taking it... take it. You will spend more time than you want to on this class, but it pays off and the field trip is a good remedy for the stress.
It's a challenging but rewarding course. Make sure to get to know Adam before enrolling and talk to people who have already taken it to make sure it's something you definitely want to do.

Talk to Adam and make sure you know what you're getting yourself into before you take this course.  This has been one of the more challenging courses I have taken at Princeton, but also one of the courses where I have learned the most.

This class is a lot of work throughout the entire semester, but it's definitely worth it. The material is interesting, and you'll learn so much from Adam about answering big picture questions and presenting you work in a clear and concise way.

This is not a course to take lightly, but if you're willing to put in the time, you will certainly get a lot out of it if you're interested in becoming a better scientist or researcher. The open-ended, qualitative nature can be very frustrating. Programming experience is a must, and it helps to have experience specifically in Matlab and Latex. The field trip is an amazing experience that teaches you skills that you'll never be able to learn out of a book. Overall, I'd recommend taking this course, even though there will probably be times when you don't enjoy the material or the work you're doing for the course.
prereqs: MAT 104, PHY 103, CHM 201 or equivalent..
descrip: This course presents a treatment of the physical and chemical processes that shape Earth's surface, such as solar radiation, deformation of the solid Earth, and the flow of water (vapor, liquid, and solid) under the influence of gravity. In particular,the generation, transport, and preservation of sediment in response to these processes is studied in order to better read stories of Earth history in the geologic record and to better understand processes involved in modern and ancient environmental change.

title: Apocalypse Now
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: The class is absolutely great, and I learned a lot that I would not have learned in other conventional classes. Thermo and Quantum are challenging but very important to learn, and you only get that in ISC. Also, doing such interesting experiments and writing lab reports is an important experience that should not be missed.

There are many reasons not to take this course, but there are just as many to take it. If you enjoy feeling overwhelmed intellectually, and are good at maths and physics, go ahead. Is it worth it? I don't know... I don't think I ever will. One thing I do know, is that ISC has taught me that I will never be a scientist
This isn't an easy sequence by any means, but is the most worthwhile thing I have done at Princeton thus far. Everyone who stays, loves it.

This was my favorite class this semester. It covers the most meaningful material and provides so many meaningful relationships. There were less moments of despair this semester than last, because I already knew the generally pattern of what to expect and because they basically cut the problem sets in half.
answered in ISC 233 evaluation
great
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); S. Shvartsman (CBE); H. Yang (CHM); R. Sedgewick (COS); P. Andolfatto (EEB); E. Wieschaus (MOL); J. Gadd, A. Leifer, B. Machta, A. Nourmohammad (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.

title: Topics in Greek Literature - Hesiod
reviews: Best language class I've taken at Princeton. Take it. Duh.

If you are into classics, take any course offered by Professor Katz--you won't be disappointed. This course is no different. The material (Hesiod) and the instructor make this course a must for any classics-oriented student.
Prof. Katz has the ability to make Hesiod enjoyable!
Take it!

Take it! Dr. Katz was very engaging and the material was very interesting.  My only caution is to make sure your Greek is up to scratch because there isn't really time to cover basic grammar questions since there is so much material.
Take it. Take anything with Joshua Katz.
Take this course, especially if Prof. Katz is teaching it. Hesiod is a wonderfully bizarre author, and reading him in Greek is a truly great experience.
prereqs: CLG 108 or permission of instructor..
descrip: An intensive reading of the Theogony and Works and Days. Special emphasis will be paid to Hesiod's language and questions of poetics; we will also explore the Near Eastern and Indo-European background of the poems, as well as their cultural context.

title: Energy Conversion and the Environment: Transportation Applications
reviews: A must take. No matter if you're interested in the subject or not - you'll become interested!
Fantastic course.
Highly recommend, without a doubt. Professor Mueller is an incredible lecturer and friend to students.
I don't know about Rockets, but Engines is a great class to take as an MAE student! Professor Mueller is the man!

I would take this class. Go in and talk to Mueller in office hours whenever you can. He is so good at explaining things that I thought were going to be complicated and are really quite straightforward. He also doesn't make you feel like an idiot for asking questions like a number of profs do.
Its hard but incredibly well taught - you will learn a lot and be constantly interested.
Mueller is amazing. The class is fantastic. I don't even care about cars and motors and I loved this class.

One of the most interesting and enjoyable MAE courses I've taken here. Engaging mix of fundamental theory and design application. Fair amount of work (nothing extraordinary) but psets are worth the time. Prof. Mueller is terrific.

Really good class. Prof Mueller is great and always available to help. There is some chemistry in the beginning that some people (like me) may not particularly enjoy but once we get into the details of engines the class is great.
Strongly recommend! One of my favorite courses. It is more organized than rockets and covers more material. Psets are average MAE length, but this is 50-100% longer than those in rockets

Take it. Professor Mueller is an incredible lecturer, and he does a really wonderful job of presenting the material in an interesting way. I came in thinking I wouldn't particularly like the class, since I didn't have much of an interest in engines/gas turbines, and I still really don't like thermochemistry. BUT, this has been one of the most enjoyable classes that I have taken at Princeton. It is challenging, but it's 100% worth it.
Take notes on the lecture slides - it makes life so much easier. Mueller's a great professor, and Jon is a great TA. Highly recommended.
This class is tough and exactly how Professor Mueller describes it - "like drinking from a firehose". But it is very interesting material and I would definitely suggest taking it if interested.
You have to take it for MAE but it is very well taught and Mueller makes it actually kind of interesting to apply concepts from chemistry, thermo, and fluids.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or equivalent, or by permission of instructor..
descrip: Overview of energy utilization in and environmental impacts of propulsion systems for ground and air transportation. Roughly half of the course will be devoted to reciprocating engines for ground transportation, and the other half of the course will be devoted to gas turbine engines for air transportation. The course will focus on device efficiency/performance and emissions with future outlooks for improvements in these areas including alternative fuels and alternative device concepts. Relevant thermodynamics, chemistry, fluid mechanics, and combustion fundamentals will be reviewed or introduced and will permeate the course material.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - ICT for International Development
descrip: Information and communication technologies (ICTs) are rapidly growing in significance in sectors such as health, agriculture, finance, education, democracy and governance. The aim of this course is to provide a practical framework for students to apply participatory approaches to ICT to accelerate development with a special focus on low and middle-income countries. Using the "principles for digital development" as a lens, we will explore ways that mobile phones, tablets, sensors, drones and other computer-based applications and tools can be designed and implemented for social change.

title: Modern Latin America since 1810
reviews: Amazing class! Fair amount of reading for a history class and very accessible at that. Be prepared to write fast in lecture but don't worry if you miss something because Professor Karl and his preceptors are always willing to answer questions and discuss material further.
Amazing class! Lots of reading.
Be aware that lectures are fairly fast-paced but overall very interesting and engaging.
Definitely worth taking, Professor Karl is fantastic - try and get in his precept
Go to every lecture and do take advantage of office hours!
Go to lecture and record them. Do readings. Visit professor in office hours.
Good class. Not easy, but not too hard. If you want Latin American culture, this won't float your boat, but for politics/economic history this is great.
Great intro to history from a non-U.S./European point of view! Strongly recommend to people considering concentrating in the History department.
I learned a ton about Latin America and would really recommend taking this course.  It is a moderate, manageable workload.

I would 100% recommend this course for anyone even remotely interested in the topic. It is not a super easy course, but it is not too hard either, a great HA to take, in my opinion! It has made me reevaluate a lot of my academic choices, because it was so good. The preceptors and professor are even good about telling you which parts of the readings are the most important if you're short on time.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in History or not

If Prof. Karl is teaching, and you're even moderately interested in Latin America, take this course! Prof. Karl is the man. Get into his precept if you can. Start on the written work early, and go to office hours. I found it helpful to make audio recordings of the lectures to refer back to later, because Prof. Karl talks super fast. Do the readings too! They're really good!
If you are interested in the subject and modern Latin America it is a good class to take.
If you're into modern history, the second half of the semester will really excite you. The first half is a little messy and confusing, though.
It is a good class to take and if you are willing to do most of the readings you will learn a lot.

Latin America is such an interesting part of the world, anyone with even the slightest inclination should take it. Professor Karl is passionate, knowledgable, and extremely approachable. The work is significant, but manageable. Stay on top of the lectures before the midterm!
Not a class to get excited about but very solid if you want to know more about continental themes.

Sometimes I felt it was a Colombian history class. Since Colombian History is the Professor's expertise, he talks about it a lot. Take home final and analysis paper is based on Colombia. A lot of work if you want an A.
TAKE IT! Professor Karl is one of those professors that genuinely cares about his students. Also, the content was really interesting and the assignments were very engaging.
TAKE THIS.
Take it if you're interested in Latin America, or just history in general. Stick through the first semester and the payoff will be worth it

Take it take it take it. So interesting. Professor Karl is great, the preceptors are amazing, even if you aren't in their section, and they all care so deeply about the material--and your understanding of it. Best class I've taken here.
Take it! Honestly it's the best humanities class I've taken at Princeton. Great lectures and a teaching staff that really cares. Do it!
Take it! kinda a pain, but v interesting nonetheless. Possible PDF

Take this course - for an HA, for general interest, for whatever - you will become interested simply b/c Prof. Karl is a master storyteller, especially for a subject that is too often taught from a US-centric view. Prof. Karl is also one of the kindest, most helpful, most interested in the well-being of his students, among all the professors at Princeton.
Take this course if you are interested in Latin America and/or need an interesting HA.
Take this course!  Very well taught, and learn a great deal about a very important part of the world.

The class itself is very fast paced and the reading load is heavy, so I would recommend taking that into consideration when picking courses. Although its a survey of Latin America and other countries are mentioned, you really only focus on Argentina, Brazil, Mexico, and especially Colombia. That being said, I would still recommend the class. Professor Karl genuinely cares about his students.
The first 4 weeks of this course are a little slow, but the second half of the semester is FASCINATING. For anybody interested in Latin American politics and history, I highly recommend this class.

This is a great course. It helped spark an interest in Latin American history, which I hope to continue in the future. If you keep up with the readings and go to every lecture, it is also a manageable PDF option.

This is an incredibly well-taught and engaging course. Lectures are fast-paced yet organized, and the books and articles assigned are some of the most interesting readings I've had to read for any class at Princeton. Definitely recommend.

With no previous knowledge of Latin America, this was one of the best history classes I've taken at Princeton - previous knowledge will not hold you back as long as you go to lectures and do the readings.
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators.
descrip: This course surveys the main themes of Latin American history from independence to the present. The main focus is on the interaction between states and citizens, social relations, and economic development.

title: Madness and Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Innovation through Empathic Design
reviews:
Do not take this class until they have worked out all the kinks.... be prepared for "busy work" readings that seem pointless (a lot of the readings are meta) 
Take 392 before you take this class so you don't make it miserable for the other people in the class
Show up on time and be respectful of Natalie, Arnava, Michael and Rae's time, as well as everyone else in the class's. 

I'm pretty sure they grade you based on how artsy you are... consider wearing weird tie dye outfits or growing your hair out and braiding flowers into it.
It's a good course that I'd recommend, especially if you've taken the prerequisite course.
Take it if you are interested in the subject.
Take it!
Take this course if you have an interest in empathy and/or design. Unlike most classes at Princeton, it's practical and fun. The Subrosa team is excellent.
Take this if you've taken the intro design thinking course! It's more focused on what a professional design agency might do, so less principle of design thinking, more actualization of the process.
pretty easy, annoying time, not huge work load, dont take it if you already believe in design in some way
take it!!!!! <3 sub rosa
prereqs: EGR 392 or permission of instructor ( please email vdorman@princeton.edu).
descrip: This course will build on the foundational design-thinking curriculum of EGR 392. The goal is to extend students' understanding of creativity and innovation, so as to productively apply it to cross-disciplinary problem solving. The course will emphasize empathic methodologies for breaking down complex organizational challenges and for developing meaningful solutions within experience design, brand strategy, storytelling and communications.

title: Research Methods in Demography
reviews: All the work is directed at earning the topics of the course. So, taking this work seriously is very important. Not just applying formulas but really understanding what you are doing is crucial.
The methods can be challenging and it may take more time than you think to master the material but it is worthwhile.
This course is part of a first-year Ph.D. student methods sequence, so if you're interested you should reach out to the instructor. Most people taking it already know they have to take it.
prereqs: POP 501/ECO 571/SOC 531 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Source materials used in the study of population; standard procedures for the measurement of fertility, mortality, natural increase, migration, and nuptiality; and uses of model life tables and stable population analysis and other techniques of estimation when faced with inaccurate or incomplete data are studied.

title: Topics in German Culture and Society - Klassik in Weimar: Golden Age or Fabricated Legend?
descrip: You cannot write German literary history without a strong focus on the Weimarer Klassik. With authors like Goethe, Schiller, Wieland and Herder, German literature became world literature. This seminar will investigate Weimar's improbable ascendance. We will read original texts by the greats, investigate "Weimar" as a unique place, and follow the afterlife of this amazing period of an intellectual peak performance.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research (Half-Term)
reviews: Good.
N/A
descrip: This course will cover the essential topics of what constitutes responsible conduct in research.

title: Technologies of Communication
reviews: Definitely take this course! Professor Sherouse is so great, he gives such interesting readings, and you can be as creative as you want with your final project.
Strongly recommended, Professor Sherouse is amazing and the class is very interesting and engaging. Honestly do the readings and take the projects seriously as they are well worth the effort.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! PERRY IS THE BEST.
Take it! Perry is great- it isn't stressful, and I enjoyed it!

This class is extremely interesting and worth-while. The workload is manageable, but not a breeze. Professor Sherouse is great and genuinely interested in his students and their interests. Definitely attend office hours before each written assignment?Professor Sherouse offers great guidance. The in-class discussions are the best. A great class if you're interested in technology and its social implications
prereqs: This course will especially interest students in anthropology, history, and linguistics. There are no prerequisites or restrictions..
descrip: From the telegraph to snapchat, technologies of communication have been heralded as progress, yet also denounced as catalyzing negative social and linguistic changes. Discussions about communicative technologies reflect values of the present, and anxieties and hopes about possible futures. In this course, we query claims about interfaces among communicative practices, technologies, and social life. After a theoretical overview of mediated communication, we turn to specific technologies: the telegraph, radio, telephone, mobile phone, television, and internet.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: All the content can be learned in lectures. Textbook readings are not very helpful.

Based on the title of the course and the titles of each topic, this class might seem incredibly interesting, but the presentation of the material itself does not turn out to be as exciting as one might expect.
Definitely take this course. Professors, preceptors, and TA's are super supportive, and the material is very interesting and intellectually stimulating.
Don't take unless necessary!!

Go to all the lectures, they're probably more useful than the book, and let you know what to focus on. You won't get a third as much from just looking at the lecture slides they post. Read the book, too.
Go to every single lecture and take good notes.
Good class
Good survey of cognitive neuroscience.
Great course for NEU majors, lots of cool topics!
Great course! Definitely take it, if you are interested!
Highly recommend.  A little surface-y at times but good

I heard from some that NEU 202 is hard and uninteresting. After taking NEU 201 with Prof. Witten (which I found to be a horrible class), I was quite discouraged but still decided to try NEU 202. I'm so glad I did. NEU 202 turned out to be AMAZING. There's work involved obviously, but it's super well taught, the professors are great people and are super approachable. Also, take 202B (the lab). It's basically no work and you learn really interesting things. I don't know if Professor Norman will still be teaching next year (probably not), but he was amazing. He kept the whole class super well organized and everyone just loves him. Professor Niv and Professor Botvinick were also great. take it take it take it

If you do not have a background or an interest in computer science do not take the lab option of this course. The material is very interesting during lecture but its presentation makes it less engaging.

If you're going to do the labs, make sure you really find this stuff interesting! Otherwise, just do the precepts. Also, go to lecture. Most of the exam material is based off of lecture notes rather than book notes.

It's super interesting and the lectures are great.
The lab section is an intro to the skills you'll need for neuroscience research. Be prepared to do some coding! (It's not that fun, but neuroscience is fun, so just keep that in mind)
