Just take notes in lecture. If it works like this semester, the book was zero helpful. Just take notes in lecture. Also, the labs are not as useful as you think they are. It's intro MATLAB for non-coders. Doesn't teach you about computational experiments or anything. If you don't have to take lab, take the precept. Also, one and a half hours lectures are really draining.
Make sure to attend lecture because everything is lecture based

NEU 202B really isn't a bad prereq class for a major. Your will be engaged to varying degrees during the lectures depending on the subject of the day. Lecturers were all very knowledgeable and handled questions very well. Workload is pretty small. Tests are open note open answer and aren't bad. Grade distribution was skewed left the year I took the class. Labs introduce you to MATLAB and MATLAB data collection. Overall, this really isn't a bad class and I would recommend for anyone with an interest in cognitive neuroscience (sort of like the intersection of psychology and neuroscience but not as abstract as you think) Also Su Keun is a really nice lab preceptor.

Pay as much attention as you can during lecture! What they say is true...exams are very much based on the lecture. And it's super nice that it's open note but you still need to review the material beforehand and be familiar with it before the exam.
Take careful notes on the lectures -- always paying attention in class is really important for this course since the slides are sparse and need lots of context.
Take if interested! Enough biology and psychology, but not too molecularly based.
Take this class if you are a neuro major or getting a neuro certificate. Challenging class but the exams and work are fair if you put in the time and effort.

The class is a bit disorganized because 7 different lecturers teach the main section. It's not too much stress and pretty easy to do well in. Lab will make you want to kill yourself because you learn nothing but required for neuro majors

The content is good, but the way the class is structured is awful. Exams were difficult mostly because professor refused to post practice exams or even hold a review session. Slides are mostly just pictures and readings are not always assigned. You must go to every lecture, and if I were you I would record them or something because that's all the review you'll get.
The lectures are interesting.
This 202 course was very interesting because it wasn't focused on biology at all. It focused more on behavior which is more easily relatable and understandable.

This class was revamped for the neuroscience major this year (S2016) and last, and it seems like it's been a pretty messy process. The class is inherently disorganized; the lecture series consists of a random smattering of topics with no clear organization. The labs (which you'll have to take if you're considering the neuroscience major) were interesting in theory (you get to analyze the fMRI data of a student in the class?could even be your own fMRI data), but in practice were incredibly boring and unhelpful. For most of them, we simply copied down MATLAB code from the board; I usually just did work from another class. You're probably taking this class as a prereq for the major or certificate, so just grin and bear it. By no means a stimulating or enjoyable class.

This is a fantastic course! The material is really interesting, and the lectures are great. If you do not have any coding experience, the labs will be confusing and fast-paced, but the grading is fair.
This is a fun and interesting course, I definitely recommend taking the lab section, you get to do really incredible experiments.

This is a good survey course of what is happening in princeton neuroscience, lots of lectures are guest lectures, the tests are actually fun to take, everything is interesting if you are interested at all in neuro, just be careful in the lab section if you don't know any matlab it will be tough...get mingbo as a ta
Unless you want to do MatLab, don't take the lab component.
Use piazza!
You have to take this class for NEU--go to class.
great course if you're interested in neuro and want to try it out. it's a lot more on the psych side, so you learn a lot more about neuro in your life.
great course, but the labs are useless
prereqs: NEU201/PSY258 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course surveys current knowledge about the neural underpinnings of cognitive functions such as attention, language, memory, learning, and decision making. Cognitive neuroscience is a young field where many questions are yet unanswered. Through this course students will learn to extract overarching principles of cognitive function and neural organization, and to effectively address questions about the neural substrates of high-level human behaviors using current neuroscientific methods and clever experimental design. Labs will provide hands-on experience with behavioral experiments, fMRI, EEG and computational modeling.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Classes can get a little boring, and its not as fun as 1st or 2nd year, but the teacher still make it worth.
I would take this class! The teachers are amazing and kind, and your Chinese improves.
If you've made it this far in Chinese, you might as well stick around.
Just work hard and it will pay off!

Put in the time to do the readings, preview and review the vocab. This course is so worth it -- definitely take it even if you are not aiming for a certificate or concentration. This is an amazing program that I would highly recommend you take advantage of!
TAKE IT! Very rewarding and you actually get to discuss interesting topics by the time you get to 3rd year!!

Take this course if you want to continue your Chinese ability. You will not get the fast progress of fist or second year if you've taken those at Princeton, but you will actually realise you got a lot better and use more precise vocabulary and better constructions.
There's really no reason not to take it if you have time. It's not much different than 2nd year, just a bit more advanced.
This course is a lot of work. You will need to dedicate time everyday.
prereqs: CHI 303 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of CHI 303, designed to improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of newspaper essays and commentaries.

title: Ecology and Epidemiology of Parasites and Infectious Diseases
reviews: Andy is the bomb dot com and his research is super interesting. Pick a project you like and have fun with it, pay attention to his lectures because they're awesome, go to the TUPPER talks.

This is a really wonderful course; the labs are enjoyable and really educational, and the independent projects are very rewarding. Prof. Dobson does a great job, also, of making the course fun and enjoyable in every way.
engage. write drafts early. ask for help with stats and R early. Leave the schoolhouse if you can, this course can cause cabin fever if you are inside for too long.
n/a
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: An introduction to the biology of viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, worms, arthropods, and parasitic plants. The major emphasis will be on the parasites of animals and plants, with further study of the epidemiology of infectious diseases in human populations. Studies of AIDS, anthrax, and worms, and their role in human history will be complemented by ecological and evolutionary studies of fig wasps, measles, myxomatosis, and communities of parasitic helminths. The course combines lectures with daily field laboratories to explore the dynamics and abundance of parasite in a variety of host species in the Panama Canal zone.

title: Literature of the American Renaissance, 1820-1860
reviews: If you are interested in this era of literature, take the class! But make sure you actually are, or else the readings may not be very enjoyable.
Take it. If you like reading and you like great literature this is a phenomenal foundation in it.
The best way to tackle some of the most important pieces of American Literature, especially Moby Dick.
This course is great, but you have to be willing to be engaged and sink time into readings that can be quite daunting.
You should read these books.
descrip: Close study of nine authors--the so-called literary "renaissance" of the new republic--who defined a native brand of literature that would influence all subsequent American writers. Our focus will be on narrative and poetic forms that signaled independence from older ideals, offering an exhilarating yet deeply unsettling transition in literary history.

title: Seminar in Musicology
descrip: Study of analytical methodology through direct comparison of multiple analyses of the same composition. Methods studied include thematic, Schenkerian, set-theoretical and hermeneutic. Compositions are chosen from the output of J.S. Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Brahms, Schoenberg, Debussy and Stravinsky. A term paper is required.

title: Introduction to Critical Theory - Phenomenology
descrip: Phenomenology is a tradition concerned with how the world gives itself to appearances. It is also a method, committed to perpetual beginning as a way of apprehending the world and our place in it. This course is an introduction to this philosophy of continual introductions. We begin with Edmund Husserl, then consider how phenomenology transforms as it is articulated by Merleau-Ponty, Heidegger and Levinas. We explore the treatment of language and literature in this tradition, and in the latter half of the course read contemporary phenomenology engaging questions of gender and sexuality, race, environmental justice and mass incarceration.

title: International Political Economy
reviews: A good course for anyone interested in political economy from a more political standpoint (as opposed to a purely economic one). The readings really are essential to a solid understanding of the course content, but if you do them in a reasonable timeframe, the lectures are quite worthwhile. Professor Ahmed is really knowledgable in his field, so ask questions! Prepare to think critically. Memorizing the models and reciting information won't get you very far in this class, but it's worth your time to put in the effort.
A good course with good readings, recommended for politics major, not for economics ones.

I would recommend this course anyone interested in international economics and international economic policy. The course is engaging and provides a great opportunity to develop a good understanding of economic concepts.
Interesting course. Manageable workload

This course grounds your knowledge about things you really ought to know, and are presumed to know when reading newspapers. Lectures a bit dry, but the lecture slides are great.
You learn the major debates in international trade and finance, and wrestle with evaluating the effects of globalization. 
Xander is a really approachable preceptor. And Prof Ahmed is a wonderful person -- would recommend getting to know him personally.
Would recommend to economics majors and politics majors.
descrip: This course explores the following questions: who wins and who loses from globalization of trade and finance? Who sets the rules under which the game of international capitalism is played? How powerful are international organizations like the WTO or the IMF, nation-states, or NGOs? These issues are explored with reference to economic and political theories, history and contemporary events.

title: Psychology for Policy Analysis and Implementation
descrip: Course covers basic concepts and experimental findings of psychology that contribute to an understanding of the effects of policy on human behavior and well-being; and psychological factors that affect the formulation, communication, and execution of policy. Topics include a descriptive analysis of boundedly rational judgment and decision making, a consideration of social motives and attitudes, and an introduction to the ways in which agents influence and negotiate with one another, including an examination of the psychological roots of conflict.

title: Structural Design
reviews: Stay focused. Ask questions whenever anything is not clear.
descrip: Introduction to the design of building structures of steel, timber and reinforced concrete.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II
reviews: Be prepared to work hard.  Do practice problems.  GG is a nice prof and cares for students, even if he is kind of intimidating in lecture sometimes.
Be ready to spend lots of time doing the HW.
Buckle your seatbelts buckaroos
Good
I hope your AI is as helpful as this year's AI.
If interested in learning complex analysis, PDE's and numerical methods, this course may be useful. However, be prepared to learn independently as the material is not well explained in the lectures.
It is very helpful to seek for textbooks from somewhere else to understand the topics better.

You will primarily be learning from the textbooks as the lectures only give a "survey" of the material while you will be expected to have a deep understanding of it for the problem sets and examinations.
descrip: A complementary presentation of theory, analytical methods, and numerical methods. The objective is to impart a set of capabilities commonly used in the research areas represented in the Department and more broadly in engineering and the physical and biological sciences. Analytical methods are emphasized, but standard computational packages are made available and some assignments are designed to use them. Topics include Complex variables, PDE, Fourier and Laplace Transforms, and a brief introduction to numerical methods for ODE and PDE.

title: Metabolic Engineering
reviews: Ask for help early on the final proposal if you aren't sure what to write about.  I was glad I did.

Definitely go to every lecture, take notes, but really the exam is based on the notes the professor puts on blackboard. The first half is a bunch of memorizing and learning the background information, but the second half is very laid-back. The research project is a bit of work, but very interesting. I didn't take BioChem and still managed, but it is better to take BioChem for the first half.
I would advise them to attend every class and to engage in the discussions.

I'd be careful to enter into this class without having taken biochem. Professor Brynildsen will move quickly through material especially at the beginning of the semester, and you will likely feel lost if you haven't had biochem. That being said, the class is still doable. But the midterm requires a lot of preparation (although, again it's doable as long as you're willing to put the time in). It's definitely an interesting class and a change in pace from other courses,  however, I probably wouldn't have taken it if I had a better understanding of what it would be going in.

Pretty cool class! The proposal at the end made me realize how much I had learned throughout the semester. Definitely gave me a better understanding of what one aspect of biotech is all about! A great survey course!

Professor Brynildsen is a very caring person, even though he might not explicitly show it, and one of the best CBE professors in the department. Metabolic engineering is the engineering of metabolic pathways in various organisms to achieve targeted production of a certain product. If this interests you, you should definitely take it. I learned a great deal from this course. Keep in mind though that the final proposal project can prove to be a quite time-consuming so make sure you try to at least get things done at each milestone set (you'll know what I mean). And lastly, the midterm is very fair, not necessarily easy, but fair. Enjoy!
Take it even if you know biochemistry! The papers will put it into context.
Take this class. The first part would be difficult if you have not taken biochem, but if you can get through it, the second part of the class is really cool.
This course is difficult if you do not have much background. Either come in extremely prepared to not afraid to be wrong about a few things.

This is a great course and caters to a mix of MOL and CBE students. Each will have difficulties in the first half: CBE students are missing biochemistry knowledge, MOL students are missing some of the math. Know this going in and focus on your weaknesses; they will be covered in the midterm. It's awesome in that it presents a very broad overview of metabolic engineering, including the tools used to conduct research in the field and diverse applications; the whole second half of the course is just discussions about the primary literature, and you will learn a lot about how to evaluate other people's research. The final proposal is a lot of work, and Prof. Brynildsen, who is still my favorite CBE professor, makes you start early. This is for your own good, and you will get a lot out of it if you invest in it. It's not your typical class work and you are expected to really make a strong, thorough case for your proposed research, which was a really cool challenge.
Very interesting class, difficult but definitely worth it if you're at all interested in metabolic engineering.
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215, or equivalent. Designed for sophomores, juniors, and seniors in engineering, molecular biology, and chemistry..
descrip: Introduction to the engineering of metabolism. The objective of this course is to introduce students to current techniques and challenges within the field of metabolic engineering. Specific topics will range from applications for energy and the environment to human health. The course will also include lectures from industrial speakers, a mock NSF panel review of research proposals, and debates structured as reviewers discussing the appropriateness of manuscripts for publication.

title: Creative Non-Fiction
reviews: Absolutely apply and take it.  McPhee is such a resource and your writing style will improve- he'll point out little writing ticks of yours you never realized you had.

Apply for this class. The mini-conferences with McPhee are wonderful, and he is both extremely kind and incredibly talented at editing work. Be warned - you will want to be a writer at the end of this class.

Courses like this are why we came to Princeton! Professor McPhee is unbelievably kind, attentive, and helpful. He's also funny and insightful and, you know, a Pulitzer Prize winner. Assuming you get in, if you put the time into writing your pieces, which you absolutely must do or you're wasting an incredible opportunity, then your writing will improve so much over the course of this class. Apply! Dedicate a lot of time to writing your pieces!
Do whatever you can to take it, and when you do, devote all your free time to it. You deserve to do that.

During my senior spring of high school, a Princeton alumna and senior editor at TIME emailed me with one piece of advice for the four years ahead: "Take John McPhee's class. It's a life-changer." Two years have since passed, and I stand by these words wholeheartedly. Kindhearted and selfless, insightful and humorous, immensely talented yet endlessly humble, Professor McPhee is hands-down the most incredible professor I have ever had the honor to meet. For an aspiring writer, there is no better gift than to sit across a table with him for three hours each week. For as long as I live, I will never forget Mondays with McPhee.

If you get in, TAKE IT!!! This is what a course at Princeton should be: purely for the sake of learning, taught by a master of the subject who genuinely cares about each and every student, and lacking a focus on just getting a good grade on the next test. Professor McPhee is INCREDIBLE (there's a reason this class is legendary) and the conferences were PRICELESS. I never considered creative writing before taking this class, but it has changed me and my opinion of my own writing completely. APPLY AND IF YOU GET IN TAKE THIS COURSE! It will change your life!
TAKE IT. At the very least, apply.
TAKE IT. Probably the best class at Princeton.
TAKE THIS CLASS! you'll never get an opportunity like this again! professor mcphee is incredible and kind and funny and smart and so helpful!
Take it!
Take this course and cherish it. Professor McPhee is incredible. Put everything you have into the writing assignments.
prereqs: Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu/journalism/courses. For the writing sample, submit whatever you consider to be your best work, from any source, written since you came to Princeton, including, if you like, a new piece written for the application. Application deadline is November 18, 2015..
descrip: This is a course in factual writing and what has become known as literary nonfiction, emphasizing writing assignments and including several reading assignments from the work of John McPhee and others. Enrollment is limited to 16 second-year students, by application only.

title: Electronic Commerce
reviews: A lot of the class is hands-on creating your own e-commerce website/company/app. The guest lecturers are interesting. The professor is interesting, as well, but he can be difficult to deal with. The class is not that organized; the syllabus changes constantly, so check the course website before/at the start of the week
Don't take it unless you have to. If you know how to program it's easy
Don't take this course to actually learn about E-commerce. Take this course to learn about ALK's very narrow views on the future of e-commerce.
Good if you want an ORF departmental. May don't take it senior year though.
He has an interesting style but also great insights.
It's easy, but don't expect to learn much

Kornhauser has a pretty rough personality; the class itself is pretty easy especially if you have prior knowledge of web development. Don't expect to learn much, however. Take it if you want an easy class and if you can deal with Professor Kornhauser.
Proceed with caution
Take if you are an ORF major.
Take it
Take it for some practical knowledge about HTML/PHP/Website Design. Prof. Kornhauser is also funny.

Take it! It's not hard and as long as you know how to code/find a partner who does it's a great class. You basically get to start your own company for the final project and that's exactly what Kornhauser wants you to do.
Take the course.
Take this course to get a very tiny taste of website design and hear some fascinating guest speakers from various industries. Also, worth it to get to know Prof K. You'll laugh a lot.
Take this if you are a very self-directed learner and also if you are fairly tolerant of big personalities.

This class isn't a particularly difficult ORF departmental and I suspect most people in the class took it for that reason. Kornhauser is an interesting fellow. I personally like him a lot and enjoy his shenanigans and comments. However, I can also definitely see why some people might not appreciate it as much. Take the class to gain a cursory introduction to e-commerce.
Took it as an outside departmental for COS. Not too much work. Most people use wordpress for final project.
prereqs: COS 126 or equivalent.
descrip: Electronic commerce, traditionally the buying and selling of goods using electronic technologies, extends to essentially all facets of human interaction when extended to services, particularly information. The course focuses on both the software and the hardware aspects of traditional aspects as well as the broader aspects of the creation, dissemination and human consumption electronic services. Covered will be the physical, financial and social aspects of these technologies

title: Taboo and Transgression
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Seminar in Colonial Spanish American Literature - Writing history in the New World:Spanish & Indian Chroniclers
reviews: An opportunity not to be missed. Regardless of your field, the professor's methodology will change your perception of your own work and the world.
Probably the best professor anyone could have in SPO
This is a wonderful class! Professor Gruzinski is a genius and I am very grateful to have been able to learn from him as an undergraduate. Take this class, even if you are an undergraduate!
descrip: Writing History in the New World: How XVIth century History, a provincial set of knowledges elaborated in Western Europe, Northern Italy and Spain, became, once applied and adapted to the New World, a discipline able to interpret non Western pasts and societies? The course compares standard European Humanist History and the new forms of history writing appearing in Mexico during the XVIth century. Special attention is given this semester to the Indian responses to European historicism such as Mexican Codices, Images and Songs considered as an alternative to the European and Christian models.

title: Irreversible Processes in Plasmas
reviews: It's hard to know how next year's course will be, given that Matt Kunz probably has a wildly different style of teaching than Greg (and Krommes). But this course can be helpful for digging deeper into concepts learned in GPP I.
descrip: Introduction to theory of fluctuations and transport in plasma. Origins of irreversibility. Random walks, Brownian motion, and diffusion; Langevin and Fokker-Planck theory. Fluctuation-dissipation theorem; test-particle superposition principle. Statistical closure problem. Derivation of kinetic equations from BBGKY hierarchy and Klimontovich formalism; properties of plasma collision operators. Classical transport coefficients in magnetized plasmas; Onsager symmetry. Introduction to plasma turbulence, including quasilinear theory. Applications to current problems in plasma research.

title: Special Topics in Statistics and Operations Research - Quantitative Asset Management
reviews:
*Don't bother with the readings
*Don't show up to the class if it doesn't look interesting
Don't be intimidated, Fabozzi uses this course as a way to introduce you to a very interesting field.
Good professor, good guest speakers
Great course, great professor. Unfortunately I do not think he will take the course again, though if so you should take it!

Strongly recommend to anyone interested in quantitative asset management, especially those exploring internship options. The opportunity to network with the guest speakers is rarely found at other courses.
This is a great class to give you a broad overview of many different investment strategies. Definitely take it if you plan on working on the buyside (i.e. asset management / hedge funds etc)
Unfortunately this course by this very instructor will not open again...
descrip: This course covers asset management focusing on quantitative models applied to equities and bonds (with emphasis on mortgage based securities). The quantitative models discussed are asset allocation models and portfolio construction models that include optimization models (mean variance framework and extensions such as robust portfolio optimization), multi factor risk models for performance evaluation are covered. Model risk and model/strategy backtesting will be highlighted. Guest speakers from quantitative asset management firms are scheduled.

title: Space System Design
reviews: 6 Prefrosh sat in on the course during Preview. Within 15 min 5 had left and the last one was asleep.
Avoid taking a class with Professor Stengel if possible. I've never complained about a course so much in my life

Be prepared for your teammates to take advantage of your work ethic and contribute nothing to your group projects. Otherwise an interesting class with a cool final project about deflecting an asteroid
Don't take this course unless you have a lot of time for the final project around deans date and you really like learning about different types of space systems.
Extremely boring lecture but the project was interesting. Ridiculously long and weird problem sets.
I would take this only if you really enjoy the material. It is a challenging and time consuming course so I give warning to anyone not fully committed.
If space systems is your thing, you will find Stengel to be super knowledgeable. Classes do seem very long for lectures though.
If you;re determined to study Space, you have to take it. If you're on the fence between this and Aircraft, do yourself a favor and take aircraft.
It is a slow class that is difficult to stay awake in. The material is interesting but the majority of what you learn will be through independent reading to complete the assignments.
It seems like it should an interesting class but if Stengel is the professor expect to gain very little from it. Hopefully Kasdin teaches it next time around.
Our year was taught by Prof. Stengel. He teaches it the same way he does his other courses. So our year is really the exception.
Professor Stengel teaching this course was effectively a one-time thing while Kasdin was on sabbatical. Look at previous semesters of reviews, not this one.

Take it with Kasdin if you're interested with the subject. Stengel's brilliant, but the lectures are incredibly dry, and the assignments can fluctuate wildly in difficulty. The information is super interesting though.
Take it!

Take the class but expect to be overwhelmed and at times bored. Take note of the things that interest you and then look them up yourself later or reach out to Professor Stengel for more information. Professor Stengel is always willing to meet with students and talk about assignments, the lectures, or really anything else. You can even just walk up to his office and knock; he will often make time for you then and there. Prepare yourself for the problem sets appropriately and make sure to work ahead.
The course is very interesting and Prof. Stengel is very knowledgeable!

The problem sets take longer than you think. You can also get through this course without doing too much work, but what you get out of this course is entirely dependent on what you put into the course. And so, I would highly recommend getting involved in the group problem sets. Also, learn Matlab when you have a chance.
Very interesting course if you're interested in Systems Engineering

You probably have to take this class if you have taken MAE341...but if you can avoid this, I think you should. I can't speak for future runs, but this class had little to do with designing spacecraft. Almost all of it was simply a continuation of MAE341, just in a more complex and arbitrary form. Be prepared: Professor Stengel likes to assign groups randomly.
prereqs: MAE 305. MAE 341 recommended or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines the design of a modern spacecraft or complex space system, including the space environment and its impact on design. The principals and design aspects of the structure, propulsion, power, thermal, communication, and attitude subsystems are studied. The course also introduces systems engineering, project management, manufacturing and test, mission operations, mission design, and space policy. Acting as a single project team, students will design a satellite or space system from conception to critical design review.

title: Theory of Knowledge
reviews: A very interesting course, especially if you liked the flavor of previous metaphysics/epistemology classes. Harman's lectures are not everyone's cup of tea, but they can be rather pleasant. The readings are crucial to the class, although they're very interesting and not too long.

TAKE THIS IF HARMAN IS TEACHING!!! He makes what would normally be a very dry topic witty and fun. If you're willing to sit through slow-paced lectures, you'll enjoy seeing Professor Harman every week and basically chatting with a leader in his field for an hour three times a week.
Take it if ur interested
Take this course if you need to fulfill the requirement because it's certainly painless, but you might find something more intellectually stimulating elsewhere.

Take this course if you want an easy pass-fail, but if you actually want to learn from a philosophy course, I would recommend other courses. Professor Harman is so much fun to be around, and I am not sure if he will be co-teaching another course. If so, I have high hopes for it and it might be worth taking!
descrip: This course will examine central issues in contemporary epistemology. Topics covered will include the following: skeptical arguments that all we can really know about are our own private thoughts and experiences; the nature of testimony and our dependence upon others (including others far removed from us in space and time) for much of what we ordinarily take ourselves to know; questions about what makes an argument rationally compelling. Why (if at all) should we value knowing the truth?

title: Capitalism, Utopia, and Social Justice
descrip: See website

title: Solar Cells: Physics, Materials, and Technology
reviews: Highly recommend for student interseted in semiconductor devices, such as solar cells, LED. The course covers almost all kinds od solar cells, materials, designs, etc. Prof. Rand is very nice. Wo not take long time to finish the assgnments.
I would highly recommend this course for all who are interested in solar technology.

This course provides a nice, comprehensive overview of solar cells and how different devices operate. Moreover, it provides an introduction to research efforts being made for future solar cells. A previous class on semiconductor devices is helpful, but not necessary as Prof. Rand will work with you outside of class to get you caught up. Class expectations (homework, lab, etc.) are very relevant in solidifying your understanding of the concepts, and are a good use of your time.
descrip: Photovoltaic materials & devices discussed. Topics: solar flux distribution & spectra, photovoltaic parameters, loss mechanisms, Shockley-Queisser detailed balance approach, stability, light management, module design & various solar cell technologies, drawing distinctions between heterojunction and homojunction devices including crystalline Si and III-V & thin film cells such as CIGS, CdTe, dye sensitized, & organic. In-dept treatment of organic solar cells, including lab to fabricate & analyze an organic solar cell. Finally, we present methods to go beyond classical limits, such as intermediate band solar cells & multijunction devices.

title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: If Jianfei Chen and Tao Peng are teaching this class, definitely take it. Actually, I'm sure all the Chinese teachers here are really good, so take it regardless. The textbook readings are stimulating texts about Chinese culture and really gets you thinking. There's a lot of memorization (vocabulary), but hey, it's a language class.
It's hard, but take it 100%. 10/10 course.
Know that in order to learn the subject matter well you must spend quite a bit of time
Memorize vocab lists and word nuances.
Practice speaking a lot/as much as you can!
Take it! You'll get to know the Chinese teachers very well, and the student environment is very encouraging.

This is a good class for improving your Chinese, and I found it very chill. The teachers are great and care about not making you too stressed, but at the same time demand a lot out of you to help your Chinese level improve.
take it if you can and want to! small classes are great.
prereqs: CHI 305 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 305, designed to further improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of essays published in contemporary Chinese newspapers and magazines.

title: Topics in Arithmetic Geometry - Elliptic Curves over Function Fields
prereqs: Undergraduates must request permission of instructor..
descrip: Over the course of the semester, the class will discuss various problems about arithmetic geometry of elliptic curves over function fields, including modular parametrizations by Shtukas, Waldspueger and Gross-Zagier formulas for the special values of L-functions as well as recent developments.

title: Intersectional Activisms and Movements for Social Justice
reviews: A class that will broaden your world view. Professor Strolovitch was heavy on the reading list but an understanding and compassionate professor.
I would encourage any student interested in activism - from both an academic or practical perspective - to take this class!
I would recommend the course but caution about the reading load and encourage students who don't mind less structured discussions to take it.
I would recommend this course as the issues are worth thinking through and the selection of readings is quite good.
I'd highly recommend that anyone who is thinking about race, gender, sexuality, etc. and activism take this course in order to consider more critically some of the problems present in that activism.

Overall, I would recommend the course. Recognize though, it is an upper level seminar and the readings can be quite dense. It is presently structured as a mix of theory and then application to various movements in the second half. That said, it is interesting material and Professor Strolovitch is really supportive- I definitely think you will learn a lot about intersectionality theory and intersectional movements if you take the course.
This class has an insane amount of work, but it can be very rewarding. Professor Strolovitch is also great and very understanding. Take if you can!

This was one of the most important classes I've taken at Princeton, and it was only fitting that I took in during my last semester. Take the course if you want to explore your own intersectionality or just social movements that grapple with these difficult concepts. Everything--the readings, assignments, Professor Strolovitch--was great.
descrip: Examines the role of intersectionality roots as a political intervention growing out of and based in movement politics. Begins with early articulations of intersectional perspectives on the part of Black feminists and feminists of colour, emphasizing its movement roots. Examines empirical research about social movements and political activism, focusing on scholarship that considers both the potential of and the challenges to movements that try to address the imbrication of racial inequalities with other forms of marginalization and domination, including (though not limited to) heteropatriarchy, capitalism, abelism, and the carceral state.

title: Topics in International Relations - International Relations in East Asia
descrip: This course reviews and analyzes the foreign policy of the People's Republic of China from 1949 to the present. It examines Beijing's relations with the Soviet Union, the United States, Northeast Asia, Southeast Asia, and the Third World during the Cold War, and discusses the future of Chinese foreign policy in light of the end of the Cold War, changes in the Chinese economy, the post-Tiananmen legitimacy crisis in Beijing, and the continuing rise of Chinese power and influence in Asia and beyond.

title: Principles of Quantum Engineering
reviews: Great class. Professor Shayegan is amazing and explains the material very clearly.
If Professor Shayegan is co-teaching the course again, take it.  With Alejandro's energy, and Shayegan's wisdom, the course was awesome this past year.
Take it.
Take the course if you have an interest in Quantum Mechanics and want to go into devices... The pace is manageable and covers a lot of information.
This course was graded very fairly, and was not scary at all. I learned a lot about quantum, and I would highly recommend that you take this course if you are an engineer.
This is a really good course, and you'll be fine if you stay on top of things (read the notes, the textbook, and go to office hours if things are unclear).
prereqs: (PHY 103 or PHY 105) and (PHY 104 or PHY 106).
descrip: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the basic principles that govern the operation of modern solid state and optoelectronic devices. The emphasis is on fundamentals rather than applications. The major portion of the course will be devoted to quantum mechanics and statistical physics with examples from solid state and materials physics and quantum electronics. This provides the basic background needed to understand the physics of device operations and also prepares the student for more advanced courses in solid state and quantum electronics (such as ELE 441, 442 and 453). For more details, see Undergraduate Announcement.

title: Physical Oceanography
reviews: A great refresher of GFD even for people who work on the atmosphere.
Read Vallis Ch. 14-16 before the lectures.
Review the lecture notes before class! Rong references concepts from previous lectures regularly.
descrip: Response of the ocean to transient and steady winds and buoyancy forcing. A hierarchy of models from simple analytical to realistic numerical models is used to study the role of the waves, convection, instabilities, and other physical processes in the circulation of the oceans.

title: Advanced Spanish
reviews: Attend class.

Awesome! Professor Bores is such a good teacher. She's really kind to students, always helpful in class, speaks clearly, and generally makes it a comfortable learning environment. I really really feel like this semester has improved my verbal fluency and writing skills!
Difficult and the writing assignments are very personal.
Do not be afraid to take this course. The instructors are fair, caring, and helpful and well as great at teaching.
Good course if you like Spanish.
Great course! Nadia is the best :)

I took this course to fulfil the language requirement and even though I usually hate language classes this one wasn't that bad. There's a lot of busy work but most of it is interesting so it isn't too painful. Language classes are nice because the class is small so you bond with your classmates. We had a lot of fun in this class and Nadia Cervantes Perez is a great instructor!
I would recommend the course to anyone seeking to improve in Spanish.
If you're taking this you probably don't have much choice. At least it isn't five days a week
It's a distribution requirement.
It's a lot of work and time, but it will help a lot with your engagement with Spanish.
Make sure you participate!! It helps you learn more and it affects your grade a lot. Take if you need to - it's a good advanced level foreign language class.

Monserrat is a great professor and a really nice person. Read her comments on your work carefully and study the vocabulary, and you will learn Spanish this semester. There is a lot of work but I believe it's worth it.
Most people taking this don't really have a choice anyway, but its a fine class so don't be bummed about it.
Not a very hard course and you learn a lot of Spanish.
Participate and take a genuine interest.
Pay close attention to the grammar lessons.

TAKE THE CLASS! 
It's so much fun.
Lots of work that will keep you busy everyday, but your spanish really does improve and you get such a great sense of accomplishemnt.
Take it and make the most of it.

Take it with Nadia! You'll address stimulating cultural issues unfolding in the Spanish-speaking world with a fun variety of stories, movies, and other texts; do fun group projects with your peers; and generally be astounded by how much your speaking and writing abilities will improve. Nadia wants to see you improve and feel comfortable with the language, and will do anything to help you succeed. Challenging for those with little exposure to Spanish prior to college, but do-able and definitely worth it.

Take this course if you want to have a pretty good basis in Spanish (but maybe not able to speak as well as you can write or read). More work than SPA 105 but not by much and worth it if you like the language.

Take this course. It is amazing. Sna. Borres was an amazing professor. The class itself is so enriching, leaves you with a greater appreciation for the entire Spanish language, and improves your reading, writing, and especially speaking skills tremendously.

Take this course. It will be the first language course that you have taken which is interesting in itself. I would have taken it, even if it were in English. The content is fun, and you'll improve a lot.
This class is pretty laidback and very doable, class i interesting and professor is really nice.
This class is very helpful in improving language skills, but make sure to keep up with the grammatical concepts.
This course will really teach you about the cultures related to the Spanish language through the use of the language.
This is a great course to help complete the language distribution requirement.

This was a great class where I improved a lot with my Spanish, learned a lot about different cultures and history, got to know my classmates, and had fun! Be sure to really commit to speaking Spanish in class and doing your best with assignments and I believe you can be proficient in Spanish by the end of this course.

Unlike 105, this course emphasizes speaking and writing over pure grammar. Still a lot of work, but definitely rewarding and thought-provoking. The course materials are very well organized and focus primarily on the chicano and chilango cultures of LA and Mexico City. Professor Cervantes is fantastic, and she does an excellent job presenting the material.
VERY harsh grading compared to 105. Really excessive workload. Take 107 to fulfill the language requirement instead of 108.

You'll take it because you have to, and you probably won't love it. I doubt this is an indication of the quality of the upper-level Spanish classes. The course wasn't overly rigorous, but wasn't graded as easily as it perhaps should have been. Very easy to get a B, hard to get an A.
go to office hours and meet with Montserrat. She is extremely helpful and explains concepts in a way that will be tested on th exam.
take it!
prereqs: SPA 105 or satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test. SPA 108 is offered both semesters..
descrip: SPA 108 develops fluency and precision in speaking and writing by focusing on functional language in context. It aims to strengthen and consolidate comprehension and production of oral and written Spanish by paying attention to cultural awareness and cross-cultural communication. Through a series of current and thought-provoking texts, images, films, paintings, and related activities, this course enhances linguistic proficiency and language performance while reflecting on important aspects of the history, art, society, language and cultural identity of two of the largest Spanish-speaking urban communities: Mexico City and Los Angeles.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Juniors only (except for sophomores who have completed EGR 251)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Development - Global Challenges of Infection, Burden & Control
descrip: An exploration of the biological, public health and global dimensions of infectious disease. The basic features of human-microbe interactions by examining several viral, bacterial and parasitic infections are analyzed.. Emphasis includes biology, burden of illness and domestic and global forces shaping the expanding threat. Control strategies, including chemotherapy, vaccines and environmental changes; and the role of international organizations such as WHO, UNICEF, and GAVI and the major philanthropies, are considered.

title: Readings in Western American History
reviews: Good class! No prior reading knowledge necessary. Engaging prof!
She does a very good job of leading discussion but has a very hard time seeing the value of approaches, ideas, and opinions that differ from her own. She will line edit your reading journal.
Take this class! It will challenge received wisdom about the American West while offering key insights into historical craft and the significance of studying the past.
descrip: This readings course focuses on the central problems engaged by recent scholarship on the American West, with particular attention given to how this regional history intersects with the larger thematic concerns of national history. Topics to be addressed include environmental history, Native American history, race, gender, urban history and popular culture.

title: What Is Art?
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Beginner's Russian II
reviews: Absolutely recommend taking it. One of the best taught introductory language classes at Princeton.

Definitely take this class! Russian is an amazing, beautiful language, and starting next year this class will have a textbook designed by the professor that will be soooo much better than the old textbook (have seen snippets). The teachers are very helpful, and Russian is a wonderful language with a rich history and a global relevance. Could not recommend it enough.
Definitely take this if you have an interest in Russian! Great teachers

I would strongly recommend Russian 102! (Of course, you have to first take 101, but I'd recommend that too.) RUS 102 is where you start feeling like you have a real grasp of the language - forming real sentences and so forth.
I'm not going to lie: Russian is a hard language, so don't expect an easy A. If you want to learn Russian, though, then there's no better way to do it.

Russian has been by far one of my best experiences academic experiences at Princeton. Russian itself is a challenging language but the class is extremely well run and you learn an amazing amount in such a short time
Take it,Mark knows the material in and out, and If you speak another language, chances are he knows it and he can help you make connections to it. The workload is also manageable.
Take some personal time to study Russian on your own. This can be as simple as reviewing vocabulary once a day. It will be very helpful for retention.
Take this course because you enjoy Russian.
You will learn so much from Mark and end the year with a solid foundation in Russian.  I think it is pretty averagely demanding of a 102 language class.
prereqs: RUS 101 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The objective of RUS 102 is to give a basic knowledge of Russian: basic training in speaking, reading, writing, and comprehending the Russian language in a cultural context.

title: Directed Research
prereqs: Students must prepare a written plan for research and submit copies to the supervising faculty member and DGS for approval before enrolling in the course..
descrip: Under the supervision of a faculty member, students carryout research on a directed topic and present results. Students must identify a supervising faculty member and submit a written plan for research and evaluation which must be approved by the supervising faculty member and director of graduate studies.

title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy II
reviews: Excellent course, interesting and useful methods in various IO topics, also useful for people not taking the IO general.
Helpful for anyone interested in applied work.
descrip: Theoretical and empirical study of the public regulation and deregulation of rate of return, prices, and entry in public utilities and franchise oligopolies. Theory and practice of antitrust policy is examined, including some elements of antitrust law. In addition, regulation of product quality, advertising, and safety is examined. This course draws heavily on material developed in 541.

title: Independent Study I
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Minmin Fan in E-211..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.

title: Viscous Flows and Boundary Layers
reviews: A lot of work as the semester goes on, will make you think a lot, but definitely an amazing course worth taking.
Challenging but rewarding.  I learned a lot after a rather weak undergraduate fluids background.
Definitely a worthwhile and intellectually stimulating course. Despite 8:30 am lectures, it was exciting to go to class each day.
Definitely take this course. It's a privilege to be in that classroom.
Even if your not a mechanical engineer you will learn a lot about fluid mechanics and how it can be applied in a broader context. Very interesting, but also challenging.

Excellent course that will drastically improve your understand of fluid mechanics.  Although the course has a lot of homework, the assignments are helpful for learning the material and ingraining the concepts in your memory.
Good

Not only does this course cover a wide spectrum of fluid dynamics topics and apply them to relevant problems of study, but it does so in an interesting and clear way. It does move at a fast pace, so it is necessary to review material after lectures to fully understand it, and the homework aids in this process. In addition, learning from Dr. Stone is a wonderful experience from his lectures to his investment in his students. I would highly recommend this to any engineer who is either interested in fluid dynamics or in teaching later in their career.

Read the lecture notes provided by Professor Stone. Review the lecture notes after class and before tackling each problem set. Start on the problem sets early, for they will take a long time to complete.
Take this, highly recommended.
The lecture is very fast-paced. The problem sets can be challenging sometimes. It is a great and rigorous introductory course to fluid mechanics.

The material is engaging and fundamental. Stone presents it beautifully and draws your attention to details you would have otherwise missed. Enjoy it. Get started early on the Psets, and ask lots of questions.
This course is a great one for those interested in fluid mechanics. Be ready for lots of chugging through math in the homework, though.
This is a difficult yet rewarding class.
This is a very insightful class that you will learn so much from. It is also very challenging. This class is absolutely essential for understanding fluid mechanics.
Try best to understand homework, don't wait till last minute on assignments. Ask Dr. Stone to explain problems if needed. He is very helpful.
Try your best to keep up in lecture; they are very helpful if you can! And you learn a lot from the homeworks too!
Very interesting course if interested in fluid dynamics. The professor covers a lot of material, but I recommend it.
You need to spend really a lot of time in this class. This class would also be a challenge of your mathematical skills.
descrip: An introduction to the mechanics of viscous flows. The kinematics and dynamics of viscous flows. Exact solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations. Lubrication theory. The behavior of vorticity. The boundary layer approximation. Laminar boundary layers with and without pressure gradients. Introduction to stability. Introduction to turbulence.

title: Nonlinear Processes in Fluids and Plasmas
reviews: At least doing the homeworks is helpful, but best would be to go through the lectures by hand, paying special attention to the recommended exercises. If you have a lot of time to review this material, you can learn an amazing amount from this course.
Prof. Krommes is an authority in the field of plasma turbulence. For those young ones, who wish to do research in this domain, this course is an excellent introduction to the field.
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to the theory of nonlinear phenomena in fluids and plasmas, with emphasis on turbulence and transport. Experimental phenomenology; fundamental equations, including Navier-Stokes, Vlasov, and gyrokinetic; numerical simulation techniques, including pseudo-spectral and particle-in-cell methods; coherent structures; transition to turbulence; statistical closures, including the wave kinetic equation and direct-interaction approximation; PDF methods and intermittency; variational techniques. Applications from neutral fluids, fusion plasmas, and astrophysics.

title: Environmental Engineering and Energy
reviews: A very easy and stimulating course.

Do take this course-- very low commitment while giving you an appreciation and awareness for environmental issues. Assignments are enjoyable in the sense that you're able to choose your own topic and explore an area of environmental issue that you are personally interested in. Before taking this class I was indifferent about environmental movements; now I am much more inspired to be a more environmentally responsible individual and to help inform others of what they can do to make our practices on Earth more sustainable. Also more convinced that environmental engineers are the real-life superheroes...

Take this course! It was taught by a new professor this semester so I was unsure what it would be like but it was really good. The structure where different environmental and energy challenges were presented each week was easy to follow and also really stimulating because the prof. related them to current events and brought in lots of guest lecturers to teach the bits they were experts in. There was no homework and instead we went to office hours once every two weeks to talk to the prof so she could make sure we were following classes. These office hours were really enjoyable and inspiring since we just talked about what had caught our attention and what we wanted to know more about. I really enjoyed doing the projects because we got to pick whatever topics we wanted so I could focus on what I had experience with and was interested in. Great class for senior spring - not too work intensive and really interesting!

Take this course!!! The topics are extremely interesting and it is rather low-commitment. You choose your own topics for the various projects so you're very engaged and doing research is interesting, not daunting. You get to learn about all sorts of environmental issues and you might get to taste some of Prof Peters' delicious vegan treats. Go talk to the professor every other week or so!

This course is a great survey of how environmental engineering addresses energy challenges. It's not too much work, and you don't need a quantitative background. Lectures are interesting, and engagement is necessary because discussions in class and meetings with the professor outside of class are important components.
prereqs: CHM 201 and MAT 104 (can be taken concurrently) or permission of the instructor.
descrip: In our sustainable future, the world's energy needs will be met while protecting natural resources and minimizing risks to human health. The course covers the environmental and geological engineering principles relevant to the entire energy supply chain from mining and extraction of fuels, to power production, to disposal of wastes and sequestration of greenhouse gases. Both conventional and renewable energy are considered. Students will learn the engineering principles and practices to address environmental challenges and to find the best ways to utilize earth systems to our advantage.

title: Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
reviews: Definitely take it. No reason not to. It won't be much work at all.

Do take it! Not only is it an incredible opportunity to take the class with Jhumpa Lahiri, but if you are at all interested in translation, it is a great class to try your hand at it and you will certainly surprise yourself! The workload is not that heavy, and it's PDF, so it's also a good 5th class, if that's what you're looking for.

Professor Lahiri is a great teacher, and her insights into this subject, both as author and translator, are fascinating. A good chance to get some practical experience translating anything you are interested in.

Unless you really enjoy translation, this class does not offer the same amount of liberties that a fiction or poetry class might. There is much less room for being "unique" and adventurous in translating that comes very easily in other CWR workshops.
prereqs: Students apply by submitting a writing sample of 3-4 pages of translations and a paragraph describing their interest in the author(s) included in the sample, noting any previous experience with the genre. No prerequisites. Application deadline is November 22, 2015..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students must be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Listening In: Sonic Culture in American History
descrip: See website

title: Community in Historical Perspective
descrip: This course examines how historians have employed the notion of community in the study of the past. While the majority of our readings emerge from scholarship on communities in early modern Europe, we also look at examples from other times and places. What insights does the notion of community release into the historical study of the past? What insights does it inhibit?

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Military Force Planning & Decision Making
descrip: Course introduces important issues of conventional force planning and military decision making and includes discussion of service cultures, doctrines, capabilities, and limitations. Broadly covers strategy, planning, readiness, force projection, employment, and logistics throughout the spectrum of conflict, including conventional war, the global war on terrorism and peacekeeping operations. Through theoretical and doctrinal readings and examination of selected case studies, course provides background essential for those involved in the study and practice of national security decision making.

title: Art and Science of Motorcycle Design
descrip: See website

title: Recent Advances in Cosmology (Half-Term)
descrip: This half-term course focuses on problems with the current paradigms of the early universe (big bang inflation), dark matter (weakly interacting massive particles) and dark energy (cosmological constant and analyze recent approaches for resolving the problems. The course uses published literature for the readings.

title: Philosophical Analysis Using Argument Maps
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Psychology
reviews: A good class to fulfill an STL distribution, particularly for students unfamiliar with any of the science courses
A great "extra" class. If you've ever been interested in psychology, Princeton does it well.

An okay course to take for STL, not uninteresting topics, but not necessarily my highest recommendation. Very broad. The midterm and final can be a lot of material to study that wasn't covered in lecture, and it's npdf..

Choose something more specialized I would say. The guest lectures are pretty cool but you'll like those way more than n your everyday lectures, so why not just take a class in it instead of wasting your time with general psych?
Definitely a survey course. The readings and lab were rather dry. A good STL if that's your motivation for taking this course. Otherwise, I would advise against it.
Definitely a very good STL, pretty interesting.

Don't take this class. Just don't. It's mind-numbingly boring and you learn so very little that is new. It is the worst class I have taken at Princeton. It's one of those classes that you take if you don't care to be inspired by the subject material and only want an STL. This class is a serious waste of time.
Don't take this course unless you have to. It's boring, a waste of time.
Gives a good survey of topics in psychology and easily accessible to someone who hasn't taken psychology. Enjoyable lectures.
Go to lectures, try to read the textbook chapters, and stay on top of your assignments. Don't let negligence deteriorate your grades.
I thought Professor Cooper was a great lecturer. Also, labs are improving each year.

I would not recommend this class if you're just trying to get an STL or fulfilling a PSY requirement. While I love Prof Cooper (amazing man) the class is a whole is somehow both boring and hard to do well in, the labs are tedious and uninteresting and I would recommend trying a higher level PSY course rather than taking 101.
I wouldn't take this course for an STL. Take Bridges or something else instead. If you're a psych major, it's alright.

I wouldn't take this course. It's pointless if you're a psych major since it isn't a requirement for the concentration. It covers a ton of material in a short span of time, and exams are incredibly random and specific. Don't take it for an STL or an easy grade.

If Joel Cooper is teaching it, TAKE IT! He is absolutely amazing and really made the course interesting for people not interested in Psych. He's really engaging and helpful with any questions. Labs suck and are annoying but seem pretty easy compared to other STLs, just take sometime
It isn't necessary to do all the readings. Lectures are engaging, labs are a bit boring. The tests are specific as a result, difficult.
It's a good intro to psychology! Professor Cooper is awesome.

Labs were horrible. The lectures with Professor Cooper were pretty good though. Not the worst way to get an STL out of the way, but I'd look elsewhere for something actually interesting and well-organized.
Lecture is the highlight (over labs). Try to skim through the readings, although the textbook is too long.
Make sure to keep up with the readings and go to every lecture
Not the best STL. They are constantly changing the labs etc so it may be different in the following semesters but was not a huge fan of this class.
Overall it's an interesting and easy STL if you want to complete the distribution requirement or figure out if you're interested in psych.

Pay attention to lecture and really understand the experiments and explanations behind theories. If you're looking for a class that briefly introduces many psych concepts, this is for you. If you want to explore psychology in-depth, this is not the best course.
Reccomend.
Start studying for the midterm and final a few weeks ahead of time so you don't have to cram.
Take if you need an STL, but be ready to switch into a good lab section because your lab will make or break your course experience.
Take it if you really like psych or if you need it. Not the best lass for fun as TAs don't explain much and lectures/book coincide in some ways but not many which makes midterms and exams hard.
Take this class if you are unsure about majoring in psych.
Take this course b/c its interesting and you need it to be a psych major!

Take this course, much better than in years past, the labs are pretty interesting, the midterm curve is only applied at the end of the year, you need to make sure you really study for the midterm as while many students think they did well, the grading was tougher than expected.
The course is useful if you want to explore a potential interest in psychology.
The course material is not difficult but the labs are poorly organized. Still, the labs aren't difficult, either.

There are easier STL courses (that you can PDF) and better psychology courses.  The material in this course isn't difficult at all, but it can be a lot of time-consuming work.  A lot of the concepts covered are common knowledge, so if you really want to learn new material don't take this.
This class in not a bad STL for those who are not in STEM  but gets very monotonous and dull.
This course is fun, but be prepared to memorize a lot of small things rather than bigger concepts.
This is a good course to take to fulfill an STL, but be wary -- this is absolutely a course where you get out of it what you put it.
This is a very approachable STL, the labs are interesting and not super time consuming and Professor Cooper is engaging.
This is not a bad choice for fulfilling the STL requirement. The Midterm was graded surprisingly harshly, which is something to consider. However, the labs are very manageable as well as enjoyable.
Very broad overview of psychology. Do the readings

Would not really recommend this course, especially if you've already taken psychology. As someone who had, I learned very little, did a fair amount of busy work in lab, and still didn't get the grade that I hoped for. Prof. Cooper is fine.
good lab, interesting subject, simple
take labs very seriously
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course can be used to satisfy the science and technology with laboratory general education requirement.

title: Quantum Optics
reviews: A thorough understanding of quantum mechanics is helpful before beginning this course. While the material can become complex and somewhat messy towards the end of the course, the final project is extremely rewarding and allows for the most thorough learning and understanding of the material.
Good course, presents complicated material in a very accessible way.  Need strong background in quantum mechanics to keep up and the course project is a lot of work however.

If you want to work on quantum optics or related disciplines, definitely sign up for this course. It has the right balance of theory, physics, homework and an independent project-work section at the end.
The psets for this course are not too much work, keep up with the lectures and you will be rewarded in the final project- good addition to the physicist's toolbox!

This class is very theory heavy and most of it is deriving different phenomena on the board. While I enjoyed it for the most part, this class can be difficult if you have not taken a fair amount of quantum already (e.g., familiarity with operators, commutation relations, Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures, etc.).
Topics cover recent developments in quantum optics. Final project is difficult, but after this course you will be quite up to date on some specific areas of AMO physics.
descrip: Semiclassical field theory of light-matter interactions. Quantum theory of light, vacuum fluctuations and photons. Quantum states and coherence properties of the EM field, photon counting and interferometry. Quantum theory of light-matter interactions, Jaynes-Cummigns (JC) model. Physical realizations of JC model, case study:circuit QED. Quantum theory of damping. Resonance fluorescence. Coupled quantum non-linear systems.

title: Advanced Arabic II
prereqs: ARA 301 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Study of Modern Standard Arabic at the advanced level, continued from ARA 301. Attention given to speaking, listening, reading and writing, with special emphasis on grammar and readings in a variety of authentic texts.

title: Policy Research Seminar
reviews: Beware of lots and lots of readings if you are in Kotkin's seminar, but take it if you like to push yourself and want to learn a lot.
Centeno is amazing.
Great course.
If you like psychology; if you're interested in why people are polarized on any given topic, and the implications of that polarization for people and for policy, then take it.
It's independent work- you have to learn everything on your own for the most part. Be ready to put in time.
It's unfortunate that WWS makes you take this. Writing a JP can be an incredible process--the way this class is structured made it far more reductive than empowering.
Make sure to take advantage of office hours.
Method's lab will be a pain, but definitely take advantage of the TA's for office hours. I wouldn't have been able to do my quant research without Carlos or Tyler!
Necessary but helpful
One of the best and most engaging ones, would recommend if you're stuck between this and one or two other courses.
Professor Yashar is excellent and her section will make you a better writer and thinker.
Take prof Yashar's course!
The topic is interesting, but  hope you get a good group
Use methods lab as 2 hours of study hall. Go to the preceptors/methods lab professors for help because they will fix all your problems.
We don't have a choice in taking this course.  Enjoy the effort the professors put in, and try not to be too peeved at how useless the class seems.
You have to take it anyway.
prereqs: Assignment to these seminars is by a separate application process through the department..
descrip: The junior policy research seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in policy research and writing. Students may choose from a range of topics.

title: Composition
descrip: Emphasis is placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.

title: Pro-Sem in Chinese & Japanese Studies - A History of Money in East Asia from Antiquity to the Early 20thC
descrip: General seminar dealing with the problems and possibilities of research peculiar to the fields of East Asian Studies. This year, the topic is a history of money in East Asia from antiquity to the early twentieth century.

title: Beginner's Italian II
reviews: Absolutely participate in class and do the homework before hand so you seem like you know what you are talking about. I would suggest studying before the day of the quiz because they are challenging but if you know the language like you should you will get an A. Go to office hours and discuss what you did wrong because its helpful and the professors are interesting and will love you more for it.

De Feo is amazing, definitely try to take it with him. Not too hard as long as you study for the bi-weekly quizzes and keep up with the homework but it's not too much work and is rewarding since you learn a ton.
Definitely take Italian.
Definitely take this class with Sara Teardo!
Do all of the daily homework. You will be tested on it every day. Just do it after class and get it over with if you can. Then it is fresh in your mind.
Go to class! Even just listening to others speak Italian will help you improve your skills.
I hope that everyone will consider this.
I would recommend studying with other students to discuss/clarify difficult concepts before exams.

I've loved my intro Italian courses this year.  They are laid back and the professors are full of energy and personality.  I personally found the online exercises a bit annoying and easy to forget about, though.
Keep up with the material and homework, especially on quiz weeks. It helps to speak Italian aloud when you study, even if you're just reading from the textbook.
Take it if not particular on which language. All the professors are amazing and truly care about your progress.

Teardo and Dossena are two of the most fun people and engaged instructors you could find on campus. They make learning Italian engaging and easy. The workload is very light but you still learn a great amount of Italian. If nothing else, take this course just for the instructors!

The Italian department is full of lovely people who are a joy to take classes with. Would definitely recommend taking this as lang. requirement if needed (or if you're interested in Italian!) Not too intense of a class and the professors create a nice atmosphere. I really liked class with Daniele or Dossena
The department is very nice and engaging. Take it if you truly want to learn the language. Straightforward language, much easier than others.
The italian department is most definitely the best language department at princeton

This course is necessary in order for you to get credit for taking 101, but it's just as fun and interesting! I'd especially recommend this course to those who have a background in Spanish or French. Don't forget to do online coursework as it can pile up quickly.
prereqs: ITA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Further study of Italian grammar and syntax with increased emphasis on vocabulary, reading, and practice in conversation. Skills in speaking and writing (as well as understanding) modern Italian will also be further developed. Some aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering - Trustworthy Computing
reviews: Don't recommend taking - timing consuming, and don't learn too much.
It's a good course that covers lots of emerging areas. Beneficial if you are working in this field. Requires background knowledge.
Strongly recommended this course.
This course is useful and must be attended.
descrip: How can we design computer systems to be more trustworthy and secure? We consider cloud computing systems, smartphones and IoT (Internet-of-Things) devices, integrating security in hardware, software and networking components. We discuss concepts like self-protecting data, dynamic information flow tracking, thwarting information leakage through side-channel attacks, preserving availability, detecting abnormal behavior, novel ways of authenticating users, security verification, and designing secure processors, caches, memory systems and virtual machines. Suitable for students interested in security, computer architecture or system design.

title: Financial History
reviews: Do all the readings.

I strongly recommend this seminar if you have an interest in finance and want to learn more about the history behind the financial instruments and institutions you have learned about in other classes.
Not the hardest or most engaging class... But, man, it is super boring.
Pretty easy class that covers a lot of material that pertains to issues today. Definitely take, James is awesome.
Stay up to date on the readings and make a list of key terms and you will have no problems.
Take it if you're interested, but only if you plan to participate actively and do the readings, otherwise it's really a waste of time for you.
definitely take it!
descrip: The course examines the history of financial innovation and its consequences. It examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, and securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader development? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility? How is resulting conflict and instability managed, on both a national and international level?

title: Intensive Korean II
reviews: Definitely recommend if you want to learn more Korean.
Do your work, read through the slides, study vocabulary.
It's a great class for touching up on Korean. The fact that they're 1.5 hours is a little annoying, but it's a lot better than having to go to class every day.
Korean is the best
Take if you know how to speak korean but don't really know how grammar works in Korean.
