This course is for students who already have a significant background in Korean. I would highly recommend taking the course if you have been placed in the course. Make sure to do all the assignments and to attend classes. I would recommend making a list of frequently made mistakes and reviewing that list in addition to other course materials.
? ??? is so great!! This has been one of my favorite classes. If you are a heritage speaker, this class is a great balance of challenging and rewarding
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. Credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing two-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: A continuation of Korean 103. This course covers the 2nd Year Korean material focusing on complex grammatical structures, reading, and writing. Journals are kept for writing practice. The students who have successfully completed KOR 103 and KOR 108 will be placed in the 3rd or 4th year Korean if they wish to continue.

title: American Museums: History, Theory, and Practice
reviews: She takes few grades throughout the semester, so the final is worth a lot and there isn't much build up.  Very interesting course especially because you get to travel off campus to visit museums.

Super interesting!  Take this course if you're interested in museums and/or museum work and you want to take a course that will be different from the rest of your courseload.  The field trips are super interesting and the professor invites lots of guest lecturers.   You'll come out of the class with a much better appreciation for all of the work that goes into running a museum and an understanding of why curators do what they do.

Take this course if you have interest in museums! It's a great way to learn a little about art history, while understanding the complexities of an institution we take for granted. Readings are the best I've done at Princeton.

The behind-the-scenes looks into the Princeton University Art Museum and other museums were a once-in-a-lifetime experience and the class was thoroughly interesting and engaging. Having a small background in art history is helpful, but not at all necessary. Professor McCauley brings a very unique perspective to museum studies and she was very thought-provoking. Readings are extremely interesting, have little jargon, and are of a manageable size. Classes always change so they keep you excited to attend: hearing a lecture, meeting a museum director, talking to a curator, seeing storage, going to our conservation room. Take this class!!! You get to go on field trips to museums and see awesome things!!
very good
prereqs: Art majors should have had at least one 300-level course in the Dept. of Art and Archaeology. Students majoring in history, anthropology, public policy, and American Studies with an interest in cultural studies and museum work are particularly welcome..
descrip: Museums are privileged places where material artifacts from the manmade and natural world are preserved, shown, studied, classified, and refashioned into narratives about our past, amusements for our leisure hours, and models for our future. Why did these institutions appear and what do they say about our values and selective/collective memories? Through readings, field trips, meetings with museum staff, and practical exercise, students will explore the history of American museums (art, ethnographic, natural history, material culture) and the challenges that they confront in an increasingly multi-cultural and digital age.

title: Introduction to Screenwriting: Writing for a Global Audience
reviews: Absolutely fantastic class with a terrific professor. If you want to become a better screenwriter, or just a better writer/story writer in general, take it! Only take it, though, if you're going to be engaged and excited about your work. I would also recommend going into it with glimmers of story ideas in your head, as there's not too much time to think of story ideas in the class as there is to develop those ideas.
I loved this course!  If you're interested in learning about screenwriting, Professor Lazaridi is an excellent teacher.

Really great course! You will learn so much about the particularities of screenwriting as an art form. If you are used to other forms of creative writing, screenwriting well definitely take you down a totally different lane. It's fun to write the screenplays and get/give critiques, and it's a very light workload.
Strongly recommend to all students with even a passing interest in creative writing or screenwriting.
Take the class if you are curious about the subject.
Take this class! Professor Lazaridi is amazing. She offers great guidance on writing and is super nice and approachable.
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (http://arts.princeton.edu/academics/creative-writing/creative-writing-courses/) by attaching a statement about why they want to take the course and a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre..
descrip: How can screenwriters prepare for the evolving challenges of our global media world? What types of content, as well as form, will emerging technologies make possible? Do fields like neuroscience help us understand the universal principals behind screenwriting and do tech advances that alter the distance between audience and creator, man and machine, also influence content of our stories? This class will use fairytales, films, games and new media to illustrate universal script principles while creating a rich interdisciplinary lens to explore the innovative intersection of narrative screenwriting, science and technology.

title: Automatic Control Systems
reviews: 99% of students taking this class are required to. If the university ever offers an alternative, take it. Take this course with easy classes.
Definitely take this class (although if you're MAE you have to). It's extremely well taught, the labs don't have reports, and the problem sets are fair.

Definitely take this course. Be prepared to work hard if you want a proper understanding of the material but it will be very rewarding. Make sure to really step back and understand the big picture since some of the stuff seems very abstract but has clear and relatable effects on the system as a whole. Brush up on your linear algebra since this is a fairly math heavy course. You can get by without it but understanding the math helps you get a much better picture of what is going on.

For those who have a choice in whether to take it: It is an interesting, if rather difficult, quantitative course that has broad applications to a lot of fields. Shop the class for the first two weeks and make sure you like how things are going!
Go to class, it helps.

Go to lectures, and really put in an effort to learn the material as soon as it is presented to you. It gets very complicated very quickly, and this course is very dependent on mastering the fundamentals in order to be successful as the semester progresses.
Good course but I think it's overrated.
Hard but solid.
Hard course but also very fair. You learn really cool material that you will get to see in the lab.
If you're taking it, it's probably for a departmental. It's one of the tougher requirements but you learn a lot about some awesome concepts!
Interesting course if you really apply yourself but it can be hard. Start the problem sets early.
Long psets, but very interesting and you learn a ton

Not the most frantically-paced of courses, but you still learn a fair amount. The modern controls content is interesting and is a good gateway to further classes, but as a non-MAE student, I found this course to be useful on its own.

Prof. Rowley is one of the best lecturers out there! I've learned a lot from the course. It's very fair, and while some of the mathematical concepts can be generally challenging, the homeworks and labs are incredibly helpful in gaining an understanding of everything.
Really cool class if you have any interest in robotics.
Stay on top of material - go to office hours.
Take it if you're at all interested in robotics or control. Rowley's great, the class is not much work, and I loved it.
Take it!
Take this course! The assignments are long and material difficult, but you will never find it taught better than here!
The course is a lot of work and challenging but if you like the material definitely take it. It is really well taught.

The professor is nice and approachable, but it's all so theoretical that I really don't know what useful knowledge I gained at the other end. I even worked on a robotic control project the same semester and couldn't really apply much of anything!
This class is challenging but great at teaching the material.

This class is much harder than you think it's going to be. P-sets are either hard or a time sink, or both; exams try to fit half again as much material in as they should, and labs are three hours of your week. It's useful information, and the material is taught well, just be prepared to work very hard.

This course is amazing! The material is super interesting and really well taught. It brings together a lot of previous knowledge and the idea of designing a controller to automatically modify a system is pretty cool! It is a good balance between theory and practice that can be hard to find at Princeton with a lab that is well-developed from years of testing and without stressful reports. Take your time on the psets to understand them and the course should be rewarding!

This course is great. Prof. Rowley is great. Fair amount of work but not horrendous. May be a little light on mathematical rigor for those who like that kind of thing, but it's pretty easy to fill in the gaps (esp. if you've taken MAE 306).
This is a great course and I would definitely recommend it. Professor Rowley is an excellent lecturer.

This is really a mixed bag of a class. The lectures have very interesting and cool material, though they are a bit on the dry side. There is a LOT of linear algebra later on; I highly recommend brushing up on it. The labs are very cool! Problem sets tend to be quite long and repetitive, and there is often one problem that is made MUCH simpler if you have already had lab, so if you can have lab early in the week, I recommend it. You'll waste less time being confused about something you would just do in lab.
Very good lecture. Can't miss it if you are interested in controls

Very hard. Do not take five courses during the semester that you are taking this class as it will occupy the majority of your time.  For the exams, just looking over the problem sets is not nearly enough. You actually have to understand the fundamentals in order to succeed
great class! you will love it!
take it
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop an understanding of feedback principles in the control of dynamic systems, and to gain experience in analyzing and designing control systems in a laboratory setting.

title: Advanced Sculpture
prereqs: VIS 203/204, or VIS 221/222, or VIS 231/232, or VIS 331/332 or instructor's permission..
descrip: In this course, each student will determine a specific theme that they will poke, prod and refine throughout the semester, ultimately completing three fully realized, thematically-linked sculptures and/or installations. While wood, metal and plaster will be readily available, various mixed media and experimental materials and approaches are highly encouraged. Regular individual and group critiques monitor the progress of each project. In addition, the class will collaboratively complete and install and outdoor public sculpture somewhere on campus. Field trips and image driven discussions will be part of the course.

title: American Politics
reviews: Class is alright and lectures are extremely boring.
Don't take unless you have to - there are other more interesting Politics courses out there

Don't worry too much about the readings-- just make sure you have a basic knowledge of what the author is arguing. Participate in precepts and try to develop a stance on whatever issue that the class is discussing, as that is how you can get the most out of the course.
Easy WWS core, but not gripping.

Easy class. You can do well as long as you have general knowledge about American Politics. The course isn't really interesting or beneficial, especially for POL/Woody Woo majors. Take it if you need a fifth class.

Even if you took something like civics or AP US Gov in high school, this is really good class to take.  It gives you a good overview of the research and theories in American politics and a deeper understanding of controversial issues.  Keep organized notes on the basic points of the readings; it'll be very helpful for the midterm and final.
Good for the SA requirement. Don't really need to keep up with readings (just need to do them before final). Easy to get A- on assignments.
Great class
Great course if you are interested in American politics! I would recommend! Be prepared to do a fair amount of reading.. it's quite a bit :)
Great course, learned a lot, and I definitely recommend it!
Great departmental for WWS, and very useful and applicable to life in general. McCarty's lectures are a bit dry, but the material in general is interesting, and the class is not that much work.

I would not take this class unless you have to, or unless the lecture format changes. The lack of incorporation of current American Politics into the lecture material seemed like a huge wasted opportunity, especially with the current election cycle. Having Mary as a preceptor was the one thing that saved the class for me.

If you are interested in politics I would recommend this course. It will teach you some very interesting theories, and there are a good mix of contemporary readings like newspaper articles and then denser political theory.
If you are very interested in politics this is a good course to take, but a lot of it is very theoretical and the readings can be hard to get through.
If you have a rudimentary understanding of current political events, you can take this for an easy A. If you don't, you should learn about current political events.

If you think this is a repeat of APUSH, think again. It's more analytic and delves more into political models from a critical perspective. The workload is very reasonable, and (in my experience) the preceptors are great. The lectures can seem a little straightforward (read: dry) at times, since Professor McCarty uses powerpoint heavily, but make sure to attend lecture and pay attention, as you'll come to realize that he heavily augments the contents of the slides with additional information you can only get by being there in person. For the essays, make sure you are aware of most readings, and well-versed with one or two. Overall, one of the more interesting courses I've taken at Princeton. Didn't expect this walking in, but definitely worth giving this course a try if you are at all interested in the American political landscape!

If you're doing this for one of the Politics Woody Woo departmentals, then do it if nothing else is available - won't kill you. That being said it's not a must take class and if you're really into politics you may not learn anything new. It may solidify some things but that's about it. The papers are manageable and if you have a good preceptor you'll get feedback about how to write well. The readings are a lot but if you don't do a lot it won't kill you but it may hurt you for the final and midterm if you don't make it a priority to do at least a few of the readings per week. Overall a solid course but wouldn't choose it over another politics or Woody Woo course.
Interesting subject, badly taught.
It was an informative class, but slightly boring. An easy PDF
It's a good introduction to American politics, and it covers the basics well. If you've taken AP Gov or if you're a politics junkie, this may be a bit easy for you.
Its a very informative class and is very interesting especially in the middle of election season.
Keep up with the readings, however, I don't think reading them all end to end is necessary. Relate them all to each other and find a way to organize and relate all of the topics together.

Keep up with the readings, there are a lot and they are pretty interesting. Go to lecture even though sometimes it is not applicable. McCarty is a good guy and try to be engaged as much as possible even though sometimes you don't really get a lot out of it.  If you are engaged you can learn a lot about American politics.
Lecture is a bore, readings have interesting conclusions but they are pretty dry. Grading is pretty easy.

McCarty is a great professor. Everything is in the lecture notes. So few assignments (2 papers, midterm, final) that controlling your grade is quite tough. One medium-level grade and you're pretty screwed.
Not a particularly exciting class but it is an easy departmental/requirement.  McCarty is knowledgable but the lectures are pretty boring.  Keep up with the readings.
Not too easy, not too hard. Good course to take and you learn some important stuff.
Pay attention in precept- it's the most important part of the class as lectures can be very boring.
Precept is most important.
Really interesting and classic readings/papers, but terribly boring lectures

Set aside lots of time to read, and attend all lectures--not only because they're essential for achieving the highest grade possible, but also because they undoubtedly enhance the already-great experience that is POL 220.
Take - interesting

Take for Woody Woo departmental as it's overall very easy. Large amount of reading but you can get away with doing none of it as you can just read a few of them for the takehome midterm and papers (and split them later for the final). Material is fairly easy and McCarty was knowledgeable but his lectures are extremely dry and boring, so this class isn't too inspiring. Altogether it was easy though.
Take it if it is a departmental. otherwise, you might be bored.
Take notes on the readings!
Take this class mainly if you want to know about all of the political jargon you hear about but don't really understand. It's certainly necessary. Lectures were dull but precept was enlightening.

Take this course if you are interested in politics. The lectures are not that interesting, especially if you already have prior knowledge of politics/government, it will be repetitive. The precept topics are interesting as are the readings. Overall the class isn't too much work and it isn't difficult as long as you are able to analyze the readings and articulate opinions about political matters.
There is a lot of reading. Do the reading- don't let it pile up.
This class is somewhat boring, but the material is easy to grape. The paper topics are easy if you have done the readings.
This course is a very introductory class so if you know anything about American Politics, it might be better to take another class.
This course was a good, interesting overview of American politics. It was defintiely challenging for me as someone who had never taken a politics or government course before.
This is a pretty solid course, I would recommend taking it.
This is a really interesting course if American politics is your thing but it is definitely not an easy class. You will have to work to keep up with the long, often thick readings.
This is not a very engaging course, but it's fine, considering it is a requirement.
Unless you're taking for a distribution requirement, avoid. In fact, even if you are taking for a distribution requirement, I'm sure there are more interesting ones.
Very good class to take, especially in an election year. Prof McCarty is really knowledgeable so definitely go to lecture!

You should obviously take this if you're planning on being an American Politics major, but in that case you probably won't learn a ton of new stuff and may get bored. It doesn't cover detailed procedures like how a bill is passed by Congress, so much as it focuses on the ideas behind the American political system, and the behavior of its participants. Try to get Mary as your preceptor, she is really awesome!!
if you're taking it it's probably a departmental. If you want a less bland class take 329
recommend
take it
descrip: A survey of the institutions of American democracy. Topics will include the Constitutional order, federalism, legislative deliberation, executive power, elections and representation, interest groups and social movements, the courts, and policymaking.

title: The Evil Empire: Reading Putin's Russia
reviews: Consider taking if you have a strong background in Russia's 20th century history and are curious to examine the last 25 years more closely, particularly if your interests verge toward the literary.
I would recommend that people look up historical backgrounds on Wikipedia before coming to class. Otherwise just listen and enjoy - Kirill's a good lecturer.
Take the course. It offers a lot of interesting insight into the Russian psyche.

The reading material in this class was a bit zany at times, but always deeply enjoyable to do. The class is worth taking for the readings alone. Professor Osvopat presented thought-provoking perspectives on contemporary Russian culture and politics and would allow us to ask questions on any Russia-related subject. For this reason,  I think this class would be of great value for politics/woody woo types interested in Russia.
descrip: This seminar, situated between literary, political, cultural, and art studies, will address Putin's authoritarian Russia and the symbolic patterns that govern its erratic and seemingly irrational policies. We will draw on political theory and investigative journalism as well as contemporary Russian film, fiction, and art in order to explore the peculiar, yet not unprecedented cult of violence that underlies Putin's authoritarian regime. We will examine the origins of this cult in Russian imperial and Soviet culture and its implications for our understanding of current events.

title: The Soviet Empire
reviews: A really interesting course! I would recommend it to everyone! It's hard to get an A, but is a really fun course to take as a PDF

A very hard course, with tons of material to go through and big assignments (midterm and final paper as well as a final exam), but if you have a PDF to spare on a dist. requirement, this is a course to take.
An outstanding course that everyone should take. Kotkin is one of a kind.
Definitely a phenomenal general interest class- I learned a lot about something that's super relevant to today and that I only knew bits and pieces about.

Definitely take this class. Kotkin should not be missed as a professor. That said--do not expect this to be a blowoff class. Not unbelievably hard or anything, but not a GPA booster. One midterm paper (2.5k words), one final paper (3k), a final exam of IDs, and a map quiz in the beginning of the semester. The grade is based on your "trend" though, so you can make up for a bad grade. I also think this means participation probably counts for a lot. Don't take this class if you're not interested, but if you have even a mild interest, this will probably be your favorite class. I am so, so glad I took this my freshman year, cannot recommend enough.
Definitely take this course if you have a lot of time to devote to it. But it is amazing and Kotkin is a great professor.
Do not slack on the reading, otherwise you lose a critical piece of understanding the Soviet Empire.
Excellent course. It was a lot of work and not easy to get a good grade in, but it forces you to really learn the subject. Definitely take it if you have time and interest.
Form study groups to study for the final! It helped to split up all of the work and talk through terms.
HARD WORK, but you will learn so much. Amazing lecturer and great readings, but lots of work. Do not expect it to be an easy course, but do expect to learn a whole lot.
I recommend this class, but the exam is a real doozy, and the rest of the course does not prepare you for it.

If you have any interest at all in modern European/Russian history, you will LOVE this course!!!! Don't take it for an easy A, but it is so worth it. The lectures are so enjoyable; Prof Kotkin is really funny and a fantastic lecturer. I learned SOO much! It's so worth it!

Professor Kotkin is an incredible lecturer and the authority on the Soviet Empire. Know this is going to be a hard class, not because of the relatively decent reading load, but because the graded assignments are annoying. The map quiz is a pain and the papers are graded very harshly, but it is worth it to learn so much and study with such a brillant scholar. Also not terrible to PDF if you just want to learn and get the most out of Professor Kotkin's great lectures (which are really the best part of the course).
Take it if you are ready to work a lot for the final, but the rest of the semester is pretty chill
Take it if you're at all interested in the subject. It's a lot of work, but you will get a lot out of it.
Take it!
Take it, but expect a lot of work.
Take this class if you are ok with working very hard and getting an average great.  I would highly recommend taking the class while PDFing it, because the course itself is exceptional.
Take this class if you will have enough time to finish the readings and study. Details from the readings will be on the final exam.

Take this course--the subject is fascinating, and Kotkin is one of Princeton's best. You learn and gain a lot of knowledge both about the material itself, but it may also change the way you think about history as a discipline.

This class is incredibly difficult, but very rewarding as well. Prof. Kotkin's analysis is unrivaled, his lectures are great, and he is invested in the success of his students. If for no other reason, he should be enough to make you take this class. Be prepared, however, for a heavy workload and tough grading (especially if you're a freshman)

This is a wonderful course taught by a charismatic and wickedly smart professor.  Kotkin will challenge your preconceptions and ask you to work harder than you have for a humanities course before.  If you do so, you will possibly get more out of this class than any other at Princeton.  N.B. This is not a class for people who worry about their GPAs

This is an absolutely amazing course and a must-take for history majors, anyone with subject area interest, and anyone else willing to work hard to learn from Kotkin. Definitely not the easiest class in the department, but well worth it and a great experience.
be prepared to work your butt off and probably get a bad grade but its worth it because its a super interesting class.
i dont even know why i took this course
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: An examination of the transformation of the Russian Empire into the Soviet Empire. Topics include: the invention and unfolding of single-party revolutionary politics, the expansion of the machinery of state, the onset and development of Stalin's personal despotism, the violent attempt to create a noncapitalist society, the experiences and consequences of the monumental war with Nazi Germany, and the various postwar reforms. Special attention paid to the dynamics of the new socialist society, the connection between the power of the state and everyday life, global communism, and the 1991 collapse.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: History, Philosophy, and Religion
prereqs: See HUM 218.
descrip: In combination with 218, this is the second half of a year-long interdisciplinary sequence exploring Western culture from the 15th to the 20th centuries. Students must register for both HUM 218 and HUM 219, which constitute a double-course. The lecture component for 219 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 218. There are no separate meeting times for 219.

title: Modernism and Modernity - Modernization and Modernism in France and Germany, 1848-1914
descrip: This seminar attempts to understand the rise of modernism in French and German literature, architecture, painting, and photography as part of the processes of modernization that dominated Europe in the era of commodity capitalism. Topics to be considered include Baudelaire and the transformation of Paris, aestheticism and symbolism as forms of retreat, aesthetic urbanism in turn-of-the century Berlin, and modern tensions between individual subjectivity and public life.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
reviews: It will be a class you enjoy and spend lots of time on.
Professor Richard Garlock is a very smart person who works on very interesting projects. His assignments and feedback are sometimes unclear, but overall this course is great. But a TON of work.

Very very necessary and useful course that uses much of previous CEE coursework (particularly statics and concrete). Helps you comprehend where each of the calcs from statics/concrete psets fits in relative to an entire building. At times, can be frustrating due to the iterative nature of design and the vague nature of the "problem" - you'll often have to formulate the problem and then answer it yourself. Make sure to ask Garlock and TA for as much clarification as you can get - what's expected & when, help on specific concepts, etc. Worst case, they'll just refuse to answer your question and have you make your own decisions.
prereqs: Students should have taken both CEE 312 and CEE 366, or have permission from the instructor..
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: The Great War in the Middle East
reviews: A lot of reading and a good amount of work but worth it if you are interested. Professor Reynolds is extremely knowledgeable and class is always super interesting.
Everyone with an interest in the modern history of the Middle East has to take this course. It is good for history and it is really helpful to understand contemporary Middle East.
He is a tough professor and will expect your best every week. Prepare for seminar or you will suffer. You'll learn a lot but it's an uphill battle.
If you're at all interested in this topic, I highly recommend the course! Professor Reynolds is a stud, and you will learn so much. You should take it!
Take this course if you really want to know how Middle East, as we know it today, formed. Do the readings and be active in class, and you'll learn a ton.
descrip: World War I changed - and ended - the lives of millions. Its impact upon the Middle East is widely acknowledged but not often explored. The war destroyed the old imperial Ottoman order, paving the way to the elimination of the Caliphate and the emergence of nation-states across the Middle East and the Caucasus. It fundamentally altered concepts of identity, patterns of authority, notions of religion, and ethnic and political borders. This seminar examines the Great War in the Middle East from right before WWI through the immediate post-war period. Topics include geopolitics, empire, Pan-Islam, nationalism, ethnic conflict, Zionism, and oil.

title: Introduction to Programming Systems
reviews: A class you need to take, but be prepared: it might be the most boring and annoying class you will probably ever take.

An important course. I can't say much about lectures because I skipped most of them, but I enjoyed the assignments (they do take some time, especially the ones in the second half, so don't underestimate them). I recommend this course!

Assignments can get v annoying and time consuming but you get to learn all the cool stuff that goes on inside the cpu at a low level. im doing the shell assignment rn and am on my 56th hour and writing this to procrastinate. with that said, the class is v rewarding, just time consuming. take it fam. 5/5

COS 217 is one of those classes that I'd recommend to everyone?both for the material covered and for the quality of the course as it is presented at Princeton. As you are taking this class, try to be able to grasp both the larger picture and the finer details. Think and plan before you start programming!
COS217 is pretty straight forward. It's not too difficult. A good class. Don't fear it.
Can be a time-suck but is ultimately very worthwhile -- it completely changed the way I understand programming and computer systems.

Considerate amount of time could be put in if bug persists. However, the material is interesting and helpful in understanding how computer really works under the hood. It also helps you to be a Strong Independent Programmer - cite Prof Petras. His precept is really awesome.

DEFINITELY TAKE IT. Robert Dondero and Aarti Gupta are both incredible teachers. I strongly recommend taking this course because it is interesting, very well taught, very well organized, and you will learn a lot!
Definitely take this class if you're interested in learning about the inner-workings of programming. The assignments are tough and time consuming, but I definitely feel like I learned a lot.

Do Dondero for precept. Don't take this course if you don't have to/don't really care about really really low level stuff. But do take it if you want a challenge of understanding what other people built.
Do not miss precept, but do get a good preceptor. Lectures are generally good and not too boring. There is a large time commitment but I liked this better than cos226
Do not take this if you're thinking that this course is not tedious.
Don't fall behind early. Don't start assignments late. Utilize the help provided.
Dondero is excellent, and the final assignment makes it worthwhile, but please be prepared to dedicate a large amount to it.
Expect to spend time doing assignments, but there is always help available. The "extra challenge" parts can be quite frustrating from time to time.

For the first few weeks, stay on top of the readings (this becomes less essential as the semester goes on). Pay attention in both lecture and precept, as the info is not only useful, but very applicable to the assignments as well.

GO TO PRECEPT. Precepts will help so much with assignments. Also, pay attention to lecture slides and precept handouts. Those will help with doing your assignments so much. 217 is an interesting course but will not make you happy if you're overloading yourself with other time consuming courses.
Go to office hours!!!!
Go to precept.
Go to precept. I thought the material was a bit dull, but people on the border between COS and ELE seem to enjoy it.
Go to precept. Read lectures for review.

Good course if you like programming. Definitely provides an interesting view into computer systems and what goes on "under the hood". Would recommend taking 217 after 226 because assignments occasionally referenced material from 226, but this is by no means necessary. Professor Gupta's slides are detailed enough so that you don't have to go to lecture, but make sure you get Dondero as your preceptor and go to every precept - assignments become much easier once Dondero explains how to do them in precept. Textbooks do not add much value.

Great class for those majoring in or interested in COS. The assignments take some time to get done, so plan out your schedule accordingly. The precepts are much more useful than the lectures so keep that in mind also. Get started early enough on the assignments and you should be fine.
Great class, but it is quite time consuming. Will help you a lot in becoming a better programmer.
I mean take it if you have to, if you're a certificate student take a different class.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is considering COS as a major, because it is a good way to decide if COS is right for you: 126 and 226 are very similar and explore a very accessible and fun part of CS. COS 217 goes into a lot of depth on a topic which will be less interesting to a broad audience, and if you enjoy this class you are more likely to enjoy varied topics in computer science which you will be learning during the major (though many of them go in different directions from COS 217).
I strongly recommend the precepts of Drs. Dondero, Petras, and Karlin. I am unfamiliar with Sophie Qiu's precepts so I cannot commenton them.
IF YOU GET DONDERO AS YOUR PRECEPTOR THEN TAKE IT REGARDLESS OF YOUR MAJOR!!

If you are interested in programming but want something more low-level or easier than 226, this is probably the class for you. It will also make you much better at debugging. It is a decent amount of work, but not nearly as much as some people will have you think. Shell is a decent amount of work in particular, but is also very rewarding.

If you didn't like 226, don't worry! This course is so different from 226, you'll learn a lot about how things work behind the scenes and the assignments actually seem like they have practical implementations that would be useful and meaningful in the real world.

If you ever wondered how a computer works and wanted to try a bit of low-level coding (C, assembly, and a bit of machine language), this is the course for you! Just realize, it is a major time sink. The weekly assignments will eat up hours upon hours of time (average: 10-15 hours, longer for later assignments). The final assignment in particular requires a lot of time. Only take the course if you have a course load that could handle a time-consuming course like COS 217. It is a lot of fun!

If you're trying to decide between 217 and 226, my thoughts are that this course takes up less time on average, but has a bigger final project, and at times, the material can be far more annoying (machine language and assembly anyone?).  Very good overall though
It is very cool!
It's a very difficult and time-consuming class.

It's not a particularly difficult course; I just found it less interesting and more tedious than COS 226. Start the assignments early, but only after the precept(s) relevant to the assignment. The assignments are fairly straightforward but debugging can be a pain. I hardly did the readings (unless Dondero suggested a section for an assignment). The old exams were the most helpful in preparing for exams.
It's not as fun as 226 and 126, but you learn a lot and the profs are very helpful. I wouldn't take this as a fun class. but if you are doing the major its not the worst thing ever.
It's poor but necessary experience

It's probably better to take this course in the fall in order to get a bit more time to work on the Shell assignment. Taking this course at the same time as writing sem meant there wasn't really any time during the semester where I could truly relax--there were always substantial due dates coming up--but it was still manageable and it forced me to be better at starting work on assignments in advance. Dondero is a fantastic preceptor, and I've heard Karlin and Petras are good as well. Go to all the precepts, but the lectures are probably skippable / not much better than just reading the slides. (Although the lecture slides themselves are quite good and are useful references for doing the assignments.)
Keep up with the materials and pay extra attention in precept!
Lectures are no necessary to attend but make  sure you understand what you are doing. Assignments are not that hard once you understand what you are doing.
Obviously don't take this if you don't have to. If you do, sorry. Although, it won't feel as bad if you've taken 226 first.
Only take if necessary.
PRECEPT WITH DR. DONDERO. I CANNOT EMPHASIZE ENOUGH. He's amazing!!!

Personally, I loved the course. It is extremely well taught and the assignments are enjoyable even if frustrating at times. My biggest piece of advice, which holds true for nearly all COS courses, is to start assignments early. You never know when you'll run into a bug you simply can't solve, so it's beneficial to have more time in case that arises.

Professor Dondero is very dedicated to the course and the lectures are thorough and really spark an interest in Systems ? the course made me want to take more systems courses in the future.
Precepts are super important - you basically learn all the specific details you need for assignments during them.
Prepare to spend a lot of time doing the assignments, and get help when you need it.
Pretty good course. Good for learning C and about lower level operation of computers.
Some people really like this course and others not so much. The assignments are really interesting, though, and definitely try to get into Dondero's precept!
Start Assignment early and go to Prof Dondero for help with debugging.
Stay caught up with the material or it is difficult to catch up
Stay engaged with the material and you will get alot out of this course.

TAKE IT; the assignments are long but they are worth it and super interesting. You learn so much about what happens inside a computer. It is absolutely fantastic, you feel like a real programmer by the end.
Take it
Take it even if you aren't COS.  Nothing to fear except ish and the exams.
Take it if you are interested in system-level programming, and if you have to. The workload is considerable.
Take it if you want to be able to say you can program.
Take it! Great COS class; as good as 226!
Take it! It's one of the best taught courses I've taken so far at Princeton. Try to get into Dr. Dondero's precepts, and experience the magic of his teaching!
Take this course if you're interested in learning about the nitty gritty details (but not too deep) of computing and computer systems
Take this course, even if you're not a COS major. I'm an MAE, but now I've taken 126, 226, and 217 and this was my favorite hands down.

Tedious to debug, but you will be proud of the code you produce for your assignments. It was also conceptually pretty cool to get more of an idea what's going on in your computer to execute your code.
The assignments can be very interesting and also one of the most helpful ways for you to learn the material.
The course was fun. It was just too large of a time commitment. Like, Jesus Christ, seg faults are the vain of my existence now.

This course is great and helps to broaden your understanding of how computers work at a low level. If you do decide to take this course I would strongly recommend having Robert Dondero as your preceptor.
This course is very well taught and provides a wonderful overview of computer systems and C. Take it if you have any interest in how computers work.

This is a demanding but rewarding course. The format of the course is expertly arranged, and the material (and particularly the programming assignments) build upon themselves in satisfying ways. Precepts are required and are extremely helpful, so make sure to pay attention during them. Programming assignments run on a 1.5wk rotation. Professor Dondero is extremely knowledgable and hugely helpful in debugging assignments. Piazza is also an incredibly helpful tool for this class. You will learn a lot, and your programming skills will definitely improve! I really enjoyed this class and would highly recommend it to others.

This is a really great course. Most don't enjoy it as much as 226 but you will learn a ton and there is a lot of support in place when you need it. I would definitely say take 226 first if you can but it won't be too difficult to manage with just 126.
Time consuming but awesome class. Dondero is god.
Very good course for the material. The assignments take time.
Very interesting course. Poorly taught.
You learned a lot in this class. If you consider a career in CS, this class is a must-take! But beware, this class is quite time-consuming. Assignments can take 8-15 hours.

You need to be able to process material extremely well in precept and be fully attentive. There is so much to learn really quickly, so make sure you don't slack off during the first part of the semester.
You probably are required to take it, so take it. But make sure to keep up with lectures as you go. Also GET DONDERO AS A PRECEPTOR no matter what you do he is AMAZING. And go to office hours.

i thought i would hate this course but it was actually an unexpected high point of my semester.  awesome.  precepts are a perfect 10/10 so go to those even if the lecturer is not very good. you'll feel like a 1337 hacker after assignment five and like someone who actually knows what they're doing after assignment seven.  i liked it more than 226.
it's a lot of work but you'll learn a lot if you do it all
prereqs: COS 126, ISC 231-234, or approval by the COS placement officer..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.

title: Marvels and Wonder in Classical Arabic Literature
descrip: This course explores a variety of medieval Arabic texts through the lens of wonder. It is through marveling at the foreign and inexplicable that we position ourselves in the world and separate the Self from the Other. Yet, wonder is also what prompts our curiosity for discovery and provokes our search for explanations. Where was the line drawn between the familiar and the strange in medieval Arabic culture? How was wonder defined? What role did it play? The course is taught in English in its entirety. No prerequisites.

title: Experimental Physics Seminar
reviews: Great course and fun to take a course outside of your comfort zone.  Definitely take it
PDF only so obviously good. Really poorly organized, but no homework or exams and you get out early half the time.
Really fun and relaxed. Tully a great professor. There is literally no work outside class so take it if you want to learn about circuits in a completely stress free environment.
Take it if you can.  It is great.
Take it if you need a lab course!
Take it! It's PDF only!
Take this course if you have any interest in circuits or want an easier semester. Absolutely no take home work
please take this course
descrip: The seminar introduces students to the basic techniques of electronics and instrumentation used to conduct experiments in the physical sciences. The course begins by teaching a foundation in analog and digital circuits including programmable digital logic devices using an iPad interface for data acquisition. Students develop measurement techniques in a wide range of experimental areas.

title: German Philosophy since Kant - Heidegger
descrip: A reading of Heidegger's "Being and Time", and perhaps some other works of his. Secondary sources include Hubert Dreyfus' "Being-In-The-World".

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
prereqs: Students apply by submitting a writing sample of 3-4 pages of translations and a paragraph describing their interest in the author(s) included in the sample, noting any previous experience with the genre. Prerequisite: CWR 205 or 206 Introductory Translation. Please see application on CWR website: arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app Application deadline is November 22, 2015..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students must be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Object and Text in Premodern Japan
prereqs: At least one lower level course in art history, comparative literature, or Japanese studies, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar examines the dynamic interrelationship between objects and texts in premodern Japan, from the seventh through the seventeenth centuries. The series of meetings will introduce topics in a sequence that exemplifies the gradual layering of meaning and complication that comes from a culture with a strong classical awareness. We will examine a set of core themes in Japanese culture, such as love, death, nature, and enlightenment, as expressed in a range of mediums, including painting, gardens, lacquer, and ceramics, Chinese and Japanese poetry, imperial court and warrior narratives, and Noh dramas.

title: Theoretical Orientations in Cultural Anthropology - Conspiracy Theory and Social Theory
reviews: I would definitely recommend taking this class.

If you are considering taking this course, you should take it!  It is just as interesting as it sounds from the title.  Be sure to read everything - there are theoretical works and fascinating case studies that will both teach you something new and enrich your previously held views on the course themes.
Take it! Professor Davis is fantastic and this is a very, very interesting topic.
The course has a high level of applicability to research that is beyond conspiracy theory.
This is an excellent, thought-provoking course with engaging reading selections. Very worthwhile for any student considering further study in anthropology or related disciplines.
prereqs: At least one anthropology course or permission of instructor..
descrip: What does it mean to theorize in paranoid times? Social theory shares with conspiracy theory an array of analytic tools for connecting seemingly disparate cultural practices, characterizing the consciousness and agency of political subjects, and accounting structurally for the invisible workings of power. This course will examine these intersections between conspiracy theory and social theory on epistemological and ethical grounds, asking what kinds of knowledge are enabled and what kinds of politics are empowered by conspiracy theories and by their debunking, and how theorists use different kinds of evidence to substantiate their claims.

title: Introduction to Differential Equations
reviews: If you love your life, your family, or anything, please do NOT take this class. Lectures are unintelligible, the book is a disaster and a half, and the problem sets do nothing to help learn the material.
If you've taken PHY 205 don't bother taking this class
Professor E is great, but the class is a little disorganized. Not much work outside of class but on the flip side that means you don't learn the material quite as well.
Take it only if you already have hard classes.
descrip: This course will introduce the basic theory, models and techniques for ordinary and partial differential equations. Emphasis will be placed on the connection with other disciplines of science and engineering. We will try to strike a balance between the theoretical (e.g. existence and uniqueness issues, qualitative properties) and the more practical issues such as analytical and numerical approximations.

title: Politics in Africa
reviews: Definitely take this class! Even if you're not interested in African politics, per se, you will still learn a lot.
Do the readings and start thinking about what interests you about the class; use the readings in class as a way to shape your research.

For this course it is essential that students attend all lectures, as this is critical for understanding course readings and subject matter - as well as applying course information to broader course themes.

I will encourage students to attend lecture and complete the assigned readings. This is the only way one can engage with the material and learn. I will also encourage students to take advantage of the professor's/preceptor's office hours.
I would tell them to make sure that presentations are done early on.
Meh
Prof is great. Get to know him

Take advantage of this course's incredible professor and the assigned work, as it is highly appropriate for the study of African politics and provides a sound approach to comprehensively appreciating the political implications of the continent.

Take this class if you don't mind a lot of student presentations and have a genuine interest in learning about democracy, state formation, politics, and a little bit of anthropology through the context of sub-saharan Africa.

This is a pretty easy and laid back class. You can get whatever you want from it. There are a lot of readings you can do or not do and they are looking to help you write a nice research paper at the end.

sounded interesting to me but this was a bad class. wantchekon is a nice guy with a legit background but not a good teacher. lectures are filled with boring student presentations, the readings are boring and theoretical and if you aren't woodywoo/politics you will be a step behind others
would definitely recommend!
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the study of African politics. The lectures and readings briefly review the social and historical context of contemporary political life. They then profile the changes of the early post-Independence period, the authoritarian turn of the 1970s and 80s, the second liberation of the 1990s, and problems of war, state-building, and development. Although the lectures trace a narrative, each also introduces a major analytical debate and an important policy problem.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
reviews: Don't take unless you want to be bored.
Good introductory finance course
Take the class to learn more not just about risk management but financial economics more generally.
prereqs: FIN 501, FIN 522.
descrip: Course examines the concept of risk and its mitigation, and how the ideas can be applied in the practice of risk management for financial and non-financial companies. The basic toolkit draws on economics, probability theory and statistics, and they are integrated with more advanced concepts drawn from portfolio choice, derivative securities and dynamic hedging. Overall aim of the course is to demonstrate how the main concepts have practical applications.

title: Topics in Low Dimensional Topology - Bordered Algebras & Knot Floer Homology
prereqs: The course assumes familiarity with basic low-dimensional topology..
descrip: Knot Floer homology is a bigraded homology theory, defined for knots in closed oriented three-dimensional manifolds. In the course, we study applications of knot Floer homology, and computational methods as well.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: Absolutely take this. Super interesting and not too much work.
Amazing class, with an awesome professor, and very little work required.
Attend all lectures and precepts. Otherwise, interesting and straightforward course.
Definitely take this course!  It's pretty laid back, but you really learn a lot!
Don't be shy to ask questions. Some topics might be confusing.
Even if you're gonnna pdf it or get the easy A, it's a really interesting class. I thoroughly enjoyed it.
Good LA to take that's easy
Great distribution for engineers.
I would recommend this for a good distribution requirement. Although be prepared, the weekly time commitment is more than you expect going in.

If taking without lab, take something else that you actually find interesting as your "easy fifth class." I genuinely think bridges are cool and like learning about them, but the BS psets, final paper, and midterm and final are not worth it, and although it is a very straightforward class, there is a lot of busy work.

If you are at all interested in learning about civil engineering or how different buildings and bridges work, definitely take this class. Professor Garlock is really passionate about this field, and that is easily passed on to the rest of the class. The material is very interesting, and you will definitely learn something that you never knew before and will remember for the rest of your life.

If you really just want an easy class but don't care how interesting it is, take this class. However, don't be surprised when your level of engagement drops with the class and you end up getting a lower grade than you anticipated.

If you think you might be at all interested in bridges or structural engineering take this class!! Material is super interesting. Attend lectures and the class is very reasonable. Also a very reasonable amount of work.

If you're a math major like me who hates going to lecture, this will not be as easy as say ECO 310 or ORF 309, where you don't have to go to lecture and can basically complete the assignment in a day or less with a great set of course notes, like 309, or a textbook, like 310.

Rather the difficulty in this class lies in being able to make the effort to get to 10 AM class and precept and "contributing". I would suggest an easier LA to be honest. The term paper I expect will be very tedious as well.
If you're interested in learning about structures, I recommend this course!
Just study the lecture slides - they're pretty helpful.
Lectures are very helpful if you don't want to do a lot of extra work outside of class.
Liked the content a lot. Lecturer was OK. Generally interesting class. Not too hard especially if u are good at basic math and physics
Minimal work load, but don't slack off too much.
Not a bad class to take for PDF if you're remotely interested in bridge design
Really great LA.
Surprised me by its quality. It was actually interesting to learn about the history and depth of the world's greatest structures, and it wasn't too hard.
Take it
Take it if you're interested in bridges and structures, and want to gain a greater appreciation for engineering feats that surround you in every day life.
Take it, very interesting and you'll look at buildings and bridges in a new way

Take the STL version if you want a relativelyyyyyy easy A... it will take time to study, but the concepts are not conceptually hard at all. The LA version will take a lot of time in precept assignments, reading, and an extensive term paper, which may be especially tedious if you are not interested in bridges.
Take this class! Super interesting and well organised.
The LA is not an easy A.You will have to put in the work or PDF the class.
The class is easy but you still have to do work if you want to get an A.
This course is not particularly hard, but there is a decent amount of tedious work involved.

This is a good class. I don't think it's quite the "easy A" people expect, but if you put in the effort you are definitely rewarded with your grade. The subject matter is fairly interesting, especially if you are at all interested in architecture and/or structure.

This is a great course. The material is very interesting and the lectures are engaging. It's fairly easy and doesn't have too much work, but if you're in the A section, make sure you start the essay with enough time to ask questions and do a decent amount of research.
Would recommend
Yes, take it
subject matter is not difficult, but you are required to know a lot and do a fair amount of work. if you are interested at all in buildings/bridges/structures, take it!
take it -- it might not be your favorite class but its a princeton classic
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through critical analysis of major works students are introduced to the methods of evaluating structures as an art form. Students study the works and ideas of individual structural artists through their elementary calculations, their builder's mentality and their aesthetic imagination. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities.

title: Race Relations in Twentieth Century Cuba
reviews: I like the idea of this course changing to also address gender and sexuality. With this change, I think this class will be much more engaging in the future.
It was overall a good course that covered a very complex but important topic, but it was not well organized.
It's interesting and chill
Pressure Adrian to take you around the city and to find a way to engage more with Cubans throughout the whole semester.
Try to reflect on the readings in your daily experiences in Cuba.
prereqs: This class will be offered in Havana, as part of the Princeton in Cuba Program. For more information, see: http://www.princeton.edu/oip/sap/programs. Fluency in Spanish..
descrip: The Cuban revolution has been one of the most radical sociopolitical experiments of the past century. Comparing historiographical accounts with the recollections of individuals involved in the actual events, this course investigates the impact of the revolutionary process on Cuban racial politics. At the center of our enquire is an attempt to understand how Cubans see themselves in terms of race, and the role of those perceptions on the production of discourses and silences regarding racial inequality and discrimination.

title: Philosophical Logic
reviews: A good course for EC.

Chapters 1,2 and 5 are quite accessible and there are easily available resources on the web. Chapters 3 and 4 are somewhat more challanging if you do not find the manner in which the book presents them very helpful.
Interesting course, but very difficult if you do not have a strong background in logic or proofs.
Probably don't take it. The course goes over five different logical systems, not very much in depth, and the lectures aren't all that good. If Kezia is one of the preceptors, avoid her precept(s)!

Seriously only take if you are already well into mathematics or classical logic. You need a very strong understanding of at least one to make sense of the course. It's really assuming very good knowledge of classical logic before going into the somewhat more esoteric or alternate logics. You will need to do a lot of work on your own to make any sense of the stuff.
prereqs: PHI 201 or instructor's permission.
descrip: An introduction to non-classical formal logics: temporal, modal, conditional, relevantistic, intuitionistic.

title: Research Seminar in Empirical Investigation
descrip: Preparation of quantitative research papers based on field observation, laboratory experiments, survey procedures, and secondary analysis of existing data banks.

title: Contemporary Art: 1950 to the Present
reviews: A good overview of contemporary art with a focus on history but it's not an easy course and the works might be eccentric.
A lot of readings, but AnnMarie is a great lecturer and makes the class interesting and fun

Amazing class! Great overview of contemporary art for those with no prior knowledge. Professor Perl's lectures are so thorough and engaging--I wish we had more than 50 minutes each time to hear more. Definitely take this class regardless of your major--it's so eye-opening and just generally really interesting!!
An easy and great course w prior knowledge and interest in contemporary art, a lot of information without
Definitely take this class!! Professor Perl's lectures are engaging and informative.
Go to class often. Slides are posted but they mainly contain pictures with the name, title and year of the artwork. No detailed notes are posted.
Good class, do the readings. Best to do them BEFORE class. She lectures under the assumption that you've done the readings.
Good survey of contemporary art!
Great survey course about modern art -- I know a lot more than I did 12 weeks ago. Perfect PDF.
Interesting subject matter, very light course load, but not always the most interesting lectures.
Love this class and definitely recommend people to take it!

Prof Perl is a fun and very passionate teacher. This class is a good art history class if you have a vague background of art history and want to dive into contemporary art.  The work load is not overwhelming at all and Prof Perl will gladly answer questions if you have them.  I loved the class and definitely recommend!

TAKE THIS COURSE. Prof. Perl will change your life forever. She is so passionate and so helpful. Make sure you go talk to her about your day, you r interests, and why you took this class. go in the class with dedication and curiosity and you will get so much out of it.

Take if interested, Perl is a great professor, I'd strongly recommend to PDF unless you are an art history major because the exams are pretty rough since you have to know each artist, each artwork, as well as the year (within 5 years). I found this difficult to fit into my schedule and ended up PDFing, while still being able to enjoy the material, precepts, as well as the papers (one small one and a research paper). Don't take if its not interesting to you!
Take it! I loved it. A lot of work (quite overwhelming sometimes) but definitely worth it.

Take this class! I had no background in art history, and found this class really interesting (took it for my LA PDF). Especially because it's modern art, you learn a lot about how to analyze pieces and connect them to their art historical context. Sometimes the lectures go fast, but they're relatively easy to follow. Professor Perl is really passionate about her work, and it comes across in lectures.
Take this course if you have an interest in modern art or simply want to understand what all the fuss is about like I did.
Take this with Prof. Perl!
Very challenging exams, lots of memorizing, not suited to people who have never taken an art class.
Would definitely recommend, though I'd also recommend taking some courses in modern art, too, to get some context.
descrip: A survey of postwar art from an international perspective, focusing on the major artistic movements in their historical contexts, including the Second World War, the Cold War, decolonization, the civil rights movement, feminism, globalization, and economic boom and recession. Lectures explore several themes including art's relationship to popular culture, the mass media, consumer society, historical memory, and political and social activism. Throughout, we account for the startling formal metamorphoses of art itself, as it is transformed from traditional painting and sculpture into new forms that challenged the very nature and limits of art.

title: Independent Instruction in Voice or Instrument
prereqs: Open to Music concentrators and Musical Performance certificate students only. Students must complete MUS 298 (Fall) and MUS 299 (Spring) in the same academic year to receive one course unit of credit..
descrip: Independent instruction in voice or instrument is an intensive immersion in all aspects of recreating music for performance. Lessons are geared towards the development and embedding of solid technique, and the application of this technique to proper style and musical expression. Issues explored include but are not limited to interpretation, stylistic appropriateness, historical context, theoretical/syntactical underpinnings, the avoidance of injuries, audition and performance strategies, and career planning.

title: Problems in Near Eastern Jewish History
descrip: This course offers a hands-on introduction to primary sources composed by Jews in the Islamic Near East and their uses for social, cultural, and intellectual history. Readings are chosen according to student interests and language competencies, and may include medieval rabbinic responsa and legal codes, biblical commentaries, and documents from the Cairo Geniza.

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - Hormonally Active Pollutants
reviews: Pretty engaging if you're interested in the material, definitely a manageable workload but be prepared to read and analyze scientific papers
Take it! New perspective on environmental pollutants and how they may affect our health.
Take this course if you are interested in the environment, pollutants, or healthcare. It opens up an extremely interesting field of study that many people do not know or even think about.

Take this course if you're interested at all in hormonally active pollutants! The course is extremely interesting, the professor is very engaging and her lectures are stimulating. Ruderman is also very sweet and caring so it makes participating in class all the better.

Take this course! It's very interesting and not an overwhelming amount of work. you'll learn a lot about the different ways your hormones are affected by the food you eat/the chemicals you interact with on a day-to-day basis
Take this course! Very interesting information on a newly emerging field

Take this course! While the title may not be very clear, the topic is incredibly important and relevant. This course may sound very technical, but Prof. Ruderman breaks down the material really well, and choses to talk about important studies that are easy to understand.
descrip: A large number of common chemicals designed for one purpose are now known to have a second, completely unexpected ability to mimic or interfere with estrogen or testosterone. Examples include bisphenol A (BPA) and phthalates that leach from many plastics, DDT and other pesticides, and tributyltins in marine anti-fouling paints. Many of these end up as personal or environmental contaminants. There is growing evidence that exposure to hormonally active pollutants can interfere with health and reproduction in both humans and wildlife. This seminar examines landmark discoveries, explores current research, and looks at emerging regulatory action.

title: Human Rights in China
descrip: See website

title: Functional Analysis
prereqs: MAT 314/320, 332; MAT 317/330 or MAT331/335 helpful but not required; or permission by instructor..
descrip: Basic introductory course to modern methods of analysis. Topics include Lp spaces, Banach spaces, uniform boundedness principle, closed graph theorem, locally convex spaces, distributions, Fourier transform, Riesz interpolation theorem, Hardy-Littlewood maximal function, Calderon-Zygmund theory, oscillatory integrals, almost orthogonality, Sobolev spaces, restriction theorems, spectral theory of compact operators. Applications to partial differential equations and probability theory are presented.

title: Mitigating Climate Change
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Modern Classical Dynamics
reviews: Don't try to take this expecting a structured course with lots of hand holding. The material presented is fascinating, so focus on just enjoying the material.

I strongly recommend against taking this course. The material itself is interesting. However, Polyakov's lectures are very disorganized and hard to understand. The material is often not found in the textbooks and there are no lecture notes, so it is very hard to learn the material. The problem sets themselves are not much work and the grading is fairly lenient.
Interesting but all over the place.

Proceed with caution. This class is pretty much what you make of it. As a lecturer, Polyakov is extremely unconventional and it is pretty much up to the student to get as much out of the lecture as he or she can.

Take the class for Polyakov's insight into the entire development of modern classical and mathematical physics. It's not about learning some set of equations you can apply to solving problems. It's about learning the chains of reasoning that led scientists down these paths.
descrip: Discussion of the most beautiful and important parts of classical dynamics: variational principles, ergodicity and chaos, fluid dynamics of vortices, shock waves and solitons as well as the theories of developed turbulence.

title: Microeconomic Theory II
reviews: I am planning on pursuing micro-theory, and didn't truly enjoy this course, which does not bode well for how others in the cohort viewed the class.
I can't recommend or not recommend this class because the professors teaching this class didn't manage to raise my interest.

If you put in the time to do the problem sets, you will generally learn from them. Going over the lecture notes carefully also helps. I recommend working with classmates who can help provide any additional intuition, since the instructors and preceptor might not be able to communicate this as well.
descrip: This course is the second term of a 2 term sequence in Microeconomics.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - House of Debt: Understanding Macro & Financial Policy
descrip: Why do severe recessions happen? Could we have prevented the Great Recession and its consequences? And what actions are needed to prevent such crises going forward? We undertake an empirical exploration of these questions in this course and debate the various macro and financial policy questions that arise. Our discussions are strictly disciplined by data and evidence. The course analyzes the role of debt in generating the Great Recession and the Great Depression, as well as the current economic malaise in Europe.

title: Clientelism and Redistributive Politics
descrip: Clientelism has evolved from the analysis of archaic and mostly agrarian political structures to a more general study of opportunistic electoral strategies. It has also become a central debate in comparative politics, on how to turn democratic reforms into better governance and effective development policies. The goal of this course is to document and analyze clientelism and discuss conditions under which it can be replaced with or evolve in programmatic, universalistic and more efficient electoral and policy-making practices.

title: The Making of Modern France: French Literature, Culture, and Society from 1789 to the Present
reviews: Definitely take this class to practice your French. You will get a lot of reading practice in a fairly chill environment, as well as some speaking and listening practice. I would highly recommend. Not too much work.
Do the readings
Do the readings and try to speak more in class. There is not a lot of work and could be a good PDF option.

FRE 222 is a great 200-level French class. Workload wise I would describe it as similar to a 300-level. As a whole, its a great overview of French history and culture. I took it during an overall busy semester and found it quite doable.
Great course- 10/10 recommend. Make sure you do all the reading and participate a lot in class.

I took 222 instead of a higher level french class because I thought it would be a good bridge and was interested in learning the essentials of French history, art, and literature. I really regret not dropped this class after the first few lecture or PDF-ing it. I learned more from wikipedia than I did from lectures and felt that essays and participation were graded harshly considering what we were presented with in class. Try another french class, maybe a higher level which will be more focused.
Prof. Blix is a great, engaging and friendly professor. It's a great class if you're interested in French history/culture.

The best way to profit from the classroom discussions and to enhance your language skills is to actually engage the material and make sure you understand as much of the reading or film as possible prior to class.
You should take it if you are interrested
stay on top of the weekly readings, and take a ton of class notes
prereqs: Prerequisites: 107, 108, or equivalent. 207 recommended as a co-requisite..
descrip: This course examines the major historical and cultural developments that have shaped France since the Revolution. By studying a series of classic texts, important films, paintings, and essays, we will undertake an interdisciplinary tour through two centuries of French cultural history, addressing issues such as nationhood, colonialism, democracy, and consumer society. The focus will be on the relations between artistic renovation, social change, and historical events.

title: Language & Subjectivity: Theories of Formation
descrip: The purpose of the course is to examine key texts of the twentieth century that established the fundamental connection between language structures and practices on the one hand, and the formation of selfhood and subjectivity, on the other. In particular, the course focuses on theories that emphasize the role of formal elements in producing meaningful discursive and social effects. Works of Russian formalists and French (post)-structuralists are discussed in connection with psychoanalytic and anthropological theories of formation.

title: The Media in America - What to Read and Believe in the Digital Age
reviews: Absolutely take this course! The final project is the best part of the course because it requires you to develop a lot of skills that have applicability in the real world- research, sending out emails and calling people for interviews, the interviews themselves, and analyzing all of these primary sources to come to a conclusion about the topic you've chosen. The individual meetings with Professor Stephens are extremely helpful for talking out your ideas and forcing you to stay on top of work. The guest speakers Professor Stephens brought in were also amazing: Walter Robinson from Spotlight, Neil Barsky (founder of the Marshall Project), James Steele (a famous investigative reporter)

Awesome course!! Prof. Stephens is the best. So passionate and enthusiastic. A total journalism nerd. Really makes the class feel like a big journey of discovery, with plenty of surprises and a couple cool field trips to boot! Great class to take to learn more about the state of the media and dunk your head for a bit into the world of journalism.
Definitely take! The workload is manageable, and even as someone not especially interested in going into journalism, it was a great experience!

Super interesting class with fun guest speakers! Be prepared to do the readings and work hard on your assignments - you really get to delve deeply into topics both in class discussions and in your own work. It helps to have some journalism experience but it's not necessary. Professor Stephens is great and really cares about making the class engaging and fun!

TAKE THIS CLASS. Do not even think twice. Professor Stephens is absolutely incredible, the class discussions are a blast, and there are are guest speakers and field trips galore. One of the most challenging but most rewarding classes I've taken at Princeton.
TAKE THIS COURSE. I'M WRITING THIS IN CAPS LOCK BECAUSE THIS COURSE STILL MAKES ME EXCITED.

TAKE. If Professor Stephens is teaching, this will likely be your favorite course at Princeton. I have had many extraordinary seminars but this has certainly been my favorite. He's a great, friendly guy -- perfect for drawing people into interesting discussions. Everyone always seems to feel welcome and eager to contribute. Great subject matter too. One day we spent twenty minutes watching a story through VR headsets he brought. Another day we had the founder of the Marshall Project come in. Another day it was Robby Robinson from the Boston Globe's Spotlight team. Twice we took field trips into the city. You'll have great fun, you'll learn, you'll feel welcome and engaged, and you'll become not only a better media consumer but also a better writer and journalist.
Take this class! Engaging material, manageable coursework, fantastic guest speakers. You'll be surprised every class!
Take this course, you will learn so much about media in America and engage with problems you may not have known existed. The guest speakers are also amazing.

This class was by far and away the best class I've taken at Princeton. Professor Stephens is absolutely incredible: he brings such energy and enthusiasm to every seminar.
