Put a lot of time and thought into your final project over the course of the semester--not only in order to do well, but because doing so is really rewarding.

This course was absolutely amazing, and I am normally not a fan of seminars, as I generally can't sit for that long. Each week was completely different, lots of incredible guest lecturers, and Professor Stephens is great.
This is the best class I've taken at Princeton. Take a course with Professor Stephens before graduating.
prereqs: If the course fills, you may email ldetitta@princeton.edu to be put on a waiting list. Please include a paragraph about the reasons for your interest in the course..
descrip: This seminar will explore the challenges and opportunities that today's rapidly evolving media landscape presents to freedom of the press, and to the democracy that the media serve. Discussion will focus on where news comes from and how citizens can best assess the credibility of individual news reports. Students will evaluate how successful traditional mass-media outlets and emerging digital media have been at accomplishing the lofty goals embodied in the First Amendment. They will craft strategies for determining their own personal media diet and work to develop new models for serious, sustainable news ventures.

title: Sonic Cinema: Music, Noise, and the Moving Image
reviews: Amy is absolutely amazing! If you have any interest in Film or Music TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
Definitely take this course! You will encounter a range of film and media and will learn a lot about how sound shapes our experience. Amy is fantastic!

If you are looking for a quantitative course or a history of films, this course is not for you. If you want a course that you will leave you feeling like you know every significant film and its sound from mainstream Hollywood, this is also not the right course for you. But, if you want a course that will push your boundaries and make you think about sound?both in film and other environments?differently, this course will become a source of continual intellectual stimulation/challenge and entertainment. It has been my favorite course so far at Princeton. 10/10 stars! It has made me see sound in a whole new way!!

Professor Herzog is very engaging and she has so much outside knowledge...she has made this course intellectually stimulating. Take this course if you have any interest in film and sound. Don't expect to watch a ton of films that you've seen-- that's part of the fun of this course.
TAKE IT!! Amy is amazing and you come out with a more tangible way to analyze sound and film in general.
Take this class. It's entertaining, fun, and Amy is a fantastic professor
The readings are important, but not the focus of the class. Closely read the ones by the main scholars, quick-read the others, and come in prepared to talk about the screening.

This course deals with a lot of really interesting intersections between sound and film. It's not really about scoring so much as it is about sound in general, though so don't go in expecting that, but it is a very interesting course.
Yes, I would recommend. I wasn't raving about the class but it was a pleasant experience and the professor is really nice and fun.
descrip: This course will explore the use of sound in relation to moving images, including film scoring, musicals, soundtracks, music videos, and experimental sound and video art. Significant attention will be devoted to digital technology and media soundscapes,and we will return to several questions throughout the course: How does sound reinforce regimes of audiovisual representation? How does it disrupt them? To what political ends do artists deploy sound, music, and noise? What role does technology play in their effectiveness? Screenings will range from Hollywood blockbusters and immersive media to fine art, video games, and independent cinema.

title: What is Vernacular Filmmaking?
reviews: Erika's theories are sometimes very difficult, so it sometimes takes some patience to see her core ideas. Incredibly rewarding class if you put in the effort though! Certainly changed the way I see film.
Great film seminar; I will never view films the same way. Good course to take for a distribution (and/or senior spring course).
It's silly that Princeton doesn't have a film department- but at the same time, it means you can take this class regardless of your major! Embrace the films, and have fun!
Please take this class if you are interested in film!!! The seminar is long, but not too difficult and always interesting. I can't wait to take this class again next time it is offered.
Take it. You will enjoy it, and learn to look at films in a different way.

This is a great class to take, if you get the chance to take it. It's a good opportunity to watch intriguing films you otherwise might never hear about, and the class challenges you to see film in a way you may not have considered before.
descrip: We will study films that address global audiences while rooted in particular, local,vernacular sources of artistic creation. In order to understand this aesthetic phenomenon of World Cinema, we will examine theories of World Literature. Especially, we will focus on Auerbach's famous book, Mimesis and his work on the formation of vernacular audiences.

title: Reasoning about Computation
reviews: A decent course

Although this has a reputation for being the weed-out course for COS majors, I thought it was not so bad if you have a good study group. The midterm and final are very challenging, but it's not too difficult to ace the homeworks if you put in the time, have a good group, and are willing to go to office hours.
Avoid if at all possible. Will take up loads and loads of time. Will be miserable at times.

COS 340 has a pretty bad rep for being this terrible course all COS majors have to take. Bernard Chazelle is the man, and will make this course bearable, if not enjoyable. Definitely take it with him, and you might actually enjoy your theory requirement!

Chazelle is a good teacher; I would recommend taking it with him. He's really funny and explains things well. I also found the material to be relatively interesting, despite the fact that I don't generally enjoy theoretical classes.

Chazelle is a horrible lecturer and I dislike him as a person because he makes people feel stupid for asking questions, but the class was less challenging with him than it seems to have been in previous years. If you do the readings though you can skip lecture and avoid Chazelle as much as possible. Go to precept though.

Chazelle is a poor lecturer. Take the LL and LLM books and read them in the comfort of your room instead of going to lecture. Find a problem set group with Math majors. Have some background in probability, number theory and be prepared to move at lightspeed.
Chazelle is very good at providing intuition and generally making lecture entertaining. The material is really interesting but the problem sets are time-intensive.

Chazelle was an amazing professor who made this class as bearable as possible, and sometimes even enjoyable.  Prof. Batista was also always ready to help and was very flexible and the preceptors and TAs provided so much help.

Definitely take it -- the best course I've taken, at Princeton or otherwise! The concepts are really interesting, Chazelle and the textbook very funny, and the course material makes you actually think. It improves your reasoning skills in general, and you learn a lot of interesting mathematical things along the way.
Did not like this class

Do not take this course with 426 and 333. You will have sleepless nights consistently throughout the whole semester. Otherwise, engage in the material and enjoy everything you're going to learn because it's extremely fascinating!
Do the reading, and start the assignments early, so you have time to ask questions.

Fairly straightforward class. It takes up time, as psets may take a while to complete, but it's not terrible. Also if you have to take it, don't go into it dreading the class. It's honestly not as bad as its reputation says it is.
Final was super hard, hard to study for
Get a good group!!
Get a good pset group, go to lab hours if you need to, use the resources and Piazza if you need it.
Go to office hours! Bring good questions and you'll learn the most there.
Good cos class if you like math-y stuff. Completely reasonable as far as what this class is trying to teach.
Good course. Take for a fun quantitative course if in possession of a solid mathematical background, though I can see how this course would be difficult without.

Honestly: only take it if you have to, but if you do know that it's doable if you put several good hours a week into the homeworks. GO TO OFFICE HOURS: Sandra and the other TAs are all excellent resources. I ended up structuring my entire week around 340 office hours. Also, make sure you get a good group of 3 together by the first or second week of the semester or the rest of the course will be absolutely miserable. At least the sense of camaraderie is unbeatable? There will always be people to ride the struggle bus with you.
I had no math background but still enjoyed much more than 226. You can do it with enough dedication. Grind through it if you have to!
I liked it but I'm not a COS major, so take with a grain of salt.
I love professor Chazelle! He is the FUNNIEST professor ever! He is just AMAZING! Take it with Chazelle. You won't regret it. He makes this class 100 times better.

I really enjoyed the class. If you have a strong math background this will be easy (I am a math major), otherwise I could see people struggle. I think it's a good class for cos students to understand math processes. The problems were actually good and meaningful.

I wouldn't take this unless it's a requirement. If you're thinking of taking this for interest, and you're only interested in a particular subset of the topics, I would take a different course that covers the topic in more depth.

If Sandra is still in charge of the course, go to her a lot. She's a lot more receptive than at first impression, and will help you a lot. If everyone in the course makes known an issue or problem, she and the other instructors will work to make an extra problem-solving session or more office hours or whatever is needed. Also, while you shouldn't freak out about the problem sets (people exaggerate), do try to get responsible group members. Start the psets together, look over it together, split up the problems and work a bit by yourselves, go to office hours, get back together to continue working on the problems. And DON'T BE AFRAID TO GO TO SANDRA.

If you are not so inclined for mathematical proofs this one can be very difficult. Be prepared! Take it with easier courses. I took it with 5 classes, but one was pdf only. This was manageable. Also office hours are a must. Psets are long and difficult, but at least they offer a lot of help at office hours and lab hours. After covering error bounds (around week 7) it starts to get easier. Despite the difficulty the material is fairly interesting and Chazelle is a pretty engaging lecturer. He goes through the material pretty fast though. Overall, very difficult/interesting class that you probably have to take as cos major, so get ready.

If you're COS, you pretty much are required to take it. Be prepared to spend lots of time in office hours, but problem sets really help you understand the material! Chazelle is a funny lecturer if you can stay awake, and the Lab TA's and preceptors (Sandra and Jonathan) are extremely helpful.

If you're a COS major, you have no choice. Take it with Prof. Chazelle because he's cool and pretty reasonable! The preceptors seemed to care a lot about the students and they now have Lab TAs, videos, and a lot of office hours to help you out. A lot of weekly work, but you'll get through it. If I could (not a math person), you can too!
Interesting stuff. Chazelle isn't particularly good at lecturing though.
It's a fun-math class.
It's bearable.

It's honestly a hard class, but chances are, as a COS major you are going to have to take it. Find a really good PSET group, this can literally make or break the class for you. Also make use of office hours, the preceptors will help you because they understand the struggle.
Know that it is very time consuming, but go in with curiosity rather than fear and you may enjoy it more than you think you will
Liked the class a lot, very interesting problems discussed. Medium amount of work especially for a cos class
Make sure to stay on top of readings.
Math majors, do it for the GPA boost.  COS majors, do it cause you should know this stuff anyway.
Pick a good team to work with that is at your same level.

Problem sets are unnecessarily hard but I suppose you learn. This course is easier if you take ORF 309 first. The material isn't really presented in a reasonable way if this is your first time seeing it.
Stay ahead of readings and go to office hours/TA hours. Those are extremely helpful to completing the assignments and understanding the material.
Take advantage of office hours.

Take it because you have to. Find a good group. Sometimes while working on a problem set you'll feel like a simple caveman trying to rediscover how to create fire out of a flower and a grasshopper (you can't). And when you reach moments like those, you go to off office hours where if the TA is helpful will hand you a lighter and you go "ahhh" and you are able to create fire. Other times the TA is just as clueless as you are and tells you to replace the grasshopper with a cricket and sends you on your way.
Take it if you are interested in sampling some mathematical topics relevant to computer scientists or if you want to take some sort of upper-level math survey course.
Take it if you have to. If you don't you probably shouldn't. It's an overview of a lot of theory topics, and I think that I learned a lot, but uncertain the pain was worth it.
Take it if you need it.

Take it with Chazelle - tremendously easier than it has been in previous semesters. The probability weeks were kind of tough for me as I've not taken a single probability class here, but those with ORF classes under their belts did just fine.
Take the course as it is a prerequisite for a lot of other theory classes, but if you do not have a math background be prepared to play catch-up.
Take this class! Chazelle is hilarious and absolutely amazing. You also learn so much theory and it is a great introduction/survey of tools you'll need for other COS classes!
The course moves quickly but is doable.  I am bad at math and was able to come out ok.  Go to lab hours and try not to depend on anyone but yourself.

The key to my success in this course was office hours!!  In general, it was definitely not as bad as I had heard.  The readings are very helpful and the preceptors and everyone at office hours are really willing to help!
The weekly problem sets are short but can take some time to figure out. Start early, and it's definitely one of the courses with a manageable weekly course load.
This class is hard and time consuming. A pset will take at least 10 hours without counting the hours needed to just understand the material.

This class is one you need to take with a friend or two in order to be able to work on psets together. Also, it's wise to start the psets three days before they are due to allow yourself time to think about the proofs. Timing them up with LaTeX can also be annoying for beginners. Take it if you like the material being covered and you have a friend.

This class is really hard. Be willing to work a lot and go to office hours for help. Do well on the problem sets because exams are really difficult. If you are a COS major you have to take it, so just be ready to work hard.

This class is very difficult, there's no way around it. To have any chance at a good grade, you must form a smart problem set group - don't automatically go for your best friends - because a near perfect homework grade is manageable if you spend the time. Exams are brutal and you will be completely stumped on some questions and that is why homework is so important. For the love of everything that is good, start problem sets early and go to basically all office hours that are available. You will spend so much more time on this class then you already have to if you don't get help. And if you don't have to take this course, don't take this course.
This course is quite difficult as a CS major with little theoretical background. The in class exams are a bit more difficult than expected.
This course is very math heavy and thus requires a significant effort from a student who is not mathematically inclined.
This is a math course. It's not that fun. Chazelle is great. Take it if you must and you're COS. Find partners who are good at math proofs. Go to office hours.

This is a theory requirement.  Take it, but expect considerable time spent on homework assignments (Choose a smart/good group!) If you are a math nerd (you know who you are) than this class will challenge and be fun. If you are not a math person, welcome to mandatory hell.
Tough course but also rewarding and enlightening if you've never seen the material before. Find a good group to work on the problem sets with.
Try to take this class when Chazelle is teaching it.

Very fun problems, challenging but fair. Great collaboration policy: take with friends. If you want to learn the content, you will enjoy the course a great deal. If you need to take a theory course, you might as well take this one.

Very hard.  Take it if you have to, but understand what you're getting into. P-sets are nearly impossible without spending 8 hours in office hours.  A solid half of my week every week went into this class.  Material is interesting, just hard and time consuming.
Wonderful course, gives you the capacity to think deeply about problems. Every COS person needs it.
You have to take it if you're COS, don't take it if you're not
You will learn a lot but it's a lot of work. Only those who put in the work will survive. Take it if you can: I am not a CS major, took the class and I liked it (though I found it very very hard).

You'll have to spend a lot of hours in OH. Start psets early and do the readings before lecture. Be aggressive about understanding material the first time you encounter it - you won't be able to revisit it.

You're probably gonna have to end up taking it anyway, so don't be too miserable about it. I didn't think it was as bad as others made it out to be, but find a good study group, keep up with the material (as you would for any other class), and be proactive about your own learning. Don't expect things to be handed to you, but don't complain if you're not being proactive. The course staff are good and friendly enough to offer very good help if you ask for it, but you've gotta work for it. Good luck!
could be better, could be worse
interesting course, Chazelle is great
take it w chazelle!!!! & go to office hrs
prereqs: COS 126 and 226 (or sufficient mathematical background), and MAT 175, 202, 204. COS 226 can be taken along with COS 340 in the same term. Please contact the professor directly with any questions you may have..
descrip: An introduction to mathematical topics relevant to computer science. Combinatorics and probability will be covered in the context of computer science applications. The course will present a computer science approach to thinking and modeling through topics such as dealing with uncertainty in data and handling large data sets. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts such as NP-completeness and cryptography that arise from the world view of efficient computation.

title: The Italian Renaissance: Literature and Society
prereqs: A 200-level Italian course or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will introduce students to the basic trends and problems of Renaissance literature as the main source of our civilization. The major literary figures of the 16th-century Italian revival (such as Machiavelli, Leonardo, Galileo, Castiglione, Michelangelo, etc.) will be studied in relation to their time, the courts or the cities where they lived, and their seminal contributions to modern Europe culture including works of visual art, theater, and good living.

title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition
reviews: Excellent course, but of course not easy at all. Generally equal in difficulty and workload to 105, but easier overall due to having a semester to get used to Dmitri. For precepts, Dmitri's will be much much more advanced - he does not review lectures but uses the time to go more in depth (but the harder material is not homework or exams).
Go to lecture, work really hard on the psets because they're a huge part of the grade. Read the handouts. If you don't have Dmitri, your year will be a lot easier.
Highly recommend, super interesting

If you have taken MUS 105 and you though it was interesting, take this course. If you haven't (maybe you placed out), and you are interested in music, take this course - even if you feel like you are very experienced. If you take this class with Dmitri, you will come out of it with new perspectives of music - some of which he invented himself. He really gives you a coherent and beautiful presentation of music.
It is not an easy class but if you're really interested in composing great music, it could be extremely useful.
Keep up with everything and you'll do fine
MUS 106 is AWESOME!!!! TAKE IT!!! (especially if Tymoczko is teaching)

Next year 105-106 is likely to be easier and less rewarding since Dmitri isn't teaching it, but still the basics of music theory will change the way you think about music so it's a great sequence to take.
Not sure if Dave Molk is going to be back or not, but this is a must take if he's precepting. Otherwise, do it if you have to for the certificate as I did.
Take if you're interested in learning a lot about theory in one year! It's a lot of work, but by the end you'll be composing very well.
Take this course!  It's a lot of work and Professor Tymoczko cuts an intimidating figure, but it's so worth it--whether you're a music major or simply a lover of music.

This is a great course to take. If you enjoyed Music 105, then I would say this course is still slightly better, since you learn modern harmonies such as Jazz, Impressionism and Romanticism, but still all connected to the classical tradition it is built on. This course has certainly helped me learn enjoy more music and has made me compose a lot of awesome stuff!
Very very good class - take

this will be much different without Dmitri. probably easier. theory is really helpful obviously and composing is fun. analysis is a pain. you probably need to take it but if you're just interested i would also recommend
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of the instructor. This course is a prerequisite for all upper-level theory work, and should be taken by any freshman considering majoring in music, entering the Certificate Program, or taking upper-level music courses..
descrip: A continuation of MUS 105, with an emphasis on the harmonic and formal principles of Western classical music. We will focus on modulation, chromatic harmony, and form, continuing to study and compose music in classical and other styles.

title: A Gendered History of the Avant-Garde: Bodies, Objects, Emotions, Ideas
reviews: Absolutely take this course! The instructor is incredibly knowledgeable, approachable, and helpful.

Read everything thoroughly - it's all fascinating (particularly the Futurist texts) and quite beautiful. This is probably a class you could get through without reading the material for, but don't deprive yourself of this fantastic literature that probably isn't taught in any other classes at Princeton (or the nation, for that matter). Professor Giammei also often brings in correspondences with the writers themselves, which is extremely exciting, as we often have the chance to communicate with actual poets and visual artists in Italy today. You also probably have to be a feminist to take this class, or at least open to acknowledging the prejudices women face. Keep an open mind - again, this is a class on the avant-garde, but if that worries you, you can almost always trace a work's roots back to classic antiquity or medieval times. Quite a few of the pieces are rewritings of other writers. You're not obliged to love everything discussed in the class, but that's just part of studying the avant-garde - the class is heavily discussion-based!
Take this class!!

Take this course. Professor Giammei is amazing and so passionate, and although it is a lot of work, the expectations are clear and help is more than available. The teaching and material is well worth it.
take
prereqs: No knowledge of Italian language is required. All the linear texts will be provided in English. Students may choose to read part of the texts in the original language (Italian, French, German). Freshmen are welcome..
descrip: An investigation on modern and post-modern experimentalism focused on gender issues and gendered perspectives. The main object of analysis will be Italy, from futurism to the current revivals of vanguardism, but a variety of trans-national and international voices will substantiate the historical landscape. We will address a number of case studies and their socio-cultural contexts: from aviatrixes and futurist women to the bodies of surreal metamorphic creatures in paintings and stories, to neo-avant-garde movements in the Sixties and Seventies, to post-punk books, non-textual literature, and audio/video-poetry.

title: Infection: Biology, Burden, Policy
reviews: Attend lectures. Ask questions. Do well on presentations and try to keep up with readings.
Chill and interesting senior year mol class
Great course! Very chill senior year course!
I really enjoyed the class and a wide range of topics were covered, but it was much more science oriented than policy oriented. Overall the class had very little work.

I would highly recommend this course for anyone. There are a few lectures that rely heavily on biology but this shouldn't be a reason for not taking the course. Basically, you can still do well in the class even if biology is not your forte. The professors know that not all the students in the class are MOL or EEB students.
If you can get into this course, take it! It is truly a gift to be taught be these two professors.
It was a great senior spring class in terms of the workload, but I don't feel like I got as much out of it as I would have liked.
It's a really good, interesting course to take senior spring!
More science than it seems like from the description. It's like 90% bio 10% policy. I was the only student from the humanities in the class.
Really really engaging course!

Take it if you can get in. 1 presentation. 1 week of discussion leadership. 1 five-page paper. 
Take it, so easy. Full of checked-out seniors, super sweet profs. V low-commitment.
Take this class!
This class is a really good senior spring class. Not too much work, but also very interesting and engaging.

This is a great class for those interested in global health and some current diseases, health concerns, and infectious diseases. The size of the class make participation difficult, but the topics are interesting. Prof. Mahmoud is a great lecturer and knowledgeable about pretty much anything you ask about global health. The workload is one major presentation, a short paper for Dean's Date, and participation.
good! take it, super chill course - more MOL biology than expected
prereqs: MOL101, MOL 214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will examine fundamental determinants of human microbe interaction at the biological and ecological levels. The focus will be on major global infectious diseases, their burden of illness and policy challenges for adequate prevention and control. Each infectious agent will be discussed in terms of its biology, mechanisms of pathogenesis, and epidemiology, as well as strategies for its control. Specific emphasis will be placed on the public health aspects of each disease.

title: Civitas Foundation Finance Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Nonlinear System Theory
reviews: If you are interested in the subject, go for it. The professor is a bit new, but gives clear lectures, answers questions well, and is very open to feedback.
If you will be doing control theory for your research then this course is essential background material for most applications.
It's very theoretical.
be prepared to self-teach
it is a course to see theory of nonlinear system.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ELE521/MAE547 or MAE434.
descrip: This course covers topics in nonlinear dynamical systems including phase plane analysis, Lyapunov stability, input-output stability, passivity, averaging and singular perturbations for time-scale separation.

title: Educational Psychology
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of busy work. Decently interesting if you're into it. Take it if you really like the material or are interesting in being a teacher or psych major, not otherwise. Good luck!
Keep up with the written work!
Only take this class if you're in TPP.

Take if you have to. It's a bit boring unless you're really interested in all the possible topics that can come up in the class. The professor tries really hard, but it doesn't make the class very interesting.
Take this course if you are interested in teaching.

take the course if you are TPP or interested in learning about being a teacher.. even though I was not a fan of the professor.. I still found the course materials AMAZING and was stoked to have so many opportunities in class and for weekly assignments to directly apply what I had learned about from the perspective of a teacher
prereqs: This course is required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Priority is given to Juniors and Seniors in TPP. Other Juniors and Seniors may enroll only with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.

title: The Great Russian Novel and Beyond: Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, and Others
reviews: A great class, but be warned - reading load is 300-400 pages/week. Take it if you're either willing to sink lots of time into it or PDF.
Do the readings! they're great
Do the readings.
Don't underestimate amounts of reading -- it's a TON. That said, they're great texts and I had fun challenging myself to read them.
Funny, clear and enthusisastic teacher. Fascinating material. A lot to read, but it worth doing it.

Good class, not great. If you want to expand your knowledge of classic literature, like I did, or are looking for a relatively easy LA that you don't have to do all the reading for, this is a good class.
Great books, though prepare to read a lot of sadness, which can get annoying. I would recommend a course with greater scope beyond exclusively Russian literature.

If you have even a passing interest in Russian literature, take this class. Professor Chances is an amazing professor who brings her enthusiasm and passion for literature to class with her every week. The reading is heavier than suggested on the registrar page (realistically falls between 150 and 400 pages a week), but with a mixture of reading, skimming, and cliffs notes it is still manageable. The grading in this class is very reasonable. I was a little nervous before taking this class (as it was to be my first discussion-based course), but ended up feeling comfortable in the class, despite being a BSE frosh amongst mostly upperclassmen majoring in Slavic lit, philosophy, woody woo, etc. Have definitely recommended this course to friends.
Lots of reading so make sure you have the time but the content is incredible.
Professor Chances is a solid lecturer and genuinely interested/engaged in discussions with you

Really loved the books. This is a great course, something you can take as a nonmajor interested in the subject and really get something out of. Being able to take exams rather than papers lessens the workload as well.
Take it!  Reading load can be heavy (and it's really only worth it if you intend to do all the reading), but the class is very enjoyable and informative.  And the books are (mostly) good!
Take it! It;s definitely worth it for the Russian Lit if nothing else
Take it!!!! One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton

Take this course if you want to read and discuss some influential works of fiction and get a sense of the topics of interest of Russian authors. Be prepared to keep up with the readings if you want to get the most out of this class. That can be difficult, of course, as some of the novels are long and dense, but even if you are not able to do so completely, you will learn a lot from lecture and precept.
Take this course--one of the best courses offered at Princeton.
The lectures were not great. The books are great but a lot of reading (300pp a week). Professor chances is incredibly nice .
Very interesting course; fascinating literature.
take it!
take it! Readings are much heavier in the beginning of the course, but after the midterm you can give it as much attention as you want. Also, interesting ideas and new topics emerged with each unit
prereqs: Curiosity. Knowledge of Russian not required. Open to first-year students as well as to sophomores, juniors, and seniors in any department..
descrip: An examination of significant trends in Russian literature from the 2nd half of the 19th century to the Russian Revolution and a bit beyond. The course focuses on many masterpieces of 19th & 20th-century Russian literature. The works (mostly novels) are considered from a stylistic point of view and in the context of Russian historical and cultural developments. The course also focuses on questions of values and on the eternal "big questions" of life that are raised in the literature. Authors read include Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bely, Nabokov, and Kharms.

title: Elementary Turkish II
reviews: It's a super fun class.
Take it! You'll learn alot in a short span of time and she truly is the best.
prereqs: TUR 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Familiarity with all grammatical aspects of Modern Turkish. Reading text of moderate difficulty; developing communicative skills: ability to comprehend and engage in daily discourse; ability to write short compositions.

title: German Literature after 1945 - Ingeborg Bachmann und Susan Taubes -- Literatur und Philosophie nach
descrip: A comparison of contemporaries, whose oeuvres show many parallels although their lives differ greatly, who never met but were partly in contact with same people (e.a. Scholem, J. Taubes): German writing Bachmann (1926 Klagenfurt - 1973 Rome) and English writing S. Taubes (1928 Budapest -1969 New York, exiled in 1939). Against the backdrop of the intellectual climate in post-war Europe, U.S., and Israel, the reading includes the novels Malina (1971) and Divorcing (1969), selected poetry and prose, the dissertations and essays on philosophy (e.g. Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Simone Weil), and correspondence (with P. Celan, H.-W. Henze, J. Taubes).

title: Advanced Topics in Modern Architecture - The Perversions of Modern Architecture
reviews: Take this class if you are interested in building an alternative history of the Modern movement.
Would like for more access to what the instructor is thinking.
descrip: Modern architecture was never straightforward. Despite the surface rhetoric of rationality, clarity and efficiency, modern architects were engaged with everything that escapes rationality: sexuality, violence, exoteric philosophies, occultism, disease, the psyche, pharmacology, extraterrestrial life, artificial intelligence, chance, the primitive, the fetish, etc. Through a series of case studies from the early twentieth century till today, of both mainstream figures and misfits, the class will explore the backwaters of modern architecture to reveal the astonishing richness and eccentricity of the field.

title: Illusions, Delusions, and Neuroscience
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Information Signals
reviews: Alright course if interested in signals - gives good foundation. More complicated concepts Going to class and office hours probably would've made it more manageable

Although this class has a lot more math than 203/208/208, I still found it surprisingly interesting. It's a bit challenging, but Fourier is actually really cool. The labs are bad though, hopefully they get updated before you take the course.
Be prepared to learn. Be prepared to study hard. Be ready.
Be warned that Professor Cuff doesn't really care whether the students do well or do poorly, so it's on you to make sure you learn the material.
Go to class and stay on top of things.
Go to lectures and keep up with that material or it'll be really difficult to complete problem sets.
Good class! Interesting and easy STL if you're good at math. 9AM quizzes are a pain.
Good course for an into to information theory and signal analysis. Workload is very manageable and lectures are good.
I loved this course!! The material was very interesting, take it if you're interested in a practical introduction to signal processing and information in general

I really enjoyed the course. It felt a bit scattered at times, and labs were sometimes confusing and detached from lecture, but the class ultimately gave a nice introduction to signals and systems. There are so many cool ways to apply the material learned in this class!
I'd think again before taking this class if not in ELE.

If you're taking this, you're probably ELE. This is a course with a refreshing, more mathematical side to it. I liked it. Early lectures were a pain, and it could use more readings, but it was otherwise very cool. Recommended.
It was more math than engineering

It's very math-heavy, and I would only take it if you're interested in the subject, or are an ELE major. There's a lot of trying to wrap your head around concepts and code in MATLAB, but the things that you can do with it are pretty cool.

Obviously take it if you're ELE and you have to, but don't expect much. Also, don't let it impact your view of ELE as a major. Other classes are much better taught and more engaging. The professor seemed butt-hurt because people didn't show up to his lectures last year, so he made us take 9am attendance quizzes that we'd get a zero on if we weren't there to finish it by 9:03. The TA's were altogether very unhelpful and/or arrogant, and the course overall lacked transparency, clarity, and cohesion. Good luck.
Take it
Take it even if you're not ELE - it is very useful and interesting.
Take it for a basis in the material but do not expect to really enjoy this course
Take it only if you need to
The labs are a bit confusing but you learn a lot in this course. Be prepared to put in a lot of work and read the Kulkarni text.
This course can be confusing. The material itself isn't too difficult, but given the way it is presented, I would say try to be on top of things: go back to the online lectures and use the textbook.
Very interesting! More math and more theory than ELE 208 or 206, but less math than 203. Cuff is a very engaging lecturer. Strongly recommend!
Watch the video lectures.
Work with friends to get help on homework. Watch previous lecture videos.
You have to take it if you're ELE. If you're not, it's probably still a good STL.
prereqs: The prerequisite for this course is knowledge of elementary calculus..
descrip: Signals that carry information play a central role in technology and engineering---ranging from sound and images to MRI, communication, radar, and robotic control. This course teaches mathematical tools to analyze, manipulate, dissect, and preserve information signals. For example, many continuous signals can be perfectly represented through sampling (Nyquist theorem), which leads to digital signals. A major focus of the course is the Fourier transform. We also study linear time-invariant systems, modulation, quantization, and stability (Laplace transform and z-transform). Lab design projects in Matlab include a "Shazam" music ID system.

title: Intermediate Korean II
reviews: A good course for Korean language learning.
I would definitely recommend Korean to anyone who is interesting. The professors are all great and the course material is lovely.

If you have been taking Korean, this is obviously the next step. I feel like I improved a lott compared to first year. Despite that, things have gotten more difficult (the workbook homework takes a while and is really annoying, but necessary)
This is a great course. I would highly recommend it.
prereqs: KOR 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 105. Continued development of four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) in Korean. Complex grammatical structures and irregularities will be taught while the basics are reviewed. Idiomatic expressions will be introduced; journals will be kept for writing practice.

title: Intermediate Syriac
descrip: The aim of the course is to provide the linguistic skills and the academic tools that are necessary to carry out research in Syriac Studies. The first session deals with the transcription of Syriac and presents an overview of the basic resources for academic research. The rest of the course centers on a selection of Syriac texts and addresses fundamental notions of literature, culture, and history.

title: Mortality at the Margins: Race, Inequality and Health Policy in the United States
reviews: Alecia is very approachable!
An interesting subject to learn about and very informative of American politics and history. I would recommend taking it!
Don't be afraid to shoot Alecia an email with any concern she might have because she is super responsive. Also, do the readings because they are really good and informative.
Great class, I highly recommend it. The readings are not too heavy.
Great course. Definitely recommend.
Pretty laid back course. Great readings.
Take it!! Take any class by her :)
Take this class! Not too much work, and you will gain important information you should have particularly if you're premed

Take this course! The subject is very interesting and really teaches you about the health inequalities that people face in America every day. Alecia is a wonderful lecturer (and person) and has great experience in her own public health work that she shares throughout the course. The workload is reading-heavy but manageable. If you have any interest in minority groups in the U.S. or the health field, there is a lot of valuable information you can learn in this class that will help you outside of it.
n/a as she is no longer teaching at PU.
descrip: This course will critically examine the unequal distribution of disease and mortality in the United States along the axes of race, ethnicity, class and place. Through in-depth engagement with case studies, critical historical texts and public health literature we will explore why individuals from some race/ethnicities, class backgrounds, and geographies are more vulnerable to premature death and adverse outcomes than others. Student work will culminate in a policy memo and a presentation, allowing them to hone valuable skillsets for future participation in the research and policy processes.

title: Topics in Science, Technology and Environmental Policy - Global Environmental Governance
descrip: Examines intl law & governance in the context of environmental problems. Considers the need for regulation under conditions of scientific uncertainty in issues such as climate change, fisheries management, whaling management, biodiversity conservation, and ozone depletion. Explores the efficacy of diverse regulatory approaches, mechanisms for scientific advice to policymakers & participation by business firms and NGOs. Considers intersections between environmental regulation (both domestic and international) with trade, investment, & multilateral development and aid programs.

title: Ancient Greek: An Intensive Introduction
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to Ancient Greek. It covers in one semester material usually done in the two-semester introductory sequence (CLG 101/102). Students who complete this course can take CLG105 in the Fall and CLG108 in the Spring. This course aims at providing a reading knowledge of Classical Greek, quickly. Students are expected to be motivated and will have to set aside sufficient time for daily assignments.

title: Seminar in Observational Astrophysics - Current Research Topics in Astrophysics
reviews: Be prepared for it. Esp. please make sure that your presentation time consumption is under control!

I would not recommend this course.  It is undoubtedly worthwhile to get some experience public speaking, but in a course so big, you spend most of the time listening to other talks, rather than talking yourself.  I do not think it is an effective way to learn about astronomy.

The astro seminar course has been undergoing some changes over the last few semesters, and not all of them good.  Please consider carefully whether this course will be an investment of time or a waste of time, if you have the option of not taking it.
This is a good course if you're looking to improve your presenting and speaking abilities . If you're a graduate student in the Astrophysical Sciences Dept., you have to take it anyway.
This is super good chance to practice presenting skills.
take even if you are not a grad student, you can still learn a lot about astro
descrip: Students prepare and deliver presentations on selected topics in observational astronomy, and discuss each other's work.

title: Lighting Design
reviews: Absolutely take this course! Jane lets you take a break to get late meal, and she's an amazing teacher, so the four hours seem to fly by! You learn a lot and have a lot of fun, so it's a great way to get an LA. But even if you don't need a distribution requirement, take it anyways! You won't regret it.

Definitely take the course! Professor Cox works really hard to fit the course to everyone's level of experience with light and theater in general, the work is manageable, and the class covers all kinds of aspects of light. There's a lot of group project work, which has its own good and bad aspects. Start the final project early, especially if you are doing it by hand.
TAKE IT NO MATTER WHO YOU ARE
Take the course if you have experience in lighting design, or just interest in theater.
Take this class with Jane! Take any class with Jane! It's a great class and although a little long it does not require much effort
Take this class, but don't expect to be able to slouch through it.
Take this course if you have any interest in learning about theatrical design!  Jane Cox is an excellent teacher and wonderful person.

This is a wonderful class and Jane Cox is an amazing professor! She truly cares about the material and is able to help students grow from whatever level of technical theater understanding they come in to the class with.

Without a doubt, take this course if you have any interest in light, want to see professional shows, get to work hands on with working designers, and want to work with one of the most generous and interesting designers in the field today.
prereqs: By Enrollment Permission: Please contact Professor Jane Cox at: janecox@princeton.edu.
descrip: An introduction to the art and craft of lighting design for the stage and an exploration of light as a medium for expression. Students will develop an ability to observe lighting in the world and on the stage; to learn to make lighting choices based on text, space, research, and their own responses; to practice being creative, responsive and communicative under pressure and in company; to prepare well to create under pressure using the designer's visual toolbox; and to play well with others-working creatively and communicating with directors, writers, performers, fellow designers, the crew and others.

title: Human Evolution
reviews: A complete joke if you're EEB - never did a reading and went to <50% of lectures and probably pulling an A out of the class. Could be more interesting if Professor Monge was more organized and could lecture more clearly but I'll just take my A!
A great pdf/senior spring class. Professor Monge is a fun/positive/chill/crazy lecturer, which keeps things fairly interesting!
Take this course! It is very interesting and Prof. Monge is excellent.
Take this course. Do it.
This is a good course to learn the basics of human evolution. If you prefer structure and clear expectations, though, this course may not be for you.
Very good course! Taken as an EEB major and I really enjoyed it; if you took EEB 211 you'll be a step ahead in terms of background knowledge
prereqs: Students who wish to receive EEB credit for the course Human Evolution should enroll in this course, ANT 206B/ EEB 306. All other students should enroll in ANT 206A, including EEB (or MOL) majors who do NOT need to receive EEB credit for taking this course (and would not complete the fossil lab project). Please consult your adviser in EEB (or MOL) if you are unsure whether you need EEB credit..
descrip: An investigation of the evidence and background of human evolution. Emphasis will be placed on the examination of the fossil and other evidence for human evolution and its functional and behavioral implications. (See below to determine whether this course or ANT 206A is more appropriate for your interests and needs.)

title: Black & White Photography
reviews: Do not take.  I never want to take a photo again. Way too many projects and horrible time in the lab.  Not an easy A
Don't think this is a low time commitment class. Expect to spend many many hours in the darkroom.

I went into the course with the goal of becoming a better photographer, and came out feeling as though I am. However, the course is a huge time commitment. If you're willing to put in about 10 hours of work per assignment (which is almost every other week), then you could take the class and get an A. The readings that Deana gives are useful, read them. Also be prepared to talk about some topics that you don't know much about.

If anyone tells you that photography is "easy," they probably haven't taken this course. There is a lot of time expected outside class time dedicated to developing, printing, etc. That isn't to say, however, that you don't have great fun doing it and appreciate learning the skill. Such a great LA and worth the time. Plus you can bond with your classmates in the darkroom the night before crits... what else do you need??

If you are not prepared to spend a ton of time (i.e. 12  hours) on assignments DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.  You have to shoot assignments, develop film, and print your own photos in the darkroom.  The printing process can take more than 2 hours for one photo and assignments range from 4-10 final photos.

This class is great, and Deana is an amazing professor. However, the course listing says it is only 3 hours estimated work time outside of class, but it is more like 8  hours per project so don't expect this to be an easy class.

This class takes a lot of time, but it is very worthwhile. Don't take this class unless you really want to. Some people say that the critiques are BS, but that's only true if you feel the need to BS and don't take them seriously.

This is an introductory course to black and white film photography. It's made for people who have never used an advanced camera but have an interest in aesthetics. If you know how to use a DSLR, you'll be repeating some material that you already know but it'll still be interesting and you'll still learn from the class.

Very significant time commitment. Do not take if you are already heavily engaged in other activities/classes. Don't be misled by the course description - expect to spend at least 6 hours outside of class before each assignment is due to develop and print photos. Would not recommend if you are not patient/meticulous/attentive to details. 

Also please be economical with papers! They only provide one box and expect us to get perfect prints, which isn't realistic!
descrip: An Introduction to the processes of analog photography through a series of problems directed toward the handling of film-based cameras, light-sensitive paper, darkroom chemistry, and printing. Weekly laboratory sessions will explore the critical issues of working with black and white imagery today, supported by slide lectures, readings, and discussions of photography as a documentary tool, a political device, an art form. Class critiques of student work are augmented by feedback from guest photographers.

title: Mapping Gentrification
reviews: Class gets boring, is poorly organized. Professor gets frustrated often and does not respond well.
Good to force yourself to take ArcGIS, but Princeton has plenty of better seminars to take.
Interesting material, but even the professor felt the lack of enthusiasm for discussing gentrification near the end of the class. Glad I got to learn some new mapping software though.

Take it for the ARC GIS
Take it for Aaron too
Take the course if you are interested in mapping and gentrification, but it's a good bit of dense reading. The more you put in, the more you'll get out of the course.

This is a good introduction to gentrification. It's a great class to go along with an urban studies certificate or an elective to learn about how you (as a Princeton graduate) may impact the city where you eventually live and work.
descrip: This seminar introduces the study of gentrification, with a focus on mapping projects using GIS (Geographic Information Systems) software. Readings, films, and site visits will situate the topic, as the course examines how racial landscapes of gentrification, culture and politics have been influenced by and helped drive urban change. Tutorials in ArcGIS will allow students to convert observations of urban life into fresh data and work with existing datasets. Learn to read maps critically, undertake multifaceted spatial analysis, and master new cartographic practices associated with emerging scholarship in the Digital and Urban Humanities.

title: Fantastic and the Real, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Rocket and Air-Breathing Propulsion Technology
reviews: Great MAE class for senior spring - psets follow lectures well with the examples and concepts so do not take long at all (~3 hours a week). The midterm required a lot of memorising but also followed problem sets and nothing too unexpected. Really enjoyed the class, learning about rockets and would recommend!
I would definitely consider taking this class if you have an interest in this topic.
Nice TE to take.
Pretty easy if you keep up and do the homework
The assignments are good, and the classes are very interesting! Professor Yu is a motivating knowledgeable teacher!
The problem sets aren't too hard, which is nice. It's a fair course that's a pretty chill upper-level MAE. Why not take it?
Very good course for learning about rockets, the assignments are well designed to help students learn efficiently without doing busy work.
Very interesting class! You spend most of the time on rockets, with at least a week on the history, development, and future of aerospace propulsion, and about two weeks on air-breathing.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222.
descrip: The study of principles, flight envelopes, and engine designs of rocket and ram/scramjet propulsion systems. Topics include jet propulsion theory, space mission maneuver, combustion control, and system components of chemical and non-chemical rockets (nuclear and electrical propulsion), gas turbine, ramjet, and scramjet engines. Characteristics, optimal flight envelopes, and technical challenges of combined propulsion systems will be analyzed.

title: Topics in Critical Theory - Comparative Literature Writing and Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: The Writing and Dissertation Colloquium is a biweekly forum for graduate students in Comparative Literature to share works in progress with other graduate students. The seminar welcomes drafts of your prospectus, article, dissertation chapter, conference paper, exam statement and grant or fellowship proposal. Work is pre-circulated. The 90 minute sessions, done in conjunction with a rotating COM faculty member, are designed to offer written and oral feedback.

title: Sex on the Brain
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Divided We Stand: Economic Inequality and Its Discontents
descrip: See website

title: Sci-Fi Experiments
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Contemporary Theories of Gender and Sexuality
prereqs: GSS 201 or equivalent..
descrip: One is not born, but becomes, woman. So writes Simone deBeauvoir in her landmark work of feminism, The Second Sex. But how do we become women, anyway? In this course we will read The Second Sex in its entirety, exploring Beauvoir's ideas, along with our current ones, about childhood, coming of age, the family, sexuality, relationships, work, the social order, and the philosophical imaginary. We will read Beauvoir alongside the work of her primary interlocutors as well as contemporary theory, memoir, and fiction considering the question of what it means to become a woman--or not--in contemporary culture.

title: Genetics
reviews: Don't do textbook readings. Going to lecture isn't critical (the notes they post online after each lecture are basically everything that is said). Study for exams with the psets. Watch out for psets due Tuesday afternoon and orgo exams Monday nights.........killed me.
Don't take it if you don't need to
Don't take it just for fun because it's a time suck.
Don't take it unless you have to, and work with a group on problem sets.
Don't take this unless you have to. And if you do, brace if yourself.

I came into the class expecting it would be a painful experience based on what past students had told me about it. But the subject matter is actually really interesting and the problem sets are doable if you work with other people. Get a study group - even if you don't have friends in the class (I didn't know anyone when I took it) just ask someone in your precept to work on the problem sets or to join their study group.

I heard bad things about this course going in, but actually found it to be quite a decent course. Workload is absolutely manageable (just one problem set a week) and the lectures, though a bit dry sometimes, are very helpful. If you're MOL (which you almost certainly are if you're taking this course), this course is quite helpful for independent research.
I would advise students to attend all precepts, and participate in precepts in order to understand the material better.
I wouldn't recommend this course unless it is required. Although it is interesting, it is very challenging and time consuming.

If you are a Mol major, you are going to have to take this class. It is a lot of work, but as long as you keep on top of it all semester, it is definitely manageable! Take the time to really work your way through the problem sets and make sure you understand everything on them.

If you are not a MOL major but have a passion for understanding how life works (I'm looking at you, EEB people), then this would be a good class to take. Expect to put in a lot of work, but to come out with a powerful genetic toolkit.
If you have to take this course then take it. For those who have the option it really depends on what you are looking for.
It's tough and time-consuming and agonizing but you'll definitely understand genetics very well when it's all over.
Make sure you actually understand how to answer the questions on the psets because the exams pull from them a lot.
Stay on top of the material, form a reliable study group, and try your best. The material is challenging and the problem sets are very tough and time-consuming. Plan accordingly.
Study for the exams and you'll be fine. One of the better MOL departmentals.
Take the class only if you need it as a departmental!
The textbook is not necessary but make sure to do the practice exams many times and meet with the preceptor if you need it.

This class is hard, but also very interesting if you care about genetics. Just make sure to review often, even if it is difficult. The material sinks in after reviewing it several times. Meet with the professors if you need additional help or clarification on some concept.

This class seems daunting because you have to translate the lectures to help you apply what you have learned to the psets. You will not necessarily be taught how to do the problems in class, and they might look completely foreign, but if you revisit the lecture notes and engage with the material, they are manageable. Also, FIND A PSET GROUP. This class was ultimately engaging because I found a fantastic group to review psets with, and it is pretty hard to get by without taking advantage of that resource.
Very difficult course with very inaccessable lectures. Be prepared to devote large amounts of time to reviewing lecture notes and textbook if you want to succeed.
WORK IN A GROUP FOR PSETS, but still make sure you understand the material on your own.

WORK IN STUDY GROUPS to complete the problem sets. They take a lot of time and doing them with other people help to understand the material while simultaneously completing the problems. It isn't as scary as some people say just make sure you know how to do the problems by the time tests come around.
When I work hard, I feel more reward at the end so I liked it. However, it is a very difficult and frustrating course. There's a lot to be learned though!
Work hard - do a study group and work, work work - repeat the problem sets - if you struggle ASK for help, I was silly not to do so earlier on, and in the end it helped me a lot
Would not take if I didn't have to, extremely time consuming and difficult
You're probably taking this as a requirement. Not too bad, but don't expect anything amazing either.
can gain some appreciation for how people figured this stuff out without all the molecular tools we have today
obviously only take it if you're a MOL major
prereqs: MOL 214 or 215 or by permission of instructor.
descrip: Basic principles of genetics illustrated with examples from prokaryote and eukaryote organisms with emphasis on classic genetic techniques. The evolving conception of the gene and genome will be the primary focus of the course. Selected advanced topics will include Drosophila developmental genetics, yeast cell biology and human disease.

title: Points of Focus in 20th-Century Music
descrip: An analysis course focused on Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" and Mahler's Ninth Symphony. We will spend half the class on each piece.

title: Contemporary Technique and Choreography
prereqs: DAN 219, equivalent previous training, or instructor's permission. Interview information: there is no application for this course. In order to assure correct placement, interested students should contact Professor Tina Fehlandt (Fehlandt@) by email to schedule an interview during the time period of November 9th through 20th, 2015..
descrip: Incorporating aspects of jazz, modern and ballet, this contemporary dance class focuses on strengthening fundamental alignment and coordination. Technique class will start with exercises designed to organize the body and prepare for more technical movement. Class will build in physical intensity culminating in phrase work that is vigorous and challenging. In choreography, students will develop their understanding of the ways in which structural elements and movement vocabularies contribute to a dance's impact and content.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions.

title: Biotechnology
reviews: Arbitrary grading.
Awesome class - great lectures and interesting assignments.
Be cautious if you have a limited bio background (i.e. haven't taken anything beyond mol bio and biochem)

Definitely do the readings. If you haven't taken a ton of MOL courses previously (immunology especially), you might feel out of your depth. Overall though, I learned a lot of really cool things and all of them are really relevant and applicable for someone who is interested in entering the biotech industry someday.
I loved this class. Professor Flint is an amazing teacher and is knowledgeable about all things biotech if that is a field that you want to go into.
If you enjoy talking in class then take it. If not, stay away.

If you want to participate and rack up those points, you must read the research articles closely/carefully beforehand (1-2 times before each class). That way you have a feel for the workflow and experiments done by researchers. The assignments and final project were manageable, so that was nice..

Papers don't necessarily connect to lecture material (you can still do well on them without fully comprehending the seminars). Participation is a major part of the class, so be prepared to fully understand the methods and results sections of the main papers each week.
Participate in class, you will get more out of it.
The class is easy, but you get out what you put in.  If your interested in learning something, you need to put in the effort.
This class is pretty chill, although you should come in pretty comfortable with experimental design in molecular biology so that you can discuss the papers. Good senior class.
This is a well-taught and interesting course. My biggest complaint is how closely participation is monitored--the TA at the front of the class made a note every time someone participated.
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345, or permission of the Instructor.
descrip: This course will consider the principles, development, outcomes and future directions of therapeutic applications of biotechnology, with particular emphasis on the interplay between basic research and clinical experience. Topics to be discussed include production of hormones and other therapeutic proteins, gene therapy, oncolytic viruses, and stem cells. Reading will be from the primary literature.

title: Introduction to Post-Classical Greek from the Late Antique to the Byzantine Era
prereqs: This course is open to all students with a good grasp of Greek grammar and syntax who have an interest in pagan and Early Christian literature and thought in Late Antiquity. Students (graduate and undergraduate) from every department are welcome..
descrip: This course focuses on the debate among pagans and Christians about Homer and the value of pagan literature in Late Antiquity. We will look at how authors opposed Homer to the Bible as a guiding text for society and thought by reading Christian and pagan texts that criticize Homer and the Bible to understand the larger Late Antique debate on intellectual trends in society. This course offers both an understanding of intellectual history, education, and the pagan/Christian debate as well as a survey of various genres and authors in Late Antiquity. Texts read in Greek and in translation.

title: Energy Storage Systems
reviews: A solid coverage of battery technologies and the tradeoffs researchers must make when designing batteries. We only touched briefly on other energy storage technologies like flywheels and pumped hydro. Professor Steingart was engaging and always ready to help. Unfortunately he had to miss about 8 lectures to attend conferences. The assignments were interesting but don't expect to get any of them back. If you're interested in batteries, I recommend at least shopping the course.

Absolutely take this course if you have an interest in batteries. One of the more specialized courses at Princeton, you will learn so much and really be able to take this knowledge into your career path.

Dan has a lot of enthusiasm for the topic and really knows his stuff (it could easily be retitled  Steingart Lab 101). The lectures are engaging and the work is interesting, especially the final project. A lot of the discussion topics are cutting-edge, which is refreshing compared to most other MAE courses, in which the undergrad material hasn't changed for a century.

Don't let Thermo scare you off - Dan's a great professor, and this class is really well taught. It's not easy material, by any means, but you get a lot out of it if you work hard. Definitely take if you have any interest in batteries or energy storage, or if you want a class that feels like a grad seminar without actually being one.

I would only take this if you are interested in chemistry/chemical engineering, even as a side interest. Once you get past the first 1/3 of the class, the content is mostly chemistry. Do not be deceived by its being in the MAE dept.

If you are remotely interested in batteries or energy, you must take this class! Dan is a rising expert in the field, and he conveys his expertise very well. However, Dan is very busy in the spring so expect to see him in class for half the time, and the other half expect to see him give a lecture via google docs. Also find a group in the class to do psets and to study with. That helped me a ton.

This is a great class, and Dan is the man. Energy storage is very relevant to today's world, and Dan does a great job getting your feet wet with it in a way that's applicable to modern/recent developments. I didn't think I was going to do batteries for a career before taking this class and still don't want to go into batteries after this, but I now feel much more comfortable in understanding what batteries' limitations are, where battery development is going, and how to interpret new publications on energy storage. If you're ever struggling in the class, talk to Dan early and often.
fun class to learn about batteries!
prereqs: MAE 221 or Equivalent, Freshman Physics, Freshman Chemistry, Knowlege of ODE/PDE.
descrip: This is a survey course on energy storage systems with a focus on electrochemical energy storage. Fundamentals of thermodynamics will be reviewed and fundamentals of electrochemistry introduced. These fundamentals will then be applied to devices such as batteries, flywheels and compressed air storage. Device optimization with respect to energy density, power density, cycle life and capital cost will be considered.

title: Introduction to Media Theory
reviews: A broad course that covers lots of interesting material, but make sure to stay on top of the readings, especially before precepts.
Definitely take this course if you're interested in German Philosophy/ liked GER210
Dense reading load. Not recommended as an elective.
Do all the reading!
One of the most interesting and intellectually challenging classes I've taken. If you suspect that you'll be interested in the course material, you'll have a good time. Highly recommend.
Take it for distribution req! Really interesting and you'll learn a lot.
Take it if the material appeals to you. It's a very interesting course and will definitely change the way you think about your interactions with various forms of media.
Take it if you're interested in the material. Note that the readings take a while and lecture requires your attention in order to understand what's going on.

Take this course if you're prepared to do a lot of challenging readings. This is not a course for slackers, and it is not a course for people who just want the distribution requirement. This is a really challenging, but worthwhile, course.
This class is more difficult than its 200-level number might suggest, but it's a great intro to the topic and Professor Fore is amazing.

This course is mind blowing. It changed the way I think about language and communication on a fundamental level. I took this course as a lecture, which was the first time that that had been done. The lectures weren't that great, but the precept was awesome, so I imagine that this is a fantastic seminar class. The readings can be a bit hard to understand at times, but again, they are mind blowing. I took it with Fore, who is cool, and I hear that the other guy who teaches it is pretty cool too.
Worth it.  The readings are tough, but good things in life aren't easy.
descrip: Through careful readings of a wide range of media theoretical texts from the late 19th to early 21st century, this seminar will trace the development of critical reflection on technologies and media ranging from the printing press to photography, from gramophones to radio technologies, from pre-cinematic optical devices to film and television, and from telephony and typewriters to cyberspace. Topics include the relationship between representation and technology, the historicity of perception, the interplay of aesthetics, technology and politics, and the transformation of notions of imagination, literacy, communication, reality and truth.

title: Scenic Design
descrip: An introduction to the art and craft of scenic design for the stage and and exploration of the use of space as a medium of textual interpretation. Students will develop an ability to think about scenography as a way deepening and reinforcing an interpretation of a play or other form of performance event. While no experience in scenic design is anticipated, students will learn to create model renderings in order to acquire the creative, theatrical vocabulary needed to work with collaborators to turn a vision of text into a fully articulated visual world.

title: Fantastic and the Real, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Painting
reviews: Pam really helps you grow as an artist, and the class is super laid back! Strongly recommend.
This is a fun class, that requires some hours but not incredibly hard thinking. It's a nice break in the middle of the week.

if you enjoy painting, you will love this class! pam is awesome and the assignments are very productive. class time is enjoyable and you'll have fun doing your homework each week. time spent outside of class is around 3 hours per week but is totally fun. final assignment is a great opportunity to take what you've learned and do your own thing. take this class!
prereqs: VIS 203/204 or VIS 309.
descrip: Painting has always entailed artists establishing a particular link between thinking, seeing and making. This course explores a variety of possible "equations" by which a painting gets made. Students will experiment with different media and approaches: direct observation, ways to use photography, digital images and post-digital imagery. Translation and transformation will be emphasized. Experimentation will provoke students to work in new and unpredictable ways, as well as enable them to discover and develop their own artistic preoccupations. Slide lectures, critiques, and weekly assignments with readings are integrated into studio practice.

title: African-American Literature - The Archival Turn
descrip: If the institutionalization of African American literary history entailed constructing a usable past, what does the field's recent archival turn recommend for future study? The seminar takes up this question as a matter of critical inquiry and research practice. We survey foundational and contemporary black archive theory, paying special attention to problems of history and memory, loss and recovery. At the same time, we grapple with the politics and procedures of actually doing archival research, weighing our desire to tell new stories against the realization that sometimes we cannot.

title: Themes in Islamic Law and Jurisprudence
descrip: Selected topics in Islamic law and jurisprudence. The topics vary from year to year, but the course normally includes reading of fatwas and selected Islamic legal texts in Arabic.

title: Readings in Modern Japanese II
prereqs: JPN 401/EAS 401 or permission of instructor..
descrip: One or two short novels will be used to read for critical thinking. Reading is under focus but speaking, listening and writing (including translation) are intensively practiced. This course is designed to help students develop critical thinking through reading and discussing Japanese novels.

title: Seminar on Student Learning and Methods for Teaching
reviews: Great course. Way less writing than PSY 307, but more "work" in terms of hours observing and teaching a lesson in schools.
If you're considering being a teacher, this is a great class to prepare you -- or help you realize you aren't as sure as you thought you were.
Take it if you're going into education.
This class is a lot of work in terms of teaching observation hours, but very rewarding. Essential if you want to be in the classroom one day.
prereqs: The course is required for students in the Program in Teacher Preparation and is open to non-program students provided space is available. Interested non-program students should contact the Teacher Preparation Office for permission to take the course..
descrip: A study of essential methods of learning and teaching, including learner characteristics and needs, organization and structure of educational institutions, development of curriculum and instructional goals, preparation of evaluation and assessment, and design of subject/level specific methodologies and classroom management techniques. Required course work includes 18 hours of site-based field experience and evening laboratory sessions.

title: Multivariable Calculus
reviews: A good introduction to multivariable calculus.
An experience.

An underrated course if you are genuinely interested in math. A lot of students take it for their engineering requirement and thus find it annoying, but the course is very interesting and Professor Pusateri is a great teacher.
