Anyone taking this course should read the textbook, go to office hours, and pay close attention in class, because this class is very demanding. Keeping up in the class is vital because falling behind can be dangerous if you don't catch back up again. Be ready for each examination as much as possible, and don't treat this class lightly.
Can be frustrating with a bad professor, which is hit or miss. But the material isn't incredibly hard to grasp.

Definitely do not be afraid to ask questions and utilize the textbook to help clarify ideas and concepts. It was definitely a more challenging course, especially if you haven't seen this material before. I would definitely recommend doing a lot of practice problems from previous examinations to prepare for the midterm and final.

Despite what you hear about this course, it is possible to get an A. I had a C  in 104, but I put in a lot of work and pulled an A. However, I devoted quite a bit of time to this course, so really only take this i you have too or if it is very interesting because it is difficult.
Do not take unless you have to

Do the readings and learn the material as it is taught. If you wait until just before the exams to learn all the material, the exams will not go so well. Just doing the homeworks won't really give you a good enough grasp on the material.
Don't go to class, watch Adrian Banner and Khan in the time instead. Or sleep in.
Don't take of you can
Don't take this class unless you have to.  Overly difficult.
Don't take this class unless you have to. It's a lot of work and not much payoff.
Don't take unless you have to. Neither the instructors nor students are interested in this course.
Dont take this course unless you have to. Very challenging.
Get Montezuma as your preceptor, he's great at explaining things.
Get Pusateri as a professor if you can. Don't fall behind in the material, and the 2nd half gets much harder after the midterm.

Go to office hours and McGraw and don't be afraid to ask questions in class for clarity. This material is difficult and if you don't like the way your preceptor teachers shop around and find a professor that would be good for you.
Go to office hours and really work at it. It is a tough class and you have to have a very broad understanding of the material.
Go to office hours.
Go to office hours. I think that is one big mistake I made. And stay on top of your information.
Go to review sessions and ask questions

I found this course much harder than MAT 104, but others found it much easier. It really comes down to whether you find it easy to think spatially and visualize objects in three dimensional space, especially for the second half of the course.
I would tell other students to pay a lot of attention to psets and make sure you understand the material as the course goes along.  Cramming is a mistake.

I wouldn't have taken this course if I didn't have to for engineering, but it's not as bad as people say. If you follow the content and read the textbook you will be fine. The problem sets are much easier than those from 104.

I'd recommend this course if you like math and think you'd be good at it.  It's hard, and most of the kids who take it come from a strong math background, so the curve's pretty tough, but not impossible.

If you can do math it shouldn't be too hard. People say it's hard but it's not that bad. Just do the psets, and the exams are curved. If it's not required, but you have a use for math in 3 dimensions with whatever your career will be, you should take it.
It is a challenging course, but rewarding

It is a required class that needs a lot of improvement. Find a competent teacher of the course and go to office hours to discuss problems from the practice finals and midterms; do these more challenging problems throughout the course.
Keep up with problem sets and textbook readings
Keep up with the textbook and start studying for the final really early!

Learning multivariable calculus solidifies your understanding of regular calculus. In addition, it is far more applicable (in both engineering and everyday uses) than single-variable calculus.

The class itself is enjoyable and well-taught, but is often stressful in terms of exams because of how low grades can be. Furthermore, math courses at Princeton are notorious for having lower grades than other departments, and so it can be frustrating to take an exam with an average of a 51%.
Look at online Khan Academy videos to help you. Just get through the course since its a requirement for a lot of people such as BSE. Get a good teacher!
Make connections as soon as you can and note them down, then confirm them with a preceptor. Create cheatsheets to prepare for an exam, but don't use them during a practice test.
Make sure that you understand the material - if you try to memorize formulas you will not be able to think critically and do well on the tests
Make sure to attend class and to not fall behind on material.
Make sure to understand things as you go along and don't try to learn everything at the end. Go to office hours and McGraw. Read the textbook. Do as many practice exams as possible.
Many people scared me of this course before I took it but I found it very interresting. You need to attend every precept and try to follow the subjects closely if you want to manage in this course

Many people will tell you this class is hard. But compared to what? I skipped MAT 104 to take MAT 201 and I came through pretty much onpar with most, maybe a bit better. I cannot emphasize enough that you should find a good problem set group, but more than that, spend time every week reviewing the concepts outside of class and building upon them, especially in the beginning. Take the time to thoroughly understand the concepts of the course, not only because this will help on tests, but understanding 3D space ends up being a very useful new way for you to think about the world.
N/A
Only take it if you have to.

Please ask other students about the instructors of each section! Some of the instructors are terrible and you will learn nothing from them, so pick your section wisely. Probably one of the worst courses I've taken here because my instructor was so bad. Also, the material is much harder than it seems in the moment, when you take the final, you realize that you are screwed.
Practice as much as you can and don't fall behind because it moves so quickly!

Prepare for a world of hurt. If you have not taken multivariable calculus this will be one of the most miserable experiences you have here at Princeton. If you are just coming from MAT 104 or from AP Calc BC this will be the deciding factor on whether you stay bse.

RUN AWAY IF YOU AREN'T REQUIRED TO TAKE THIS COURSE. If you have to take this course, I pray to God for your GPA. You better expect exams to go from 0 to 100000 faster than you can see "OMG someone help me". Whatever you do, DO NOT TAKE LUCIA MOCZ'S CLASS OR YOU WILL PERISH!!!!!!!!!!!!
Rather easy intro to multivariable.
Read the book and make sure you understand each chapter before moving on to the next one. Go to office hours frequently, Fabio is great and it will be super helpful.

Start early. Do all the practice exams. Go to office hours before finals week. Don't let yourself get behind. Watch Adrian Banner videos to supplement classes, not in one go the day before the final exam. MAT 201 is challenging, so don't feel bad if you're struggling with it.

Stay ahead and keep up with the lectures and problem sets. If at all possible, do the problems before they are covered in class so you can better engage and clarify your learning during the lecture/precepts.
Study, attend office hours, get problem sets done earlier
Switch to AB and don't take this class.
Take it because you probably have to
Take it if you have to. But be ready to be challenged. The class is pretty chill until the last three or so weeks- then you have to focus for dear life.
Take it with Fabio!
Take it. Not too difficult

Taking calculus and applying it in higher dimensions takes some visualization and geometric understanding, which can make it less algebraic than Math 104 but more difficult to know where to begin. Still, class is fair and well organized. Prof. Kommemi is a great instructor-- makes a point to instill problem solving skills and teach how to approach these more complicated problems.
The course is simple enough to understand. And with a little bit of revision at the end, you can get a good grade at the end. It is also very nicely curved.

The most important material comes in the last two weeks- if you can understand what Stokes', Green's, and divergence theorem say from the beginning, the rest is just filling in the meaning and the mechanics of how to use them

The way I found that I did best in this course was to do PSETs ahead of time and try learning the material on your own. I know this sounds crazy but I found that lectures made a lot of sense that way and you did not have the looming pressure of a PSET due that week since you had it done.
There are many nuances and added complexity to the material that you discover only when you go and do the practice exams. Do them early as possible when preparing for exams.
This class is very useful and I would recommend it.

This course is not as bad as everyone says. The tests and quizzes are difficult, but with the curve, if you study and make sure you understand what you're doing, you'll be fine. Most importantly, you want Anibal Velozo as your preceptor -he is super helpful and an excellent teacher!

This is a fantastic course. The material is difficult so don't slack off, especially not at the end where the material gets the most complex. Teach yourself and practice a lot. Make sure you really understand what the concepts mean, rather than memorizing mindless formulas. If you actually understand what's happening, you can derive all the formulas you need.

Try to not be taken in by how conceptually easy the first half of the semester is. At the end of the semester, concepts get confusing quickly, and a concrete understanding of everything that came before is important.
Try to understand the material that you take even though it might be overwhelming at start
Would not take unless you have an interest in Math or need to for your major.
Would recommend this course to non-BSE students who aren't required to take this course but want to explore math at a higher level past MAT 103/104.
You can do it, don't let people say it is too hard. Do the work and go to class.
You're probably taking this course because you have to, not because it looks fun ... so my only advice is, brace yourself.
don't take it you don't have to.
its just youre average math class so difficult exams, around 4 hours a week on problem sets.  If you review throughout the semester you will be fine
make sure you can put a lot of time into it because it takes a lot of time to understand and to do problems. only take it as a requirement for engineering or some other stem major
only take if you have too
take the course
prereqs: MAT 104 or equivalent..
descrip: Vectors in the plane and in space, vector functions and motion, surfaces, coordinate systems, functions of two or three variables and their derivatives, maxima and minima and applications, double and triple integrals, vector fields and Stokes's theorem.

title: Visions of Paris
reviews: An interesting course. I enjoyed the books a lot, but it is a fairly heavy workload, and the lectures can feel a bit long at times.
Be prepared to read ALOT. The first book by Zola was about 50-75 pages of reading a night, which was a lot, but worth it.

I would definitely recommend this course.  It was a very interesting and multifaceted approach to Paris, its history, and its inhabitants, and it made me want to visit the city again very soon with my newfound understanding of its literary and intellectual history.

I would recommend this course to anyone who would like to gain a diverse outlook on Paris and its history. The readings are a bit light for a 300-level course and discussion quality varies greatly depending on who is in your precept.

If you are at all interested in the French & Italian department, French certificate program, summer programs in Paris, or the evolution of Paris and its residents, than this course is a MUST. Take the time to engage meaningfully with the course materials and you will benefit immensely from the course.
If you are interested in Paris, take this course!
Prof Benhaim is great, take the course, especially if you've spent time in Paris.
Really interesting, but definitely challenging. A good, wide-variety readings.. Overall, I really liked the course.
Take it to keep up your French.
Take it! Paris is a great city and you will see it with a new lens.

This class is great! Professor Benhaim makes it really interesting and really cares about the students. Try to get in his precept, if possible. This course will be especially interesting to you if you have been to Paris and can picture and know the neighborhoods. It explores the history of Paris chronologically since the 1860s and teaches you about the development of the city and culture up until today.
prereqs: FRE 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A study of Paris as urban space, object of representation, and part of French cultural identity. Topics include Paris in the Ancien Regime; Revolutionary and Napoleonic Paris; the transformation of Paris in the 19th century; Paris as a site of European art and literature; modern and multicultural Paris in the 1900s; and challenges in the new millennium. Prerequisite: a 200-level course in French or instructor's permission. One 90-minute lecture, one 90-minute preceptorial.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Behavioral Approaches to Policy
descrip: Behavioral science is now widely seen as an insightful tool to address social problems. Several governments, including the UK and US, have embraced this new approach by setting up central 'nudge squads'. Yet, the practice of applying behavioral insights to real-world problems is still very much an emerging science. The same behavioral insights sometimes don't work well even in situations that are seemingly identical. The course introduces methodologies for diagnosing behavioral barriers underlying social issues and then designing solutions to them. We then practice applying the methodologies to several social problems.

title: Advanced Social Statistics
descrip: Introduces theories of inference underlying most statistical methods and how new approaches are developed. The first half of the course covers maximum likelihood estimation and generalized linear models. The second half covers a number of topics useful for applied work including missing data, matching for causal inference and, others. The course concludes with a project replicating and extending a piece of work in the scholarly literature.

title: Contemporary Literary Theory
descrip: Is it possible to have a theory of everything--a theory of the cosmos, of worlds, of life, souls, minds, matter? We will pose this question to a range of thinkers from Plato to Deleuze, all of whom think about reality in the most comprehensive terms. We will think big, contemplating deep time--even time before time itself. We will experiment with scale, conceptualizing the infinitesimally small to the infinitely large. In sum, we will read a variety of forms of worldmaking within a history of thought from antiquity to modernity.

title: Interdisciplinary Research - Keywords in Anthropology Today
descrip: This seminar draws inspiration from Raymond Williams's classic book "Keywords: A Vocabulary of Culture and Society" and explores two sets of terms: the first are concepts that anthropologists are using to interpret and interact with worlds and emergent forms of life (multispecies, becoming, ethics, moral economy, public ethnography): the second are subjects that anthropologists are studying (borders, punishment, security, environment, neoliberalism, virtual) that speak to a certain state of the world and of the social today. Each key word is analyzed at the crossroads of ethnography and critical theory.

title: Religion and Culture: Muslims in America
reviews:
Aly K-R is a university administrator, not a formal professor. So that should factor into your decision.

But yes, I learned a lot out of this class and the readings and videos helped me so much to understand the history and culture of the Muslim population in America. In fact, I think this canon of readings could be a healthy pack of knowledge for anyone whose confused about the status of Muslims in this country.

But be warned, the professor grades unnecessarily harshly. But yeah, you'll get a lot out of the readings. Though the seminars can feel like a waste of time
Any amount of background (or lack thereof) in Islam is welcomed in this course.  It is very interesting and Professor K-R is a kind, approachable professor with a great facilitation style!
Take advantage of the writing center and workshop your papers! It will help tremendously.
Take it! Professor Kassam-Remtulla is very smart and approachable.
Take it.
Take this class if you're interested in learning more about the Muslim community in America.  Professor Kassam-Remtulla is incredibly helpful and kind.
descrip: This course is an introduction to Muslim cultures in the United States. Each week we will draw upon texts from anthropology, sociology, history, and other fields to develop an understanding of the historical and present diversity of Muslim communities in America. The first third of the course provides a survey of Muslim communities in this country from the 17th to the 21st centuries. The second two-thirds features a thematic approach to a variety of topics: 9/11, women and gender, religious conversion, interfaith relations, youth, mosques as institutions, and Islamophobia.

title: Decoding Dress
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Elementary Japanese II
prereqs: JPN 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of JPN 101, which emphasizes the basic four skills to achieve survival proficiency level.

title: International Relations of East Asia
reviews: A course that is very rewarding if you put work into it. No-brainer for students inclined to East Asian affairs. And if you don't have a background in EAS, take it just for Professor Christensen.
Be prepared to invest work and time, but such efforts will be rewarding if you are genuinely interested in the topic.
Christensen is a champion!!! Expert in the field, cares about his students.  Essentially a history course, with you being expected to make the connections to the present day

Christensen is a great professor who has been there and done that. Take this course -- period. East Asia is the most important part of the world for the 21st Century, and 317 is a crucial crash course for anyone interested in the world as it WILL BE.

Do the readings, and buy the books or share so you don't have to rely on the scans which sometimes are missing from ereserves, and maintain a good idea for dates because the midterm is all IDs. Also do go to Office Hours for preceptors and the Professor it's an invaluable opportunity. Do not underestimate the papers and exams. The readings are long and sometimes boring so be prepared.
Excellent course, take it. Christensen does a fantastic job making it interesting and fast paced, not too difficult to get a good grade... just pay attention and be engaged.
It's still a very good course. Take it!
Professor Christensen's classes are a must if you are interested in East Asia. Take them. They are hard classes, but they are definitely worth it.

Take this class! The work load is a lot, but Professor Christensen is an amazing professor with a ton of insight into the mechanics of diplomacy in East Asia. Even if you feel like you know a lot about China and Asia already, you will learn a ton from this course. Make sure you go to class because there are no lecture slides.

The readings are insightful and very helpful for papers. Pay attention to lectures, as Prof Christensen has a lot of great insight to share. Take advantage of office hours to chat with preceptors and the professor - they are very approachable, and I wish I had been able to get to know them better.

There's a lot of reading, but it's manageable. I'd highly recommend this to anyone with an interest in East Asia or international relations. Also you shouldn't pass up on the chance to learn from Professor Christensen.
This class requires a lot of time commitment. The readings are very long but are very interesting. This is not an easy class so only take it if you have an interest in East Asia.
Would recommend; take the time to read at least the major books and attend lectures!
YOU HAVE TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  I cannot stress this enough.
easy class to PDF, i enjoyed coming to class for all lectures despite PDFing, he is amazing! i still learned a ton!
this is an extremely well-taught course. Please take it!
descrip: This course will concentrate on the Cold War and post Cold War international relations of East Asia. In the first two weeks we will cover general theoretical approaches to international relations and a brief historical backdrop of Western and Japanese imperialism in the region. In the following weeks, we will discuss the interaction between changes in the broader international system and changes in international relations in the East Asian region. The course will finish with discussion of implications of events and trends since the end of the Cold War.

title: Contemporary Music through Composition and Performance
descrip: Student composers and performers create new works. Composer Barbara White co-teaches with Visiting Lecturer and Shakuhachi Grand Master Riley Lee (Japanese bamboo flute). Lee collaborates in crafting and premiering student compositions. Guest lectures by Adam Sliwinski of So Percussion explore percussion techniques and timbres. We study eclectic, mostly modern, concert music, considering points of contact and divergence between shakuhachi, percussion, and other instruments. Foci include the fluid boundary between composition and performance, ambiguities of notation, and riches of collaboration. Final concert of new works by students.

title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
reviews: Avalos is still a fairly new professor who cares a lot about his students. While his lectures might not be the greatest, he's always open to feedback and willing to give your suggestions a try. I can say that over the course of the year, they've improved significantly. He's also better one on one than he is in a classroom setting so take advantage of his office hours!

Be sure to start homework assignments early enough to complete them on time. Also, consult AI's with any questions far enough in advance that will allow them to respond prior to your having to submit your problem sets. Otherwise, the course seems fairly manageable.
CBE only of course.
CBE's will have to take the course, but unlike other CBE core classes, this is one you will actually enjoy!

Clearly you're here because you're a rising junior CBE, and you have to take this class. It's one of the best of the CBE departmentals, and is fair and well-taught. Just make sure either to go to lecture or read the book--this course is only hard if you don't keep up with it. If you stay on top of things (it's not much work), you'll learn a lot and you won't have a hard time. Core lab is the one you have to worry about - this class is fine.
Fascinating topic in chemical engineering.

Hi CBE major, don't be afraid this course is not that much more difficult than previous CBE core courses that you've been through. Professor Avalos is super nice and caring. Oh being a little comfortable with matlab should also help. Other than that good luck!
If you're CBE you have to take this course and if you're not CBE you have no reason to take it, but this should be one of your less painful core CBE courses.
It's a fairly boring class, and with Prof. Avalos, the material wasn't particularly rigorous. Do attend lectures, but focus your time on core lab. Precept is effectively optional.
Not as interesting as the name may suggest
Possibly the most manageable CBE course since 245, but also not very interesting.
Pretty standard CBE lecture course, if you've made it this far through the department you will be fine.

Reactors isn't too difficult but can be a very dry course. This was Avalos's first time teaching and he spent a lot of time deriving equations as opposed to showing us how to apply them, so note that psets and exams are somewhat different from the lecture, but he also cares about his students; I strongly recommend that you engage with the course by asking questions and giving feedback about what you think could be improved because this is a class where you will be heard. Also, the book is excellent (the only good CBE textbook really), so if you're confused do read the text.
Read the book!  You can actually take notes in the book in class because the lectures follow the book flow exactly!
Read the book.

You may have Sundar back next year. Either way, read the textbook during the lecture, since the lectures usually come straight out of the textbook. Also check out the textbook online site, since that has excellent practice exams and good lecture slides that summarize the book chapters in case you prefer slides to pages. A class that's not as easy as 245, but not as hard as transport.
read the textbook, go to class, go to office hours!
prereqs: CBE 341.
descrip: Introduction to chemical reaction engineering and reactor design in chemical and biological processes. Concepts of chemical kinetics for both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions. Coupled transport and chemical/biological rate processes.

title: Baroque Art and Architecture
reviews: Definitely take this class! Prof. Mangone is a great lecturer and the material is great.

Definitely take this course! Professor Mangone is a wonderful lecturer, learns all of her students' names, and makes each lecture truly interactive by posing questions to the group. The precepts are a great opportunity to explore the art museum. The assignments are fair, and you receive plenty of help and support from Professor Mangone and our preceptor, Katherine. I'm so glad I took the course!
Go to lectures. For papers, get feedback from the preceptor and/or professor as this is the best way to ascertain what they are looking for.

I would say that if you are interested in art history then definitely take this course, as it will not be particularly difficult if you put work into it. That being said, if you are taking this as a PDF class, do note that you NEED TO GO TO PRECEPTS.
Prof. Mangone's precepts are fantastic. It's a treat to see some of the art in the museum up close in the study room.
Professor Mangone is a fantastic lecturer. Precepts were interesting and the workload is extremely manageable. Certainly take this course if you have an interest in the topic.
Take it! Professor Mangone will change your view about art.
Take it! The professor is great and she's very willing to help. Go to office hours before the papers because the prompts can be confusing at times.
Take this!! It's super fun.
The essays can be really fun to write if you invest enough time into them
This is a great course for students interested in art history.
Whether you are an art history major or not, I would strongly recommend this course. It caters to all levels of art/architecture-related interests and prior exposure to art history/architecture.
Work hard on the papers.

fantastic course! professor mangone is extremely knowledgable and well-spoken and lectures are extremely informative and enjoyable. most productive ART precepts I've had at princeton and really interesting prompts for written assignments. professor and preceptor were both very accessible for questions in advance of paper writing and general course material questions. definitely take this course! mangone loves the material and it really makes a difference in the class
take it! Light workload, interesting subject matter, great professor
descrip: From circa 1580 through 1700, Western Europe experienced the division of the Christian world into Protestant and Catholic confessions, the centralization of power by monarchs, the development of the middle class and unparalleled colonial expansion. This course explores how artists and architects like Caravaggio, Bernini, Rembrandt, Borromini, Rubens and Velazquez responded to these and other cultural transformations. Through class lectures and the study of art in local museums, we will examine key themes such as artistic novelty, the affective language of religious art, the rise of new subject matter and the mobility of artists and objects.

title: Topics in Spanish Civilization of the Golden Age - Gastronomy in Spanish Literature
reviews: I would advise participating actively in class discussion.
Professor Surtz is retiring, but it was a privilege to be his student for two semesters.
Take if you are interested in Spanish History and like to read about it
Take the course!
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or equivalent..
descrip: Cuisine is always more than nutrition; it functions as an agent of identity at both the regional and the national level. Moreover, gastronomy intersects with other manifestations of culture such as painting, literature, medicine, and religion. Readings, in addition to cookbooks, handbooks of table manners, and medical treatises, will include literary texts ranging from medieval to Golden Age to modern.
